name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which is Today's debate is a first and certainly a success for Parliament. Another EU policy area is becoming a bit more democratic today as a means of this debate. For the first time, the President of the Eurogroup, Jeroen Dijsselbloem, is taking part in a debate here in plenary to discuss with the directly elected Members the way forward in economic and monetary union. This debate is a decisive step towards greater democratic accountability and more parliamentary control in economic and monetary union. This improvement in democratic legitimacy is also a central demand of the five-president report, which both President Juncker and President Dijsselbloem have co-authored with me and Mr Draghi. With today's debate, Parliament is showing that it is prepared to assume its responsibilities in this area and to comply with it. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which This debate is a first- and I said it is a first-time one, but it is also needed, because the impression that important decisions in Brussels are, above all, taken behind closed doors is a very big problem for many people in Europe. To counteract this and to create as much transparency and publicity as possible is the objective of this debate as well. However, this debate is only one step. Until now, the President of the Eurogroup has regularly addressed the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs.  However, today's debate is not meant to be a one-off step, as we have already discussed it, Mr Dijsselbloem.  The European Parliament – and I also tabled this in the debate on the Five Presidents' Report – wants a full say in order to be able to make economic and monetary union truly democratic.  The European Commission – and I warmly welcome President Juncker – has for the first time presented the recommendations for the euro area, together with the annual growth report. This is also a move in the right direction. To look at the situation in the eurozone as a whole, and not always broken down into individual countries, can help to better address interrelationships and transnational developments. I am glad that the debate is taking place and I hope that this discussion between Parliament and you, Mr Dijsselbloem, will soon be repeated. I am pleased that you have come today and I would also like to express my thanks to you personally for your willingness to speak in Parliament today.

name: Jeroen Dijsselbloem
text: President of the Eurogroup. – Mr President, thank you for inviting me to this plenary session of Parliament. It is the first time I have had the honour to be here. I find it quite intimidating. You, of course, are very much used to this arena, but to me it is still a new experience. It is a sincere pleasure for me to take part in today’s exchange of views on the euro area recommendation. I am sure President Juncker will explain the Commission’s proposal of 26 November. He is best placed for this, so I will not go into the details.  As the Eurogroup President, I support a timely discussion of the euro area recommendation which gives a more prominent role to the euro area dimension in the context of a revamped European Semester. This fits into a necessary push towards a closer coordination of Member States’ economic policies. One lesson learned from the crisis is that Member States that are sharing a single currency need to be particularly mindful of the possible spillovers, both positive and negative, of their domestic policies.  In that sense, I believe, broadly speaking, that the Commission’s draft recommendation raises the right issues. The gradual economic recovery is ongoing and is relatively broadly based across Member States. This shows that the work we have done together over the last couple of years is starting to pay off and bolster confidence. However, since we will not be able to count on several supportive factors, such as low oil prices and a very accommodative monetary policy, forever, we need to ensure that the recovery becomes self-sustained, in particular given the weaker external environment. Therefore it is essential that policy agendas remain focused on investment, structural reforms and, obviously, sustainable and growth-friendly fiscal policies. This is needed to improve competitiveness, in particular by unlocking the euro area’s productive capacity, and thereby fostering higher sustainable and inclusive growth. It is the surest way to address the still unacceptably high unemployment rates and legacy debt in many countries. It is crucial if we want a thriving euro area in a globalised world, and it is also the only way to preserve our European social model.  Although the euro area recommendation and the country-specific recommendations by and large address the right issues, effective economic policy coordination requires attention for implementation at Member State level. Going forward, it will be important to regularly monitor the progress made in implementing the recommendations and enhancing national ownership. This is why the issues I have just mentioned have figured and will continue to figure prominently in the Eurogroup’s work programme, notably in the context of our thematic discussions on growth and jobs.  These discussions are a follow-up to the euro area recommendation, working on best practices and benchmarking, for example on the tax wedge on labour, or pension reforms. And this brings me to the so-called Five Presidents’ Report on completing Europe’s Economic and Monetary Union, which the President of the European Parliament and I co-authored, together with Presidents Juncker, Tusk and Draghi.  The report pointed out that despite significant improvements in recent years, more work is needed to make the EMU more resilient and its institutional architecture more complete in order to maximise the benefits of participating in the single currency to its members. We aimed to strike the right balance between realism and vision, which is reflected in a stage-based approach. Until mid-2017 it proposes short-term measures to make the euro area more resilient, while making the best possible use of the current legal framework. These are intended to pave the way for more far-reaching measures for completing the EMU in the second stage.  Pursuing convergence is a key theme in the report. Over the last years, Member States have made significant steps, but the smooth functioning of a monetary union requires further efforts to reduce divergence in economic and fiscal performance, financial market fragmentation, as well as differences in national institutional architecture. All these aspects are interlinked, and simultaneous progress is needed. It is indisputable in my mind that participation in a monetary union comes with the sharing of sovereignty. The key question is, however, how much sovereignty should be shared under which conditions. In other words, we need to be clear on what we want to achieve, and then determine how to go about it.  The process of deepening the EMU is indeed also about risk sharing, but in order to make progress on this front, Member States need to make progress in further reducing risks. This entails repairing economic and fiscal imbalances through a consistent and faithful application of instruments like the Stability and Growth Pact and the macroeconomic imbalance procedure.  Between risk reduction and risk sharing, we need to work on our economic risk absorption capacity. It will not surprise you that I am convinced that private risk sharing is as important as public risk sharing. The experience in the US has shown that integrated financial markets account for the largest part of the absorption of asymmetric economic shocks. Developing the Capital Markets Union, therefore, should be a priority.  Similarly, we need a comprehensive approach to completing the Banking Union in order to decisively break the vicious sovereign banking nexus. The key element in building the Banking Union was the paradigm shift from bail-out to bail-in. This is a fundamental shift in our approach, where risks will be pushed back to where they belong. But more needs to be done to strengthen the resilience of our banking system. For example, dealing with over 150 national options and discretions left to date, reducing sovereign risks, and applying the bail-in rules in full to ensure a level playing field. This is as important as decisive progress towards a European deposit insurance scheme or a credible backstop to the Single Resolution Fund. The three will have to be brought forward together.  It is essential that we join efforts to build dynamic, flexible and upward converging economies that are supported by a well-integrated financial market with private risk sharing and by sound public finances with fiscal buffers for difficult times.  My plea for further integration at euro area level should go hand in hand with greater accountability, legitimacy and institutional strengthening. This affects national and European policy makers, as well as national parliaments and the European Parliament. As far as the European Parliament is concerned, I believe it should be able to fully exploit its prerogatives under the current treaties and secondary legislation when it comes to the European Semester.  The preparatory work for moving to the second stage of completing the EMU should include a debate on the role and competences of the different institutional actors in a deep and genuine monetary union.  The measures outlined in the Five Presidents’ Report and the recent Commission initiatives to operationalise them are given careful consideration in different fora. I will assume my responsibility and facilitate the non-legislative and legislative procedures, both from the perspective of the Eurogroup Presidency and of the next Presidency of the ECOFIN Council.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Präsident der Kommission. – Sehr verehrter Herr Präsident, Herr Präsident der Euro-Gruppe, Herr Vizepräsident der Kommission, meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren, liebe Kollegen! Dies ist eine wichtige Debatte, wie der Präsident zu Recht ausgeführt hat, was ja auch die massive Präsenz in diesem Plenarsaal zur Genüge belegt. (Beifall) I have always said that the European Parliament is the Parliament of the euro, and I say it again today. The euro is a political project, and that means that it requires political supervision and democratic accountability. You are the Parliament of the European Union, but you are also the Parliament of the euro. This is why I wanted President Schulz to contribute to our roadmap for Economic and Monetary Union – the Five Presidents’ Report, which we presented last June and to which Jeroen was referring. Our report makes it clear that the legitimacy of the euro is paramount, at least as important as its economic significance and its stability on the financial markets. In the years to come, as we will need to develop and strengthen the common institutions that the single currency demands, that legitimacy will acquire only greater importance. This has nothing to do with institutional power grabs or federal dreams. This has to do with the pressing reality of the European Union, where so many people are still unemployed, and where our economic recovery is still fragile. From my perspective, the crisis is not over and there should be no complacency. Even if we are helped by the action of the European Central Bank, we only have a short window of opportunity to press ahead with our agenda for reforms, investment and responsible public finances, with social fairness at its core. The crisis has also been a crisis of legitimacy – at all levels. Economic governance is not about legal rules or numerical percentages: it is about people and it is about the political decisions that affect them. It is about political responsibility and political accountability. The Five Presidents’ Report makes clear that Parliament should play a central role, starting with its power to legislate, but also its power to hold accountable. The Commission is the natural ally of this House in making sure this is the case, even more so in the future. We are not starting from a blank sheet. Today Parliament is playing a new and growing role in the economic governance of the EU and the euro area, and that is how it should be. The European Semester of economic policy coordination is more transparent and more accountable now that Parliament is more involved. When Parliament organises its economic dialogues with Member States and with the Commission, the President of the Eurogroup – who is present here and I greet him with the deepest respect – and the President of the ECB, it helps to shape the agenda and delivers parliamentary oversight, and that is vital for our democracy. Vice-President Dombrovskis, sitting beside me today, was once a Member of this Parliament. As you know, he was also a Prime Minister of his country, where he pursued a successful programme of national reform. If there is one person here who understands why the euro demands democratic legitimacy, it is he. This is why I entrusted him with this particular job. And for the conduct of the European Semester, he is working closely with Marianne Thyssen and Pierre Moscovici, who are also two former Members of this House. This year, Vice-President Dombrovskis came to debate with you during the preparation of the Annual Growth Survey. I remember that this was a request both from the President of this House and by some Party and Group leaders, like Philippe. He put this forward years ago, but he had to wait until this Commission to have the chance to participate in these kinds of debates. But it was the first time that the Commission had discussed and debated with the Parliament the Annual Growth Survey before the adoption of that important document. Together with Commissioner Moscovici, Valdis Dombrovskis came to debate and report on the Greek programme to you. Again last week, the two of them – together with Commissioner Thyssen – attended a joint meeting of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) to present the priorities we see for 2016. When you invite us, we come. And by doing so, we keep improving the way our economic and fiscal surveillance works – making it more predictable and more transparent, giving more time for discussions and debates, and creating more opportunities for engagement at all levels.  For countries that are experiencing financial instability, I also believe that monitoring is now stronger with this Parliament’s participation. It is this Parliament that can host an open political debate on a country’s adjustment programme. Before I took office last year, I made it clear that I recognised the shortcomings of the so-called ‘Troika’. I was determined to do things differently, and under this Commission, we have done – and are doing –precisely that. We have also made a new start in that respect together with the President of the Eurogroup. Today, if a country needs to pursue an adjustment programme, we will see more transparency and more accountability. The Commission is, for instance, conducting social impact assessments so that we can, from the outset, design measures to support the most vulnerable and ensure a fair adjustment. We will report to this House on progress with the programme. We are implementing these new methods in the new programme with Greece, which for the first time is being done under the European Stability Mechanism – our European financial firewall. This is the first programme for which a full social impact assessment was published, as promised, and presented to the Committees of this Parliament. I know that – for some of you – all these various innovations do not go far enough, and some of you wanted to re-open and revise the six-pack and the two-pack legislation before the ink was dry. However, if the Five Presidents adopted the approach you find in our report, it is because we were convinced – and I know the large majority of you are equally convinced – that our first task is to implement what was agreed by Parliament and Council and focus on what we have just put in place. Rather than create new uncertainty, let us fully use our newly agreed tools and make them work to the best effect. We know that the provisions of the six-pack and two-pack legislation, which have been in force for just a few years, are both far-reaching and useful in terms of Parliament’s involvement. All this is part of our pragmatic, yet ambitious, approach to completing Europe’s Economic and Monetary Union. As we promised in the Five Presidents’ Report, we have already launched Stage 1 of the roadmap, which is expected to last until mid-2017. We are ‘deepening by doing’, which means that we are using existing powers and tools to work towards Economic Union, Financial Union, Banking Union and Political Union. It is pragmatic, but it is ambitious. It is at this stage where we, the Five Presidents, have said that we will make use of all possibilities, including legislative ones, within the existing Treaties. This is why I associated your President with this report. We need this Parliament as our strong partner during this phase. One concrete example is the recommendation for the economic policy of the euro area that we issued for the first time in November, as promised, at the start of the new European Semester. This is something I had committed to in my State of the Union speech: to create scope and time for an in-depth debate, including in this House, of the priorities for the euro area as a whole, before discussing priorities for individual Member States later in spring.  We are also already coming forward with legislation wherever this is needed, for instance to complete our Banking Union or deepen our Capital Market Union. Just think of our proposal for a European Deposit Insurance Scheme. What could be more urgent than protecting the savings of our citizens and reinforcing their trust in the banking system? It is not for the Commission to say how Parliament wishes to organise itself, but let me share today a few thoughts on how we might deepen the cooperation between our institutions under Stage 1, now, as we are moving towards Stage 2, which we plan to initiate in spring 2017 on the basis of a white paper. Firstly, it is good practice for the Commission to seek the views of the European Parliament before we adopt our Annual Growth Survey, as we did this year. I would also hope that priorities for the next European Semester could be debated in as many committees as possible. Secondly, the Commission is fully committed to making the European Parliamentary Week – which is organised under your guidance, Mr President – a key moment in our economic governance, and to bringing national Parliaments into the process. In our view, these exchanges would best take place at the start of each year in order to shape the European Union and euro area priorities ahead of national discussions on our Member States’ programmes. Thirdly, when a Member State is pursuing an adjustment programme, we should make full use of the practice of the Commission reporting to Parliament after each review of the programme’s implementation. I know there are further reflections ongoing within this House as to how this could best be done, and I will be happy to consider these in due course.  These arrangements should be part of a new practice between our two institutions, based on reinforced political dialogue. Our two institutions have a common interest to succeed for our citizens. I believe everything which strengthens Parliament will also strengthen the Commission. And I believe Parliament should be vigilant to preserve the role of the Commission in all these discussions. As you know, there are some who want to weaken the role of the Commission in the management of our common economic and fiscal rules. Some even call for transferring the tasks we have under the Treaty to an agency of technocrats. I am sure I can count on this Parliament to agree with me that decisions on budgetary priorities, the balance between revenues and expenditures, the level of taxation, the performance of public administrations and social systems are all political decisions which require a political Commission which can account for its role and action before this Parliament.  As foreseen in the Five Presidents’ Report, I believe that we should test and improve these new practices which we are now developing in order to progressively agree upon a broader interinstitutional agreement among our institutions in full respect of their distinctive roles. The practical and institutional steps that we are discussing today are all necessary to complete our Economic and Monetary Union. They are a means to an end: jobs and growth, fairness and democratic change. This is what we have been focusing our minds and energy on and what we should remain focused on. The ideas I presented to you this morning are faithful to the Political Guidelines I presented for this Commission, as well as to the Five Presidents’ Report I co-authored with the President of this House. I put them to you in a spirit of good will and with an open mind. I hope they will produce an honest and useful debate.  (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you for the praise for the full hall. Thank you also for your comments on who is talking about where. We take that into account.

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: Author. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President of the Commission, President of the Eurogroup, this is a very important debate, just as it is important for the Commission to present a proposal for a recommendation on the economic policy of the eurozone, which is a major innovation in the process of completing economic and monetary union. Discussing and adopting a recommendation on the economic and budgetary policy of the euro area, conceiving it as an organic entity and doing so before the debate on the different countries taken individually, is a change not only procedural, but also conceptual and political; it is a change that is consistent with a conception of the euro area as an economic union and not as a mere monetary union.  Parliament therefore appreciates this innovation, which we consider to be the most positive and significant element of the communication of 21 October, and with this debate we intend to contribute to enriching this innovation politically and democratically, aware as we are of the responsibilities arising from being – as you, even now, have rightly acknowledged in this House – the Parliament of the euro. That is also why we believe that the modalities and nature of our contribution to the six months of the euro area, if we want to call it that, must also be strengthened and formalised by means of an interinstitutional agreement which should also cover Parliament's role of democratic control over the implementation of macroeconomic adjustment programmes linked to the provision of financial assistance through the European Stability Mechanism.  But let us come to the substance of these recommendations. Thanks to the European Central Bank's accommodative monetary policy, but also thanks to a more balanced and growth-conscious policy mix that your Commission, Mr Juncker, rightly pursued in its first year, the economic recovery is underway, supported by increased domestic consumption that is also offsetting the weakening foreign demand of emerging countries. And yet the recovery remains fragile, weighed down also by geopolitical factors. It is no coincidence that the ECB, as soon as it has adjusted rates and extended its programme of buying assets, has declared itself ready to step it up if price developments do not improve.  But monetary policy alone is not enough to solve the fundamental problems underlying the anemic nature of the recovery. Firstly, the low growth potential of our economy, which requires us to continue resolutely along the path of structural reforms and to strengthen their coordination and convergence, but also the cyclical dimension of recovery, without which we will have no structural recovery, is still too modest and requires stronger action to strengthen domestic demand and private sector expectations. On both fronts, the decisive factor is investment, which both acts on the demand and supply side.  The Commission has rightly sounded the alarm about the unprecedented current account surplus and the extraordinary gap between savings and investment. That is our main problem, which we must tackle with determination. We are rightly committed to increasing the capacity of our financial system to support the economy; Parliament is committed to supporting the capital markets union and the completion of the banking union. Also because full financial integration, primarily of the euro area, is essential not only for growth, but also to strengthen our ability to share risks and absorb shocks, and therefore the legislative proposal on the European deposit insurance system is an essential element.  Of course, there is also the issue of risk reduction, on which, moreover, much has already been done with the first two pillars of the banking union, but every further step must be examined with caution, responsibility and graduality, because we need everything but to create problems where fortunately there are none, and then to discover that rash actions dictated by domestic policy reasons end up increasing the risk and not reducing it.  With regard to private financing of financial integration, it is very positive that one of the four recommendations is devoted to the issue of non-performing loans. I also see it as a recommendation to the Member States, but also as a recommendation that the Commission makes to itself, given, as you know, that, from the point of view of the state aid framework, many obstacles have so far been placed in the way of effective and reasonable solutions to this problem.  Another key piece to relaunch investment is the plan that bears his name, Mr Juncker, Parliament strongly supports this and hopes that all its potential will be exploited to the full. It is very positive that the recommendations recognise that all these measures are necessary, but not sufficient without proper fiscal policy on the part of the Member States. From this point of view, the first recommendation is central. , if necessary.  Of course, the best use of the instruments at our disposal to boost growth must be accompanied by a strengthening of our governance, by a clear vision for the future. Parliament is asking for ambition, Parliament has made useful proposals, convergence guidelines, fiscal capacity, which can also be achieved by constant treaties, and we are naturally ready for an active dialogue with the Commission in the run-up to phase two of the deepening of EMU.  Mr Juncker, we are counting on you to give the necessary impetus and ambition that are essential in the debate on growth and governance, demonstrating that Europe when it thinks of itself as a unit, and when it equips itself with an appropriate democratic dimension, is stronger than the obstacles that are before it and is equal to the great challenges, not only economic but also political, that the complex world , terrible, difficult but also full of opportunities puts us.

name: Dariusz Rosati
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I welcome the communication by the Commission on completing the European Economic and Monetary Union. The document sets a very ambitious agenda for the future. It builds on the Five Presidents’ Report and it proposes a set of measures that focus on four strategic fronts: building an economic union, a financial union, a fiscal union and a political union. I see this document as a proposal to fill the gaps that have been left in the European construction of economic governance and the gaps that have been made apparent by the recent crisis. These reforms are definitely necessary. The project is very ambitious, but it is necessary if the euro area is to survive and to flourish. It is necessary if integration and convergence are to continue to strengthen. We all know the status quo cannot continue because it is too prone to crisis. I think that the choice which is ahead of us is: either we go forward and build a genuine union, or we simply have to go back and return probably to national currencies. Now, the key question here is: to what extent is this politically feasible? To what extent are all actors of this process – including this Parliament and the Commission, but above all the national governments – ready to go ahead under the current difficult political circumstances? This current political climate in Europe is not very prone to far-reaching integration projects, but we are all convinced that this is absolutely necessary to move forward. In order to complete the EMU, we all need more political ambition and more political determination. Our political group is ready to cooperate on this front.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Rosati, it seems that in view of the crisis – the creeping crisis – the resilience of countries which did not adopt the common currency is greater than that of other countries. It seems that only the most powerful countries of the eurozone are able to overcome the crisis successfully. The weaker ones have to share the asymmetric portion of their sovereignty. Is it true?

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – The resilience of individual Member States of the euro area has nothing to do with the common currency, but rather with the sort of macroeconomic policies they have pursued over the last several years. We see that within the euro area there are countries that fare perfectly well – these are mostly northern countries – yet there are other countries that, as a result of irresponsible policies in the past, have got into big trouble, so this is not a question of the common currency. The common currency gives quite a lot of advantages to those countries, but what we have to pay attention to is the pursuit of reasonable domestic policies.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the euro area is the engine of the European economy and it needs to deliver growth and jobs in order to deliver much stronger support to the European project. That is why Parliament needs to have a strong say in all these matters, and that is why this dialogue today is so relevant.  I would like to welcome the President of the Eurogroup, the President of the Commission, and the Vice—President of the Commission in charge of the eurozone. The eurozone is confronted with three major problems: a clear output gap, macroeconomic imbalances and worrying economic and social divergences. These problems are there. I believe there is a key word to respond to these problems, which is investment: investment turned to the future, and investment on a European scale.  We need to have much more investment to raise domestic demand in Europe. Success in exports is positive, of course, but we cannot only rely on exports. That is why we believe that this aggregate fiscal stance should be used to identify clearly the investment gap we have in Europe, and to organise Member States to share their efforts to address this investment gap. When it comes to macroeconomic imbalances, we need to ask those Member States that have a current account surplus to make more effort to invest for their own benefit. Otherwise, the macro imbalances will rely only on the efforts made by Member States which have a deficit. That means that they have to reduce wages, demand and jobs. We need a joint effort from surplus and deficit countries to reduce macroeconomic imbalances. Then we have the problem of divergences. Again, we need to have investment in all members of the eurozone to push for upward convergence. This is necessary. And while Member States do need to make their own catching-up efforts, these should be complemented by the necessary European instruments: completing the banking union and building up fiscal capacity. These are issues where Parliament will remain very active. We plan to be active on the road to completing economic and monetary union and in the key moments of the European Semester. This is, again, a very important moment.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – It is good that you are here. This is an interesting debate, and I have a question, although it is a shame that so many of our colleagues are more interested in the Single Market – that is, the Strasbourg Christmas Single Market – than being here. Would a more honest approach for 2016 – a New Year’s resolution for Europe – be to say there is only one choice: to become a United States of Europe with European Monetary Union, closer, coming together, all of the things we have heard today, or independence, sovereignty and the nation state? There is no middle ground, is there?

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Etheridge, I agree with your identification of choices, but I believe my choices are different from yours, because I really think that the solution for us Europeans is to move forward quickly in completing and rebalancing the Economic and Monetary Union. I really believe there is a future for all members of the euro area.

name: Bernd Lucke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When we have a debate on economic and monetary union, there are many interesting questions. What is even more interesting is what answers are given to them by the majority groups in this House – from the Christian Democrats, from the Social Democrats, from the Greens, from the Liberals, from the Liberals, from the Liberals, from the Liberals. Questions arise, such as: why do we have an investment gap in the eurozone? Why do we have so little private investment despite the lowest interest rates? The answers are essentially given in such a way that they say: we do not know for sure, but it is not the euro. The question arises: why do we not have inflation in the eurozone despite the European Central Bank's extremely expansionary monetary policy? The answer is that we do not know, but it is not the euro. The question arises: why do we in Europe have rising public debt, for five years still rising public debt, since we have really tried to limit, limit and return public debt to sustainable levels? The answer is that we do not know, but it is certainly not the euro. The question arises: why does the eurozone have the weakest growth of all the world's major economic regions, despite structural reforms, despite falling oil prices, despite a depreciating euro? The answer is essentially: we do not know, but it is not the euro. Ladies and gentlemen! It is time we looked back at what we wanted to achieve with the euro. We wanted to have a zone of growth and stability. What we have received is a zone in which public debt is now doubled, or sometimes even triple, in many countries, where unemployment is alarmingly high in many eurozone countries – including youth unemployment – where banks are sitting on bad loans, where the ECB is printing money in bulk and is unwilling to announce an end where savers fear for their pensions. because they no longer receive interest on their assets. Ladies and gentlemen, we should ask ourselves the question: is it not perhaps the common currency?

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to invite the honourable member who has not seen the Liberals wear glasses. The Liberals outnumber members of his group to participate in this debate.

name: Sylvie Goulard
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, I wanted first of all to welcome Mr Dijsselbloem's presence among us. I think it is important that we have these debates, which are democratic, cross-border and public. Mr Dijsselbloem, you come to the ECON committee on a regular basis, and we are grateful for that, but it is even better that you also come to the plenary. I thank Mr Juncker and Mr Dombrovskis for being here as well. You have rightly pointed out the levels of unemployment, which I believe should be at the centre of all our discussions on the future of economic and monetary union.  I would also like to make one point: you have spoken about legitimacy and paid tribute to economic dialogue. So I'm going to, for once, be totally immodest. Having been at the origin of the introduction of economic dialogue in the six-pack, I would say that it encourages me because at the time - colleagues present, such as Elisa Ferreira, and others who are no longer there certainly remember it - the Member States did not want it at all. The idea that we could introduce this horrible thing that would be a public discussion between the Community institutions, the states and Parliament, we did not want to hear about it. So you see that when you face an opposition, it is sometimes worth trying to overcome because after the fact, you find yourself happy to have innovated. The report of the five presidents was timely, since at the date it was delivered, we were still in a very difficult moment of the crisis on Greece. However, I do not think we should be too self-centered. Outside the European sphere, people barely know that there is a report from the five presidents; in fact, they do not know that there was one of the four presidents. It is better because they would wonder if the next one would be that of the six presidents.  In the report of the five chairs, we announced the creation of a working group. I think all of this is a bit of a public eye and a little more needs to be actioned. As Mr Rosati said very well earlier, the real question is whether we are doing everything we can to ensure that economic and monetary union continues, prospers, brings work and competitiveness. From that point of view - and it is not a reproach; I am just stressing the effort that we must make collectively, we cannot go to the opinion of the 'capital markets union'. People don't know what it is, Mr. President! Call it a "financing union" or an "innovation union"; it is the goal that counts, not the instrument. I would still like to make one final point on one issue. You said that this Parliament is the one of the eurozone, the Parliament of the euro. Yes, but why? Because, in the current institutional framework, as the treaties establish, there is a currency for the whole of the European Union, with a Parliament in which Members from all countries make decisions. But if we are going towards a multi-currency union, what should we do? Would it be legitimate to continue to have a Parliament that speaks for people who tell us that they do not want to be part of the same system anyway? I would also say to colleagues that many criticise Europe and the euro, but if their country is doing well, it is also because there are transfers of 4% of the GDP of their own country. In conclusion, I just wanted to say, Mr President, that we have to pay attention to stowaways. This Parliament is indeed the Parliament of the euro area, and it intends to remain so as long as everyone wants to be part of the common project. However, we are likely to have to clarify things in the months and years to come.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Presidents for their excellent work and for their excellent work. French star economist Piketty says the architecture of the euro is a monster. I am afraid that, after reading the Five Presidents' Report, he has not changed his mind. Wage developments in Germany have been too weak for many years, and Germany's export surpluses and capital exports have driven southern Europe into private debt. The cuts in government spending, wages, pensions have been a fiasco, they have deepened the depression. The stronger the eurozone's competitiveness, the deeper the depression became. Germany has an export surplus of 8% of GDP. That is against all the rules of the game of a monetary union. Now, trade unions are also to be disempowered through competition committees. The left, like the German Trade Union Confederation, rejects this. The Stability of Growth Pact is holding back investment despite low interest rates. We need investment right now in the refugee crisis to end the state's failure in housing, in education, in health. We need public investment, because the Fed may raise interest rates tomorrow, because the ECB's cheap money ends up in financial markets, but not for business and household investment. The mechanism against economic shocks is supposed to take effect when euro states submit to permanent shock therapy, i.e. wage and pension cuts. This means that there is an eternal euro crisis in the wallets of employees. Such a euro is not more democratic, such a euro will only benefit le Pens!

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, the euro is a federal currency, it is not an intergovernmental currency. That is why I welcome you, Mr Dijsselbloem, as President of the Eurogroup, because you are right, the members of the Eurogroup, as finance ministers, are accountable to their national parliaments, but it is quite normal for the President of the Eurogroup to be accountable to the European Parliament. You do it regularly in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, I think it is only fair that you do it in plenary, and therefore be welcome. Are the revenues that have been used today - for the last five or six years - in Europe to preserve this federal currency, which we also care about, work? In any case, if I take your favourite indicator, namely growth, I find that it is, at best, evanescent.  And if we look a little more specifically at what is happening in the countries - and I am not going to talk about Greece because it is such a complicated case that it would blur the message, but spain, a country that has applied with conviction the revenues that you are advocating, namely the reduction of the role of the state, the reduction of direct and indirect wages, what do we see? Yes, growth is coming back to Spain, but at what cost? When employment increases, it is unskilled employment, it is part-time employment. This is what creates this new category of working poor. In Spain, the eurozone's flagship country, one in three children faces poverty. So if you call it success, let me have some doubts. Your recipes are actually deflatory. They are countercyclical: they compress public demand and private demand. As a result, there is no growth. So if you care so much about it, it's not the right solution.  By the time COP 21 concludes, we should actually put the whole package on investment in the energy transition. It is obviously a climate requirement, but it is also a geostrategic requirement if we want to stop defending people like Putin or Saudi Arabia. This is a macroeconomic requirement if we want to stop spending hundreds of billions of dollars a year on fossil fuels. This is a demand in terms of jobs since everyone knows that renewable energy is much more job intensive than traditional energy. Second message: 150 years after its unification, 25 years after its reunification, Germany, which is a monetary union and a customs union, is still not homogeneous. It is not tomorrow the day before that the European Union and the euro area will be homogeneous, and therefore there is no euro that holds without powerful rebalancing mechanisms within the euro area. These mechanisms must go through the private sector, namely the banking union, which we know remains incomplete - we know that it will be difficult to bring out the third pillar, the common deposit guarantee - but also by the public sector. These include a common tax system, a euro area budget and also a common social security embryo. However, of all this, it is only very vaguely discussed in the report of the five presidents, and it is well known that today there is no political will to do so. If we do not go through these rebalancing mechanisms, the euro area is doomed. I do not want it to disappear, and therefore these rebalancing mechanisms will have to be put in place. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Lamberts, do you not think that what is really lacking is domestic demand? That is the critical factor which is stymieing growth. Mr Dijsselbloem has laid the accent on competitiveness, and the first point in the Five Presidents’ report is these competitiveness councils. Now that only means additional pressure on wages so that seemingly things will start growing. Do you not think that is nonsense?

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear Mr Pirinski, I think competitiveness is a real issue. It is not just a question of foreign trade, because every day our countrymen buy goods and services and look at what they get for their money. In terms of principles, I am not opposed to having advice on this subject, but on certain conditions. First, they need to deal with competitiveness in all its aspects, that is, values and not just costs. Second, when we talk about costs, it is not just labour costs, but also energy costs, resource costs, capital compensation, that is, all costs. Finally, these councils should not be content to bring together experts, who are well known where they come from in general, but must deliberately include social interlocutors, be they trade unions, employers or political representatives. In these circumstances, I would like to consider the idea of setting up these competitiveness councils, but as a real subject.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are here to discuss economic and monetary union with three of the five presidents who have shaped the future for 500 million people, and we must certainly remember who Juncker is, the one who supported Luxembourg for more than fifteen years, the elusive tax system of the large multinationals and Dijsselbloem, his successor to the Eurogroup, a Dutch minister, another person with responsibilities in this system.  Your text is nothing more than the will written by those who wanted you there, in those positions that you held; it is certainly not democracy, but a different design that frees citizens from the possibility of choosing an economic alternative to that imposed by your vision. Budgetary stability, private investment, structural reforms, the banking union and, above all, the monetary union, the euro: the recipe for failure for years? It serves private capital to strategically share the rights and public property of sovereign states, that is to tell the citizens and, above all, to deprive us of the dream, of the union of peaceful and democratic peoples.  To date, the roadmap has as your priority a union of banks that has already failed at launch and with its first two pillars. The first pillar, single supervision, is not in a position to assess the real weight of systemic risk in the banking system, not considering derivatives, for example, and is full of conflicts of interest between private shareholders, managers and politicians. The rescue in Italy these days is a clear example of this.  The second pillar, the crisis resolution system, is already having victims among savers and has already proved largely unsuccessful. Who has to pay for the greed of the unsustainable financial system, savers or taxpayers? We propose that banks should once again become banks, with a real separation between those who use money for the real economy and those who use it to bet, that central banks guarantee systemic risk as lenders of last resort for the healthy system. We are telling you this before the bomb goes off in your hand, because under these conditions the financial paper castle will fall ruinously sending so many people to the ground. Our proposal is on the table in banking structural reform, take it and make it yours.  I now turn to monetary union, the means by which you are staring at us and terrorising us. As a currency area with major imbalances – as you admit in your report – we have built the house from the roof without foundations. You have taken away our monetary sovereignty and therefore democracy is rebelling against this, because you can no longer decide on the type of economic policy. We only have this strategy, which is that of the Commission, which has failed and then we are heading for those extremisms; extremism is not right, we must have a post-ideological ideology and therefore good ideas must be put before us, not extremism.  So the rules apply only to the weak and not to the strong, and the current-account surplus in Germany is an example of this. We must sanction these behaviours or monetary union makes no sense, the only solution here too, before everything breaks out in your hands, is an agreed dissolution of the eurozone and only in this way will we be able to lay the foundations for a different Union, in solidarity, that puts fiscal justice at the centre, the transparency of bank flows and a certainly brighter future for all, but to do so we will need people other than Juncker. , Dijsselbloem and you, I'm sorry, Mr President.

name: Gerolf Annemans
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr Dijsselbloem, I would like to welcome you here in this Parliament of the European Union. You arrive here as president of the part of the European Union where the euro is governed, in a fully divided European Parliament. It has become impossible to agree even on the broad outlines of euro policy and monetary union in this Parliament.  A large group here is in favour of more euro and of the euro. It wants to unify socio-economic policy and further austerity in the south of Europe, even if it causes social carnage there.  Then there is a large group, also in favour of your euro area and of the continuation of the euro. That group needs to know much less about austerity, don't expect much of it, nothing structural, nothing fundamental and also wants a continuation of your unhinged ECB policy, while retaining more or less of the derailed budgetary situations.  And then there is a third group that believes that holding on to one euro is a dream for all our countries to let go slowly and better sooner rather than later. This group will grow and bring out more and more truth in the coming year, which will hurt, because the euro crisis will continue, as will the asylum crisis. For these reasons, I wish you a lot of reflection and a lot of relief during your Christmas holiday.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Mr President, we are talking about deepening EMU, which means enlarging and strengthening The European Union's unpopular structures, further consolidating and scaling up anti-labour policy in all countries and not just the over-indebted, with a view to the profitability of capital. Through competition, the supervision and role of the Eurogroup is strengthened and a European Council and National Fiscal Councils are set up with the sole aim of automatic cuts in wages, pensions, social expenditure sacrificed to monopolistic profits. The integration of markets, such as energy, digital and banking capital markets, without removing the divisions of the Member States, aims to raise capital and upgrade European monopolies, with a view to the signing of the Transatlantic Agreement. In Greece, the SYRIZA-ANEL government intensifies the unpopular offensive and, with the aim of extracting the consent of the people, attempts to deceive it. It invokes, like many here, the supposed democratic control of the European Semester and the Memorandum by the European Parliament, a reactionary tool of the Union that has voted and ratified anti-labour policy. By showing the possible withdrawal of the International Monetary Fund from the programme as a factor in the relaxation of measures, it throws ash in the eyes of the people because the exact same measures are directions of the European Union. No, supposedly democratic, accountability is going to make it pro-grassroots. The conflict between the people and the strategy of the capital of the European Union and the governments is the only way out that is in their interest.

name: Jeroen Dijsselbloem
text: President of the Eurogroup. – Mr President, I think it was Mr Annemans who said that we have here a divided parliament. Now, I have been a member of a national parliament for 12 years and I always think that it is a good thing that parliaments are divided, for the obvious reason that we have to represent different political ideas in our society. The real question is whether we can share common goals, whether we can find an agreement on the way forward, on the choice of instruments. I think, listening also to the different contributions from Parliament, that there is quite a large agreement on the way forward, and it is about the right policy mix. Those of you have said that we have made mistakes over the course of the crisis are right. We went into unknown territory at the beginning of the financial crisis, in the eurozone crisis, and we developed our instruments and we developed new frameworks for policy. We set up emergency mechanisms, we created new institutions to strengthen our economic cooperation, and we have come a long way, so there is no reason for cynicism. There is reason for optimism, for example if you see at what pace we have designed and set up the Banking Union, and yes, everyone who says we need to complete it now is right.  One of the lessons that we should learn over the course of the history of the European Union is that we should finish our projects and not set up a framework and leave it half finished. So let us finish the Banking Union. I am convinced that setting up and finishing the Banking Union will be more important for economic recovery than any other project at the moment. So that is what we should do and we know what we need to do. We need to fight the risks that are remaining in our banks and we need to make sure that it becomes more solid. As President Juncker said, it protects the deposits, which is key for our citizens. Let us get it done.  Part of that mix of instruments should also be strengthening investments. The Commission has taken a strong initiative with the EFSI. Let us get it up and running. Let us expand it if necessary. Let us see that we get the investments going. Completing the Banking Union will be crucial to get a stronger credit flow back to our SMEs, companies wanting to reinvest again and others opening for business. A lot of young people all over Europe want to start businesses. Can they get their hands on credit? That is what the Capital Markets Union is about, that is what completing the Banking Union is about. And yes, part of that policy mix also has to be growth-friendly fiscal policy. One of the key issues that is holding us back, holding back our economic recovery, is the indebtedness of our societies – governments with high debt, households with high debt, SMEs sometimes with high levels of debt, which is holding back our recovery. But there is no quick fix. Anyone who believes that with a snap of one’s fingers one can get rid of those high levels of debt is mistaken. It will take time, but we have to get through it and we have to get financing and credits for our economies. That is key, and fiscal policy will support that. Demand is returning in many of our eurozone countries. Growth has returned to all of our countries except for Greece, and I am sure that working with Greece as we are now in a very constructive mode, and taking difficult measures that will help get the Greek economy back on track, is the way forward. Yes, there are issues of balance – political balance, economic balance – within our eurozone, but do not be negative about what we have accomplished. We have come out of a deep crisis, we have strengthened our cooperation, we have strengthened our monetary union in many respects and let us continue to do that, but let us do it in a way that sticks and not in a way that brings us new problems. So if we take new steps forward, and we will do in the second phase of the Five Presidents’ Report, let us design it well. Let us build a monetary union that becomes more resilient to shocks, rather than creating new ones.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: I would also like to thank all the Presidents without mentioning them by name for their presence here. I think it is important that the debate here on the euro area as a whole, openly and with all the differences that exist, can be conducted. As we have already seen in previous reports by the European Parliament, transparency, democratic legitimacy, but also the ownership of the governance of the euro area must be improved. I would like to thank the President of the European Commission for a number of concrete suggestions for our organisation. Many of them were also included in Mrs Berès's report. I am pleased that he mentioned, among other things, the semester week as one of the key points when it comes to setting the priorities in that European discussion. This semester week, of course, takes place with the national parliaments and is about who has what responsibility. I found it interesting in that context that our President said that the EP would stand for a 'full Duty of A Mitsprache' - something I have not often come across in our texts, I must honestly say - and that the President of the Eurogroup came up with the unambitious 'the European Parliament can make full use of its prerogatives according to the Treaty'.  We as the EPP think that the truth is a bit in the middle. What we are anticipating for the future is a real debate at European level on convergence guidelines, the main lines of codecision policy. But let us be honest, ladies and gentlemen, as long as Member States are partly responsible for rescuing other Member States, then those Member States too will have to have a say in decisions and policies. We cannot pretend that we can only do that here at European level.  I have two key points in terms of content. One point is about the eurozone. This debate must be about what the Germans so beautifully call 'Standort Europa'. And yes, ladies and gentlemen of the Socialist Group, which has to do with investment, but then say that this cannot be public investment, which is based on even more debt. The second point concerns the completion of the banking union and the relationship between risk sharing and risk reduction. In this context, the President of the Eurogroup has said that both must go hand in hand. My question is whether there is not also a timing difference, whether the one, namely that reduction and proof that this reduction works in Europe, is not a prerequisite for being able to take that next step in that risk-sharing? (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – The package adopted by the Commission to complete the Economic and Monetary Union does not provide the necessary instruments to allow the Economic and Monetary Union to enhance economic and social convergence. It is only by enhancing economic and social convergence between the members of the euro area and the other Member States of the European Union that we are finally going to make this currency – and the common Economic and Monetary Union – a success.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – That was not a question, but a statement. As long as this debate continues to centre around one-liners such as ‘we need convergence’, yes, we all agree. We disagree about how we get there. I think the Commission had the right policy mix on how to get there, and – as the President of the Eurogroup has said as well – it is a mix of investments and responsible policies. What I miss in this debate is that one political group wants to focus on only one element, and the other on only the other elements. We should be honest and say we need this mix and that this also requires painful decisions in the Member States. Why can you not admit, for example, that it is a good thing to lower debt, while at the same time stimulating investment? It baffles me that I cannot get some political groups to say we should talk about that.

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this debate is extremely important. The three Presidents who co-signed the Five Presidents’ Report are here and we are, for the first time, discussing in plenary the stance and functioning of the eurozone. So this moment is very welcome indeed.  The truth is that, more than seven years after the 2008 crisis, in spite of the welcome massive quantitative easing by the European Central Bank and also in spite of a more intelligent application of the governance rules by the Commission, the eurozone economy is stagnant. It is basically flat with strong internal divergences and alarming levels of poverty and unemployment. The reality confirms what we have repeatedly been saying here and what President Draghi said in 2014, which is that in a recessive economic environment, monetary union alone is not enough to boost the economy. In a zero lower bound interest rate and stagnant economy, investment projects are hardly viable, thus limiting the potential to increase competitiveness and create new jobs, while non-performing loans jeopardise the viability of banks and other lenders.  So the Commission and Council urgently need to acknowledge that the policies which have been imposed until now need urgent change. In 2015, GDP per head and the level of productive investment in the euro area remain below the levels in 2007. The future of the EU – and in particular the future of the eurozone and its acceptance by its citizens – depends on this policy change. Change means that the eurozone cannot, in 2016, pursue a neutral aggregate fiscal stance as, once again, is being proposed by the Commission and the Council. It is suicidal to ignore the facts and to persist in this neutral stance. The aggregate fiscal stance should instead be expansionist, clearly countercyclical, protect productive investment and limit internal divergent trends. But what instruments do we have? Until now, only pre-crisis external deficit countries have adjusted, whereas external surplus countries continue to increase their current account surpluses. The surplus largely reflects excess domestic savings over investment, which leaves the eurozone without a stimulus. This asymmetric adjustment, incapable of generating internal investment or conception, is further reducing the viability of the common currency. Apart from interpreting the existing rules in a wiser way, we need immediately to prepare for the next phase of the 2015 Five Presidents’ report, which is already a diluted version of the 2012 Van Rompuy report. But we need to prepare immediately for the establishment of conditions to create a fiscal capacity for the eurozone. Without a reinforced budget, monetary union cannot function. European institutions also need to respect and comply with all the promises made, on the banking union in particular, by urgently providing an indispensable permanent credible backstop to the single resolution mechanism, by accelerating the common guarantee of deposits, and by allowing the ESM to directly recapitalise banks. I recall that this element is included in the first phase of the Five Presidents’ Report. I do not think that this can be a trade—off for anything else. It is just finishing what has been promised. This is essential for mutual trust and the belief of citizens.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: Thank you, Mr President, and thank you to all the presidents who are here today. Unfortunately, I do not have a pleasant message for you either, because I think your report is a piece of outdated philosophy: a fiscal union, a transfer union, a tax union.  This is not what the Europeans are waiting for. On the contrary, I think they've had enough. In Britain, people are debating a Brexit. In Denmark, they are voting against justice policy. In France, the National Front has never won so many votes. In Eastern Europe, something is brewing against Europe, against this pensée unique. It is always either more Europe or total ruin.  Dear colleagues, that will not work and how do I know? Because we tried it in Belgium. We have had a federal union with transfers, with a lack of democratic support and that is not working.  What does work is more responsibility, responsibility both for the European institutions and for all european Member States, and so we have to look at that 'no bailout rule' as we had it in the Maastricht Treaty; we need to see if and how we can restore it, strengthen it again. Because that is how we can secure the euro perfectly, and that is what we have to do.  That way we can do it without all these new institutions, without all these new powers and without all these new taxes. Responsibility, unity and diversity, doing what Europe really is strong at and not opting for a stifling European superstate. That is the way forward for this European Union.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we can discuss how to complete the monetary union, we can talk about the banking union, and we can talk about how to start some sort of fiscal union, but as fundamental as taking new steps is compliance with the rules that we have already agreed on. The European Union loses more and more credibility every time that the Member States decide not to comply with a European directive. It is happening with the ‘two-pack’ and it happened with the ‘six-pack’. Our experience shows that two things are more and more necessary in order to make the euro stronger. First, more political legitimacy for the Commission. Second, more regulations and fewer directives. The EU needs more binding regulations, because the goodwill of national governments cannot be taken for granted. If we want a strong and more integrated eurozone we need first to comply with our own rules.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, Mr Dijsselbloem, Mr Dombrovskis, the Vice-Chancellor of Germany, Mr Dijsselbloem Gabriel said three days ago that for the high rates of Mrs Marine Le Pen, in France the obsession with a harsh unilateral austerity is to blame. The performance of the euro area shows that this austerity is not paying off, as we have anemic and weak growth, high unemployment, low investment and an increase in poverty and inequality. The power of the far right is also threatening the eurozone itself with disintegration and so the eurozone, if it wants to live and not break up, must move faster to more substantial changes. What you have told us about strengthening democratic accountability is positive, but it is not enough. There must be partial reciprocity at European level on the problem of unemployment, with the acceptance of the Padoan proposal. There must be partial reciprocity in response to the debt problem which is unsustainable for several European countries. There must be a European deposit guarantee which is the third pillar of the Commission's proposal, despite the reactions of Mr. Schäuble hastened to disagree and there must be transfer payments and stronger convergence policies within the euro area, and all this must not be postponed until two years later. In order to achieve all this, we need above all a political direction of the euro area and not to refer everything, as Mr. Schäuble, in the "autopilot" of a committee of technocrats.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I have listened very eagerly to this debate, and I think that we are feeling the very dilemma that economic and monetary union is currently facing. On the one hand, like the statements of right-wing Eurosceptics, on the other hand, members of the Left Group, who are basically describing the drama, have the fact that the euro is to blame for everything, and that is why we in Europe do not get out of social problems on the one hand and economic problems on the other. On the other hand, we hear the different variations of pro-Europeans making different reform proposals, each limited by their different taboos. Some people do not want to talk about social crises, others just want investment, others like to talk about reducing debt and so on, so it goes back and forth. The result is clear: there are proposals on the lowest common denominator. Likewise, in this form, the first step of the five-president paper has been laid out.  In other words, we actually see the major problems that we have within the euro area, but we do not dare to make these proposals, partly because there is another taboo to be added to fear, namely the taboo of many pro-Europeans: to share even more sovereignty. This maximisation of different taboos leads to political incompetence, and thus feeds the political dismay of those who believe anyway that the EU – and the euro in particular – is to blame for everything.  I believe that we are really in a critical situation, if we do not make it clear that the euro is to be launched with deep reform, then this euro will probably not be sustainable. The situation in the markets, at the long end of the yield curve, is so bad, the investment dynamics are so low despite the situation of low interest rates – we need a firm policy. In my view, the various actors must overcome their taboos. In other words, we must both make reforms to increase competitiveness and finally have a common tax policy that ensures that even the wealthy in the Union can no longer take a slender foot. We need a banking union that clarifies on both sides, shares risks, but also reduces risks accordingly, and because it also addresses difficult issues such as the valuation of government bonds. We also need a Capital Markets Union. But not one that leaves out the difficult issues from the outset and therefore will not produce their result. The drama now is that the actors involved, the chairman of the Eurogroup, perhaps the Germany-France axis, the European Parliament and the Commission alike, do not currently have the courage to make such large, broad-based pro-European proposals. This is exactly what the eurozone needs now: we need bold reforms, not despondency, not a retreat from Europe's opponents. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. – Mr Giegold's analysis of this debate was sharp and good, but it was actually completely lacking in what the benefits of this euro area have been. After all, this has, for example, benefited citizens greatly from the fact that interest rates have been low and from a certain predictability. However, you quite briefly acknowledged the need to increase the social dimension of EMU in this reform work. Could you elaborate on that idea so we can find common ground?

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for the question. Reforms have clearly been launched in the crisis, particularly in those countries that have been under pressure. There, however, the social burden was unilaterally offloaded with the weaker and the middle class. On the other hand, we have not put forward a common financial and fiscal policy. Unfortunately, the Eurogroup has allowed a policy mix to be made in the countries that has unilaterally offloaded the burden on the most vulnerable. That would basically have to be overcome. This means that the eurozone needs both a socially and ecologically oriented investment policy and signals of social compensation, for example in the form of a common unemployment insurance scheme, as proposed by many economists.

name: Patrick O’Flynn (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, a former British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Denis Healey, who sadly passed away this year, had a famous law of holes. It was quite simple: when you are in one, stop digging. Even the current British Chancellor, George Osborne, knows of Healey’s law of holes, which is perhaps why he recently abandoned his plan to slash tax credits for working people. But clearly the law of holes is yet to reach continental Europe, because the eurozone is in the mother of all holes and yet rather than climb out you lot keep digging.  The euro does not work. Even after quantitative easing, eurozone growth this year is a dismal 1.5% – this seven years after the financial crash upon which you still blame all your woes. In Italy, growth is 0.8%; in poor Greece, 0.5%. After so many productive resources were taken out of use following the crash, your annual growth number should be starting with a three and not a zero anywhere in the euro area. My EFDD Group colleagues in the Five Star Movement put it very well when they say sufficient time has passed to assess the political and economic failure of the euro project, and that divergences and imbalances have been exacerbated.  On unemployment, the British rate is 5.3%. The eurozone rate is twice as high, at 10.7%, even though we have been taking surplus labour off you via migration, and yet you want more compulsory integration rather than setting disparate economies free in their own currencies with their own interest rate regimes, supervised by their own democracies. The hole you are digging now is so deep you will soon be able to bury the EU’s entire economic prospects inside it.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF).
text: Mr President, since the beginning of the euro crisis, you have imposed urgently on Europeans the legislation on banking union, including the Single Resolution Mechanism (MRU) or the lease-in, in order to bail out the capital of troubled banks, thus rejecting the principle of nationalisation, even temporary, by a State. Your project was prescient since nine banks have already gone bankrupt in 2015 in Europe, including four regional banks in Italy.  What is the finding? In Italy, with your miraculous measures to resolve bank failures, more than 100,000 small shareholders and customers have lost everything, as in Cyprus in 2013. Savers were completely unaware of the risk of loss. The deposit guarantee of 100,000 euros is completely illusory, because Empress Merkel does not want one.  Your banking union is starting to look like a euthanasia of savers that will probably end in a banking panic. It's already gone! The proof: in Mr Draghi's homeland, which is missing today, a ruined pensioner committed suicide last week.  From 1 January 2016, in order to save the single currency again, citizens will have to pay for the damage to irresponsible investment bankers. In order to avoid being guilty of this disaster, are the presidents of the troika ready to withdraw this totalitarian legislation from the banking union?

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The free movement of capital, the free movement of goods and the free movement of services within the European Union take place in the same direction, from the so-called centre countries or colonial countries to the so-called peripheral countries or colonies within the European Union. These freedoms mean to us that the building, protection or strengthening of our own national economies is hampered by this set of rules, on the one hand, and this set of rules on the other hand makes it possible to completely devastate our markets.  The other freedom of the European Union, the free movement of labour, takes place in the opposite direction, they can migrate from peripheral countries to the centre countries, so to speak, or they can flow to skilled nurses, doctors and other professionals earning EUR 300, EUR 500, thereby satisfieding the need for cheap labour for the central countries.  I ask the Head of the Eurogroup here how the situation is different for the peripheral countries that already belong to the euro area, because it seemed as if this was a balance of power.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I strongly believe in the future of economic and monetary union, in the future of the euro, in so far as we will implement the mode of action provided for in the Presidents' report.  I note with regret, however, that Member States that are outside the euro area are too easily making the commitment they made when they joined the European Union, namely that they will take all the necessary measures to adopt the euro. I believe that the Council and the European Commission can do more to get these Member States to fulfil their commitment.  I believe that the European Semester has become an effective tool for coordinating the economic and budgetary policies of the Member States. However, there is a crack in the functioning of the European Semester, which must be removed, namely: national parliaments must be involved from the spring stage in examining national reform development programmes and convergence or financial stability programmes, when they, governments, are required to pass them on to the European Commission.  I fully support the need to set up national competitiveness councils in each Member State. I believe that this is the primary responsibility of each Member State, of firms and local and national authorities. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I am very pleased that you have raised the case of non-euro area countries and that the parliaments of non-euro area countries should also be more involved here through the European Semester. My question is, is that the only reason you're worried? Because I believe that the Agenda for the European Semester has just pushed the European Parliament itself out of the fair line of debates. Thank you very much!

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Thank you for asking. The problem is this: some national parliaments learn about national reform programmes, convergence programmes, only in the autumn, when governments present draft budgets in national parliaments, having already received the European Commission's recommendations on economic and social policies. That is why I believe that national parliaments need to intervene as early as April, to know these programmes.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, three out of five presidents to talk about the 'eurozone' recommendation is a good step. But we have to go back to basics, because the reality of the functioning of the euro area is that we have set up negative interdependencies and what is definitely missing is the reality of that solidarity.
