Today, even Germany, in order to manage the influx of refugees it faces, considers it to be an essential part of the functioning of the European Union. The Commission keeps saying that the European Parliament must be involved in the process, that we need Parliament to make the eurozone work democratically - I note that Jean-Claude Juncker has left us and that the package he put on the table on 21 October leaves no room for the European Parliament, as it sets up a Competitiveness Council to decide on structural reforms in the Member States , a Tax Council that will lead the Commission's analysis of the Member States' budget. It seems to me that there was a place for the European Parliament in all of this. Secondly, the recommendation of the euro area, which we are talking about today, is certainly an element, but we must make it a tool for debate on economic policy. Is a tax neutral stance satisfactory? I note that this recommendation mentions the existence of a current account surplus. So what do we do with it, at a time when, including the IMF, is concerned about the prospect of deflation exported by the euro area globally? This is the economic political debate that this recommendation from the euro area should allow. Mr Dijsselbloem, I hear you when you say that we need simultaneous progress, but when you set out your strategy, I do not feel that this is exactly what you are considering, since you are telling us that private capital must first be mobilised by setting up this famous capital markets union and completing this banking union. It seems to us that this cannot work without the famous budgetary capacity that we so desperately need because interest rates are at zero, because the incentive of the private sector to invest, in the current context, does not exist, and you will not have a strong capital union if you do not have a euro area budget.  That is the reality of the debate. However, the whole of history teaches us that by small steps, we are damaging the project of the euro area. He suffered a warning shot with the Greek affair. It is now essential to put all the cards on the table to ensure the viability and sustainability of the euro at the service of our fellow citizens and therefore first of all of investment and employment. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR)
text: "blue card" question. It is remarkable that Mrs Berès's contributions are always identical. She is always able to tell us what is lacking in solidarity, what is missing from the relationship with the European Parliament and the powers that the European Parliament lacks, but I never hear her talk about the crux of the matter, namely the financial and economic position of France where her government is now in power.  France has been failing for years when it comes to meeting the criteria of the Stability and Growth Pact, which has been lagging behind in the economy for years. Why don't I ever hear you stick your hand in your own bosom?

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. "Mr van Dalen always says the same thing and never looks at what is happening in France! France, under the leadership of François Hollande, has undertaken more structural reforms than any government before. I would like to continue to talk to you, but keep an update on what is happening in my country.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, Mr Dijsselbloem, Economic and Monetary Union has become a great prison for the peoples and the economy itself. With the policy of merch austerity and the violent fiscal adjustment imposed by the Eurogroup, Europe has finally been filled with armies of unemployed people, the debt of the euro zone states has skyrocketed and the countries of the European South are stuck in recession. With your memorial policy you have turned Greece into a vast social cemetery, where 40% of the population lives below the poverty line and the unemployed exceed one and a half million.  What you finally managed, Mr Dijsselbloem, you and the troika, was to rescue the Greek oligarchs, to throw the Greek people into poverty and to threaten them now from above and with rescue by their own means, the notorious bail-in. As if that were not enough, with Memorandum III, you proceed to the plundering of public property, dissolve the insurance, cut salaries and pensions and hammer the homes of the Greeks. But know, Mr Dijsselbloem, that the Greek people will not tolerate you for long and will soon throw the Troika out of Greece.

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Populists' approach is simple answers to complex issues. This morning we are hearing the lyre again, that the euro is to blame for everything and for everyone. All experts know that this cannot be a satisfactory and, above all, correct answer. The euro is neither the cause nor the solution to the problems. The euro is a currency.  There are countries that have the euro, they are in crisis, that is true. But there are also countries that do not have the euro, which are also in crisis. So it cannot be the euro. But the fact is that, in an economic and monetary union, the adjustment mechanism via the currency is no longer necessary. It must then take place in real economic terms. That is precisely why we need not only a monetary union, but also an economic union.  In economic union, we need a common understanding of how this market economy works. There are the nationalists, the budgetists and the socialists, calling for more state, for cyclically-financed employment programmes. We know that all of this can be at most straw fires that mislead. In a continent where the population is declining, in a continent where we have built our prosperity on technical progress, on innovation, prosperity can only be maintained in the future if we address and strengthen these very issues. Competitiveness must be brought into focus. If citizens fail to develop in companies on a daily basis products that anyone in the world needs, which can be sold on world markets, we will not secure our prosperity.  So let's get to grips with the problems at the root of the problem! Let us strengthen competitiveness in Europe, including through bold institutional reforms in the Economic and Monetary Union! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, support economic and monetary unity. I support it, too. You have made the claim that an economic mechanism would be needed to regulate the relationship between euro-currency countries and other countries. Can you tell us how you see this regulation through the economy? Because we obviously have countries with the euro and countries without the euro.

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Grapini, I would like to thank mrs Grapini for her excellent work and for her excellent work. In the eurozone, the eurozone compensates for only 40% of national income shocks. In the US, it is 80% – through an integrated capital market in the US, through better-functioning credit markets, through a functioning banking union, and also through functioning tax transfers. I believe that we must do the same in the European Economic and Monetary Union. The question will be: what happens to countries that are not in the euro? And here I say: respect the Maastricht Treaty, finally implement the Treaty in accordance with the law. Anyone who can should join the euro, then much easier.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – We are talking about another step in deepening the process of economic governance, seeking to respond to the proven failure of the European Semester. To the Stability Pact we add the Six Pack, the Two Pack, the Euro+ Pact. We are now with this proposal by the five Presidents to discuss more rules and more procedures, all of them seeking to respond to a social and economic crisis and further cleave the budgetary policy of national states. There is talk of non-compliance with the recommendations by countries, but their opportunity or applicability is not disputed. Instead, it is preferred to impose more expert bodies which, under a supposed infallible scientificity, will only throw more confusion and deepen the undemocratic nature of economic governance. But as political as the report is, it still does not resolve this insanible contradiction of having a system in which countries that need to invest cannot and those that can do so because there is no capacity for consumption. External imbalances are now persistent. Countries accumulate surpluses at the expense of others. The report now proposes that it be the process of economic governance that encourages governments with surpluses to spend more in the interests of all, i.e. we seek to resolve an administrative balance that was ensured through the money market that existed before the euro. It's unfortunate.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: Thank you, Mr Dijsselbloem, and welcome Mr Dijsselbloem as chairman of the eurogroup. It is a historic moment when we have a real democratic debate on the economy of the whole euro area. Moreover, I think that we in the European Parliament also need to take a closer look at our procedures in order to make that debate a real debate, because you are still sitting here for an hour, Mr Dijsselbloem. However, I would ask you to take a more serious look at the democratic deficit of the euro area.  When I hear you in the House of Representatives, you are actually saying: things are going very well, there is no democratic deficit in the eurogroup. The European Parliament can have a nice debate, that is what I come here for, and the various national parliaments are also talking about the euro area. That's not true. There is no real mention of the economic state of the euro area in any national parliament. Each country has its own national debate, looks at its own situation, but no one looks at the situation of the entire euro area.  This requires clear democratic control for the euro area. That is what the debate here in the European Parliament is about. If you also think that more needs to be done there, then you will not only have to make the case here in Strasbourg, but you will certainly have to express the role of the European Parliament more clearly and defend it more clearly in The Hague. Because you too have a contribution to contribute to the democratic content of the entire EU and in the House of Representatives it can definitely be improved. I am very curious to see what exactly you think of the Commission's proposal to look at aggregate fiscal stance, whether the whole euro area situation, whether fiscal policy is pro-cyclical or countercyclical.  I have heard about this in The Hague, but not yet here in Strasbourg. And according to the recommendation, the surplus countries must also get to work, the surplus countries clearly have to make more investments themselves. So this is also about the Netherlands. Do you intend to take action as surplus country the Netherlands itself, so that the entire euro area will function better?

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, twenty years ago Europe initiated a momentous decree to bring about a great beacon of hope to millions of Europeans, or so they said. At this Christmas time, instead of hope, joy and happiness, the spirit of European life is being extinguished for those trapped in the consequences of this failed European political project. At this Christmas time, 23 million people will be unemployed across all of Europe. At this Christmas time: 53% of Greek youth unemployment, 49% of young people unemployed in Spain and 48% of young people unemployed in Italy.  The prospects for the future of the eurozone are not great either. We see the gaps in investment increasing year on year. Eurozone productivity is declining from 0.6% to 0.2%. The share of world GDP will decline to 14% by 2018 and further. But there are those in this Commission, like Mr Moscovici, who said to me that he did not recognise the Europe of high unemployment and high suicides like those in Greece. There are those in this Parliament, like Mr Theurer, who do not recognise that the euro is an element of competitiveness, and how it improves the prospects of European economies. There are those in the Eurogroup like yourself, Mr Dijsselbloem, who are probably enjoying the too many dinners and meetings with those from Goldman Sachs and the bankers who will give you the indication that the Capital Markets Union is beneficial for Europe – it is beneficial for them. We have come to a momentous time for Europe, a time when the British vote to leave the European Union will not only free my nation but will give European nations the impetus to consider a bright, better future and a Christmas that all can enjoy.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Eurogroup, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has The Five Presidents' Report of June this year provides for the creation of an economic, financial, fiscal and political union with the aim of creating economic policy coordination, convergence and solidarity in the euro area. The Commission has currently proposed the creation of national competitiveness committees in order to specify Stage 1. There has already been talk of a minimum solution in this context today. These committees will be staffed by independent experts who will monitor national competitiveness and get involved in wage negotiations. These committees will also incorporate their recommendations into the European Semester and will be used for the macroeconomic imbalances procedure. The whole thing is to be coordinated by the Commission. All this may sound very good in theory, but in practice it is an unworkable solution to create growth and employment in Europe. The national competitiveness committees have no significant influence on Member States' policies, nor on the implementation of structural reforms or wage negotiations. And a new pillar of European social rights to be developed will lead to one, namely to restrict entrepreneurial freedom – with the result that less investment is being made, less employment is created, and less growth happens in Europe.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr Dijsselbloem, you came here today to talk to us about the future of the euro. We Greeks know you very well, unfortunately, and I can say that I am not at all happy to see you, because you are one of those who have forced the Greek people to live in conditions unheard of for a European state. With your obsessive approach, which has nothing to do with reality, you have turned Greece, but also Cyprus, into doomed guinea pigs. It is your behaviour that deconstructs the single currency.  In any case, the euro had the wrong foundations from the outset. But both the ideological anchorages it formed and the structures it formed ultimately resulted in it not being able to function. In addition, you have not taken into account the needs of the smaller economies at all, but you have actually tried to simply serve the interests of the larger countries, especially Germany. For us Greeks, the euro proved to be an extremely expensive currency that acted as a catalyst to give the final blow to an already weak economy. As far as the future is concerned, under no circumstances do we believe that the single currency can survive in its present form. Fundamental changes are needed either, for a more centralised approach or, as we would prefer, for countries to prepare for a return to national currencies in order to restore their national sovereignty.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Eurogroup president, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has For many, many years, we have established, through the Treaties and many rules of the game, how we can imagine a common currency. And as soon as we have decided anything, we have said: this is far from enough, we need new steps. But we should actually do something completely different. But we have not implemented what we have decided up to then. I believe that if the euro suffers from one, it is in the way of implementing what was decided in Brussels by those who participate in the euro at home. Instead, we go back to Brussels and say: this and that should be added. The euro will not work if people say that I am transforming responsibility at European level, at an international level, but budgetary responsibility, which I continue to have nationally. The Markoeconomics, Which I continue to have nationally. Then it will not work. So: Spending, but not being liable for it, doesn't work. Having macroeconomic responsibility, but not wanting to be liable for it, does not work.  That is why I criticise the Five Presidents' Report in a very fundamental way, because it does not analyse at all what has already been agreed and is not being complied with. Before we keep discussing new steps with each other, we should be sober in astosising what is not working. It is not enough to say that Hollande has made a few reforms and more than his predecessors. France is not doing enough reforms! Point - off - end! France has been violating the Stability and Growth Pact for many years! Point - off - End. You can't lie about it. I could also denote this for other countries. Then to say that one country should invest more than the others, and everything will be fine – ladies and gentlemen, I would just like to point out that the country that exports the most in the European Union is also doing so in a way that is divided into labour. Most countries in the eurozone and the European Union also benefit from this. That is why we are not implementing new proposals, but what has long since been decided, in a concrete and consistent way, then we are on the right track. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Ferber, your run-off theory is not working and I note that Germany's surpluses are also not compatible with the rules we have in terms of monitoring macroeconomic imbalances.  You always talk about the rules, but what do you think of the economic and financial committee that has just, in the utmost secrecy, reinterpreted the communication on flexibility, when this Parliament has not had to debate it? I would also like to hear from Mr Dijsselbloem on this new interpretation of the communication.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I believe that this is an idle discussion. I can pin this on a product: a German car has about 80% of value added in the whole of the European Union outside Germany. A French car has a 70% share of value added of 70% of parts produced only in France.  That is why to accuse us of making surpluses at the expense of others is simply not fair.

name: Jakob von Weizsäcker (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The exchange between my colleague and my colleague has just shown that if we carry on like this in the euro area, these conflicts will get worse and worse. It is quite clear from my point of view that, in the long term, monetary union will only work with a euro government, a euro parliament and a budget for the euro area. This is also necessary for the credible change of the banking union. In the end, there will be no fiscal backstop without this. Unfortunately, the first part of the Five Presidents' Report on this issue is a cliffhanger, and the crucial questions about the future of the eurozone will not be answered until the second part. The questions that need to be answered are: what exactly should democratic decision-making in the eurozone look like? What should the fiscal capacity for the eurozone look like? How will it be financed? How should they be decided? Above all, however, how can proper macroeconomic insurance be offered in the euro area at the same time and the budgetary restrictions imposed by the individual Member States can finally be hardened? Because here, too, we have a massive problem. As we all know, the Maastricht Treaty was not credible on this issue. Going into the 2017 Super Election year with clear and honest answers to these questions is not easy. I know that. But it would be very dangerous not to give these clear and honest answers for the 2017 super election year. This would damage what actually holds the euro together: the basic confidence in the common project, which is still in place in Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr von Weizsäcker, you agree with me that the question of how much integration and, above all, how much joint supervision we need at European level – that is, how much communitarisation, that this measure also depends on how compliant the individual Member States of the euro area are.  In other words, the greater the commitment made by the Member States, such as implementing structural reforms and applying fiscal discipline, the less intensive the scope for intervention at European level must be.

name: Jakob von Weizsäcker (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, Mr Theurer, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent work. Of course, we not only need common rules, but we also need to adhere to them. And the big problem today is that we cannot even know: do individual states not abide by the rules because the rules are so bad that they cannot be adhered to, or do they not abide by the rules because they basically do not want to abide by the rules? Only if we have sensible rules, a sensible architecture for the euro, will we be able to answer this question.

name: Jeroen Dijsselbloem
text: President of the Eurogroup. – Mr President, in my final contribution, I would just like to pick up on a couple of points that the Members have made.  First of all, I think building the monetary union – and the same goes for the banking union – is about solidarity and organising it in our social economic system. Therefore it is about reducing risks, becoming more resilient, becoming stronger and more flexible, and, at the same time, gradually sharing risks. That is the only way forward. That is the way we have built the banking union and must complete it, and that is the way we must strengthen the monetary union.  Ms de Lange asked me whether it was not first about reducing risk and then sharing risks. I think that is too simple. We are at the moment in a phase of building up the banking union. As of 1 January 2016, new rules will apply. We are starting to build up the Resolution Fund, which will be complete in eight years’ time, and gradually we will share the risks inside the resolution framework. So it will go hand in hand. Yes, we will start sharing risk in the banking union. We already do now, and in the coming eight years we will continue to do so until it is a fully common system. It is about the two approaches at the same time, and that is the only way to get it done – politically as well. Ms Ferreira was absolutely right when she said that you cannot leave economic policy up to the ECB. The ECB is already far beyond what can reasonably be expected from monetary policy with a very accommodative stance.  So it is now up to politicians at national and European level. It is for both national and European levels to take their responsibilities, and that is also about applying what has been agreed. How can you build a common system and how can you build a union if you cannot apply the rules, and if you will not stick to the rules and the agreements that have been reached?  Ms Ferreira also asked me about the fiscal stance for the eurozone. At the moment a neutral stance for the eurozone as a whole is a reasonable approach, but there are big differences between countries. Some can do more, but there are limitations: there are few countries that actually have a fiscal surplus at the moment and could invest more. So there will be a different approach at national level in the fiscal stance and, overall, in the eurozone a neutral stance is, at this time, the right position to take.  For the future we need to have that debate about the fiscal capacity. We have put it in the second phase of the Five Presidents’ Report, but there is no reason why we should not debate it now, because there are many different ideas of what a fiscal capacity could mean. Some see it as a common backstop for our monetary union, some see it as an investment instrument, and some see it as a social security funding system. These are very different approaches. Let us debate that, because only if you have an agreement on the design of it do you know what size it has to have. Then you have to find agreement on where the funding is to come from. These are big questions that will touch upon our labour market policy, on our social security system and possibly even our pension systems. It depends very much on how you design this fiscal capacity, and there is no agreement as yet on what their instrument should look like. So let us do the work on that and let us not wait until 2017.  Many of you have spoken about the responsibilities of Member States and I fully agree. When you talk about structural reforms, part of it – a major part, I would say – is national responsibility and will probably be so for a very long time. The issues vary from one country to another, yet some are very much the same in all of our eurozone countries. The tax pressure on labour is much too high, forcing labour out of our economy. Let us reverse that process. We are working on that in the eurozone, and many countries are taking measures there. We need further work on the pension system to make it sustainable, also in Greece. Pensions systems need to be sustainable if we want to insure our pensioners, also in the future.  Part of the structural reforms will also have to come from the European side. We talked about the Capital Markets Union. Let me reassure Mr Woolfe that I do not dine with Goldman Sachs and, if I do dine with them, I certainly do not take their instructions. But I do believe that the Capital Markets Union is a way to open up financing needs to create more financing for our companies. We are still much too dependent on the banking system throughout Europe. Let us diversify that, become more resilient and strengthen economic recovery.  I have to react to Mr Eickhout who always, when I meet him in Brussels or here in Strasbourg, addresses me as a Dutch Minister. His point is that I say different things in the national parliament than I do in the European Parliament. I never do that. I always stress both the importance of this European dialogue and that of the national parliament. I strongly disagree with him that in national parliaments there is no serious debate about the European economy or European economic governance. He should come to the Dutch Parliament to participate in those debates. They are in depth, broad and serious, and I have to go to my parliament at least twice a month to discuss those issues.  Finally, Mrs Berès asked me about flexibility in the pact. Over the course of the crisis, the pact has proven to be flexible. A number of countries have been given more time to deal with their fiscal deficits. Fiscal targets have been adjusted over and over again. The real question is whether we can, in time, build fiscal buffers into our budgets again. That is my greatest concern: that we still have high sovereign debts, many countries still have high deficits, even though a lot of work has been done, and if a new economic setback were to occur, we do not have enough buffer capacity.  On the flexibility that the Commission has proposed: I strongly agree with that kind of flexibility, but it should be used well. The Commission should take the requests for flexibility of the Member States seriously and make sure that the credibility of the pact is not damaged. There is a balance between the flexibility in the pact and the credibility of the pact. Finally, we have a lot of work to do in the short term. So let us have a debate about long-term monetary union governance, let us start that debate now, but let us also work on the very short—term measures we can take. I have already mentioned the banking union, competitiveness, structural reforms and the Capital Markets Union, etc. There is work to be done.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen! Mr Dijsselbloem had told us before this debate that he had to leave at 11 a.m. on a date that he could not postpone. I had informed you of this in advance.  Nevertheless, I am grateful to you for having postponed this date for us this morning and for having been here for this two hours – or it has already been more than two hours – in Parliament. We look forward to seeing you again soon, Mr Dijsselbloem.  So, the invitation to you is a constant one. I believe that the outcome of the debate is also clear. The accountability of the President of the Eurogroup cannot be limited to a committee to Parliament, but must already take place here in plenary. We are therefore grateful that you have opened this new chapter with us. We need to discuss how we can proceed structurally now. In any case, thank you for this morning.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Of all the European Union's projects, economic ones, such as the single market, are among the most successful. It is good that, after years of misi definitions, the single currency project is called a political project. I leave it to the Members of the Eurogroup to assess the value of this project, its effectiveness, especially in relation to costs. It is important that all Member States of the European Union, regardless of the currency adopted, have equal access to the common market and its benefits. All the proposals prepared by the Presidents should go in this direction.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE).
text: Mr President, the eurozone is in danger. Let us recognize that its architecture is wobbly, since it has a monetary pillar based on the European Central Bank, of federal essence, but it remains devoid of the indispensable fiscal and political pillar. The changes that have been made since 2012 are progress, but the euro area still does not have an economic policy. It adds up national policies, framed by the Stability and Growth Pact, a pact regularly broken by many countries and which is merely a co-ownership regulation of the euro.  The euro area, unlike the United States of America, cannot practice the policy mix, that is, support for growth and jobs. There is an urgent need to equip it with the appropriate institutions so that it can finally be managed and governed: the appointment of a full-time finance minister, whose function is incompatible with the office of minister in one of the euro area Member States, the issue of availability and the issue of conflict of interest prevention; establishing a Treasury Directorate-General to coordinate the management of government borrowing, strengthen the banking union, stabilize financial markets and guarantee deposits; establishing a euro area budget to neutralise systemic shocks and encourage, by rewarding them, structural reforms and investment; and finally, the creation of a European Monetary Fund, probably by transferring the European Financial Stability Mechanism. And, as a corollary, I think it is essential to place this new governance under the democratic control of a committee in which representatives of the European Parliament and representatives of the national chambers would sit.  Any sharing of sovereignty requires democratic legitimacy. So, Mr Presidents, I urge you to be bold and courageous. I believe in the benefits of the euro, which is to say how urgent it is to remedy the fragilities of the euro area.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, while the Founding Treaties of the European Union refer to people's well-being, economic convergence, employment and growth as objectives, the countries and peoples who share the same currency see nothing of it. They don't see democracy and they don't see solidarity. The euro has become a monetary prison, with a prison guard - with what legitimacy - the now overactive Mr Dijsselbloem. The euro has become a Roman arena of German inspiration, where the strong impose their will and interests on the weak. It has plunged countries into recession, unemployment and the eurozone in general to stagnation. He has condemned the new generation to long-term unemployment.  Ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, for the Peoples of Europe it cannot be a one-way street to submit to the policies of EMU and the euro and poverty cannot be a one-way street. It is said, and so it is, that the euro is a political project. But the euro with its operation creates new divisions: North-South, rich-poor, lenders-borrowers, surplus-deficits. In this respect, ladies and gentlemen, how can the plan be? The euro cannot be the plan, it cannot be the way, it cannot be the way that leads to the union of peoples and countries.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, I will still speak, but I am a little surprised that neither the President of the Commission nor the President responsible for the Eurogroup are there. So, finally, who are we talking about? I would like to point out that in 2012, before being elected by this abominable Mrs Le Pen, did we not propose a stimulus programme based on the Central Bank with the big public banks, using quantitative easing to invest in the real economy, in transport and energy infrastructure, in SMEs, in the development of exports.  This plan was blocked because of the German initiative. As long as, in a single area, there are no transfers to invest and balance the levels of the economy, the euro is doomed. Yet you continue on this path. You are responsible for the failure of the euro, it is not us.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, Vice-President Dombrovskis, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has said. Helmut Kohl said the day after the conclusion of the negotiations on monetary union: now the European Union is irreversible. After all, a decision on a single currency is, in fact, the initial ignition for the creation of a political union. A common currency and a political union belong together. However, we are not yet a political union. The crucial point, therefore, is that we finally present an action plan, a plan for the operational implementation of all the proposals, a sanctions plan and a timetable for the creation of a political union. My second point is that we all agree today that the euro is a common currency that does not only refer to the euro area. In other words, this Parliament democratically legitimises the necessary political decisions for the single currency. The President of the Commission has said that Parliament and the Commission must be strengthened. Yes, all measures to develop the monetary union into economic and social union, to create a banking and capital markets, fiscal and investment union must be taken on the basis of Community law. This is the only way to legitimise democracy. That is why we need our own EU finance minister, so we need a joint presence in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. And we need a voice from the European Union in international committees such as Basel, and we need a European budget. And, of course, we also need sanctions mechanisms for those who do not comply with what we decide and determine. Because anyone who does not do what he says and does not act as he decides weakens the currency and the European Union.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the area of management structures built for the eurozone in the past years is impressive, though still incomplete. All of it was set up in fire-fighting mode, with the EU leaders doing their best to contain crisis after crisis. The same happened this year, with successive crises occurring on a wider front than that covered by the euro narrative. The fire-fighting has been successful. The collateral social costs have been high, but the structures set up under the Stability and Growth Pact might reflect too much the contingencies surrounding the euro crisis of that past. They are probably sufficient now to protect the euro from a recurrence of a crisis like that of 2008. Will they be adequate to face up to the challenges of the future, and to a new kind of crisis? Today's challenges arise from economic fragility and stagnation, from lack of job creation and competitiveness, and from low public and private investment. Success in dealing with them has been very limited. As we follow the liturgy of the European semester, has the time also come to reflect radically on the design of the Economic and Monetary Union? Do we need to think outside the box? Not to undermine the achievements, but to update them? As we bemoan the lack of competitiveness, could it be that the design of the Stability and Growth Pact itself inhibits competitiveness. Why with more Europe, as this has been hesitantly implemented, have we failed to achieve higher competitiveness and higher investment? Is the setting up of new bureaucratic councils to preach about competitiveness really the right answer? Do we need a revision of the Stability and Growth Pact? Perhaps, beyond the consolidation of existing management structures, we need a root and branch appraisal of how EMU has developed up to now.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: – This EMU lays a foundation in which a huge crack has been going on since day one. Socio-economic relations between Member States are far too diverse. The eurozone is far from an optimum currency area. And enforcement is nothing.  For years, the criteria of the Stability and Growth Pact have been widely violated by a number of countries, and frontrunner Greece has a huge debt of 175% of gross national product, and that country believes that it can be saved by increasing loans and selling cutlery - I think silverware is too generous - to sell out the cutlery such as the port of Piraeus.  The Chinese are the smiling third, while debt relief and a fresh start with their own currency would really help the Greeks. In short, EMU must indeed make a paradigm shift. Looking at an option like debt relief, looking at sanctions and investing more in the relationship with countries that are outside the euro. If you do that, you build a credible EMU.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE).
text: The presidents who were present this morning are no longer here, but I would like to address Vice-President Dombrovskis. It has already been mentioned a few times today: the ecb's non-existent President, Mr Draghi, has a tough task in monitoring monetary policy. And he also says all the time: I cannot do that if structural reforms are not being worked on at the same time, if we do not work on a balanced fiscal policy.  Mr. Draghi is doing everything he can. He pops 60 billion into the European economy every month with his super bazooka. Actually as a type of bodybuilder uses growth hormones, we use this as financial growth hormones. Unhealthy, I think, because if you do not work at the same time on good nutrition and training of your body - i would compare that to structural reforms and fiscal policy - then you end up with a disastrous legacy. Mr Draghi said: "I'm gonna do whatever it takes".  Is it not even time for the Commission to say: 'We'll do whatever it takes' and are you not going to go ahead with the fact that we are talking about Member States that are constantly ignored the country-specific recommendations?  Mr. Dombrovskis has a fantastic track record in his own country. So I would urge him to go through with Mr Moscovici within the Commission and say, just like Mr Draghi: 'We'll do whatever it takes'.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, full economic and monetary union was the core of the original great plan rejected by the Member States at the design stage of the currency. At that point the project should have been scrapped. That it was not scrapped, that we had catastrophe in country after eurozone country after launch, with five bankrupted and most others with vastly increase debt-to-GDP ratios, that we now have EMU being eased through, begs the question: was this Plan B from the start? Was that the thinking of those who have masterminded all this? The catastrophes in the likes of Ireland and Spain were accurately foretold as early as 1998 by such a renowned economist as Paul De Grauwe, and thus must also have been foreseen by those who were at the fore in pushing forward this currency union. Have we all been taken for a ride? Was all this pain, suffering and hardship – and even death – in Ireland, in Greece, in Portugal, Spain, Italy, Cyprus, foreseen, or even planned? I am against the EMU. The sooner Ireland gets out the better. This is meant to be a debate on the future of this Union. I, for the vast majority of this debate, was the only Irish MEP present. Where the hell is the democracy? It is dead.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, you assured us that the expansion of central bank liquidity would not increase hyperinflation, because it remained within the framework of asset inflation, but Draghi, in a recent speech in Frankfurt, revealed on the contrary that spillover is possible and that the ECB is pursuing precisely this objective. Too bad you couldn't tell him in his presence because he defected this morning.  But we see the consequences of the partial experimentation of bail-in, carried out with the rescue of four small local Italian banks. In Italy it is a scandal that has been filling the front pages of all newspapers and news openings for days and days, also because there has been the death, I would remind you, of a small saver, a retired worker, poor Luigino D'Angelo, one of the many victims, in this case victims also in a physical sense, for his suicide, of these mistakes.  The truth is that the Italian Government has not been able to intervene in the drafting of the bail-in directive to prevent the very serious consequences and is now failing to compensate small savers. I make this cry, this appeal to Europe: "allow, impose on the Italian Government compensation for all poor savers ..." (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: – Any minimal reference to further strengthening the European Union is enough today to make a whole group of politicians stand up to a European superstate that would deter citizens. I find it frankly painful to see that even a mere reference to the completion of the banking union is too sensitive for some Member States. I would like to hear from those ministers how, without a finished banking union, including a genuine European deposit guarantee mechanism, they think they are avoiding a repeat of the debacle in 2008, 2009, in which bank and public debt reinforced each other.  For me, strengthening or deepening EMU is a matter of pure pragmatism. My inspiration is the mere need to give EMU the necessary tools to function better and thus also to increase its legitimacy and public support. I therefore welcome the fact that the Commission is not paralysed by these short-sighted national reflexes and putting realistic concrete proposals on the table. It is important that it wants to strengthen its commitment to increasing the ex-ante national ownership of the country-specific recommendations. The appropriate timing of the semester also allows greater involvement of national parliaments and social partners, not to mention.  But the closer involvement of that national level should not be interpreted as a signal that it is where the real legitimacy can be achieved. No, the European construction is characterised by a multi-layered legitimacy in which the European Parliament naturally plays a crucial role. The European interest is much more than the sums of the interests of individual Member States. The founding fathers realised that they had to protect themselves from their own national reflexes, because they undermine the surplus of European cooperation. It is precisely for this reason that the European Union is essentially supranational, which is precisely why the Union needs strong institutions and a strong European Parliament, partly to ensure the legitimacy of this construction. So no, I am not a young dreamer stubbornly clinging to an overtaken idea of a European superstate. I just want to be purely pragmatic and do what is necessary to make this European and monetary union work better in the future. Thank you.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the truth is that we are facing a very important debate for the future of the whole Union and especially for the future of the euro area.  And, in the context of this debate, with the presence at the beginning of three of the presidents who signed the report of the five presidents on the future of the euro area, I would like to ask a clear question – and I also ask Dombrovskis – where, in which paragraph of that report of the five presidents, it is said that public debt must no longer be a risk-free asset? Where?  Because I've had enough of reading that report, page by page, paragraph by paragraph, and nowhere does this debate open up. And this debate is now open, within Europe, with some country, with some finance minister who wants to use this debate to paralyze the future of deposit insurance across the euro area. We cannot allow deposit insurance to be taken hostage by those who want to end public debt as a risk-free asset, because this poses a threat to the union of capital, to the banking union and to the whole euro area project.  And, therefore, this Parliament and this Member who speaks to you will be firmly defending this deposit insurance, which has to be clearly European, which has to be clearly from the euro area. Because those threats posed by some ministers, posed by some to block the euro area, can be a direct attack on the banking union and capital union.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Today's debate is overwritten: Five presidents for the euro – further proof that offices do not necessarily confer wisdom or even wisdom. The euro has led to low economic growth in the eurozone, high unemployment, social tensions, economic imbalances, political tensions.  Ladies and gentlemen of the ALDE Group, when we have been asked today: where are the Liberals?, I say to you: it is not enough to call ourselves liberal, we must also pursue liberal policies. When Mr Theurer says that the euro is neither a problem nor a solution, and complains about the budgetists, I ask: who is running the centralised European deposit guarantee? Who is cutting red tape under the single market label? Who of you does not dream of the Social and Tax Union, criticise economic stimulus programmes and adopt a Juncker pocket trick of EUR 315 billion? Then finally, be in favour of free monetary competition! Stop the central government, the planned economic domination of the central banks! Read your Hayek! Then you will find that the solution means free market money. That would be liberal. The euro is anti-competitive, it is anti-social, it is a tatist, and its practice is contrary to the rule of law!

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE).
text: – When I hear some of these people in this House, it seems that our economies are not connected. They are, of course, through the internal market. That, of course, they are for a number of countries also because of the single currency, which is why we need to work together to solve this problem. We, as the European Union, the Commission, Parliament, as Member States, must take our responsibility together.  Firstly, by ensuring that the credibility of the Stability Pact is restored. Secondly, by finishing the banking union in order to ensure financial stability to citizens and businesses. And thirdly, by completing that capital markets union to make sure that we are less dependent on bank financing and we can finally make real investments in our real economy. But the countries must also take responsibility in this story. Surely they cannot agree on structural reforms and then implement only 10 or 15% of these reforms at home. How can you pursue a common economic policy if it is the credibility and lack of ownership of different countries? So you will have to put more pressure there so that these structural reforms are implemented in those countries as well. A final point is democratic responsibility. Here too, I believe that we need to start a debate to ensure that this Parliament can play its part more than ever with national parliaments in order to ensure that these reforms and stability are achieved. The European Central Bank, as politicians, has given us time, given politicians time to take responsibility. It is time for the European Central Bank to do its job as an independent monetary institution and for us politicians to work together european and nationally to solve this problem once and for all.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, it would have been nice if Mr Juncker had stayed to listen to all the interventions. I think Mr Juncker is right when he says that monetary union is a political project. I agree with him. Since the beginning of the crisis, this has become clear to European citizens. The Union's policies have increased inequality and violated the sovereignty of the countries of the South, based on a political project that takes precedence over the interests of large private and Central European banking.  The integration project now before us is moving in the same way: to increase, through the Competitiveness Councils, the Union's power over budgets, tax systems and wage policies. And with their proposal to integrate the European Stability Mechanism into the European Treaties, they seek to extend to europe as a whole the whip of austerity and blackmail. With the banking union, they also promote a financial concentration that lifts huge mud giants that can fall on all of us.  If you really want democratic control over such a deeply unequal and unfair system, this is a sham. If you really want democracy, encourage progressive fiscal harmonisation so that those who have more pay, build a budget that boosts Europe's sustainable and redistributive investment, create a public bank that really guarantees the social function of credit and holds up to listen to all the interventions of all Members.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF).
text: Madam President, once again we are being offered measures and wishful thinking to improve the functioning of the euro area. But no further involvement of the European Parliament will change that. No technocratic mechanism camouflaged under increasingly light democratic ornaments can hide the reality: the euro is a total failure. It is a failure because it is based, from the beginning, on false principles.  Forcing monetary union between the countries of Europe has not united them and will never lead them towards unity. On the contrary, economies are increasingly divergent, European countries outside the euro are doing much better. The poor are getting poorer, the richest are getting richer, tensions are rising and people are standing up against each other. They are being asked to make unsustainable sacrifices to save a currency, instead of putting the economy at their service. The Greeks have been humiliated and are even more humiliated every day. Other peoples will soon be.  Many Nobel laureates and renowned economists have said, reality proves it relentlessly: we must give up this aberrant golden calf, we must stop sacrificing peoples to save the euro and rather sacrifice the euro to save the peoples.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the eurozone’s challenges, both its architecture and its common governance, so far based on the intergovernmental approach, are often characterised by a too far-going respect for diversity of preferences and past—dependency thinking. Rules in the institutions have been under improvement, but reforms have not yet reached a critical mass. We have to make further decisive steps on the institutions and rule reforms to make the governance system effective. But before this happens, sound fiscal positions in every jurisdiction and an unprecedented level of policy coordination at eurozone level are fundamental. In 2016 we will have to prepare for the ECB’s shift towards normal monetary policy in a way that will not lead to further contraction. To make it possible for the ECB to handle the transition to higher interest rates in a successful way, there is a need to have – on the fiscal and structural policies side of the Eurozone – right, timely and well-coordinated reaction. It is worth recalling that over the last years we have had a bad experience of Mr Draghi’s calls for action by Member States not resulting in support for his efforts. We cannot afford it this time around. Let us use the opportunity created by the fact that the Commission has presented eurozone recommendations six months before country—specific recommendations and that there is a eurozone working programme for the first half of 2016. Full use of these two vehicles can give us an effective policy coordination.

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: – Many people in Europe have little or no way of keeping their heads above water and have been hit by the storm of the economic crisis. It is therefore the task for European politicians to get the economy on dry land in order to weather the economy with new storms. The European Commission lays sandbags. The focus on the budgetary impact for the whole euro area as a whole is good.  The proposal to complement the banking union and also the recommendation to countries with a current account surplus to encourage investment is good.  Nevertheless, the sandbags show exactly where the holes in the dikes are. Due to budgetary prudence and financial fragmentation, the adjustment is slow, unbalanced and therefore costly in terms of growth and high unemployment. It seems as if the ECB is alone in its remit to get the economy going again. Moreover, the potential for growth and jobs is less than ever. Investment is 20% lower than before and public investment has been snapped up while interest rates are still lower than ever.  Lugging with sandbags is not enough. We need a European Delta Plan for a democratic and solidarity eurozone, so that everyone can keep their heads above water and a new storm cannot threaten us again.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: Madam President, Mr Dombrovskis, I would like to thank mr Dombrovskis for his excellent work and for the work she has done. It is good that you want to restore confidence in the single currency, but you are doing the opposite. Again and again you break your own rules. You keep sending money to Greece – in the meantime, more than Mr Juncker's entire investment package. Likewise, you are breaking the rules by allowing Italy and Spain to keep making new debts, not to mention France, because the Commission is simply far too weak to punish France. In addition, the European Central Bank encourages new debt to be made. Every month, it buys new government bonds for 60 billion euros. This is also a breach of the rules. In addition, there is an interest rate that is close to zero. You have only one paper tiger in the face of this invitation to take on debt: its Growth and Stability Pact. You do not need any new rules, Mr Dombrovskis, you do not need a banking union and what do I know, what everything, you need compliance with the existing rules. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: Blue card question. I have heard that my fellow Member mentioned Italy doing new debts. I would like to know from my colleague, if when he mentions Italy, he mentions why he has data, why he actually said bullshit, why Italy is no longer making debts, Italy is below 3% debt/GDP, indeed it is at 2.4%, so if there is one country that has complied with the pacts, it is precisely our country, italy. So, when he intervenes at least on Italy, say the exact things.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Well, you can discuss who is talking stuss here. Italy's debt is around 140%, and 2.4 – the figure you mentioned, Mr Buonanno – is the new debt. Italy is in debt by 2.4% this year or last year. That is the first thing. Secondly, there is still covert financing by the National Bank of Italy – at that time Mr Draghi was still in power. I believe that Italy has made 140 billion more debts, which are hidden somewhere in balance sheets. In your place, I would be very, very quiet.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, the economic crisis of 2008 demonstrated two things: the first, which some people did not like our economic and monetary union, was an effective tool and shield for our national economies; the second, which we must, of course, go further in this union and the convergences it demands if we want to withstand future shocks that are bound to occur. Our economic and monetary union is incomplete and certainly too fragile. Focused on the financial stability needed, it has abandoned growth, which is also essential for economic recovery. As such, I welcome the initiative of President Juncker, who, since his speech on the State of the European Union, has placed this subject at the heart of his priorities. I also welcome the consideration of the democratic framework in which these reforms are to take place, including the establishment of national competitiveness councils and a European budget committee. It is wise not to repeat the mistakes we have sometimes made to move faster, by not involving Europeans and their representatives enough in decision-making. Like the European semester, these two bodies will have to raise competitiveness and economic growth as priorities in order to create sustainable jobs and strengthen our economic and monetary area, i.e. to strike the right economic and political balance between reducing Member States' deficits and implementing stimulus policies. In conclusion, I will send a short message to all those who demonstrate their scepticism or opposition to such a strengthened union: what would be the weight of any European country, not exceeding no more than 80 million inhabitants compared to the other economic powers? How could we weigh and assert our positions without coming together on a continent-wide scale? To believe in national isolation is dangerous not only for our economies but also for our democracies. On the contrary, political courage is to adapt and anticipate a world that is constantly changing, not to deny this reality.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D). Madam President, we are talking about economic and monetary union and of course we are talking about the euro. But this debate takes us back years, when the financial crisis began and when we were discussing public debt and, by extension, the risk of banks. I will therefore focus my intervention on just one point, the decisions and policies taken ex post, when they should be implemented in advance. Today, therefore, we are trying to supplement the banking union ex post, with the third part of its architecture, the Single Deposit Guarantee System, which was part of the original architecture of the banking union which was not implemented because there were political reactions. We all know where these reactions came from, in addition to any other problems of a technocratic nature. The Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats has long insisted on the need to eliminate the discrimination of depositors which has worked to the detriment of the weak Member States in economic crisis in particular. Today we have an admission from the protagonists, including the absent Mr Dijsselbloem, that mistakes have been made. Who made the mistakes? They became one of the protagonists. Deposits in Cyprus have been cut, people are getting poverty, Greece is going through an unprecedented economic crisis. I would like to say one last word about the rules: common rules are not an end in themselves, the aim is the convergence of our economies.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A gold-backed currency enjoys confidence because the banknotes circulating can be redeemed for gold at any time. In the case of a paper currency such as the one we have, the citizens must trust the Central Bank, which is responsible for that currency. What can citizens in the eurozone trust? On Mario Draghi and his team? Mario Draghi inflates the ECB's balance sheet. He prints money to buy government bonds. He says he wants to fight deflation. We do not have Europe-wide deflation, and there is no deflation. This is a pretext for monetary state financing. There is only one reason for inflation: financing the state budget through the press. Prices for real assets – equities and real estate – are still rising. This is a deliberate redistribution from poor to rich. Prices for private consumption goods will follow. Draghi handles dynamite. If it goes up , as I warn everyone – it will destroy the European Monetary Union.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that economic and monetary union has been strengthened by the last serious economic crisis compared with what we had in the past, but unfortunately it remains unfinished.  Despite the progress we have made and with regard to strengthening economic governance and also the start of the banking union, we still have a lot to do. Our commitment must be to achieve a Union capable of achieving greater growth, more employment and prosperity for all citizens, therefore without distinction of class, but at the same time it must also be founded on solid foundations in order to meet challenges not only internally, but also globally.  We must certainly be more competitive with the United States and China as well. I am well aware that employment and social developments have been examined in detail in country reports this year, addressing country-by-country recommendations, but I would like to reiterate the urgency and the need to improve the labour market and social performance, certainly in order to give confidence to all those young people who are still out of work and have a very high rate of youth unemployment.  Flexsecurity is certainly important, we must have flexible, reliable – not precarious – employment contracts that are a totally different issue, a favourable taxation of work, so that it naturally facilitates new recruitment, lifelong learning programmes and employment aid. I think that at the moment we must certainly be more operational from an employment point of view as well.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like first to thank Roberto Gualtieri for his topical contribution and I agree with him, but we still know that today technically the Eurogroup is not a formal entity within the EU. However, its impact and hard decisions are really heavy, especially for Member States in the special macroeconomic consolidation programme. It controls areas that do not belong to the full competence of the EU, such as taxation, budgetary policy, the public sector, employment, or even health policy regulations. In the case of Greece, for example, the Eurogroup replaces the European Semester, as you all know, and also the Stability and Growth Pact, by imposing hard rules through the blurred and questionable method of soft loan.  What is the limit of these hard policies created by the Eurogroup’s soft loan policy? Who sets the limits, and where and when are we going to discuss the content and also evaluate the effects of these policies? Shouldn’t the European Parliament have the answers? It seems that for the euro area to institutionalise its functioning within the European economic governance framework, the Council’s recommendation indeed makes an important step forward, but much more should be done in order to form the environment of legitimacy for the euro area’s economic decision-making, and this should be crystal clear. There is no path to recovery and macroeconomic policy without the political consent and transparency that only the European Parliament can provide.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Speaking in the debate on economic and monetary union, as a representative of a non-euro area country, I would like to express my doubt that, at a time of serious problems experienced by the economies of several countries in the euro area, the ambitious intentions of the so-called Five Presidents' Report can be pursued. I would like to take this opportunity to point out that the Countries of the Union using their own national currencies have been experiencing both higher levels of economic growth and, consequently, lower unemployment rates than most countries using the euro. It is sufficient for these countries to comply with the two main fiscal criteria of Maastricht – that is, a public finance deficit not exceeding 3% and public debt of 60%– which means the sustainability of their public finances and, consequently, stable economic growth and declining unemployment. I do not mind, of course, strengthening cooperation within the euro area, namely the creation of more union: financial, fiscal or finally political, but I do not think that they will solve the main problems faced by more and more euro area countries.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It must be pleased that further steps are taking to stabilise and develop, and with all the positive attitudes towards the document we are talking about, we must also talk about issues that raise doubts. Firstly, I would include such an unjustified belief in institutional solutions – as is the problem, it is necessary to create an institution, as there is already an institution, then the next one must be created. Here, too, we have a proposal to set up new institutions, such as the European Fiscal Council, but above all I have doubts about the proposal to set up national competitiveness councils. As for this, I am absolutely convinced that these will be completely fictitious bodies. The second point is the pace of change. It has been seven years since the outbreak of the crisis, and here the proposal concerns the prospect of as many as ten years in three stages. Today, it is difficult to plan even in a short period of time, let alone in a long time. Ten years to take important solutions is, in my opinion, too long. Thirdly, the largest, best guarantee of economic development and protection against crises is a sound and fair market. We, on the other hand, have a problem with the single common market, because it is infected with a virus of overregulation and protectionism. This is what we have to fight against, then it will be easier for us to create economic and monetary union as well.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the EU needs more economic growth and it needs to become more competitive. The recommendations made are balanced instruments. The euro area needs to get back on track economically. That means not just focusing on deficiencies in some smaller southern Member States, but also on larger Member States, where domestic demand needs to be stimulated. And yes, labour markets need reform, but reform in the right direction. It needs to be easier to hire people, not to fire them. The priority has to be to reduce the 25 million unemployed people in the EU, not to increase that number. Moreover, people need proper contracts and social protection, and not zero-hour contracts.  But what of the problems with these recommendations? They focus just on the euro area, but as a Union the EU is highly interdependent. We are 28 members in this club and we are all interlinked. Therefore, it is in all our interests to have a well-performing euro area. Deficits, excessive debt and imbalances all need to be properly tackled in a socially acceptable way. Representing the UK, our ties are close: 40% of our exports go to the euro area and major UK-owned banks have financial exposure to the euro area totalling almost twice their capital, worth a quarter of the UK’s GDP.  In a couple of days, the Council will be discussing the reforms on economic governance and competitiveness proposed by the British Prime Minister ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). Mr President, Economic and Monetary Union has gained a positive momentum and significant successes are already being recorded. After all, the crisis in the euro area began with fifteen countries in the euro and ended with nineteen countries in the euro. Strong support mechanisms have been set up for countries with specific or general problems in their economy, which are proving effective. Ireland has excellently completed its own programme, Spain has dealt with the crisis of the banks with help but without getting into a programme, Portugal and Cyprus have to show very positive results. So Greece's problems, which many cite, in a futile attempt to discredit the euro and the eurozone, are the exception, not the rule.  But even in Greece, where the forces of the Left have been so harshly critical of the eurozone and its operating rules, even there these same forces finally gave it their all and agreed to implement, when they became government, a much tougher adjustment programme than they used to denounce so that Greece could stay in the eurozone. This says it all about the stability and perspective of the euro area. We must therefore find the political courage to complete a difficult but necessary policy and to become more dynamic, fair and effective in its implementation. There's no other way.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we are in a debate on the euro area, which is at the same time a debate about your future project and also about the looming economic recovery. And it's true that we have to be clear.  Even today the euro area is seeing a slower and weaker recovery, for example than the European Union of the twenty-eight: we have fewer investments than our competitors in monetary areas elsewhere on the planet; our poverty remains undes diminished; we create employment levels, but the employment we create is still weak and, above all, precarious.  And, first of all, the question is: is the european Commission's answer to us — the report of the five presidents - sufficient to achieve the objective of achieving a stronger economic recovery and, above all, to create an optimal monetary zone, when we have a single market with twenty-eight fragmented labour markets, a monetary union with nineteen different fiscal policies and a political union without a common strong budget that strengthens it , what's the sorry? I don't think so.  Many things are missing from your proposal: we do not see anywhere the European minimum wage framework, which, for example, can prevent us from tackling wage devaluation again, which is generalising labour poverty in the European Union.  European automatic stabilisers are lacking, which must also serve us to deal with asymmetric shocks: European unemployment insurance, which this Eurochamber has so often claimed.  Debt mutualization is also lacking. We cannot live – neither the euro area nor the future project nor the economic recovery – only draghi and monetary policy.  We need more ambition from the European Commission and need more vision for the future to avoid future crises.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, let me start with the fact that the economic crisis highlighted a lot of gaps and problems in the architecture of monetary union, and we have been able to improve. We now have far better rules, better instruments and a better monetary union, and we should be proud of that. But what should we do now? Obviously, we have a very good agenda before us and I am supporting that, but at the same time we should not forget that most of the work needs to be done by the Member States. The Member States should continue with structural reforms to improve their competitiveness, because that is the only way to deal with the issue of unemployment, which is very critical in most of the Member States. At the same time, they should continue with responsible fiscal policy. There is no alternative to responsible fiscal policy, and these two goals do not exclude each other but, rather, are supportive. This is the only way to restore confidence – and I am talking about confidence among the Member States and the self-confidence of the eurozone. This is what we badly need in order to move forward. Member States ought to understand that, for the sake of a better future, they should be able to coordinate economic policies better and give up some economic sovereignty to make the eurozone more stable. I believe that the European Parliament can assist in this development and play an important role.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker has reminded us that we are experimenting with a better structuring of institutional relations with a view to the necessary reforms in the second phase of the five presidents' report.  In the meantime, I think it is clear that we need a better structure of institutional relations, and this debate shows that. I believe that the central point, which has also emerged from many critical debates and not just from positive debates, is that we need greater political responsibility and democratic legitimacy of the euro area and that we expect the Commission to tell us quickly what it thinks can be done immediately within the Treaty of Lisbon, within the existing Treaties and what needs to be done by appropriately amending the Treaties. , if necessary.  In my opinion, there are two economic points and one political one. The two economic points are: we need more investment and therefore we need instruments that will allow eurozone investment to be increased to at least the two thousand billion that are needed for the coming years; that is an estimate made by the Commission. The second is a social pact defining social rules within a highly integrated area such as the euro area. At institutional level, I believe that the debate should continue on political relations between the Commission and the European Parliament, the European Parliament and the national parliaments.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Thank you for the debate this morning. I think it is important that, far from crisis management, we address the issue of the further development of economic and monetary union. Any debate, however, must begin with an analysis of the status quo: where do we stand? Mr Dijsselbloem pointed it out this morning, including Mr Juncker: there are a number of measures, of the rules that we have adopted in recent months and years, which we have put in place. It is also important, and in the credibility and confidence in our economic and monetary union, that the measures and rules adopted are also consistently implemented. This is primarily a challenge for the Member States. Many colleagues have mentioned it. I share this view. It is primarily a question of structural reforms, of budgetary consolidation and debt reduction. We can develop what we want in Europe, at European level, if the homework is not done in the Member States, then we will not make any progress. I am also very confident, or I am pleased to have heard from President Juncker this morning, that we should make better use of existing instruments, make consistent use of them. So, thank God, he also made it clear that the six-pack and the two-pack will not be laced up, and I support that too. Finally, we are also discussing the communitarisation of deposit insurance. I think that is the wrong step at the moment. First, we have to implement the existing directive, make the Member States accountable, and then we can think about further steps.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE).
text: – A number of concerns have been raised today, but it is indeed worth remembering that for the third year in a row the European Union is actually on the path of economic recovery. We expect European gross domestic product to increase by 2% in 2016. Yes, the rates are still low, but the important thing is that we are moving towards growth. Partial consumption is also increasing, financing and employment are improving.  Perhaps it is time to recognise not only the problems and gaps, but also the successes of European economic governance. For example, the Juncker Plan is already in operation, mobilising over EUR 44 billion in additional funding for around 100 projects in 18 Member States.  Yesterday's Communication from the Commission on the European Structural and Investment Funds underlines that by 2023 EUR 637 billion of European and national co-financing will be invested through over 500 different programmes under the European Structural and Investment Funds. This is the place, and as my colleague Nibler mentioned, national responsibility. Member States must increase the use of financial instruments and make full use of synergies between the Structural Funds and efsi and other sources of funding, such as Horizon 2020 at project level, financial instrument level and through investment platforms. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of a strong currency in the European Union. Britain's desire for the European Union to be declared a multi-currency union can be used by a number of other member states, leading to the European Union being more fiscally uncertain and in an economic prospectus.

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE).
text: Madam President, Vice-President Dombrovskis, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work As we continue to develop economic and monetary union, it is clear to our group that any form of further development will only be a success if it is in line with the underlying foundation. Our foundation is the budgetary stability anchor, which is laid down in the Treaties, our foundation is the Stability and Growth Pact, which commits each member State, and thus every euro state, to sustainable economic policy. A view of the eurozone must not distract from the fact that Member States have lived beyond their means for years and must be liable for them.
