A view of the eurozone must clearly show that the path to greater competitiveness lies first and foremost with the responsibility of the individual states themselves. If the Commission uses the European Fiscal Council to disclose the shortcomings in the Member States, if the Commission ensures that the European Fiscal Council will operate independently, then it certainly has our support for it. And if the Commission addresses structural weaknesses in the Member States and strengthens the principle of liability, we also give our full support. And when the Commission criticises the reciprocal links between sovereign debt and banking risks, focusing on targeted measures to reduce risk and reduce debt, we are certainly on their side as well. However, we do not give support if efforts for greater convergence should distract from national responsibility. We do not support promoting economic policies for the euro area that provide the wrong incentives in the fiscal policies of the individual Member States, and we certainly do not give support if the communitarisation of risks outside the principle of liability is promoted. We call on the Commission, Mr Dombrovskis, to stick to what the founding fathers of economic and monetary union have given us: they have combined economic and monetary union with the promise of lasting stability. We all have a duty to keep this promise.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we want to strengthen the Monetary Union, but also to extend it to all Member States, as we do not aim to divide into the eurozone and others. This is why meeting the objectives of the Economic Union, which are convergence and social cohesion, is essential. All instruments must be put into the function of meeting the objectives of the Economic Union while strengthening the single market with a broader coverage of structural reforms and investments. We need to answer the question of how we see the future of cohesion policy, how to strengthen it and connect it more strongly with the objectives of the Economic Union. Likewise, how we see the future of the EU budget and the multiannual financial framework and how to better coordinate different European policies. Finally, we must not forget that the most important thing without which there is no convergence and sustainable economic growth relates to the partnership, unity and determination of Member States in implementing joint initiatives and changes.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we have witnessed today, from 9.00 a.m., almost four hours of debate here. It's an extremely important subject. Besides, what do we want with economic and monetary union? If we go back to what those who signed the treaty thought almost 23 years ago, we see that they are the three pillars: economic and monetary union is included in the first pillar.  Of course we need to look at both ourselves, Parliament and the Commission, responsibly and see if the measures that have been taken - the effects of the measures - are those expected by Europeans, by citizens. After all, it is the citizens who are looking at us if we have taken concrete action and we must say very objectively that, looking back, we see that there are very serious things that have happened that have not led to the resolution of expectations – if I am referring here to terrorism, drugs, organised crime, but also to economic and monetary union.  For me it is the clear answer, I do not know if and for the Commission. The Juncker Investment Plan must take into account poor areas and be allocated there, because we cannot talk about the union when there is no social cohesion.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, critics of the euro suggest that the euro is a political project and therefore cannot succeed. It's all a political project. And the European Union is a political project, a single market and a future common digital market, an energy market, it's all a political project. So is the Euro political project. Of course the euro originated in other conditions, in other economic conditions. It may be part of the idealism of the European Union, but that it is definitely necessary and that there is definitely no real alternative, because the alternative would only be chaos, that is clear to each of us here today. That is why I want to support the Commission and all the competent eurozone institutions that want to deepen and expand the euro to all Member States. I think it's extremely important for the future of our continent.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the euro has been a scam for the peoples of the South. If this is not recognized, if not analyzed and not evaluated, the consequences of the economic and monetary union they envisage will continue to widen inequalities and aggravate situations of poverty.  The President of the Eurogroup told us this morning, again, about structural reforms, pension reforms, labour reforms. We already know these proposals, and they have been nothing more than an extortion to the popular classes throughout the European Union and, above all, to the peoples of the South.  We would have liked Mr Juncker today to talk about how policies are going to be put in place to rescue people from poverty, how worthy employment will be recovered and generated, and how pay prices will be guaranteed for the peasantry, how small trade and small and medium-sized enterprises will be maintained and , also, how public education and health will be ensured.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is great to be taking part in this debate in the atmosphere we have now as opposed to four or five years ago. The feeling is that the recession is behind us, matters have stabilised and we are on an upward trajectory. Obviously to keep that going we have to complete the EMU, and the CMU and banking union are vital parts of that architecture. As has been mentioned, structural reforms at Member State level are also vital. In my own country, we were one of worst affected by the crisis: we had to enter a bailout; we had to take tough decisions; the government had to take a lot of criticism; and the Irish people had to make many sacrifices. But now we are, as a result, the fastest growing economy in Europe. So that means that it is important for every Member State to abide by the rules agreed and especially in relation to the Stability and Growth Pact. If one Member State gets away with breaking these rules again, the whole thing will unravel and we would be back to square one. So abiding by the rules and implementing them is vital.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D).
text: – Mr President, there has been an interesting debate here and only negative features have been expressed about economic and monetary union and the single currency in general. Perhaps I would also like to say that it has increased predictability, and in fact the public has benefited from record low interest rates. But there really is another side to this coin, and that is a more unfortunate side that has been the subject of much debate here. That weakness of economic and monetary union is actually our own fault. In banking regulation, we have gone for overly fragmented solutions. Fiscal policy is not going in the same direction and the structural problems of many countries are still a problem, so at the end of the day, it is a question of getting better from the euro with quite concrete and unanimous solutions after all.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank Members for this fruitful debate. While different views and opinions were expressed, I draw comfort from the fairly broad agreement on the need to strengthen Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). Completing the EMU institutional framework is one of the key issues the EU is facing today, and I believe that the other major challenges which have emerged makes this task even more – not less – urgent.  The Commission has proposed concrete steps and we value very highly the debates we have held on these matters with Parliament and the feedback we have received. As President Juncker has stressed, the Commission thinks that Parliament has a key role to play in ensuring the democratic legitimacy and accountability of economic governance. We need to build on the stronger involvement of Parliament, which has happened in recent years, for instance via the economic dialogue. The Commissioners concerned and I will continue to be available for discussions on economic matters. We are already listening to Members’ calls, for instance by giving more attention to the euro area dimension and to social considerations in the European Semester. We must work together to fine tune the best way forward.  I have also carefully taken note of Members’ remarks on the euro area recommendation. The views of Parliament on this recommendation are important and, in the Commission’s view, they should feed into the finalisation of the recommendation as it goes through the Council. Let me conclude by saying that I look forward to continuing to work together during the 2016 European Semester.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 December 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The completion of the Economic and Monetary Union should be of the highest priority in order to unleash the full potential of the single currency and structures and economic instruments at our command. The euro has already become a currency recognised and used worldwide. However, we still need to aim not only for a better representation of the euro in relation to monetary and banking union but also to reinforce the governance of the Eurozone – for this a genuine dialogue between the Member States and the European Parliament is the key.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to focus on two points. The first concerns investments which, as you know, are held back in the euro area by at least three factors: weak demand dynamics, debt accumulation and fragile private sector confidence. It is absolutely necessary for the eurozone, in addition to supporting demand, to address the issue of debt and fragile confidence. The European Central Bank must put in place monetary policy measures that can actually help support the economic recovery of the euro area.  The second point concerns a proposal recently adopted by the College of European Commissioners to review the approach to the European Semester and improve the economic governance of the euro area. Euro area Member States should have unified representation in international financial institutions, in particular in the International Monetary Fund. If every Member State of the euro area speaks for itself, or worse if they contradict each other, the eurozone will never have the weight that it should be given To complete economic and monetary union much depends on how it is implemented and whether the coordination mechanism will be created to prepare the unified positions that the President of the Eurogroup could and should present to the International Monetary Fund on behalf of all eurozone Member States.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The completion of Europe’s economic and monetary union raises a number of serious concerns and is a matter which all Member State governments should be very attentive to.  On a wide scale it is designed to undermine the principle of subsidiarity and to strip Member States of their decision-making competencies in key economic areas.  As part of this package, Member States are required to set up National Competitiveness Boards.  However, Competitiveness Boards are a dangerous solution addressing the wrong issue. With euro-area exports exceeding imports by more than 3% of GDP, the euro area is not suffering from a lack of competitiveness. The euro area’s main problem is the (private) debt overhang inherited from a financial market-driven boom that went bust. This cannot be addressed by trying to export our problems to the rest of the world. Squeezing wages will make matters worse by undermining internal demand and by triggering deflation. Meanwhile, export market gains will eventually be neutralised by currency appreciation or by weakening of the euro area’s trading partners’ economies. The focus on (cost) competitiveness is short-sighted. Establishing a system of Competitiveness Boards will contribute to further imbalances at the expense of social cohesion.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – Today's debate in the plenary session of the European Parliament on economic and monetary union highlights the gap between the various European leaders and the unpleasant reality. The architecture of the union has key deficits which some of the Member States do not want to admit and much more to deal with. Economic and monetary union without harmonisation of tax policies, such as that currently in force in the euro area, leads to transnational competition to attract businesses through preferential tax treatment and results in tax immunity of large multinational capital. A single currency without a pan-European deposit guarantee scheme, which is now proposed by the Commission but it is unknown when it can be implemented, means credit suffocation for the heavily indebted Mediterranean countries and the inability of their small and medium-sized enterprises in particular to survive, due to the resulting prohibitive borrowing costs for them. A single currency without a common border guarantee entails a long-term burden on public debt at unsustainable levels from extremely high defence spending for geopolitically exposed Member States such as Greece, which has faced a decades-long officially formulated war threat from its neighbour Turkey. Ostrichism must be stopped and these critical problems addressed if we are to save European unification.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: in writing. – Mr Dijsselbloem, where is the European deposit guarantee without which the Banking Union is incomplete, leaving the citizens unprotected – they who are called to pay ever more into State revenue, while multinationals and wealthy individuals park tax-evaded capital in tax havens with banks’ assistance? This is indeed a crisis of legitimacy, as President Juncker noted, so evident in the ongoing race into the bottom on tax dumping among Member States, aggravating tax injustice.  Look at my country, Portugal: a former Tax Authority director just stated that 1 000 of the wealthiest families who should pay for 25% of the national revenue in personal income tax actually only pay 0.5%. And that, under the Troika’s noses, the Tax Authority Unit set to make these families pay their dues was dismantled. Until the Commission and Council put into practice the measures recommended by our TAXE Committee, harmonise taxation and on that basis adopt a proper European Budget for relaunching investment and growth, the legitimacy crisis will only deepen, together with unemployment, stagnation and divergence in the Eurozone. Only the electoral scores of Le Pen and other xenophobic and anti-European forces will ominously grow!

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. – Firstly, the package proposed by the Commission does not leave enough room for parliamentary supervision and debate at European level. The Commission should launch negotiations for an interinstitutional agreement on European economic governance, including the European Semester, and the monitoring of the implementation of the macroeconomic adjustment programme with the European Parliament, the Council and the Eurogroup, as set out in the five-presidents' report. Secondly, we need to think about the future. The euro area will expand. It is important that the new Member States adhering to the euro area when their economy is ready to deal with the rigours and restrictions it entails.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – By deepening economic and monetary union, it is also within reach of the establishment of an EU budget council, the creation of a euro area treasury, i.e. the European IMF, and the creation of EU unemployment benefits. It has become clear to us that the deepening of the euro area has begun and is irreversible. Only national governments who want to stay outside the euro area by burying their heads in the sand on the grounds of a doubtful defence of sovereignty do not understand this. I am convinced that there is no alternative to the introduction of the euro in the short term.  Joining the euro area is in the interests of the Hungarian people, as the exchange rate risk is eliminated, hungarian bank deposits would be backed by a European guarantee, the Commission would put the Hungarian government, which squanders Hungarian taxpayers' money, and the National Bank, which can no longer be described as independent, on a short leash. Participating in the world's strongest economic cooperation cannot be a domestic political game or a prisoner of nationalist rhetoric. The later we join the euro area Member States, the harder it will be for us to fit in. Hungarian interests dictate the introduction of the euro as soon as possible, so that we are not permanently marginalised in the European Union.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. – While Europe has been able to bounce back from the economic bottom it was on until a few months ago, it must be added that an optimal solution has clearly not been found. At the moment, our continent is facing considerable social divergence and a very low rate of economic recovery. The situation is not helped by lagging domestic demand, which must be stimulated. European citizens deserve their representatives to take steps to reduce poverty and social inclusion. They also deserve to stimulate investment, including those in human capital and social investment. We must be able to fully exploit the potential offered to the European economy by the Juncker Plan. But the plan is currently off to a cumbersome start. The European Commission and the European Investment Bank, which are responsible for the European Fund for Strategic Investments, should reflect this and therefore try their best to communicate the fund's possibilities. Furthermore, it is important to stress that monetary policy is not a universal solution that Europe can apply to all its economic ills. Fiscal policy must also be involved and capacity created that works anti-cyclically. Furthermore, we must not forget that the completion of economic and monetary union is not just about the euro area. As all states have committed themselves to the adoption of the euro by the Access Treaty, with exceptions, the debate on reform needs to be shared with all members of the Union.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. "European roots are so deep that the European idea will survive all crises and revolutions," said Jean Monnet, one of the founding fathers of the European Union. We're sure that's right. And we want it to be. In our time, the European community is in the deepest crisis of the world after the world burns – and before a world burn not hoped for – and solutions are only visible in the medium term. We must choose between a separate position fuelled by national egotism and a two-speed Union on its heels, or closer integration along real, meaningful compromises.  The economic crisis and the financing problems that are straining Europe undoubtedly reassess the issue of the effectiveness of the euro area, but stability also requires stable positions. The two-speed Union, now increasingly organised by core countries calling for ever closer integration on economic and monetary issues, is Hungary without a single crisis. Of course, I cannot tolerate hungarians being marginalised. As a European Democrat, I support closer integration, but it would also be appropriate for the core countries to play more open cards about their own plans.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, it is a bit like in Paris. We were also delayed in connection with COP. In order to update the text – because you know that in Paris, one of the big achievements was to mention the 1.5°C limit – so we added at the end of the sentence: ‘below 2 degrees Celsius’ and ‘efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5 degrees Celsius’.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the incorporation of the Swiss Confederation into the EASO (European Asylum Support Office). This incorporation had been delayed due to new Swiss legislative measures thought to be in breach of the Geneva Convention. However, after the review of the legislation, it has been concluded that this is not the case and that Switzerland can access this institution, which has among its obligations to ensure compliance with international law in this area. We believe that coordination and support between different countries on asylum policy is essential in order to be able to better respond to the situation and that is why we are in favour of incorporation, as we demand that coordination be more effective and that human rights are actually ensured.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report plans to pass a Council decision to approve, on behalf of the European Union, the arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office I voted against this report because I am opposed to the existence of this office which removes its jurisdiction over asylum and immigration from States. States must be able to manage these issues on their own, especially in the current context.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report approves the Agreement between the European Union and Switzerland on the latter's participation in the European Asylum Support Office. In particular, Switzerland's full participation in the Agency's activities and its financial contribution according to its GDP are authorised. It is also envisaged that this contribution will be increased if this is deemed necessary. Since I believe that this agreement will strengthen the Agency's capabilities, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls on the Council to adopt a decision on behalf of the European Union that approves the arrangement between the Swiss Confederation and the European Union on the terms of Switzerland's participation in the European Asylum Support Office. We are against the existence of this office. We want to preserve the sovereignty of the Member States on immigration and asylum. However, Switzerland is an ally, especially on these issues. Is it therefore appropriate to refuse his request to join this office? I have chosen to vote in favour of this approval.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent with the principles of UKIP to vote against asylum matters being determined at European Union level, and therefore by extension to oppose this proposed agreement.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it concludes an arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. It seems natural to me for Switzerland, which is landlocked in The European territory, as well as for the European Union, to strengthen our cooperation on asylum. I would like to reiterate my personal conviction in favour of a European asylum law.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Agreement between the EU and the Swiss Confederation on its participation in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this little "arrangement" demanded by bureaucrats who want to impose their immigrationist lubies at all costs. Migration policy must remain a competence of our respective states: it is all the more necessary as the Commission wants to open the external borders of the European Union even more to the uninterrupted floods of so-called refugees.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The 2010 Regulation creating the European Asylum Support Office opens up the possibility of offering Iceland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Switzerland observer status through the conclusion of an ad hoc agreement. With this report, which I have approved, Parliament is giving a positive opinion on Switzerland's participation. This will result in full participation in the areas of ongoing assistance, information collection, alert system and Switzerland's contribution to the Agency's budget.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The European Asylum Support Agency (EASO) is a European Union agency operating since 2011. Its functions are: to promote cooperation between Member States in the field of asylum, to support Member States whose asylum and reception systems are subject to special pressures and to improve the implementation of the Common European Asylum System (SECA). Switzerland joined EASO as a partner country. We voted IN FAVOR.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This recommendation relates to an arrangement with the Swiss Confederation on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. The FN is basically opposed to this office because we believe that only the Member States have jurisdiction over asylum and immigration and that these policies are part of the loss of state sovereignty. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Switzerland has concluded an agreement with the EU to gain access to the European Asylum Support Office. I do not wish to oppose the agreement, but I do not agree with the management of the EU's migration policy, which is why I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I have supported this Resolution by which the European Parliament approves the Agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office, its representation and its financial contribution.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the conclusion of an Agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the conditions for Switzerland's participation in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it extremely important that there should be a balanced relationship on a contractual basis between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of the recommendation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. International cooperation in the field of security and data exchange between the EU and third countries is of paramount importance. As a member of the Schengen area, Switzerland plays a special role in these relations, and I therefore support the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and the Swiss Confederation on the details of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. I am convinced that this will further strengthen the already excellent cooperation in the area of internal affairs between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls on the European Council to adopt a decision to approve the arrangement between the European Union and Switzerland on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. We are by definition opposed to this Office which violates the sovereignty of Member States on asylum and immigration. It is not up to the European institutions to determine our migration policy because it is a jurisdiction that is rightfully the responsibility of the national authorities. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Asylum Support Office is a body aimed at strengthening asylum cooperation between Member States, strengthening the process of implementing the common European asylum system and providing support to Member States whose asylum and reception systems are under particular pressure. The European Asylum Support Office enjoys the contribution made by both Member States and some associated countries, in particular Switzerland, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway. Thus, the agreement with the Swiss Confederation developed in a natural way, given the openness that this Office manifests towards countries that have concluded agreements with the Union. The involvement of the Swiss Confederation in the work of the Bureau has a positive impact in terms of the support provided by this office, namely the exchange of best practices and expertise, the permanent and emergency assistance provided by the Support Office, the collection and analysis of information by the Support Office and the early warning and training system of the Support Office, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this agreement.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Switzerland wants to be part of the European Asylum Support Office. The Swiss Government approves the conclusion of the agreement and, however much we do not agree with the management of migration at European level and of the EU asylum support office, we advise against this agreement while respecting the sovereign will of a third state (our neighbour) to be part of this mechanism. That is why I abstained.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office, because the path taken in 2010 with the adoption of Regulation (EU) No 439/2010 establishing the European Asylum Support Office must be continued. We are called upon to improve the implementation of the common European asylum system, in order to strengthen cooperation and help Member States to cope with crisis situations, and the accession of the Swiss Confederation is heading in this direction, especially in order to encourage the exchange and sharing of good practice.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This agreement’s intention is to enable Switzerland to contribute to and participate in the European Asylum Support Office. Therefore, its aim is also to allow Swiss nationals to work with the European Asylum Support Office. As this is a positive and progressive move, I voted in favour of this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP fundamentally opposes any attempt by the EU to determine the UK’s immigration policy. This would include involving Switzerland in the process. We note that the Swiss people are much more Eurosceptic than their political class, and suspect this agreement may have something to do with this.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the approval of an agreement between the EU and Switzerland which essentially provides for Switzerland's participation in the activities of EASO, representation on the Board of Directors with observer status and the provision of annual financial contributions from Switzerland to the EASO budget. I voted in favour without any doubt.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the draft Council decision on the arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the arrangements for its participation in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The arrangement with the Swiss Confederation on the arrangements for its participation in the European Asylum Support Office is a positive cooperation process that serves the overall objective of proper functioning of all European States. As it concerns asylum issues and provides for cooperation with EASO, it is obvious that it must be welcomed by the European Parliament. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement with the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office. The agreement will make it possible to formalise existing cooperation with Switzerland.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation because I believe that greater integration of Switzerland into European affairs is, over and above the rhetoric of Swiss political announcements, an added value. This agreement responds to the principle of 'Clear pacts, long friendship' and, in everyone's interest, I am pleased to have voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Switzerland has agreed to participate voluntarily in the EU resettlement and both the EU relocation programmes. So far Switzerland informally participates in EASO activities. Putting in place this working arrangement will allow both EASO and Switzerland to formalise the collaboration. I am in favour of this.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Swiss Federation has an extensive set of agreements with the European Union, in particular with regard to the internal market, but beyond this area. In this sense, Switzerland has offered to take part in the European Union's refugee resettlement effort. To this end, it has so far cooperated informally with the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). This agreement, to which Parliament now gives its consent, will formalise this cooperation.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with what was said in the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – Switzerland has agreed to participate voluntarily in the EU resettlement and both the EU relocation programmes. So far Switzerland informally participates in EASO activities; putting in place this working arrangement will allow both EASO and Switzerland to formalise the collaboration. This agreement was postponed after the results of the referendum in Switzerland. The Arrangement should now be approved on behalf of the EU, thus I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are still many EU Member States that cannot rely on a political asylum and reception mechanism adapted to the emergency situation that we have been experiencing for months. The European Asylum Support Office (EASO) was established by Regulation (EU) No 439/2010 to strengthen cooperation between states on political asylum. The aim of the resolution before us is to support Those Member States that are under great pressure on this issue. In fact, with this resolution, the Council approves the agreement on Switzerland's accession to EASO, with the aim of having full state participation in the work of EASO. As I believe that it is essential for the EU to maintain a cohesive position on the issue of asylum and support for states, I am voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the incorporation of the Swiss Confederation into the EASO (European Asylum Support Office). This incorporation had been delayed due to new Swiss legislative measures thought to be in breach of the Geneva Convention. However, after the review of the legislation, it has been concluded that this is not the case and that Switzerland can access this institution, which has among its obligations to ensure compliance with international law in this area. We believe that coordination and support between different countries on asylum policy is essential in order to be able to better respond to the situation and that is why we are in favour of incorporation, as we demand that coordination be more effective and that human rights are actually ensured.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Regulation establishing the European Asylum Support Office stipulates that "in order to achieve its objective, it is necessary that the Support Office be open to the participation of the countries which have concluded an agreement with the European Union on the basis of which Union law has been adopted and applied in the field covered by this Regulation." Such countries include Switzerland. The Regulation also regulates the need to provide for agreements between these countries on the nature, extent and manner of their participation in the work of the Office. Under the draft agreement, Switzerland will now participate fully in the work of the Support Office and shall be entitled to receive assistance from the Support Office, as described in the Regulation and in accordance with the conditions laid down in this Agreement. Until now, Switzerland has only voluntarily participated in the Agency's resettlement programme. The current agreement will provide an appropriate framework for cooperation. For this agreement to be reached, the European Parliament must give its consent, which was done with today's vote.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, whose purpose is to conclude the arrangement with Switzerland on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. The proposal provides for Switzerland’ full participation in the activities of the Support Office and representation in its Management Board as an observer, without voting rights. It will also result in an annual financial contribution from Switzerland to the budget of the Support Office.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ During this time of crisis it is especially important that we work together with our partners to solve Europe’s migration problems, so I welcome this cooperation agreement with Switzerland. Switzerland already participates in the Dublin Regulation so by allowing Switzerland to participate formally in the European Asylum Support Office we enable them to offer much-needed expertise and assistance in order to ensure that the Dublin Regulation continues to operate effectively in Europe. The long—term effective operation of the Dublin Regulation is something that we in the UK have very much prioritised in the area of asylum and migration.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This non-legislative report proposes the opinion of the European Parliament on the conclusion by the European Union of an agreement between the Union and the Swiss Confederation on how the latter will participate in the European Asylum Support Office. Switzerland has already expressed its willingness to participate in European programmes to reallocation of asylum seekers by cooperating informally with EASO. The draft decision aims to formalize this collaboration and was postponed following the attacks in Paris on 13 November. Supporting the objectives of this report, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fundamentally opposes any attempt by the EU to determine the UK’s immigration policy. This would include involving Switzerland in the process. We note that the Swiss people are much more Eurosceptic than their political class, and suspect this agreement may have something to do with this.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to strengthen practical cooperation between Switzerland and the EU Member States on asylum policy issues. Switzerland's participation as an observer member and financial contributor adds value to the activities of the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Asylum Support Office (EASO) plays a fundamental role in the establishment of the common European asylum system and supports EU Member States whose asylum arrangements and reception capacities are under particular pressure. This is the case with the refugee crisis we are experiencing today. Its regulation provides that the four states associated with the Dublin collaboration can take part in the activities of the Support Office.  I am pleased that Switzerland wishes to continue this collaboration and I have therefore voted in favour of the resolution giving the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the terms of its participation in EASO.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aimed to integrate Switzerland into the European Asylum Office. Although these supranational structures are, in my view, totally illegitimate, the Swiss Confederation is a friendly country. Thus, I was rather predisposed to vote against this report advocating the enlargement of a body that was supposed to decide on regal policies. However, this report de facto argues for a greater role for Switzerland, of which we support most of the reasoned policies on the right to asylum. So I voted for this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Switzerland is not an EU member state, but has nevertheless decided to join the european asylum support office and contribute to funding, additional staff and the acceptance of a quota of 1,500 refugees. Although I am against the quota distribution of refugees, I support the idea that a country should have the opportunity and sovereign right to choose for itself whether or not to join it.  I supported the report "The arrangement with the Swiss Confederation on the terms and conditions for its participation in the European Asylum Support Office" precisely because it is an expression of a sovereign decision taken by Switzerland to participate in European refugee displacement policy.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Asylum Support Office strengthens the practical cooperation of Member States on asylum issues, promotes the implementation of the common European asylum system and offers support to Member States whose asylum and reception systems are under particular pressure. In particular, the financial contribution of the 'associated countries' and their participation in the work of the Office, given their connection to the Dublin system, would only be of particular added value if the Schengen and Dublin Treaties were to operate in the protection of the economic interests of the citizens of the EU States, their security and the values of the member states.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because I want more cooperation with Switzerland.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation deals with a draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office (EAsA), and essentially aims to enable Switzerland to participate in and receive support from the EAsA, as well as the possibility of having an observer on the board of directors of the EAsa. The situation of refugees who have been relocated to Europe in recent months raises serious humanitarian concerns. The high number of refugees arriving requires the creation of conditions of assistance and reception, which are far from guaranteed. Contrary. The European Union has not been up to the problem, so little of the responsibility it has and is at the origin of this scourge. The establishment of this agreement may be positive, but it is only a drop in an immense ocean of problems that need to be addressed to ensure effective protection and reception for the thousands of refugees - children and adults - who arrive every day fleeing war and persecution in their countries of origin.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure as it strengthens cooperation with countries such as Switzerland and is now a key element in managing the current migration crisis.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Voted in  favour as it is a positive move for human rights.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main reason for this proposal is to conclude an arrangement with Switzerland on the conditions for its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. This agreement in question may be concluded only after the consent of the European Parliament has been given. The main provisions of the Agreement include the full participation of Switzerland in the activities of the Support Office, representation on the Management Board of the Support Office as an observer and without the right to vote, and Swiss contributions to the EASO budget in accordance with its GDP.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am not opposed to the Swiss Government's desire to be part of the Eu ropean Union asylum support office, but I do not agree with migration management at European level and will therefore abstain in the vote.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Asylum Support Office strengthens the practical cooperation of Member States on asylum issues, promotes the implementation of the common European asylum system and offers support to Member States whose asylum and reception systems are under particular pressure. In particular, the financial contribution of the 'associated countries' and their participation in the work of the Office, given their connection to the Dublin system, would only be of particular added value if the Schengen and Dublin Treaties functioned in the protection of the economic interests of the citizens of the EU Member States, their security and the values of the Member States. For these reasons, I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the arrangements for its participation in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this proposal is to conclude the arrangement with Switzerland on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). The main provisions of the arrangement foresee the full participation of Switzerland in the activities of the Support Office, representation in the Support Office’s Management Board as an observer and without voting rights, and annual financial contributions by Switzerland to the budget of the Support Office by an annual sum calculated, in accordance with its GDP, as a percentage of the GDP of all States participating in the Support Office’s work. Switzerland accepted provisions concerning a possible increased contribution if the Union contribution is increased. I support the adoption of the report, since I believe that Member States must cooperate more closely on asylum matters.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the agreement bearing in mind the importance of international collaboration in support of the asylum seeker, as well as for Switzerland's contribution to its protection in collaboration with the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agreed with the structure of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office, because cooperation and cooperation between Member States and non-EU countries in managing the refugee crisis is a priority for me. Indeed, I believe that the Council's decision to allow Switzerland to be part of the European Asylum Support Office is a step in the right direction if we consider switzerland's importance for the difficult management of migratory flows, given that it is a country directly bordering many Member States. Switzerland's membership of EASO will therefore make it possible to involve switzerland fully in all those actions and actions that may be necessary should the situation worsen and opens the way to even more important cooperation in other areas, I am thinking of the exchange of information and the fight against terrorism, which is necessary for the effective management of all the challenges facing the EU in this area. In this respect, I also consider it important to make the financial commitment to support EASO that Switzerland undertakes to make.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. So far, the swiss Confederation's participation has been based on informal and voluntary participation in the European distribution of asylum seekers. This will now also be formally defined. A further step towards a European solution, which I very much welcome.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office given close practical cooperation on asylum matters is of paramount importance.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The European Asylum Support Agency (EASO) is a European Union agency operating since 2011. Its functions are: to promote cooperation between Member States in the field of asylum, to support Member States whose asylum and reception systems are subject to special pressures and to improve the implementation of the Common European Asylum System (SECA). Switzerland joined EASO as a partner country. We voted IN FAVOR.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, whose purpose is to conclude the arrangement with Switzerland on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. The proposal provides for Switzerland’s full participation in the activities of the Support Office and representation in its Management Board as an observer, without voting rights. It will also result in an annual financial contribution from Switzerland to the budget of the Support Office.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office, because it will give the consent to the conclusion of the Arrangement, which I support.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report because the participation of Switzerland and other countries in asylum cooperation, at a time of an expanded humanitarian crisis, is absolutely essential. The report concerns the technical ways in which Switzerland will participate in EASO's work and how EASO will support Switzerland. Switzerland will have an observer on the board (but will not be a full member).

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote for this report. Switzerland has already agreed to participate voluntarily in the EU resettlement programme and both the EU relocation programmes. Switzerland informally participates in European Asylum Support Office (EASO) activities, so putting in place this working arrangement will allow the EASO and Switzerland to formalise their collaboration. It is an important step forward in helping with the resettlement and relocation of dispersed people in the European geographical region.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. In 2010, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) was set up. The objectives of this office are to strengthen practical cooperation between EU Member States in the field of asylum and to help individual states to address acute migration challenges. At the time of its foundation, the inclusion of other European countries such as Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland was envisaged. Negotiations with these four countries have accordingly begun. The present case is about involving Switzerland in the work of EASO after the negotiations between the EU and Switzerland have been concluded. The report recommends the inclusion of Switzerland. I have only voted in favour of the report, just because Switzerland has taken a largely sensible approach to addressing asylum and migration challenges in recent years. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the adoption of the report by my Maltese colleague, Roberta Metsola, on the arrangement with the Swiss Confederation on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. Although Switzerland is not part of the European Union, it is a signatory to the Schengen Convention and adheres, as such, to the principle of free movement. As a result, it is also affected by the migration crisis, being in the immediate vicinity of two countries particularly affected by the flows, Germany and Italy. For this reason, the Asylum Support Office allows the participation, as observers, of Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland who are indirectly involved in European asylum decisions.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion that will set out preparations for the Swiss Confederation regarding the modalities for its participation in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation and its participation in the European Asylum Support Office, as this gives consent for the conclusion of that agreement. In my view, it is of utmost importance to strengthen the cooperation between the European Union and third countries in this area and to enable such situations to be overcome.  The refugee crisis has shown that such a thing is crucial and that it is essential to ensure the exchange of good bangs and information, to encourage training and training, to effectively coordinate emergency assistance and to provide support in building the capacity of reception facilities and asylum systems. I also believe that strong cooperation and synergies are needed and that Switzerland plays an important role in this context. Therefore, I support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls on the Council to adopt a decision to approve, on behalf of the European Union, the arrangement between the Swiss Confederation and the European Union on the modalities of Switzerland's participation in the European Asylum Support Office. We are against the existence of the European Asylum Support Office because we want to preserve the sovereignty of Member States on immigration and asylum. However, Switzerland is an ally, especially on these issues.  Is it therefore appropriate to refuse his application to participate in the European Asylum Support Office? Our ENL group is divided on this proposal: Harald Vilimsky and Vicky Maeijer voted against, Lorenzo Fontana voted in favour. I'm voting for.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I fundamentally oppose any attempt by the EU to determine the UK’s immigration policy. This would include involving Switzerland in the process. We note that the Swiss people are much more Eurosceptic than their political class, and suspect this agreement may have something to do with this.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's recommendation on the Council decision on the conclusion of the Arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the rules for the participation of the Swiss Confederation in the work of the European Asylum Support Office has received my support, as strengthening international cooperation between all European countries in times of unprecedented refugee crisis is an indispensable part of addressing the current situation.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Roberta Metsola's report on the recommendation on the arrangement with Switzerland on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. Since the country was already informally involved in the work of the Office, this text aims to clarify the scope and modalities of this collaboration.  This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to this report because of fundamental differences in the view of this issue.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is simply ratifying an agreement with Switzerland on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. In 2010, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) was set up. The objectives of this office are to strengthen practical cooperation between EU Member States in the field of asylum and to help individual states to address acute migration challenges. At the time of its foundation, the inclusion of other European countries such as Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland was envisaged. Negotiations with these four countries have accordingly begun. The present case is about involving Switzerland in the work of EASO after the negotiations between the EU and Switzerland have been concluded. The report recommends the inclusion of Switzerland. I have only voted in favour of the report, just because Switzerland has taken a largely sensible approach to addressing asylum and migration challenges in recent years.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of Mrs Metsola's recommendation on the agreement with the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office. I have decided to give my favourable opinion because I am sure that it will make it possible to formalise and further consolidate the existing cooperation and to improve the management of asylum applications at a sensitive time such as the one we are experiencing.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. National Front MEPs voted against the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office.  This vote is by no means directed against Switzerland, a friendly country which we respect very much. The European Asylum Support Office is part of the European Union's so-called asylum and immigration acquis. However, the common asylum and immigration policy has failed catastrophically.  That is why we must give that jurisdiction back to the Member States. They must once again be able to control their borders and decide who they allow access to the territory, and under what conditions.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MEPs voted against this "arrangement" because they are against the existence of this European Asylum Support Office. States should be the only ones responsible for asylum and immigration.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. By this Resolution, the European Parliament grants its approval to the conclusion of this agreement and requests that the President forward the decision to the Council, the Commission, the European Asylum Support Office and the governments and parliaments of the Member States and Switzerland.  This decision is taken taking into account the draft Council Decision, the draft agreement between the parties on the modalities of Swiss participation in the European Asylum Support Office, the application for approval submitted by the Council in accordance with the relevant articles of the EU Operating Treaty, and the LIBE Commission Recommendation.  As beneficial as such an agreement will be for both sides, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a recommendation calling on the Council to adopt the decision to conclude an agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). The Commission's proposal concerns cooperation with the Swiss Confederation in the context of information exchanges and best bangs and assistance in the work, analysis and readiness of the Asylum Support Office. A special committee is envisaged to be set up in which non-Union member states will also participate and each will contribute financially in line with its GDP. Although Switzerland is not a member of the European Union, so it is not obliged to participate in a realistic strategy, I think that the moment in which we are facing a refugee wave, threats of terrorism and conflicts in the neighbourhood is the time to work together.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Asylum Support Office was established in 2010 with the aim of promoting an effective, comprehensive and inter-transnational cooperation-oriented policy, along with relevant actions at European Union level. Close cooperation takes place with EU agencies such as Frontex, Europol and Eurojust. Assistance to asylum seekers and the fight against smugglers and illegal immigration are key aspects of the functioning of the EASO. The EASO cannot, however, be limited to EU Member States: close cooperation must also take place with our neighbours and other partners. Switzerland is one of the direct parties, putting out a number of factors – historical, purely geographical, political, economic, .c. Cooperation with it takes place in all areas and is only expanding over time. It is therefore perfectly logical that cooperation with Switzerland could and will include not only simple bilateral cooperation, but also a much closer and fully integrated participation of the Alpine republic in the activities of the EASO.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In May 2010, the European Asylum Support Office was established by regulation of the EP and the Council. Through measures, it applies a common European asylum system and coordination of asylum policy both inside and outside the EU. Its role is important precisely in the current migration crisis. In February 2014, a number of agreements were signed with non-member states (the Principality of Liechtenstein, the Republic of Iceland, the Kingdom of Norway and the Swiss Confederation) agreeing on the forms of their participation in the European Asylum Support Office.  With the EP resolution, we agreed to the AGREEMENT concluded between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the arrangements for its participation in the European Asylum Support Office, because it is complete and documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to vote in favour of giving consent to the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this proposal. The European Asylum Support Office (EASO), as its name suggests, supports Member States and helps them achieve their asylum targets. An arrangement will be drawn up between the EU and Switzerland regarding Switzerland's participation in the Office. The purpose of this proposal is to enable the Council to approve this arrangement on behalf of the EU.  We are against the very existence of this Office. The management of the issue of asylum and migrants should be an exclusive competence of the Member States. We strongly oppose this being managed by the EU.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office.  The Aim of the European Asylum Support Office is to strengthen cooperation between Member States and thus help them to deal with crisis situations, stimulating cooperation between states in the field of asylum, helping states whose asylum and reception systems are under particular pressure and improving the implementation of the common asylum system. In order to carry out its tasks, the European Asylum Support Office must be open to the participation of countries that have concluded agreements with the EU, such as Switzerland.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament gives its favourable opinion on the conclusion of the agreement with the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office. I am voting in favour of the proposal, considering that this agreement will make it possible to formalise existing cooperation.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My support for the decision to conclude an agreement with the Swiss Confederation on the modalities for its participation in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The European Asylum Support Office is an administrative apparatus which has not yet been the source of a successful initiative. It entails high costs, with no apparent benefit. Switzerland's participation will not change this. On the contrary, it seems to be a decision against the Swiss people, because Switzerland has to participate with funds, but does not have the right to vote on the Board of Directors of the Support Office. I therefore reject this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am supportive of Switzerland voluntarily participating in the EU resettlement and EU relocation programme.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This decision is intended to allow Switzerland, which is not a member of the EU, to participate in the activities of the European Asylum Support Office and its budget.  Unlike other associated states such as Norway, the agreement was put on hold by the European Parliament following the February 2014 Swiss referendum to limit the free movement of EU citizens. Switzerland was finally forced to abandon this measure at the risk of not being able to participate in other EU programmes, such as Horizon 2020 but also Erasmus. The ruling right also had no interest in ignoring more than a million European residents and workers on its soil.  This office coordinates ongoing assistance and the exchange of data and best practices on the reception of refugees. It therefore has a clear mandate to ensure a safe reception of refugees in Europe.  I vote to remind people that refugees and asylum seekers have internationally recognised rights and more broadly denounce that only a quarter of applications are accepted within European states.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls on the Council to adopt a decision to approve, on behalf of the European Union, the arrangement between the Swiss Confederation and the European Union on the modalities of Switzerland's participation in the European Asylum Support Office. We are against the existence of the European Asylum Support Office because we want to preserve the sovereignty of Member States on immigration and asylum. However, Switzerland is an ally, especially on these issues. Is it therefore appropriate to refuse his application to participate in the European Asylum Support Office? I'm voting for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of their participation in the European Asylum Support Office. The European Asylum Support Office has been an AGENCY of the European Union in operation since 2011. It is to increase cooperation between Member States on asylum and to support Member States whose asylum and reception systems are particularly under pressure. Switzerland is a member country.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This recommendation was aimed at strengthening the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and allowing formal cooperation between the Agency and Switzerland. As rapporteur for the report I was happy to show my support.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent on the Arrangement with the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. The purpose of this proposal is to conclude the arrangement with Switzerland on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). This will enhance practical cooperation between Member States and Switzerland on asylum matters and in the current crisis it is an important priority for Member States to cooperate more closely on asylum matters.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 At the negotiations between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation, the parties reached agreement on detailed rules for Switzerland's participation in the European Asylum Support Office. The draft agreement was approved by the Council and requested Parliament's consent in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. In its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended that Parliament agree with the draft agreement. I voted accordingly on the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 439/2010 established the European Asylum Support Office with the aim of strengthening practical cooperation between Member States on asylum and strengthening the implementation of the Common European Asylum System. In view of the above in the report, on the way Switzerland participates in the European Asylum Support Office, I am in favour of concluding this Agreement.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Roberta Metsola report aims to urge the Council to adopt a decision approving, on behalf of the EU, the conclusion of an arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss confederation on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office.  Although against the existence of this European Asylum Support Office because I believe that immigration and asylum policy is the exclusive competence of the Member States, and therefore the EU should not get involved, Switzerland being a country whose democratic life and concern for sovereignty can be envyed, it would be perfectly normal to accede to its request for participation in this Office.  So I decided to vote for this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which ratifies the EU agreement with the Swiss Federation which allows Switzerland to participate in EASO’s work as well as receive support from EASO. In addition, Switzerland will also be represented in the EASO management board as observers.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the modalities of the Swiss Confederation's participation in the European Asylum Support Office. Like Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway, Switzerland can participate in the work of this support office as an observer country. I approved the Council's plan to define the nature and extent of this participation.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Through this report, the European Parliament gives its favourable opinion on the conclusion of an agreement with the Swiss Confederation, which concerns how the Swiss Confederation should participate in the European Asylum Support Office. In view of the fact that this agreement will make it possible to formalise existing cooperation, I have decided to support the document with my vote in favour.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Perhaps the biggest challenge facing the European Union so far is the ongoing migrant crisis. As the crisis has developd, the role of the European Asylum Support Office has increased. The primary objective of the Office is to strengthen cooperation between Member States and to support countries under particular pressure.  I believe that the Agency can only gain by working with Switzerland, since, like experience in gathering and analysing information, the sharing of established practices and expertise can greatly facilitate the office's effective work. That is why I support the conclusion of the convention.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Through its bilateral treaties with the European Union the Swiss Confederation has adopted various provisions of European Union law in order to participate in the Union’s single market. I have voted for this recommendation on the draft Council decision that will define the modalities of the Swiss Confederation’s participation in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Switzerland's participation in the European Asylum Support Office will help Member States to bear the burden of asylum seekers, exchange the necessary information and provide assistance in crisis situations.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fundamentally opposes any attempt by the EU to determine the UK’s immigration policy. This would include involving Switzerland in the process. We note that the Swiss people are much more Eurosceptic than their political class, and suspect this agreement may have something to do with this.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is necessary to define the modalities for the participation of the Swiss Confederation in the European Asylum Support Office and i have therefore decided to vote in favour of the conclusion of the agreement to regulate these aspects.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the conclusion of an agreement with the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office. This step forward by Switzerland, which is not a member of the European Union but which shows a willingness to accept responsibility for tackling the large influx of refugees from war-affected areas, is an example to all European countries of how they should behave in difficult times.  The intentions of the Swiss authorities to participate in this programme give hope that the spirit of European communion and solidarity exists. In difficult times, Europe has always shown its humane side, but we need new solidarity towards the victims. Switzerland's well-regulated social services system will give refugees the opportunity to achieve a dignified life in the freedom and fullness of human rights. I support the Swiss initiative and its willingness to participate and hope that other non-EU countries will follow its example and act together to facilitate the situation on the ground.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Roberta Metsola report calls on the Council to adopt a decision approving, on behalf of the EU, the conclusion of an arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. Although I am opposed to the existence of this European Asylum Support Office (because I believe that immigration and asylum policy is the exclusive competence of the Member States and that, therefore, the EU should not get involved), I consider that Switzerland is a country whose democratic life and concern for sovereignty can be envyed and that it would be perfectly normal to accede to its request for participation. So I decided to vote for this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Council's draft decision to conclude an agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office. At a time when we are facing an increasing number of refugees and migrants and are still trying to find a common response at European Union level, any additional cooperation and contribution is welcome, especially when it comes to a country that is territorially surrounded by member states of the European Union and cooperates with the Union as a whole on a number of other issues and competences.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider Switzerland's full involvement in the work of the European Asylum Support Office to be very beneficial, especially in the light of the current situation. Moreover, Switzerland's involvement is certainly a logical step in the context of Switzerland being associated with the so-called Dublin system. I welcome the fact that Switzerland will be able to contribute with its expertise and many years of experience in this area. Switzerland will, by signing the Agreement, participate fully in the Office's activities since its entry into force, be represented in the Governing Structures of the Office and provide an annual contribution to the Office's budget (a contribution calculated on the basis of the country's GDP).

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Asylum Support Office (EASO) was set up with the task of strengthening practical cooperation between Member States in the field of asylum and supporting countries whose asylum and reception systems are under great pressure. The agreement, on which the European Parliament has been asked for approval, provides for Switzerland's full participation in EASO's activities, in this way formalising existing cooperation. Switzerland will be able to participate in the Management Board of the European Asylum Support Office as an observer and without the right to vote. In addition, the Swiss Confederation will be required to make annual financial contributions to the EASO budget with an amount calculated on the basis of GDP. I voted in favour of approving this agreement with the aim of making our continent's asylum system more efficient.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Switzerland's support for the European Asylum Support Office is another step forward in our approach to migration policy. The influx of recent months knows no borders, and we must share our thoughts and tools.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 439/2010 has set up a European Asylum Support Office in order to strengthen cooperation between Member States in this area, improve the implementation of the Common European Asylum System and help Member States whose asylum systems are under the greatest pressure. Under these Regulations, it is admitted that the Office may be open to the participation of the designated associated countries (Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland) and, to that end, arrangements specifying the nature, scope and their forms of participation in the work should be concluded.
