Having taken this framework in mind, the Commission received, on 27 January 2012, authorisation from the Council to open the corresponding negotiations with those countries, and in this sequence the final text of the agreement with Switzerland was initialled on 28 June 2013.   Since the participation of these countries in the work of the Cabinet is not only a logical step, given their association with the Dublin system, but also has added value for the support provided by the Office, I voted in favour of concluding the Agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of their participation in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP fundamentally opposes any attempt by the EU to determine the UK’s immigration policy. This would include involving Switzerland in the process. We note that the Swiss people are much more Eurosceptic than their political class, and suspect this agreement may have something to do with this.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft resolution which, in view of the draft arrangement already in place between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office, gives its approval to the conclusion of the arrangement.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Switzerland has voluntarily decided to participate in the work of the Office of Asylum and European Support - a Cabinet which has strongly strengthened cooperation between Member States on asylum and reception policy and has unfortunately not yet formalised its participation in it. Following the results of last year's referendum, Switzerland decided to suspend the procedures leading to its formal participation in the cabinet (switzerland currently has observer status), and this recommendation from the European Parliament - which voted in favour, approves the Council's decision and invites the parties involved - in particular the Swiss Confederation, to conclude this procedure (initiated on 28 June 2013 , i.e. two and a half years ago).

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The European Asylum Support Agency (EASO) is a European Union agency operating since 2011. Its functions are: to promote cooperation between Member States in the field of asylum, to support Member States whose asylum and reception systems are subject to special pressures and to improve the implementation of the Common European Asylum System (SECA). Switzerland joined EASO as a partner country. We voted IN FAVOR.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the incorporation of the Swiss Confederation into the EASO (European Asylum Support Office). This incorporation had been delayed due to new Swiss legislative measures thought to be in breach of the Geneva Convention. However, after the review of the legislation, it has been concluded that this is not the case and that Switzerland can access this institution, which has among its obligations to ensure compliance with international law in this area. We believe that coordination and support between different countries on asylum policy is essential in order to be able to better respond to the situation and that is why we are in favour of incorporation, as we demand that coordination be more effective and that human rights are actually ensured.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement with the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) because I believe that it helps to strengthen cooperation between all the countries of European territory in order to better manage the migration crisis that we are experiencing.  Switzerland has so far been informally involved in the work of EASO, but this agreement will clarify the nature and scope of the cooperation instruments through which switzerland can participate in the work of the European Office.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in any asylum policy so I voted against this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ At a time when thousands of people are seeking asylum in Europe, a coordinated asylum policy is crucial. It is a priority that Member States cooperate more closely on asylum matters, and this must include cooperation with Switzerland. The proposal can only be concluded once the European Parliament gives its consent to the agreement. For this reason I feel it is only right to vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The conclusion of an agreement on Swiss participation in the common asylum system comes at a time when member states' asylum capacities are under particular pressure. The main objective of the European Asylum Support Office is to ease this onslaught. I therefore support this agreement, which sets out the ways in which Switzerland will be involved in the activities of the European Asylum Support Office.  Switzerland shall be fully involved in the activities of the Office shall be represented on its Management Board as an observer without voting rights and shall also contribute a pro rata amount to the Budget of the Office. This means that Switzerland will actively cooperate with other Member States in practical and operational matters in assessing asylum applications and in receiving applicants. Information exchange and mutual assistance are the best ways to cope with the current challenges of the migration wave.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. In 2010, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) was set up. The objectives of this office are to strengthen practical cooperation between EU Member States in the field of asylum and to help individual states to address acute migration challenges. At the time of its foundation, the inclusion of other European countries such as Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland was envisaged. Negotiations with these four countries have accordingly begun. The present case is about involving Switzerland in the work of EASO after the negotiations between the EU and Switzerland have been concluded. The report recommends the inclusion of Switzerland. I have only voted in favour of the report, just because Switzerland has taken a largely sensible approach to addressing asylum and migration challenges in recent years.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Asylum Support Office (EASO) has the task of strengthening cooperation between Member States in this area and assisting them in resolving the situation. I consider switzerland's interest in actively cooperating with the EU on the activities of the Support Office as an expression of solidarity and a step forward.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the draft agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office, taking into account the draft agreements so far between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on how to participate in the European Asylum Support Office, but also taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Therefore, I give my consent to the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report ratifying the agreement which allows Switzerland to participate in the work of the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). Additionally, the report enables Switzerland to receive support from EASO and be represented as an observer in the EASO management board.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 2012 439/2010 The European Asylum Support Office was established. The Regulation provides that the Relief Office should be open to the participation of countries that have concluded agreements with the Union.  Switzerland has concluded agreements with the EU on the basis of which EU law applies in the area to which the Regulation applies, in particular the Agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation. That agreement shall specify the criteria and mechanisms for determining the state responsible for examining asylum applications submitted in a Member State or switzerland. With this agreement, Switzerland also contributes to the SupportIng Office's revenue by an annual amount calculated in accordance with its gross domestic product (GDP) as a percentage of the GDP of all participating countries. I fully support the Council's proposal for a European Union agreement with the Swiss Confederation with a view to strengthening practical cooperation between Member States in the field of asylum, implementing the Common European Asylum System and supporting Member States whose asylum and reception systems are under particular pressure.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal and welcome Switzerland's participation in EASO's activities.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Federation on the details of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. In recent months, we have been experiencing a high migratory flow, which is why agencies directly involved in responding to migratory pressures need both financial assistance and assistance from Member States and non-member countries. I support any agreement and initiative that goes towards increasing the efficiency and productivity of the agencies: in addition to the European Asylum Support Office, I am also thinking of Frontex and Europol.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the technical ways in which Switzerland will participate in EASO's work and how EASO will support Switzerland. We voted in favour of the report because the participation of Switzerland and other countries in asylum cooperation, at a time of an expanded humanitarian and refugee crisis, is absolutely essential.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Asylum Support Office strengthens the practical cooperation of Member States on asylum issues, promotes the implementation of the common European asylum system and offers support to Member States whose asylum and reception systems are under particular pressure. In particular, the financial contribution of the "associated" countries and their participation in the work of the agency, given their connection to the Dublin system, would only be of particular added value if the Schengen and Dublin Treaties functioned in the protection of the economic interests of the citizens of the EU Member States, their security and the values of the member states.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation, which approved switzerland's access to the work of the European Asylum Support Office. Established in 2010, the office's role is to assist in the implementation of the Common European Asylum System and to provide support to Member States where there is significant asylum pressure. So far, the legislation has given Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland observer status. As an alternate member of the delegation responsible for relations with Switzerland and Norway and delegated to the EU-Iceland Joint Parliamentary Committee and the EEA Joint Parliamentary Committee, I consider it particularly important that all such cooperation be regulated in detail. I am pleased that Switzerland can thus achieve full participation in the work of the organisation once the Council adopts the draft agreement.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The existence of conflicts and crises in certain countries of the world implies a consequent increase in the number of persons seeking asylum for various reasons in the territory of the Member States of the Union, but also of neighbouring States. In accordance with the rules of international and humanitarian law, Member States are required to grant these rights to persons who justifiably request them.  The work of the European Asylum Support Office is aimed at coordinating and supporting policies to assist asylum seekers in host countries. This activity would not, however, be possible without the involvement of Member States and those associated with the EU. Involvement is achieved specifically at the level of day-to-day activities, but also by providing financial support to support these activities. Switzerland's participation in the Bureau is a complement to the institutional jurisdiction over the entire European territory. As a country located in the heart of the continent and which is fully targeted by asylum seekers around the world, Switzerland's participation in this European policy is beneficial for both the Union and the Swiss state. The adoption of the current agreement is, for these reasons, necessary in order to achieve a more coherent European asylum policy.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We have given our approval to the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report by which Parliament gives its consent to the Council to conclude the Arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). The Regulation establishing EASO opened its membership also for Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland as observers. According to the Arrangement, Switzerland will fully participate in the activities of EASO, which I support, taking into account also its involvement in the Dublin system. Such enhanced cooperation can facilitate among other things the exchange of best practices, information gathering and early warning system.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I supported this agreement, as I think it is important to accurately determine the nature, scope and manner of Switzerland's participation in the work of the European Asylum Support Office, as well as Switzerland's financial contributions to it.  Switzerland has agreed to voluntarily participate in resettlement and realisation programmes and has so far informally participated in the work of the Office. However, issues such as switzerland's accountability and financial contribution have so far not been covered, so I consider that the conclusion of an agreement formalising cooperation and assistance in providing long-term and multiple deployments, including aid and presence in hotspots, is fully justified.  As an MP coming from a country through which almost half a million migrants have passed, I believe that cooperation with a country such as Switzerland is extremely important for managing the current migration crisis, as it can offer much-needed expertise and assistance in ensuring the effective management of the current crisis.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the agreement with the Swiss Confederation on the details of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. Switzerland has voluntarily offered to participate in the redistribution of refugees. It already operates informally in similar activities of the European Union. The agreement will formalise this cooperation.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The European Asylum Support Agency (EASO) is a European Union agency operating since 2011. Its functions are: to promote cooperation between Member States in the field of asylum, to support Member States whose asylum and reception systems are subject to special pressures and to improve the implementation of the Common European Asylum System (SECA). Switzerland joined EASO as a partner country. We voted IN FAVOR.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal calls on the Council to adopt a decision to approve, on behalf of the European Union, the arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the terms of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. I am against the existence of this Office because the National Front wants Member States to have jurisdiction over asylum and immigration.  So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view, inter alia, of the draft agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on detailed rules for the latter's participation in the European Asylum Support Office, I agreed with the conclusion of the agreement and the establishment of Parliament's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The European Asylum Support Agency (EASO) is a European Union agency operating since 2011. Its functions are: to promote cooperation between Member States in the field of asylum, to support Member States whose asylum and reception systems are subject to special pressures and to improve the implementation of the Common European Asylum System (SECA). Switzerland joined EASO as a partner country. We voted IN FAVOR.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Arrangement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office, because I believe it is important to support the participation of non-EU countries in EASO and increase cooperation, especially on issues that are as important as asylum is.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a proposal inviting the Council to adopt the Decision concluding the Agreement between the EU and the Swiss Confederation for participation in the European Asylum Support Office. This formalizes an informal participation that is already taking place. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'As we face a huge influx of people seeking asylum in our European Union, it is more than once necessary that we work towards a coordinated asylum policy. It is crucial that Member States work better together on asylum policy. Cooperation with Switzerland should not be overlooked. That is why I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office (EADa) is essentially intended to enable Switzerland to participate in and receive support in the work of the EAsA, as well as the possibility of having an observer on the management board of the EAs. The situation of refugees who have been relocated to Europe in recent months raises serious humanitarian concerns. The high number of refugees arriving requires the creation of conditions of assistance, which are far from guaranteed. The European Union has not been up to the problem, so little of the responsibility it has and is at the origin of this scourge. The establishment of this agreement may be positive, but it is only a drop in an immense ocean of problems that need to be addressed to ensure effective protection and reception for the thousands of refugees - children and adults - who arrive every day fleeing war and persecution in their countries of origin.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The European Asylum Support Office is an administrative apparatus which has not yet been the source of a successful initiative. It entails high costs, with no apparent benefit. Switzerland's participation will not change this. On the contrary, it seems to be a decision against the Swiss people, because Switzerland has to participate with funds, but does not have the right to vote on the Board of Directors of the Support Office. I therefore reject this report.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Arrangement with Switzerland on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office. The proposal is very straightforward. Switzerland has already agreed to participate voluntarily in the EU resettlement as well as the EU relocation programmes. Moreover, so far, Switzerland has informally participated in European Asylum Support Office activities. Therefore, adoption of this arrangement will allow both of the parties – EASO and Switzerland – to formalise the collaboration.  Taking all of the above into consideration, the proposal is just a formal tool aimed to provide us help, in order to make the resettlement and relocation easier and as painless as possible.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this recommendation as it aims to increase Switzerland's involvement in mechanisms to address the migration crisis. In my opinion, it is sensible for Switzerland to benefit from the existence of the European Union and the free trade area in order to contribute to its solution even in times of crisis. Given that Switzerland itself has agreed to participate, there is nothing fundamental to prevent its involvement, and I believe that the Council will speed up its action as much as possible.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation. Switzerland is already informally involved in resolving asylum issues and is cooperating with the European Asylum Support Office. It is also commendable that it has voluntarily participated in relocation programmes for asylum seekers. I think that cooperation with countries such as Switzerland is very important in finding solutions to the migration crisis, as Switzerland can greatly assist in asylum application processing processes or provide valuable assistance in so-called hot spots. This is what this report has been directed towards, and by concluding a working agreement, Switzerland will be able to cooperate formally with the Asylum Support Office.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation deals with a draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the modalities of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office (EAsA), and essentially aims to enable Switzerland to participate in and receive support from the EAsA, as well as the possibility of having an observer on the management board of the EAs. The situation of refugees who have been relocated to Europe in recent months raises serious humanitarian concerns. The high number of refugees arriving requires the creation of conditions of assistance, which are far from guaranteed. The European Union has not been up to the problem, so little of the responsibility it has and is at the origin of this scourge. The establishment of this agreement may be positive, but it is just a drop in an immense ocean of problems that need to be addressed to ensure effective protection and reception for the thousands of refugees - children and adults - who arrive every day fleeing war and persecution in their countries of origin. We voted for it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on the details of its participation in the European Asylum Support Office because it will finally formally confirm Switzerland's active participation in EASO's activities.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Dominican citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted, with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments, I voted in favour of the ratification of the negotiations as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement with the Commonwealth of Dominica for visa exemption for short-term stays.  If in this report the liberalisation of visas for short-term stays is presented as an opportunity to boost tourism, simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs or encourage investment, I consider that at present it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude similar agreements.  Faced with a growing terrorist threat and European mass immigration policy, these agreements seem inappropriate to me. Indeed, even if the Commonwealth of Dominica is not directly a starting point for immigration, I do not think it is appropriate to make this kind of agreement in the current context, regardless of the country concerned.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report gives Parliament the consent to waive the visa requirement for stays of up to three months (90 days) over a period of six months (180 days). Since this decision represents progress in bilateral relations between the European Union and Dominica, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement requires the exemption of short-stay visas for people from the Dominican Republic. The aim is to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  However, it is not appropriate to conclude such agreements, even though the porousness of Europe's borders is the bed of terrorism in Europe. On the other hand, together with my colleagues on the national front, we oppose this desire to create a world without borders. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent with the principles of UKIP to vote against such issues being determined at European Union level. It is for individual sovereign nations to determine their own visa requirements, and to assess whether or not a short-stay visa waiver scheme is appropriate for them. This opposition should not be taken as making any commentary upon the appropriateness of the United Kingdom, hypothetically, making a bilateral agreement with Dominica along similar lines.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the agreement between the EU and Dominica on the short stay of visa waiver. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and Dominica, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which endorses the agreement with Dominica on visa exemption for short-term stays. Since the European Union refuses to control its external borders as it should and has abolished the internal borders of the Schengen area, it is urgent that France regains control of its national borders... and enforces its laws, particularly in the area of border deportation. It is therefore on principle that I am opposed to these types of agreements.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the approval of an agreement exempting Dominica, a democratically stable state, from Schengen visas for a maximum stay of 90 days over a period of 180 days in the European Union and vice versa. This will, in particular, promote political dialogue and economic exchanges with the State. I approved this agreement.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Dominica.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which supports the visa waiver for short-term stays for the citizens of Dominica with the aim of facilitating travel between this destination and the European Union (EU). The removal of visas in Dominica will apply to travel of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days, for any tourist, cultural, scientific or business trip, except those in a paid activity. Visa liberalisation in these countries is part of a proposal by the European Commission which extends to the exemption of visas in nineteen countries. We also call for full reciprocity to be used.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are supposed to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. The report also states that the country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, security or public order.  However, it is questionable whether it is useful to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the EU has lost control over mass immigration. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement establishes visa-free travel for EU and Commonwealth of Dominica citizens travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. The measure does not raise any problems of any kind, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. After the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the Commonwealth of Dominica was included in the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation, and the Council's authorisation, the Commission closed the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica between November and December 2014. The Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015 and the European Parliament is now granting its approval, with my vote in favour.  The Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Commonwealth nationals travelling to the territory of the other party for a stay of up to 90 days within a period of 180 days. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica on the short stay of visa waiver. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party and staying there for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The visa waiver agreement for short-stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order. I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed visa waiver decision as it implements the agreement signed in May between the EU and the Union of Dominica on visa-free travel by citizens of both communities. This arrangement will apply to journeys of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period.  The exception will be the only trip with the intention of carrying out paid work, which will still require a working visa. This strengthens cooperation between the EU and the Union of Dominica also at political level. We know that economic cooperation is already very good, and this agreement will, in my view, be further strengthened, particularly in the area of tourism and investment. I agree that the abolition of the visa requirement between the two Parties is an important means of bringing European and Caribbean nations closer. This agreement will also have a profound impact on the lower financial and practical costs of citizens, and I am pleased to welcome it!

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement with the Commonwealth of Dominica is an important milestone of symbolic and political value: it is a sign of the good path that the EU and its contracting party have taken together in recent years, witnessed by the deepening of political, diplomatic and joint cooperation relations. An action that facilitates the movement between the citizens of both contractors, and which – because of the sign of closeness and trust it represents – will be another instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on the issues to which the European Union and the Member States are attached, not least the protection of the human rights and fundamental freedoms of each human being.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to this report, these visa-free agreements for short-term stays should boost tourism and strengthen our trade relations with the Commonwealth of Dominica. These new provisions will make it easier for entrepreneurs and investors to move around, intensifying economic ties between businesses. Moreover, this liberalisation of visas should not pose a threat in terms of illegal immigration in view of the particularly low visa refusal rate. On the other hand, at a time when Western countries, in particular France, are facing an extremely serious terrorist threat, it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude these agreements. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Strong trade is one in which product diversity and membership are constantly increasing and rules are enjoyed by transparency and fairness. Such trade has also been a step forward through negotiations and the provisional agreement with the Union of Dominica, which takes significant political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Given that Dominica has fully integrated human rights and promotes the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and, on the other hand, has made considerable efforts to diversify and offers real growth potential, particularly in the tourism and geothermal energy production sector, I believe that this agreement will boost tourism and help strengthen trade and investment relations.  That is why I voted in favour of finalising this agreement and I support the visa waiver.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. This series of agreements establishes visa-free travel for Union citizens and third-country nationals (in this case the Commonwealth of Dominica) who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for their stay, with the exception of stays for paid employment. These are, in all cases, countries which are not problematic for the European Union. The most are known as "dream tourist destinations". There is no immigration problem in Europe and they are all very small or even small island countries.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commonwealth of Dominica, as highlighted in the report, is a small state with genuine growth potential, particularly in the tourism and geothermal sectors. In addition, 11% of the country's GDP is agriculture. These numbers encourage the Union to strengthen political dialogue and economic relations with the member countries of the Cotonou Agreement. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Dominica when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.  Whilst Ireland is not party to this agreement and therefore not subject to its provisions, the intentions are nonetheless very positive and progressive. Most Irish citizens are quite aware of the benefits that this type of agreement brings to citizens of a country as we have a somewhat similar agreement with the US.  It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Dominican Republic, assuming important political significance as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  Under reciprocal conditions, visa-free travel also brings benefits for tourist or business travel to the EU and makes it easier for Europeans to visit their family members who have settled in these countries or to travel for professional or tourism reasons. Furthermore, the Dominican Republic does not pose a threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a European Union and Commonwealth of Dominica Agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica - taking on a strong political significance under the Cotton Agreement - and is a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  Dominica's Commonwealth economy relies primarily on agriculture, which accounted for an average of 11% of the country's GDP between 2000 and 2010. The Commonwealth of Dominica is a small developing island state that makes considerable diversification efforts and offers a real growth potential, especially in the field of tourism and geothermal energy production. This agreement will strengthen tourism and contribute to strengthening bilateral relations in the field of trade and investment.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Union Agreement with the Commonwealth of Dominica on short-stay visa waiver is a positive effort for cooperation and coexistence, which can only have a positive impact on citizens of both parties. So while there are still many details and procedures that need to be carefully regulated, I believe that this effort should be welcomed and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. The signed agreement establishes visa-free travel for Union citizens and Commonwealth citizens of Dominica who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling more cheaply and practically.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation because I agree with the aim of the proposal, namely an agreement on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. Furthermore, the agreement, which provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens, is, in my view, the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica and a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  Finally, the Commonwealth of Dominica is a democratic and stable country which, like the European Union, defends the values and principles of democracy, good governance and respect for human rights and the rule of law. I therefore believe it is essential to strengthen our relations with that country and encourage it to continue along this path.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote because the agreements will encourage people-to-people contacts, boost  tourism, and invigorate business between the EU and these countries

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 To cross the external border of the European Union, third-country nationals need to hold a visa, in this case of short duration. However, many countries are already exempt from this obligation because they meet a set of criteria approved in 2001 and 2014 by the European Parliament and the Council, which include respect for fundamental rights, security of the visa issuance system or risk of illegal immigration. The visa waiver goes far beyond benefits for European tourists and the third country. Rather, it can enhance rapprochement and dialogue between cultures, economic growth, as well as contributed to the consolidation of democratic regimes.  So I am pleased to see Domínica on the list of visa-free countries for short stays.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement represents the completion of relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica, assuming important political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I have therefore decided to support this agreement as it could be an opportunity to boost tourism and help strengthen relations in the area of trade and investment, especially through visa liberalisation, which will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs. I believe it is appropriate for the European Commission and the Commonwealth authorities in Dominica to ensure full reciprocity of the visa waiver in order to allow equal treatment for all citizens. I am also convinced that this agreement poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order, as the European Union has long been committed to the fight against criminal networks alongside the Commonwealth of Dominica.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The purpose of the proposal on the visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement with Dominica on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Dominica when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Border crossing has never been a marginal issue. Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listed third countries in which nationals had to hold a visa in order to enter the host State. With the negotiations that began in November 2014, the regulation is drastically amended. With visa waiver agreements, citizens of the State of the Dominican Republic no longer have to hold a visa, but can cross borders with an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport that is valid. According to the agreement, the stay must be short and must not have work purposes. A national of one of the signatory States may travel to the territory of the other State for a maximum of 90 days within a period of 180 days. As I believe that this resolution can bring benefits to the current short-stay visa waiver agreements, I am voting in favour of this issue.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Dominican citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted, with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments, I voted in favour of the ratification of the negotiations as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Dominican Community are governed by the Partnership Agreement (Cotonou Agreement) between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and by the CELAC-EU dialogue and the EU-CARIFORUM dialogue. The Dominican Community has been transferred to third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Agreement was signed in Brussels on 28 May 2015. Since then, the agreement has been applied provisionally, pending the approval of the European Parliament, which has just been granted by the EP. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Dominican Community for travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (private, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) and to travel for any purpose other than the pursuit of gainful activity. The agreement will dynamise tourism and strengthen links in trade and investment. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and enhance economic relations between businesses.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report is about the negotiation of the Commission with Dominica on a short-stay visa waiver that provides visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of this territory when travelling to the Commonwealth of Dominica for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica – which is politically highly significant, an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. For all these reasons I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships that this agreement with Dominica will hopefully provide. However, as the deal concerns the visa regime operated by the Member States which belong to the Schengen area, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Dominica negotiated by the European Commission, aimed at facilitating the issuance of short stays. It allows EU citizens and citizens of Dominica to obtain a free visa on the territory of all contracting parties for up to 90 days over a period of 180 days. This visa applies to all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, official and special passport holders) travelling for any type of reason except for paid activities.  Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This short-stay visa exemption measure is an important step forward in strengthening political dialogue and economic relations between EU Member States and the Commonwealth of Dominica. I supported this report to facilitate travel between nationals of both parties.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The Gabriel report aimed to remove the visa requirement for the Commonwealth of Dominica, Vanuatu, Trinidad and Tobago, Samoa, Grenada, East Timor, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the United Arab Emirates. These countries certainly do not pose a risk of uncontrolled immigration or a disturbance of public order. However, at a time when Islamist terrorists are looking for the slightest flaw in our defence in order to attack us, I do not find it appropriate to exempt certain countries from visas and to facilitate in general, access to our territory from non-European countries. Although I am in favour of closer economic ties with these countries, I cannot knowingly take the risk of allowing ill-intentioned people to take advantage of this to harm European security. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In May this year, an agreement was signed to abolish short-stay visas between the EU and seven countries in the so-called Region of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, including the Dominican Community. I supported the report as I believe that the short-stay visa waiver agreement is an achievement in deepening relations with the Dominican Community, which at the same time has great political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural ties and strengthening political dialogue on a range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is believed that the short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica and constitutes a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is considered that the high degree of confidence in applicants is justified in view of the low rejection rate. According to the same view, citizens are thus given the opportunity not only to take full advantage of the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling at a reduced economic and practical cost. This is a completely wrong view.  The short-stay visa requirement helps to ensure order, prevent the admission of criminal elements and create a climate of mutual trust while the rules are respected. It is inconceivable to apply the practice of signing visa waiver agreements and their provisional application before the European Parliament has adopted them.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to visa-free travel for third countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the draft Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Community of Domínica on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and domínica nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. The agreement facilitates travel and is in itself positive. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica. This agreement will be an effective instrument for intensifying political, cultural and economic relations between the two countries. In addition, the visa waiver will undoubtedly bring benefits for tourist or business travel to the European Union.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as visa liberalisation will simplify travel for businesspeople, facilitate investment and intensify economic links among businesses.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has negotiated, on behalf of the European Union, an agreement with the Dominican Community on the lifting of the short-stay visa requirement. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of that territory when travelling to the Dominican Community for a maximum duration of 90 days in any 180-day period. At the same time, this agreement represents the culmination and deepening of relations between the European Union and the Dominick Community, which is a politically very important way of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I give my positive opinion to the conclusion of the visa agreement for short stays.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. – The view that the short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica and constitutes a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms, and that there is a high degree of confidence in visa applicants , as resulting from the low rate of rejections, but allowing citizens not only to take full advantage of the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling at a reduced economic and practical cost, is completely wrong. The short-stay visa requirement helps to ensure order, prevent the admission of criminal elements and create a climate of mutual trust while the rules are respected. Finally, it is inconceivable that visa waiver agreements should be signed and applied provisionally before the European Parliament has adopted them. For these reasons I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica on the short-stay visa waiver.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has negotiated on behalf of the EU an agreement with the Commonwealth of Dominica on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Commonwealth of Dominica when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica – which is politically highly significant as an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I support the report as the new visa regime provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens; it will bring people closer and will boost tourism.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we are giving our consent to the conclusion of the Agreement with the EU, which has already been negotiated with the Commission.  The purpose of the proposal on visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas.  The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. We support today’s resolution and believe that it is important to have a good agreement because it helps to fight organised crime and terrorist organisations.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Dominican Community, which is of great political importance in the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  Dominica's economy is primarily based on agriculture, which averaged 11% of the country's GDP between 2000 and 2010. As a developing small island country, Dominica has made considerable efforts to diversify and has significant growth potential, for example in tourism and geothermal energy production. The agreement will dynamise tourism and strengthen links in trade and investment. I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the agreement with the aim of deepening relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica, as well as as being a supplementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The agreement is a further step towards intensifying cooperation between the countries of Europe and Dominica. Especially uncomplicated short stays make an important contribution to cultural exchange and economic development.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning the short-stay visa waiver programme which allows for EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement takes into account the situation of the Member States that are not part of Schengen such as Ireland and the UK.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Visa waiver agreements for short stays represent a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Dominica.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement on the short-stay visa waiver between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica, not only because it requires Parliament’s consent to go through, but because we should also be seeking to improve our relations with the countries of the Caribbean. It is highly significant that we bring EU citizens and the people of Dominica closer together; it will mean a boost in tourism – especially for Dominica – and it will step up economic and cultural relations, intensifying political dialogue on various issues, most importantly human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As with the majority of my constituents, I do not feel that it is the place of the EU to decide who can and cannot come into my country.  I voted against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica on the short-stay visa waiver because I support reducing restrictions on EU citizens travelling to third countries.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the reports because, as ACPL, we always take a positive attitude towards a general visa regime for third-country travellers, despite our opposition to the procedure followed, as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this agreement because the waiver of short-stay visas simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Dominica, which is a small island developing country, is making considerable efforts to diversify its economy and has real potential for growth, particularly in tourism and the production of geothermal energy. This agreement will encourage tourism and will help to intensify trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel for businesspeople, facilitate investment and intensify economic links among businesses.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Short-stay visa waiver agreements, which would provide visa-free travel for citizens, were signed in May 2015 between the EU and St Lucia, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St Vincent and the Grenadines, the Republic of Vanuatu, the independent State of Samoa, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, the United Arab Emirates and Timor-Leste. The visa would cover a period of 90 days out of any 180-day period. The agreement has received unanimous support in the Council and will not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland. Since this agreement will likely increase commercial opportunities through increased tourism and promote commercial opportunities, which I strongly support, I have voted in favour of this report. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If we take the particular case of the Commonwealth of Dominica, I see no particular difficulty in lifting the requirement for a short-stay visa, that is, three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this small Caribbean island much more oriented to the United States than to France.  The risk of migration is very low. However, beyond the Commonwealth of Dominica, I wonder about the strategic choice of granting short-stay visa exemptions in turn when for some of these countries, particularly those in the Western Balkans, the risk of migration and to the internal security of the Member States of the European Union actually exists. There is a regulation that lists a positive list of countries whose nationals are exempt from the short-stay visa requirement. These countries are now 42 including the United States and Japan and will soon be 61. Should this list not be revised in light of international upheavals?

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Dominica has made a lot of progresses regarding civil and human rights and demonstrated that it has the same democratic values as the European Union. I voted in favour of this report on the Cotonou agreement regarding the waiver of short-stay visas as an important step forward for Dominica’s economic and cultural area.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and the Community of Dominica on the waiver of short-stay visas, on the basis that this abolition will benefit the tourism sector, which can make a significant contribution to the development of the economy and the production of geothermal energy.  The Community of Dominica has great growth potential, and therefore conditions for investment and international trade need to be improved, and visa liberalisation will certainly contribute significantly to this. It is also important to note that the Community of Dominica is a stable democratic state that respects the fundamental values of the European Union and does not pose a threat to illegal migration, and therefore I support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment, and boost tourism. It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order. Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted against this legislative vote with my UKIP MEPs’ vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With my vote, I supported the lifting of the visa requirement for short stays of citizens of selected ACP Group partner countries and the United Arab Emirates in the European Union. This measure concerning exclusively safe countries with an excellent level of cooperation with European countries will increase the interest of non-European tourists in visiting EU countries. At the same time, reciprocal visa waiver for short stays will greatly facilitate travel by Union citizens to the countries concerned.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica. The European Parliament was to decide on the conclusions of the agreement between the UNION and Dominica which was negotiated by the Commission. The aim was to facilitate the obtaining of visas. Citizens of both groups will be exempt from visas for stays of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. This exemption does not apply to people who will be travelling on business. This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the visa exemption at this time. This raises security concerns that would not be responsible for Europe in this situation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the agreement as it provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will boost tourism.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This agreement provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and Commonwealth citizens of Dominica travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party. This visa waiver covers all categories of persons and further strengthens both economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica. I have therefore decided to vote in favour, as visa liberalisation will also simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, while facilitating investment and strengthening economic links between businesses.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the EU-Dominica visa waiver agreement for short-term stays. According to Gabriel's report, the country in question poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants would be high, with a relatively low rate of visa refusal. Visa liberalisation simplifies travel conditions.  However, we have a duty to ask ourselves whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted against the agreement because they are hostile to the exception of visas for short-term stays, which it endorses. Visas are necessary to ensure national security, except for our reliable partners, especially European ones.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution promotes visa waiver for short-term stays between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica. This deepens the relations already established through the partnership agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific And EU group ̶Acred Cotonú̶ Agreement and the CELAC-European Union dialogues.   It is also a supplementary means that is expected to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.  Dominica is a small island developing state whose main economic engine is agriculture and which strives to diversify in this regard towards the tourism sector and geothermal energy production. This agreement will activate tourism, simplify employers' travel conditions, facilitate investment and strengthen economic links between businesses.  For these reasons I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Dominica for the exemption from short-stay visas has been concluded. The agreement provides for a visa-free regime for Citizens of the European Union, and for the citizens of Dominica a visa for a maximum period of 90 days for a period of 180 days when they travel to the territory of the European Union. I supported Mariya Gabriel's report, as the agreement was concluded and signed in accordance with the Council Decision, applies on an interim basis and requires the consent of the European Parliament to enter into force.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 European-Dominica relations have been longing for obvious historical reasons, while the official relationship between the European Union (then the European Economic Community) and the Commonwealth of Dominica has been in place since 1979. Over the past decade, they have evolved in a number of areas, from culture and tourism to the economy and politics. Both sides have a similar attitude to the promotion of active and universal human rights and other fundamental values. Given the level of development of relations and their future prospects, there is no reason not to approve the draft decision of the Council of the EU on the abolition of the short-stay visa waiver. This will allow for the intensification of contacts between people and for the economic and multi-facet to progress on both sides of the Atlantic, where the interests and cooperation of the parties involved intersect.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Dominican Republic is one of the democratic and politically stable countries that respects human rights and the rule of law. In view of its economic, social, economic and political stability, the EU and the Republic of Dominica concluded an agreement in May 2015 allowing citizens of the Contracting Parties to travel without a visa to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. The lifting of the visa requirement applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason other than the pursuit of a paid activity. By resolution, the EP agrees to this agreement. At the same time, the European Commission needs to monitor compliance with the agreement and check reciprocity in the treatment of citizens.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica on the short-stay visa waiver because it is not complete and documented.  Furthermore, it is well probable that the implementation of this Recommendation will be used by potential beneficiaries to enter the EU without a visa and then illegally extend their stay in the Union after the expiry of the present short stay, thereby contributing to the increase in illegal immigration within the Union.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. This agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica – which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. This is a whole series of agreements on the exemption of short-stay visas with several countries.  This agreement is supposed to help boost tourism, and strengthen trade relations and investments with these partners.  The key to these agreements is trust: the rate of visa refusal is very low because countries have confidence in visa applicants. According to the rapporteur, the countries covered by these agreements do not pose a threat, either in terms of irregular migration or security.  In view of the mass immigration that we are experiencing and which the EU is no longer able to manage, in view of the risks and the recent attacks against France, we can only be surprised, if we are worried, about this sudden desire for openness. Perhaps the timing is not the most timely!

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica. This agreement, which covers all categories of persons, establishes visa-free travel for EU citizens and Commonwealth citizens of Dominica for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. This strengthens the bonds of friendship that bind them and facilitates travel, giving their citizens visa-free entry conditions. This exemption also, by simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs and thus intensifying economic links between businesses and facilitating investment, is also important for economic relations.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mr Gabriel's report on the short-stay visa waiver agreement for EU citizens and Commonwealth of Dominica citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. It represents a further and important deepening of relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica, which is politically significant within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement and is fundamental to the strengthening of economic and cultural relations and political dialogue on issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing.
