U2012 I am voting in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica on visa waiver for stays with a maximum duration of 90 days. It is great news for deepening relations between the two sides and for strengthening economic, cultural and political ties, something we must continue to deepen in order to achieve a growing rapprochement between the Peoples of Europe and the Caribbean.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On the merits of the case, I am in favour of short-stay visa exemptions in order to facilitate the mobility and travel of citizens of two parties, in this case from the Member States to Dominica and vice versa. Nevertheless, I regret that the French Overseas Are Excluded from it. Moreover, cooperation with this country cannot be strengthened without holding it to account for the tax haven it represents.  On form, I denounce all this procedure. Only the Commission has the power to negotiate these agreements on behalf of states and citizens. It does not keep the European Parliament informed of the state of the negotiations until the very end of the process. Above all, these agreements are implemented even before the European Parliament gives its approval or not. An exemplary witness that democracy has no place in the EU (note that the same procedure will be applied in the case of the transatlantic agreement). Under these conditions, I vote against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment, and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  With regard to the United Arab Emirates, it should be noted that 150,000 EU nationals are based there and most of them work there. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the UAE each year, and some 230,000 Emiratis have travelled to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism.  Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Community of Domínica on visa-free travel for short stays. I share the rapporteur's position that this agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Community of Dominy, constituting an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, but also for deepening the debate and political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Dominica when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I chose to support this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The visa-free agreement between the EU and Dominica is an important further step in the intensification of our relations. Dominica, a member of the Cotonou Agreement, shares with the EU a number of values such as democracy, human rights and the rule of law.  Her successful actions against trafficking in women and children can be commended. In addition, renewable energy (geothermal, wind, solar), the environment (water and waste), and the construction of infrastructure (roads, anti-seismic and anti-cyclonic construction) are all sectors that present real opportunities for the European market.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement includes the lifting of the visa requirement when crossing the borders of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days, which is a positive consequence of the deepening of relations. Dominica is a country which, like the Union, protects democratic principles and human rights; The country has high growth potential and has made significant progress on human rights. The aim of the agreement is to strengthen relations, tourism dynamics and, importantly, to support the country in making progress. I consider it important to develop relations with the Dominick Community in order to raise public awareness of compliance with the edi allied human rights rules.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Dominica agreement on the short-stay visa waiver, which will provide visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and of the Commonwealth of Dominica when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica – which is politically highly significant an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should wisely allow legal access to third country nationals, as one of the means of both managing migration and protecting its good image, consistent with its values. Of course, reciprocity should also always be sought, in order to also benefit directly EU citizens when travelling abroad. The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver with Dominica is part of this possible menu of wisdom.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2014, the Dominican Community is one of the third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently negotiated a bilateral agreement to this end between 12 November and 9 December 2014 between the European Union and the Dominican Community. The agreement was corked in Brussels on 28 May 2015 and has been awaiting parliament's approval ever since. In its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs voted in favour of approving the agreement and voted in favour of the draft accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. These agreements provide for visa exemption for short-term stays for listed countries, in order to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants in these countries is high, with a historically low visa refusal rate. According to the rapporteur, the countries in question pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order.  However, the question arises whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.  The answer is no, hence a vote against.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has established a visa-free agreement for short-stay stays for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Community of Domínica in connection with travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days, and the European Parliament therefore needs to approve the agreement.  Visa facilitation allows peoples to rapprochement and strengthen economic, cultural and political relations between the European Union and the Domine community, strengthening the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement, a partnership agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the European Union and its Member States. Several categories of persons, regardless of the reason for visiting the country, are covered by this visa facilitation agreement, except in the case of paid activities.  I am voting in favour of this agreement, because I consider it essential to establish relations between the European Union and other communities, which will provide benefits for both sides in the economic, political and social field and enhance bilateral cooperation dialogues.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Gabriel report concerns visa-free agreements for short-term stays that are supposed to encourage tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. This report is about the Dominican Republican. It is expected that travel conditions will be simplified due to the liberalisation of visa issuance, which should lead to investment facilitation and increased economic links between companies.  The rapporteur points out that the countries concerned do not pose any threat in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. While it is true that for some of these countries, economic ties are already established and that many European nationals are settled there, it is questionable whether it is appropriate to conclude agreements on the facilitation of visa issuance with countries in the Middle East at a time when the EU has lost control over mass immigration.  So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which ratifies the agreement on short-stay visa waiver and allows for EU citizens and citizens of the participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica. The aim was to allow the visa-free travel regime for European and Dominican nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of our colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on the exemption of short-stay visas under the agreement between the European Union and Dominica in the Caribbean. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for nationals of both parties concerned who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period. The visa exemption covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, apart from paid work.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, signed by Mr De Clercq, on be it was a good example of this. Gabriel, supports an agreement establishing visa-free travel for EU citizens, on the one hand, and those of the Commonwealth of Dominica, on the other, when they travel to their territories for a maximum period of 90 days. Considering that a bureaucratic streamlining of the issue of obtaining short-stay visas is desirable, I have decided to support the document with my vote in favour.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I vote in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Dominican Community on the exemption from short-stay visas. This agreement provides an excellent opportunity to boost tourism, facilitate investment and dynamise trade, thereby increasing the importance of economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the higher state. In addition, the agreement offers new allies to join forces on issues of such importance as the fight against terrorism. We also see the emergence of political dialogue as a positive, most often aimed at joint action against corruption, criminal networks and trafficking in human beings.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I have voted for this Recommendation on the draft Council decision that provides a visa-free travel agreement for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Commonwealth of Dominica when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period amongst other provisions.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have voted against this recommendation because I believe that more security is needed now than ever before. Furthermore, I do not believe that this country is really ripe for visa-free travel. We must take the fears of our people seriously. Visa-free travel at the wrong time can seriously harm a Europe without internal borders.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is an additional tool for deepening economic and cultural relations and for more intensive political dialogue on issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. The agreement will stimulate tourism and help strengthen relations in the area of trade and investment. The liberalisation of the visa regime will facilitate travel for businesses, facilitate investment and enhance economic links between businesses.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The achievement and adoption of an agreement between the EU and the Commonwealth of Dominica, allowing short-stay visa-free travel, is an important step towards closer rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and those of the Caribbean and, more generally, a politically relevant instrument under the Cotonou Agreement. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support an agreement between the European Union and the Dominican Republic on the exemption from the short-stay visa requirement. I welcome the further development of friendly relations between the European Union and the Dominican Republic. I am pleased that the visa waiver covers all categories of persons wishing to facilitate travel and short-term stay without a visa, of a maximum of 90 days in any period within 180 days from the date of the first registered entry. The agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Dominican Republic to stay without a visa on the territory of the other Contracting Party.  This also offers numerous opportunities not only for the citizens of the Dominican Republic, but also for EU citizens through new business opportunities and facilitation of travel. Due to the close relationship between the European Union and Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, in particular on the basis of the association agreements of those countries to the implementation, application and development of the Schengen acquis, I call on those countries to conclude bilateral visa waiver agreements with the Dominican Republic for short stays containing provisions as in this agreement.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Gabriel report concerns visa-free agreements for short-term stays that are supposed to encourage tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. This specific text concerns the Dominican Republican. It is expected that travel conditions will be simplified due to the liberalisation of visa issuance, which should lead to investment facilitation and increased economic links between companies.  The rapporteur points out that the countries concerned pose no threat in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. While it is true that, for some of these countries, economic ties are already established and that many European nationals are settled there, it is questionable whether it is appropriate to conclude agreements on the facilitation of the issuance of visas with so many countries at a time when the EU has lost control over mass immigration.  So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the abolition of short-stay visas for Dominican citizens within the European Union, with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. I believe this decision will enhance EU-Dominica cooperation and boost exchanges and development, which is why I supported this proposal.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – I support The Recommendation of Mariya Gabriel on the draft Decision of the Council on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and the Community of Dominica on the waiver of short-stay visas. The community of Dominica is a small developing state in the Caribbean Sea which, along with many others, is a signatory to the Cotonou Agreement.  The GDP of the Community of Dominica is largely based on agriculture, and according to reports it has great potential for economic growth in the coming years. Dominica's policy is based on a strong commitment to human rights guaranteed by the Constitution for every resident and sees strong progress in the context of women's and children's rights. The problem of human trafficking is decreasing thanks to raising public awareness of the problem.  In addition to all of the above, past experience has shown that the vast majority of visas requested are accepted, which is another reason in favour of the cancellation of short-stay visas. I believe that the acceptance of this proposal is crucial for further development of relations between the two sides, which will increase tourist travel and trade and investment intensify.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica are governed by the Partnership Agreement known as the Cotonou Agreement. The agreement establishes visa-free travel for Union citizens and Commonwealth citizens of Dominica who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of those aimed at carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour of this agreement because it represents the conclusion of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the approval of the agreement between the EU and Dominica to remove the visa requirement for short stays, i.e. 90 days less for all categories of people (ordinary, diplomatic). Indeed, it is important that European citizens can return to Dominica without a visa and vice versa. This visa exemption should hopefully support the tourism sector in this Caribbean island.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. This agreement seals the visa exemption for very short stays and on the basis of reciprocity with Dominica. A way to make travel easier for our nationals, whether for tourism or business.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment to Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the Community of Domínica has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that Regulation, the Council authorised the Commission on 9 October 2014 to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the Union and the Community of Domine. The negotiations were concluded on 9 December 2014 and the Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015.  The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and domínica nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days.  Because I believe that this is an important agreement to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue between the European Union and the Community of Dominy, I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the EU and the Community of Dominia, with high political importance, and is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this draft agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica with regard to the short-stay visa exemption, which has already been applied on an interim basis since May 2015. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and third country nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  It should be noted that the United Kingdom and Ireland do not participate in these agreements and are not subject to the provisions of these agreements, as are the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the Proposal for a Recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and The Domínica on the exemption of visas for short stays.  As in the other visa exemptions voted today, in this case too the strengthening of economic and cultural relations and the enormous political importance of the Cotonou Agreement were essential for this strengthening of bilateral cooperation and for the facilitation and conclusion of this agreement.  Dominia has an economy predominantly focused on the agricultural sector. However, it has made numerous efforts to boost growth in the tourism and geothermal energy production sector. This agreement will not only enable tourism to be boosted, but also to intensify trade and investment relations, simplifying travel conditions, which will consequently enhance interconnections between companies and entrepreneurs - whether with a view to new investments or consumer-supplier relations. As Domínica is a democratically stable country with significant progress in the defense of human rights, it is essential to continue to ensure and expand this path of democratic dialogue. As the EU is the main driver of fundamental rights in Domínica, this agreement is expected to be an added value for both co-signatories, which is why I supported the recommendation to conclude this agreement.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Dominica nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between EU and Commonwealth of Dominica citizens as it brings benefits in the tourism and trade sectors. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons holding an ordinary passport, regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Dominica.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Dominican citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted, with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments, I voted in favour of the ratification of the negotiations as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement approved by the European Parliament today lays down new provisions for short-term visa waiver for UNION citizens and Commonwealth citizens of Dominica travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for their stay. This agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic, tourist and cultural relations and, finally, will serve to intensify political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in any visa policy so I voted against this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement on the short-stay visa waiver between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica, not only because it requires Parliament’s consent to go through, but we should also be seeking to improve our relations with the countries of the Caribbean. It is highly significant that we bring EU citizens and the people of Dominica closer together; it will mean a boost in tourism – especially for Dominica – and it will step up economic and cultural relations, intensifying political dialogue on various issues, most importantly human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The small island state of Dominica, which is part of the Little Antilles in the Caribbean, represents a potential partner for the EU in economic and cultural cooperation. The country has recently made great progress towards democratisation and stability. It has succeeded in improving the governance of its public affairs, respect for human rights and the rule of law, making it a safe and attractive tourist destination for European citizens. For this reason, I agree with the two-way visa waiver for short stays of up to 90 days for all citizens.  For the Dominican Community, visa liberalisation will mean simplifying travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitating investment opportunities and deepening the economic interconnecting of businesses. The tourism of this island state is also not sufficiently exploited, and Dominica could benefit from it. Despite its potential, Dominica's economy is still based on agriculture, even as the country seeks diversification. Its true potential could be revealed by the more intense relationships that this facilitation of travel can bring.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this amendment to the agreement between the European Union and Dominica taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Also, such a proposal to amend the agreement improves relations between these countries. The abolition of short-stay visas allows citizens to gain new experiences and promotes the development of mobility.  After their stay in the European Union, citizens can transfer their newfound experiences to the country from which they come and thus further improve relations between the European Union and the country in question, as well as the situation in their country. And in an indirect way they promote the European Union in their own country.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement which will allow EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver programme takes into account the situation of Member States not part of Schengen such as the UK and Ireland.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Negotiations on a visa waiver agreement with Dominica and four other Caribbean countries began on 12 November 2014 in Brussels. The agreement between the European Union and the Community of Dominica on the waiver of short-stay visas allows citizens of the European Union and Dominican nationals to stay visa-free in the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any period of 180 days.  The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, official and special passport) whose purpose of travel does not include the performance of paid activity The Agreement takes into account the situation of Member States which do not yet fully apply the Schengen acquis. By revoking visas, Dominican nationals acquire the right to stay of 90 days for any 180-day period in the territory of each of these Member States (Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus and Romania), regardless of the period calculated for the entire Schengen area. I support the Council's decision to abolish visas with Dominica, as I believe that by abolishing visas we develop friendly relations between the Contracting Parties and facilitate travel by ensuring entry and short-term stay without visas for our citizens.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal and welcome the abolition of the short-stay visa requirement as this will increase the freedom of both EU and Dominican Community citizens.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Union of Dominika on the short-stay visa waiver. I support the agreement concluded between the European Union and the Union of Dominica at the end of last year, which brings a maximum of 90 days visa-free travel on the territory of the Union of Dominica in any 180-day period. I welcome that the agreement includes any purpose of visiting the country and that paid work is excluded. The agreement reached has a strong political note and brings about strengthening cooperation in the area of the economy.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These reports relate to the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States. As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and will not take part in the agreement, I have abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although we disagree with the procedure followed, as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations, we nevertheless voted in favour of the reports because, as ACPL, we are in favour of a general visa liberalisation regime for third-country travellers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is completely wrong to think that the short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica and is a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the mistaken view that there is a high degree of confidence in visa applicants , which results from the low rate of rejections, and that this agreement allows citizens not only to take full advantage of the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling at a reduced economic and practical cost. The short-stay visa requirement helps to ensure order, prevent the admission of criminal elements and create a climate of mutual trust only if the rules are respected. Finally, it is inconceivable that the practice of signing visa waiver agreements should be applied and that they should be provisionally implemented before they are approved by the European Parliament.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union maintains good cooperation relations with all the countries of the world that share its democratic values and norms. In this respect, the European Commission is in constant dialogue with the States concerned in enhancing collaborative relations with the Union and the Member States. An important area in collaborative relations is visa-free movement for short periods of stay. Those periods are usually covered by tourist stays or business trips. The abolition of the visa regime is a significant impetus for the development of the tourism field in both directions. The Caribbean is a predilection region for the taking of leave for citizens of the Member States of the Union, as it offers excellent natural conditions at any time of the year. In these circumstances, eliminating the need for visas for European citizens would facilitate organisational steps and increase the number of European tourists in the countries of the area, with significant effects on the economies of those States. The benefits would be mutual, allowing our citizens easier access to holidays in this region of the world. For these reasons, I believe that supporting the adoption of the agreement between the EU and Dominica, but also between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago, Grenada, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines with a view to eliminating short-term residence visas, is an important impetus for the development of tourism.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed my political group and the subject matter expert. This visa-free agreement for short-term stays is a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country, which has strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of concluding the Agreement between the EU and the Commonwealth of Dominica on the short-stay visa waiver, which was signed in May 2015. It allows visa-free travel for EU citizens and for the citizens of the Commonwealth of Dominica when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons, travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I welcome that the Agreement strengthens relations between the EU and the Commonwealth of Dominica, which is significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. It is also another way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the recommendation to conclude an agreement between the EU and Dominica on the abolition of short-stay visas, which provides a framework for continued cooperation open to democratic treatment. Cooperation between EU Member States and the ACP group of countries, if strictly controlled and regulated, can mean benefits for both parties to the agreement and contribute to improving democratic relations between EU member states and ACP group members. The community of Dominica is a small state, that is, a small island in the Caribbean Sea and has great development potential. Its economy is primarily based on agriculture, which accounts for 11% of GDP and given its agricultural and tourism potential, the short-stay visa liberalisation agreement will contribute to strengthening the tourism sector, promoting business links and providing business opportunities for both EU Member States and the Community of Dominica. So I voted positively.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the agreement between the European Union and the Union of Dominica on the short-stay visa waiver. The proposal for an agreement on visa facilitation is intended to conclude an agreement with the Union of Dominica on the facilitation of the issue of short-stay visas.  The Agreement takes into account the fact that some Member States do not fully apply the Schengen acquis. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for European Union citizens and Union citizens of the Union of Dominika when travelling to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of carrying out paid work.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Dominica.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation would simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. However, the question arises as to whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. This inflection in visa policy is contrary to what common sense dictates.  So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Dominican Community, which is of great political importance in the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Dominica.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe it is important to support this agreement that was based on the open negotiations with a view to the conclusion of the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Dominica. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Commonwealth of Dominica when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity, and I believe this is an important step in improving relationships between countries and at the same time offering greater  possibilities for mobility.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament must approve the conclusion of this agreement, which has already been negotiated by the European Commission. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, as well as the rapporteur, have given a positive recommendation and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour of such an agreement.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report which includes an exemption from the short-stay visa requirement for Dominica citizens and our own EU citizens. The abolition of the visa requirement shall apply to journeys of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. I am convinced that this agreement will contribute to better trade relations, more investment and more tourism.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the draft Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and that third country on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that third country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the draft Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Community of Domínica on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and domínica nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Union of Dominica on the short-stay visa waiver. The concrete agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Union of Dominika, inter alia, to travel visa-free to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Vanuatuense and European citizens to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the ̶ negotiations have been conducted with obscurantism and without the participation of the ̶ I voted in favour of the ratification of the negotiations, as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement with Vanuatu for visa exemption for short-term stays.  If in this report the liberalisation of visas for short-term stays is presented as an opportunity to boost tourism, simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs or encourage investment, I consider that at present it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude similar agreements.  Faced with a growing terrorist threat and European mass immigration policy, these agreements seem inappropriate to me. Indeed, even if Vanuatu is not directly a starting point for immigration, I do not think it is wise to make this kind of agreement in the current context, regardless of the country concerned.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report gives Parliament's consent not to require a visa for stays of up to three months (90 days) over a total period of 6 months (180 days). Since this decision represents progress in bilateral relations between the European Union and Vanuatu, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement requires the exemption of short-stay visas for people coming from Vanuatu. The aim is to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  However, it is not appropriate to conclude such agreements, even though the porousness of Europe's borders is the bed of terrorism in Europe. On the other hand, together with my colleagues on the national front, we oppose this desire to create a world without borders. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent with the principles of UKIP to vote against such issues being determined at European Union level. It is for individual sovereign nations to determine their own visa requirements, and to assess whether or not a short-stay visa waiver scheme is appropriate for them. This opposition should not be taken as making any commentary upon the appropriateness of the United Kingdom, hypothetically, making a bilateral agreement with Vanuatu along similar lines.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the agreement between the EU and Vanuatu on the short stay of visa waiver. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and Dominica, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which endorses the agreement with Vanuatu on visa exemption for short-term stays. Since the European Union refuses to control its external borders as it should and has abolished the internal borders of the Schengen area, it is urgent that France regains control of its national borders... and enforces its laws, particularly in the area of border deportation. It is therefore on principle that I am opposed to these types of agreements.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the approval of an agreement exempting Vanuatu, a democratically stable state, from Schengen visas for a maximum stay of 90 days over a period of 180 days in the European Union and vice versa. This will, in particular, promote political dialogue and economic exchanges with the State. I approved this agreement

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Vanuatu.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which supports the exemption of visas for short-term stays for citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu with the aim of facilitating travel between this destination and the European Union (EU). The removal of visas in the Republic of Vanuatu will apply to travel of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days, for any tourist, cultural, scientific or business trip, except those in a paid activity. Visa liberalisation in these countries is part of a proposal by the European Commission which extends to the exemption of visas in nineteen countries. We also call for full reciprocity to be used.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are supposed to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. The report also states that the country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, security or public order.  However, it is questionable whether it is useful to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the EU has lost control over mass immigration. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement establishes visa-free travel for EU and Vanuatu citizens travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. This measure does not raise any problems of any kind, which is why I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. After the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the Republic of Vanuatu was included in the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation and the council's authorisation, the Commission negotiated and closed the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu between November and December 2014. The Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015 and is now granted by Parliament, with my vote in favour.  The Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of the Republic of Vanuatu travelling to the territory of the other party for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except to pursue a paid activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the short stay of visa waiver. This agreement on the short stay of visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement establishes a visa-free regime for nationals of the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party and staying there for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both a success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a new instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order. I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed visa waiver decision as it implements the agreement signed in May between the EU and the Republic of Vanuatu on visa-free travel by citizens of both communities and countries. This arrangement will apply to journeys of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period.  The exception will be the only trip with the intention of carrying out paid work, which will still require a working visa. This strengthens cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Vanuatu at political level as well. We know that economic cooperation is already very good, and this agreement will, in my opinion, be further strengthened, particularly in the areas of tourism and financial investment and agriculture. I agree that the abolition of the visa requirement between the two Parties is an important means of bringing European and Caribbean nations closer. This agreement will also have a profound impact on the lower financial and practical costs of citizens, and I am pleased to welcome it!

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement with the Republic of Vanuatu is an important milestone of symbolic and political value: it is a sign of the good path that the EU and its contracting party have taken together in recent years, witnessed by the deepening of political, diplomatic and joint cooperation relations. An action that facilitates the movement between the citizens of both contractors and which – because of the sign of closeness and trust it represents – will be another instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on the issues to which the European Union and the Member States are attached, not least the protection of the human rights and fundamental freedoms of each human being.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to this report, these visa-free agreements for short-term stays should boost tourism and strengthen our trade relations with the Republic of Vanuatu. These new provisions will make it easier for entrepreneurs and investors to move around, intensifying economic ties between businesses. Moreover, this liberalisation of visas should not pose a threat in terms of illegal immigration in view of the particularly low visa refusal rate. On the other hand, at a time when Western countries, in particular France, are facing an extremely serious terrorist threat, it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude these agreements. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's negotiations with the 14 countries of the Pacific region, including Vanuatu, through the Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement, are welcomed, with the aim of creating new trade opportunities, strengthening multilateral trade rules, putting at the heart of the negotiations both the needs of the Union and the needs and interests of developing countries.  From a commercial point of view, relations with Pacific States such as Vanuatu, the Union and its Member States mainly import agricultural products such as palm oil, coffee and fishery products and export electrical and mechanical equipment. From the point of view of mobility, taking into account that the vast majority of Schengen visa applicants do not pose risks and therefore obtain a short-stay visa, but also that 36.6% of applicants obtain multiple-entry visas, we have strong elements that allow the exclusion of security risks and, at the same time, the highlighting of the benefits of visa waiver. The agreement adds value to the EU's current support for democracy, and its completion is essential, and that is why I supported the objective it proposes by voting in favour.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This series of agreements establish visa-free travel for Union citizens and third-country nationals (in this case the Republic of Vanuatu) who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for their stay, with the exception of stays for paid employment. In all cases, these are countries which are not problematic for the European Union. The most are known as "dream tourist destinations". There is no immigration problem in Europe and they are all very small or even small island countries.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Like the previous positions in favour of the other countries covered by the Cotonou Agreement, I am also in favour of the Republic of Vanuatu. I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu in order to intensify political dialogue and strengthen economic relations with that country.  As the recommendation pointed out, Vanuatu's economy is mainly based on agriculture, which accounts for 19% of GDP, while in Europe agriculture and agri-food industry now account for 46 million jobs and 6% of European GDP. I therefore believe that these kinds of agreements can really have an effect, especially in terms of investment.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement which is aimed at improving economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue. Whilst Ireland is not party to this agreement and therefore not subject to its provisions, the intentions are nonetheless very positive and progressive. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Vanuatu, taking on important political significance, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  Under reciprocal conditions, visa-free travel also brings benefits for tourist or business travel to the EU and makes it easier for Europeans to visit their family members who have settled in these countries or to travel for professional or tourism reasons. Vanuatu also does not pose a threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the short-stay visa waiver. This short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu – taking on strong political significance under the Cotton Agreement – and is a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Union's Agreement with the Republic of Vanuatu on the short-stay visa waiver is a positive effort for cooperation and coexistence, which can only have a positive impact on citizens of both parties. So while there are still many details and procedures that need to be carefully regulated, I believe that this effort should be welcomed and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for Union citizens and citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling more cheaply and practically.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation because I believe that the signed agreement establishing visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days is very positive. Furthermore, it should not be underestimated that, on the economic front, the main areas of cooperation and assistance between the Union and Vanuatu are still the development of the private sector for job creation, on the one hand, and support for the formulation of economic policies for agriculture and tourism, on the other.  Finally, I would like to call on the European Commission and the authorities in Vanuatu to ensure full reciprocity of the visa waiver, which must allow equal treatment for all citizens, especially all citizens of the European Union.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote because the agreements will encourage people-to-people contacts, boost tourism, and invigorate business between the EU and these countries

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 To cross the external border of the European Union, third-country nationals need to hold a visa, in this case of short duration. However, many countries are already exempt from this obligation because they meet a set of criteria approved in 2001 and 2014 by the European Parliament and the Council, which include respect for fundamental rights, security of the visa issuance system or risk of illegal immigration. The visa waiver goes far beyond benefits for European tourists and the third country. Rather, it can enhance rapprochement and dialogue between cultures, economic growth, as well as contributed to the consolidation of democratic regimes.  So I am pleased to see Vanuatu on the list of exempt countries for short stays.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement represents the completion of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I have therefore decided to support this agreement as it will improve cooperation and assistance relations between the Union and Vanuatu, both in terms of the development of the private sector for job creation and in terms of support for the formulation of economic policies for agriculture and tourism, sectors with strong development potential within these areas.  In this regard, I believe it is appropriate for the European Commission and the authorities of the Republic of Vanuatu to guarantee full reciprocity of the visa waiver in order to allow equal treatment of all citizens.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The purpose of the proposal on the visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement with Vanuatu on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Vanuatu when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Border crossing has never been a marginal issue. Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listed third countries in which, in order to enter the host State, citizens had to hold a visa. With the negotiations that began in November 2014, the regulation is drastically amended. With visa waiver agreements, in fact, citizens of the State of Vanuatu no longer have to be in possession of a visa, but can cross borders with an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport that is valid. According to the agreement, the stay must be short and must not have work purposes. A national of one of the signatory States may travel to the territory of the other State for a maximum of 90 days over a period of 180 days. As I believe that this resolution can bring benefits to the current short-stay visa waiver agreements, I am voting in favour of this issue.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Vanuatuense and European citizens to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the ̶ negotiations have been conducted with obscurantism and without the participation of the ̶ I voted in favour of the ratification of the negotiations, as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu are governed by the Partnership Agreement (Cotonou Agreement) between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part. The Republic of Vanuatu has been transferred to third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Agreement was signed in Brussels on 28 May 2015. Since then, the agreement has been applied provisionally, pending the approval of the European Parliament, which has just been granted by the EP. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period of travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (private, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) and to travel for any purpose other than the pursuit of gainful activity.  In general, trade and investment volumes and rates are low between the European Union and the Pacific countries, but significant progress is possible. The visa waiver agreement may have a particularly positive impact on investment and the development of the tourism sector.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report is on the negotiation of the Commission with Vanuatu on a short-stay visa waiver which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of this territory when travelling to the Republic of Vanuatu for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu – which is politically highly significant, an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. For these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this agreement with Vanuatu will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen member states, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Vanuatu negotiated by the European Commission, aimed at facilitating the issuance of short stays. It allows EU citizens and citizens of Vanuatu to obtain a free visa on the territory of all contracting parties for up to 90 days over a period of 180 days. This visa applies to all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, official and special passport holders) travelling for any type of reason except for paid activities. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report introducing a short-stay visa exemption measure between the EU Member States and the Republic of Vanuatu. In addition to strengthening political dialogue and economic relations, this measure will have a direct positive impact on the economic costs of travel for travellers from contracting countries.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The Gabriel report aimed to remove the visa requirement for the Commonwealth of Dominica, Vanuatu, Trinidad and Tobago, Samoa, Grenada, East Timor, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the United Arab Emirates. These countries certainly do not pose a risk of uncontrolled immigration or a disturbance of public order. However, at a time when Islamist terrorists are looking for the slightest flaw in our defence in order to attack us, I do not find it appropriate to exempt certain countries from visas and to facilitate in general, access to our territory from non-European countries. Although I am in favour of closer economic ties with these countries, I cannot knowingly take the risk of allowing ill-intentioned people to take advantage of this to harm European security. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In May this year, an agreement was signed to abolish short-stay visas between the EU and seven countries in the so-called Region of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, including the Republic of Vanuatu.  I supported the report as I believe that the short-stay visa waiver agreement is an achievement in deepening relations with the Republic of Vanuatu, which at the same time has great political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural ties and strengthening political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement for citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu neither constitutes a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms, nor does it have a positive impact on investment and development in the tourism sector.  I would also like to point out that this is a country in which gender-based violence and violations of human rights are a daily occurrence. Finally, I find it unacceptable that in the Joint Committee on the Management of the Agreement (Article 6), the European Union is represented only by the European Commission, without the participation of directly elected Members of the European Parliament.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to visa-free travel for third countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the exemption from a visa for short stays. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Vanuatu who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. The agreement facilitates travel and is in itself positive. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu, as I consider it to be an excellent political instrument capable of strengthening and facilitating relations between that country and the European Union from an economic, political and social point of view.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the agreement on visa liberalisation because it will simplify travel for businesspeople, facilitate investment and intensify economic links among businesses.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission negotiated an agreement with Vanuatu on the visa waiver for short stays on behalf of the European Union. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for Citizens of the European Union and for citizens of this territory when travelling to Vanuatu for a maximum duration of 90 days in any 180-day period. At the same time, this agreement represents the culmination and deepening of relations between the European Union and Vanuatu, which is a politically very important way of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I give my positive opinion to the conclusion of the visa agreement for short stays.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu neither constitutes a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms, nor does it have a positive impact on investment and development in the tourism sector , especially in a country where gender-based violence and human rights abuses are a daily occurrence.  In addition to the above, I find it unacceptable that in the Joint Committee for the Management of the Agreement (Article 6), the European Union is represented only by the European Commission, without the participation of directly elected MEPs. For these reasons, I am voting against the EU-Vanuatu Agreement on short-stay visa waiver.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has negotiated, on behalf of the EU, an Agreement with the Republic of Vanuatu on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens the Republic of Vanuatu of when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu – which is politically highly significant an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we are giving our consent to the conclusion of the Agreement with the EU, which has already been negotiated with the European Commission.  The purpose of the proposal on visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas.  The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.
