The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. We support today’s resolution and believe that it is important to have a good agreement because it helps to fight organised crime and terrorist organisations.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as a new instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The most important area of economic cooperation and assistance between the UNION and Vanuatu is currently the development of the private sector for job creation and the development of economic policies relating to agriculture and tourism.  I voted in favour of this recommendation because the agreement allows dialogue to continue and cooperation, inter alia, on human rights and combating gender-based violence.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the desire to strengthen ties between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU association, but also to participate in it by travelling with less economic and practical costs.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today, as coordinator of my group for the EU-ACP dialogue, for the recommendation on the EU-Vanuatu visa waiver agreement, because I believe that rapprochement is valuable and, for me, includes the simplification of tourist bureaucracies.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The agreement is a further step towards intensifying cooperation between the countries of Europe and Vanuatu. Especially uncomplicated short stays make an important contribution to cultural exchange and economic development.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning the short-stay visa waiver programme which allows for EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement takes into account the situation of the Member States that are not part of Schengen such as Ireland and the UK.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Visa waiver agreements for short stays represent a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general.  That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Vanuatu.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The new visa regime, which I voted in favour of, will provide visa-free travel for EU citizens and will bring the people of Vanuatu and the European Union closer together, as well as giving the South Pacific island nation a much needed boost in tourism. This is an incredibly significant development between the Republic and the EU, and will allow us to extend our dialogue regarding fundamental freedoms with the states that we are issuing short-stay visa waivers to.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As with the majority of my constituents in Wales, I do not feel that it is the place of the EU, to decide who can and cannot come into my country.  I voted against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the short-stay visa waiver because I believe that allowing easier travel to the EU for citizens of some third countries can encourage people-to-people contacts, boost tourism, and invigorate business.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Since, as ACPL, we have always taken a positive attitude towards a general visa regime for third-country travellers, we voted in favour of the reports, despite the fact that we deplore the procedure followed, as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this agreement because the waiver of short-stay visas simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Politically, Vanuatu is a stable parliamentary democracy, and the most recent elections, in 2012, were described by international observers as free and fair. Fundamental rights and freedoms are protected by the constitution and generally respected in practice. The European Union’s political dialogue with Vanuatu on this subject emphasises preventing torture, combating corruption and promoting political participation and the development of civil society. This agreement will make it possible to maintain the dialogue and to cooperate on such issues as promoting human rights and combating gender violence.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Short-stay visa waiver agreements, which would provide visa-free travel for citizens, were signed in May 2015 between the EU and St Lucia, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St Vincent and the Grenadines, the Republic of Vanuatu, the independent State of Samoa, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, the United Arab Emirates and Timor-Leste. The visa would cover a period of 90 days out of any 180-day period. The agreement has received unanimous support in the Council and will not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland. Since this agreement will likely increase commercial opportunities through increased tourism and promote commercial opportunities, which I strongly support, I have voted in favour of this report. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If we take the particular case of Vanuatu, I see no particular difficulty in lifting the requirement for a short-stay visa, i.e. three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this small, predominantly Christian island of Oceania. The risk of migration is very low. However, beyond Vanuatu, I wonder about the strategic choice of granting short-stay visa exemptions in turn when for some of these countries, particularly those in the Western Balkans, the risk of migration and to the internal security of the Member States of the European Union actually exists. There is a regulation that lists a positive list of countries whose nationals are exempt from the short-stay visa requirement. These countries are now 42 including the United States and Japan and will soon be 61. Should this list not be revised in light of international upheavals?

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the Cotonou agreement regarding the waiver of short-stay visas as an important step forward for the Republic of Vanuatu’s economic and cultural area.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the abolition of short-stay visas, as this agreement will boost the private sector, economic policy and tourism. It will also improve political dialogue, investment and economic and cultural links.  Vanuatu's economy is characterised by agricultural activities, and I believe that closer cooperation with the European Union and its Member States will contribute to growth and a greater tourism offer. The abolition of visas also implies the rapprochement of the peoples of Europe and the Pacific and the further strengthening of the Cotonou Agreement. Therefore, I support this recommendation and the efforts of both sides to achieve better bilateral relations.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment, and boost tourism. It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order. Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted against this legislative vote with my UKIP MEPs regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With my vote, I supported the lifting of the visa requirement for short stays of citizens of selected ACP Group partner countries and the United Arab Emirates in the European Union. This measure concerning exclusively safe countries with an excellent level of cooperation with European countries will increase the interest of non-European tourists in visiting EU countries. At the same time, reciprocal visa waiver for short stays will greatly facilitate travel by Union citizens to the countries concerned.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu. The European Parliament was to decide on the conclusions of the agreement between the EU and Vanuatu which was negotiated by the Commission. The aim was to facilitate the obtaining of visas. Citizens of both groups will be exempt from visas for stays of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. This exemption does not apply to people who will be travelling on business. This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the visa exemption at this time. This raises security concerns that would not be responsible for Europe in this situation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the agreement as it provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will boost tourism.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. I have chosen to vote in favour because the agreement will help, on the one hand, to give greater impetus to the private sector for job creation and, on the other, to the development of economic policies for agriculture and tourism.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the EU-Vanuatu visa waiver agreement for short-term stays. According to Gabriel's report, the country in question poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants would be high, with a relatively low rate of visa refusal.  Visa liberalisation simplifies travel conditions. However, we have a duty to ask ourselves whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted against the agreement because they are hostile to the exception of visas for short-term stays, which it endorses. Visas are necessary to ensure national security, except for our reliable partners, especially European ones.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution promotes visa waiver for short-term stays between the EU and Vanuatu, deepening the relations already established through the partnership agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific States group and the EU - Cotonou Agreement.   The signed agreement provides for a visa-free travel arrangements for EU nationals and those of the Republic of Vanuatu travelling for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days.  It is therefore a means that will strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. Agriculture and the services sector, in particular tourism and financial services, are Vanuatu's economic engines. This agreement is expected to have a positive impact on investment and development in the tourism sector. For these reasons I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Agreement was concluded between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu for the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free regime for Citizens of the European Union, and for the citizens of Vanuatu a visa for a maximum period of 90 days for a period of 180 days when they travel to the territory of the European Union. I supported Mariya Gabriel's report because the agreement was concluded and signed in accordance with the Council Decision, applies on an interim basis and requires the consent of the European Parliament to enter into force.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of political, economic, cultural and other forms of relations between the European Union and the Pacific states occupies an important place in the line of our community's international diplomatic efforts. This applies in particular to ecology, tourism and fishing. The Republic of Vanuatu is one of the most successful and effective parliamentary republics and democracies in the region as a whole, whose system of values is quite similar to that of our community. While at the moment the number of reciprocal visits is not very high, firstly, because of the distance, the abolition of the short-stay visa regime could certainly give some springboard to our relations, to the development of tourism, as well as, for example, cultural exchanges and long-term progress in the regional maritime transport system through closer links.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In May 2015, an AGREEMENT was concluded between the EU and the Republic of Vanuatu, which is provisionally implemented and allows Citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Vanuatu to travel without a visa to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. The lifting of the visa requirement applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason whatsoever, with the exception of persons travelling for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. The country is one of the stable parliamentary democracies with low security risk. Agriculture is the predominant sector, and the Visa Waiver Agreement will have a positive impact, in particular on investment and the development of the tourism sector.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Vanuatu on the short-stay visa waiver, because it is not complete and documented.  Furthermore, it is well probable that the implementation of this Recommendation will be used by potential beneficiaries to enter the EU without a visa and then illegally extend their stay in the Union after the expiry of the present short stay, thereby contributing to the increase in illegal immigration within the Union.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. As with the previous one, this is a whole series of agreements on the exemption of short-stay visas with several countries.  This agreement is supposed to help boost tourism, and strengthen trade relations and investments with these partners.  The key to these agreements is trust: the rate of visa refusal is very low because countries have confidence in visa applicants. According to the rapporteur, the countries covered by these agreements do not pose a threat, either in terms of irregular migration or security.  In view of the mass immigration that we are experiencing and which the EU is no longer able to manage, in view of the risks and the recent attacks against France, we can only be surprised, if we are worried, about this sudden desire for openness. Perhaps the timing is not the most timely!

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu. Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 amending Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 contains in Annex II a list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement, including the Republic of Vanuatu. This agreement could have positive effects, both from an economic and political point of view, on investment and the development of the tourism sector, since vanuatu's economy is also based mainly on agriculture and various services, such as tourism and financial services.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The signed agreement establishes visa-free travel for UNION citizens and citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu for short stays. The Republic of Vanuatu is based on a predominantly agricultural economy, but the services sector, in particular tourism and financial services, is also of great importance. From this point of view, trade relations with the countries of the Union are essential, which would, moreover, be facilitated by visa liberalisation. I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the Recommendation on the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on visa waiver for stays with a maximum duration of 90 days. I am convinced that this agreement can have positive effects for both sides and achieve a greater relationship, supporting investment and the development of the tourism sector in this country from Europe.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On the merits of the case, I am in favour of short-stay visa exemptions in order to facilitate the mobility and travel of citizens of two parties, in this case from the Member States to the state of Vanuatu and vice versa. Nevertheless, I regret that the French Overseas Are Excluded from it.  On form, I denounce all this procedure. Only the Commission has the power to negotiate these agreements on behalf of states and citizens. It does not keep the European Parliament informed of the state of the negotiations until the very end of the process. Above all, these agreements are implemented even before the European Parliament gives its approval or not. An exemplary witness that democracy has no place in the EU (note that the same procedure will be applied in the case of the transatlantic agreement). Under these conditions, I vote against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment, and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order. With regard to the United Arab Emirates, it should be noted that 150,000 EU nationals are based there and most of them work there. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the UAE each year, and some 230,000 Emiratis have travelled to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism.  Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on visa-free travel for short stays. I share the rapporteur's position that this agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu and is an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, but also for deepening the debate and political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Vanuatu when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I chose to support this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The approval of the visa-free agreement between the European Union and Vanuatu completes a process initiated under the previous Parliament to exempt from visas to nationals of several third countries who meet all security, immigration and public order requirements. I am pleased that among the 9 countries whose bilateral agreements have been approved are several African-Caribbean-Pacific Group states.  The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly initiated this visa-free process. The agreement with the Republic of Vanuatu is part of the wider relationship between the Union and the Pacific Republic, which focuses on cooperation, particularly in the areas of private sector development, agriculture and tourism.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement is based on visa liberalisation, which results from the successful completion of the deepening of relations between the EU and the Republic of Vanuatu. Vanuatu is dominated by the services sector, which accounts for up to 72% of GDP. The agreement already aims at developing the private sector, promoting the import of agricultural products and the export of technology and equipment, creating jobs and, in particular, promoting agriculture and tourism. The country is a stable parliamentary democracy and the Union is to work together to promote human rights, combat gender-based violence and develop civil society. The agreement will have a significant impact on the investment and development of the tourism sector.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Vanuatu agreement on the short-stay visa waiver, which will provide for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu – which is politically highly significant as an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should wisely allow legal access to third country nationals, as one of the means of both managing migration and protecting its good image, consistent with its values. Of course, reciprocity should also always be sought, in order to also benefit directly EU citizens when travelling abroad. The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver with Vanuatu is part of this possible menu of wisdom.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2014, the Republic of Vanuatu is one of the third countries whose nationals are exempt from visa requirements when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently negotiated a bilateral agreement to this end between 19 November and 4 December 2014 between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu. The agreement was corked in Brussels on 28 May 2015 and has been awaiting parliament's approval ever since. In its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs voted in favour of approving the agreement and voted in favour of the draft accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. These agreements provide for visa exemption for short-term stays for listed countries, in order to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants in these countries is high, with a historically low visa refusal rate. According to the rapporteur, the countries in question pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order.  However, the question arises whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.  The answer is no, hence a vote against.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has established a visa-free agreement for short-stay stays for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Vanuatu in connection with travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days, and the European Parliament therefore approved the respective agreement.  Visa facilitation allows peoples to rapprochement and strengthen economic, cultural and political relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu, strengthening the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement, a partnership agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the European Union and its Member States. Several categories of persons, regardless of the reason for visiting the country, are covered by this visa facilitation agreement, except in the case of paid activities.  I am voting in favour of this agreement, because I consider it essential to establish relations between the European Union and other communities, which will provide benefits for both sides in the economic, political and social field and enhance bilateral cooperation dialogues.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the previous report, this one concerns the facilitation of the issuance of Visas, but this time for Vanuatu. Economic ties with the country are expected to intensify from an increased relationship of trust through visa exemption. However, even if the rapporteur assures us that this country does not pose any threat to the security of the EU's territory or to its migration policy, the timing of these liberalisations does not seem appropriate. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which ratifies the agreement on short-stay visa waiver and allows for EU citizens and citizens of the participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu. The aim was to allow the visa-free travel regime for EU nationals and Vanuatais nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of our colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on the agreement between the European Union and Vanuatu on the short-stay visa exemption. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for nationals of both parties concerned who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period. The visa exemption covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, apart from paid work.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I vote in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanutatu on the exemption from short-stay visas. This agreement provides an excellent opportunity to boost tourism, facilitate investment and dynamise trade, thereby increasing the importance of economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the higher state. In addition, the agreement offers new allies to join forces on issues of such importance as the fight against terrorism. We also see the emergence of political dialogue as a positive, most often aimed at joint action against corruption, criminal networks and trafficking in human beings.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this Recommendation on the draft Council decision that provides a visa-free travel agreement for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period amongst other provisions.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. As in my previous explanation of vote, I would have opposed this recommendation in this vote, because I believe that more certainty is needed now than ever before. Furthermore, the visa-free regime would cause even more concern to our citizens.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Visa waivers will have a positive impact on investment and the development of the tourism sector and will allow for further political dialogue and cooperation.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The achievement and adoption of an agreement between the EU and the Republic of Vanuatu, allowing visa-free travel for short stays, is an important step towards closer rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and those of the Caribbean and, more generally, a politically relevant instrument under the Cotonou Agreement. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the exemption from the short-stay visa requirement. I welcome the further development of friendly relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu. I am pleased that the visa waiver covers all categories of persons wishing to facilitate travel and short-term stay without a visa, of a maximum of 90 days in any period within 180 days from the date of the first registered entry. The agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu to stay without a visa on the territory of the other Contracting Party. This also offers numerous opportunities not only for the citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu, but also for EU citizens through new business opportunities and facilitation of travel.  Due to the close relationship between the European Union and Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, in particular on the basis of the association agreements of those countries to the implementation, application and development of the Schengen acquis, I call on those countries to conclude bilateral visa waiver agreements with the Republic of Vanuatu for short stays containing provisions such as in this Agreement.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. As the previous report, this report concerns the facilitation of the issuance of visas, but this time for Vanuatu. Economic ties with the country are expected to intensify as a result of an increased relationship of trust through visa exemption. However, even if the rapporteur assures us that this country does not pose any threat to the security of the EU's territory or to its migration policy, the timing of these liberalisations does not seem appropriate. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the abolition of visas for short stays of Vanuatu citizens within the European Union, with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. I believe this decision will enhance EU-Vanuatu cooperation and encourage exchanges and development, which is why I supported this proposal.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – I support Mep Gabriel's recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the waiver of short-stay visas. The Republic of Vanuatu is one of the 78 countries that signed the Cotonou Agreement and is in very strong relations with the European Union.  The GDP of the Republic of Vanuatu is mainly based on agriculture (19%) tourism amounting to as much as 72% of GDP. The EU imports agricultural products such as palm oil from the Republic of Vanuatu, while the Republic of Vanuatu imports electrical and mechanical equipment from the EU. Current trade and investment in the Republic of Vanuatu is weak, but I think that thanks to this decision, trade will intensify.  The political situation in the Republic of Vanuatu is stable and the democratic elections of 2012 by international observers have been described as free and fair. In addition to all of the above, past experience has shown that the vast majority of visa applications are accepted, so in the last year only 2 percent of applications were rejected. I believe that accepting this proposal is essential to further break down relations between the EU and the Republic of Vanuatu.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation on the approval of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu. Schengen visa applicants from the Republic of Vanuatu are considered in the vast majority of cases to be 'good faith travellers', i.e. they do not involve any particular risks. In 2014, out of 190 short-stay visa applications in the Schengen area, 186 were accepted, which corresponds to a near-zero refusal rate. 36.6% of applicants obtain a multiple entry visa, a sign of greater confidence in them by consulates in schengen member states.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the approval of the agreement between the EU and Vanuatu to remove the visa requirement for short stays, i.e. 90 days less for all categories of people (ordinary, diplomatic). Indeed, it is important that European citizens can travel to Vanuatu without a visa and vice versa. This visa exemption should hopefully support this small Pacific island, which was hit hard last March by Cyclone WFP.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. This agreement seals the visa exemption for very short stays and on the basis of reciprocity with Vanuatu. A way to make travel easier for our nationals, whether for tourism or business.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the Republic of Vanuatu has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that Regulation, the Council authorised the Commission on 9 October 2014 to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the Union and the Republic of Vanuatu. The negotiations were concluded on 4 December 2014 and the Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015.   The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Vanuatu who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days.  Because I believe that this is an important agreement to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu, I voted in favour of their adoption.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the EU and Vanuatu, being of high political importance and also provides an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this draft agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the short-stay visa exemption, which has already been applied on an interim basis since May 2015. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and third country nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  It should be noted that the United Kingdom and Ireland do not participate in these agreements and are not subject to the provisions of these agreements, as are the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Proposal for a Recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and Vanuatu on visa-free travel for short stays.  Vanuatu has a small economy predominantly focused on the agricultural and services sector, including financial and tourism. The areas of cooperation and economic assistance of the Union with Vanuatu are mainly concentrated in the private sector - through support for job creation, as well as on agricultural and tourism policies. Although the trade and investment relations established between the EU and the Pacific are relatively tenuous to date, this visa-free agreement is expected to bring some potential for the development of this small country, which is our partner, particularly in the tourism sector, and is an asset to both peoples.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Vanuatu nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the conclusion of the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu establishing visa-free travel for nationals of signatory countries travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. This compromise, in addition to strengthening cooperation between the European Union and the Pacific countries, promotes the development of the tourism sector and the private sector.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Vanuatu.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Vanuatuense and European citizens to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the ̶ negotiations have been conducted with obscurantism and without the participation of the ̶ I voted in favour of the ratification of the negotiations, as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement approved by the European Parliament today lays down new provisions for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for their stay. This agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that State, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic, tourist and cultural relations and, finally, will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in any visa policy so I voted against this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The new visa regime, which I voted in favour of, will provide visa-free travel for EU citizens and will bring the people of Vanuatu and the European Union closer together, as well as giving the South Pacific island nation a much needed boost in tourism. This is an incredibly significant development between the Republic and the EU, and will allow us to extend our dialogue regarding fundamental freedoms with the states that we are issuing short-stay visa waivers to.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the EU's facilitated travel to remote countries such as the Pacific archipelago of Vanuatu. Lifting visa requirements for stays of less than 90 days will promote economic and cultural relations, but will also benefit from intensifying political dialogue. Vanuatu is already a stable parliamentary democracy, but it still needs to improve the fight against corruption and increase the political involvement of its citizens. I also support the agreement on visa waiver because it will have a positive impact, particularly on investment and the development of tourism. The services sector accounts for more than two thirds of GDP for Vanuatu, and thus loosening relations with the EU could be most beneficial precisely for tourism and financial services. In addition, the abolition of visas also has an impact on the convergence of the European and Pacific populations, which in the long term could lead to the development of the private sector and trade relations that would go beyond the current imports of several agricultural products.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this amendment to the agreement between the European Union and Vanuatu taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Also, such a proposal to amend the agreement improves relations between the countries mentioned. The abolition of short-stay visas allows citizens to gain new experiences and promotes the development of mobility.  After their stay in the European Union, citizens can transfer their newfound experiences to the country from which they come and thus further improve relations between the European Union and the country in question, as well as the situation in their country. And in an indirect way they promote the European Union in their own country.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement which will allow EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.  The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver programme takes into account the situation of Member States not part of Schengen such as the UK and Ireland.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. Negotiations on the visa waiver agreement with Vanuatu began on 19 November 2014 in Brussels. The agreement allows European Union citizens and Vanuatu nationals to stay visa-free on the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period.  The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, official and special passport) whose purpose of the trip does not include the performance of paid activity. The agreement takes into account the position of Member States that do not yet fully apply the Schengen acquis. By revoking visas, Vanuatu citizens acquire the right to stay of 90 days for any 180-day period on the territory of each of these Member States (Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus and Romania), regardless of the period calculated for the entire Schengen area. I support the Council's decision to revoke visas with Vanuatu, as I believe that by abolishing visas we develop friendly relations between the Contracting Parties and facilitate travel by ensuring entry and short-term stay without visas for our citizens.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the short-stay visa waiver. I support the agreement concluded, which brings a maximum of 90 days visa-free travel to the territory of the Republic of Vanuatu in any 180-day period and includes any visit other than paid work. The agreement concluded will strengthen political, economic, cultural and tourism ties. The agreement will also help to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and african, caribbean and pacific countries.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's proposal to agree to the conclusion of agreements between the EU and several Caribbean and Pacific countries on the abolition of the visa requirement for short stays. It should be noted that The Member States have already agreed to the introduction of a visa-free regime for citizens of these states by approving the European Commission's mandate for negotiating these visa-free agreements. The security aspect has thus already been considered primarily by the responsible authorities of the Member States. The list of countries whose citizens can travel to the EU visa-free is the content of the Annex to Regulation No 539/2001 and, until now, the visa-free regime has generally been introduced precisely by changing this Annex. Given that some Member States may already have bilateral visa waiver agreements from an earlier period and these agreements may make it difficult to implement the basic rule allowing stays in Schengen territory for only 90 days every 180 days, it was decided to conclude UNION visa-free agreements with third countries as part of the introduction of visa-free travel, which would clearly replace national visa waiver agreements and reflect rule 90 in the 180th EDF.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These reports relate to the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States. As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and will not take part in the agreement, I have abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although we disagree with the procedure followed, as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations, we nevertheless voted in favour of the reports because, as ACPL, we are in favour of a general visa liberalisation regime for third-country travellers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu is not an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms, nor does it have a positive impact on investment and development of the tourism sector, especially in a country where gender-based violence and the violation of human rights are a daily occurrence. In addition, in the Joint Committee for the Management of the Agreement (Article 6), the European Union is represented only by the European Commission, without the participation of directly elected MEPs.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The dialogue that the European Union maintains with the other countries of the world is beneficial to boost cooperation at international level. Furthermore, following the signing of agreements to collaborate in certain specific areas, European values can be better promoted by establishing implicit conditionalities. One of the important areas of collaboration is visa-free travel for short periods of stay. Those periods relate in particular to tourist stays or business trips. The abolition of the visa regime is a significant impetus for the development of the tourism sector. The Pacific area is a developing region with excellent natural conditions for tourist activities at any time of the year. Eliminating the need for visas for European citizens would facilitate organisational steps and increase the number of European tourists in the countries of the region, with significant effects on the economies of those States. The benefits would be mutual, allowing our citizens easier access to holidays in this region of the world. For these reasons, I believe that supporting the adoption of the agreement between the EU and Vanuatu, as well as with Samoa and East Timor, with a view to eliminating short-term residence visas, is an important impetus for the development of tourism activity.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed my political group and the subject matter expert. This visa-free agreement for short-term stays is a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country , which has strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of concluding the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the short-stay visa waiver, which was signed in May 2015. It allows visa-free travel for EU citizens and for the citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons, travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I welcome that the agreement strengthens relations between the EU and the Republic of Vanuatu, which is significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. It is also another way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the recommendation to adopt an agreement between the EU and Vanuatu to abolish short-stay visas, as visa liberalisation with this Pacific country can have direct benefits in the tourism sector. 72% of Vanuatu's GDP is a tourism activity, and therefore the abolition of visas for a certain period of time, both for eu nationals and Vanuatu nationals, can encourage individuals or businesses to cooperate with each other for the purpose of achieving business opportunities, and in particular in this case, for the purpose of mutually increasing the number of tourists.  Trade and investment have great potential for further development and progress, as the Union and its Member States import non-fertile products from Vanuatu, such as palm oil and coffee, and on the other hand export electrical and mechanical equipment. I believe that the benefits of adopting this agreement can be mutual, both in terms of investments and in the development of tourism activities and therefore I voted yes.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the short-stay visa waiver. The proposal for an agreement on visa facilitation is intended to conclude an agreement with the Republic of Vanuatu on the facilitation of the issuance of short-stay visas.  The Agreement takes into account the fact that some Member States do not fully apply the Schengen acquis. The Agreement also provides for visa-free travel for European Union citizens and citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu when travelling to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of carrying out paid work.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Vanuatu.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation would simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. However, the question arises as to whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. This inflection in visa policy is contrary to what common sense dictates.  So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Vanuatu.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution that provides visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. This agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas simultaneously represents the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu – which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament must approve the conclusion of this agreement which has already been negotiated by the European Commission. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, as well as the rapporteur for the agreement, have given a positive recommendation and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report which includes an exemption from the short-stay visa requirement for Vanuata citizens and our own EU citizens. The abolition of the visa requirement shall apply to journeys of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. I am convinced that this agreement will contribute to better trade relations, more investment and more tourism.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the draft Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and that third country on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that third country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the exemption from a visa for short stays. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Vanuatu who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Vanuatu on the short-stay visa waiver, because the agreement signed will allow citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Vanuatu to travel visa-free to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I also believe that the Agreement will have a beneficial effect, in particular, on the investments and development of the tourism sector.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Trinidadian citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted — with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments - I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement with the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago for visa exemption for short-term stays.  If in this report the liberalisation of visas for short-term stays is presented as an opportunity to boost tourism, simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs or encourage investment, I consider that at present it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude similar agreements.  Faced with a growing terrorist threat and European mass immigration policy, these agreements seem inappropriate to me. Indeed, even if the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is not directly a starting point for immigration, I do not think it is appropriate to make such an agreement in the current context, regardless of the country concerned.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report gives Parliament the consent to waive the visa requirement for stays of up to three months (90 days) over a period of 6 months (180 days). Since this decision represents progress in bilateral relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement requires the exemption of short-stay visas for people from Trinidad and Tobago. The aim is to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  However, it is not appropriate to conclude such agreements, even though the porousness of Europe's borders is the bed of terrorism in Europe. On the other hand, together with my colleagues on the national front, we oppose this desire to create a world without borders. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent with the principles of UKIP to vote against such issues being determined at European Union level. It is for individual sovereign nations to determine their own visa requirements, and to assess whether or not a short-stay visa waiver scheme is appropriate for them. This opposition should not be taken as making any commentary upon the appropriateness of the United Kingdom, hypothetically, making a bilateral agreement with Trinidad and Tobago along similar lines.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the AGREEMENT between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago on visa-free travel in the case of short stays. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and Trinidad and Tobago, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which endorses the agreement with the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on visa exemption for short-term stays. Since the European Union refuses to control its external borders as it should and has abolished the internal borders of the Schengen area, it is urgent that France regains control of its national borders... and enforces its laws, particularly in the area of border deportation. It is therefore on principle that I am opposed to these types of agreements.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the approval of an agreement exempting Trinidad and Tobago, a democratically stable state, from Schengen visas for a maximum stay of 90 days over a period of 180 days in the European Union and vice versa. This will, in particular, promote political dialogue and economic exchanges with the State. I approved this agreement.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which supports the visa waiver for short-term stays for citizens of Trinidad and Tobago with the aim of facilitating travel between this destination and the European Union (EU). The removal of visas in Trinidad and Tobago will apply to travel of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days, for any tourist, cultural, scientific or business trip, except those in a paid activity. Visa liberalisation in these countries is part of a proposal by the European Commission which extends to the exemption of visas in nineteen countries. We ask, too. to be seen for full reciprocity.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are supposed to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. The report also states that the country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, security or public order.  However, it is questionable whether it is useful to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the EU has lost control over mass immigration. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement establishes visa-free travel for EU and Trinidad and Tobago citizens travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. This measure does not raise any problems of any kind, which is why I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Following the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago was included in the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation, and the Council's authorisation, the Commission closed the bilateral agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago between November and December 2014. The Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015 and the European Parliament is now granting its approval, with my vote in favour.  The signed Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago travelling to the territory of the other party for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on visa waiver in the case of short stays. This agreement on the short stay of visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement establishes a visa-free regime for nationals of the European Union and of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party and staying there for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The visa waiver agreement for short-stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order. I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the proposed visa waiver decision, as it implements the agreement signed in May between the EU and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on visa-free travel by citizens of both communities or countries. This arrangement will apply to journeys of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period.  The exception will be the only trip with the intention of carrying out paid work, which will still require a working visa. This strengthens cooperation between the EU and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago also at political level. We know that economic cooperation is already very good, and this agreement will, in my opinion, be further strengthened, particularly in the areas of tourism and financial investment and agriculture. In addition, Trinidad and Tobago can also become a key partner in the field of security, particularly in the fight against drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings. I agree that the abolition of the visa requirement between the two Parties is an important means of bringing European and Caribbean nations closer. This agreement will also have a profound impact on the lower financial and practical costs of citizens, and I am pleased to welcome it!

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement with the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is an important milestone of symbolic and political value: it is a sign of the good progress that the EU and its contracting party have taken together in recent years, witnessed by the deepening of political, diplomatic and joint cooperation relations. An action that facilitates the movement between the citizens of both contractors and which – because of the sign of closeness and trust it represents – will be another instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on the issues to which the European Union and the Member States are attached, not least the protection of the human rights and fundamental freedoms of each human being.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to this report, these visa-free agreements for short-term stays should boost tourism and strengthen our trade relations with the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. These new provisions will make it easier for entrepreneurs and investors to move around, intensifying economic ties between businesses. Moreover, this liberalisation of visas should not pose a threat in terms of illegal immigration in view of the particularly low visa refusal rate. On the other hand, at a time when Western countries, in particular France, are facing an extremely serious terrorist threat, it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude these agreements. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The idea of the Union's role at international level and of overcoming the borders of Member States is intrinsically linked to the Union itself's success and the strengthening of its institutions. In this context of internationalism, visa liberalisation comes naturally as an opportunity for European citizens to access new territories, targeting tourism and trade. Another Caribbean country covered by this liberalisation is the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, which has one of caricom's most dynamic and prosperous economies, thanks to oil and gas resources, high direct investment and rising tourism. The EU is the second trading partner of trinidad and Tobago, which has an outward-looking approach and an intense, open trade policy. This agreement will enable relations between the two parties to be strengthened and trade to be boosted. I support the Commission's position on how this framework for the conduct of business or tourist travel will be ensured and improved, a position which has resulted in the provisional agreement with Trinidad and Tobago, and I believe that only a favourable vote can continue the beneficial course started.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This series of agreements establish visa-free travel for Union citizens and third-country nationals (in this case Trinidad and Tobago) who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for their stay, with the exception of stays for paid employment. These are, in all cases, countries which are not problematic for the European Union. The most are known as "dream tourist destinations". There is no immigration problem in Europe and they are all very small or even small island countries.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As well as for the Commonwealth of Dominica and the Republic of Vanuatu, I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. It is important to strengthen political dialogue with this state, because it allows citizens greater mobility, not only in terms of practicality, but also in economic terms. It should not be underestimated that this agreement will certainly give greater impetus in the area of trade and investment, since the EU is the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago's second largest trading partner.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Trinidad and Tobago when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.  Whilst Ireland is not party to this agreement and therefore not subject to its provisions, the intentions are nonetheless very positive and progressive. Most Irish citizens are quite aware of the benefits that this type of agreement brings to citizens of a country as we have a somewhat similar agreement with the US.  It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
