text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Trinidad and Tobago, assuming important political significance, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  Under reciprocal conditions, visa-free travel also brings benefits for tourist or business travel to the EU and makes it easier for Europeans to visit their family members who have settled in these countries or to travel for professional or tourism reasons. Furthermore, Trinidad and Tobago does not pose a threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support and vote in favour of the draft Council decision. This short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago - taking on a strong political significance under the Cotton Agreement - and constitutes a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  This agreement will stimulate tourism and help strengthen trade and investment relations, as the EU is the second trading partner of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. The visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs and facilitate investment.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Union Agreement with the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the short-stay visa waiver is a positive effort for cooperation and coexistence, which can only have a positive impact on citizens of both parties. So while there are still many details and procedures that need to be carefully regulated, I believe that this effort should be welcomed and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for Union citizens and citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling more cheaply and practically.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation because I believe that the short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  Finally, I would like to highlight the impetus that visa-free travel gives to bringing the peoples of Europe and the Caribbean closer together, because the agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling more cheaply and practically.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote because the agreements will encourage people-to-people contacts, boost tourism, and invigorate business between the EU and these countries

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 To cross the external border of the European Union, third-country nationals need to hold a visa, in this case of short duration. However, many countries are already exempt from this obligation because they meet a set of criteria approved in 2001 and 2014 by the European Parliament and the Council, which include respect for fundamental rights, security of the visa issuance system or risk of illegal immigration. The visa waiver goes far beyond benefits for European tourists and the third country. Rather, it can enhance rapprochement and dialogue between cultures, economic growth, as well as contributed to the consolidation of democratic regimes.  So I am pleased to see Trinidad and Tobago on the list of exempt countries for short stays.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago as it will be able to boost tourism and help strengthen trade relations. The visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs and facilitate investment. The economy of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is in fact one of the most dynamic and prosperous in Caricom thanks to the presence of resources such as oil and gas, high levels of direct investment and growing tourism. The country is therefore a favourite destination for foreign direct investment. In addition, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is committed to promoting a diversified and competitive economy that is oriented towards technology, innovation and knowledge. With its external approach and its open and liberal trade policy, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is a full partner of the Union. In this respect, the agreement will make it possible to strengthen relations between the two parties and to give a new impetus to trade.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The purpose of the proposal on the visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement with Trinidad and Tobago on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Trinidad and Tobago when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Border crossing has never been a marginal issue. Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listed third countries in which nationals had to hold a visa in order to enter the host State. With the negotiations that began in November 2014, the regulation is drastically amended. With visa waiver agreements, citizens of the State of Trinidad and Tobago no longer have to hold a visa, but can cross borders with an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport that is valid. According to the agreement, the stay must be short and must not have work purposes. A national of one of the signatory States may travel to the territory of the other State for a maximum of 90 days over a period of 180 days. As I believe that this resolution can bring benefits to the current short-stay visa waiver agreements, I am voting in favour of this issue.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Trinidadian citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted — with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments - I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago are governed by the Partnership Agreement (Cotonou Agreement) between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the Celac-EU Dialogue and the EU-CARIFORUM Dialogue, of the other part. The Republic of Trinidad and Tobago has been transferred to third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Agreement was signed in Brussels on 28 May 2015. Since then, the agreement has been applied provisionally, pending the approval of the European Parliament, which has just been granted by the EP. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago for travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (private, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) and to travel for any purpose other than the pursuit of gainful activity.  The agreement will dynamise tourism and strengthen relations in the area of trade and investment, as it is the EU's second most important trading partner in Trinidad and Tobago. The visa waiver will simplify travel for investors, thereby facilitating investment.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report is about the negotiation of the Commission with Trinidad and Tobago on a short-stay visa waiver which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of this territory when travelling to Trinidad and Tobago for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Trinidad and Tobago – which is politically highly significant, an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues. For these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this agreement with Trinidad and Tobago will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen member states, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago negotiated by the European Commission, aimed at facilitating the issuance of short stays. It allows EU citizens and citizens of Trinidad and Tobago to obtain a free visa on the territory of all contracting parties for up to 90 days over a period of 180 days. This visa applies to all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, official and special passport holders) travelling for any type of reason except for paid activities. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this short-stay visa exemption measure between the EU Member States and Trinidad and Tobago. As Trinidad and Tobago's second largest trading partner, this will facilitate investment and boost tourism.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of legislative resolutions giving the Approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union of agreements on the exemption of short-stay visas with eight small islands in the Caribbean and the Pacific and the United Arab Emirates. These agreements will allow EU nationals to travel to these destinations without a visa requirement for short stays and vice versa for nationals of these countries when travelling within the Schengen area.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The Gabriel report aimed to remove the visa requirement for the Commonwealth of Dominica, Vanuatu, Trinidad and Tobago, Samoa, Grenada, East Timor, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the United Arab Emirates. These countries certainly do not pose a risk of uncontrolled immigration or a disturbance of public order. However, at a time when Islamist terrorists are looking for the slightest flaw in our defence in order to attack us, I do not find it appropriate to exempt certain countries from visas and to facilitate in general, access to our territory from non-European countries. Although I am in favour of closer economic ties with these countries, I cannot knowingly take the risk of allowing ill-intentioned people to take advantage of this to harm European security. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In May this year, an agreement was signed to abolish short-stay visas between the EU and seven countries in the so-called Region of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, including the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. I supported the report as I believe that the visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and enable strengthening relations between the two countries and a new boost to trade.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is not a guarantee of cooperation in the exploitation of oil and gas reserves, high-level direct investment and developing tourism. What is mainly promoted is the unilateral exploitation by the various trust funds and by the banks of the citizens of the parties. The EU must not interfere in the constitutional reality of Trinidad and Tobago, for example by demanding the abolition of the death penalty. Finally, I find it inconceivable that the visa waiver agreements should be signed and applied provisionally before the European Parliament has given its approval.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to visa exemption for third countries

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. The agreement between the EU and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, which provides for short-stay visa-free travel, must be seen as an opportunity to deepen economic and cultural relations and to intensify political dialogue between the EU and this Caribbean country.  This agreement, which will make it possible to deepen relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, assumes important political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. In this context, it will also be possible to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. For these reasons, including the possibility of developing a solid security partnership, particularly with regard to the fight against drug trafficking and the fight against trafficking in human beings, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the exemption from a visa for short stays. The Agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for Union citizens and citizens of Trinidad and Tobago who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. The agreement facilitates travel and is in itself positive. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. Thanks to this agreement, the European Union will be able to enjoy strengthened economic, social and political relations with the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, while at the same time strengthening the tourism sector.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because Visa liberalisation will simplify travel for businesspeople, facilitate investment and intensify economic links among businesses.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission negotiated an agreement with Trinidad and Tobago on short-stay visa waiver on behalf of the European Union. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for Citizens of the European Union and for citizens of this territory when travelling to Trinidad and Tobago for a maximum duration of 90 days in any 180-day period. At the same time, this agreement represents the culmination and deepening of relations between the European Union and Trinidad and Tobago, which is a politically very important way of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I give my positive opinion to the conclusion of the visa agreement for short stays.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is not a guarantee of cooperation in the exploitation of oil and gas reserves, high-level direct investment and developing tourism. What is mainly promoted is the unilateral exploitation by the various trust funds and by the banks of the citizens of the parties. The EU must not interfere in the constitutional reality of Trinidad and Tobago, for example by demanding the abolition of the death penalty. Finally, I find it inconceivable that the visa waiver agreements should be signed and applied provisionally before the European Parliament has given its approval.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has negotiated on behalf of the EU, an Agreement with the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago – which is politically highly significant an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. – Today we are giving our consent to the conclusion of the agreement with the EU, which has already been negotiated with the European Commission. The purpose of the proposal on visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. We support today’s resolution and believe that it is important to have a good agreement because it helps to fight organised crime and terrorist organisations.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and the Republic of Tobago, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as a new instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  The agreement will dynamise tourism and strengthen relations in the area of trade and investment, as it is the EU's second most important trading partner in Trinidad and Tobago. The visa waiver will simplify travel for investors, thereby facilitating investment. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the agreement to contribute to the deepening of political and trade relations between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago. I am convinced that visa-free trade relations, tourism and mutual knowledge of our societies will increase.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago because I believe that this agreement brings EU and Central American citizens closer and strengthens the tourism sector of both signatory parties. The Commission's negotiation of an agreement with Trinidad and Tobago, already provisionally in force, for the elimination of visas in the event of short stays follows similar procedures negotiated with the Commonwealth of Dominica, the Republic of Vanuatu, Samoa, the United Arab Emirates, Grenada, East Timor, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. I believe that the agreement will really strengthen economic relations between the two parties, allowing our entrepreneurs access to those markets, strengthening trade, increasing investment in the country, increasing tourism and promoting the cultural growth of the country. In particular, this cultural growth may lead to a strengthening of democracy, the rule of law, fundamental freedoms and human rights in a country that is already at the forefront of the region, but which will benefit even more from the EU's openness and proximity.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today, as coordinator of my group for the EU-ACP dialogue, for the recommendation on the EU-Trinidad and Tobago visa waiver agreement, because I believe that rapprochement is valuable and, for me, includes the simplification of tourist bureaucracies.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The agreement is a further step towards intensifying cooperation between the countries of Europe and Trinidad and Tobago. Especially uncomplicated short stays make an important contribution to cultural exchange and economic development.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning the short-stay visa waiver programme which allows for EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement takes into account the situation of the Member States that are not part of Schengen, such as Ireland and the UK.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Visa waiver agreements for short stays represent a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With this agreement the citizens of the EU would have the opportunity to travel visa-free to the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. This will come as good news to the families in the West Midlands who have relatives in this Caribbean republic. I voted in favour of this agreement because it will bring people closer and will boost tourism.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As with the majority of my constituents in Wales, I do not feel that it is the place of the EU to decide who can and cannot come into my country. I voted against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the short-stay visa waiver because a visa waiver agreement helps the EU promote reforms in third countries in relation to strengthening respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the reports because as ACPL we have always taken a positive attitude towards a general visa regime for third-country travellers, although we disagree with the procedure followed, as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote for this agreement. As regards the political and institutional situation in Trinidad and Tobago, civil and political rights are guaranteed by the constitution and respected in the country. The Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is a stable, democratic country, which, like the European Union, defends the values and principles of democracy, good governance and respect for human rights and the rule of law. Its high governance standards and its good practices in this regard afford every reason to continue the development of our relations with the country. This agreement will increase tourism and help to intensify trade and investment relations, the EU being ranked second among the trading partners of Trinidad and Tobago. The visa waiver will simplify conditions for travel by businesspeople and will facilitate investment. The Republic of Trinidad and Tobago has one of the most dynamic and prosperous economies in CARICOM, because of the oil and gas resources, the high levels of direct investment and growing tourism.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Short-stay visa waiver agreements, which would provide visa-free travel for citizens, were signed in May 2015 between the EU and St Lucia, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St Vincent and the Grenadines, the Republic of Vanuatu, the independent State of Samoa, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, the United Arab Emirates and Timor-Leste. The visa would cover a period of 90 days out of any 180-day period. The agreement has received unanimous support in the Council and will not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland. Since this agreement will likely increase commercial opportunities through increased tourism and promote commercial opportunities, which I strongly support, I voted in favour of this report. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If we take the particular case of Trinidad and Tobago, I do not see any particular difficulty in lifting the requirement for a short-stay visa, that is, three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of that Caribbean state, which is predominantly U.S.-oriented. The risk of migration is very low. However, beyond the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, I wonder about the strategic choice of granting short-stay visa exemptions in turn when for some of these countries, particularly those in the Western Balkans, the risk of migration and to the internal security of the Member States of the European Union actually exists. There is a regulation that lists a positive list of countries whose nationals are exempt from the short-stay visa requirement. These countries are now 42 including the United States and Japan and will soon be 61. Should this list not be revised in light of international upheavals?

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report on the Cotonou Agreement regarding the waiver of short-stay visas as an important step forward for the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago’s economic and cultural area.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the abolition of short-stay visas, as it is of utmost importance to facilitate the travel of European Union citizens in third countries, to encourage human contacts, to strengthen tourism and to strengthen the economy.  The European Union is the second economic partner of Trinidad and Tobago, and therefore visa liberalisation will ease travel conditions for entrepreneurs and investors. On top of that, Trinidad and Tobago are rich in oil and gas, and are also showing signs of a growing tourism sector. On the other hand, as regards the political and institutional situation, Trinidad and Tobago respect the fundamental values of the European Union in the domain of fundamental and human rights and values, although further efforts are needed. Moreover, it poses no threat to illegal migration, security and public order, and I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment, and boost tourism. It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order. Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted against this legislative vote with my fellow UKIP MEPs regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With my vote, I supported the lifting of the visa requirement for short stays of citizens of selected ACP Group partner countries and the United Arab Emirates in the European Union. This measure concerning exclusively safe countries with an excellent level of cooperation with European countries will increase the interest of non-European tourists in visiting EU countries. At the same time, reciprocal visa waiver for short stays will greatly facilitate travel by Union citizens to the countries concerned.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. The European Parliament was to decide on the conclusions of the agreement between the Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago which was negotiated by the Commission.  The aim was to facilitate the obtaining of visas. Citizens of both groups will be exempt from visas for stays of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. This exemption does not apply to people who will be travelling on business. This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the visa exemption at this time. This raises security concerns that would not be responsible for Europe in this situation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the agreement as it provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will boost tourism.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU is the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago's second largest trading partner. The agreement approved today will give a greater boost to tourism and help to strengthen relations in the field of trade and investment. I have decided to give a positive opinion because, in addition to the economic reasons, this agreement will further strengthen cooperation in key areas such as human rights and the fight against trafficking in human beings.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the EU-Trinity and Tobago visa waiver agreement for short-term stays. According to Gabriel's report, the country in question poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants would be high, with a relatively low rate of visa refusal. Visa liberalisation simplifies travel conditions. However, we have a duty to ask ourselves whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted against the agreement because they are opposed to visa exemption for short-term stays, which it endorses. Visas are necessary to ensure national security, except for our reliable partners, especially European ones.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution promotes visa waiver for short-term stays between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago, deepening the relations already established through the Cotonou Agreement and the CELAC-European Union dialogues.  The signed agreement provides for a visa-free travel arrangements for EU nationals and those of Trinidad and Tobago travelling for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days.  Trinidad and Tobago's economy is one of CARICOM's most dynamic and prosperous thanks to oil and gas resources, increasing tourism and high levels of direct investment. Its commitment to democracy, good governance, human rights and the rule of law make democracy a full partner of the EU. So I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago for the exemption from short-stay visas has been concluded. The agreement provides for a visa-free regime for Citizens of the European Union, and for the citizens of Trinidad and Tobago a visa for a maximum period of 90 days for a period of 180 days when they travel to the territory of the European Union. I supported Mariya Gabriel's report because the agreement was concluded and signed in accordance with the Council Decision, applies on an interim basis and requires the consent of the European Parliament to enter into force.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trinidad and Tobago is one of the most developed and richest countries in the Western Hemisphere, whose relations with the European Union have generally evolved for the first decade. Tourism, sport, energy, trade, investment, ecology – all this and much more form the cornerstone of interpersonal relations. Moreover, in terms of reciprocal visits, an absolute majority of the inhabitants of this Small Antilyle country travelling within the Schengen area are considered honest travellers, with the number of visa refusals not exceeding 0.3% last year. The Caribbean occupies an important part of the EU's diplomatic efforts, and Trinidad and Tobago is undeniably one of the most important regional actors in this respect. Consequently, the abolition of the short-stay visa regime would be another positive step capable of bringing a strong impetus to the development of our mutual relations.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This May 2015 Agreement allows citizens of the Contracting Parties to travel without a visa to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. The lifting of the visa requirement applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason other than the pursuit of a paid activity. It will also boost tourism and contribute to strengthening trade and investment relations. The agreement also creates scope to address the issues of abolishing the death penalty or promoting the rights of women and children, which are a priority for the Union. Due to its strict rules, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago can become a key security partner, in particular as regards the fight against drug smuggling and the fight against trafficking in human beings.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Commonwealth of Trinidad and Tobago on the short-stay visa waiver because it is not complete and documented.  Furthermore, it is well probable that the implementation of this Recommendation will be used by potential beneficiaries to enter the EU without a visa and then illegally extend their stay in the Union after the expiry of the present short stay, thereby contributing to the increase in illegal immigration within the Union.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to vote for this report as this agreement will dynamise tourism and help to intensify trade and investment relations, the EU being ranked second among the trading partners of Trinidad and Tobago. The visa waiver will simplify conditions for travel by business people and will facilitate investment.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. As with the previous ones, this is a whole series of agreements on the exemption of short-stay visas with several countries.  The agreement is expected to help boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations with these partners.  The key to these agreements is trust: the rate of visa refusal is very low because countries have confidence in visa applicants. According to the rapporteur, the countries covered by these agreements do not pose a threat, either in terms of irregular migration or security.  In view of the mass immigration that we are experiencing and which the EU is no longer able to manage, in view of the risks and the recent attacks against France, we can only be surprised, if not worried, by this sudden desire for openness. Perhaps the timing is not the most timely!

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Annex II to Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 also includes the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago among third countries exempt from visas when crossing external borders for short stays. According to that agreement, nationals of the European Union and of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago shall be exempt from this obligation if they travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The agreement, which has great political value, is an instrument that strengthens economic and cultural relations and focuses on issues of human rights and fundamental freedoms. That is why I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of Mr Gabriel's report on the short-stay visa waiver agreement for EU citizens and citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. This agreement represents a further deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago and has the function of strengthening political dialogue and economic and cultural relations. The agreement will boost tourism and help strengthen relations in the area of trade and investment, also considering that the EU is the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago's second largest trading partner.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the EU-Trinidad-Tobago agreement to dispense with the visa for stays of less than 90 days. I hope that this agreement will enable tourism to be activated and contribute to strengthening trade and investment relations, as the EU is Trinidad and Tobago's second trading partner.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On the merits of the case, I am in favour of short-stay visa exemptions in order to facilitate the mobility and travel of citizens of two parties, in this case the Member States in Trinidad and Tobago and vice versa. Nevertheless, I regret that the French Overseas Are Excluded from it.  On form, I denounce all this procedure. Only the Commission has the power to negotiate these agreements on behalf of states and citizens. It does not keep the European Parliament informed of the state of the negotiations until the very end of the process. Above all, these agreements are implemented even before the European Parliament gives its approval or not. An exemplary witness that democracy has no place in the Union (note that the same procedure will be applied in the case of the transatlantic agreement). In these circumstances, I vote against

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  With regard to the United Arab Emirates, it should be noted that 150,000 EU nationals are based there and, for the most part, are working there. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the United Arab Emirates each year and some 230,000 Emiratis travel to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism.  Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on visa-free travel for short stays. I share the rapporteur's position that this agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, constituting an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, but also for deepening the debate and political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Trinidad and Tobago when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I chose to support this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the visa-free agreement between the European Union and Trinidad and Tobago. This approval completes a process initiated under the previous Legislature to exempt from visas nationals of several third countries who meet all security, immigration and public order requirements.  I am pleased that among the 9 countries whose bilateral agreements have been approved today are several African-Caribbean-Pacific Group states. The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly has also contributed to the implementation of this visa-free process. The agreement with Trinidad and Tobago will further strengthen the state's relationship with the European Union, particularly in trade policy. Human rights cooperation will also be strengthened.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement on short-stay visa waiver between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago resulted from good relations between the two parties. The importance of this agreement is to bring dynamism to tourism, to strengthen cooperation in the field of trade and to facilitate investment. The economy of Trinidad and Tobago is one of the most dynamic within the Caribbean Community thanks to its richness in natural resources, high levels of direct investment and beneficial tourism. The Union sees a functional partner in the country as a result of a liberal, diversified economy focused on foreign investment. Both parties protect the same democratic values, defend human rights, and political dialogue on the abolition of the death penalty and the promotion of rights in women and children remain a priority for the Union. The Republic of Trinidad and Tobago may become an important partner of the Union, so it is desirable to give its consent to the Agreement.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Trinidad and Tobago agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of this territory when travelling to Republic of Trinidad and Tobago for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago – which is politically highly significant, an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should wisely allow legal access to third country nationals, as one of the means of both managing migration and protecting its good image, consistent with its values. Of course, reciprocity should also always be sought, in order to also benefit directly EU citizens when travelling abroad. I supported the agreement on the short-stay visa waiver with Trinidad and Tobago as part of this menu of wisdom.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2014, the Republics of Trinidad and Tobago were among the third countries whose nationals are exempt from visa requirements when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently negotiated a bilateral agreement to this end between 12 December and 15 December 2014 between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and the Republic of Tobago. The agreement was corked in Brussels on 28 May 2015 and has been awaiting parliament's approval ever since. In its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs voted in favour of approving the agreement and voted in favour of the draft accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. These agreements provide for visa exemption for short-term stays for listed countries, in order to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants in these countries is high, with a historically low visa refusal rate. According to the rapporteur, the countries in question pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order.  However, the question arises as to whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. The answer is no, hence a vote against.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has established a visa-free agreement for short stays for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, in connection with travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days, and the European Parliament therefore approved the agreement.  Visa facilitation enables peoples to be rapproched and economic, cultural and political relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago strengthened the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement, a partnership agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the European Union and its Member States. Several categories of persons, regardless of the reason for visiting the country, are covered by this visa facilitation agreement, except in the case of paid activities.  I am voting in favour of this agreement, because I consider it essential to establish relations between the European Union and other communities, which will provide benefits for both sides in the economic, political and social field and enhance bilateral cooperation dialogues.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the previous report on Vanuatu, it is about liberalizing the issuance of visas, but this time with Trinidad and Tobago. For the reasons mentioned above (visa exemption which comes at a time when the Union is unable to control who is in its territory), I voted against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which ratifies the agreement on short-stay visa waiver and allows for EU citizens and citizens of the participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. The aim was to allow the visa-free travel regime for European and Trinidad and Tobago nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by our colleague Mariya Gabriel on the agreement on the short-stay visa exemption between the European Union and Trinidad and Tobago. These agreements provide for a visa-free travel regime for nationals of both parties concerned who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period. The visa exemption covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, apart from paid activity.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I vote in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and the Republic of Tobago on the exemption from short-stay visas. This agreement provides an excellent opportunity to boost tourism, facilitate investment and dynamise trade, thereby increasing the importance of economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the higher state. In addition, the agreement offers new allies to join forces on issues of such importance as the fight against terrorism.  We also see the emergence of political dialogue as a positive, most often aimed at joint action against corruption, criminal networks and trafficking in human beings.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Recommendation on the draft Council decision that provides a visa-free travel agreement for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. As in my previous explanations of vote, I would have opposed this recommendation in this vote. For me, visa-free travel for certain countries is out of the question.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Trinidad and Tobago is democratic and stable and defends the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law. The agreement will stimulate tourism and help strengthen relations in the area of trade and investment.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The achievement and adoption of an agreement between the EU and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, allowing visa-free travel for short stays, is an important step towards closer rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and those of the Caribbean and, more generally, a politically relevant instrument under the Cotonou Agreement. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the exemption from the short-stay visa requirement. I welcome the further development of friendly relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. I am pleased that the visa waiver covers all categories of persons wishing to facilitate travel and short-term stay without a visa, of a maximum of 90 days in any period within 180 days from the date of the first registered entry. The agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago to stay without a visa on the territory of the other Contracting Party. This also offers numerous opportunities not only for the citizens of trinidad and tobago, but also for EU citizens through new business opportunities and facilitation of travel.  Due to the close relationship between the European Union and Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, in particular on the basis of the association agreements of those countries to the implementation, application and development of the Schengen acquis, I call on those countries to conclude bilateral visa waiver agreements with the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago for a short stay containing provisions as in this Agreement.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the previous ones, this report deals with the liberalisation of visa issuance, but this time with Trinidad and Tobago. For the reasons mentioned above (visa exemption which comes at a time when the Union is unable to control who is in its territory), I voted against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the abolition of short-stay visas for citizens of Trinidad and Tobago within the European Union, with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. I believe this decision will enhance EU-Trinidad-Tobago cooperation and boost exchanges and developments, which is why I supported this proposal.  Citizens of my country, Croatia, can already travel to Trinidad and Tobago without a visa, which makes it appropriate to provide the same to the citizens of this country. I hope that the EU will consistently stick to visa reciprocity rules with third countries that do not yet apply the same visa regime for nationals of all 28 member states.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I support the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the waiver of short-stay visas. The Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is one of the signatories to the Cotonou Agreement and is a strong partner of the European Union.  Trinidad and Tobago has one of the most advanced economies in CARICOM (Caribbean community) thanks to large sources of oil and gas. Also, it is a very desirable destination for foreign investments. In a political context, the Constitution of Trinidad and Tobago firmly protects the civil and political rights of citizens and, like the European Union, successfully implements democratic processes.  Experience shows that the vast majority of travellers travel in good faith and only 0.3% of short-term visa applications were rejected last year. This is why I believe that Trinidad and Tobago do not pose any security risk or risk of secret immigration in the EU. I believe that the conclusion of this agreement is the next step in relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, which will increase trade and tourism.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement in question provides for visa-free travel for Union citizens and citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. The economy of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is one of the most dynamic and prosperous in Caricom (Caribbean Community) thanks to the presence of natural resources such as oil and gas and a growing tourism sector. I voted in favour because the EU is the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago's second largest trading partner and the visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs and facilitate investment. I therefore hope that this agreement will make it possible to strengthen relations between the two parties and that it will give new impetus to trade.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the approval of the agreement between the European Union and Trinidad and Tobago to remove the visa requirement for short stays, i.e. less than 90 days for all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic). Indeed, it is important that European citizens can travel to Trinidad and Tobago without a visa and vice versa. This visa exemption should, I hope, support the tourism sector in this Caribbean island.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. This agreement seals the visa exemption for very short stays and on the basis of reciprocity with Trinidad and Tobago, a way to smooth the movements of our nationals, whether for tourism or business.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that Regulation, the Council authorised the Commission on 9 October 2014 to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. The negotiations were concluded on 15 December 2014 and the Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015.  The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period.  Because I believe that this is an important agreement to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago, being of high political importance and also provides an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this draft agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago with regard to the short-stay visa exemption, which has already been applied on an interim basis since May 2015. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and third country nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  It should be noted that the United Kingdom and Ireland do not participate in these agreements and are not subject to the provisions of these agreements, as are the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Proposal for a Recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the exemption from visas for short stays. Although the main objective is to strengthen the EU's relations with Trinidad and Tobago - which have been taking place in recent decades under the Cotonou Agreement, I would like to point out that Trinidad and Tobago is a stable country that upholds democratic principles, the protection of human rights and the rule of law and it was compliance with these principles that made the agreement possible.  The conclusion of the Agreement also contributed to the intensification of trade and investment relations as well as the tourism promotion with Trinidad and Tobago, which were the motto for facilitating the agreement and concluding it.  Thus, European citizens travelling to Trinidad and Tobago (and each other from Trinidad and Tobago) will be able to enjoy free short-stay visas, except when the motivation for travel is due to the exercise of paid activities.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Trinidad and Tobago nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for up to 90 days of 180-day stay. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, which will bring benefits for tourism, trade and innovation. It strengthens the economic and cultural relations of the contracting countries under the Agreement. In fact, visa-free travel simplifies travel conditions, facilitates investment and promotes an open and liberal trade policy.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Trinidadian citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted — with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments - I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement approved by the European Parliament today lays down new provisions for visa-free travel for UNION citizens and citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for their stay. This agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that State, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic, tourist and cultural relations and, finally, will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in any visa policy so I voted against this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With this agreement the citizens of the EU would have the opportunity to travel visa-free to the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. This will come as good news to the families in the West Midlands who have relatives in this Caribbean republic. I voted in favour of this agreement because it will bring people closer and will boost tourism.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is a good signal that the EU facilitates travel to remote countries such as Trinidad and Tobago in the Caribbean. Lifting visa requirements for stays of less than 90 days will promote economic and cultural relations, but will also benefit from intensifying political dialogue. Trinidad and Tobago is one of the Caribbean Community's most dynamic and prosperous economies and the preferred destination for foreign direct payments. Although Trinidad and Tobago are already a democratic and stable country, this agreement makes it possible to deepen cooperation on human rights issues. The abolition of the visa requirement also relates to the fact that already today most Schengen visa applicants are considered to be well-intentioned travellers and do not pose a risk to the EU. On the contrary, a country can become a key partner in the fight against illegal migration, drug smuggling and human trafficking. The impact that the abolition of visas will have on the convergence of the European and Caribbean populations is also not inconsiderable, which in the long term could lead to the development of the private sector and trade relations.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this amendment to the agreement between the European Union and Trinidad and Tobago taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Also, such a proposal to amend the agreement improves relations between these countries.  By abolishing short-stay visas, it allows citizens to gain new experiences and promote mobility development. After their stay in the European Union, citizens can transfer their newfound experiences to the country from which they come and thus further improve relations between the European Union and the country in question, as well as the situation in their country. And in an indirect way they promote the European Union in their own country.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement which will allow EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.  The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver programme takes into account the situation of Member States not part of Schengen, such as the UK and Ireland.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Negotiations on a visa waiver agreement with Trinidad and Tobago and four other Caribbean countries began in Brussels on 12 November 2014. The agreement allows European Union citizens and Trinidad and Tobago nationals to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period.  The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, official and special passport) whose purpose of the trip does not include the performance of paid activity. Each Member State and Trinidad and Tobago may introduce a visa requirement for nationals of another Party under applicable Union or national law for that category. The agreement takes into account the position of Member States that do not yet fully apply the Schengen acquis.  I support the Council's decision to abolish visas with Trinidad and Tobago, as I believe that by abolishing visas we develop friendly relations between the Contracting Parties and facilitate travel by ensuring entry and short-term stay without visas for our citizens.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the short-stay visa waiver. I support the lifting of the VISA requirement between the EU and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago for all types of purposes (tourism, cultural or business visit), except for paid work. As the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is an economically viable country and as such attractive for foreign direct investment, the European Union will, in my opinion, gain enormously by concluding an agreement. The agreement will enable entrepreneurs to invest in this country and simplify their business.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These reports relate to the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States. As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and will not take part in the agreement, I abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although we disagree with the procedure followed as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations, we nevertheless voted in favour of the reports because as ACPL we are in favour of a general visa liberalisation regime for third-country travellers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago is not a guarantee of cooperation in the exploitation of oil and gas reserves, high levels of direct investment and developing tourism. On the contrary, it further promotes the unilateral exploitation of the various trust funds and banks, to the detriment of citizens of the parties. The EU must not interfere with the constitutional reality of Trinidad and Tobago by, for example, demanding the abolition of the death penalty. Finally, it is inconceivable that the practice of signing visa waiver agreements should be applied and that they should be provisionally implemented before they are approved by the European Parliament.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed my political group and the subject matter expert. This visa-free agreement for short-term stays is a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country , which has strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of concluding the Agreement between the European Union and Trinidad and Tobago on the short-stay visa waiver, which was signed in May 2015. It allows visa-free travel for EU citizens and for the citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons, travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I welcome that the Agreement strengthens relations between the EU and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, which is significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. It is also another way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The Cotonu Agreement, which agreed cooperation between EU Member States and the ACP group of countries, namely Trinidad and Tobago, is a good basis for further deepening the cooperation reflected in this report. I believe that the adoption of the agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas can bring mutual benefits for the signatory states, as the EU is the second largest trading partner with Trinidad and Tobago- a state that bases its economic growth on liberal trade policy.  We are also witnessing terrible accidents that have hit and are still affecting the most vulnerable groups of those moving in search of a better life. The benefits of this Agreement are also reflected in possible joint action to combat irregular migration as one of the pressing problems currently facing the Union. In addition to economic, I believe, a high-quality political dimension of security cooperation can be developed in the common fight against illegal migration, trade and people smuggling. So I voted for this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the short-stay visa waiver. The proposal for an agreement on visa facilitation is intended to conclude an agreement with Trinidad and Tobago on facilitating the issuance of short-stay visas.  The Agreement takes into account the fact that some Member States do not fully apply the Schengen acquis. The Agreement also provides for visa-free travel for European Union citizens and citizens of Trinidad and Tobaga when travelling to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of carrying out paid work.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation would simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. However, the question arises as to whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. This inflection in visa policy is contrary to what common sense dictates.  So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and the Republic of Tobago, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as a new instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Trinidad and Tobago.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution that provides visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. This agreement will boost tourism and help to intensify trade and investment relations, the EU being ranked second among the trading partners of Trinidad and Tobago. The visa waiver will simplify travel conditions for business people and will facilitate investment.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament must approve the conclusion of this agreement which has already been negotiated by the European Commission. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, as well as the rapporteur for the agreement, have given a positive recommendation and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report which includes an exemption from the visa requirement for short-stay citizens of Trinidad and Tobago and our own EU citizens. The abolition of the visa requirement shall apply to journeys of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days.
