I am convinced that this agreement will contribute to better trade relations, more investment and more tourism.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the draft Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and that third country on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that third country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the exemption from a visa for short stays. The Agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for Union citizens and citizens of Trinidad and Tobago who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted for the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago on the short-stay visa waiver, because it will, inter alia, abolish travel visa requirements and, in particular, simplify the conditions for entrepreneurs and facilitate investment.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Samoan citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted — with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments - I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement with Samoa for visa exemption for short-term stays.  If, in this report, the liberalisation of visas for short-term stays is presented as an opportunity to boost tourism, simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs or encourage investment, I consider that at present it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude similar agreements.  Faced with a growing terrorist threat and European mass immigration policy, these agreements seem inappropriate to me. Indeed, even if Samoa is not directly a starting point for immigration, I do not think it is appropriate to make this kind of agreement in the current context, regardless of the country concerned.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report gives Parliament the consent to waive the visa requirement to stay for up to three months (90 days) over a period of 6 months (180 days). As this decision represents significant progress in bilateral relations between the European Union and Samoa, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement requires the exemption of short-stay visas for people from Samoa. The aim is to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for those countries which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  However, it is not appropriate to conclude such agreements, even though the porousness of Europe's borders is the bed of terrorism in Europe. Moreover, together with my colleagues from the National Front, we oppose this desire to create a world without borders. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent with the principles of UKIP to vote against such issues being determined at European Union level. It is for individual sovereign nations to determine their own visa requirements, and to assess whether or not a short-stay visa waiver scheme is appropriate for them. This opposition should not be taken as making any commentary upon the appropriateness of the United Kingdom, hypothetically, making a bilateral agreement with Samoa along similar lines.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the EU-Samoa agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short stays. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and Samoa, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which endorses the agreement with the independent state of Samoa on visa exemption for short-term stays. Since the European Union refuses to control its external borders as it should and has abolished the internal borders of the Schengen area, it is urgent that France regain control of its national borders and enforce its laws, particularly in the area of border return. It is therefore on principle that I am opposed to these types of agreements.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the approval of an agreement exempting Samoa, a democratically stable state, from Schengen visas for a maximum stay of 90 days over a period of 180 days in the European Union and vice versa. This will, in particular, promote political dialogue and economic exchanges with the State. I approved this agreement.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Samoa.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which supports the exemption of visas for short-term stays for citizens of the independent State of Samoa with the aim of facilitating travel between this destination and the European Union (EU). The removal of visas in Samoa will apply to travel of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days, for any tourist, cultural, scientific or business trip, except those in which they are in a paid activity. Visa liberalisation in these countries is part of a proposal by the European Commission which extends to the exemption of visas in nineteen countries. We also call for full reciprocity to be used.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. The report also states that the country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, security or public order.  However, it is questionable whether it is useful to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the Union has lost control over mass immigration. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement establishes visa-free travel for EU and Samoa citizens travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. This measure does not raise any problems of any kind, which is why I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. After the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the Independent State of Samoa was included in the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation on 20 May 2014, and the Council's authorisation, the Commission negotiated and closed the Agreement between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa between November and December 2014. The Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015 in Brussels and the European Parliament is now granting its approval, with my vote in favour.  The signed Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of the Independent State of Samoa travelling to the territory of the other party for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except to pursue a paid activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa on the short stay of visa waiver. This agreement on the short stay of visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the Sovereign State of Samoa, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement establishes visa-free travel for nationals of the European Union and the Member State of The United Kingdom travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party and staying there for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The visa waiver agreement for short-stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order.  I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed visa waiver decision as it implements the eu-Samoa agreement signed in May on visa-free travel for citizens of both communities and countries. This arrangement will apply to journeys of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period.  The exception will be the only trip with the intention of carrying out paid work, which will still require a working visa. This strengthens cooperation between the EU and Samoa also at political level. We know that economic cooperation is already very good, and this agreement will, in my opinion, be further strengthened, particularly in the areas of tourism and financial investment and agriculture. I agree that the lifting of the visa requirement between the two Parties is an important means of bringing European and Pacific nations closer. This agreement will also have a profound impact on the lower financial and practical costs of citizens, and I am pleased to welcome it!

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement with the independent State of Samoa is an important milestone of symbolic and political value: it is a sign of the good path that the EU and its contracting party have taken together in recent years, witnessed by the deepening of political, diplomatic and joint cooperation relations.  An action that facilitates the movement between the citizens of both contractors and which – because of the sign of closeness and trust it represents – will be another instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on the issues to which the European Union and the Member States are attached, not least the protection of the human rights and fundamental freedoms of each human being.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to this report, these visa-free agreements for short-term stays should boost tourism and strengthen our trade relations with the independent state of Samoa. These new provisions will make it easier for entrepreneurs and investors to move around, intensifying economic ties between businesses. Furthermore, this visa liberalisation should not pose a threat in terms of illegal immigration in view of the particularly low visa refusal rate. On the other hand, at a time when Western countries, in particular France, are facing an extremely serious terrorist threat, it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude these agreements. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is also defined by the diversity of business models and economic production, which are protected at European level, and greater openness to third countries can only strengthen the economic mechanisms already formed in the European area. In this respect, the rapprochement between the Peoples of Europe and those of the Pacific Islands is a beneficial decision, and this report is making progress towards deepening relations between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa, the main areas of the Union's economic cooperation with Samoa being the private sector, the water sector and the tourism development sector. As this country has been a stable parliamentary democracy since independence in 1962, which protects fundamental rights and freedoms through the Constitution, the EU's political dialogue with Samoa is an additional possibility of deepening human rights cooperation. Given that no Member State has a consulate in Samoa, which means significant costs for nationals of that country to apply and obtain a visa abroad, exemption from this obligation will be a definite advantage for travel of any kind in the European Union and that is why I support this agreement.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This series of agreements establish visa-free travel for Union citizens and third-country nationals (in this case Samoa) who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for their stay, with the exception of stays for paid employment. These are, in all cases, countries which are not problematic for the European Union. The most are known as "dream tourist destinations". There is no immigration problem in Europe and they are all very small or even small island countries.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important for the Union to intensify political dialogue within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, in order to strengthen not only economic relations, but also dialogue on environmental issues and climate change, an issue that is at the heart of the European and international debate today. That is why I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the independent State of Samoa.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Samoa when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.  Whilst Ireland is not party to this agreement and therefore not subject to its provisions, the intentions are nonetheless very positive and progressive. Most Irish citizens are quite aware of the benefits that this type of agreement brings to citizens of a country as we have a somewhat similar agreement with the US.  It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Samoa, taking on important political significance, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Under reciprocal conditions, visa-free travel also brings benefits for tourist or business travel to the EU and makes it easier for Europeans to visit their family members who have settled in these countries or to travel for professional or tourism reasons. Furthermore, Samoa does not pose a threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the draft Council decision. This short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the independent State of Samoa - taking on a strong political significance under the Cotton Agreement - and is a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  Samoa's economy is one of the most dynamic economies in the Pacific islands. The agricultural sector employs two thirds of human resources and accounts for 90% of exports. The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with 14 countries in the Pacific region, to which the Samoan islands belong. At present, the Main Areas of Economic Cooperation between the Union and the Samoan Islands are the development of the private sector, the water sector and the development of tourism.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Union's Agreement with the Independent State of Samoa on the short-stay visa waiver is a positive effort for cooperation and coexistence, which can only have a positive impact on citizens of both parties. So while there are still many details and procedures that need to be carefully regulated, I believe that this effort should be welcomed and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for UNION citizens and citizens of the independent State of Samoa who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling more cheaply and practically.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation because I would like to emphasise that no Member State has a consulate in Samoa and that Samoan citizens therefore have to bear huge costs in applying for and obtaining a visa abroad. The exemption will therefore bring undoubted benefits for tourist or business travel to the European Union. Furthermore, I would remind you that the Samoan economy is one of the most dynamic of the Pacific islands, where the agricultural sector employs two thirds of the workforce and accounts for 90% of exports. The EU is currently negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with 14 countries in the Pacific region, including Samoa. Finally, the main areas of economic cooperation between the Union and Samoa are still the development of the private sector, the water sector and the development of tourism. I am convinced that improving the economy and agriculture is one of the aims of the European People's Party, not to mention the tourist advantages that the citizens of the Union will be able to enjoy thanks to this agreement.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote because the agreements will encourage people-to-people contacts, boost tourism, and invigorate business between the EU and these countries

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 To cross the external border of the European Union, third-country nationals need to hold a visa, in this case of short duration. However, many countries are already exempt from this obligation because they meet a set of criteria approved in 2001 and 2014 by the European Parliament and the Council, which include respect for fundamental rights, security of the visa issuance system or risk of illegal immigration. The visa waiver goes far beyond benefits for European tourists and the third country. Rather, it can enhance rapprochement and dialogue between cultures, economic growth, as well as contributed to the consolidation of democratic regimes.  So I am pleased to see Samoa on the list of exempt countries for short stays.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the independent State of Samoa as it will foster the development of the private sector and tourism. In particular, it will help to improve trade relations with regard to imports of agricultural products such as palm oil, coffee and fish products. In addition, this visa waiver agreement could have a positive impact on investment and the development of the tourism sector. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the agreement as it will help to strengthen economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the independent state of Samoa and to intensify political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The purpose of the proposal on the visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement with Samoa on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Samoa when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Border crossing has never been a marginal issue. Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listed third countries in which nationals had to hold a visa in order to enter the host State. With the negotiations that began in November 2014, the regulation is drastically amended. With visa waiver agreements, citizens of the State of Samoa no longer have to hold a visa, but can cross borders with an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport that is valid. According to the agreement, the stay must be short and must not have work purposes. A national of one of the signatory States may travel to the territory of the other State for a maximum of 90 days over a period of 180 days. As I believe that this resolution can bring benefits to the current short-stay visa waiver agreements, I am voting in favour of this issue.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Samoan citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted — with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments - I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa are governed by the Partnership Agreement (Cotonou Agreement) between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part. The Independent State of Samoa has been transferred to third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Agreement was signed in Brussels on 28 May 2015. Since then, the agreement has been applied provisionally, pending the approval of the European Parliament, which has just been granted by the EP. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Independent State of Samoa for travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (private, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) and to travel for any purpose other than the pursuit of gainful activity. The visa waiver agreement may have a particularly positive impact on investment and the development of the tourism sector. In particular, none of the EU Member States has a consulate in Samoa, which means that nationals of that country can only apply for and receive visas abroad at considerable costs. A visa waiver would therefore confer a clear advantage on tourist or business trips to the Union.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report is about the negotiation of the Commission with Samoa on a short-stay visa waiver. This agreement represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Samoa – which is politically highly significant, an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues. For these reasons I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this agreement with Samoa will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen member states, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to the European Parliament to approve the conclusion of the agreement between the Union and Samoa, negotiated by the European Commission, which aims to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas. It allows EU citizens and Samoan citizens to obtain a free visa on the territory of all contracting parties for up to 90 days over a period of 180 days. This visa applies to all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, official and special passport holders) travelling for any type of reason except for paid activities.  Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report which aims to introduce a short-stay visa exemption measure between the Member States of the European Union and Samoa. In particular, this agreement will provide a definite advantage to nationals of the independent State of Samoa wishing to travel to the Union and promote tourism in Europe.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The Gabriel report aimed to remove the visa requirement for the Commonwealth of Dominica, Vanuatu, Trinidad and Tobago, Samoa, Grenada, East Timor, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the United Arab Emirates. These countries certainly do not pose a risk of uncontrolled immigration or a disturbance of public order. However, at a time when Islamist terrorists are looking for the slightest flaw in our defence in order to attack us, I do not find it appropriate to exempt certain countries from visas and to facilitate in general, access to our territory from non-European countries. Although I am in favour of closer economic ties with these countries, I cannot knowingly take the risk of allowing ill-intentioned people to take advantage of this to harm European security. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In May this year, an agreement was signed to abolish short-stay visas between the EU and seven countries in the so-called Region of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, including China. I supported the report as I believe that as one of the most dynamic in the Pacific Islands region, Lonelia has significant development potential. The abolition of short-stay visas is an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural ties and strengthening political dialogue on a number of issues and, last but not least, could have a positive impact on investment and the development of the tourism sector.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I consider it wrong to sign a short-stay visa waiver agreement for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Samoan islands because such an exemption does not constitute a significant advantage for tourist or business travel, on the other hand it will not have a positive impact on investment and development in the tourism sector. Account must be taken of the large migration flows of Samoan citizens to the US and what will happen if these flows are directed towards the EU.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to visa-free travel for third countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Independent State of Samoa who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. All categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) benefit from visa-free travel, regardless of the reason for travel, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. The agreement facilitates travel and is in itself positive. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the independent State of Samoa. This agreement will be an effective instrument for intensifying political, cultural and economic relations between the two countries. In addition, the visa waiver will undoubtedly bring benefits for tourist or business travel to the European Union.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because visa liberalisation will simplify travel for business people, facilitate investment and intensify economic links among businesses.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has negotiated an agreement with Samoa on short-stay visa waivers on behalf of the European Union. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for Citizens of the European Union and for citizens of this territory when travelling to Samoa for a maximum duration of 90 days in any 180-day period. At the same time, this agreement represents the culmination and deepening of relations between the European Union and Samoa, which is a politically very important way of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I give my positive opinion to the conclusion of the visa agreement for short stays.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the EU-Samoa Agreement because I think the short-stay visa waiver agreement is wrong for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Samoan islands, because it will neither create a significant advantage for tourist or business travel nor have a positive impact on investment and development in the tourism sector. I am thinking about the large migration flows of Samoan citizens to the US and what will happen if these flows are directed towards the EU.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has negotiated on behalf of the EU, an agreement with the Independent State of Samoa on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement can only be concluded if the European Parliament has given its consent. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of this territory when travelling to the Independent State of Samoa for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa – which is politically highly significant and an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we are giving our consent to the conclusion of the agreement with the EU which has already been negotiated with the European Commission. The purpose of the proposal on visa facilitation is the conclusion of an agreement on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out paid activity. We support today’s resolution and believe that it is important to have a good agreement because it helps to fight organised crime and terrorist organisations.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Samoa's economy is one of the most dynamic of the Pacific island economies. The agricultural sector employs two thirds of workers and accounts for 90% of exports. The EU is currently negotiating a Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement with 14 countries in the Pacific region, including Samoa. The main areas of economic cooperation between the Union and Samoa are the development of the private sector, the development of the water sector and tourism.  In the light of the above, I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the visa waiver agreement taking into account that it could have positive effects, in particular on investment and development in Samoa's tourism sector, which would result in improving the well-being of its citizens.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today, as coordinator of my group for the EU-ACP dialogue, in favour of the recommendation on the EU-Samoa visa waiver agreement for short-stay visas, as I believe that rapprochement is valuable and, for me, includes the simplification of tourist bureaucracies.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The agreement is a further step towards intensifying cooperation between the countries of Europe and Samoa. Especially uncomplicated short stays make an important contribution to cultural exchange and economic development.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning the short-stay visa waiver programme which allows EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement takes into account the situation of the Member States that are not part of Schengen such as Ireland and the UK.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Visa waiver agreements for short stays represent a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Samoa.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement represents a culmination of the deepening relations between the Independent State of Samoa and the European Union. It will bring people closer together and boost tourism. But I also feel that it was incredibly important to vote in favour of this agreement because, although Samoa is a relatively small country, the potential benefits in terms of political dialogue on things like human rights and fundamental freedoms will reveal how much of a beneficial force the European Union is in the world when it comes to extending these norms we hold valuable.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As with the majority of my constituents in Wales, I do not feel that it is the place of the EU to decide who can and cannot come into my country. I voted against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the United States of America on the conclusion of the Visa Waiver for Short Stays on behalf of the European Union, as it will make it easier for EU citizens to travel to EU third countries, to promote people-to-people contacts, to increase tourism and to revitalise business.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the reports because, as ACPL, we have always taken a positive attitude towards a general visa regime for third-country travellers, although we disagree with the procedure followed, as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote for this agreement because a the waiver of short-stay visas simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Samoa has one of the most dynamic economies of all the Pacific islands. Two thirds of the work force is employed in agriculture, which accounts for 90% of exports. Generally, trade and investment between the EU and the Pacific countries remain weak both as regards their value and in relative terms, but they have strong potential for development. The visa waiver agreement could in particular have a positive impact on investment and on the development of tourism.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Short-stay visa waiver agreements, which would provide visa-free travel for citizens were signed in May 2015 between the EU and St Lucia, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St Vincent and the Grenadines, the Republic of Vanuatu, the independent State of Samoa, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, the United Arab Emirates and Timor-Leste. The visa would cover a period of 90 days out of any 180-day period. The agreement has received unanimous support in the Council and will not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland. Since this agreement will likely increase commercial opportunities through increased tourism and promote commercial opportunities, which I strongly support, I have voted in favour of this report. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If we take the particular case of Samoa, I see no particular difficulty in lifting the requirement for a short-stay visa, that is, three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this small constitutional monarchy of 192,000 people located in the Pacific Ocean. The risk of migration is very low. However, beyond the island of Samoa, I wonder about the strategic choice of granting short-stay visa exemptions in turn when, for some of these countries, particularly those in the Western Balkans, the risk of migration and to the internal security of the Member States of the European Union actually exists. There is a regulation that lists a positive list of countries whose nationals are exempt from the short-stay visa requirement. These countries are now 42, including the United States and Japan, and will soon be 61. Should this list not be revised in light of international upheavals?

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the Cotonou agreement regarding the waiver of short-stay visas as an important step forward for the economic and cultural area of the Independent State of Samoa.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa on the waiver of short-stay visas giving consent to the conclusion of it, on the basis that it further strengthens the Cotonou Agreement. The Economy of Samoa is one of the more developed in the Pacific islands region, while the agricultural sector is the strongest branch. Key sectors of cooperation between the Union and Samoa are the development of the private sector, the water sector and the development of tourism.  On the other hand, Samoa is a parliamentary democracy that has shown progress in respecting fundamental freedoms, and political dialogue with the Union is aimed at protecting the environment, human rights and equality between men and women. I believe, therefore, that the Agreement will contribute to economic growth, economic and cultural ties and the launch of a strong tourism sector.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism. It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order. Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems weak. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I, with my fellow UKIP colleagues voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With my vote, I supported the lifting of the visa requirement for short stays of citizens of selected ACP Group partner countries and the United Arab Emirates in the European Union. This measure concerning exclusively safe countries with an excellent level of cooperation with European countries will increase the interest of non-European tourists in visiting EU countries. At the same time, reciprocal visa waiver for short stays will greatly facilitate travel by Union citizens to the countries concerned.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the independent State of Samoa. The European Parliament was to decide on the conclusions of the agreement between the UNION and the independent state of Samoa which was negotiated by the Commission. The aim was to facilitate the obtaining of visas. Citizens of both groups will be exempt from visas for stays of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. This exemption does not apply to people who will be travelling on business. This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the visa exemption at this time. This raises security concerns that would not be responsible for Europe in this situation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the agreement as it provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will boost tourism.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The independent state of Samoa is a growing economic reality, the population of which is mainly engaged in the fisheries, agriculture and tourism sectors. Despite being small, this island, which is a state, is a reliable partner of the EU, in which its citizens invest and stay. I have chosen to vote in favour because I believe that the conclusion of the exemption agreement will have beneficial effects on investment and the development of the tourism sector.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the EU-Samoa visa waiver agreement for short-term stays. According to Gabriel's report, the country in question poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants would be high, with a relatively low rate of visa refusal.  Visa liberalisation simplifies travel conditions. However, we have a duty to ask ourselves whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted against the agreement because they are hostile to the exception of visas for short-term stays, which it endorses. Visas are necessary to ensure national security, except for our reliable partners, especially European ones.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution promotes visa waiver for short-term stays between the EU and Samoa, deepening the relations already established through the Cotonou Agreement agreement. In particular, it is hoped to delve into economic and cultural relations and political dialogue on human rights and fundamental freedoms.   Samoa has one of the most dynamic economies in the Pacific islands despite the great weight of the agricultural sector. It is to be expected that this agreement will have positive results in terms of investment and the tourism sector, as well as in the rapprochement of the European and Pacific peoples.  Since no State of the Union has a consulate in Samoa, the costs associated with obtaining visas are quite high, so exemption from them will contribute significantly to tourism and business travel from the EU.  I therefore declare myself in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ An agreement has been concluded between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa for the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and Samoa and the possibility to stay for a maximum period of 90 days for a period of 180 days on the territory of the Union and Samoa. I supported Mariya Gabriel's report because the agreement was concluded and signed in accordance with the Council Decision, applies on an interim basis and requires the consent of the European Parliament to enter into force.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main sectors of cooperation between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa are currently private sector development, tourism and guaranteeing access to fresh water. Palm oil, coffee and fishery products in turn form the primary part of imports from Samoa. Climate change is another very important area of cooperation, especially given the rather strong exposure of this Pacific country to climate change, firstly, rising sea levels. A highly dynamic economy, a developed parliamentary democracy, where human rights are respected in their various ways – this is the independent State of modern Samoa. In view of the potential future prospects, the abolition of the short-stay visa requirement is an important, logical and productive step that will also help to further develop our mutual relations.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement abolishes the visa requirement for citizens of the Contracting Parties for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. Cancellation shall apply to all categories of persons travelling for any reason other than the pursuit of a paid activity. Samoa's independent state is an independent parliamentary democracy with a strongly developed agriculture. Two thirds of the population work in this sector. Exports of agricultural products account for 90 % of total exports. Migration from the country is currently mainly directed to the US, to the EU to a small extent. In addition to the simplified movement of the population, the agreement creates space for trade, tourism and investment.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa on the short-stay visa waiver, because it is not complete and documented.   Furthermore, it is well probable that the implementation of this Recommendation will be used by potential beneficiaries to enter the EU without a visa and then illegally extend their stay in the Union after the expiry of the present short stay, thereby contributing to the increase in illegal immigration within the Union.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. It should be noted that no EU Member State has a Consulate in Samoa, which means that at present Samoan nationals must incur substantial costs in order to apply for and obtain visas abroad. The visa waiver will therefore constitute a definite advantage for travel to the European Union for purposes of tourism or business.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. As with the previous ones, this is a whole series of agreements on the exemption of short-stay visas with several countries.  The agreement is expected to help boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations with these partners.  The key to these agreements is trust: the rate of visa refusal is very low because countries have confidence in visa applicants. According to the rapporteur, the countries covered by these agreements do not pose a threat, either in terms of irregular migration or security.  In view of the mass immigration that we are experiencing and which the Union is no longer able to manage, in view of the risks and the recent attacks against France, we can only be surprised, if not worried, by this sudden desire for openness. Perhaps the time is not the most opportune!

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the independent State of Samoa. Thanks to this agreement, EU citizens will be able to travel visa-free to the territory of the independent State of Samoa for a short stay. With this agreement, people-to-people contacts will be encouraged, tourism will be fostered and trade relations between the European Union and the independent State of Samoa will be strengthened. Furthermore, from a mobility point of view, recent data show that there is great confidence in the citizens of Samoa applying for visas and the country poses no threat in terms of migration as well as in terms of security and public order.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the Union and of the independent State of Samoa who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. Visa liberalisation would result in one less obstacle than the development of the main areas of economic cooperation between the Eu ropean Union and Samoa, including the private sector, the water sector and the development of tourism. I am therefore voting in favour of Mrs Gabriel's proposal.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. Samoa's economy is one of the most dynamic in the Pacific Islands. The EU is negotiating a comprehensive economic partnership agreement with fourteen countries in the Pacific region, of which Samoa is a part and, at present, the main areas of economic cooperation between the Union and Samoa are private sector development, the water sector and tourism development. I therefore believe that it will be good for these relationships and to make the visa waiver agreement for short-term stays more intensive in the future.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On the merits of the case, I am in favour of short-stay visa exemptions in order to facilitate the mobility and travel of citizens of two parties, in this case the Member States in Samoa and vice versa. Nevertheless, I regret that the French Overseas Are Excluded from it.  On form, I denounce all this procedure. Only the Commission has the power to negotiate these agreements on behalf of states and citizens. It does not keep the European Parliament informed of the state of the negotiations until the very end of the process. Above all, these agreements are implemented even before the European Parliament gives its approval or not, an exemplary witness that democracy has no place in the Union (note that the same procedure will be applied in the case of the transatlantic agreement). In these circumstances, I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism. It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order. With regard to the United Arab Emirates, it should be noted that 150,000 EU nationals are based there and, in most part, they work there. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the United Arab Emirates each year and some 230,000 Emiratis travel to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism. Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems weak. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa on visa-free travel for short stays. I share the rapporteur's position that this agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Independent State of Samora, constituting an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, but also for deepening the debate and political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Samoa when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I chose to support this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Samoans travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for up to 90 days of stay over any 180-day period was discussed at the 8th regional meeting of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly.  I am very pleased to see that we have reached the end of this process initiated in July 2012 in Apia. The conclusion of the bilateral agreement between the EU and the State of Samoa will strengthen the relationship between the two parties, which are already cooperating successfully on key issues relating to human rights, gender equality, climate change and the environment.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Samoa is a small island in the Pacific Ocean with a dynamic economy focused on the agricultural sector. Cooperation between the two Contracting Parties shall focus on the development of the private sector, the water sector and tourism. An agreement on visa waiver between the EU and the Independent State of Samoa would bring many benefits for tourist and business trips to the Union, as no Member State has a consulate in Samoa, which makes it difficult to submit applications and obtain visas. The agreement would therefore mean a reduction in the cost of travel and trade between the Contracting Parties, and mutual trade has the potential for development.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to the EU-Samoa agreement on the short-stay visa waiver, which will provide new visa regime for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will bring people on both sides closer and will boost tourism.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should wisely allow legal access to third country nationals, as one of the means of both managing migration and protecting its good image, consistent with its values. Of course, reciprocity should also always be sought, in order to also benefit directly EU citizens when travelling abroad. I supported the agreement on the short-stay visa waiver with Samoa as part of this possible menu of wisdom.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament and the Council amended Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by regulation of 20 May 2014, classilating the Independent State of Samoa as one of the third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently negotiated a bilateral agreement to this end between 19 November and 15 December 2014 between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa. The agreement was corked in Brussels on 28 May 2015 and has been awaiting parliament's approval ever since. In its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs voted in favour of approving the agreement and voted in favour of the draft accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. These agreements provide for visa exemption for short-term stays for listed countries, in order to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants in these countries is high, with a historically low visa refusal rate. According to the rapporteur, the countries in question pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order.  However, the question arises as to whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. The answer is no, hence a vote against.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has established a visa-free agreement for short-stay stays for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Independent State of Samoa, in connection with travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days, and the European Parliament therefore approves the agreement.  Visa facilitation allows peoples to rapprochement and strengthen economic, cultural and political relations between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa, strengthening the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement, a partnership agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the European Union and its Member States. Several categories of persons, regardless of the reason for visiting the country, are covered by this visa facilitation agreement, except in the case of paid activities.  I am voting in favour of this agreement, because I consider it essential to establish relations between the European Union and other communities, which will provide benefits for both sides in the economic, political and social field and enhance bilateral cooperation dialogues.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. As with previous visa liberalisation reports, I voted against this visa-free text for Samoa, since it is not appropriate to implement this policy at a time when the Union is unable to know who is entering its territory. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which ratifies the agreement on short-stay visa waiver and allows for EU citizens and citizens of the participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and the independent state of Samoa. The aim was to allow the visa-free travel regime for European and Samoan nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by our colleague Mariya GABRIEL on the agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and Samoa. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for nationals of both parties concerned who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period. The visa exemption covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, official service and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except that of a paid activity.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Independent State of Samo on the exemption from short-stay visas. This agreement provides an excellent opportunity to boost tourism, facilitate investment and dynamise trade, thereby increasing the importance of economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the higher state. In addition, the agreement offers new allies to join forces on issues of such importance as the fight against terrorism. We also see the emergence of political dialogue as a positive, most often aimed at joint action against corruption, criminal networks and trafficking in human beings.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation on the draft Council decision that provides a visa-free travel agreement for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Independent State of Samoa when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. – Instead of repeating the mistakes made with the visa waiver for the Western Balkans, Europe should at last take serious care to secure Europe's borders. That is why I would have opposed this agreement.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Samoa's economy is one of the most dynamic in the Pacific Islands. Visa liberalisation provides an advantage for boosting tourism and trade.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The achievement and adoption of an agreement between the EU and the independent State of Samoa, allowing short-stay visa-free travel, is an important step towards closer rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and those of the Caribbean and, more generally, a politically relevant instrument under the Cotonou Agreement. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support an agreement between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa on the exemption from the short-stay visa requirement. I welcome the further development of friendly relations between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa. I am pleased that the visa waiver covers all categories of persons wishing to facilitate travel and short-term stay without a visa, of a maximum of 90 days in any period within 180 days from the date of the first registered entry. The agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Independent State of Samoa to stay without a visa on the territory of the other Contracting Party. This also offers numerous opportunities not only for citizens of the Independent State of Samoa, but also for EU citizens through new business opportunities and facilitation of travel.  Due to the close relationship between the European Union and Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, in particular on the basis of the association agreements of those countries to the implementation, application and development of the Schengen acquis, I call on those countries to conclude bilateral visa waiver agreements with the Independent State of Samoa for short stays containing provisions such as in this Agreement.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. As with previous visa liberalisation reports, I voted against this visa-free text for the Samoan Islands, since it is not appropriate to implement this policy at a time when the Union is unable to know who is entering its territory.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the abolition of short-stay visas for Samoa citizens within the European Union, with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. I believe this decision will enhance EU-Samoa cooperation and boost exchanges and developments, which is why I supported this proposal. Citizens of my country, Croatia, can already travel to Samoa without a visa, which makes it appropriate to provide the same to the citizens of this country. I hope that the EU will consistently stick to visa reciprocity rules with third countries that do not yet apply the same visa regime for nationals of all 28 member states.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – The independent State of Samoa is one of the signatories to the Cotonou Agreement and is a strong partner of the European Union. Samoa has one of the most dynamic economies in the Pacific. Two thirds of the population works in agriculture, which amounts to 90% of total exports. The main areas of cooperation between the EU and the Independent State of Samoa are the development of tourism, the private sector and the water industry.  Samoa has been a stable democratic state since independence in 1962. Fundamental human rights and freedoms are respected and the EU's political dialogue with Samoa focuses on environmental issues and human rights. The information shows that the vast majority of visa applications are accepted and that Samoa poses no security risk to the European Union.  As no member of the European Union has representation in Samoa, the costs of applying for a visa so far have been extremely high. Consequently, I believe that short-term visas between the EU and the Independent State of Samoa should be abolished.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the independent State of Samoa are governed by the Cotonou Agreement. I voted in favour of approving this agreement because, due to the lack of consulates from EU Member States, Samoan citizens have to bear huge costs in applying for and obtaining visas for travel abroad, and therefore any exemption would undoubtedly bring benefits for tourist or business travel to the European Union. In this way, Samoan citizens will be able to benefit fully from the partnership between the ACP (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific) and the EU.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the approval of the agreement between the European Union and Samoa to remove the visa requirement for short stays, i.e. less than 90 days for all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, etc.).  Indeed, it is important that European citizens can return to Samoa without a visa and vice versa. This visa exemption should, I hope, support the tourism sector on this Pacific island.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. This agreement seals the exemption of visas for very short stays and on the basis of reciprocity with Samoa, a way to smooth the movements of our nationals, whether for tourism or business.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the Independent State of Samoa has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that Regulation, the Council authorised the Commission on 9 October 2014 to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the Union and the Independent State of Samoa. The negotiations were concluded on 15 December 2014 and the Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Independent State of Samoa who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period.  Because I believe that this is an important agreement to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa, I voted in favour of its approval.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the EU and Samoa, with high political importance and also provides an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as for intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this draft agreement between the European Union and the independent state of Samoa with regard to the short-stay visa exemption, which has already been applied on an interim basis since May 2015. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and third country nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  It should be noted that the United Kingdom and Ireland do not participate in these agreements and are not subject to the provisions of these agreements, as are the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The strengthening of economic and cultural relations, as well as the political importance of the Agreement between the ACP countries (Africa, Caribbean, Pacific) and the European Union, were fundamental to the will to strengthen bilateral cooperation by concluding this agreement, which, like the other Agreements of the same nature voted today, had been provisionally in force since 6 May last. The Island of Samoa is one of the most dynamic economies in the Pacific Islands, where the agricultural sector accounts for 90% of its exports. The areas of cooperation and economic assistance of the Union with Samoa are mainly concentrated in the private sector, in particular in the water sector and tourism. However, trade relations between the EU and Samoa are so far scarce. However, in view of the fact that no Member State has a consulate on the Island of Samoa, it is expected that in this visa-free agreement the potential for development and growth, particularly in the tourism and business sector, will be an asset, in particular for Samoa, so I have decided to support this Proposal for a Recommendation.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the independent State of Samoa on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Samoans travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official, or special) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the independent State of Samoa as it strengthens economic and cultural relations. The agreement signed allows Union citizens and citizens of the independent State of Samoa to travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons such as holders of an ordinary passport, with the exception of stays for paid employment.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Samoa.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Samoan citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted — with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments - I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.
