name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement approved by the European Parliament today lays down new provisions for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of the independent State of Samoa travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for their stay. This agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic, tourist and cultural relations and, finally, will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in any visa policy so I voted against this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement represents both a culmination of the deepening relations between the Independent State of Samoa and the European Union. It will bring people closer together and boost tourism. But I also feel that it was incredibly important to vote in favour of this agreement because, although Samoa is a relatively small country, the potential benefits in terms of political dialogue on things like human rights and fundamental freedoms will reveal how much of a beneficial force the European Union is in the world when it comes to extending these norms we hold valuable.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement will facilitate travel between the EU and Samoa. Lifting visa requirements for stays of less than 90 days will promote economic and cultural relations, but will also benefit from intensifying political dialogue. Samoa's independent state is one of the most dynamic islands in the Pacific Ocean and has been a stable parliamentary democracy politically since independence in 1962. I also agree with the visa waiver agreement because it will have a positive impact, particularly on investment and the development of tourism, as eu trade with Pacific countries is currently at a low level. The main areas of union cooperation with Samoa include private sector development, the water sector and tourism development. In the future, however, it is also possible to consider extending trade relations over today's imports of palm oil, coffee and fishery products. On international issues, political dialogue with Samoa focuses on environmental problems and climate change, as Samoa, as an island state, is threatened by rising ocean levels. As no Member State of the Union currently has a consulate in Samoa, the lifting of the visa requirement will confer an advantage on tourist and business trips to the EU for the people of that country.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this amendment to the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Samoa taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Also, such a proposal to amend the agreement improves relations between these countries.  The abolition of short-stay visas allows citizens to gain new experiences and promotes the development of mobility. After their stay in the European Union, citizens can transfer their newfound experiences to the country from which they come and thus further improve relations between the European Union and the country in question, as well as the situation in their country. And in an indirect way they promote the European Union in their own country.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement which will allow EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.  The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver programme takes into account the situation of Member States that are not part of Schengen such as the UK and Ireland.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In Council Regulation (EC) No. 539/2001 lists third countries whose nationals must have a visa when crossing the external borders of the Member States and countries whose nationals are exempt from that requirement. Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013 509/2014 Of the European Parliament and the Council, Regulation (EC) No 509/2014 has been amended. 539/2001 by listing third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement, including Samoa.  The visa waiver agreement with Samoa was initialled on 15 December 2014. On the union's part, the legal basis of the agreement is Article 77(2) (a) of the TFEU, in relation to Article 218 there is no such thing as article 77(a) of the TFEU. The agreement allows Citizens of the European Union and Samoa nationals to stay visa-free on the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period. The agreement includes a provision that Samoa may suspend the application of the agreement or cancel it only in relation to all Member States of the European Union and the Union may suspend the application of the agreement or cancel it only in relation to all Member States. I support the Council's decision to conclude this Agreement, as the objectives set by the Council in its negotiating directives have been achieved, the Agreement is acceptable to the Union and the suspension provision ensures equal treatment of all EU citizens.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and Samoa on the short-stay visa waiver. The volume of trade and investment between the European Union and the Pacific countries is small, and by lifting the visa requirement, we will increase this volume and strengthen economic cooperation. In addition to increasing investment between the EU and Samoa, the agreement will also lead to greater development of the tourism sector. The State of Samoa also does not pose a threat in terms of illegal migration, nor in the area of security.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These reports relate to the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States. As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and will not take part in the agreement, I have abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although we disagree with the procedure followed, as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations, we nevertheless voted in favour of the reports because, as ACPL, we are in favour of a general visa liberalisation regime for third-country travellers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Samoan islands is not correct as it does not constitute a significant advantage in terms of tourist or business travel nor will it have a positive impact on investment and development in the tourism sector. We need to take into account the large migration flows of Samoan citizens to the United States and consider what will happen if these flows are directed towards the EU.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed my political group and the subject matter expert. This visa-free agreement for short-term stays is a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country , which has strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of concluding the Agreement between the European Union and Samoa on the short-stay visa waiver, which was signed in May 2015. It allows visa-free travel for EU citizens and for the citizens of the Independent State of Samoa when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons, travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I welcome that the Agreement strengthens relations between the EU and the Independent State of Samoa, which is significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. It is also another way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The links between the Independent State of Samoa and the EU Member States are based on the Cotonou Agreement, which is a comprehensive framework for continued action in the context of empowerment, both political and trade dialogue. I support the rapporteur's position implying that the signing of a short-stay visa waiver agreement for a certain period of 90 days will facilitate the flow of travellers, as no EU Member State has a consulate in the Independent State of Samoa.  Given that the rate of positively resolved visa applications for Samoa nationals is extremely high, which is supported by the fact that most migrants applying for a visa as their preferred destination are listed by the United States, I believe that nonetheless control mechanisms, i.e. monitoring that requires compliance with agreed standards, should not be ignored in order to avoid unintended consequences. I agree that facilitating the flow of passengers in this case can have a positive impact and therefore I voted for this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the Agreement between the European Union and Samoa on the short-stay visa waiver. The proposal for an agreement on visa facilitation is intended to conclude an agreement with Samoa on the facilitation of the issuance of short-stay visas.  The Agreement takes into account the fact that some Member States do not fully apply the Schengen acquis. The Agreement also provides for visa-free travel for European Union citizens and Citizens of Samoa when travelling to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of carrying out paid work.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Samoa.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation would simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. However, the question arises as to whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. This inflection in visa policy is contrary to what common sense dictates.  So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Samoa.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of providing visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the Republic of Independent State of Samoa when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. Currently no EU Member State has a Consulate in Samoa, which means that at present Samoan nationals must incur substantial costs in order to apply for and obtain visas abroad. The visa waiver will therefore constitute a definite advantage for travel to the European Union for purposes of tourism or business.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament must approve the conclusion of this agreement which has already been negotiated by the European Commission. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, as well as the rapporteur for the agreement, have given a positive recommendation and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report which includes an exemption from the short-stay visa requirement for samoan citizens and our own EU citizens. The abolition of the visa requirement shall apply to journeys of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. I am convinced that this agreement will contribute to better trade relations, more investment and more tourism.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the draft Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and that third country on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that third country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa on visa-free travel for short stays The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Independent State of Samoa who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. All categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) benefit from visa-free travel, regardless of the reason for travel, with the exception of a paid activity. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Independent State of Samoa on the short-stay visa waiver, because I believe that the visa waiver will further strengthen the cooperation of European and Caribbean nations and will also have a positive impact on the trade exchange and development of the tourism sector.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Granadan citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted – with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments – I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement with Grenada for visa exemption for short-term stays. If in this report the liberalisation of visas for short-term stays is presented as an opportunity to boost tourism, simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs or encourage investment, I consider that at present it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude similar agreements.  Faced with a growing terrorist threat and European mass immigration policy, these agreements seem inappropriate to me. Indeed, even if Grenada is not directly a starting point for immigration, I do not think it is wise to make this kind of agreement in the current context, regardless of the country concerned.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report gives Parliament the consent to waive the visa requirement to stay for up to three months (90 days) over a period of 6 months (180 days). As this decision represents progress in bilateral relations between the European Union and Grenada, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement requires the exemption of short-stay visas for people coming from Granada. The aim is to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for those countries which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  However, it is not appropriate to conclude such agreements, even though the porousness of Europe's borders is the bed of terrorism in Europe. Moreover, together with my colleagues from the National Front, we oppose this desire to create a world without borders. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent with the principles of UKIP to vote against such issues being determined at European Union level. It is for individual sovereign nations to determine their own visa requirements, and to assess whether or not a short-stay visa waiver scheme is appropriate for them. This opposition should not be taken as making any commentary upon the appropriateness of the United Kingdom, hypothetically, making a bilateral agreement with Grenada along similar lines.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the agreement between the EU and Grenada on visa-free travel in the case of short stays. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and Grenada, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which endorses the agreement with Grenada on visa exemption for short-term stays. Since the European Union refuses to control its external borders as it should and has abolished internal borders in the Schengen area, it is urgent that France regain control of its national borders and enforce its laws, particularly in the area of border return. It is therefore on principle that I am opposed to these types of agreements.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the approval of an agreement exempting nationals of Granada, a democratically stable state, from Schengen visas for a maximum stay of 90 days over a period of 180 days in the European Union. This will, in particular, promote political dialogue and economic exchanges with the State. I approved this agreement.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Grenada.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which supports the visa waiver for short-term stays for the citizens of Granada with the aim of facilitating travel between this destination and the European Union (EU). The elimination of visas in Granada will apply to travel of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days, for any tourist, cultural, scientific or business trip, except those in a paid activity. Visa liberalisation in these countries is part of a proposal by the European Commission which extends to the exemption of visas in nineteen countries. We also call for full reciprocity to be used.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. The report also states that the country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, security or public order.  However, it is questionable whether it is useful to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the Union has lost control over mass immigration. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement establishes visa-free travel for EU and Grenada citizens travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. This measure does not raise any problems of any kind, which is why I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. After the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, Granada was included in the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation on 20 May 2014, and with the authorisation of the Council, the Commission negotiated and closed the bilateral agreement between the European Union and Grenada between November and December 2014. The Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015 in Brussels and the European Parliament is now granting its approval, with my vote in favour.  The signed agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and Nationals of Granada travelling to the territory of the other party for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Grenada on the short stay of visa waiver. This agreement on the short stay of visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and Grenada, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Grenada travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party and staying there for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The visa waiver agreement for short-stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order.  I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed visa waiver decision as it implements the EU-Grenado agreement signed in May on visa-free travel for citizens of both communities and countries. This arrangement will apply to journeys of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period. The exception will be the only trip with the intention of carrying out paid work, which will still require a working visa.  This strengthens cooperation between the EU and the Grenado at political level as well. We know that economic cooperation is already very good, and this agreement will, in my view, be further strengthened, particularly in the area of tourism and financial investment. I am convinced that this kind of cooperation will help, above all, to strengthen tourism, which, unlike neighbouring island states, is not as well developed. I agree that the abolition of the visa requirement between the two Parties is an important means of bringing European and Caribbean nations closer. This agreement will also have a profound impact on the lower financial and practical costs of citizens, and I am pleased to welcome it!

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement with the territory of Grenada is an important milestone of symbolic and political value: it is a sign of the good path that the EU and its contracting party have taken together in recent years, witnessed by the deepening of political, diplomatic and joint cooperation relations. An action that facilitates the movement between the citizens of both contractors and which – because of the sign of closeness and trust it represents – will be another instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on the issues to which the European Union and the Member States are attached, not least the protection of the human rights and fundamental freedoms of each human being.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to this report, these visa-free agreements for short-term stays should boost tourism and strengthen our trade relations with Grenada. These new provisions will make it easier for entrepreneurs and investors to move around, intensifying economic ties between businesses. Furthermore, this visa liberalisation should not pose a threat in terms of illegal immigration in view of the particularly low visa refusal rate. On the other hand, at a time when Western countries, in particular France, are facing an extremely serious terrorist threat, it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude these agreements. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Union has fought a fight to promote and encourage democratisation and a genuine and sustainable democracy in countries that are strengthening after periods of political transitions. However, beyond the level of speech, these objectives must be implemented through negotiations with third countries which seek to achieve the results listed above and, moreover, through associations with these countries, so as to provide them with real, economic support, and our citizens can also enjoy a diversification of products on the market, a decrease in product prices, and , why not, new territories in which they can enter without further formalities. The first step towards these objectives was correctly applied provisionally on the Commission's initiative, namely the liberalisation of short-stay visas, and I can only support its finalisation. Considering the agreement for both parties involved, I voted in favour of this report and I welcome the work undertaken by the EU through these agreements which will ensure greater openness of its citizens to these areas.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This series of agreements establish visa-free travel for Union citizens and third-country nationals (in this case Grenada) who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for their stay, with the exception of stays for paid employment. These are, in all cases, countries which are not problematic for the European Union. The most are known as "dream tourist destinations". There is no immigration problem in Europe and they are all very small or even small island countries.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Grenada, like the other Member States of the Cotonou Agreement, in order to strengthen economic and cultural relations. It is important to simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs but, above all, I agree with the rapporteur that the agreement will make it possible to stimulate tourism and give new impetus to trade.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Grenada when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.  Whilst Ireland is not party to this agreement and therefore not subject to its provisions, the intentions are nonetheless very positive and progressive. Most Irish citizens are quite aware of the benefits that this type of agreement brings to citizens of a country as we have a somewhat similar agreement with the US.  It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Grenada, assuming important political significance, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Under reciprocal conditions, visa-free travel also brings benefits for tourist or business travel to the EU and makes it easier for Europeans to visit their family members who have settled in these countries or to travel for professional or tourism reasons. Furthermore, Grenada does not pose a threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the draft Council decision. This short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and Grenada – taking on strong political significance under the Cotton Agreement – and is a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Having an economy heavily dependent on banana and spice exports, Grenada has taken initiatives to transform and diversify its economy to a large extent. Grenada has experienced a sharp decline in the agricultural sector's weight in favour of the services sector, particularly tourism and construction. Despite the progressive development of tourism, this sector remains at a low level of development compared to other countries in the region. Like all developing small island countries, Grenada faces numerous challenges, due to its size, the distance separating it from the markets, its vulnerability to external threats and its limited resources. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and strengthen economic ties between businesses.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Union's Agreement with Grenada on the short-stay visa waiver is a positive effort for cooperation and coexistence, which can only have a positive impact on citizens of both parties. So although there are still many details and procedures that need to be carefully regulated, I believe that this effort should be welcomed and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for Union citizens and Grenada nationals travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling more cheaply and practically.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation, as I believe it is an instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms in Grenada. I would also like to stress that Grenada is heavily dependent on banana and spice exports and has taken measures to substantially transform and diversify its economy. The country has had a significant decline in the weight of the agricultural sector in favour of services, particularly in the tourism and construction sectors. Tourism has made gradual progress, but remains little developed compared to other countries in the region. Finally, I believe that this agreement can not only improve and develop the economy of Grenada, but also help the citizens of the European Union who will be able to benefit from a better tourist service.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote because the agreements will encourage people-to-people contacts, boost tourism, and invigorate business between the EU and these countries

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 To cross the external border of the European Union, third-country nationals need to hold a visa, in this case of short duration. However, many countries are already exempt from this obligation because they meet a set of criteria approved in 2001 and 2014 by the European Parliament and the Council, which include respect for fundamental rights, security of the visa issuance system or risk of illegal immigration. The visa waiver goes far beyond benefits for European tourists and the third country. Rather, it can enhance rapprochement and dialogue between cultures, economic growth, as well as contributed to the consolidation of democratic regimes.  So I am pleased to see Granada on the list of exempt countries for short stays.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of the intensification of relations between the European Union and Grenada. It is an important political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations, with the aim of intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. That is why I welcome the Council's decision to conclude this agreement, as visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and strengthen economic links between businesses. The agreement will also make it possible to stimulate tourism and give new impetus to trade. The country in question does not pose any threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order and, thanks to the introduction of this agreement, there will be significant benefits for both tourist and business travel to the European Union.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The purpose of the proposal on visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement with Grenada on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Grenada when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Border crossing has never been a marginal issue. Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listed third countries in which nationals had to hold a visa in order to enter the host State. With the negotiations that began in November 2014, the regulation is drastically amended. With visa waiver agreements, citizens of the State of Grenada no longer have to hold a visa, but can cross borders with an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport that is valid. According to the agreement, the stay must be short and must not be for work purposes, the citizen of one of the signatory States, in fact, can travel to the territory of the other State for a maximum of 90 days in a period of 180 days. As I believe that this resolution can bring benefits to the current short-stay visa waiver agreements, I am voting in favour of this issue.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and Grenada are governed by the Partnership Agreement (Cotonou Agreement) between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and the CELAC-EU dialogue and the EU-CARIFORUM dialogue.  Grenada has been transferred to third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Agreement was signed in Brussels on 28 May 2015. Since then, the agreement has been applied provisionally, pending the approval of the European Parliament, which has just been granted by the EP. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union or citizens of Grenada for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period of travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (private, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) and to travel for any purpose other than the pursuit of gainful activity.  Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and enhance economic relations between businesses. The agreement could boost tourism and give new impetus to trade relations.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which is about the negotiation of the Commission with Grenada on a short-stay visa waiver.  This agreement represents the deepening relations between the European Union and Grenada – which is politically highly significant, an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this agreement with Grenada will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen member states, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the agreement between the UNION and Grenada, negotiated by the European Commission, to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas. It allows EU citizens and citizens of Grenada to obtain a free visa on the territory of all contracting parties for up to 90 days over a period of 180 days. This visa applies to all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, official and special passport holders) travelling for all types of reasons, with the exception of paid activities.  Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This short-stay visa exemption will strengthen political dialogue and economic relations between EU Member States and Grenada. I voted in favour of this measure in order to bring our territories closer together.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The Gabriel report aimed to remove the visa requirement for the Commonwealth of Dominica, Vanuatu, Trinidad and Tobago, Samoa, Grenada, East Timor, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the United Arab Emirates. These countries certainly do not pose a risk of uncontrolled immigration or a disturbance of public order. However, at a time when Islamist terrorists are looking for the slightest flaw in our defence in order to attack us, I do not find it appropriate to exempt certain countries from visas and to facilitate in general, access to our territory from non-European countries. Although I am in favour of closer economic ties with these countries, I cannot knowingly take the risk of allowing ill-intentioned people to take advantage of this to harm European security. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In May this year, an agreement was signed to abolish short-stay visas between the EU and seven countries in the so-called Region of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, including Grenada. I supported this report because Grenada is a democratic and stable country which, like the European Union, protects democratic values and principles, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law. The conclusion of this agreement will allow for strengthening cooperation and deepening dialogue in many areas, including human rights.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Grenada is a country facing numerous challenges due to its size, the distance it divides it from the markets, its vulnerability to external threats and its limited resources. In particular, there is a lack of democracy and basic human rights in the country, as evidenced by the lack of child protection and the inability to eradicate domestic violence. In this light, any short-stay visa waiver agreement is a wrong political and moral decision.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to visa-free travel for third countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council's decision on behalf of the Agreement between the European Union and Granada (small island state of Central America, part of the small Antilles) on short-stay visa waiver. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Granada who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. The agreement facilitates travel and is in itself positive. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Grenada, which is instrumental in encouraging trade, economic and political relations between these countries.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because I believe it will help citizens in need as a result of globalisation.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has negotiated an agreement with Grenada on behalf of the European Union on short-stay visa waivers. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for Citizens of the European Union and for citizens of this territory when travelling to Grenada for a maximum duration of 90 days in any 180-day period. At the same time, this agreement represents the culmination and deepening of relations between the European Union and Grenada, which is a politically very important way of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I give my positive opinion to the conclusion of the visa agreement for short stays.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Grenada is a country facing serious problems due to its size, the distance it divides it from the markets, its vulnerability to external threats and its limited resources. It is also characterised by a lack of democracy and basic human rights, such as the protection of the child, while the problem of domestic violence remains serious. In this light, any short-stay visa waiver agreement is a wrong political and moral decision and that is why I am voting against the EU-Grenada Agreement.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has negotiated on behalf of the EU an agreement with Grenada on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement can only be concluded if the European Parliament has given its consent. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of this territory when travelling to Grenada for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Grenada – which is politically highly significant and an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we are giving our consent to the conclusion of the agreement with the EU which has already been negotiated with the European Commission. The purpose of the proposal on visa facilitation is the conclusion of an agreement on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out paid activity. We support today’s resolution and believe that it is important to have a good agreement because it helps to fight organised crime and terrorist organisations.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and Grenada, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Visa-free travel is not a negligible means of ence with the peoples of Europe and the Caribbean. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the ACCS-EU partnership and to make this process cheaper and easier. I therefore voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the agreement considering that visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for employers, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. This agreement will boost tourism and give new impetus to trade.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today, as coordinator of my group for the EU-ACP dialogue, in favour of the recommendation on the EU-Grenada visa waiver agreement for short-stay stays, as I believe that rapprochement is valuable and, for me, includes the simplification of tourist bureaucracies.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The agreement is a further step towards intensifying cooperation between the countries of Europe and Grenada. Especially uncomplicated short stays make an important contribution to cultural exchange and economic development.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning the short-stay visa waiver programme which allows EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement takes into account the situation of the Member States that are not part of Schengen such as Ireland and the UK.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Visa waiver agreements for short stays represent a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Grenada.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement represents the deepening relations between the European Union and Grenada – which is politically highly significant, an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As with the majority of my constituents in Wales, I do not feel that it is the place of the EU to decide who can and cannot come into my country. I voted against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Grenada on the conclusion of the Visa Waiver for Short Stays on behalf of the European Union, as it will make it easier for EU citizens to travel to third countries, to promote people-to-people contacts, to increase tourism and to revitalise business.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the reports because, as ACPL, we have always taken a positive attitude towards a general visa regime for third-country travellers, even though we disagree with the procedure followed, as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote for this agreement. As regards the political and institutional situation, the country stresses its commitment to human rights and is committed to improving its human rights machinery. Recent proposals for constitutional reform to promote and protect human rights, and the legislative reforms which have been undertaken, particularly the adoption of the new law on family violence and a new law on child protection, show that Grenada is resolved to incorporate into its national law the principles on which international human rights instruments are based. Grenada is a stable, democratic country, which, like the European Union, defends the values and principles of democracy, good governance and respect for human rights and the rule of law. The conclusion of this agreement will make it possible to step up cooperation and intensify dialogue in many fields, including that of human rights.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Short-stay visa waiver agreements, which would provide visa-free travel for citizens, were signed in May 2015 between the EU and St Lucia, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St Vincent and the Grenadines, the Republic of Vanuatu, the independent State of Samoa, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, the United Arab Emirates and Timor-Leste. The visa would cover a period of 90 days out of any 180-day period. The agreement has received unanimous support in the Council and will not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland. Since this agreement will likely increase commercial opportunities through increased tourism and promote commercial opportunities, which I strongly support, I have voted in favour of this report. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If we take the particular case of Grenada, I see no particular difficulty in lifting the requirement for a short-stay visa, i.e. three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this small, sparsely populated island state 200 km north of Venezuela. The risk of migration is very low. However, beyond Grenada, I wonder about the strategic choice of granting short-stay visa exemptions in turn when, for some of these countries, particularly those in the Western Balkans, the risk of migration and to the internal security of the Member States of the European Union actually exists. There is a regulation that lists a positive list of countries whose nationals are exempt from the short-stay visa requirement. These countries are now 42, including the United States and Japan, and will soon be 61. Should this list not be revised in light of international upheavals?

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the Cotonou Agreement regarding the waiver of short-stay visas as an important step forward for the economic and cultural area of Grenada.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and Grenada on the abolition of short-stay visas, on the basis that it will contribute to the growth of tourism in Grenada which can certainly boost economic growth.  Grenada is a country that is faced, due to its size and distance, great challenges, and therefore I believe that closer cooperation with the European Union, i.e. visa liberalisation, can stimulate investment and economic ties with European companies. In addition, the tourism sector and international trade will be strengthened. Also crucial is that Grenada has initiated constitutional reform in the form of fostering and protecting human rights and legislative reform. Therefore, I support this recommendation and agreement that will bring European and Caribbean peoples closer.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism. It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order. Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I, with my fellow UKIP colleagues voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With my vote, I supported the lifting of the visa requirement for short stays of citizens of selected ACP Group partner countries and the United Arab Emirates in the European Union. This measure concerning exclusively safe countries with an excellent level of cooperation with European countries will increase the interest of non-European tourists in visiting EU countries. At the same time, reciprocal visa waiver for short stays will greatly facilitate travel by Union citizens to the countries concerned.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and Grenada. The European Parliament was to decide on the conclusions of the agreement between the Union and Grenada which was negotiated by the Commission. The aim was to facilitate the obtaining of visas. Citizens of both groups will be exempt from visas for stays of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. This exemption does not apply to people who will be travelling on business. This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the visa exemption at this time. This raises security concerns that would not be responsible for Europe in this situation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the agreement as it provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will boost tourism.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This short-stay visa waiver agreement aims to strengthen economic and cultural relations between the European Union and Grenada. It is another tool for intensifying dialogue in a number of areas, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I have chosen to vote in favour because visa liberalisation will facilitate business travel conditions, as well as trade relations. Finally, I believe that this agreement will have beneficial effects on tourism, as citizens will be allowed to travel more practically and at reduced prices.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the EU-Grenade visa waiver agreement for short-term stays. According to Gabriel's report, the country in question poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants would be high, with a relatively low rate of visa refusal.  Visa liberalisation simplifies travel conditions. However, we have a duty to ask ourselves whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted against the agreement because they are hostile to the exception of visas for short-term stays, which it endorses. Visas are necessary to ensure national security, except for our reliable partners, especially European ones.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution promotes visa waiver for short-term stays between the EU and Grenada, deepening the relations already established through the Cotonou Agreement agreement, the CELAC-EU and EU-Cariforum dialogues. In particular, it is hoped to delve into economic and cultural relations and political dialogue on human rights and fundamental freedoms. Grenada's economy is highly dependent on banana and spice exports, although it has already taken steps to diversify its economy. Thus, the services sector, in particular the tourism and construction branches, has gained weight. Despite this, it is a small country and limited resources, so visa waiver is expected to have particularly positive effects on investment and tourism.  I therefore declare myself in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ An agreement has been concluded between the European Union and Grenada for the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and Grenada and the possibility to stay for a maximum period of 90 days for a period of 180 days on the territory of the Union and Grenada. I supported Mariya Gabriel's report because the agreement was concluded and signed in accordance with the Council Decision, applies on an interim basis and requires the consent of the European Parliament to enter into force.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although Grenada is one of the smallest countries in the Caribbean and the world as a whole and its economy is heavily dependent on exports of fruit and spices, over the last couple of decades the country has managed to diversify its economy to some extent, so tourism and construction currently also account for not a small proportion of its GDP. A democratic country that actively develops relations with its neighbours and other partners, firstly Britain (for historical reasons), and where human rights occupy an important place in the strategy for national development – Grenada is one of those countries with which it is certainly worthy of a short-stay visa requirement. Our economic, political, cultural and other links will only benefit from this. This will also potentially contribute to the development of more active contacts with other countries in the region, thanks to a kind of 'transfusion' of progress.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Grenada is a country with approximately 110 thousand inhabitants. It poses no threat to illegal immigration, security or public order. In the economy, the most important export of spices and bananas is the country, tourism is underdeveloped. The short-stay visa waiver agreement concluded in May 2015, since it has also been provisionally implemented, allows citizens of the Contracting Parties to travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party without a visa for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. This applies to all categories of passengers for any reason other than the pursuit of a paid activity. The agreement opens the way for strengthening mutual trade, tourism and strengthening human rights dialogue and cooperation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and Grenada on the short-stay visa waiver, because it is not complete and documented. Furthermore, it is well probable that the implementation of this Recommendation will be used by potential beneficiaries to enter the EU without a visa and then illegally extend their stay in the Union after the expiry of the present short stay, thereby contributing to the increase in illegal immigration within the Union.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Grenada – which is politically highly significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement – and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. As with the previous ones, this is a whole series of agreements on the exemption of short-stay visas with several countries.  The agreement is expected to help boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations with these partners.  The key to these agreements is trust: the rate of visa refusal is very low because countries have confidence in visa applicants. According to the rapporteur, the countries covered by these agreements do not pose a threat, either in terms of irregular migration or security.  In view of the mass immigration that we are experiencing and which the Union is no longer able to manage, in view of the risks and the recent attacks against France, we can only be surprised, if not worried, by this sudden desire for openness. Perhaps the time is not the most opportune!

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Grenada. With this agreement, which allows EU and Grenada citizens to be exempt from the visa requirement for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days, counterparties will strengthen friendship ties and travel will be facilitated, as citizens will be able, for short periods, to be exempt from this obligation. This will also ensure the principle of equal treatment for all citizens of the European Union.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Grenada. Grenada has taken measures to substantially transform and diversify its economy, leading to the development of the service sector to the detriment of the agricultural sector, with particular reference to the tourism and construction sectors. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and strengthen economic ties between businesses.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The visa waiver agreement for short stays is a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and Grenada, so I support the decision. Visa liberalization will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. This agreement will boost tourism and give new impetus to trade in this country.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On the merits of the case, I am in favour of short-stay visa exemptions in order to facilitate the mobility and travel of citizens of two parties, in this case from the Member States to Grenada and vice versa. Nevertheless, I regret that the French Overseas Are Excluded from it.  On form, I denounce all this procedure. Only the Commission has the power to negotiate these agreements on behalf of states and citizens. It does not keep the European Parliament informed of the state of the negotiations until the very end of the process. Above all, these agreements are implemented even before the European Parliament gives its approval or not, an exemplary witness that democracy has no place in the Union (note that the same procedure will be applied in the case of the transatlantic agreement). In these circumstances, I vote against

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism. It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  With regard to the United Arab Emirates, it should be noted that 150,000 EU nationals are based there and most of them work there. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the UAE each year, and some 230,000 Emiratis have travelled to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism.  Nevertheless, the conclusion of such agreements, even though the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Grenada on visa-free travel for short stays. I share the rapporteur's position that this agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and Granada and is an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, but also for deepening the debate and political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Grenada when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I chose to support this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the agreement between the European Union and Granada on visa-free travel. This approval completes a process initiated under the previous Legislature to exempt from visas nationals of several third countries who meet all security, immigration and public order requirements.  I am pleased that among the 9 countries whose bilateral agreements have been approved today are several African-Caribbean-Pacific Group states. The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly has also contributed to the implementation of this visa-free process.  The agreement with Granada will allow the two partners to open an additional chapter in their relationship; which must focus above all on the values dear to both the State of Granada and the Union, including good governance and the rule of law.  This type of agreement encourages exchanges between young people and contacts between individuals, stimulates tourism and gives new impetus to trade between the EU and Granada.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The AGREEMENT between the EU and the island state of Grenada is intended to liberalise visa requirements, dynamite tourism and give a new impetus to trade. Grenada is an agricultural country that is ready to face industrialisation, the transition of the economy from primary to services, tourism and construction. The agreement is intended to facilitate travel, investment and is intended to strengthen cooperation. The Union supports the constitutional reform of Grenada on human rights, in particular the adoption of a new law on domestic violence and the protection of the child, and is open to dialogue on deepening relations.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to the EU-Grenada agreement on the short-stay visa waiver, which will provide new visa regime for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will bring people on both sides closer and will boost tourism.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should wisely allow legal access to third country nationals, as one of the means of both managing migration and protecting its good image, consistent with its values. Of course, reciprocity should also always be sought, in order to also benefit directly EU citizens when travelling abroad. I supported the agreement on the short-stay visa waiver with Grenada as part of this possible menu of wisdom.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2014, Grenada was one of the third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently negotiated a bilateral agreement to this end between 12 November and 9 December 2014 between the European Union and Grenada. The agreement was corked in Brussels on 28 May 2015 and has been awaiting parliament's approval ever since. In its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs voted in favour of approving the agreement and voted in favour of the draft accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. These agreements provide for visa exemption for short-term stays for listed countries, in order to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations.  Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants in these countries is high, with a historically low visa refusal rate. According to the rapporteur, the countries in question pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order.  However, the question arises whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. The answer is no, hence a vote against.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has established a visa-free agreement for short-stay stays for CITIZENS of the European Union and nationals of Granada, in connection with travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days, and the European Parliament therefore needs to approve the respective agreement.  Visa facilitation allows peoples to be rapproched and economic, cultural and political relations between the European Union and Grenada strengthened, strengthening the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement, a partnership agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the European Union and its Member States. Several categories of persons, regardless of the reason for visiting the country, are covered by this visa facilitation agreement, except in the case of paid activities.  I am voting in favour of this agreement, because I consider it essential to establish relations between the European Union and other communities, which will provide benefits for both sides in the economic, political and social field and enhance bilateral cooperation dialogues.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the exemption of short-stay visas between the EU and Grenada.  While it may seem desirable to facilitate the formalities in issuing visas, or even to exempt nationals, in order to increase the intensity of economic links and remove barriers to investment, the timing does not seem appropriate, given the EU's difficulties on migration policy. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which ratifies the agreement on short-stay visa waiver and allows for EU citizens and citizens of the participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and Grenada. The aim was to allow the visa-free travel regime for EUROPEAN and Grenadian nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by our colleague Mariya GABRIEL on the agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and Granada.  This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for nationals of both parties concerned who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.  The visa exemption covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, officially serviced and special passport holders) whose travel has all kinds of objectives, except that of a paid activity.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Grenada on the exemption from short-stay visas.
