This agreement provides an excellent opportunity to boost tourism, facilitate investment and dynamise trade, thereby increasing the importance of economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the higher state. In addition, the agreement offers new allies to join forces on issues of such importance as the fight against terrorism. We also see the emergence of political dialogue as a positive, most often aimed at joint action against corruption, criminal networks and trafficking in human beings.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation on the draft Council decision that provides a visa-free travel agreement for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Grenada when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would also have opposed this recommendation. Instead of repeating the mistakes made with the visa waiver for the Western Balkans, Europe should at last take serious care to secure Europe's borders.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Grenada's economy is heavily dependent on exports of bananas and spices, but measures have already been taken to reshape the economy and diversify significantly. The share of the agricultural sector in Grenada has declined greatly and the services sector, in particular tourism and construction, is on the rise. Visa liberalisation facilitates travel for businesses, facilitates investment and enhances economic links between businesses.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The achievement and adoption of an agreement between the EU and Grenada allowing short-stay visa waivers is an important step towards closer rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and those of the Caribbean and, more generally, a politically relevant instrument under the Cotonou Agreement. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the agreement between the European Union and Grenada on the exemption from the short-stay visa requirement. I welcome the further development of friendly relations between the European Union and Grenada. I am pleased that the visa waiver covers all categories of persons wishing to facilitate travel and short-term stay without a visa, of a maximum of 90 days in any period within 180 days from the date of the first registered entry. The agreement allows Citizens of the European Union and citizens of Grenada to stay without a visa on the territory of the other Contracting Party. This also offers numerous opportunities not only for the citizens of Grenada, but also for EU citizens through new business opportunities and facilitation of travel.  Due to the close relationship between the European Union and Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, in particular on the basis of the association agreements of those countries to the implementation, application and development of the Schengen acquis, I call on those countries to conclude bilateral visa waiver agreements with Ernad for short stays containing provisions such as in this agreement.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the exemption of short-stay visas between the EU and Grenada. Like the others, it is part of the belief that facilitating the issuance of visas, or even exempting nationals, increases the intensity of economic ties and removes barriers to investment.  The timing is particularly unse opportune, given the EU's difficulties on migration policy. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the abolition of visas for short stays of Grenada citizens within the European Union, with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. I believe this decision will enhance EU-Grenada cooperation and boost exchanges and developments, which is why I supported this proposal. Citizens of my country, Croatia, can already travel to Ernada without a visa, which makes it appropriate to provide the same to the citizens of this country. I hope that the EU will consistently stick to visa reciprocity rules with third countries that do not yet apply the same visa regime for nationals of all 28 member states.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - This proposal is strongly tied to the fact that Grenada is one of the signatories of the Cotonou Agreement and is a tool to strengthen political dialogue between the European Union and Grenada on fundamental human rights and freedoms. Although it has taken many measures to diversify the economy, Grenada is still highly dependent on banana and spice exports.  In the past few years, tourism and the construction sector have started their growth, but still not enough compared to other countries in the region. Grenada is a stable democratic state and by changing the constitution has strengthened fundamental human rights and strengthened the fight against domestic violence.  The information shows that the vast majority of visa applications are accepted and that Grenada poses no security risk to the European Union. For these reasons, I am in favour of adopting this agreement, which will continue to develop relations between Grenada and the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Grenada. The Caribbean country faces numerous challenges due to its limited size, its remoteness from foreign markets and the vulnerability of its natural resources. I therefore believe that visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and strengthen economic links between businesses. The agreement will also make it possible to stimulate tourism and give new impetus to trade, to strengthen cooperation with the countries of the Union and to deepen bilateral dialogue in a number of areas.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the approval of the agreement between the EU and Grenada to remove the visa requirement for short stays, i.e. 90 days less for all categories of persons (ordinary passport holders, diplomatic).  Indeed, it is important that European citizens can return to Granada without a visa and vice versa. This visa exemption should hopefully support the tourism sector in this Caribbean island.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. This agreement seals the visa exemption for very short stays and on the basis of reciprocity with Granada. A way to make travel easier for our nationals, whether for tourism or business.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, Granada has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that Regulation, the Council authorised the Commission on 9 October 2014 to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the Union and Grenada. The negotiations were concluded on 9 December 2014 and the Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015.   The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Granada who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days.  Because I believe that this is an important agreement to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify the political dialogue between the European Union and Granada, I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the EU and Granada, with high political importance and also provides an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this draft agreement between the European Union and Grenada on the short-stay visa exemption, which has already been applied on an interim basis since May 2015.  This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and third country nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  It should be noted that the United Kingdom and Ireland do not participate in these agreements and are not subject to the provisions of these agreements, as are the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Like other votes on the same subject today, I have decided to support the Proposal for a Recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and Granada on visa-free travel for short stays.  The strengthening of economic and cultural relations as well as the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement were fundamental to the willingness to increase bilateral cooperation and the conclusion of this agreement.  It is also intended that this Agreement can strengthen relations between the EU and Granada at various levels - such as intensifying dialogue on human rights issues and the rule of law. This country is heavily dependent on the export of bananas and spices. However, recently there has been a decrease in the importance of the agricultural sector in favour of the services sector, in particular tourism and construction. Although relatively poorly developed, Granada faces numerous challenges either because of its size, the distance from the main consumer markets or its limited resources.  With this agreement, entrepreneurs traveling to the country will benefit from more attractive travel conditions, which could facilitate investments in the country, strengthening economic partnerships, boosting trade and boosting tourism.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and Grenada on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Grenada nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft European Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Grenada, as it aims to develop the tourism and trade sector. The agreement simplifies travel conditions for entrepreneurs and facilitates and increases trade between businesses.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Grenada.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Granadan citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted – with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments – I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement approved by the European Parliament today lays down new provisions for visa-free travel for EU citizens and Grenada nationals travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for their stay. This agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic, tourist and cultural relations and, finally, will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in any visa policy so I voted against this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Just as the report was adopted by a huge majority in the committee, it was great to see it being adopted with as much enthusiasm in the plenary today. I am happy to say that I voted in favour of this agreement which the Commission has negotiated on behalf of the EU. This agreement will allow visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union to travel to Grenada for a maximum of 90 days (in any 180-day period). This will come as good news to those families in my constituency who have family and friends in Grenada, as well as those who might want to go on holiday to this island. There will be less hassle when travelling here and it will bring a welcome boost in tourism for this country. Furthermore it will allow us to increase the political dialogue with Grenada and promote our aims and goals in terms of human rights, climate change and whole range of other things.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Lifting visa requirements for stays of less than 90 days with the island state of Grenada will promote economic and cultural relations, but will also benefit from intensifying political dialogue. At present, Grenada's economy is heavily dependent on banana and spice exports, so it is important that the country focuses on transformation and diversification, which can also be helped by the relaxation of travel opportunities.  I therefore support this agreement on visa liberalisation, which will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and deepen the economic interconnecting of businesses. Although Grenada has already reduced the share of the agricultural sector, tourism or construction are still underdeveloped. However, the development of the country also depends on how it can cope with the many challenges it faces as an island state. Grenada is small in size, is far from the markets and is vulnerable to external shocks and limited resources. I therefore believe that intensifying relations with the EU will be beneficial for Grenada, while at the same time making it possible to strengthen cooperation and deepen dialogue in many areas, including human rights.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this amendment to the agreement between the European Union and Grenada taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Also, such a proposal to amend the agreement improves relations between these countries.  By abolishing short-stay visas, it allows citizens to gain new experiences and promote mobility development. After their stay in the European Union, citizens can transfer their newfound experiences to the country from which they come and thus further improve relations between the European Union and the country in question, as well as the situation in their country. And in an indirect way they promote the European Union in their own country.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement which will allow EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver programme takes into account the situation of Member States that are not part of Schengen such as the UK and Ireland.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 2012 509/2014 Of the European Parliament and the Council, Regulation (EC) No 509/2014 has been amended. 539/2001 by listing third countries whose nationals are exempt from visa obligations, including Grenada. Negotiations on a visa waiver agreement with Ernad and four other Caribbean countries began on 12 November 2014, with the agreement initialled on 15 December 2014.  On the union's part, the legal basis of the agreement is Article 77(2) (a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), in connection with Article 218 TFEU. The agreement allows Citizens of the European Union and Grenada nationals to stay visa-free in the territory of another Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period. The agreement includes a provision that Grenada may suspend the application of the agreement or cancel it only in relation to all Member States of the European Union and the Union may suspend the application of the agreement or cancel it only in relation to all Member States. I support the Council's decision to conclude an Agreement between the European Union and Grenada on the waiver of short-stay visas, as the objectives set by the Council in its negotiating directives have been achieved and the Visa Waiver Agreement is acceptable to the Union and the suspension provision ensures equal treatment for all EU citizens.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and Granada on the short-stay visa waiver. As a small island state, Granada is facing under-developed tourism and an economy that relies to a greater extent only on banana and spice exports. By lifting the short-stay visa requirement, we will strengthen economic cooperation between businesses, increase investment and help develop tourism in the country.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These reports relate to the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States. As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and will not take part in the agreement, I have abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although we disagree with the procedure followed as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations, we voted in favour of the reports because as ACPL we take a positive stance in favour of a general visa liberalisation regime for third-country travellers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Grenada is a country facing numerous challenges due to its size, the distance it divides it from the markets, its vulnerability to external threats and its limited resources. Above all, it has a lack of democracy and respect for basic human rights, such as the protection of the child and the elimination of domestic violence. In this light, any short-stay visa waiver agreement is a wrong political and moral decision.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed my political group and the subject matter expert. This visa-free agreement for short-term stays is a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country , which has strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of concluding the Agreement between the European Union and Grenada on the short-stay visa waiver, which was signed in May 2015. It allows visa-free travel for EU citizens and for the citizens of Grenada when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons, travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I welcome that the Agreement strengthens relations between the EU and Grenada, which is significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. It is also another way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the recommendation to adopt the EU-Grenada Agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas allowing nationals of both parties to the Agreement to stay visa-free on the territory of the other party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period.  I believe that the agreement contributes to strengthening both economic and cultural ties, as well as intensifying political dialogue. Further efforts to achieve the priorities of development cooperation between EU member states and the ACP group are very necessary, and of course with the main aim of preventing a deepening humanitarian and political crisis. Since Grenada, like all smaller islands with certain potentials, faces many challenges due to its size, visa liberalization can provide many opportunities for a certain period of time through controlled conditions. By revoking short-stay visas and seeing developments and achievements in the economy, economy and other areas of developed countries, individuals can gain the necessary experience and knowledge to help them to encourage the necessary social development in the country from which they come from the lowest level.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the Agreement between the European Union and the Grenado on the short-stay visa waiver. The proposal for an agreement on visa facilitation is intended to conclude an agreement with The Grenado on facilitating the issuance of short-stay visas.  The Agreement takes into account the fact that some Member States do not fully apply the Schengen acquis. The Agreement also provides for visa-free travel for European Union citizens and Grenada citizens when travelling to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of carrying out paid work.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Grenada.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation would simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. However, the question arises as to whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. This inflection in visa policy is contrary to what common sense dictates.  So I voted AGAINST.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and Grenada, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Grenada.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of providing visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of Grenada when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. Improving mobility options and visa waiver system will not only have a positive effect on mobility and economy, but also on other fields.  Grenada is a stable, democratic country, which, like the European Union, defends the values and principles of democracy, good governance and respect for human rights and the rule of law. The conclusion of this agreement will make it possible to step up cooperation and intensify dialogue in many fields, including that of human rights.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament must approve the conclusion of this agreement which has already been negotiated by the European Commission. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, as well as the rapporteur for the agreement, have given a positive recommendation and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report which includes an exemption from the visa requirement for short-stay citizens of Grenada and our own EU citizens. The abolition of the visa requirement shall apply to journeys of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. I am convinced that this agreement will contribute to better trade relations, more investment and more tourism.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the draft Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and that third country on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that third country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Grenada on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Grenada who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and The Grenado on the short-stay visa waiver, because I believe that it will, inter alia, simplify the conditions for business travel, which will have a positive impact on economic links between businesses, trade exchange and tourism.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Timorese and European citizens to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted – with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments – I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement with East Timor on visa exemption for short-term stays.  If in this report the liberalisation of visas for short-term stays is presented as an opportunity to boost tourism, simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs or encourage investment, I consider that at present it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude similar agreements.  Faced with a growing terrorist threat and European mass immigration policy, these agreements seem inappropriate to me. Indeed, even if East Timor is not directly a starting point for immigration, I do not think it is appropriate to make such an agreement in the current context, regardless of the country concerned.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report gives Parliament the consent to waive the visa requirement to stay for up to three months (90 days) over a period of 6 months (180 days). As this decision represents progress in the process of bilateral relations between the European Union and East Timor, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement requires the exemption of short-stay visas for people from East Timor. The aim is to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for this country, which, according to the report, poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  However, it is not appropriate to conclude such agreements, even though the porousness of Europe's borders is the bed of terrorism in Europe. On the other hand, together with my colleagues on the national front, we oppose this desire to create a world without borders. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent with the principles of UKIP to vote against such issues being determined at European Union level. It is for individual sovereign nations to determine their own visa requirements, and to assess whether or not a short-stay visa waiver scheme is appropriate for them. This opposition should not be taken as making any commentary upon the appropriateness of the United Kingdom, hypothetically, making a bilateral agreement with Timor-Leste along similar lines.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the EU-East Timor Agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short stays. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and East Timor, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which endorses the agreement with East Timor on visa exemption for short-term stays. Since the European Union refuses to control its external borders as it should and has abolished the internal borders of the Schengen area, it is urgent that France regain control of its national borders and enforce its laws, particularly in the area of border return.  It is therefore on principle that I am opposed to these types of agreements.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and East Timor.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which supports the exemption of visas for short-term stays for the citizens of East Timor with the aim of facilitating travel between this destination and the European Union (EU). The removal of visas in East Timor will apply to travel of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days, for any tourist, cultural, scientific or business trip, except those in which they are in a paid activity. Visa liberalisation in these countries is part of a proposal by the European Commission which extends to the exemption of visas in nineteen countries. We also call for full reciprocity to be used.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations.  Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. The report also states that the country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, security or public order.  However, it is questionable whether it is useful to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost control over mass immigration.  So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement establishes visa-free travel for EU and Timorese citizens travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. This measure does not raise any problems of any kind, which is why I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. After the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, the Democratic Republic of East Timor was included in the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation on 20 May 2014, and with the authorisation of the Council, the Commission negotiated and closed the Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor between November and December 2014. The Agreement was signed on 26 May 2015 in Brussels and the European Parliament is now granting its approval, with my vote in favour.  The signed Agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for Union citizens and nationals of the Democratic Republic of East Timor travelling to the territory of the other party for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and East Timor on the short stay of visa waiver. This agreement on the short stay of visa-free travel is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and East Timor, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and East Timor travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party and staying there for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short-stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order.  I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed visa waiver decision as it implements the EU-East Timor agreement signed in May on visa-free travel by citizens of both communities or countries. This arrangement will apply to journeys of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period. The exception will be the only trip with the intention of carrying out paid work, which will still require a working visa.  This strengthens cooperation between the EU and East Timor at political level as well. We know that economic cooperation is already very good, and this agreement will, in my view, be further strengthened, particularly in the area of tourism. This is a key sector for the development of the country, and therefore strengthening cooperation is of paramount importance. I agree that the lifting of the visa requirement between the two Parties is an important means of bringing European and Pacific nations closer. This agreement will also have a profound impact on the lower financial and practical costs of citizens, and I am pleased to welcome it!

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement with the Republic of Timor Leste is an important milestone of symbolic and political value: it is a sign of the good path that the EU and its contracting party have taken together in recent years, witnessed by the deepening of political, diplomatic and joint cooperation relations. An action that facilitates the movement between the citizens of both contractors and which – because of the sign of closeness and trust it represents – will be another instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on the issues to which the European Union and the Member States are attached, not least the protection of the human rights and fundamental freedoms of each human being.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to the report, these visa-free agreements for short-term stays should boost tourism and strengthen our trade relations with the Democratic Republic of East Timor. These new provisions will make it easier for entrepreneurs and investors to move around, intensifying economic ties between businesses. Furthermore, this visa liberalisation should not pose a threat in terms of illegal immigration in view of the particularly low visa refusal rate.  On the other hand, at a time when Western countries, in particular France, are facing an extremely serious terrorist threat, it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude these agreements. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the 'Cotonou Agreement', to which the Democratic Republic of East Timor joined shortly after its declaration of independence, and at the same time taking into account relations between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor, as well as the relationship between Member States and members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific group, the latest political dialogue was favourable to facilitate cooperation with regard to the visa regime. This agreement to hold a fixed-term residence visa constitutes progress on the relationship between the EU and the Democratic Republic of East Timor, strengthens the economic and cultural relationship and enhances political dialogue on a number of issues that include both human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted in favour of this report on the Agreement between the European Union and East Timor on the exemption from the requirement to hold a short-stay visa because I believe it is beneficial for both the European Union and East Timor, for better cooperation both politically and economically and culturally.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This series of agreements establish visa-free travel for UNION citizens and third-country nationals (in this case Timor Leste) who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for their stay, with the exception of stays for paid employment. These are, in all cases, countries which are not problematic for the European Union. The most are known as "dream tourist destinations". There is no immigration problem in Europe and they are all very small or even small island countries.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of relations with the member countries of the Cotonou Agreement, I reiterate the need to strengthen the dialogue in favour of the Republic of Timor Leste. In this sense, the short-stay visa waiver can be a means of simplifying the conditions for leisure or business travellers, especially for countries of which the Union is one of the main trading partners. Given that the European Union is one of the main trading partners of the Republic of Timor Leste, I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision providing for short-stay visa-free travel between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Timor-Leste when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.  Whilst Ireland is not party to this agreement and therefore not subject to its provisions, the intentions are nonetheless very positive and progressive. Most Irish citizens are quite aware of the benefits that this type of agreement brings to citizens of a country as we have a somewhat similar agreement with the US.  It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Timor Leste, taking on important political significance, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Under reciprocal conditions, visa-free travel also brings benefits for tourist or business travel to the EU and makes it easier for Europeans to visit their family members who have settled in these countries or to travel for professional or tourism reasons. Furthermore, Timor Leste does not pose a threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the draft Council decision. This short-stay visa waiver agreement is the ultimate objective for deepening relations between the European Union and the People's Republic of East Timor - which is of strong political importance under the Cotton Agreement - as well as a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and a more substantive political dialogue on various issues. , including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  The short-stay visa waiver agreement is an opportunity to promote economic relations and tourism. Tourism is precisely an area key to the development of East Timor, for which European citizens can be interested both as tourists and as investors. The EU is currently the pacific countries' third trading partner after Australia and China. However, the EU remains in sixth place for exporters to East Timor. The visa waiver is therefore an additional incentive for European entrepreneurs and investors.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Union's Agreement with the People's Republic of East Timor on the short-stay visa waiver is a positive effort for cooperation and coexistence, which can only have a positive impact on citizens of both parties. So although there are still many details and procedures that need to be carefully regulated, I believe that this effort should be welcomed and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for UNION citizens and citizens of the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling more cheaply and practically.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation because I am convinced that the short-stay visa waiver agreement represents an opportunity to enhance economic relations and tourism. The latter, in particular, is a key sector for the development of the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste, which could attract European citizens both as tourists and as investors. I would like to remind you that at the moment the Union is the Pacific countries' third largest trading partner and nevertheless still ranks sixth among exporters to the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste. The visa waiver offers, in my view, an additional incentive for European entrepreneurs and investors.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote because the agreements will encourage people-to-people contacts, boost tourism, and invigorate business between the EU and these countries.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 To cross the external border of the European Union, third-country nationals need to hold a visa, in this case of short duration. However, many countries are already exempt from this obligation because they meet a set of criteria approved in 2001 and 2014 by the European Parliament and the Council, which include respect for fundamental rights, security of the visa issuance system or risk of illegal immigration. The visa waiver goes far beyond benefits for European tourists and the third country. Rather, it can enhance rapprochement and dialogue between cultures, economic growth, as well as contributed to the consolidation of democratic regimes.  So I am pleased to see Timor-Leste on the list of exempt countries for short stays.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of the intensification of relations between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste. It is an important political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations, with the aim of intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The Democratic Republic of Timor Leste has experienced extremely rapid and laudable democratic stabilisation since it gained its independence and has since established relations with the European Union which have been characterised by their quality: a democratic culture in the country and the electoral process have been radicalised.  I support the Council's decision to conclude this agreement because the visa waiver will lead to the rapprochement of the peoples of Europe and the Pacific, as well as enabling citizens not only to benefit fully from the partnership established by having the opportunity to travel more cheaply and practically.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The purpose of the proposal on the visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement with Timor-Leste on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Timor-Leste when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Border crossing has never been a marginal issue. Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listed third countries in which nationals had to hold a visa in order to enter the host State. With the negotiations that began in November 2014, the regulation is drastically amended. With visa waiver agreements, citizens of the State of Timor Leste no longer have to hold a visa, but can cross borders with an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport that is valid. According to the agreement, the stay must be short and must not have work purposes. A national of one of the signatory States may travel to the territory of the other State for a maximum of 90 days over a period of 180 days. As I believe that this resolution can bring benefits to the current short-stay visa waiver agreements, I am voting in favour of this issue.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Timorese and European citizens to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted – with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments – I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor are governed by the Partnership Agreement (Cotonou Agreement) between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, which became a member of the Democratic Republic of East Timor shortly after independence. The last political dialogue with East Timor took place in Brussels on 16 October 2014, when the decision was taken to facilitate cooperation on visas. The Visa Waiver Agreement was signed in Brussels on 26 May 2015. Since then, the agreement has been applied provisionally, pending the approval of the European Parliament, which has just been granted by the EP. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Democratic Republic of East Timor for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period of travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (private, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) and to travel for any purpose other than the pursuit of gainful activity.  The agreement granting visa-free travel for short stays is an excellent opportunity to prioritise economic relations and contribute to the development of tourism. Tourism is a key sector for the development of East Timor, and Europeans can be interested both as tourists and investors in this respect.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 East Timor is the first sovereign state to be established in the 21st century. For many years, the Indonesian occupation is a rather little-known region, making the tourist infrastructure there underdeveloped. The Consent of the European Parliament will allow for the full implementation of the Agreement with East Timor, under which EU citizens will not need an entry visa for a maximum stay of 90 days over a 180-day period. East Timor has attractive, little-affected nature. I believe that visa-free travel will all the more encourage European citizens to see it, and the resulting tourist traffic will have a positive impact on the development of local trade. With no objection to this agreement, I supported it in the vote.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that is about the negotiation by the Commission with Timor-Leste on a short-stay visa waiver which represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Timor-Leste – which is politically highly significant.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this agreement with East Timor will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen member states, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and East Timor negotiated by the European Commission to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas.  It allows EU citizens and citizens of East Timor to obtain a free visa on the territory of all contracting parties for up to 90 days over a period of 180 days. This visa applies to all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, official and special passport holders) travelling for any type of reason except for paid activities.  Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to introduce a short-stay visa-free measure between the Member States of the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor.  This agreement is of regional political importance at a time when the European Union has announced a strengthening of its strategic partnership with ASEAN - an organisation in which East Timor is destined to join.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The Gabriel report aimed to remove the visa requirement for the Commonwealth of Dominica, Vanuatu, Trinidad and Tobago, Samoa, Grenada, East Timor, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the United Arab Emirates. These countries certainly do not pose a risk of uncontrolled immigration or a disturbance of public order. However, at a time when Islamist terrorists are looking for the slightest flaw in our defence in order to attack us, I do not find it appropriate to exempt certain countries from visas and to facilitate, in general, access to our territory from non-European countries. Although I am in favour of closer economic ties with these countries, I cannot knowingly take the risk of allowing ill-intentioned people to take advantage of this to harm European security. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas is an achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural ties and strengthening political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I supported the agreement as it represents an opportunity to harness economic relations and to develop tourism. The EU is currently the third largest trading partner of pacific countries after Australia and China. However, the EU is still in sixth place among exporters in East Timor. Visa waivers are therefore also an additional incentive for entrepreneurs and European investors.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement for citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of East Timor is impractical because it is a country that is seriously lagging behind in establishing democratic concepts such as human rights, media freedom and gender equality, in particular the fight against domestic violence and good governance. As with the agreements with the other countries of the 'Koton Agreement', I find it inconceivable practice to sign visa waiver agreements and to apply them temporarily without the approval of the European Parliament.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the proposal for the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste on visa-free travel for short stays because I believe that this measure will facilitate the movement of Timorese citizens to European territory and vice versa. This circulation is of increased importance in the case of Timorese who come to Europe in search of better living conditions, an opportunity in which Portugal also plays an important role in the history and tradition of proximity between these two countries. This measure also promotes the same status for citizens of the European Union who wish to move to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste, in both cases within a maximum period of 90 days.  In addition to the natural practical objectives of this measure, there are other purposes such as the intensification of political dialogue and the democratic deepening of Timor-Leste, the strengthening of economic and cultural relations and the facilitation of tourist travel, and tourism is a key sector for the development of Timor-Leste.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to visa-free travel for third countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council's decision to conclude, on behalf of the European Union, the Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. All categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) benefit from visa-free travel, regardless of the reason for their travel, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. The agreement facilitates travel and is in itself positive. We rejoice in this advance. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste. Thanks to this agreement, the European Union will be able to enjoy strengthened economic, social and political relations with the Republic of Timor Leste, while at the same time strengthening the tourism sector.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because visa liberalisation will simplify travel for business people, facilitate investment and intensify economic links among businesses.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has negotiated, on behalf of the European Union, an agreement with East Timor on the lifting of the short-stay visa requirement. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for Citizens of the European Union and for citizens of this territory when travelling to East Timor for a maximum duration of 90 days in any 180-day period. At the same time, this agreement represents the culmination and deepening of relations between the European Union and East Timor, which is a politically very important way of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I give my positive opinion to the conclusion of the visa agreement for short stays.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of East Timor is impractical because it is a country that lags far behind in critical areas such as the consolidation of democratic concepts, the application of human rights, freedom of the media and gender equality and, in particular, the fight against domestic violence , but also good governance. I also believe, just as it does for the other countries of the 'Coton Agreement', that the practice of signing visa waiver agreements and their provisional application without the approval of the European Parliament is inconceivable.  For these reasons I am voting against the EU-East Timor Agreement.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has negotiated on behalf of the EU, an agreement with the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement can only be concluded if the European Parliament has given its consent. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of this territory when travelling to the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste – which is politically highly significant and an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including Human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we are giving our consent to the conclusion of the agreement with the EU which has already been negotiated with the European Commission. The purpose of the proposal on visa facilitation is the conclusion of an agreement on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out paid activity. We support today’s resolution and believe that it is important to have a good agreement because it helps to fight organised crime and terrorist organisations.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both a success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Visa-free travel is not a negligible means of ence with the peoples of Europe and the Pacific. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the ACCS-EU partnership and to make this process cheaper and easier. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EU's role in consolidating democracy and fundamental rights in East Timor, as well as bearing in mind that the EU is currently the third trading partner of the Pacific countries after Australia and China. The EU continues to occupy, however, the sixth position among exporters towards East Timor. Visa waiver is therefore another additional incentive for European entrepreneurs and investors.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the recommendation on the EU-Timor-Leste visa waiver agreement for short-stay stays, as I believe that rapprochement is valuable and, for me, includes the simplification of tourist bureaucracies.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The agreement is a further step towards intensifying cooperation between the countries of Europe and Timor-Leste. Especially uncomplicated short stays make an important contribution to cultural exchange and economic development.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning the short-stay visa waiver programme which allows EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement takes into account the situation of the Member States that are not part of Schengen such as Ireland and the UK.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Visa waiver agreements for short stays represent a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and East Timor.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that is about the negotiation by the Commission with Timor-Leste on a short-stay visa waiver which represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Timor-Leste – which is politically highly significant.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As with the majority of my constituents in Wales, I do not feel that it is the place of the EU to decide who can and cannot come into my country. I voted against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste on the short-stay visa waiver because I believe that a visa waiver agreement help the EU promote reforms in third countries in relation to strengthening the respect of fundamental rights and the rule of law.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the reports because as ACPL we have always taken a positive attitude towards a general visa regime for third-country travellers. We voted in favour even though we have an objection to the procedure followed, as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this agreement because a short-stay visa waiver agreement represents an opportunity to intensify economic relations and develop tourism. Tourism in particular is a key sector for the development of Timor-Leste, which may attract European citizens both as tourists and as investors. The EU currently ranks third among the trade partners of the Pacific countries, behind Australia and China. Despite that, the EU remains in sixth place in the league table of exporters to Timor-Leste. The visa waiver is therefore an additional incentive for European entrepreneurs and investors.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Short-stay visa waiver agreements, which would provide visa-free travel for citizens, were signed in May 2015 between the EU and St Lucia, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St Vincent and the Grenadines, the Republic of Vanuatu, the independent State of Samoa, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, the United Arab Emirates and Timor-Leste. The visa would cover a period of 90 days out of any 180-day period. The agreement has received unanimous support in the Council and will not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland. Since this agreement will likely increase commercial opportunities through increased tourism and promote commercial opportunities, which I strongly support, I have voted in favour of this report. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If we take the particular case of East Timor, I do not see any particular difficulty in lifting the requirement for a short-stay visa - that is, three months over a period of 180 days - for nationals of this young state which gained independence in 2002, and which is certainly poor but has experienced an average growth rate of 9.5% over the last five years. The risk of migration is very low. However, beyond East Timor, I wonder about the strategic choice of granting short-stay visa exemptions in turn, whereas for some of these countries, particularly those in the Western Balkans, the risk of migration and to the internal security of the Member States of the European Union actually exists. There is a regulation that lists a positive list of countries whose nationals are exempt from the short-stay visa requirement. There are now 42 countries in these countries, including the United States and Japan, and will soon be 61. Should this list not be revised in light of international upheavals?

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the Cotonou Agreement regarding the waiver of short-stay visas as an important step forward for the economic and cultural area of the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste on the exemption from the short-stay visa requirement, as it improves political dialogue and fosters economic and cultural links.  Accordingly, this agreement enables the valorisation of economic relations and tourism and empowers the Role of the Union as an important partner of the Countries of the Pacific Region. Tourism is a key sector of Timor-Leste, while the European Union is the country's third economic partner. In this framework, this exemption is an additional incentive for European investors and entrepreneurs, while at the same time empowering the institutions and the good governance of Timor-Leste.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism. It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order. Nevertheless, the conclusion of such agreements, even though the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I, with my fellow UKIP colleagues voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With my vote, I supported the lifting of the visa requirement for short stays of citizens of selected ACP Group partner countries and the United Arab Emirates in the European Union. This measure concerning exclusively safe countries with an excellent level of cooperation with European countries will increase the interest of non-European tourists in visiting EU countries. At the same time, reciprocal visa waiver for short stays will greatly facilitate travel by Union citizens to the countries concerned.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor.  The European Parliament was to decide on the conclusions of the agreement between the Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor which was negotiated by the Commission. The aim was to facilitate the obtaining of visas.  Citizens of both groups will be exempt from visas for stays of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. This exemption does not apply to people who will be travelling on business. This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the visa exemption at this time. This raises security concerns that would not be responsible for Europe in this situation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the agreement as it provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will boost tourism.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The Democratic Republic of Timor Leste is to be regarded as an important trading partner for the European Union. I believe that the high flow of exports could be more favoured through the short-stay visa waiver agreement. I have therefore decided to give a positive opinion to this agreement which, together with the other measures adopted today, will be able to generate a driving force for the economy.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement between the European Union and East Timor on visa exemption for short-term stays.  According to Gabriel's report, the country in question poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants would be high, with a relatively low rate of visa refusal. Visa liberalisation also simplifies travel conditions.  However, we have a duty to ask ourselves whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted against the agreement because they are hostile to the exception of visas for short-term stays, which it endorses.  Visas are necessary to ensure national security, except for our reliable partners, especially European ones.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution promotes visa waiver for short-term stays between the EU and East Timor, deepening the relations already established through the Cotonou Agreement. In particular, it is hoped to delve into economic and cultural relations and political dialogue on human rights and fundamental freedoms.
