The EU is now the third trading partner of the Pacific countries, yet it is the sixth largest exporter to East Timor. In this context, short-term visa exemption is expected to provide a new incentive for European entrepreneurs and investors, and to have equally positive effects on tourism. Also noteworthy is the democratic stabilisation carried out by the country since its independence, as well as the collaboration with the then established and high-quality European Union.  I therefore declare myself in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste for the exemption from short-stay visas has been concluded. The agreement provides for a visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and Timor-Leste and the possibility to stay for a maximum period of 90 days for a period of 180 days on the territory of the Union and Timor-Leste. I supported Mariya Gabriel's report because the agreement was concluded and signed in accordance with the Council Decision and requires the consent of the European Parliament to enter into force, for better relations and easier travel.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Democratic Republic of East Timor has experienced rapid development of statehood since its independence in 2002, which can equally certainly be attributed to the development of its democracy as well as the economy, international trade, and .c. East Timor's accession to ASEAN could soon be a step forward. Although the number of visas currently issued to the population of East Timor is rather low and did not exceed one thousand last year, the abolition of the short-stay visa regime could to some extent change this dynamic to the bottom. Moreover, as the European Union is actively seeking to increase its role in the regions of the world and to promote more active relations with several countries, the abolition of the visa requirement in the case of East Timor can be seen as an important step in this direction.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement allows citizens of the Union and the Eastern Democratic Republic to travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party without a visa for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period, while the lifting of the visa requirement applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason other than the pursuit of a paid activity.  In addition to strengthening tourism and economic relations, this Agreement is also of political importance in the context of east Timor's accession to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, with which the Union seeks to strengthen the strategic partnership.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the People's Republic of East Timor on the short-stay visa waiver because it is not complete and documented.    Furthermore, it is well probable that the implementation of this Recommendation will be used by potential beneficiaries to enter the EU without a visa and then illegally extend their stay in the Union after the expiry of the present short stay, thereby contributing to the increase in illegal immigration within the Union.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal and would like to stress the by no means negligible impact which the visa waiver will have on rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and the Pacific. The visa waiver agreement will enable citizens not only to derive full benefit from the ACP-EU partnership but also to participate in it by travelling at a reduced, economical and practical cost.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. As with the previous ones, this is a whole series of agreements on the exemption of short-stay visas with several countries.  The agreement is expected to help boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations with these partners.  The key to these agreements is trust: the rate of visa refusal is very low because countries have confidence in visa applicants. According to the rapporteur, the countries covered by these agreements do not pose a threat, either in terms of irregular migration or security.  In view of the mass immigration that we are experiencing and which the European Union is no longer able to manage, and in view of the risks and recent attacks against France, we can only be surprised, if not worried, by this sudden desire for openness. Perhaps the timing is not the most timely!

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste. Timor Leste is on the list of Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which replaces Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, and its citizens are exempt from the short-stay visa requirement in the Member States of the Union, while fully respecting equal treatment for all European citizens. This agreement will ensure that citizens travel more cheaply and practically and will place the emphasis on issues of human rights, freedom of communication and gender equality.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste represents an opportunity to enhance economic relations and tourism in that country. The tourism sector is of key importance for the development of the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste, which could attract European citizens both as tourists and as investors. I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal in commentary.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The agreement with East Timor for the exemption of visas for stays of less than 90 days is an opportunity for the assessment of relations between the EU and this country, of which we are the third trading partner. Visa waiver is therefore another additional incentive for European entrepreneurs and investors who wish to extend their activity and products to East Timor.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On the merits of the case, I am in favour of short-stay visa exemptions in order to facilitate the mobility and travel of citizens of two parties, in this case the Member States in East Timor and vice versa. Nevertheless, I regret that the French overseas are excluded from it.  On form, I denounce all this procedure. Only the Commission has the power to negotiate these agreements on behalf of states and citizens. It does not keep the European Parliament informed of the state of the negotiations until the very end of the process. Above all, these agreements are implemented even before the European Parliament gives its approval or not, an exemplary witness that democracy has no place in the European Union. (Note that the same procedure will be applied in the case of the transatlantic agreement.) Under these conditions, I vote against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  With regard to the United Arab Emirates, it should be noted that 150,000 EU nationals are based there and most of them work there. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the UAE each year, and some 230,000 Emiratis have travelled to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism.  Nevertheless, the conclusion of such agreements, even though the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste on visa-free travel for short stays. I share the rapporteur's position that this agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste, constituting an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, but also for deepening the debate and political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I chose to support this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the agreement between the European Union and East Timor on visa-free travel.  This approval completes a process initiated under the previous Legislature to exempt from visas nationals of several third countries who meet all security, immigration and public order requirements.  I am pleased that among the nine countries whose bilateral agreements have been approved today are several African-Caribbean-Pacific Group states. The ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly has also contributed to the implementation of this visa-free process.  This agreement with East Timor will boost European investment and strengthen the union's trade and friendship ties with the Pacific state. More generally, this agreement is sure to intensify the partnership between the Union and the States of the Pacific Region.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The visa waiver agreement between the EU and the Eastern Democratic Republic of The Sea is also of political importance at regional level. The country is an independent, democratic, stable state that established a partnership with the EU after the declaration of independence. The Union assesses the positive situation in the country, promotes a democratic culture and emphasises the strengthening of state institutions. The agreement represents an opportunity to deepen economic relations and to develop tourism, which is a key area for the development of East Timor. The lifting of the visa requirement will also have the effect of increasing attractiveness for European entrepreneurs and investors, as the EU is already the third trading partner of pacific countries after Australia and China.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to the EU- Timor-Leste agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement was negotiated by the Commission on behalf of the EU with the Democratic republic of Timor-Leste and will provide new visa regime for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will bring people on both sides closer and will boost tourism.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should wisely allow legal access to third country nationals, as one of the means of both managing migration and protecting its good image, consistent with its values. Of course, reciprocity should also always be sought, in order to also benefit directly EU citizens when travelling abroad. I supported the agreement on the short-stay visa waiver with Timor-Leste as part of this possible menu of wisdom.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By decree of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2014, it amended Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, classing the Democratic Republic of East Timor as one of the third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission then negotiated a bilateral agreement to this end between 19 November and 15 December 2014 between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor. The agreement was corked in Brussels on 28 May 2015 and has been awaiting parliament's approval ever since. In its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs voted in favour of approving the agreement and voted in favour of the draft accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. These agreements provide for visa exemption for short-term stays for listed countries, in order to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants in these countries is high, with a historically low visa refusal rate. According to the rapporteur, the countries in question pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order.  However, it is questionable whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost control over mass immigration. The answer is no, hence a vote against.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has established a visa-free agreement for short stays for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste, in connection with travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days, and the European Parliament therefore needs to approve the respective agreement.  Visa facilitation allows peoples to rapprochement and strengthen economic, cultural and political relations between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste, strengthening the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement, a partnership agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific states, and the European Union and its Member States, to which Timor—Leste joined shortly after its independence. Several categories of persons, regardless of the reason for visiting the country, are covered by this visa facilitation agreement, except in the case of paid activities.  I am voting in favour of this agreement, because I consider it essential to establish relations between the European Union and other communities, which will provide benefits for both sides in the economic, political and social field and enhance bilateral cooperation dialogues.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. As with previous reports on the exemption from short-stay visas, I voted against this text, which is in agreement with East Timor, because the timing of the liberalisation of visa issuance does not seem appropriate.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which ratifies the agreement on short-stay visa waiver and allows for EU citizens and citizens of the participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor. The aim was to allow the visa-free travel regime for EUROPEAN and East Timorese nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by our colleague Mariya GABRIEL on the agreement on the short-stay visa exemption agreement between the European Union and East Timor.  This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for nationals of both parties concerned who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.  The visa exemption covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for paid activity.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I vote in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor on the exemption from short-stay visas. This agreement provides an excellent opportunity to boost tourism, facilitate investment and dynamise trade, thereby increasing the importance of economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the higher state. In addition, the agreement offers new allies to join forces on issues of such importance as the fight against terrorism. We also see the emergence of political dialogue as a positive, most often aimed at joint action against corruption, criminal networks and trafficking in human beings.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation on the draft Council decision that provides a visa-free travel agreement for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I believe that visa-free travel could exacerbate the refugee crisis. That is why I would have opposed this agreement in Parliament.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The agreement provides an opportunity to promote economic relations and tourism. Tourism is a particularly important sector for the development of East Timor and is attracted by EU citizens as tourists and investors.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The achievement and adoption of an agreement between the EU and the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste, allowing visa-free travel for short stays, is an important step towards closer rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and those of the Caribbean and, more generally, a politically relevant instrument under the Cotonou Agreement. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor on the exemption from the short-stay visa requirement. I welcome the further development of friendly relations between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor. I am pleased that the visa waiver covers all categories of persons wishing to facilitate travel and short-term stay without a visa, of a maximum of 90 days in any period within 180 days from the date of the first registered entry. The agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of the Democratic Republic of East Timor to stay without a visa on the territory of the other Contracting Party. This also offers numerous opportunities not only for the citizens of the Democratic Republic of East Timor, but also for EU citizens through new business opportunities and facilitation of travel.  Due to the close relationship between the European Union and Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, in particular on the basis of the association agreements of those countries to the implementation, application and development of the Schengen acquis, I call on those countries to conclude bilateral visa waiver agreements with the Democratic Republic of East Timor for short stays containing provisions as in this agreement.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. As with previous reports on the exemption from short-stay visas, I voted against this text, which is in agreement with East Timor, because the timing of visa liberalisation seems less than timely.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the abolition of short-stay visas for Timor-Leste citizens within the European Union, with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. I believe this decision will enhance cooperation between the EU and this island country and boost exchanges and development, which is why I supported this proposal. Citizens of my country, Croatia, can already travel to Timor-Leste without a visa, which is why it seems appropriate to provide the same to the citizens of this country. I hope that the EU will consistently stick to visa reciprocity rules with third countries that do not yet apply the same visa regime for nationals of all 28 member states.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – The Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste is one of the signatories to the Cotonou Agreement and is a strong partner of the European Union. Tourism is one of the key factors in timor-leste's development and I believe that by accepting this agreement, tourist developments between the two signatories would grow.  In addition to tourism, this agreement would intensify economic relations. I believe this agreement would strengthen the position of the European Union as a partner of Pacific states. Since declaring independence, Timor-Leste has immediately become a partner of the European Union and has undergone a very intensive democratisation process. Human rights and freedoms are protected by the Constitution.  For these reasons, and given that only 773 citizens of Timor-Leste applied for visas last year and more than 95% of them were accepted, I believe that by accepting this agreement we do not enter into any security risk.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for UNION citizens and citizens of the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. I voted in favour of this agreement because it represents an opportunity to enhance economic relations and tourism. The latter is a key sector for the development of this country which could attract many European citizens both as tourists and as investors. The agreement is also of political importance at regional level, as it would strengthen the European Union's position as a partner of the countries in the Pacific region and with a view to the accession of the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste to ASEAN (Association of South-East Asian Nations), with which the EU announced its intention to intensify the strategic partnership.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. This agreement seals the visa exemption for very short stays and on the basis of reciprocity with East Timor.  A way to make travel easier for our nationals, whether for tourism or business.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the Democratic Republic of Timor has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that Regulation, the Council authorised the Commission on 9 October 2014 to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor. The negotiations were concluded on 15 December 2014 and the Agreement was signed on 26 May 2015.   The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Democratic Republic of Timor who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period.  Because I believe that this is an important agreement to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor, I voted in favour of their approval.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the EU and Timor, with high political importance and also provides an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this draft agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor on the short-stay visa exemption, which has already been applied on a provisional basis since May 2015.  This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and third country nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  It should be noted that the United Kingdom and Ireland do not participate in these agreements and are not subject to the provisions they contain, as are the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. For reasons that the Portuguese understand, it was with great personal satisfaction that I gave my vote in favour of the Proposal for a Recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and East Timor, with a view to the exemption of visas for short stays.  Timor—Leste's political stability, respect for democratic principles, strengthening economic and cultural relations, and being an ACP country were fundamental to the will to increase bilateral cooperation, facilitation and conclusion of this agreement. Timor-Leste sees economic relations and tourism as a key factor in its development.  With the conclusion of this visa waiver agreement, the interest of European citizens as well as potential investors in this Portuguese-speaking territory in the Far East will certainly be stimulated. In addition, the political importance of this agreement is also at regional level, and strengthening the EU's position as a partner in this Pacific region is important. Finally, I would just like to mention once again the rapid and laudable democratic stability that Timor-Leste achieved after its independence.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and East Timorese nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for up to 90 days over any 180-day period.  Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the conclusion of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste, which allows their citizens to travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days with the exception of stays for paid employment.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and East Timor.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Timorese and European citizens to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have taken place – with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments – I voted in favour of the ratification of the negotiations, as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement approved by the European Parliament today lays down new provisions for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of the Democratic Republic of Timor Leste travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for their stay. This agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic, tourist and cultural relations and, finally, will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in any visa policy so I voted against this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this agreement with this young country. As the first new state of the 21st Century, it is incredibly important both for this country’s future and standing in the world, but also that the EU establishes, maintains and develops good relations with every democratic state in the world. This agreement will bring about a boost in tourism for the country and bring people closer together.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This agreement represents the successful completion of the deepening of relations between the EU and the Eastern Democratic Republic of The Sea. The country has undergone extremely rapid and commendable democratic stabilisation, which contributes to the continuous improvement of relations with the Union. I therefore welcome the lifting of the visa requirement with East Timor, as it makes it possible to valorise economic relations and seize opportunities for tourism.  I also agree that the relaxation of visa requirements provides an additional incentive for European entrepreneurs and investors. European citizens will not only be able to travel to East Timor as tourists, but will also be able to take advantage of investment opportunities in tourism. In addition, under this agreement, the EU will be able to strengthen its relations with the countries of South-East Asia and intensify political dialogue on human rights issues, media freedom and gender equality. The fact that visa requirements are abolished today is also due to the fact that most visa applicants have long been considered to be well-intentioned travellers and do not pose a risk to the EU. I believe that the agreement will contribute to the development of mutual relations and will be beneficial for mutual prosperity.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this amendment to the agreement between the European Union and Timor-Leste taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Also, such a proposal to amend the agreement improves relations between these countries. The abolition of short-stay visas allows citizens to gain new experiences and promotes the development of mobility.  After their stay in the European Union, citizens can transfer their newfound experiences to the country from which they come and thus further improve relations between the European Union and the country in question, as well as the situation in their country. And in an indirect way they promote the European Union in their own country.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement which will allow EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver programme takes into account the situation of Member States that are not part of Schengen such as the UK and Ireland.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 2012 509/2014 Of the European Parliament and the Council, Regulation (EC) No 509/2014 has been amended. 539/2001 by listing third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement, including Timor-Leste. The visa waiver agreement with Timor-Leste was initialled on 15 December 2014.  On the union's part, the legal basis of the agreement is Article 77(2) (a) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), in connection with Article 218 TFEU. The agreement allows European Union citizens and Timor-Leste nationals to stay visa-free on the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period. The agreement includes a provision that Timor-Leste may suspend the application of the agreement or cancel it only in relation to all Member States of the European Union and the Union may suspend the application of the agreement or cancel it only in relation to all Member States. I support the Council's decision to conclude an Agreement between the European Union and Timor-Leste on the waiver of short-stay visas, as the objectives set by the Council in its negotiating directives have been achieved and the Visa Waiver Agreement is acceptable to the Union and the suspension provision ensures equal treatment for all EU citizens.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and East Timor on the short-stay visa waiver. As with other Pacific countries, the Agreement applies to all types of travel with East Timor, except for the performance of paid work. The agreement is an excellent opportunity to deepen economic cooperation, investment and cultural and tourism cooperation between the European Union and the Pacific states. The quality of relations between the European Union and East Timor has improved over the years since the establishment of the country's independence, and I support the improvement of contacts.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These reports relate to the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States. As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and will not take part in the agreement, I have abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although we disagree with the procedure followed as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations, we nevertheless voted in favour of the reports because as ACPL we are in favour of a general visa liberalisation regime for third-country travellers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of East Timor is impractical, given that there is a large deficit in the consolidation of democratic concepts, such as human rights, media freedom and gender equality, but also in the fight against domestic violence and good governance. As with the other countries of the 'Koton Agreement', it is inconceivable that the practice of signing visa waiver agreements should be applied and provisionally implemented before they are approved by the European Parliament.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed my political group and the subject matter expert. This visa-free agreement for short-term stays is a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country , which has strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of concluding the Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste on the short-stay visa waiver, which was signed in May 2015. It allows visa-free travel for EU citizens and for the citizens of the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons, travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I welcome that the Agreement strengthens relations between the EU and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste, which is significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. It is also another way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to adopt an agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste on the exemption from the requirement to hold a short-stay visa. Tourism as one of the most important branches of the Timor-Leste economy is a key sector in the development path of this democratic republic and therefore a freer flow of travellers would strengthen not only tourism developments, but also investments, as the European Union is the third trading partner with Pacific countries. However, in order to achieve integral, multi-sectoral and sustainable development, both in this country and countries in the ACP group, it is necessary to ensure strong coordination and coherence between the institutions implementing the decisions. In doing so, I place emphasis on the role played by national parliaments and local authorities in the preparatory phase as well as the monitoring of strategic agreements.  I also believe that control mechanisms, i.e. monitoring, must not be ignored, which require compliance with agreed standards in order to avoid unintended consequences of such agreements. Therefore, border services should be responsible and vigilant when carrying out checks, i.e. determining whether they are intentions to travel for a shorter period of time or stay longer than intended.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the agreement between the European Union and East Timor on the short-stay visa waiver. The proposal for an agreement on visa facilitation is intended to conclude an agreement with East Timor on the facilitation of the issuance of short-stay visas.  The Agreement takes into account the fact that some Member States do not fully apply the Schengen acquis. The Agreement also provides for visa-free travel for European Union citizens and citizens of East Ti sea when travelling to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of carrying out paid work.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and East Timor.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation would simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. However, the question arises as to whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. This inflection in visa policy is contrary to what common sense dictates.  So I voted AGAINST.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both a success of deepening relations between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and East Timor.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of providing visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. Timor-Leste has undergone very rapid and praiseworthy democratic stabilisation since gaining independence. The country also entered into a partnership with the European Union as soon as it became independent, since when mutual relations have been of high quality. On the subject of human rights, it may be noted that fundamental rights and freedoms are protected by the Constitution. The political dialogue between the EU and Timor-Leste concentrates on human rights, freedom of the press and gender equality, particularly as regards combating domestic violence.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament must approve the conclusion of this agreement which has already been negotiated by the European Commission. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, as well as the rapporteur for the agreement, have given a positive recommendation and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report which includes an exemption from the short-stay visa requirement for citizens of East Timor and our own EU citizens. The abolition of the visa requirement shall apply to journeys of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. I am convinced that this agreement will contribute to better trade relations, more investment and more tourism.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the draft Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and that third country on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that third country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council's decision to conclude, on behalf of the European Union, the Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. All categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports) benefit from visa-free travel, regardless of the reason for their travel, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of East Timor on the short-stay visa waiver because I believe that the lifting of the visa requirement will be an additional incentive for European entrepreneurs and will consequently strengthen economic and cultural relations.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows citizens of St Lucia and Europeans to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted – with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments – I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement with St. Lucia on visa exemption for short-term stays.  If in this report the liberalisation of visas for short-term stays is presented as an opportunity to boost tourism, simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs or encourage investment, I consider that at present it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude similar agreements.  Faced with a growing terrorist threat and European mass immigration policy, these agreements seem inappropriate to me. Indeed, even if St. Lucia is not directly a starting point for immigration, I do not think it is wise to make such agreements in the current context, regardless of the country concerned.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report gives Parliament's consent to the waiver of a visa requirement to stay for up to three months (90 days) over a total period of 6 months (180 days). As this decision represents significant progress in bilateral relations between the European Union and St Lucia, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement provides for the exemption of short-stay visas for people coming from St. Lucia. The aim is to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for this country, which, according to the report, poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  However, it is not appropriate to conclude such agreements, even though the porousness of Europe's borders is the bed of terrorism in Europe. On the other hand, together with my colleagues on the national front, we oppose this desire to create a world without borders. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent with the principles of UKIP to vote against such issues being determined at European Union level. It is for individual sovereign nations to determine their own visa requirements, and to assess whether or not a short-stay visa waiver scheme is appropriate for them. This opposition should not be taken as making any commentary upon the appropriateness of the United Kingdom, hypothetically, making a bilateral agreement with Saint Lucia along similar lines.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the agreement between the EU and Saint Lucia on the short stay of visa waiver. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and St Lucia, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which endorses the agreement with St. Lucia on visa exemption for short-term stays. Since the European Union refuses to control its external borders as it should and has abolished the internal borders of the Schengen area, it is urgent that France regain control of its national borders and enforce its laws, particularly in the area of border return.  It is therefore on principle that I am opposed to these types of agreements.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the approval of an agreement exempting East Timor, a state that experienced a very rapid democratic stabilisation after its independence, from Schengen visas for a maximum stay of 90 days over a period of 180 days in the European Union and vice versa. This will, in particular, promote political dialogue and economic exchanges with the State. I approved this agreement.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Saint Lucia.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which supports the visa waiver for short-term stays for the citizens of St Lucia with the aim of facilitating travel between this destination and the European Union (EU). The removal of visas in St. Lucia will apply to travel of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days, for any tourist, cultural, scientific or business trip, except those in a paid activity. Visa liberalisation in these countries is part of a proposal by the European Commission which extends to the exemption of visas in nineteen countries. We also call for full reciprocity to be used.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are supposed to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. The report also states that the country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, security or public order.  However, it is questionable whether it is useful to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the EU has lost control over mass immigration.  So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement establishes visa-free travel for EU and Saint Lucia citizens travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. This measure does not raise any problems of any kind, which is why I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. After the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, Saint Lucia was included in the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation on 20 May 2014, and with the authorisation of the Council, the Commission negotiated and closed the bilateral agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia between November and December 2014. The Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015 in Brussels and the European Parliament is now granting its approval, with my vote in favour.  The signed Agreement provides for visa waiver for citizens of the European Union and St Lucia travelling to the territory of the other party for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. A joint statement concerning the interpretation of this 90-day period is attached to this Agreement. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except to pursue a paid activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia on the short stay of visa waiver. This agreement on the short stay of visa-free travel is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and St Lucia, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Saint Lucia travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party and staying there for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short-stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order.  I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed visa waiver decision as it implements the agreement signed between the EU and St Lucia on visa-free travel of citizens of both communities and countries in May. This arrangement will apply to journeys of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period. The exception will be the only trip with the intention of carrying out paid work, which will still require a working visa.  This strengthens cooperation between the EU and St Lucia at political level as well. We know that economic cooperation is already very good, and this agreement will, in my opinion, be further strengthened, particularly in the area of tourism and agriculture, which is relatively well developed in St Lucia.  I am convinced that this kind of cooperation will help precisely to strengthen tourism, which, unlike neighbouring island states, is not yet as well developed but progressing rapidly. I agree that the abolition of the visa requirement between the two Parties is an important means of bringing European and Caribbean nations closer. This agreement will also have a profound impact on the lower financial and practical costs of citizens, and I am pleased to welcome it!

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement with the territory of Saint Lucia represents an important milestone of symbolic and political value: it is a sign of the good path that the EU and its contracting party have taken together in recent years, witnessed by the deepening of political, diplomatic and common cooperation relations. An action that facilitates the movement between the citizens of both contractors and which – because of the sign of closeness and trust it represents – will be another instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on the issues to which the European Union and the Member States are attached, not least the protection of the human rights and fundamental freedoms of each human being.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to this report, these visa-free agreements for short-term stays should boost tourism and strengthen our trade relations with St. Lucia. These new provisions will make it easier for entrepreneurs and investors to move around, intensifying economic ties between businesses. Moreover, this liberalisation of visas should not pose a threat in terms of illegal immigration in view of the particularly low visa refusal rate. On the other hand, at a time when Western countries, in particular France, are facing an extremely serious terrorist threat, it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude these agreements. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The relationship between the European Union and Saint Lucia is governed by the 'Cotonou Agreement', an agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific group of states, on the one hand, and the European Union and its Member States, on the other, as well as the CELAC-EU and EU-CARIFORUM dialogues. It led to the establishment of cooperation instruments, including the EU-CARIFORUM Partnership Agreement and the Caribbean-EU Joint Strategic Partnership. This agreement to hold a fixed-term residence visa constitutes progress on the relationship in the European Union and Saint Lucia, strengthens the economic and cultural relationship and enhances political dialogue on a number of issues, namely human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted for this report because I thought it was beneficial for both the EU and the State of Saint Lucia, both economically and politically and culturally. It is also beneficial for the population of this young country.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This series of agreements establish visa-free travel for Union citizens and third-country nationals (in this case Saint Lucia) who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for their stay, with the exception of stays for paid employment. These are, in all cases, countries which are not problematic for the European Union. The most are known as "dream tourist destinations". There is no immigration problem in Europe and they are all very small or even small island countries.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia, because it is important to encourage cultural relations with the Caribbean countries, in particular With Saint Lucia, which is characterised by its commitment to fundamental rights. The conclusion of the agreement will make it possible to strengthen relations between the two parties, to give a new impetus to trade and to give dynamism to tourism, which is developing more and more in that country. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the recommendation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Saint Lucia when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.  Whilst Ireland is not party to this agreement and therefore not subject to its provisions, the intentions are nonetheless very positive and progressive. Most Irish citizens are quite aware of the benefits that this type of agreement brings to citizens of a country as we have a somewhat similar agreement with the US.  It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia, taking on an important political significance, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Under reciprocal conditions, visa-free travel also brings benefits for tourist or business travel to the EU and makes it easier for Europeans to visit their family members who have settled in these countries or to travel for professional or tourism reasons. Saint Lucia also does not pose a threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the draft Council decision. Relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, on the other, called the 'Koton Agreement', as well as by the CELAC-EU and EU-CARIFORUM dialogues. This latter dialogue led to the establishment of various cooperation instruments, including the EU-CARIFORUM Partnership Agreement (signed in 2008) and the Caribbean-EU Joint Strategic Partnership (2012).

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Union Agreement with the State of St Lucia on the short-stay visa waiver is a positive effort for cooperation and coexistence, which can only have a positive impact on citizens of both parties. So although there are many details and procedures that need to be carefully regulated, I believe that this effort should be welcomed and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for Union citizens and for citizens of Saint Lucia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling more cheaply and practically.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation because I believe that the agreement will strengthen relations between the two parties, give a new impetus to trade and instil dynamism in tourism. Furthermore, Saint Lucia is a young country which, despite the limited resources at its disposal and the small size of its population, has been able to achieve some of the Millennium Development Goals, demonstrating its commitment to fundamental rights. Finally, I would like to stress that the country intends to develop more and more the tourism sector, which is gradually taking over from the once flourishing agricultural sector. Saint Lucia is a democratic and stable country which, like the European Union, defends the values and principles of democracy, good governance, respect for human rights and the rule of law. I would remind you that all these values fall within those of the European People's Party, which is all the more reason to espouse this noble cause.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote because the agreements will encourage people-to-people contacts, boost tourism, and invigorate business between the EU and these countries.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 To cross the external border of the European Union, third-country nationals need to hold a visa, in this case of short duration. However, many countries are already exempt from this obligation because they meet a set of criteria approved in 2001 and 2014 by the European Parliament and the Council, which include respect for fundamental rights, security of the visa issuance system or risk of illegal immigration. The visa waiver goes far beyond benefits for European tourists and the third country. Rather, it can enhance rapprochement and dialogue between cultures, economic growth, as well as contributed to the consolidation of democratic regimes.  So I am pleased to see Saint Lucia on the list of exempt countries for short stays.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of the intensification of relations between the European Union and the Democratic Republic of Saint Lucia. It is an important political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations, with the aim of intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Although its economy is relatively small compared to the other Caribbean countries and is based mainly on agriculture, Saint Lucia strives to create an environment conducive to investment, private sector development and the tourism sector. I welcome the Council's decision to conclude this agreement because it will strengthen relations between the two parties, give a new impetus to trade and give tourism dynamism.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The purpose of the proposal on the visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement with Saint Lucia on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Saint Lucia when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Border crossing has never been a marginal issue. Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 listed third countries in which nationals had to hold a visa in order to enter the host State. With the negotiations that began in November 2014, the regulation is drastically amended. With visa waiver agreements, in fact, citizens of the State of Saint Lucia no longer have to be in possession of a visa, but can cross borders with an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport that is valid. According to the agreement, the stay must be short and must not have work purposes. A national of one of the signatory States may travel to the territory of the other State for a maximum of 90 days over a period of 180 days. As I believe that this resolution can bring benefits to the current short-stay visa waiver agreements, I am voting in favour of this issue.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows citizens of St Lucia and Europeans to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted – with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments – I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia are governed by the Partnership Agreement (Cotonou Agreement) between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and the CELAC-EU dialogue and the EU-CARIFORUM dialogue.  Saint Lucia has been transferred to third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Agreement was signed in Brussels on 28 May 2015. Since then, the agreement has been applied provisionally, pending the approval of the European Parliament, which has just been granted by the EP. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union or for nationals of Saint Lucia for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period of travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party. The Agreement shall be accompanied by a joint declaration on the interpretation of the 90-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (private, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) and to travel for any purpose other than the pursuit of gainful activity.  Although Saint Lucia's economy is small compared to other Caribbean countries, it is based on agriculture and exposed to external shocks, seeking to create an environment conducive to investment and private sector development. In this way, the agreement will allow relations between the two sides to be strengthened and trade to be dynamised.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The consent of the European Parliament will allow for the full implementation of the Agreement with Saint Lucia, under which EU citizens will not need an entry visa for a maximum stay of 90 days over a 180-day period. Saint Lucia is a country where tourism is the basis of the economy (it generates around 80% of GDP). The absence of the need to apply for a visa can all the more encourage European tourists to visit the country and, through increased tourist traffic, have a positive impact on local trade. Even short temporary stays can also contribute to the promotion of business contacts. With no objection to this agreement, I supported it in the vote.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which is about the negotiations between the Commission and Saint Lucia on a short-stay visa waiver. This step is politically significant including an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this agreement with Saint Lucia will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen member states, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and St Lucia negotiated by the European Commission, aimed at facilitating the issuance of short stays. It allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of St Lucia to obtain a free visa on the territory of all contracting parties for a maximum of 90 days over a period of 180 days. This visa applies to all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, official and special passport holders) travelling for any type of reason except for paid activities. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This short-stay visa exemption will allow for enhanced economic cooperation and deepening of political dialogue between EU Member States and St Lucia. That is why I supported this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The Gabriel report aimed to remove the visa requirement for the Commonwealth of Dominica, Vanuatu, Trinidad and Tobago, Samoa, Grenada, East Timor, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the United Arab Emirates. These countries certainly do not pose a risk of uncontrolled immigration or a disturbance of public order. However, at a time when Islamist terrorists are looking for the slightest flaw in our defence in order to attack us, I do not find it appropriate to exempt certain countries from visas and to facilitate in general, access to our territory from non-European countries. Although I am in favour of closer economic ties with these countries, I cannot knowingly take the risk of allowing ill-intentioned people to take advantage of this to harm European security. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In May this year, an agreement was signed to abolish short-stay visas between the EU and seven countries in the so-called Region of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, including St Lucia. I supported the report because, although it is a young country with limited resources, St Lucia has been able to reach, and even exceed, some of the Millennium Development Goals, which shows its commitment to fundamental rights, while seeking to create a favourable environment for investment and private sector development. The agreement on the abolition of short-stay visas has the potential to strengthen relations with the EU, re-boost trade and increase tourism flow.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I recognise that St Lucia is making good efforts to strengthen human rights mechanisms, but I cannot overlook the very serious incidents of lack of equality between men and women, cases of trafficking in human beings and trafficking and prostitution which always remain a reality despite the adoption of relevant legislation in 2010. As with the other countries of the 'Coton Agreement', I find it inconceivable the practice of signing visa waiver agreements and their provisional application without first giving the Approval of the European Parliament.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to visa-free travel for third countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia on visa-free travel for short-stay stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Saint Lucia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. A joint declaration on the interpretation of the concept of '90-day period' is annexed to the Agreement. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. The agreement facilitates travel and is in itself positive. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia, which is instrumental in encouraging trade, economic and political relations between these countries.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as visa liberalisation will simplify travel for business people, facilitate investment and intensify economic links among businesses.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission negotiated an agreement with St Lucia on behalf of the European Union on the lifting of the short-stay visa requirement. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for Citizens of the European Union and for citizens of this territory when travelling to Saint Lucia for a maximum duration of 90 days in any 180-day period.
