At the same time, this agreement represents the culmination and deepening of relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia, which is a politically very important way of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I give my positive opinion to the conclusion of the visa agreement for short stays.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 St Lucia, despite its best efforts to strengthen human rights mechanisms, is still plagued by cases of lack of equality between men - women, trafficking in human beings and trafficking as well as prostitution, despite the adoption of relevant legislation in 2010. As with the other countries of the 'Koton Agreement', it is, in my opinion, inconceivable the practice of signing visa waiver agreements and their provisional application before they are approved by the European Parliament.  For these reasons, my vote on the EU-St Lucia Agreement is negative.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has negotiated on behalf of the EU, an agreement with Saint Lucia on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement can only be concluded if the European Parliament has given its consent. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of this territory when travelling to Saint Lucia for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia – which is politically highly significant and an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we are giving our consent to the conclusion of the agreement with the EU which has already been negotiated with the European Commission. The purpose of the proposal on visa facilitation is the conclusion of an agreement on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out paid activity. We support today’s resolution and believe that it is important to have a good agreement because it helps to fight organised crime and terrorist organisations.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and a further instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Visa-free travel is not a negligible means of ence with the peoples of Europe and the Caribbean. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the ACCS-EU partnership and to make this process cheaper and easier. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the agreement with the intention of strengthening relations between the two Parties, giving new impetus to trade and energizing tourism. To be sure, both the citizens of St Lucia and those of the EU will benefit from this agreement.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the recommendation on the EU-St Lucia visa waiver agreement for short-stay stays, as I believe that rapprochement is valuable and, for me, includes the simplification of tourist bureaucracies.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The agreement is a further step towards intensifying cooperation between the countries of Europe and St Lucia. Especially uncomplicated short stays make an important contribution to cultural exchange and economic development.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning the short-stay visa waiver programme which allows EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement takes into account the situation of the Member States that are not part of Schengen such as Ireland and the UK.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Visa waiver agreements for short stays represent a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general.  That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Saint Lucia.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which is about the negotiations between the Commission and Saint Lucia on a short-stay visa waiver. This step is politically significant including an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As with the majority of my constituents in Wales, I do not feel that it is the place of the EU to decide who can and cannot come into my country. I voted against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia on the short-stay visa waiver because I support easier travel to the EU for citizens of some third countries that can encourage people-to-people contacts, boost tourism, and invigorate business.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the reports because as ACPL we have always taken a positive stance in favour of a general visa regime for third-country travellers. However, we disagree with the procedure followed as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because an agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Saint Lucia is a young country, with limited resources and a small population, which has nonetheless succeeded in attaining or even exceeding some of the Millennium Development Goals, thereby attesting to its commitment to fundamental rights. Although its economy is relatively small compared with that of other Caribbean countries and is mainly based on farming, and despite its vulnerability to external shocks, Saint Lucia is seeking to create an environment favourable to investment and development of the private sector. Saint Lucia is one of the highest ranked Caribbean island countries in terms of the ease with which business can be done. The country is also increasingly trying to develop tourism, which is gradually replacing its previously flourishing agriculture. This being so, this agreement will make it possible to step up relations further between the two parties, to impart fresh impetus to trade and to increase tourism.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Short-stay visa waiver agreements, which would provide visa-free travel for citizens, were signed in May 2015 between the EU and St Lucia, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St Vincent and the Grenadines, the Republic of Vanuatu, the independent State of Samoa, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, the United Arab Emirates and Timor-Leste. The visa would cover a period of 90 days out of any 180-day period. The agreement has received unanimous support in the Council and will not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland. Since this agreement will likely increase commercial opportunities through increased tourism and promote commercial opportunities, which I strongly support, I have voted in favour of this report. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If we take the particular case of St. Lucia, I do not see any particular difficulty in lifting the requirement for a short-stay visa, that is, three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this small English-speaking state located in the Caribbean whose historical ties with France are very strong. The risk of migration is very low. However, beyond the island of St Lucia, I wonder about the strategic choice of granting short-stay visa exemptions in turn when for some of these countries, particularly those in the Western Balkans, the risk of migration and to the internal security of the Member States of the European Union actually exists. There is a regulation that lists a positive list of countries whose nationals are exempt from the short-stay visa requirement. These countries are now 42 including the United States and Japan and will soon be 61. Should this list not be revised in light of international upheavals?

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the Cotonou agreement regarding the waiver of short-stay visas as an important step forward for the economic and cultural area of Saint Lucia.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and St Lucia on the abolition of short-stay visas, as this empowers the political value of the Cotonou Agreement and stimulates economic and cultural relations between the two sides.  St Lucia is a small state that has limited resources and modest economic growth, however, progress is visible, especially in investment promotion and private sector development. In addition, the tourism sector is expanding and strengthening, so this agreement will allow for greater economic and tourism links between the Member States of the Union and St Lucia, further strengthening the partnership between the ACP and the EU.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment, and boost tourism. It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order. Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I, with my fellow UKIP colleagues voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With my vote, I supported the lifting of the visa requirement for short stays of citizens of selected ACP Group partner countries and the United Arab Emirates in the European Union. This measure concerning exclusively safe countries with an excellent level of cooperation with European countries will increase the interest of non-European tourists in visiting EU countries. At the same time, reciprocal visa waiver for short stays will greatly facilitate travel by Union citizens to the countries concerned.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and St Lucia. The European Parliament was to decide on the conclusions of the agreement between the Union and St Lucia which was negotiated by the Commission. The aim was to facilitate the obtaining of visas. Citizens of both groups will be exempt from visas for stays of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. This exemption does not apply to people who will be travelling on business. This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the visa exemption at this time. This raises security concerns that would not be responsible for Europe in this situation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the agreement as it provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will boost tourism.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The short-stay visa waiver agreement between the Eu ropean Union and Saint Lucia aims to encourage investment, especially within the private sector. In view of the fact that the conclusion of the agreement will make it possible to strengthen cooperation and deepen dialogue in a number of areas, including human rights, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the EU-Saint Lucia visa waiver agreement for short-term stays. According to Gabriel's report, the country in question poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants would be high, with a relatively low rate of visa refusal. Visa liberalisation simplifies travel conditions. However, we have a duty to ask ourselves whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted against the agreement because they are hostile to the exception of visas for short-term stays, which it endorses. Visas are necessary to ensure national security, except for our reliable partners, especially European ones.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution promotes visa waiver for short-term stays between the EU and Saint Lucia, deepening the relations already established through the Cotonou Agreement, the CELAC-EU and EU-Cariforum dialogues. In particular, it is hoped to delve into economic and cultural relations and political dialogue on human rights and fundamental freedoms.   The signed agreement provides for a visa-free travel arrangements for EU nationals and those of St Lucia travelling for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days.  Saint Lucia is a young country, with limited resources and a small population. Its economy is mainly based on agriculture, although it is trying to diversify it by developing the tourism sector and the private sector and creating a favorable climate for investment. Exemption from such visas is expected to be positive in this regard.  I therefore declare myself in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The Agreement between the European Union and St Lucia for the exemption from short-stay visas has been concluded. The agreement provides for a visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and St Lucia and the possibility to stay for a maximum period of 90 days for a period of 180 days on the territory of the Union and St Lucia. I supported Mariya Gabriel's report because the agreement was concluded and signed in accordance with the Council Decision and requires the consent of the European Parliament to enter into force, for better relations and easier travel.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the fact that St Lucia is a small country with a small population, it has managed to develop its structure of national governance effectively enough in recent decades, international relations – especially with its neighbours with which it has a common currency – the defence of human rights and also the economy, which continues to diversify from the primary banana and product-growing sector to others. Leaving the existing visa issuing practice, St Lucia's travellers to our community are considered to be very reliable. The relationship between the European Union and this Caribbean country is developing qualitatively and is positively reforming not for the first year, so the short-stay visa waiver can be seen as a very positive step for continuing this dynamic.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This Agreement has been provisionally applied since May 2015 and allows EU and Saint Lucia citizens to travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party without a visa for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period, covering all categories of persons travelling for any reason other than the pursuit of a paid activity.  Saint Lucia is a democratic and stable country. Civil, human and political rights and fundamental freedoms are protected by the Constitution. The economy is small, it is based on agriculture, and tourism is the main source of income.  Saint Lucia is one of the safe countries and does not pose any threat to the EU in the area of security and public order.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia on the short-stay visa waiver, because it is not complete and documented.   Furthermore, it is well probable that the implementation of this Recommendation will be used by potential beneficiaries to enter the EU without a visa and then illegally extend their stay in the Union after the expiry of the present short stay, thereby contributing to the increase in illegal immigration within the Union.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome this agreement. Saint Lucia is a young country, with limited resources and a small population, which has nonetheless succeeded in attaining or even exceeding some of the Millennium Development Goals, thereby attesting to its commitment to fundamental rights.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. As with the previous ones, this is a whole series of agreements on the exemption of short-stay visas with several countries.  This agreement is supposed to help boost tourism, and strengthen trade relations and investments with these partners.  The key to these agreements is trust: the rate of visa refusal is very low because countries have confidence in visa applicants. According to the rapporteur, the countries covered by these agreements do not pose a threat, either in terms of irregular migration or security.  In view of the mass immigration that we are experiencing and which the EU is no longer able to manage, in view of the risks and the recent attacks against France, we can only be surprised, if we are worried, about this sudden desire for openness. Perhaps the timing is not the most timely!

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia. The agreement establishes visa-free travel for UNION citizens and citizens of Saint Lucia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons, holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport, regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. This agreement represents the improvement of economic and cultural relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Gabriel's report, which I support by voting in favour, refers to the visa waiver agreement for EU citizens and citizens of Saint Lucia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The agreement was signed in Brussels on 28 May 2015 and, from that date, applies provisionally, pending approval by the European Parliament. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons, regardless of the reason for their stay, with the exception of stays for paid employment. My vote in favour is due to the fact that this agreement has a political value that is not indifferent to the Cotonou Agreement, a partnership agreement between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, on the one hand, and the European Community and its Member States, on the other, thus crowning the deepening of relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the EU-St Lucia visa waiver agreement, which will strengthen relations between the two sides and boost this small country, which in recent years has made a great effort to promote civil and political rights, as well as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On the merits of the case, I am in favour of short-stay visa exemptions in order to facilitate the mobility and travel of citizens of two parties, in this case the Member States in St Lucia and vice versa. I regret, however, that the French overseas territories are excluded from it.  Moreover, cooperation with this country cannot be strengthened without holding it to account for the tax haven it represents. On form, I denounce all this procedure. Only the Commission has the power to negotiate these agreements on behalf of states and citizens. It does not keep the European Parliament informed of the state of the negotiations until the very end of the process. Above all, these agreements are implemented even before the European Parliament gives its approval or not. An exemplary witness that democracy has no place in the EU (note that the same procedure will be applied in the case of the transatlantic agreement). Under these conditions, I vote against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment, and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  With regard to the United Arab Emirates, it should be noted that 150,000 EU nationals are based there and most of them work there. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the UAE each year, and some 230,000 Emiratis have travelled to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism.  Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia on visa-free travel for short stays. I share the rapporteur's position that this agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia and is an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, but also for deepening political debate and dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Saint Lucia when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I chose to support this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The presence of St Lucia among the countries whose nationals are now exempt from visas will undeniably strengthen the Union's relations with this young Caribbean state. St. Lucia's progress in combating human trafficking and promoting gender equality is to be highlighted here. This progress makes St Lucia a partner of the Union in terms of the principles so dear to the Union: human rights, the rule of law and democracy.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Saint Lucia is a small and young, democratic and stable country focused on agriculture, but with ambitions to transform the economy through a suitable environment for entrepreneurship, investment and private sector development. The country successfully achieves and even exceeds some of the SDGs, developing trade and tourism. The Union therefore agrees to an agreement on visa waiver, supports the country in its development and in promoting commitment to human rights. The adoption of the agreement will facilitate the possibility of doing business on the island. The Union also appreciates the significant progress made in gender equality, the fight against trafficking in human beings and prostitution, which will deepen dialogue in these areas as well.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to the EU- Saint Lucia agreement on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement was negotiated by the Commission on behalf of the EU with the with Saint Lucia and will provide new visa regime for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will bring people on both sides closer and will boost tourism.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should wisely allow legal access to third country nationals, as one of the means of both managing migration and protecting its good image, consistent with its values. Of course, reciprocity should also always be sought, in order to also benefit directly EU citizens when travelling abroad. I supported the agreement on the short-stay visa waiver with Santa Lucia as part of this possible menu of wisdom.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By regulation of 20 May 2014, the European Parliament and the Council amended Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, classing Saint Lucia as one of the third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently negotiated a bilateral agreement to this end between 12 November and 11 December 2014 between the European Union and Saint Lucia. The agreement was corked in Brussels on 28 May 2015 and has been awaiting parliament's approval ever since. In its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs voted in favour of approving the agreement and voted in favour of the draft accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. These agreements provide for visa exemption for short-term stays for listed countries, in order to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants in these countries is high, with a historically low visa refusal rate.  According to the rapporteur, the countries in question pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order. However, the question arises whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. The answer is no, hence a vote against.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has established a visa-free agreement for short-stay stays for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Saint Lucia in connection with travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days, and the European Parliament therefore needs to approve the agreement.  Visa facilitation allows peoples to be rapproched and economic, cultural and political relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia strengthened the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement, a partnership agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the European Union and its Member States. Several categories of persons, regardless of the reason for visiting the country, are covered by this visa facilitation agreement, except in the case of paid activities.  I am voting in favour of this agreement, because I consider it essential to establish relations between the European Union and other communities, which will provide benefits for both sides in the economic, political and social field, and enhance bilateral cooperation dialogues.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the short-stay visa exemption between the EU and St Lucia, like previous reports on the issue, comes at an inopportune time, when the EU is unable to know who is entering its territory. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which ratifies the agreement on short-stay visa waiver and allows for EU citizens and citizens of the participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and St Lucia. The aim was to authorise the visa-free travel regime for EUROPEAN and Saint Lucian nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by our colleague Mariya Gabriel on the agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and St Lucia. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for nationals of both parties concerned who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period. The visa exemption covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, official service and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except that of a paid activity.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I vote in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia on the exemption from short-stay visas. This agreement provides an excellent opportunity to boost tourism, facilitate investment and dynamise trade, thereby increasing the importance of economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the higher state.  In addition, the agreement offers new allies to join forces on issues of such importance as the fight against terrorism. We also see the emergence of political dialogue as a positive, most often aimed at joint action against corruption, criminal networks and trafficking in human beings.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation on the draft Council decision that provides a visa-free travel agreement for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Saint Lucia when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I believe that visa-free travel could exacerbate the refugee crisis. That is why I would have opposed this agreement in Parliament.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. St Lucia's resources are limited and the population is small, but it has nevertheless managed to achieve and even exceed some of the Millennium Development Goals. The country is also increasingly trying to develop a tourism sector, which is gradually replacing the agricultural sector. The agreement thus makes it possible to strengthen relations between the parties and to further stimulate trade.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The achievement and adoption of an agreement between the EU and Saint Lucia, allowing short-stay visa-free travel, is an important step towards closer rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and those of the Caribbean and, more generally, a politically relevant instrument under the Cotonou Agreement. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the agreement between the European Union and St Lucia on the exemption from the short-stay visa requirement. I welcome the further development of friendly relations between the European Union and St Lucia. I am pleased that the visa waiver covers all categories of persons wishing to facilitate travel and short-term stay without a visa, of a maximum of 90 days in any period within 180 days from the date of the first registered entry. The agreement allows citizens of the European Union and the citizens of St Lucia to stay visa-free on the territory of the other Contracting Party. This also offers numerous opportunities not only for the citizens of St Lucia, but also for EU citizens through new business opportunities and facilitation of travel.  Due to the close relationship between the European Union and Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, in particular on the basis of the association agreements of those countries to the implementation, application and development of the Schengen acquis, I call on those countries to conclude bilateral visa waiver agreements with the State of St Lucia for short stays containing provisions as in this agreement.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the short-stay visa exemption between the EU and St Lucia, like previous reports on the issue, comes at an inopportune time, when the EU is unable to know who is entering its territory. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the abolition of short-stay visas for citizens of St Lucia within the European Union, with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. I believe this decision will enhance cooperation between the EU and this island country and boost exchanges and development, which is why I supported this proposal. Citizens of my country, Croatia, can already travel to St. Lucia without a visa, which is why it seems appropriate to provide the same to the citizens of this country. I hope that the EU will consistently stick to visa reciprocity rules with third countries that do not yet apply the same visa regime for nationals of all 28 member states.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I support the proposal for a draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and St Lucia on the waiver of short-stay visas. This proposal firmly relates to the fact that St Lucia is one of the signatories of the Cotonou Agreement and is a tool to strengthen the political dialogue between the European Union and St Lucia on fundamental human rights and freedoms.  St. Lucia is a young country whose economy is based on agriculture and is vulnerable to external shocks. Although its economy is small compared to other countries in the region, St Lucia has one of the most suitable conditions for foreign investment and private sector development. St. Lucia is a stable democratic state that protects civil and political rights by the Constitution and is dedicated to increasing human rights.  It has made great progress on gender equality, trafficking and prostitution. The information shows that the vast majority of visa applications are accepted and that St Lucia poses no security risk to the European Union. I believe that this agreement will deepen relations between the EU and St Lucia and intensify trade and tourism.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Saint Lucia is a young country that intends to develop more and more the tourism sector, which is progressively replacing the agricultural sector, once the state's first resource. In this sense, the agreement will make it possible to strengthen relations between the two parties, to give new impetus to trade and to instil dynamism in tourism. I therefore voted in favour of this agreement because it represents the conclusion of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia, assuming an important political and economic significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the approval of the agreement between the EU and St Lucia to remove the visa requirement for short stays, i.e. 90 days less for all categories of people (ordinary, diplomatic). Indeed, it is important that European citizens can return to St Lucia without a visa and vice versa. This visa exemption should, I hope, support the tourism sector in this Caribbean island.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. This agreement seals the visa exemption for very short stays and on the basis of reciprocity with St Lucia. A way to make travel easier for our nationals, whether for tourism or business.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, Saint Lucia has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that Regulation, the Council authorised the Commission on 9 October 2014 to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the Union and Saint Lucia. The negotiations were concluded on 11 December 2014 and the Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015.   The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Saint Lucia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period.  Because I believe that this is an important agreement to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify the political dialogue between the European Union and St Lucia, I voted in favour of their adoption.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the EU and Saint Lucia, which is of high political importance and is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as for intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this draft agreement between the European Union and St Lucia on the short-stay visa exemption, which has already been applied on an interim basis since May 2015. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and third country nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. It should be noted that the United Kingdom and Ireland do not participate in these agreements and are not subject to the provisions of these agreements, as are the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Once again, the strengthening of economic and cultural relations as well as the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement were fundamental to the willingness to strengthen bilateral cooperation, facilitation and conclusion of this agreement.  Saint Lucia is a young country with limited resources that, however, has committed itself and even overcome the challenges of the millennium, revealing strong attachment to fundamental rights. With a small economy and based substantially on agriculture, Saint Lucia is one of the Caribbean island countries that has achieved the best quotations with regard to the ease of doing business.  Its tourism development has also been a strong economic lever, even surpassing the agricultural sector that has so much weight and importance for this small economy.  It is therefore expected from this visa-free agreement that the potential for development, particularly in the tourism and trade sector, will be an asset for both co-signatories, strengthening EU-Saint Lucia relations. I have therefore decided to support this Proposal for a Recommendation.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and St Lucia on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and St Lucia nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for up to 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of concluding the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia as it aims to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue between the contracting parties. I support the European Union's willingness to work for this island state of Central America in order to develop its private sector and promote its trade.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Saint Lucia.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows citizens of St Lucia and Europeans to travel through both territories without a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted – with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments – I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement approved by the European Parliament today lays down new provisions for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of Saint Lucia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for their stay. This agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia and a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic, tourist and cultural relations and, finally, will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in any visa policy so I voted against this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Culminating the deepening of relations between the EU and Saint Lucia, this agreement comes at an important time for Saint Lucia. It will allow for EU citizens, in any 180-day period, to travel to Saint Lucia visa-free for 90 days. This new visa regime will provide more tourist opportunities for this Caribbean state and bring people closer together.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the conclusion of an agreement between St Lucia and the EU on visa facilitation. This agreement represents the successful completion of the deepening of relations with each other. St Lucia is a young country with limited resources and a small population, yet it is still managing to achieve its development goals. Although the island's economy is small and largely based on agriculture, Saint Lucia seeks to create an environment suitable for private sector investment and development. Moreover, it is one of the economies at the forefront of business facilitation among the island countries of the Caribbean. I also support the tightening of EU relations with St Lucia because the agreement will make it possible to strengthen relations between the two sides, to give a new impetus to trade and to dynamite tourism. The fact that visa requirements are abolished today is also due to the fact that most visa applicants have long been considered to be well-intentioned travellers and do not pose a risk to the EU. I believe that the agreement will contribute to the development of mutual relations and will be beneficial for mutual prosperity.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this amendment to the agreement between the European Union and St Lucia taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Also, such a proposal to amend the agreement improves relations between these countries. The abolition of short-stay visas allows citizens to gain new experiences and promotes the development of mobility.  After their stay in the European Union, citizens can transfer their newfound experiences to the country from which they come and thus further improve relations between the European Union and the country in question, as well as the situation in their country. And in an indirect way they promote the European Union in their own country.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement which will allow EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.  The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver programme takes into account the situation of Member States that are not part of Schengen such as the UK and Ireland.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 2012 509/2014 Of the European Parliament and the Council, Regulation (EC) No 509/2014 has been amended. 539/2001 It defines a list of 19 countries, including St Lucia, whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement.  The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, official and special passport) whose purpose of the trip does not include the performance of paid activity. Therefore, the agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of St Lucia to stay visa-free in the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. I support the Council regulation on the abolition of short-stay visas between the European Union and St Lucia with a view to further developing friendly relations between the Contracting Parties and wishing to facilitate travel by ensuring entry and short-term visa-free stay for its citizens.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and St Lucia on the short-stay visa waiver. By concluding the agreement, we will help both St Lucia, which has a small size of economy, and the Member States, because this agreement provides an excellent opportunity to improve economic cooperation between businesses, increase investment and develop tourism. In 2010, by adopting legislation on equality between men and women, St Lucia demonstrated its serious intention to strengthen respect for human rights.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These reports relate to the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States. As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and will not take part in the agreement, I have abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although we disagree with the procedure followed, as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations, we nevertheless voted in favour of the reports because as ACPL we have always maintained a positive attitude towards a general visa liberalisation regime for third-country travellers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 St Lucia, despite its best efforts to strengthen human rights mechanisms, continues to have shortcomings in respecting equality between men and women, and trafficking in human beings and trafficking in human beings has not been eliminated from that country, nor prostitution, despite the adoption of relevant legislation in 2010. As with the other countries of the 'Koton Agreement', it is inconceivable that the practice of signing visa waiver agreements should be applied and provisionally implemented before they are approved by the European Parliament.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed my political group and the subject matter expert. This visa-free agreement for short-term stays is a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country , which has strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of concluding the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia on the short-stay visa waiver, which was signed in May 2015. It allows visa-free travel for EU citizens and for the citizens of Saint Lucia when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons, travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I welcome that the Agreement strengthens relations between the EU and Saint Lucia, which is significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. It is also another way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the agreement between the EU and St Lucia on the abolition of short-stay visas resulting from the work of the Joint Parliamentary Group of the European Union and the African, Caribbean and Pacific Groups of States, as pointed out by the rapporteur, which indicated that the visa waiver would, inter alia, facilitate the cooperation and presence of parliamentarians from ACP countries in joint meetings for MEPs.  Although St Lucia as a young country has limited resources, population and compared to other Caribbean countries a very small economic sector, it is positioned as the Caribbean island with the least obstacles to achieving business cooperation. Therefore, a high level of market liberalisation can lead to good trade cooperation, as the Union's interest in cooperation with this group of countries stems from the economic sphere.  The conditions for economic development are obvious, because investments will be safer and the conditions of trade more favorable. In addition, the benefits of visa liberalisation with Schengen countries are also greater stability and security in terms of development. So I voted positively.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia on the short-stay visa waiver. The proposal for an agreement on visa facilitation is intended to conclude an agreement with St Lucia on the facilitation of the issuance of short-stay visas.  The Agreement takes into account the fact that some Member States do not fully apply the Schengen acquis. The Agreement also provides for visa-free travel for European Union citizens and citizens of Saint Lucia when travelling to the territory of the other Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of carrying out paid work.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Saint Lucia.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation would simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. However, the question arises as to whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. This inflection in visa policy is contrary to what common sense dictates.  So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Saint Lucia.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and St Lucia, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement and also an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of providing visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of Saint Lucia when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. Saint Lucia is a young country, with limited resources and a small population, which has nonetheless succeeded in attaining or even exceeding some of the Millennium Development Goals, thereby attesting to its commitment to fundamental rights. Although its economy is relatively small compared with that of other Caribbean countries and is mainly based on farming, and despite its vulnerability to external shocks, Saint Lucia is seeking to create an environment favourable to investment and development of the private sector. I believe this agreement represents the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Saint Lucia.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament must approve the conclusion of this agreement which has already been negotiated by the European Commission. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, as well as the rapporteur for the agreement, have given a positive recommendation and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report which includes an exemption from the visa requirement for citizens of Saint Lucia and our own EU citizens. The abolition of the visa requirement shall apply to journeys of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. I am convinced that this agreement will contribute to better trade relations, more investment and more tourism.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the draft Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and that third country on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that third country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia on visa-free travel for short-stay stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Saint Lucia who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. A joint declaration on the interpretation of the concept of '90-day period' is annexed to the Agreement. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Lucia on the short-stay visa waiver, as I support the effort to deepen relations between the European Union and St Lucia, which will encourage investment and trade.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Sanvicentin citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted – with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments – I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement with St. Vincent and the Grenadines for visa exemption for short-term stays.  If in this report the liberalisation of visas for short-term stays is presented as an opportunity to boost tourism, simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs or encourage investment, I consider that at present it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude similar agreements.  Faced with a growing terrorist threat and European mass immigration policy, these agreements seem inappropriate to me. Indeed, even if St. Vincent and the Grenadines is not directly a starting point for immigration, I do not think it is wise to make this kind of agreement in the current context, regardless of the country concerned.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report gives Parliament the consent to waive the visa requirement for stays of up to three months (90 days) over a total period of 6 months (180 days). Since this decision represents not insignificant progress in the development of bilateral relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, I voted in favour.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent with the principles of UKIP to vote against such issues being determined at European Union level. It is for individual sovereign nations to determine their own visa requirements, and to assess whether or not a short-stay visa waiver scheme is appropriate for them. This opposition should not be taken as making any commentary upon the appropriateness of the United Kingdom, hypothetically, making a bilateral agreement with Saint Vincent and the Grenadines along similar lines.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the agreement between the EU and Saint Vincent and the Grenadíns on visa-free travel in the case of short stays. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadíns, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which endorses the agreement with St. Vincent and the Grenadines on visa exemption for short-term stays. Since the European Union refuses to control its external borders as it should and has abolished the internal borders of the Schengen area, it is urgent that France regain control of its national borders and enforce its laws, particularly in the area of border return. It is therefore on principle that I am opposed to these types of agreements.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This is the approval of an agreement exempting St. Vincent and the Grenadines, a democratically stable state, from Schengen visas for a maximum stay of 90 days over a period of 180 days in the European Union and vice versa. This will, in particular, promote political dialogue and economic exchanges with the State. I approved this agreement

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and St Vincent and the Grenadines.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which supports the visa waiver for short-term stays for citizens of St Vincent and Grenadines with the aim of facilitating travel between this destination and the European Union (EU). The elimination of visas in St. Vincent and Grenadines will apply to travel of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days, for any tourist, cultural, scientific or business trip, except those in a paid activity. Visa liberalisation in these countries is part of a proposal by the European Commission which extends to the exemption of visas in nineteen countries. We also call for full reciprocity to be used.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. The report also states that the country poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, security or public order.  However, it is questionable whether it is useful to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the EU has lost control over mass immigration. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement establishes visa-free travel for EU and Saint Vincent and Grenadines citizens travelling to the territories of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days. This exemption granted to the citizens of Saint Vincent is not critical either in terms of immigration or otherwise, which is why I wanted to support the report with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Following the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines was included in the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that regulation on 20 May 2014, and with the authorization of the Council, the Commission negotiated and closed the bilateral agreement between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines between November and December 2014. The Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015 in Brussels and the European Parliament is now granting its approval, with my vote in favour. The signed Agreement provides for visa waiver for citizens of the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines travelling to the territory of the other party for a maximum period of 90 days every 180 days. A joint declaration concerning the interpretation of this 90-day period is attached to the Agreement. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except to pursue a paid activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadíns on the short stay of visa waiver. This agreement on the short stay of visa-free travel is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadíns, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement establishes visa-free travel for nationals of the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenaddin who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party and stay there for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short-stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.  With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order.  I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed visa waiver decision as it implements the EU-Saint Vincent-Grenadines agreement signed in May on visa-free travel by citizens of both communities and countries. This arrangement will apply to journeys of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period.  The exception will be the only trip with the intention of carrying out paid work, which will still require a working visa. This strengthens cooperation between the EU and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines at political level as well.  The natural disasters of recent years have greatly weakened the economy of this country, where bananas are the main export product. Therefore, any possibility of facilitating business is important. Economic cooperation between the two partners is already good, and this agreement will, in my opinion, be further strengthened. I agree that the abolition of the visa requirement between the two Parties is an important means of bringing European and Caribbean nations closer. This agreement will also have a profound impact on the lower financial and practical costs of citizens, and I am pleased to welcome it!

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement with the territory of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines is an important milestone of symbolic and political value: it is a sign of the good path that the EU and its contracting party have taken together in recent years, witnessed by the deepening of political, diplomatic and joint cooperation relations. An action that facilitates the movement between the citizens of both contractors and which – because of the sign of closeness and trust it represents – will be another instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on the issues to which the European Union and the Member States are attached, not least the protection of the human rights and fundamental freedoms of each human being.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to this report, these visa-free agreements for short-term stays should boost tourism and strengthen our trade relations with St. Vincent and the Grenadines. These new provisions will make it easier for entrepreneurs and investors to move around, intensifying economic ties between businesses. Moreover, this liberalisation of visas should not pose a threat in terms of illegal immigration in view of the particularly low visa refusal rate. On the other hand, at a time when Western countries, in particular France, are facing an extremely serious terrorist threat, it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude these agreements. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines are governed by the 'Cotonou Agreement' between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and, on the other hand, the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States. This signed agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines travelling within the territory of the other Party for a specified period of 90 days during any 180-day period. This exoneration agreement is a result of the deepening relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, with solid political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, a further strengthening of economic and cultural relations, but also an intensification of political dialogue on some topics, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted in favour of this report on the Agreement between the EU and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on the exemption from the short-stay visa requirement because I believe that this agreement represents an important step both economically and politically and culturally for both parties.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This series of agreements establish visa-free travel for Union citizens and third-country nationals (in this case the Grenadines) who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons regardless of the reason for their stay, with the exception of stays for paid employment. These are, in all cases, countries which are not problematic for the European Union. The most are known as "dream tourist destinations". There is no immigration problem in Europe and they are all very small or even small island countries.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, because I believe that this agreement has an important economic and commercial value. Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, as the report points out, have gone through a difficult period economically. This agreement can be a useful tool for giving new impetus to trade, and that is why I have decided to support it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement which provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Saint Vincent when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity.  Whilst Ireland is not party to this agreement and therefore not subject to its provisions, the intentions are nonetheless very positive and progressive. Most Irish citizens are quite aware of the benefits that this type of agreement brings to citizens of a country as we have a somewhat similar agreement with the US.  It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this agreement.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines, assuming important political significance as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Under reciprocal conditions, visa-free travel also brings benefits for tourist or business travel to the EU and makes it easier for Europeans to visit their family members who have settled in these countries or to travel for professional or tourism reasons. Moreover, St Vincent and the Grenadines do not pose a threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the draft Council decision. This short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines - taking on a strong political significance under the Koton Agreement - and is a complementary instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In the economic field, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines experienced a difficult period due mainly to natural disasters as well as to the deterioration of the export conditions of their only agricultural product, bananas.
