This has hindered the country's economic recovery and severely affected its tourism. However, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines have had a positive run in the socio-economic field in recent years.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Union Agreement with the State of St. Vincent and the Grenadines on the short-stay visa waiver is a positive effort for cooperation and coexistence, which can only have a positive impact on citizens of both parties. So although there are many details and procedures that need to be carefully regulated, I believe that this effort should be welcomed and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for UNION citizens and citizens of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling more cheaply and practically.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation because, in my opinion, the agreement will make it possible to further consolidate relations between the two parties and to give new impetus to trade. Furthermore, I would like to point out that, from an economic point of view, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines have gone through a difficult period, characterised in particular by natural disasters and the worsening export conditions of the main agricultural product – bananas – and as a result of these factors the country's economic recovery has been hampered, seriously damaging the tourism sector. Finally, I am convinced that, thanks to the macroeconomic policies adopted, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines have improved their external trade performance and have been able to successfully launch a programme of diversification of the economy, which has been accompanied by measures to increase the volume of exports, strengthen the tourism sector and improve the level of social development.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote because the agreements will encourage people-to-people contacts, boost tourism, and invigorate business between the EU and these countries.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 To cross the external border of the European Union, third-country nationals need to hold a visa, in this case of short duration. However, many countries are already exempt from this obligation because they meet a set of criteria, approved in 2001 and 2014 by the European Parliament and the Council, which include respect for fundamental rights, the security of the visa system or the risk of illegal immigration. The visa waiver goes far beyond benefits for European tourists and the third country. In addition, it can enhance rapprochement and dialogue between cultures, economic growth, as well as contributed to the consolidation of democratic regimes.  So I am pleased to see Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on the list of exempt countries for short stays.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of the intensification of relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. It is an important political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations with the aim of intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. After the difficult period of natural disasters and worsening export conditions, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines experienced positive socio-economic developments. Thanks to the macroeconomic policies adopted, the country has seen significant improvements and the room for improvement is still wide. That is precisely why I voted in favour of the Council's decision on the conclusion of this agreement, as it will make it possible to further consolidate relations between the two parties and to give new impetus to trade.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The purpose of the proposal on the visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement with Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement provides that citizens of Saint Vincent and those of the Grenadines may reside in the territory of EU Member States for a period of 90 days over a period of 180 days, without the need for a visa. The visa waiver is the culmination of the EU's relations with the countries of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines as it helps to intensify political dialogue, favours tourist travel from both these states to Europe and vice versa, with a consequent impact on the economies of the countries involved. I am in favour of the agreement, which has objectives which we can support, and I hope that England and Ireland, as EU Member States, will also be able to join it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Sanvicentin citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted – with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments – I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines are governed by the Partnership Agreement (Cotonou Agreement) between the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States, of the one part, and the European Union and its Member States, of the other part, and the CELAC-EU dialogue and the EU-CARIFORUM dialogue.  Saint Vincent and the Grenadines have been transferred to third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Agreement was signed in Brussels on 28 May 2015. Since then, the agreement has been applied provisionally, pending the approval of the European Parliament, which has just been granted by the EP. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for nationals of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period of travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party. The Agreement shall be accompanied by a joint declaration on the interpretation of the 90-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (private, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) and to travel for any purpose other than the pursuit of gainful activity.  On the economic front, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines have been through a difficult period, inter alia, due to natural disasters and the deterioration of the export conditions for bananas, the country's most important product. The agreement will allow for further strengthening of relations between the two sides and the dynamism of trade.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this agreement with Saint Vincent and the Grenadines will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen member states, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and St. Vincent and the Grenadines negotiated by the European Commission, to facilitate the issuance of short-stay visas. It allows EU citizens and citizens of St Vincent and the Grenadines to obtain a free visa on the territory of all contracting parties for up to 90 days over a period of 180 days. This visa applies to all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, official and special passport holders) travelling for any type of reason except for paid activities. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report introducing a short-stay visa exemption measure between the EU Member States and St Vincent and the Grenadines. In addition to strengthening political dialogue and economic relations, this measure will give new impetus to trade between the contracting parties.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The Gabriel report aimed to remove the visa requirement for the Commonwealth of Dominica, Vanuatu, Trinidad and Tobago, Samoa, Grenada, East Timor, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the United Arab Emirates. These countries certainly do not pose a risk of uncontrolled immigration or a disturbance of public order. However, at a time when Islamist terrorists are looking for the slightest flaw in our defence in order to attack us, I do not find it appropriate to exempt certain countries from visas and to facilitate in general, access to our territory from non-European countries. Although I am in favour of closer economic ties with these countries, I cannot knowingly take the risk of allowing ill-intentioned people to take advantage of this to harm European security. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 An agreement was signed in May this year to abolish short-stay visas between the EU and seven countries in the so-called African, Caribbean and Pacific region, including St Vincent and the Grenadines. I supported the abolition of short-stay visas, as I believe that the agreement represents a kind of achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines, which also brings with it great political significance within the framework of the Cotonou Agreement. It is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural ties and strengthening political dialogue on a number of issues and will allow for further strengthening of relations between the two countries and a new impetus for trade.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Saint Vincent and the Grenadines is a country that theoretically represents no threat, either in terms of illegal immigration, nor in terms of security and public order. The short-stay visa requirement could therefore be lifted if there were measurable data and on-the-spot tests on issues relating to illegal immigration, public policy and security, as well as on the Union's external relations with that country.  As with the other countries of the 'Coton Agreement', I find it inconceivable the practice of signing visa waiver agreements and their provisional application before the European Parliament has adopted them.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to visa-free travel for third countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council's decision on behalf of the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines – a member country of ALBA (latin American space for regional cooperation and integration, of a progressive nature, with which the EU could learn much) – on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. The agreement facilitates travel and is in itself positive. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. This agreement will be an effective instrument for intensifying political, cultural and economic relations between the two countries. In addition, visa-free travel will undoubtedly bring benefits for tourist or business travel to the European Union.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because visa liberalisation will simplify travel for business people, facilitate investment and intensify economic links among businesses.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has negotiated, on behalf of the European Union, an agreement with Saint Vincent and the Grenadines to lift the short-stay visa requirement. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and citizens of this territory when travelling to Saint Vincent and the Grenadines for a maximum duration of 90 days in any 180-day period. At the same time, this agreement represents the culmination and deepening of relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, which is a politically very important way of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the conclusion of the short-stay visa agreement.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 St. Vincent and the Grenadines theoretically represent no threat as a country, either in terms of illegal immigration, nor in terms of security and public order. I therefore believe that the short-stay visa requirement could be lifted, but I do not see how this can happen at a time when there are no measurable data and no on-the-spot investigations have been carried out on issues relating to illegal immigration, public policy and security, but also in the Union's external relations with that country.  Furthermore, as with the other countries of the 'Coton Agreement', it is inconceivable that the practice of signing visa waiver agreements and their provisional application before the european Parliament has adopted them is inconceivable. That's why my vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has negotiated on behalf of the EU, an agreement with Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement can only be concluded if the European Parliament has given its consent. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of this territory when travelling to Saint Vincent and the Grenadines for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines – which is politically highly significant and an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we are giving our consent to the conclusion of the agreement with the EU which has already been negotiated with the European Commission. The purpose of the proposal on visa facilitation is the conclusion of an agreement on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out paid activity. We support today’s resolution and believe that it is important to have a good agreement because it helps to fight organised crime and terrorist organisations.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both a success of deepening relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and a further instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Visa-free travel is not a negligible means of ence with the peoples of Europe and the Caribbean. The Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the ACCS-EU partnership and to make this process cheaper and easier. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the agreement bearing in mind the many benefits it will bring to St Vincent and the Grenadines. In addition, the Visa Waiver Agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the ACP-EU association, but also to participate in it, travelling at lower economic and practical costs.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the recommendation on the EU-St Vincent and the Grenadines agreement on the short-stay visa waiver, as I believe that rapprochement is valuable and, for me, includes the simplification of tourist bureaucracies.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The agreement is a further step towards intensifying cooperation between the states of Europe and St Vincent and the Grenadines. Especially uncomplicated short stays make an important contribution to cultural exchange and economic development.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning the short-stay visa waiver programme which allows EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement takes into account the situation of the Member States that are not part of Schengen such as Ireland and the UK.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Visa waiver agreements for short stays represent a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and St Vincent and the Grenadines.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is the fifth Caribbean country that we have voted in favour of a new visa regime for today, and this will bring a lot of benefits to this Windward Islands nation. It is regrettable that members from the ENF voted against these agreements at committee level, and evidently do not wish for better relationships with these countries. These agreements will step up economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various important issues, such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As with the majority of my constituents in Wales, I do not feel that it is the place of the EU to decide who can and cannot come into my country. I voted against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadine on the conclusion of the visa waiver in the case of short-stays on behalf of the European Union, as I believe that this can help the EU to promote third-country human rights reforms, to help develop business relations and promote European tourism.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the reports because as ACPL we have always taken a positive attitude towards a general visa regime for third-country travellers, although we object to the procedure followed, since the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this agreement as the short-stay visas simultaneously represent a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines and are an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In the economic sphere, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has been through a difficult period, marked in particular by natural disasters and deterioration in the terms under which its main agricultural product, the banana, is exported. These facts have acted as a brake on the country’s economic recovery and have seriously damaged its tourism. Nonetheless, in recent years Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has achieved positive socioeconomic progress. Thanks to the macroeconomic policies pursued, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has improved its foreign-trade performance and has been able to initiate with success a programme to diversify its economy, which is still focused on bananas, but also accompanied by measures to increase the volume of exports, boost tourism and improve the level of social development. This agreement will make it possible to step up relations further between the two parties and to impart fresh impetus to trade.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Short-stay visa waiver agreements, which would provide visa-free travel for citizens, were signed in May 2015 between the EU and St Lucia, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St Vincent and the Grenadines, the Republic of Vanuatu, the independent State of Samoa, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, the United Arab Emirates and Timor-Leste. The visa would cover a period of 90 days out of any 180-day period. The agreement has received unanimous support in the Council and will not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland. Since this agreement will likely increase commercial opportunities through increased tourism and promote commercial opportunities, which I strongly support, I have voted in favour of this report. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. If we take the particular case of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, I see no particular difficulty in lifting the requirement for a short-stay visa, i.e. three months over a period of 180 days, for nationals of this predominantly English-speaking island state located in the Caribbean. The risk of migration is very low. However, beyond the island of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, I wonder about the strategic choice of granting short-stay visa exemptions in turn when for some of these countries, particularly those in the Western Balkans, the risk of migration and to the internal security of the Member States of the European Union actually exists. There is a regulation that lists a positive list of countries whose nationals are exempt from the short-stay visa requirement. These countries are now 42 including the United States and Japan and will soon be 61. Should this list not be revised in light of international upheavals?

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the Cotonou agreement regarding the waiver of short-stay visas as an important step forward for Saint Vincent and the Grenadines economic and cultural area.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines on the exemption from the short-stay visa requirement, as the state has positively improved socio-economic indicators in recent years.  Natural disasters have seriously harmed the state, especially in economic terms, i.e. in the export of agricultural products and in the field of tourism. However, adopted macroeconomic policies have boosted international trade, strengthened tourism and improved social development.  St Vincent and the Grenadines are a democratic and pluralistic country that must, however, further foster political dialogue and cooperation on human rights. I believe that the agreement will certainly contribute to this, and therefore I support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment, and boost tourism. It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order. Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I, with my fellow UKIP colleagues voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With my vote, I supported the lifting of the visa requirement for short stays of citizens of selected ACP Group partner countries and the United Arab Emirates in the European Union. This measure concerning exclusively safe countries with an excellent level of cooperation with European countries will increase the interest of non-European tourists in visiting EU countries. At the same time, reciprocal visa waiver for short stays will greatly facilitate travel by Union citizens to the countries concerned.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines. The European Parliament was to decide on the conclusions of the agreement between the Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines which was negotiated by the Commission. The aim was to facilitate the obtaining of visas. Citizens of both groups will be exempt from visas for stays of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. This exemption does not apply to people who will be travelling on business. This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the visa exemption at this time. This raises security concerns that would not be responsible for Europe in this situation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the agreement as it provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will boost tourism.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The agreement we are debating is part of a broader reality which shows the commitment of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines to the launch of a programme of diversification of the economy. As a result, there has been a sharp increase in exports and a strengthening of the tourism sector. I have therefore decided to give a positive opinion, because the short-stay visa waiver agreement can only further strengthen relations with the European Union in a number of areas.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the EU-St. Vincent and the Grenadines visa-free agreement for short-term stays. According to Gabriel's report, the country in question poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants would be high, with a relatively low rate of visa refusal. Visa liberalisation simplifies travel conditions.  However, we have a duty to ask ourselves whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted against the agreement because they are hostile to the exception of visas for short-term stays, which it endorses. Visas are necessary to ensure national security, except for our reliable partners, especially European ones.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution promotes visa waiver for short-term stays between the EU and St Vincent and the Grenadines, deepening the relations already established through the Cotonou Agreement, the CELAC-EU and EU-Cariforum dialogues. In particular, it is hoped to delve into economic and cultural relations and political dialogue on human rights and fundamental freedoms.   St. Vincent and the Grenadines are recovering from a difficult period, as the export conditions of their main export product, bananas, were hit by natural disasters and deteriorated. The country is diversifying its economy by supporting the tourism sector and improving the level of social development. In this regard, this agreement will help to achieve these objectives and contribute to a rapprochement of the European and Pacific peoples. I therefore declare myself in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. The Agreement between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines for the exemption from short-stay visas has been concluded. The agreement provides for a visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines and the possibility to stay for a maximum period of 90 days for a period of 180 days on the territory of the Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines. I supported Mariya Gabriel's report because the Agreement was concluded and signed in accordance with the Council Decision and requires the consent of the European Parliament to enter into force, for better relations and easier travel.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The economy of St. Vincent and the Grenadines is still dominated by the banana and relevant product-growing sector, which employs more than half of the country's population. On the other hand, with the change in EU policy on banana imports, economic diversification in St. Vincent and the Grenadines has intensified in recent years, which is a significant and positive trend in any country. The European Union is not in the primary external trade and, in general, economic partners of this Caribbean country, especially compared to its regional neighbours, but this situation is gradually changing. Consequently, the abolition of the short-stay visa requirement could clearly be a strong step in this direction. Firstly, it concerns the development of tourism, which, more than two decades ago, outperformed the banana sector as the main source of replenishment of the state budget.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 An agreement which is applied provisionally and allows citizens of the Contracting Parties to travel without a visa to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period. The lifting of the visa requirement applies to all categories of persons travelling for any reason other than the pursuit of a paid activity. Saint Vincent and the Grenadines have been affected by natural disasters. This has negatively affected tourism and the economy and worsened exports of the main agricultural product , bananas. Nevertheless, the adoption of measures has succeeded in kick-starting the economy and strengthening social development. The country poses no threat to irregular migration or to security and public order.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines on the short-stay visa waiver because it is not complete and documented.   Furthermore, it is well probable that the implementation of this Recommendation will be used by potential beneficiaries to enter the EU without a visa and then illegally extend their stay in the Union after the expiry of the present short stay, thereby contributing to the increase in illegal immigration within the Union.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement. Saint Vincent and the Grenadines is now a plural and open democracy which, since it became independent in 1979, has held eight free and democratic elections and has seen three peaceful transfers of power between political parties. Civil and political rights and fundamental freedoms, such as freedom of speech and assembly, are protected by the constitution. Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has made considerable progress towards attaining the Millennium Development Goals. The conclusion of this agreement will create opportunities for cooperation in fundamental areas such as human rights and make it possible to conduct a regular and balanced political dialogue on more specific issues such as domestic violence or gender equality, which remain priorities for the Union.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. As with the previous ones, this is a whole series of agreements on the exemption of short-stay visas with several countries.  This agreement is supposed to help boost tourism, and strengthen trade relations and investments with these partners.  The key to these agreements is trust: the rate of visa refusal is very low because countries have confidence in visa applicants. According to the rapporteur, the countries covered by these agreements do not pose a threat, either in terms of irregular migration or security.  In view of the mass immigration that we are experiencing and which the EU is no longer able to manage, in view of the risks and the recent attacks against France, we can only be surprised, if we are worried, about this sudden desire for openness. Perhaps the timing is not the most timely!

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. Relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines are governed by the Partnership Agreement between the members of the African, Caribbean and Pacific Group of States, on the one hand, and the European Community and its States. The agreement signed establishes visa-free travel for UNION citizens and citizens of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons, regardless of the reason for their stay, except for stays for paid employment. This agreement is to be considered as an instrument aimed at intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms, between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines is the culmination of the deepening of political and economic relations established. Removing the visa requirement would mean helping the economic recovery of a country already heavily scarred by previous natural disasters, which have, among other things, contributed negatively to the export of the main agricultural product, bananas. I am therefore voting in favour of Mr Gabriel's report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On the merits of the case, I am in favour of short-stay visa exemptions in order to facilitate the mobility and travel of citizens of two parties, in this case the Member States in St Vincent and the Grenadines and vice versa. I regret, however, that the French overseas territories are excluded from it.  Moreover, cooperation with this country cannot be strengthened without holding it to account for the tax haven it represents. On form, I denounce all this procedure. Only the Commission has the power to negotiate these agreements on behalf of states and citizens. It does not keep the European Parliament informed of the state of the negotiations until the very end of the process. Above all, these agreements are implemented even before the European Parliament gives its approval or not. An exemplary witness that democracy has no place in the EU (note that the same procedure will be applied in the case of the transatlantic agreement). Under these conditions, I vote against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment, and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  With regard to the United Arab Emirates, it should be noted that 150,000 EU nationals are based there and most of them work there. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the United Arab Emirates each year, and some 230,000 Emiratis have travelled to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism.  Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on visa-free travel for short stays. I share the rapporteur's position that this agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, constituting an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, but also for deepening political debate and dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I chose to support this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement between the EU and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on visa liberalisation reflects the successful relations that began to be formed after Saint Vincent and the Grenadines gained independence. The situation in the country has not always been the easiest, especially as a result of natural disasters affecting the export of the most important agricultural product, bananas. Today, however, the country has seen positive developments and economic recovery, with the country starting to focus on tourism, external trade and social development. The conclusion of the agreement will be an opportunity to cooperate on human rights issues, to achieve the SDGs and to strengthen relations. However, the main objective will be to give new impetus to the ongoing trade and exchange between the two parties.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's approval of the agreement between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines on visa-free this is an opening gesture that reflects European values. This approval completes a process initiated under the previous Legislature to exempt from visas nationals of several third countries who meet all security, immigration and public order requirements.  I am pleased that among the 9 countries whose bilateral agreements have been approved today are several African-Caribbean-Pacific Group states. The presence of St. Vincent and the Grenadines among the countries whose nationals are now exempt from visas is sure to deepen the close ties that already bind the European Union to the Caribbean states. Political and commercial relations with St. Vincent and the Grenadines will only be strengthened.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to the EU-Saint Vincent and the Grenadines agreement on the short-stay visa waiver, which will provide a new visa regime for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will bring people on both sides closer and will boost tourism.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should wisely allow legal access to third country nationals, as one of the means of both managing migration and protecting its good image, consistent with its values. Of course, reciprocity should also always be sought, in order to also benefit directly EU citizens when travelling abroad. I supported the agreement on the short-stay visa waiver with Saint Vincent and the Grenadines as part of this possible menu of wisdom.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2014, the Islands of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines are among the third countries whose nationals are exempt from visa requirements when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently negotiated a bilateral agreement to this end between 12 November and 11 December 2014 between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. The agreement was corked in Brussels on 28 May 2015 and has been awaiting parliament's approval ever since. In its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs voted in favour of approving the agreement and voted in favour of the draft accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. These agreements provide for visa exemption for short-term stays for listed countries, in order to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants in these countries is high, with a historically low visa refusal rate. According to the rapporteur, the countries in question pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order.  However, the question arises whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. The answer is no, hence a vote against.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has established a visa-free agreement for short stays for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, in connection with travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days, and the European Parliament therefore needs to approve the respective agreement.  Visa facilitation allows peoples to be rapproched and economic, cultural and political relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines closer together, strengthening the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement, a partnership agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the European Union and its Member States. Several categories of persons, regardless of the reason for visiting the country, are covered by this visa facilitation agreement, except in the case of paid activities.  I am voting in favour of this agreement, because I consider it essential to establish relations between the European Union and other communities, which will provide benefits for both sides in the economic, political and social field, and enhance bilateral cooperation dialogues.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the previous reports on the short-stay visa exemption, I voted against the one concerning the agreement with St. Vincent and the Grenadines, because the timing is not appropriate.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which ratifies the agreement on short-stay visa waiver and allows for EU citizens and citizens of the participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines. The aim was to allow the visa-free travel regime for European and St Vincentian nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by our colleague Mariya Gabriel on the agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for nationals of both parties concerned who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period. The visa exemption covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, official service and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except that of a paid activity.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I vote in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and saint Vincent and the Grenadines on the exemption from short-stay visas. This agreement provides an excellent opportunity to boost tourism, facilitate investment and dynamise trade, thereby increasing the importance of economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the higher state.  In addition, the agreement offers new allies to join forces on issues of such importance as the fight against terrorism. We also see the emergence of political dialogue as a positive, most often aimed at joint action against corruption, criminal networks and trafficking in human beings.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation on the draft Council decision that provides a visa-free travel agreement for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This recommendation, too, would not have received my approval in the European Parliament. Visa-free travel is out of the question for me. Functioning border controls are very important today, and visa-free travel can very quickly have a negative impact on Europe. I also believe that visa-free travel could increase the flow of refugees into Europe.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Economically, Saint Vincent and the Grenines have had a difficult time due to natural disasters and the deterioration of the export conditions of the main agricultural product. This agreement will make it possible to strengthen relations between the parties and to stimulate trade.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The achievement and adoption of an agreement between the EU and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, allowing short-stay visa-free travel, is an important step towards closer rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and those of the Caribbean and, more generally, a politically relevant instrument under the Cotonou Agreement. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support an agreement between the European Union and the state of St Vincent and the Grenadines on a short-stay visa waiver. I welcome the further development of friendly relations between the European Union and st Vincent and the Grenadines. I am pleased that the visa waiver covers all categories of persons wishing to facilitate travel and short-term stay without a visa, of a maximum of 90 days in any period within 180 days from the date of the first registered entry. The agreement allows citizens of the European Union and citizens of St Vincent and the Grenadines to stay without a visa on the territory of the other Contracting Party. This also offers numerous opportunities not only for the citizens of St Vincent and the Grenadines, but also for EU citizens through new business opportunities and facilitation of travel.  Due to the close relationship between the European Union and Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, in particular on the basis of the association agreements of those countries to the implementation, application and development of the Schengen acquis, I call on those countries to conclude bilateral visa waiver agreements with St Vincent and the Grenadines for short stays containing provisions as in this Agreement.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the previous reports on the exemption of short-stay visas, I voted against the one concerning the agreement with St. Vincent and the Grenadines, because the timing is not right, in the midst of a migration crisis of unprecedented magnitude.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the abolition of short-stay visas for citizens of St Vincent and the Grenadines within the European Union, with the exception of Ireland and the United Kingdom. I believe this decision will enhance cooperation between the EU and this island country and boost exchanges and development, which is why I supported this proposal. Citizens of my country, Croatia, can already travel to St. Vincent and the Grenadines without a visa, which is why it seems appropriate to provide the same to the citizens of this country. I hope that the EU will consistently stick to visa reciprocity rules with third countries that do not yet apply the same visa regime for nationals of all 28 member states.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – This proposal is strongly related to the fact that St Vincent and the Grenadines are one of the signatories of the Cotonou Agreement and is a tool to strengthen the political dialogue between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines on fundamental human rights and freedoms. Natural disasters in recent years have significantly harmed agriculture and tourism, which are two main export products of St. Vincent and the Grenadines.  However, thanks to recent excellent macroeconomic moves, as well as socio-economic progress, economic developments are once again having a positive direction. In a political context, the Constitution of St. Vincent and the Grenadines firmly protects the civil and political rights of citizens and, like the European Union, successfully carries out democratic processes.  The information shows that the vast majority of visa applications are accepted and that St Vincent and the Grenadines do not present any security risk to the European Union. For all the above reasons, I support the recommendation.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement signed in Brussels on 28 May 2015 establishes visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. As a result of a number of major natural disasters, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines have improved their external trade performance as a result of macroeconomic policies and have been able to successfully launch an economic diversification programme, which has been accompanied by measures to increase the volume of exports, strengthen the tourism sector and improve the level of social development. I voted in favour of the agreement because it will further strengthen relations between the two parties and give new impetus to trade.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the approval of the agreement between the EU and St Vincent and the Grenadines to remove the visa requirement for short stays, i.e. 90 days shorter, for all categories of people (ordinary, diplomatic). Indeed, it is important that European citizens can return to St Vincent and the Grenadines without a visa and vice versa. This visa exemption should, I hope, support the tourism sector in this Caribbean island.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. This agreement seals the visa exemption for very short stays and on the basis of reciprocity with St. Vincent. A way to make travel easier for our nationals, whether for tourism or business.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that Regulation, the Council authorised the Commission on 9 October 2014 to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. The negotiations were concluded on 11 December 2014 and the Agreement was signed on 28 May 2015.   The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period.  Because I believe that this is an important agreement to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify the political dialogue between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines, I voted in favour of its approval.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the EU and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, with high political importance and is also an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, as well as intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this draft agreement between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines with regard to the short-stay visa exemption, which has already been applied on an interim basis since May 2015. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and third country nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  It should be noted that the United Kingdom and Ireland do not participate in these agreements and are not subject to the provisions of these agreements, as are the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported this Proposal for a Recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on the exemption of short-stay visas.  The strengthening of economic and cultural relations as well as the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement were fundamental to the increase of bilateral cooperation and to the facilitation and conclusion of this agreement.  This country has been heavily plagued by natural disasters that have led to difficult times, with direct economic consequences - in the case of the export of its main agricultural product, bananas. Local tourism has also been hampered, resulting in a barrier to economic recovery.  However, the positive evolution that this country has been having reflected in the improvement of foreign trade, which has allowed the diversification of its economy, the focus on export, tourism and social development.  Not posing any threat in terms of irregular migration or security and public order, this agreement will help achieve the proposed objectives, which is why I deserved my vote in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines on the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines nationals who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period. Visa exemption benefits all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason, other than paid activity.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of concluding the agreement on short-stay visas between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines as it promotes tourism, economic and cultural development. The agreement will allow all categories of persons regardless of the reason for their stay, with the exception of stays for paid employment, to travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and St Vincent and the Grenadines.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Sanvicentin citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite disagreeing with the way in which the negotiations have been conducted – with obscurantism and without the participation of parliaments – I voted in favour of its ratification as we think it is okay to lighten the bureaucratic burden and the end of restrictions on freedom of movement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement approved by the European Parliament today lays down new provisions for visa-free travel for EU citizens and citizens of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for their stay. This agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic, tourist and cultural relations and, finally, will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in any visa policy so I voted against this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is the fifth Caribbean country that we have voted in favour of a new visa regime for today, and this will bring a lot of benefits to this Windward Islands nation. It is regrettable that Members from the ENF voted against these agreements at committee level, and evidently do not wish for better relationships with these countries. These agreements will step up economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue on various, important issues, such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Lifting visa requirements for stays of less than 90 days with the Archipelazo of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines will promote economic and cultural relations, but will also benefit from an intensifying political dialogue. At present, the local economy is heavily dependent on banana exports, so it is important that the country transforms and improves the attractiveness of its tourism. It should be noted that the country has recently gone through a difficult time economically due to natural disasters and deteriorated export conditions. Facilitating travel between the EU and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines can therefore provide an incentive for an overall improvement in this difficult situation. I support this agreement on visa liberalisation, which will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and deepen the economic interconnecting of businesses. Although Saint Vincent and the Grenadines have already improved external trade performance and are applying macroeconomic policies aimed at diversifying the economy, tourism remains marginalised. I therefore believe that intensifying relations with the EU will be beneficial for Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, will make it possible to strengthen economic cooperation and will also be an opportunity to have a regular dialogue on the state of human rights.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this amendment to the agreement between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Also, such a proposal to amend the agreement improves relations between these countries. The abolition of short-stay visas allows citizens to gain new experiences and promotes the development of mobility.  After their stay in the European Union, citizens can transfer their newfound experiences to the country from which they come and thus further improve relations between the European Union and the country in question, as well as the situation in their country. And in an indirect way they promote the European Union in their own country.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement which will allow EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.  The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver programme takes into account the situation of Member States that are not part of Schengen such as the UK and Ireland.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 2012 509/2014 Of the European Parliament and the Council, Regulation (EC) No 509/2014 has been amended. 539/2001 It defines a list of 19 countries, including St Vincent and the Grenadines whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, official and special passport) whose purpose of the trip does not include the performance of paid activity.  Therefore, citizens of the European Union can reside in the territory of St Vincent and the Grenadines for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. Also, citizens of St Vincent and the Grenadines can reside in the territory of the Member States which fully apply the Schengen acquis for a maximum of 90 days for any 180-day period.  I support the Council regulation on the abolition of short-stay visas between the European Union and St Vincent and the Grenadines with a view to further developing friendly relations between the Contracting Parties and with the desire to facilitate travel by ensuring entry and short-term stay without visas for their citizens.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on the short-stay visa waiver. Natural disasters have in the past affected Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, particularly in the area of deteriorating conditions for banana exports, which constitute the most important agricultural product. In recent years, the economic situation has been improving, and I believe that the lifting of the short-stay visa requirement will only improve this. There is also a great opportunity to improve cooperation in the field of tourism, where there is still room for improvement.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These reports relate to the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States. As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and will not take part in the agreement, I have abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although we disagree with the procedure followed, as the Council and the Commission did not include the European Parliament in the negotiations, we nevertheless voted in favour of the reports because as ACPL we are in favour of a general visa liberalisation regime for third-country travellers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Saint Vincent and the Grenadines as a country, does not theoretically represent any threat to the EU, either in terms of illegal immigration, nor in terms of security and public order. The short-stay visa requirement could be lifted, but there are no measurable data and no real-world tests have been carried out in areas relating to illegal immigration, public policy and security, but also in the Union's external relations with that country. As with the other countries of the 'Koton Agreement', it is inconceivable that the practice of signing visa waiver agreements should be applied and provisionally implemented before they are approved by the European Parliament.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed my political group and the subject matter expert. This visa-free agreement for short-term stays is a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country , which has strong political significance under the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of concluding the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on the short-stay visa waiver, which was signed in May 2015. It allows visa-free travel for EU citizens and for the citizens of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons, travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I welcome that the Agreement strengthens relations between the EU and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, which is significant in the context of the Cotonou Agreement. It is also another way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The action of the ACP Joint Parliamentary Group of countries and the EU is reflected in further useful requirements, such as the request for the adoption of an agreement by this High House on the abolition of short-stay visas between the EU and St Vincent and the Grenadines. Such mutual agreements should serve development objectives, in the first place national and regional interests. St Vincent and the Grenadines are a democratic state that has made significant progress since gaining independence in 1979 in protecting fundamental rights and freedoms, such as freedom of expression, but also political rights. In order to make further progress and to assist less developed countries in eradicating poverty, fostering economic growth, but also eradicating discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, gender identity or religion, intervention of developed countries reflected in this example of cooperation is essential.  For further progress, it is necessary to implement projects that unite the resources of underdeveloped countries with those that have been developed. I therefore believe that the visa waiver agreement can contribute to the progress of this less developed country and boost its economic growth, and I voted positively.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on the short-stay visa waiver. The proposal for an agreement on visa facilitation is intended to conclude an agreement with Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on the facilitation of the issuance of short-stay visas.  The Agreement takes into account the fact that some Member States do not fully apply the Schengen acquis. The Agreement also provides for visa-free travel for European Union citizens and citizens of Saint Vincent and the Grenadine when travelling to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of carrying out paid work.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and St Vincent and the Grenadines.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation would simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. However, the question arises as to whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. This inflection in visa policy is contrary to what common sense dictates.  So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both a success of deepening relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, which is of great political importance under the Cotonou Agreement, and a further instrument for strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. That is why we voted in favour of the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and St Vincent and the Grenadines.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The Agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenaddin who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party and stay there for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I stress that visa-free travel will make a significant contribution to bring Europeans and caribbean populations closer together. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens not only to take full advantage of the ACP-EU partnership, but also to participate in it at an economically inexpensive and practical journey.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒  I voted in favour of providing visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I acknowledge that in the economic sphere, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has gone through a difficult period, marked in particular by natural disasters and a deterioration of the terms under which its main agricultural product, the banana, is exported. These facts have acted as a brake on the country’s economic recovery and have seriously damaged its tourism. But due to the positive socioeconomic progress that Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has achieved in recent years, this agreement is highly significant.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament must approve the conclusion of this agreement which has already been negotiated by the European Commission. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, as well as the rapporteur for the agreement, have given a positive recommendation and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report which includes an exemption from the visa requirement for citizens of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines and our own EU citizens. The abolition of the visa requirement shall apply to journeys of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. I am convinced that this agreement will contribute to better trade relations, more investment and more tourism.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the draft Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and that third country on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that third country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on visa-free travel for short stays. The Agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. A joint declaration on the interpretation of the concept of '90-day period' is annexed to the agreement. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity. For the foregoing, the vote in favour.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines on the short-stay visa waiver, because I believe that it will help to develop the economy in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines and simplify the investment opportunities of the European Union countries in these two countries.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Emirati citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without the need for a visa.
