Despite initially agreeing with the lightening of the bureaucratic burden and freedom of movement, we understand that this agreement has been signed in an obscurantist manner between the European institutions and the Emirati authorities. The United Arab Emirates also makes no trade-off for guaranteeing the rights of women or LGTBI persons, and maintains legislation that is completely unensure of rights for migrant workers. We have therefore decided to abstain in the ratification of the agreement.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement with the United Arab Emirates for visa exemption for short-term stays.  If in this report the liberalisation of visas for short-term stays is presented as an opportunity to boost tourism, simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs or encourage investment, I consider that at present it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude similar agreements.  Faced with a growing terrorist threat and European mass immigration policy, these agreements seem inappropriate to me. Indeed, even if the United Arab Emirates is not directly a starting point for immigration, that many Europeans leave there every year for economic reasons and the Emiratis are engaged in luxury tourism in Europe, I consider that it is not wise to make this kind of agreement in the current context, regardless of the country concerned.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report gives Parliament the consent to waive the visa requirement to stay for up to three months (90 days) over a period of 6 months (180 days). As this decision represents significant progress in bilateral relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement requires the exemption of short-stay visas for people from the United Arab Emirates. The aim of the agreement is to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism.   Nearly 150,000 EU nationals are based there and most of them work there. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the United Arab Emirates each year, and nearly 230,000 Emiratis have travelled to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism.  However, it is not appropriate to conclude such agreements, even though the porousness of Europe's borders is the bed of terrorism in Europe. Moreover, together with my colleagues from the National Front we oppose this desire to create a world without borders.  So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is consistent with the principles of UKIP to vote against such issues being determined at European Union level. It is for individual sovereign nations to determine their own visa requirements, and to assess whether or not a short-stay visa waiver scheme is appropriate for them. This opposition should not be taken as making any commentary upon the appropriateness of the United Kingdom, hypothetically, making a bilateral agreement with the United Arab Emirates along similar lines.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the agreement between the EU and the United Arab Emirates on visa-free travel in the case of short stays. This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text which endorses the agreement with the United Arab Emirates on visa exemption for short-term stays. Since the European Union refuses to control its external borders as it should and has abolished the internal borders of the Schengen area, it is urgent that France regains control of its national borders... and enforces its laws, particularly in the area of border deportation. It is therefore on principle that I am opposed to this type of agreement.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. It is the first Arab state with which the EU signs a visa-free agreement. It should be noted, however, that the EU has had a liaison office there since 1993. The exemption here is based on the desire to strengthen economic and cultural relations with the United Arab Emirates and to intensify political dialogue, particularly to stabilize the region and fight terrorism. It should also be noted that, in parallel with the agreement, an UAE-EU technical working group on human rights has been set up. More than 150,000 EU nationals are settled in the UAE mainly for professional reasons and 1.6 million Europeans visit the UAE each year. In 2014, 230,000 Emiratis travelled to Europe mainly for business or luxury tourism. The rapporteur believes that the UAE poses no risk related to illegal immigration, public order or security and has provided the European institutions with the necessary elements in this regard. In addition, they issue biometric passports to their citizens. I approved of that point.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. However, we abstained in the case of the United Arab Emirates. Respect for human rights must be a precondition for any kind of agreement between the EU and any country. In the case of the UAE, energy and commercial interests cannot serve as a pretext for re-providing respect for human, labour and social rights to the background. This is not a country in which human and labour rights violations are made specific, but are systematically given and there are no democratic mechanisms to denounce or eradicate them.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which supports the visa waiver for short-term stays for citizens of the United Arab Emirates with the aim of facilitating travel between this destination and the European Union (EU). The removal of visas in the United Arab Emirates shall apply to travel of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days, for any tourist, cultural, scientific or business trip, except those in which they enter a paid activity. Visa liberalisation in these countries is part of a proposal by the European Commission which extends to the exemption of visas in nineteen countries. We also call for full reciprocity to be used.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are supposed to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. As before, this should simplify trade, especially since the country poses no threat.  For the United Arab Emirates, it is known that more than 150,000 European nationals are settled there and the vast majority of them have seized opportunities for economic activity. In addition, 1.6 million Europeans a year visit the UAE and in 2014, 230,000 Emiratis travelled to Europe mainly for business and luxury tourism trips.  Nevertheless, I also question the usefulness of concluding visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the EU has lost control over mass immigration and its borders.  So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the importance of the economic interests of many of our citizens and entrepreneurs in the United Arab Emirates, I wanted to support with my vote this report granting visa waiver to both parties in case of stays for a maximum period of 90 days.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. Following the amendment of Regulation (EU) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EC) No 509/2014, the UAE has been included in the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of this Regulation on 20 May 2014, and with the authorisation of the Council, the Commission negotiated and closed a bilateral agreement between the EU and the UAE in November 2014. The Agreement was signed on 6 May 2015 in Brussels and the European Parliament is now granting its approval to it, with my vote in favour. This is the first Arab state with which the EU enters into a visa-free agreement, which includes the establishment of a joint technical working group on human rights. The signed Agreement establishes a visa-free scheme for EU and UAE citizens travelling to the territory of the other party for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. Visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport holders) travelling for any reason except to pursue a paid activity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on visa-free travel in the case of short stays. This agreement on the short stay of visa waiver is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the UAE, further reinforcing the important political significance of the Cotonou Agreement, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural ties and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. This Agreement establishes visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and the UAE travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party and staying there for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa-free regime applies to all categories of persons (holders of ordinary, diplomatic, service and/or official and special passports) travelling to the country for any purpose other than persons who are on paid employment.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short-stays represents both the success of deepening relations between the European Union and that country, which is of great political importance, and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. With regard to mobility, the available data show that the reliability of visa applicants is high and there are few applications rejected. The country poses no threat to irregular migration, security or public order.  I also consider it important that the visa waiver is not a negligible means of eddation between the people of the European Union and the citizens of the country concerned. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens to make full use of the opportunities provided by the partnership in a full, cheaper and simpler way.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed visa waiver decision as it implements the agreement signed in May between the EU and the United Arab Emirates on visa-free travel by citizens of both communities and countries. This arrangement will apply to journeys of no more than 90 days in any 180-day period. The exception will be the only trip with the intention of carrying out paid work, which will still require a working visa.  This strengthens cooperation between the EU and the US at political level as well. We know that economic cooperation is already very good. Many Europeans already live and work in the US, and around 1.6 million travel there annually. Tourism to the US is very highly developed, and the abolition of visas will, in my opinion, develop even more. I agree that the lifting of the visa requirement between the two Parties is an important means of bringing the European and the peoples of the Arabian Peninsula closer. This agreement will also have a profound impact on the lower financial and practical costs of citizens, and I am pleased to welcome it!

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement with the United Arab Emirates is an important milestone of symbolic and political value: it is a sign of the good path that the EU and its contracting party have taken together in recent years, witnessed by the deepening of political, diplomatic and joint cooperation relations. An action that facilitates the movement between the citizens of both contractors and which – because of the sign of closeness and trust it represents – will be another instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on the issues to which the European Union and the Member States are attached, not least the protection of the human rights and fundamental freedoms of each human being.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to this report, these visa-free agreements for short-term stays should boost tourism and strengthen our trade relations with the United Arab Emirates. These new provisions will make it easier for entrepreneurs and investors to move around, intensifying economic ties between businesses. Moreover, this liberalisation of visas should not pose a threat to illegal immigration in view of the particularly low visa refusal rate. On the other hand, at a time when Western countries, in particular France, are facing an extremely serious terrorist threat, it is absolutely not appropriate to conclude these agreements. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Collaborative relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates emerged in accordance with the 1988 Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates, and in 2013 the European Union strengthened bilateral cooperation relations. The signed agreement provides for the possibility of visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the United Arab Emirates in the case of travel within the territory of the other Party for a specified period of 90 days. Visa waiver shall apply to all categories of persons travelling for various reasons, with the exception of persons engaged in paid activities. This agreement to hold a fixed-term residence visa constitutes progress in the relationship between the EU and the United Arab Emirates and strengthens the economic and cultural relationship. It also intensifies political dialogue on a number of issues including human rights as well as fundamental freedoms. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it is beneficial for both the European Union and the United Arab Emirates, for better economic, cultural and political cooperation.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The UAE is on this list as tourism is marginal compared to economic mobility with the EU for business travel. However, the positive opinion remains given the important economic peculiarity of the country for many of our citizens and entrepreneurs.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates crowns a long-established desire in terms of bilateral cooperation between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates. I would remind you that this is the first Arab state with which the European Union will sign such an agreement. I voted in favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates, as I believe that it could have positive consequences for economic development.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this vote on the ground of human rights violations, particularly for workers, migrant workers and women. Whilst this report was concerned with a visa waiver, it must be noted that the United Arab Emirates has an appalling record on human rights.  As Human Rights Watch claimed recently: ‘The UAE uses its affluence to mask the government’s serious human rights problems. The government arbitrarily detains individuals it perceives as posing a threat, and a new counterterrorism law poses a further threat to dissidents and rights activists. Security forces have been implicated in torturing detainees in pre-trial detention, authorities have invoked repressive laws to prosecute critics of the government. Labour abuses persist, as migrant construction workers facing serious exploitation, including on one of the country’s most high-profile projects. Female domestic workers are excluded from regulations that apply to workers in other sectors.’  Due to these human rights concerns, I abstained on this vote.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates, assuming important political significance as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Under reciprocal conditions, visa-free travel also brings benefits for tourist or business travel to the EU and makes it easier for Europeans to visit their family members who have settled in these countries or to travel for professional or tourism reasons. Furthermore, the United Arab Emirates does not pose a threat either in terms of irregular migration or in terms of security and public order. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of the draft Council decision. This short-stay visa waiver agreement makes a decisive contribution to deepening relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates and is a complementary means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. More than 150 000 EU citizens have settled in the United Arab Emirates and the vast majority of them have taken advantage of opportunities for economic activities. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the United Arab Emirates each year. In 2014, some 230,000 citizens from the Emirates travelled to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The proposal for an EU agreement with the United Arab Emirates on short-stay visa waiver is part of a wider effort to improve travel conditions for citizens of third countries. Although such efforts are positive moves and must be viewed positively, there are nevertheless strong concerns about violations of human rights and freedom of expression as well as women's rights in the United Arab Emirates. As any violation of citizens' rights finds us vertically opposed, I have decided to abstain in this vote, despite its positive nature. The vote in favour was an error, which is why they corrected the vote.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. The agreement initialled provides for visa-free travel for UNION citizens and UAE citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days over a period of 180 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of stays aimed at carrying out a paid activity. The visa waiver agreement allows citizens not only to benefit fully from the EU-UAE partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling more cheaply and practically.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation because I felt it was right to take the side of the more than 150,000 European citizens residing in the United Arab Emirates, and above all because the vast majority of them took advantage of opportunities to carry out economic activities. I would also like to point out that every year, some 1.6 million Europeans visit the United Arab Emirates; in 2014, about 230,000 UAE citizens traveled to Europe, mainly for business trips and luxury tourism, data that cannot but be underestimated. Finally, this agreement therefore makes it easier for many Europeans to visit their family members who have settled in the United Arab Emirates or to travel for professional reasons or for tourism, and the same applies to citizens of the United Arab Emirates.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote because the agreements will encourage people-to-people contacts, boost tourism, and invigorate business between the EU and these countries.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 To cross the external border of the European Union, third-country nationals need to hold a visa, in this case of short duration. However, many countries are already exempt from this obligation because they meet a set of criteria, approved in 2001 and 2014 by the European Parliament and the Council, which include respect for fundamental rights, the security of the visa system or the risk of illegal immigration. The visa waiver goes far beyond benefits for European tourists and the third country. In addition, it can enhance rapprochement and dialogue between cultures, economic growth, as well as contributed to the consolidation of democratic regimes.  So I am pleased to see the UAE on the list of exempt countries for short stays.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement is the result of the intensification of relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates. It is an instrument aimed at strengthening economic and cultural relations with the aim of intensifying political dialogue on a number of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Taking into account that the United Arab Emirates finds a high percentage of citizens of European nationality, one of the main causes that hinder travel to Europe is the visa requirement, as well as its cost and the need to plan your trip in advance. The visa waiver agreement would simplify movements between Europe and the United Arab Emirates, thus allowing people to travel for professional reasons or for tourism more easily. Moreover, today, the European Union is the UAE's main trading partner: this relationship can only be facilitated by the visa agreement. For the reasons listed above, I am convinced that this agreement is necessary, as it will make it possible to fully benefit from the partnership between the two countries by allowing cheaper and more practical travel.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The purpose of the proposal on the visa facilitation agreement is the conclusion of an agreement with the United Arab Emirates on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the United Arab Emirates when travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement provides that UAE citizens can stay in the territory of EU Member States for a period of 90 days over a maximum period of 180 days, without the need for a visa. The visa waiver is the culmination of the EU's relations with the United Arab Emirates, as it helps to intensify political dialogue, promotes tourist travel both from that country to Europe and vice versa, with a consequent impact on the economies of the countries involved. I am in favour of the agreement, which has ambitious and acceptable objectives.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Emirati citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite initially agreeing with the lightening of the bureaucratic burden and freedom of movement, we understand that this agreement has been signed in an obscurantist manner between the European institutions and the Emirati authorities. The United Arab Emirates also makes no trade-off for guaranteeing the rights of women or LGTBI persons, and maintains legislation that is completely unensure of rights for migrant workers. We have therefore decided to abstain in the ratification of the agreement.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-UAE relations take place within the framework of the 1988 EU-Gulf Cooperation Council Cooperation Agreement. The European Union opened a delegation in the United Arab Emirates in 2013, demonstrating its wish to strengthen bilateral cooperation.  The United Arab Emirates has been transferred to third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The agreement was signed in Brussels on 6 May 2015 and has now been approved by the European Parliament. The agreement signed provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for UAE nationals for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period of travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party. The UAE is the first Arab country with which the European Union is signing a visa waiver agreement.  More than 150,000 European citizens have settled in the United Arab Emirates, and around 1.6 million Europeans visit the country each year. In 2014, about 230,000 UAE citizens travelled to Europe, mainly for business or luxury tourism.  As the EU is the most important trading partner of the UAE in terms of trade relations and the UAE 14th place among the trade partners of the EU and its Member States, visa waiver can further boost economic relations.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which focuses on the negotiations carried out by the Commission with United Arab Emirates on a short-stay visa waiver. The visa waiver agreement must be viewed in a wider context as a tool for intensifying cooperation, in which context both parties have a shared interest in stabilising the macro-region and acting as sound and reliable partners in combating terrorism, trafficking in persons and climate change.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the potential commercial opportunities through increased tourism numbers and enhanced business relationships this agreement with the United Arab Emirates will hopefully provide. However, as this deal concerns the visa regime operated by Schengen member states, from which the United Kingdom has opted out, I will abstain on this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the approval of the European Parliament to the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and the United Arab Emirates negotiated by the European Commission, aimed at facilitating the issuance of short stays.  It allows EU citizens and UAE citizens to obtain a free visa on the territory of all contracting parties for up to 90 days over a period of 180 days. This visa applies to all categories of persons (regular, diplomatic, official and special passport holders) travelling for any type of reason except for paid activities. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The short-stay visa exemption measure between EU Member States and the United Arab Emirates is an important step forward in removing barriers to business travel and luxury tourism.  This agreement is therefore of significant economic importance at a time when trade between the two parties is reaching more than 50 million euros. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The Gabriel report aimed to remove the visa requirement for the Commonwealth of Dominica, Vanuatu, Trinidad and Tobago, Samoa, Grenada, East Timor, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines and the United Arab Emirates. These countries certainly do not pose a risk of uncontrolled immigration or a disturbance of public order. However, at a time when Islamist terrorists are looking for the slightest flaw in our defence in order to attack us, I do not find it appropriate to exempt certain countries from visas and to facilitate generally access to our territory from third countries. Although I am in favour of closer economic ties with these countries, I cannot knowingly take the risk of allowing ill-intentioned people to take advantage of this to harm European security. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and the United Arab Emirates. It is indisputable that the UAE is an industrialized country with high incomes, which is also a popular tourist destination. However, I cannot miss the fact that suspicions of cooperation between the UAE and Islamic State have intensified recently. I believe that they are justified, and the abolition of the visa regime would, in my view, pose a threat to the security of European citizens.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The United Arab Emirates, despite the glow of the tourist resorts of Dubai and Abu Dhabi, remains an Arab state in which every concept of human rights, equality, democracy and freedom of religion remain unknown words - a fenaki. Any free movement agreement concluded with such countries is a backdoor for EU states. Trade agreements and trade agreements, tourism and others, may continue to be carried out under controlled channels with a view to maintaining security and avoiding an influx of extremist elements. Finally, I would like to reiterate that I find it inconceivable that the visa waiver agreements should be signed and that they should be provisionally implemented when the European Parliament has not yet been approved.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to visa-free travel for third countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the decision to conclude the Agreement between the EU and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and UAE nationals who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party. The UAE is part of the bloc of Arab (ultraconservative) reactionary regimes that seek to contain the growing popular uprisings, putting an end to the region's imperialist objectives of dominance. France, Britain, Germany, Italy and Spain accounted for eighty percent of arms exports in the EU. Its main clients include Saudi Arabia (€4.2 billion) and the UAE (€1.9 billion), according to 2013 data. These, in turn, supply weapons to mercenary groups that destabilise and terrorise the peoples, having led to the latest terrorist attacks that, in Europe and the Middle East, are adding to the victims. Apart from this framework, it is not too much to remember that the peoples of the UAE are confronted with the limitation and repression of fundamental freedoms and rights, such as freedom of expression, workers' rights, the rights of women and children.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates. More than 150,000 European citizens reside in the United Arab Emirates, and the vast majority of them have taken opportunities to carry out economic activities. The visa waiver agreement would therefore make it easier for many Europeans to travel, as well as lasting bilateral relations that will benefit from being deepened.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission negotiated an agreement with the United Arab Emirates on the visa waiver for short stays on behalf of the European Union. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for Citizens of the European Union and for citizens of that territory when travelling to the United Arab Emirates for a maximum duration of 90 days in any 180-day period. At the same time, this agreement represents the culmination and deepening of relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates, which is a politically very important way of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the conclusion of the short-stay visa agreement.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The United Arab Emirates, apart from the glow of the tourist resorts of Dubai and Abu Dhabi, is still an Arab state where every concept of human rights, equality, democracy and freedom of religion remain unknown concepts, a chimera. Free movement to and from such countries opens a backdoor for EU states. Trade agreements and trade agreements, tourism and others, must and can be carried out under controlled channels with a view to maintaining security and avoiding an influx of extremist elements. Finally, it is inconceivable in my view the practice of signing visa waiver agreements and their provisional application before the approval of the European Parliament. For these reasons, I am voting against the EU-United Arab Emirates Agreement on short-stay visa waiver.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has negotiated on behalf of the EU an agreement with the United Arab Emirates on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement can only be concluded if the European Parliament has given its consent. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of this territory when travelling to the United Arab Emirates for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver agreement must be viewed in a wider context as a tool for intensifying cooperation, in which context both parties have a shared interest in stabilising the macro-region and acting as sound and reliable partners in various fields such as combating terrorism, trafficking in persons and climate change.  The United Arab Emirates are also becoming major players in development and international aid. In this field too, the European Union and the United Arab Emirates can be full partners. The visa waiver agreement therefore testifies to bilateral relations which will gain by being intensified. European citizens will not only be able to fully benefit from the partnership between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates but also participate in it by travelling at a reduced, economical and practical cost.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today we are giving our consent to the conclusion of the agreement with the EU which has already been negotiated with the European Commission. The purpose of the proposal on visa facilitation is the conclusion of an agreement on facilitating the issue of short-stay visas. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out paid activity. We support today’s resolution and believe that it is important to have a good agreement because it helps to fight organised crime and terrorist organisations.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both a success in deepening relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. More than 150,000 European citizens have settled in the UNITED Arab Emirates, the vast majority of whom have moved there with some economic opportunity. Around 1.6 million Europeans visit the UAE each year. In 2014, about 230,000 UAE citizens travelled to Europe, mainly for business or luxury tourism. According to the World Tourism Organisation, the most important factors preventing UAE nationals from travelling to Europe include the visa requirement, the price of the visa and the need to plan the trip well in advance because of the visa requirement. The visa waiver agreement will make it easier for many Europeans to visit relatives in the UAE or to take part in professional or private travel, and the latter will also apply to UAE nationals. Not to mention the fact that there are already a number of direct flights linking the country to the Member States of the European Union. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the important relations between the EU and the United Arab Emirates. More than 150,000 European citizens are established in the UAE and the vast majority of them engage in economic activities. Approximately 1.6 million Europeans visit the UAE every year. In 2014, some 230,000 UAE citizens traveled to Europe, mainly on business trips and luxury tourism. The Visa Waiver Agreement will therefore facilitate existing relationships.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the EU-United Arab Emirates visa waiver agreement for short stays, as I do not support such cooperation with states that definitely lack respect for human rights.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The agreement is a further step towards intensifying cooperation between the states of Europe and the United Arab Emirates. Especially uncomplicated short stays make an important contribution to cultural exchange and economic development.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation concerning the short-stay visa waiver programme which allows EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less. The agreement takes into account the situation of the Member States that are not part of Schengen such as Ireland and the UK.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. •u2012 Visa waiver agreements for short stays represent a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. However, we abstained in the case of the United Arab Emirates. Respect for human rights must be a precondition for any kind of agreement between the EU and any country. In the case of the UAE, energy and commercial interests cannot serve as a pretext for re-providing respect for human, labour and social rights to the background. This is not a country in which human and labour rights violations are made specific, but are systematically given and there are no democratic mechanisms to denounce or eradicate them.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which focuses on the negotiations carried out by the Commission with the United Arab Emirates on a short-stay visa waiver. The visa waiver agreement must be viewed in a wider context as a tool for intensifying cooperation, in which context both parties have a shared interest in stabilising the macro-region and acting as sound and reliable partners in combating terrorism, trafficking in persons and climate change.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As with the majority of my constituents in Wales, I do not feel that it is the place of the EU to decide who can and cannot come into my country. I voted against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on the short-stay visa waiver because UAE cooperated closely with the EU during the bilateral negotiations including on the question of human rights and a UAE-EU technical working party on human rights has been set up as part of the agreement.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although in previous relevant votes we have taken a positive stance on the visa regime for third-country travellers, we choose as far as the United Arab Emirates is concerned to abstain because of the major concerns raised about the situation within the country in relation to the violation of fundamental human rights and the use of violence against dissidents, women, workers, immigrants, etc.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this agreement as the waiver of short-stay visas represent a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In 2014, around 230 000 Emiratis travelled to Europe, mainly for purposes of business and more than 150 000 European nationals live in the United Arab Emirates, the vast majority of whom have seized opportunities to engage in economic activities. Some 1.6 million Europeans visit the United Arab Emirates each year. The visa waiver agreement will therefore enable many Europeans to visit their relatives in the United Arab Emirates more easily or to travel for professional or tourist purposes, while the same is true for Emiratis.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Short-stay visa waiver agreements, which would provide visa-free travel for citizens, were signed in May 2015 between the EU and St Lucia, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Grenada, St Vincent and the Grenadines, the Republic of Vanuatu, the independent State of Samoa, the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago, the United Arab Emirates and Timor-Leste. The visa would cover a period of 90 days out of any 180-day period. The agreement has received unanimous support in the Council and will not apply to the United Kingdom and Ireland. Since this agreement will likely increase commercial opportunities through increased tourism and promote commercial opportunities, which I strongly support, I have voted in favour of this report. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I am in favour of the lifting of the requirement for a short-stay visa, i.e. three months over a period of 180 days, for UAE nationals. This country is an essential commercial and strategic partner for France, especially on the military level since it hosts a French military base on its territory. The migration risk for this country, whose GDP per capita is equivalent to that of France, is very low. However, beyond the United Arab Emirates, I wonder about the strategic choice of granting short-stay visa exemptions in turn when for some of these countries, particularly those in the Western Balkans, the risk of migration and to the internal security of the Member States of the European Union actually exists. There is a regulation that lists a positive list of countries whose nationals are exempt from the short-stay visa requirement. These countries are now 42 including the United States and Japan and will soon be 61. Should this list not be revised in light of international upheavals?

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the waiver of short-stay visas as an important step forward for the United Arab Emirates economic and cultural area.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on the abolition of short-stay visas, as this empowers relations between the Union and the UAE, but also between other Arab countries. There are a large number of EU citizens visiting the Arab Emirates, and an estimated 230,000 UAE citizens visited Europe in 2014 for official travel and luxury tourism, so the abolition of short-stay visas will allow for easier flow of people.  The United Arab Emirates is classified as an industrialized high-income country whose first economic partner is the European Union, but further efforts are needed in the domain of respect for human rights. I consider, therefore, that this agreement can further enhance bilateral relations and stabilise the macro-climate concerned.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment and boost tourism. It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order. With regard to the United Arab Emirates, it should be noted that 150,000 EU nationals are based there and most of them work there. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the UAE each year, and some 230,000 Emiratis have travelled to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism. Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I, with my fellow UKIP colleagues voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short-term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With my vote, I supported the lifting of the visa requirement for short stays of citizens of selected ACP Group partner countries and the United Arab Emirates in the European Union. This measure concerning exclusively safe countries with an excellent level of cooperation with European countries will increase the interest of non-European tourists in visiting EU countries. At the same time, reciprocal visa waiver for short stays will greatly facilitate travel by Union citizens to the countries concerned.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Mariya Gabriel's report on the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates.  The European Parliament was to decide on the conclusions of the agreement between the EU and the United Arab Emirates which was negotiated by the Commission. The aim was to facilitate the obtaining of visas. Citizens of both groups will be exempt from visas for stays of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. This exemption does not apply to people who will be travelling on business. This recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the visa exemption at this time. This raises security concerns that would not be responsible for Europe in this situation.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the ratification of the agreement as it provides for visa-free travel for EU citizens and will boost tourism.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – It is precisely today's agenda that we are voting on a report on cooperation between the Emirates and Europol, which is apropos of the fact that the country is increasingly becoming a centre of economic and financial crime. The proceeds of fraud and money laundering within the EU are often re-investing there, and criminals involved in these scams have also found refuge there. So should we make it easier for criminals with visa waiver? I could only vote no to that.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The short-stay visa waiver agreement between the Eu ropean Union and the United Arab Emirates is a further step towards strengthening economic and cultural relations. With regard to tourism, the data show that about 1.6 million citizens visit the United Arab Emirates every year. I have decided to vote in favour because the agreement, in addition to the economic advantages, will make it easier for european citizens to visit the United Arab Emirates and vice versa, giving a considerable boost to the tourism sector.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the EU-United Arab Emirates visa waiver agreement for short-term stays. According to Gabriel's report, the country in question poses no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order.  In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants would be high, with a relatively low rate of visa refusal. Visa liberalisation simplifies travel conditions. However, we have a duty to ask ourselves whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted against the agreement because they are hostile to the exception of visas for short-term stays, which it endorses. Visas are necessary to ensure national security, except for our reliable partners, especially European ones.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This Resolution promotes visa waiver for short-term stays between the EU and the United Arab Emirates, deepening the relations already established through the 1988 Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Cooperation Council of the Gulf Arab States.   The signed agreement provides for a visa-free travel arrangements for EU and UAE nationals travelling for a maximum period of 90 days within 180 days. This agreement deepens relations between the two sides in economic and cultural terms and political dialogue on issues such as human rights and fundamental freedoms, among others.  The high number of European citizens established in the UAE ̶ more than 150 000 ̶ and annual travellers for tourist or economic reasons makes this agreement ̶ tool that will significantly facilitate such mobility. For these reasons I am in favour of this agreement.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Agreement was concluded between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates for the exemption from short-stay visas. The agreement provides for a visa-free regime for citizens of the European Union and the United Arab Emirates and the possibility to travel for a maximum period of 90 days for a period of 180 days. I supported Mariya Gabriel's report because the agreement was concluded and signed in accordance with the Council Decision and requires the consent of the European Parliament to enter into force, for better relations and easier travel.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 With the full abolition of the short-stay visa regime following the signature of the relevant agreement in May this year, the United Arab Emirates will become the first Arab world country to introduce such a partial visa-free regime for schengen members. In view of the bilateral tourism figures and the overall volume of passenger traffic, the rapid development of business contacts and the dynamics of investment flows, as well as the fact that the European Union is the main trading partner of the United Arab Emirates, such a step can be seen as quite logical and positive. On the other hand, however, it would be worth noting one thing that is very important to me as a Member of the European Parliament from Latvia. As long as the citizens of my country no longer need to issue short-stay visas to travel to the United Arab Emirates, non-Citizens of Latvia will not have such a possibility, because my country does not, and occasionally, does not even have plans to enter into an agreement with the UAE that would specify this principled moment.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 There are 150,000 European citizens living in the United Arab Emirates and another 1.6 million visit the country each year. In 2014, by contrast, 230 000 Emirates citizens visited the EU. It is the visa requirement that has been included among the main obstacles to increased tourism. The agreement, which was concluded in May 2015, since it has also been provisionally implemented, allows citizens of the Contracting Parties to travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party without a visa for a maximum period of 90 days within any 180-day period, covering all categories of persons travelling for any reason other than the pursuit of a paid activity.  The United Arab Emirates is a high-income industrial country. Today, the EU is the first trading partner of the United Arab Emirates, 14th place among the trade partners of the Union and its Member States. In 2014, mutual trade amounted to EUR 51 million. The abolition of short-stay visas will strengthen mutual trade and tourism. It can also contribute to strengthening relations in the fight against terrorism, trafficking in human beings and climate change.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on the short-stay visa waiver, because it is not complete and documented.   Furthermore, it is well probable that the implementation of this Recommendation will be used by potential beneficiaries to enter the EU without a visa and then illegally extend their stay in the Union after the expiry of the present short stay, thereby contributing to the increase in illegal immigration within the Union. Finally, there is an increased risk that the regulation being adopted will also be exploited by jihadist terrorists, who will be able to enter the EU more comfortably under the new visa-free regime than the current regime that allows the competent authorities of the Member States of the Union and Frontex to exercise strict control over incoming persons into the EU.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. As with the previous ones, this is a whole series of agreements on the exemption of short-stay visas with several countries.  The agreement is expected to help boost tourism, and strengthen trade relations and investment. Currently, some 150,000 EU nationals are based in the UAE. As for tourism, there are 1.6 million Europeans who visit the UAE each year, compared to 230,000 Emiratis who travel to Europe. Obviously things are already working very well. The key to these agreements is trust: the rate of visa refusal is very low because countries have confidence in visa applicants. According to the rapporteur, the countries covered by these agreements do not pose a threat, either in terms of irregular migration or security.  In view of the mass immigration that we are experiencing and which the EU is no longer able to manage, in view of the risks and the recent attacks against France, we can only be surprised, if we are worried, about this sudden desire for openness. Perhaps the timing is not the most timely!

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the recommendation concerning the draft Council decision on the short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates. The aim of the agreement is to make it easier for many Europeans to visit their family members who have settled in the United Arab Emirates or to travel for professional or tourism reasons – and the same would apply to uae citizens. The visa waiver agreement will allow citizens not only to benefit fully from the EU-UAE partnership, but also to participate in it by travelling more cheaply and practically.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Gabriel's report aims to reach a short-stay visa waiver agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates. Considering that more than 150,000 European citizens reside in the United Arab Emirates, and the vast majority of these carry out economic activities there, considering also that in 2014, about 230,000 citizens of the United Arab Emirates traveled to Europe, mainly for business trips and luxury tourism, the obligation and cost of the visa could represent an obstacle to the tourism sector, not to mention that such an agreement would certainly represent a crowning achievement of the existing relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates United. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The visa waiver agreement between the EU and the United Arab Emirates is the first we have concluded with an Arab state. My support for this decision, which will facilitate trade relations and travel with a country where thousands of Europeans are established and where there are many citizens who travel to Europe every year.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On the merits of the case, I am in favour of short-stay visa exemptions in order to facilitate the mobility and travel of citizens of two parties, in this case the United Arab Emirates and vice versa. Nevertheless, I regret that the French Overseas Are Excluded from it. And I am surprised that the EU has chosen in the Gulf the first Arab country to benefit from this visa exemption. While our cultural and social relations are much more developed with the Maghreb and democracy is consolidating there in Tunisia. On form, I denounce all this procedure. Only the Commission has the power to negotiate these agreements on behalf of states and citizens. It does not keep the European Parliament informed of the state of the negotiations until the very end of the process. Above all, these agreements are implemented even before the European Parliament gives its approval or not. An exemplary witness that democracy has no place in the EU (note that the same procedure will be applied in the case of the transatlantic agreement). In these circumstances, I vote against

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short stays are intended to increase trade, increase investment, and boost tourism.  It is important to note that the rate of visa refusal is low for these countries, which, according to the report, pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, or in terms of security and public order.  With regard to the United Arab Emirates, it should be noted that 150,000 EU nationals are based there and most of them work there. About 1.6 million Europeans visit the UAE each year, and some 230,000 Emiratis are estimated to have travelled to Europe, mainly for business and luxury tourism.  Nevertheless, the opportunity to conclude such agreements, even as the porousness of Europe's borders makes the bed of terrorism in Europe, seems incongruous. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on visa-free travel for short stays. I share the rapporteur's position that this agreement is the result of deepening relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates and is an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations, but also for deepening political debate and dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement provides for visa-free travel for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of United Arab Emirates when travelling in the other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. I chose to support this resolution as it is an opportunity to deepen economic relations and develop tourism.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The United Arab Emirates is on the "positive list" of countries exempt from short-term travel (90 days). In return, they acceded to the EU's request to set up an UAE-EU working group on human rights, including freedom of expression, women's rights and migrant workers' rights.  Establishing a dialogue between the two partners on such an essential issue is an important step in deepening relations between the Union and the UAE in particular but also with the Gulf region in general.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Agreement between the EU and the United Arab Emirates on visa-free travel constitutes an enhanced relationship between the two Parties, as well as a means of strengthening economic and cultural exchange and intensifying political dialogue on human rights and fundamental freedoms, which are priorities of the Union. The agreement is intended to serve as a tool for deepening cooperation between the two parties, which have a common interest in stabilising the region and in a reliable partnership in several areas. There are already 150 000 European citizens living in the United Arab Emirates who have taken the opportunity to carry out economic activities, and another 1.6 million Europeans travel to the country every year. The Agreement is intended to facilitate these activities and travel between the two Contracting Parties.  Ensuring equal treatment of European citizens and ensuring their protection must remain a priority of this agreement.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-United Arab Emirates agreement on the short-stay visa waiver, which will provide for visa-free travel for citizens when travelling for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. This agreement simultaneously represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates – which is politically highly significant an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. European citizens will not only be able to fully benefit from the partnership between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates, but also participate in it by travelling at a reduced, economical and practical cost.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should wisely allow legal access to third country nationals, as one of the means of both managing migration and protecting its good image, consistent with its values. Of course, reciprocity should also always be sought, in order to also benefit directly EU citizens when travelling abroad. I supported the agreement on the short-stay visa waiver with the United Arab Emirates as part of this possible menu of wisdom. The UAE are also an important economic partner of the EU.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament and the Council amended Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by regulation of 20 May 2014, classing the United Arab Emirates as one of the third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement when crossing the external borders of the Member States. The Commission subsequently negotiated a bilateral agreement to this end between 5 November and 20 December 2014 between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates. The agreement was corked in Brussels on 28 May 2015 and has been awaiting parliament's approval ever since. In its recommendation, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs voted in favour of approving the agreement and voted in favour of the draft accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. These agreements provide for visa exemption for short-term stays for listed countries, in order to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation will simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. In terms of mobility, confidence in visa applicants in these countries is high, with a historically low visa refusal rate. According to the rapporteur, the countries in question pose no threat either in terms of irregular migration, nor in terms of security and public order.  However, the question arises whether it is appropriate to conclude visa-free agreements at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration.  The answer is no, hence a vote against.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has established a visa-free agreement for short stays for citizens of the European Union and nationals of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, in connection with travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each period of 180 days, and the European Parliament therefore needs to approve the respective agreement.  Visa facilitation allows peoples to be rapproched and economic, cultural and political relations between the European Union and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines closer together, strengthening the political importance of the Cotonou Agreement, a partnership agreement between the African, Caribbean and Pacific states and the European Union and its Member States. Several categories of persons, regardless of the reason for visiting the country, are covered by this visa facilitation agreement, except in the case of paid activities.  I am voting in favour of this agreement, because I consider it essential to establish relations between the European Union and other communities, which will provide benefits for both sides in the economic, political and social field, and enhance bilateral cooperation dialogues.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the short-stay visa exemption with the United Arab Emirates may seem useful given the intensity of the country's economic ties with those of the EU, but also the role it plays in the Middle East. However, this agreement does not come at the right time, given the failure of the European authorities in migration policy. So I voted against this agreement.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which ratifies the agreement on short-stay visa waiver and allows for EU citizens and citizens of the participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement on the exemption of short-stay visas between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates. The aim was to allow the visa-free travel regime for EUROPEAN and Emirati nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by our colleague Mariya Gabriel on the agreement on the short-stay visa exemption agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for nationals of both parties concerned who travel to the territory of the other contracting party for a stay of up to 90 days over any 180-day period.  The visa exemption covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, official service and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except that of a paid activity.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I vote in favour of the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on the exemption from short-stay visas. This agreement provides an excellent opportunity to boost tourism, facilitate investment and dynamise trade, thereby increasing the importance of economic and cultural relations between the European Union and the higher state.  In addition, the agreement offers new allies to join forces on issues of such importance as the fight against terrorism. We also see the emergence of political dialogue as a positive, most often aimed at joint action against corruption, criminal networks and trafficking in human beings.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation on the draft Council decision that provides a visa-free travel agreement for the citizens of the European Union and for the citizens of the United Arab Emirates when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have opposed this recommendation in the European Parliament. Visa-free travel is out of the question for me. Functioning border controls are very important today, and visa-free travel can very quickly have a negative impact on Europe. I also believe that visa-free travel will increase the flow of refugees into Europe. We must take the fears and concerns of the population seriously.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. More than 150 000 EU citizens have entered the United Arab Emirates, the vast majority of whom take the opportunity to participate in economic activity. Around 1.6 million Europeans visit the United Arab Emirates each year. The visa obligation is one of the biggest obstacles to travel. This is also the case for Estonian citizens, who are also subject to visa obligations when entering the UAE.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The achievement and adoption of an agreement between the EU and the United Arab Emirates allowing short-stay visa waivers is an important step towards closer rapprochement between the peoples of Europe and the Caribbean and, more generally, a politically relevant instrument under the 1988 Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Cooperation Council of gulf Arab States. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support an agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates to waive the short-stay visa requirement. I welcome the further development of friendly relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates. I am pleased that the visa waiver covers all categories of persons wishing to facilitate travel and short-term stay without a visa, of a maximum of 90 days in any period within 180 days from the date of the first registered entry. The agreement allows European Union citizens and citizens of the United Arab Emirates to stay visa-free on the territory of the other Contracting Party. This also offers numerous opportunities not only for citizens of the United Arab Emirates, but also for EU citizens through new business opportunities and facilitation of travel.  Due to the close relationship between the European Union and Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein, in particular on the basis of the association agreements of those countries to the implementation, application and development of the Schengen acquis, I call on those countries to conclude bilateral visa waiver agreements with the United Arab Emirates for short stays containing provisions as in this agreement.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the short-stay visa exemption with the United Arab Emirates comes at the worst possible time, given the failure of European authorities in migration policy and the geopolitical situation in the Middle East. So I voted against this agreement.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the conclusion of an agreement between the United Arab Emirates and the European Union that will allow citizens of the United Arab Emirates to enter the European Union without a visa, with the exception of the United Kingdom and Ireland. Citizens of my country, Croatia, can already travel to the United Arab Emirates without a visa and it is appropriate that their citizens can travel in the same way. I hope that the EU will consistently implement visa reciprocity policies towards third countries that do not apply the same visa regime for citizens of all 28 member states.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – I support Mep Gabriel's recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on the waiver of short-stay visas . The United Arab Emirates has been a long-standing economic and cultural partner of the European Union and signing this agreement would allow for a better dialogue on human rights and freedoms.  The main reason for avoiding UAE citizens travelling to the European Union is due to the costly and lengthy visa process. Last year, of all visa applications, only 7.4% were rejected, double the number since 2010. By accepting this proposal, I believe that EU revenues from tourism would increase significantly. On the other hand, more than 150,000 EU nationals live and work in the UAE, and I believe that the visa waiver would facilitate the movement of these people and their families between the two sides.  The adoption of this proposal should be seen as a way to facilitate dialogue on a number of key problems, such as human rights issues, immigrant workers' rights, women's rights and freedom of expression.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) take place within the framework of the 1988 Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Cooperation Council of the Gulf Arab States. The United Arab Emirates is a high-income industrialized country. As far as trade relations are concerned, the EU is now the UAE's main trading partner, which in turn ranks 14th among the TRADING Partners of the Union and its Member States. In 2014, trade reached a value of 51 million euros. I am voting in favour of approving this agreement because these trade relations can only be facilitated by the application of the visa waiver.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I would like to support this decision, because the Czech Republic was among the EU Member States that had a visa requirement with the United Arab Emirates. I support that visa policy should be uniform within the EU and that the EU negotiate the same conditions for all its Member States in this field, if this is, of course, possible in view of the international situation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. This agreement seals the visa exemption for very short stays and on the basis of reciprocity with the United Arab Emirates. A way to make travel easier for our nationals, whether for tourism or business.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 by Regulation (EU) No 509/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, the United Arab Emirates has been transferred to Annex II, which sets out the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement to cross the external borders of the Member States.  Following the adoption of that Regulation, the Council authorised the Commission on 9 October 2014 to open negotiations for the conclusion of a bilateral agreement between the Union and the United Arab Emirates. The negotiations were concluded on 20 December 2014 and the Agreement was signed on 6 May 2015.   The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the United Arab Emirates who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period.  Because I believe that this is an important agreement to strengthen economic and cultural relations and intensify political dialogue between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates, I voted in favour of their approval.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
