text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote regarding the granting of short term visas. Although this vote only relates to the Schengen area, which the UK is not part of, UKIP opposes the principle that the EU can decide immigration policy for any Member State. The only people who should decide immigration policy and visas are nationally elected and accountable governments, not undemocratic EU institutions in Brussels.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. This agreement shows the openness of the United Arab Emirates towards a rapprochement of the European Union, including human rights, migrant workers' rights, women's rights and freedom of expression.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this draft agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on the short-stay visa exemption, which has already been applied on an interim basis since May 2015. This agreement provides for a visa-free travel regime for EU citizens and third country nationals travelling to the territory of the other contracting party for a maximum stay of 90 days over any 180-day period.  It should be noted that the United Kingdom and Ireland do not participate in these agreements and are not subject to the provisions of these agreements, as are the non-European territories of France and the Netherlands.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the Proposal for a Recommendation on the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) on visa-free travel for short stays. The strengthening of trade and investment relations and the opening in 2013 of an EU delegation to the UAE have contributed to the willingness to strengthen bilateral cooperation as well as to facilitate the conclusion of this agreement. This Agreement has not only strengthened the EU-UAE's relations at various levels but also intensified political, economic and trade dialogue.  Although this measure has been in force in provisional terms since 6 May last, only from now on is the legislative procedure formally completed by the European Union, so both European citizens and UAE citizens will be able to benefit from this exemption on their travel (in reciprocal terms), thereby overcoming costly visa barriers and travel planning made well in advance. In this way, business and tourism travel is also enhanced, and the EU-UAE partnership is also strengthened, bringing Europe closer to the UAE - the first Arab state with which the EU signs such an agreement.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. However, we abstained in the case of the United Arab Emirates. Respect for human rights must be a precondition for any kind of agreement between the EU and any country. In the case of the UAE, energy and commercial interests cannot serve as a pretext for re-providing respect for human, labour and social rights to the background. This is not a country in which human and labour rights violations are made specific, but are systematically given and there are no democratic mechanisms to denounce or eradicate them.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This agreement allows Emirati citizens and Europeans to travel through both territories without the need for a visa. Despite initially agreeing with the lightening of the bureaucratic burden and freedom of movement, we understand that this agreement has been signed in an obscurantist manner between the European institutions and the Emirati authorities. The United Arab Emirates also makes no trade-off for guaranteeing the rights of women or LGTBI persons, and maintains legislation that is completely unensure of rights for migrant workers. We have therefore decided to abstain in the ratification of the agreement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement approved by the European Parliament today lays down new provisions for visa-free travel for EU citizens and UAE citizens travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a short stay of up to 90 days. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, service, official or special passport) regardless of the reason for their stay. This agreement is the culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and that country, as well as a further instrument aimed at strengthening economic, tourist and cultural relations and, finally, will serve to intensify the political dialogue between the parties.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in any visa policy so I voted against this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Although this is the last of the countries which the European Parliament has granted its consent for a new visa regime, it is also one of the most significant. This is because the political relations between the EU and the UAE have, since 1988, been based on a cooperation agreement through the Gulf Cooperation Council and the EU. This waiver of visas agreement will be a tool for intensifying cooperation between the UAE and Europe, where we both have a great interest in stabilising the macro-region and acting as sound and reliable partners in various fields. I voted in favour of this agreement because it stands testament to the gains to our bilateral relations and our desire to bring people together. It will also bring about a boost in tourism for the United Arab Emirates.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The short-stay visa waiver agreement represents a successful completion of the deepening of relations between the EU and the United Arab Emirates, as well as another means of strengthening economic, cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on human rights and fundamental freedoms issues. The conclusion of this agreement is to be welcomed, as more than 150 000 European citizens already live in the United Arab Emirates, and the vast majority of them also take advantage of opportunities for economic activities. At the same time, mutual tourism continues to increase. The abolition of visa requirements will thus make it easier for many Europeans to visit their family or travel for work or tourist reasons. I also support this agreement because, more broadly, it is an instrument for deepening cooperation in stabilising the entire Middle East region. The EU opened its representation in Abu Dhabi in 2013 to strengthen bilateral relations and build a strong and reliable partnership with the United Arab Emirates. The fact that it is the first Arab state with which the EU signs a visa waiver agreement is proof that countries have an eminent interest in converging with EU values. This is evidenced by the creation of a working group on human rights, where the United Arab Emirates is showing a willingness to improve workers' rights, women's rights and freedom of expression.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The new visa regime will allow EU citizens to travel to the UAE without a visa requirement. The same will apply to UAE citizens if the length of stay does not exceed 90 days during any period of 180 days. This decision develops cooperation between the UAE and the EU not only in the field of tourism, but also in cultural exchange.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this amendment to the agreement between the European Union and the UAE taking into account the recommendation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Also, such a proposal to amend the agreement improves relations between these countries. The abolition of short-stay visas allows citizens to gain new experiences and promotes the development of mobility.  After their stay in the European Union, citizens can transfer their newfound experiences to the country from which they come and thus further improve relations between the European Union and the country in question, as well as the situation in their country. And in an indirect way they promote the European Union in their own country.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this agreement which will allow EU citizens and citizens of participating countries to travel to the EU or the participating country without a visa for stays of 90 days or less.  The agreement on the short-stay visa waiver programme takes into account the situation of Member States that are not part of Schengen such as the UK and Ireland.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EU) No 2012 509/2014 Of the European Parliament and the Council, Regulation (EC) No 509/2014 has been amended. 539/2001 It defines a list of 19 countries, including the United Arab Emirates whose nationals are exempt from the visa requirement.  The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (holders of an ordinary, diplomatic, official and special passport) whose purpose of the trip does not include the performance of paid activity. Therefore, citizens of the European Union can reside on the territory of the United Arab Emirates for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. Also, citizens of the United Arab Emirates can reside on the territory of the Member States which fully apply the Schengen acquis for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period.  I support the Council regulation on the waiver of short-stay visas between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates with a view to further developing friendly relations between the Contracting Parties and the desire to facilitate travel by ensuring entry and short-term stay without visas for their citizens.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on the short-stay visa waiver. The agreement, which is the result of deep relations between the EU and the United Arab Emirates, will improve citizens' tourist journeys in particular. Indeed, many citizens of the Member States travel through the United Arab Emirates, as do UAE citizens travelling a lot through the European Union. The abolition of the short-stay visa requirement also provides an opportunity to improve trade between the EU and the UAE, which is already at a high level.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ These reports relate to the visa regime operated by Schengen Member States. As the UK is outside of the Schengen area and will not take part in the agreement, I have abstained.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We are not opposed to visa liberalisation for third-country citizens but in relation to this report we have chosen to abstain because of the major concerns that exist about the situation within the country regarding the violation of fundamental human rights and the use of force against dissidents, women, workers and migrants.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The United Arab Emirates, despite the glow of the tourist resorts of Dubai and Abu Dhabi, remains an Arab state where all notions of human rights, equality, democracy and freedom of religion are still unknown words and constitute utopia. Any free movement with such countries is a "backdoor" for EU states. Trade agreements and trade arrangements, tourism and other, may be carried out under controlled channels with a view to maintaining security and avoiding an influx of extremist elements. Finally, it is inconceivable that the practice of signing visa waiver agreements should be applied and that they should be provisionally implemented before they are approved by the European Parliament.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has in recent years supported a policy of enhancing cooperation with the United Arab Emirates in all areas of common interest. This process is based on recognition of the remarkable progress this nation has made over the past three decades. The adoption of a short-stay visa waiver regime is a first step towards strengthening cooperation between the EU and the United Arab Emirates. This is primarily beneficial for the development of tourism activity on both sides, by facilitating free movement.  Strengthening bilateral relations would also be beneficial to coordinate actions to achieve regional stability in the Gulf, combat terrorism, trafficking in human beings and climate change. As the United Arab Emirates becomes an important source of international development aid, coordination of actions with those of the European Union can benefit global economic development.  However, many issues remain in the area of democratic rights and freedoms promoted by the EU at international level. The adoption of the current agreement to abolish short-stay visas lays the foundations for a strengthened dialogue with the United Arab Emirates, which is beneficial for European citizens and for the citizens of that country.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed my political group and the subject matter expert. This visa-free agreement for short-term stays is an achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and that country, as well as an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of concluding the Agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on the short-stay visa waiver, which was signed in May 2015. It allows visa-free travel for EU citizens and for the citizens of the United Arab Emirates when travelling to each other’s territory for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons, travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I welcome that the Agreement strengthens relations between the EU and the United Arab Emirates and provides another way to intensify mutual cooperation and political dialogue on various issues, including human rights.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to adopt a short-stay visa waiver agreement between the EU and the United Arab Emirates. Although the Republic of Croatia was still exempted in March 2014 from the obligation for its residents to obtain a visa before entering the UAE, the EU-UAE Agreement will allow residents of both parties to reside on the territory of the other party for a period of 90 days in any 180-day period.  Although the Republic of Croatia does not yet fully apply the Schengen acquis, the provisions of this agreement apply equally to it. It is important to point out that the European Union is the main trading partner of the United Arab Emirates. There are also a large number of Both European and United Emirates residents who travel annually for tourism or business purposes. Therefore, visa liberalisation in this case will significantly facilitate the flow of passengers. Given the geographical location of the UAE in the Arabian Peninsula and the proximity of countries representing the sources of migration movements, proactive political, economic and social surveillance must be carried out in order to avoid unintended consequences that an agreement may have.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on the short-stay visa waiver. The proposal for an agreement on visa facilitation is intended to conclude an agreement with the United Arab Emirates on the facilitation of the issuance of short-stay visas.  The Agreement takes into account the fact that some Member States do not fully apply the Schengen acquis. The agreement also provides for visa-free travel for European Union citizens and citizens of the United Arab Emirates when they travel to the territory of the other Party for a maximum of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver applies to all categories of persons travelling for any purpose, except for the purpose of carrying out paid work.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. However, we abstained in the case of the United Arab Emirates. Respect for human rights must be a precondition for any kind of agreement between the EU and any country. In the case of the UAE, energy and commercial interests cannot serve as a pretext for re-providing respect for human, labour and social rights to the background. This is not a country in which human and labour rights violations are made specific, but are systematically given and there are no democratic mechanisms to denounce or eradicate them.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. These visa-free agreements for short-term stays are expected to boost tourism and strengthen trade and investment relations. Visa liberalisation would simplify travel conditions for entrepreneurs, facilitate investment and intensify economic ties between businesses. However, the question arises as to whether visa-free agreements should be concluded at a time when the risk of terrorist attacks is real and the European Union has lost all control over mass immigration. This inflection in visa policy is contrary to what common sense dictates.  So I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement granting visa waiver for short stays is both a success of deepening relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates and a further means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and encouraging political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Visa-free agreements for short stays are a new achievement in deepening relations between the European Union and third countries, as well as being an additional means of strengthening economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. In addition to these reasons, which are put forward in a protocol by the rapporteur for this Recommendation, we consider that we should promote the removal of barriers to the movement of persons from third countries through the EU, in general. However, we abstained in the case of the United Arab Emirates. Respect for human rights must be a precondition for any kind of agreement between the EU and any country. In the case of the UAE, energy and commercial interests cannot serve as a pretext for re-providing respect for human, labour and social rights to the background. This is not a country in which human and labour rights violations are made specific, but are systematically given and there are no democratic mechanisms to denounce or eradicate them.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – This agreement on visa-free travel in the case of short-stays is the result of the development of relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates, as well as an additional instrument to strengthen economic and cultural relations and to promote political dialogue on a wide range of issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. The visa waiver agreement would thus make it easier for many Europeans to visit family members living in the United Arab Emirates or to go for business or tourism purposes.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of providing visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and for citizens of the UAE when travelling to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days in any 180-day period. The visa waiver covers all categories of persons (ordinary, diplomatic, service/official and special passport holders) travelling for all kinds of purposes, except for the purpose of carrying out a paid activity. I believe that this agreement on the waiver of short-stay visas represents a culmination of the deepening of relations between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates and is an additional way of stepping up economic and cultural relations and intensifying political dialogue on various issues, including human rights and fundamental freedoms. Because of the fact that more than 150 000 European nationals live in the United Arab Emirates, the vast majority of whom have seized opportunities to engage in economic activities, and that some 1.6 million Europeans visit the United Arab Emirates each year and that in 2014, around 230 000 Emiratis travelled to Europe, mainly for purposes of business or luxury tourism, this agreement is necessary and therefore I supported it.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Parliament must approve the conclusion of this agreement which has already been negotiated by the European Commission. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, as well as the rapporteur for the agreement, have given a positive recommendation and I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report which includes an exemption from the visa requirement for short-stay citizens of United Arab Emirates and our own EU citizens. The abolition of the visa requirement shall apply to journeys of up to 90 days for a period of 180 days. I am convinced that this agreement will contribute to better trade relations, more investment and more tourism.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has been subject to short-stay visa waiver agreements with nine third states (Dominique, Vanuatu, Trinidad and Tobago, Samoa, Grenada, East Timor, St Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and the United Arab Emirates). For the latter, the justifications for this exemption, to say the least surprising, are the development of economic relations and business travel and the fact that many European nationals are settled there. The European Parliament has not been regularly informed of the negotiations on these agreements; they were even implemented on an interim basis without waiting for the EP's decision. I am in favour of the liberalisation of short-stay visas. Such agreements facilitate exchanges between peoples. But the EU's choices in this area do not meet any criteria other than those of strategic and diplomatic issues. The one with the United Arab Emirates is a symbol of that. So I voted for the first 8 exemption agreements and abstained on the last one with the UAE.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This recommendation concerns the draft Council decision for the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and that third country on visa-free travel for short stays. The agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of that third country who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party for a maximum period of 90 days for each 180-day period. Visa waiver concerns all categories of persons (holders of common, diplomatic, service/official and special passports), regardless of the reason for the stay, with the exception of the exercise of a paid activity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In times of mass migration, a visa waiver seems like a bad joke for many other countries. Instead of legislates that could curb mass migration, the EU is looking at visa facilitation. It is doing the people of Europe a disservice. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the reports by which Parliament gave its consent to the conclusion of an agreement with the United Arab Emirates as well as 8 other countries on short-stay visa waivers. Under the agreements that are already being provisionally implemented, citizens of these countries and, in return, citizens of the European Union will be able to travel for a maximum of 90 days without the need for a visa. All these countries have been carefully considered, the credibility of their visa applicants, the potential threat of migration from these countries to the European Union, as well as the state of democracy and respect for human rights have been examined. I therefore think that by supporting short-stay visa waiver treaties, we will send an important signal for strengthening relations with these countries, getting to know new cultures, but also new opportunities arising from increased tourism. For European citizens, this will mean, in turn, an easier situation when travelling, as some of the countries with which the agreement will be concluded are also a popular holiday destination.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement provides for visa-free travel for citizens of the European Union and nationals of the United Arab Emirates who travel to the territory of the other Contracting Party. The United Arab Emirates is part of the bloc of ultraconservative regimes and religious fundamentalists seeking to contain the growing popular uprisings, putting an end to the imperialist intention of securing control of the region at all costs, in its opportunistic interest in natural resources and geostrategic dominance. Available information shows that France, Britain, Germany, Italy and Spain accounted for 80 percent of arms exports in the EU, including Saudi Arabia (€4.2 billion) and the United Arab Emirates (€1.9 billion), according to 2013 data. These, in turn, provide weapons to mercenary groups that destabilise and terrorise the peoples, having led to the latest 'terrorist' attacks. Apart from this framework, it is not too much to remember that the peoples of the United Arab Emirates are confronted with the limitation and repression of fundamental freedoms and rights, such as freedom of expression, workers' rights, the rights of women and children. We abstained.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the United Arab Emirates on the short-stay visa waiver because I believe that the agreement will further strengthen confidence in bilateral relations and, inter alia, strengthen the partnership to combat terrorism, trafficking in human beings and climate change.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament approved the draft decision drawn up by the Council on the creation of a memorandum of understanding between OHIM and Eurojust. The main aim is to promote cooperation between the two bodies while respecting the specific nature of the objectives of both. In short, it is a question of following up the desire to improve and establish an exchange of information between these bodies, which is necessary for the prevention and combating of illegal practices. This cooperation and cooperation does not, however, authorise the exchange of personal information and data. In the event of serious violations of the provisions of the Memorandum, a clause is provided for the temporary suspension of the application of the Agreement until the consultations and negotiations provided for have been completed. I voted in favour of this, as I trust that cooperation between OHIM and Eurojust will ensure that the objectives of both are better and more timely, thereby benefiting European citizens.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves the Memorandum of Agreement between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market. This Memorandum aims to promote cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in the fulfilment of their respective mandates. The report includes a section wherein the Memorandum shall not include the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person. In my view, this is an important aspect of data protection, so I voted in favour.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I spoke out against this decision, which provides for agreements between the Internal Market Harmonisation Office and Eurojust.  The purpose of this text is to give Eurojust the ability to conclude agreements or working arrangements with institutions, bodies and agencies created by the treaties or on the basis of treaties. In addition, these agreements provide for the exchange of information, including personal data, as well as the posting of liaison officers to Eurojust.  Furthermore, I am categorically opposed to any measures to strengthen the competences of Eurojust as well as those of all supranational institutions.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 With this report, Parliament gives its positive opinion to the Council on the implementation of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation for the Internal Market and Eurojust. As this strengthens the capabilities of both organisations, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The 2002/187/JAI decision provides for the possibility for Eurojust, which represents the premises of a future European prosecutor's office, to conclude agreements or working arrangements with agencies, institutions, and bodies created by treaties or on the basis of treaties. These agreements or work arrangements allow the exchange of information, including personal data, as well as the posting of liaison officers to Eurojust. These agreements and arrangements can only be concluded after Eurojust consults the data protection body and authorizes the Council. In order to broaden its scope of collaboration with the Internal Market Harmonization Office (OHMI) established by Regulation (EC) 207/2009 of the Council, Eurojust has initiated a memorandum of understanding with OHIM. The memorandum received a favourable opinion from Eurojust's supervisory body, and was finally approved by Eurojust College on 19 May. Considering that this report provides for the strengthening of Eurojust's powers, I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As a UKIP MEP, it is natural for me to oppose such harmonisation. It enhances further the involvement of EUROJUST in the single market via its relationship with the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. The purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding is to promote cooperation between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) in accordance with the respective powers of both agencies. The exchange of information or experience referred to therein shall not apply to the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person. I agree that disputes concerning the implementation of the Memorandum of Understanding must be resolved in consultations and negotiations between the representatives of Eurojust and OHIM, thus excluding any third-party arbitrator. I also agree that, in the event of a serious breach of the provisions of the Memorandum of Understanding, or if Eurojust or OHIM considers that such an infringement may be committed in the near future, one of these agencies may suspend the application of the Memorandum of Understanding.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Eurojust is one of the many "European agencies" that have continued to multiply and strengthen in recent years by encroaching on the competences of Member States. In this case, I see the premise of a European prosecutor's office whose legitimacy I dispute in advance. That is why I am opposed and will continue to oppose any extension or strengthening of Eurojust's powers.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Eurojust and the Office concluded the memorandum because they were keen to develop strategic cooperation that could help them achieve their respective objectives. This cooperation will be based on an exchange of information but without the transmission of personal data. I approved this report.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report on the Memorandum of Agreement between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. We understand that this technical procedure of agreement serves for exchanges of information between two spaces whose exchange of information, as EU institutions, is constitutionally guaranteed.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report which aims to promote cooperation between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market in compliance with their respective mandates. The exchange of information or experience provided for in this Memorandum shall not include the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the Memorandum of Understanding between the Internal Market Harmonization Office and Eurojust provides that Eurojust may enter into agreements or working arrangements with institutions, bodies and agencies created by the treaties or on the basis of treaties. These agreements or work arrangements may include the exchange of information, including personal data, and the posting of liaison officers to Eurojust. They can only be concluded after Eurojust consults the common supervisory body with regard to the data protection provisions and with the approval of the Council. Eurojust therefore negotiated this memorandum and the supervisory body gave a favourable opinion. I would like to remind you, however, that Eurojust is the premise of a European public prosecutor's office, and I therefore oppose this vote.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Chrysogonos report is balanced and acceptable. I believe it is necessary to promote more effective cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market, which is responsible for the management of trade marks and industrial design, and Eurojust. I am convinced that a more effective exchange of information between these authorities will benefit many sectors of Made in Italy constantly affected by unfair competition and trademark infringement. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report urges the Council to implement the decision approving a Memorandum of Agreement between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. The purpose of the Memorandum is to promote cooperation between Eurojust and the Office, in compliance with their respective mandates. It should be noted that this Memorandum stresses that no exchange of information or experiences based on the Memorandum will include the transmission of operational information, including data on identified or identifiable persons.  That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the conclusion of a memorandum between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM). The purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding is to promote cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in accordance with the respective powers of both agencies. It is important to note that the exchange of information or experience referred to in this Memorandum of Understanding does not apply to the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The planned "implementing decision" gives the form of the "Memorandum of Understanding" between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM). The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate the cooperation of the two institutions in order to be able to function in accordance with the powers and responsibilities they have been given. As the document states, the aim is strategic cooperation. This decision is a specific implementing act which requires the approval of the European Council after consultation of the European Parliament. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this report proposing that the European Parliament should give a positive opinion on the implementation of the Council decision approving the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. The purpose of the Memorandum is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in accordance with its mandates.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Eurojust is the premise of a European public prosecutor's office (possibility provided for in Article 86, paragraph 1, paragraph 1, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union). I am therefore opposed to anything that can contribute to its development and strengthen its skills. I voted against it.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This decision provides that Eurojust can enter into agreements with institutions, bodies or agencies created on the basis of the treaties. These agreements will focus on the exchange of data and information, including personal information, as well as the posting of liaison officers to Eurojust. To be concluded, these agreements must be approved by the Council and the common supervisory body must be consulted beforehand. To strengthen its capacity to work with the Internal Market Harmonization Office, Eurojust negotiated a memorandum of understanding. Eurojust's joint supervisory body has also given a favourable opinion on the memorandum. Given that Eurojust is the premise of a European prosecutor's office, we can only challenge the strengthening of its powers. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against organised crime is an urgent objective that must be strengthened in the light of the latest tragic events in Europe. One of the European agencies to which this responsibility falls is Eurojust, which facilitates cooperation in criminal matters both between Member States and between those States and other third Countries with which agreements exist. Of course, this mission is always done with the support of all other European institutions, including OHIM.  Parliament has already expressed its desire to be informed of Eurojust's work, so as not to cross democratic borders through the exercise of its operations, and wants the CJEU to have jurisdiction over them. Next, aware of the scale of some operations, as well as the need for better structuring of the exchange of technical information, a memorandum between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market is welcome, and it is in the interest of both parties to develop good cooperation. In view of the vital importance of the protection of personal data and the establishment of a legislative framework in which the exchange of information is carried out safely, in order to carry out the procedures in the Eurojust system, I support and vote in favour of this memorandum.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The aim of the decision is to promote cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust (which coordinates investigations into major crime conducted in several Member States, and which also includes the fight against fraud, money laundering and cybercrime among its competences). The agreement should benefit from the exchange of information between the respective authorities and, consequently, those industrial sectors that are constantly subject to unfair competition and infringement of their trademarks. Please note that the OHIM is the office responsible for brand management and industrial design for the EU internal market.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving eurojust's conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. I believe that the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust contribute to a better performance of their respective tasks. The Memorandum of Understanding works in the common interest of both Eurojust and the OHIM, as one of the aims of the memorandum is precisely to promote cooperation between Eurojust and the OHIM in accordance with their respective mandates in order to develop strategic cooperation that can help both Eurojust and the OHIM achieve their objectives.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This vote concerns a vote on the Memorandum of understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. The intention of this report is to enable the two bodies to exchange information more easily. However, I have grave concerns with bodies such as the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market. At a time, when austerity policies are still continuing to decimate communities across EU Member States, much required resources should be directed towards boosting employment and public investment as opposed to advancing quangos.  My mandate in Europe is to represent the interests of the Irish people and it does not serve the interests of the Irish Taxpayer to have their hard earned taxes squandered through the advancement of futile, self-serving, federalist bodies. Therefore, whilst a technical report, due to the political nature behind such, I voted against this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted today to oppose approval of the enhancement of the relationship between EUROJUST and OHIM. We have always opposed the existence of Eurojust as a proto-EU Ministry of Justice with overarching powers over many aspects of the legal regimes of Member States. In particular we oppose anything (such as the instant vote) that extends the remit of Eurojust and the parameters of its activities, especially where that introduces further regulation of the Single Market.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the opinion on the proposal for a Council decision approving the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. The purpose of this memorandum is to promote cooperation between Eurojust and the OHIM in accordance with their respective mandates, and the text – which does not include the exchange of personal data – has no downside. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the draft implementing decision formalizing the conclusion by Eurojust of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) - for which the Committee on Legal Affairs is responsible in accordance with Annex VI to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament - and Eurojust. The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) aims to promote cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in the context of their respective tasks.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The proposal to adopt the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust is a technical process for validating the Council's position on the implementing decision to deepen cooperation between the two agencies aimed at improving the effectiveness of their actions. With this in mind, I drafted this report, as the rapporteur responsible, and voted in favour of it.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft implementing decision concerning the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust. The purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding is to promote cooperation between the OHIM and Eurojust in accordance with their respective mandates. According to the provisions of the Memorandum, the exchange of information or experience does not include the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person. The EP agrees with this approach and calls on the Council to monitor the application of this guarantee. The memorandum also provides that disputes relating to interpretation or application must be resolved through consultations and negotiations between the representatives of Eurojust and the OHIM, thus excluding arbitration by third parties. Finally, in the event of serious non-compliance, either Party may temporarily suspend the application of the Memorandum of Understanding pending consultations. The memorandum is in the common interest of the parties and the EP therefore invites the Council to approve it as such.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe it is right that the internal market should be better controlled through the intervention of the Judicial Cooperation Body Eurojust. I think it is essential that everything within our Union is always as clear and as secure as possible, so that, always in accordance with their mandates, the two organisations will be able to guarantee the optimisation of the market service offered in the EU.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This move fosters cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in compliance with their respective mandates.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Decision 2002/187/JAI, Eurojust may conclude cooperation agreements or arrangements with or on the basis of the institutions, bodies and agencies established by or on the basis of the Treaties. Such cooperation agreements or arrangements may relate in particular to the exchange of information, including personal data, and the deployment of liaison officers to Eurojust. Eurojust negotiated with the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. I welcome the peculiarity of Article 3(5) of the Memorandum stipulating that the exchange of information and experience does not include the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person. I support the report in question because I consider fruitful and legitimate the agreement reached which contributes to a better performance of the functions of these two bodies.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Eurojust and the OHIM concluded the Memorandum of Understanding by declaring their readiness and readiness to develop strategic cooperation in order to achieve their respective objectives. It can therefore be inferred that Eurojust and the OHIM recognise that the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding contribute to a better performance of its tasks. I therefore agree with Mr Chrysogonos' report.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The memorandum of understanding is a specific implementing measure, to be adopted by the Council with the Parliament being consulted, under provisions which were in force before the Lisbon Treaty. The purpose of this proposal is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in compliance with their respective mandates. Eurojust and OHIM want to develop strategic cooperation that could help them to achieve their objective in the fight against infringements of intellectual property rights. Cooperation between EU agencies is the key to a more efficient Europe, thus I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Illicit trade is on the rise mainly due to the increasing use of the web for buying and selling. The resolution aims to promote cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in the fight against counterfeiting and piracy. Parliament will have to give its opinion on the Council's proposal to approve the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for harmonisation of the internal market and Eurojust, in order to strengthen the fight against crime. I am in favour of this resolution, which aims to combat and limit crime and protect consumers.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves the Memorandum of Agreement between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market. This Memorandum aims to promote cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in the fulfilment of their respective mandates. The report includes a section wherein the Memorandum shall not include the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person. In my view, this is an important aspect of data protection, so I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report in question gives its approval to a memorandum of understanding (MOU) between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and EuroJust which formalises an understanding between both sides in order to foster better cooperation in compliance with their respective mandates to help combat the fight against serious crime.  The understanding in question has strong data protection safeguards and also ensures that the application of the MOU stays strictly between EuroJust and OHIM. As this report aims at cutting down on bureaucracy in the fight against serious crime I voted in favour of it.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes the positive opinion of the European Parliament on The conclusion by Eurojust of a Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Internal Market Harmonization (OHIM) and Eurojust. The Memorandum aims to strengthen cooperation between OHIM and Eurojust, in order to better achieve their respective objectives. Supporting the objectives of this report, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted today to oppose approval of the enhancement of the relationship between EUROJUST and OHIM. We have always opposed the existence of Eurojust as a proto-EU Ministry of Justice with overarching powers over many aspects of the legal regimes of Member States. In particular we oppose anything (such as the instant vote) that extends the remit of Eurojust and the parameters of its activities, especially where that introduces further regulation of the Single Market.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which aims to strengthen the capacity for cooperation between the Internal Market Harmonisation Office (OHMI) and Eurojust. This enhanced cooperation will benefit both bodies in order to achieve their respective objectives.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focused on enabling Eurojust to make agreements with institutions created by treaties. Eurojust, after consultation with the common supervisory body on personal information and data, could thus be expanded its capacity for legal action. I remain opposed, as are the peoples of Europe, to ever-increasing European integration, all the more so when it comes to the regal domain of justice that is concerned. By authorising the passing of agreements by Eurojust, it is one step further towards the establishment of a genuine European public prosecutor's office. This permanent extension of the powers of the European institutions outside of any democratic consultation is not acceptable. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust, as its aim is to strengthen cooperation between the two while respecting their respective mandates.  A provision worthy of particular attention is Article 3(5) of the MoU, according to which 'the exchange of information or experience provided for in the Memorandum shall not include the transmission of operational information including data relating to an identified or identifiable person'. I believe that this approach is correct, as we need to be very careful about what is being done on the data protection guarantee.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The planned "implementing decision" gives the form of the "Memorandum of Understanding" between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM). The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate the cooperation of the two institutions in order to be able to function in accordance with the powers and responsibilities they have been given. As the document states, the aim is strategic cooperation. This decision is a specific implementing act which requires the approval of the European Council after consultation of the European Parliament.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Is a draft implementation of the Council Decision approving Eurojust's conclusion of the Memorandum of Agreement between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. Both agreed to conclude the Mémorandum because, in the words of Article 6, they "wanted and were ready to develop strategic cooperation to help them achieve their respective objectives". It is therefore a measure in favour of greater interinstitutional cooperation, of specific application, which will be approved by the Council with consultation with Parliament, under provisions which were in force before the Lisbon Treaty.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to any additional responsibilities by Eurojust.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the Memorandum of Understanding is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) in accordance with their respective mandates, strengthening the fight against some crimes, including product marketing.  It provides for "technical and strategic" information exchanges, not including the transmission of "operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person". The rapporteur considers it legitimate to deduce that Eurojust and OHIM recognise that the terms of the Memorandum contribute to a better performance of the functions of both. It is that, in its current drafting, the Memorandum is in the common interest of Eurojust and OHIM. Despite the fact that the report is centred on a number of technical aspects and that matters relating to personal data are properly safeguarded, in the assessment of this report we do not yet take into account our positions of principle in relation to the two institutions concerned and the reservations about their tasks.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because strengthening cooperation between the Office for harmonisation of the internal market and Eurojust will contribute to improving the functions of both bodies.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Taking into account the technical character of the report and the safeguards regarding the personal data I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report in question is a Council Implementing Decision seeking the approval of a Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. The purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding is to strengthen cooperation between Eurojust and OEMs in accordance with their mandates. Any exchange of information or experience shall be provided for in a Memorandum of Understanding and shall not involve the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the decision to promote cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust, which coordinates investigations into major crime in several Member States and which also includes the fight against fraud, money laundering and cybercrime.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the draft legislative resolution as it is necessary to safeguard the personal data of individuals in cases of exchange of information between Eurojust and OHIM.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report proposes that Parliament should give a favourable opinion on the Council implementing decision approving the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. No amendments have been tabled to the draft report. The purpose of the MoU is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market in compliance with their respective mandates. Noteworthy is that any exchange of information or experience provided for in the MoU does not include the transmission of operational information including data relating to an identified or identifiable person. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The planned "implementing decision" gives the form of the "Memorandum of Understanding" between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM). The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate the cooperation of the two institutions in order to be able to function in accordance with the powers and responsibilities they have been given. As the document states, the aim is strategic cooperation. This decision is a specific implementing act which requires the approval of the European Council after consultation of the European Parliament.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft implementing decision formalises the conclusion by Eurojust of a Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust, which is the responsibility of the Committee on Legal Affairs, in accordance with Annex VI to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament.  The Purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding is to promote cooperation between Eurojust and the OHIM in accordance with their mandates. Eurojust and the OHIM decided to conclude the Memorandum of Understanding because they are willing and willing to develop strategic cooperation to help them achieve their own objectives. The Memorandum of Understanding is in the common interest of Eurojust and the OHIM and should therefore be approved by the Council.  I voted in favour of the agreement.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour, bearing in mind that the objective of the Memorandum of Agreement is to promote cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in compliance with their respective mandates, always bearing in mind respect for the guarantee of data protection.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust, because I believe that better and closer cooperation between the two authorities can produce benefits common to both institutions. I shared the green light from Parliament and the Council for the Memorandum of Understanding signed between Eurojust and the Office for harmonisation of the internal market, and I believe that a greater flow of information and data between two institutions engaged in interrelated areas, the judiciary and the protection of intellectual property, will allow for a more effective performance of Eurojust's tasks. Finally, I welcome the decision to exclude the exchange of operational information, and in particular individual data relating to identifiable or identified persons, as the right balance is struck between the need for more efficient operations on the part of the two authorities on the one hand and the protection of privacy on the other.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the agreement between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust, as I consider it extremely important to strengthen the operational cooperation between the two agencies in the fight against counterfeiting and unfair competition in Europe.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Today there was a vote on the report on the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation of the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust. The aim of the Protocol is to strengthen cooperation between the two institutions. The findings of the Protocol are intended to contribute to the better performance of the tasks entrusted to them. One important provision is Article 3, which states that the exchange of information or experience provided for in the Protocol does not include the transmission of operational information containing data relating to a specific or unspecified person. I welcome this provision, but I call for vigilance when implementing in practice the data protection guarantee provided for in this article.  The form of dispute resolution is also an important issue. In accordance with Article 6, disputes relating to the interpretation or application of the Protocol must be resolved by consultation and negotiation between the representatives. This excludes third-party arbitration. This is in line with most such agreements.  In the event of a serious breach of the Protocol or the recognition that such non-compliance may occur, any authority may temporarily suspend the application of the Memorandum of Understanding pending consultations and negotiations.  The Aim of the Memorandum of Understanding is to strategically develop cooperation that will help eurojust and OHIM achieve their respective objectives. A Memorandum of Understanding in this form is in their mutual interest. As of today, it can be said that they are ready for this cooperation.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Coordinated cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust is an important contribution to ensuring that both institutions achieve their objectives. At the same time, it strengthens law enforcement within Europe.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Memorandum of Understanding, given it is crucial to foster cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in compliance with their respective mandates. Crucial in gaining my support was the fact that any exchange of information or experience provided for in this MoU does not include the transmission of operational information including data relating to an identified or identifiable person.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the Memorandum of Agreement between the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market and Eurojust. We understand that this technical procedure of agreement serves for exchanges of information between two spaces whose exchange of information, as EU institutions, is constitutionally guaranteed.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which proposes that the Parliament should give a favourable opinion on the Council implementing decision approving the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. I am confident that such a memorandum will improve the functioning of both Eurojust and of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The planned "implementing decision" gives the form of the "Memorandum of Understanding" between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM). The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate the cooperation of the two institutions in order to be able to operate in accordance with their competences and responsibilities. As the document states, the aim is strategic cooperation. This decision is a specific implementing act which requires the approval of the European Council after consultation of the European Parliament.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I fully endorse this approach and calling on the Council to be vigilant of the implementation in practice of the data protection guarantee. The purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation, in compliance with their respective mandates.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The draft implementing decision formalises the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust, which aims at fostering cooperation between the two institutions and contributes to a better performance. This understanding is therefore in the interest of both institutions and I have voted in favour of it. By the way, I believe that the Euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The planned "implementing decision" gives the form of the "Memorandum of Understanding" between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM). The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate the cooperation of the two institutions in order to be able to function in accordance with the powers and responsibilities they have been given. As the document states, the aim is strategic cooperation. This decision is a specific implementing act which requires the approval of the European Council after consultation of the European Parliament.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report timely delivery of payments to beneficiaries of the Union budget; that will develop a strategic cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM enabling them to achieve their respective objectives.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft implementing decision authorising Eurojust to conclude a Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust, as this strengthens cooperation between OHIM and Eurojust in line with their activities.  Furthermore, the Memorandum takes into account data protection and provides for how any disputes are resolved. Strategic cooperation in the areas concerned is essential to achieve common objectives and for mutual benefit, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The 2002/187/JAI decision provides for the possibility for Eurojust, the premise of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, to enter into agreements or working arrangements with agencies, institutions, and bodies created by treaties or on the basis of treaties.  These agreements or work arrangements may relate to the exchange of information, including personal data, and the posting of liaison officers to Eurojust. These agreements and arrangements can only be concluded after Eurojust consults the data protection body and authorizes the Council.  In order to broaden its scope of collaboration with the Internal Market Harmonization Office (OHMI) established by Regulation (EC) 207/2009 of the Council, Eurojust has initiated a memorandum of understanding with OHIM. The memorandum received a favourable opinion from Eurojust's supervisory body, and was finally approved by Eurojust College on 19 May 2015.  This text would strengthen Eurojust's powers, so we are opposed to it. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I voted today to oppose approval of the enhancement of the relationship between EUROJUST and OHIM. We have always opposed the existence of Eurojust as a proto-EU Ministry of Justice with overarching powers over many aspects of the legal regimes of Member States. In particular we oppose anything (such as the instant vote) that extends the remit of Eurojust and the parameters of its activities, especially where that introduces further regulation of the Single Market.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Kostas Chrysogonos' report on the Memorandum of Understanding between the Internal Market Harmonization Office and Eurojust. Through this working arrangement, Eurojust and the Intellectual Property Protection Office will be able to exchange information which will benefit their collaboration. From now on it will be easier to combat fraud and counterfeiting in the European Union. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – It is not clear from the report and the underlying documents what data will now be transferred in detail to improve cooperation with Eurojust. That is why I am abstaining.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the memorandum as its purpose is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in compliance with their respective mandates.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The planned "implementing decision" gives the form of the "Memorandum of Understanding" between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM). The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate the cooperation of the two institutions in order to be able to function in accordance with the powers and responsibilities they have been given. As the document states, the aim is strategic cooperation. This decision is a specific implementing act which requires the approval of the European Council after consultation of the European Parliament.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The Memorandum of Understanding aims to promote cooperation between Eurojust and the OHIM in accordance with their respective mandates. It defines and improves cooperation between the two bodies, and provides for a dispute clause on the interpretation or application of the agreement. These will have to be resolved through consultations and negotiations between the representatives of Eurojust and the OHIM, thus excluding arbitration by third parties.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. Like the other Members of the National Front, I voted against the Memorandum of Understanding between the Internal Market Harmonization Office and Eurojust. It should be remembered that Eurojust is the premise of a European public prosecutor's office. We oppose anything that can strengthen its powers, because justice must remain an exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MEPs voted against the report as it aims to strengthen Eurojust's competences and is another step towards the creation of a European public prosecutor's office. Yet justice is and should remain a regal jurisdiction of states.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This report was born with the aim of promoting cooperation between the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market and Eurojust in the exercise of their respective functions.  Among the provisions raised is the exclusion of a third arbitrator from the possible approach to differences in the application or interpretation of this memorandum between the two institutions. In addition, it shall not include the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified person. The rapporteur therefore asks the Council to pay close attention to ensuring data protection.  Similarly, in the event of well-founded suspicions of the possible breach of the agreement, either party may temporarily suspend the application of the agreement.  The aim is therefore to approve the Council's approval of this Memorandum as it will contribute to an improvement in the performance of the functions of both institutions. I agree with this approval as it is a measure of common interest to both OHIM and Eurojust.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market in accordance with the mandates. I supported a report by MeP Kostas Chrysogonos approving the conclusion of the Memorandum in order to continue developing strategic cooperation that will result in the fulfilment of the objectives of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is structurally composed of dozens of different institutions and entities, whose functional standardisation and efficiency have been subject to a number of institutional reforms for decades. Cooperation between these bodies also occupies an important place in the existence of our community, in overcoming existing and potential problems, and in resolving conflicts. The Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market deals with the registration of trade marks and designs at European Union level. OHIM has legal, administrative and financial independence, although it is supervised by the Court of Justice of the European Union. Eurojust' activities, for their part, aim to improve the effectiveness of the investigation and prosecution authorities of the Member States in relation to serious cross-border and organised crime-related cases. In other words, the functions of OHIM and Eurojust often intersect closely in the area of the management of commercial crime, so the promotion of cooperation between those institutions is essential. It was therefore perfectly logical to vote in favour of the adoption of this Memorandum of Understanding.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Memorandum strengthens cooperation between the Office and Eurojust. The agreed exchange of information will not concern operational information and data relating to an identified or identifiable person, thereby guaranteeing the protection of personal data.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust, because, in my view, it is neither complete nor documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. The purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in compliance with their respective mandates.  A provision which is particularly worthy of attention is Article 3(5) of the MoU, whereby ‘[e]xchange of information or experience provided for in this MoU shall not include the transmission of operational information including data relating to an identified or identifiable person’. This clarification was positively welcomed by the Joint Supervisory Body of Eurojust. The Rapporteur fully endorses this approach and calls on the Council to be vigilant of the implementation in practice of the data protection guarantee enshrined in Article 3(5) of the MoU.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Eurojust is a European agency with the mission of promoting and strengthening coordination and cooperation between national authorities in the fight against serious cross-border crime. These agreements between Eurojust and the Harmonization Office cover the exchange of information, including personal information, and the posting of liaison officers to Eurojust. We oppose this agreement on principle: Eurojust is a draft European prosecutor's office and we oppose its existence. This agreement would strengthen Eurojust's powers, so we strongly oppose it.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the draft Council implementing decision approving eurojust's conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. The aim of the memorandum is to promote cooperation between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market – OHIM – so that strategic cooperation can be developed to help them achieve their respective objectives in order to contribute to a better performance of their tasks.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of Mr Chrysogonos' proposal because the purpose of the memorandum is to promote cooperation between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) in accordance with their respective mandates. Indeed, the Memorandum of Understanding shows that Eurojust and OHIM are ready to develop strategic cooperation aimed at achieving their objectives.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains several sensible proposals. However, the rapporteur's aim seems to be to bring about further centralisation. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Union's Judicial Cooperation Unit, or Eurojust, is the European agency responsible for strengthening judicial cooperation between Member States. Under the 2002/187/JAI decision, Eurojust can enter into agreements with the institutions, bodies and agencies created by the treaties.  These agreements focus on the exchange of information, including personal data. This is an agreement with the Internal Market Harmonization Office. The protection of personal data is taken into account "this Memorandum of Understanding does not include the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified person or identifiable person."   It is mainly a technical agreement, which requires only the approval of the Council, while the European Parliament plays only an advisory role. I abstain in protest at the lack of power of Parliament.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing.
