The 2002/187/JAI decision provides for the possibility for Eurojust, the premise of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, to enter into agreements or working arrangements with agencies, institutions, and bodies created by treaties or on the basis of treaties. These agreements or work arrangements may relate to the exchange of information, including personal data, and the posting of liaison officers to Eurojust. These agreements and arrangements can only be concluded after Eurojust consults the data protection body and authorizes the Council. In order to broaden its scope of collaboration with the Internal Market Harmonization Office (OHMI) established by Regulation (EC) 207/2009 of the Council, Eurojust has initiated a memorandum of understanding with OHIM. The memorandum received a favourable opinion from Eurojust's supervisory body, and was finally approved by Eurojust College on 19 May 2015. This text would strengthen Eurojust's powers, so we are opposed to it. I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving eurojust's conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. The objective of this memorandum is to develop strategic cooperation, taking into account the functions of Eurojust and OHIM.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This draft implementing decision reinforces conclusions by Eurojust about the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust. This draft decision will solidify the agreement made by Eurojust and OHIM to further develop their cooperative strategies. Following on from the Council’s support, I chose to support this draft decision.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the conclusion of this agreement between Eurojust and the EU's main ip property protection agency. The Internal Market Harmonization Office aims to best manage the instruments for the protection of creativity and innovation, such as the Community brand and registered Community design.  This technical agreement will encourage and develop strategic cooperation between Eurojust and the Office while respecting the principle of data protection. The memorandum "does not include the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person."

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market and Eurojust. The purpose of the MoU is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in compliance with their respective mandates.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding is to promote cooperation between Eurojust and the OHIM in accordance with their mandates. Eurojust and the OHIM declare that they are 'willing and willing to develop strategic cooperation that will help them achieve their own objectives'. The Committee on Legal Affairs points out in its report that the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding will contribute to the better performance of their tasks under both bodies, i.e. the agreement is in the common interest of Eurojust and the OHIM and must therefore be approved by the Council. Accordingly, it recommends that Parliament approve the Council's draft. I supported the proposal accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal to amend Council Regulation (EC) No 207/2009 and the proposal to amend Directive 2008/95/EC on the Community trade mark are intended to harmonise the registration systems of trade marks existing in all Member States of the European Union, as well as to ensure coexistence and complementarity between the Community trade mark system and national trade mark systems. I advocate this change in order to make trade mark systems more efficient for businesses by reducing their costs, bureaucracy and the complexity of processes, ensuring them greater speed, predictability and legal certainty. In this way, I am sure that there will be a substantial increase in innovation and economic growth.  It is important to highlight the need to extend the acquis communautaire on the protection of geographical indications at Union level to include, through a future EU legislative act, geographical indications of goods other than agricultural goods and foodstuffs, wines and spirits.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text relates to the memorandum of understanding between the Internal Market Harmonization Office and Eurojust, which was taken to strengthen their capacity for collaboration. Eurojust may enter into agreements with other institutions or agencies that may cover the exchange of information, including personal data and the posting of liaison officers to Eurojust.  I oppose the adoption of this text because it contributes to the strengthening of Eurojust, which is an embryo of European prosecutor's office and therefore an instrument to undermine the sovereignty of the French nation. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which will ensure cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in areas in which their interests overlap, for example in cyber-piracy.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Memorandum of Understanding between the Internal Market Harmonization Office and Eurojust. The aim was to approve a Council decision to improve cooperation between the two bodies, enabling them to set up an information exchange system.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 draft Council implementing decision approving its conclusion by Eurojust.  I consider it very important to promote cooperation between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market. As set out in the recital to the Memorandum of Understanding in question, Eurojust and the OHIM are ready for strategic cooperation and recognise that the Memorandum of Understanding will allow them to better carry out their tasks. For this reason, I see that the Memorandum of Understanding is in the common interest of Eurojust and the OHIM, and I will therefore vote in favour of its adoption.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which will foster cooperation between the agency of the European Union (EU) dealing with judicial cooperation in criminal matters, Eurojust, and the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market in compliance with their respective mandates.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Memorandum is essential to encourage more effective cooperation between the two parties.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted today to oppose approval of the enhancement of the relationship between Eurojust and OHIM. We have always opposed the existence of Eurojust as a proto-EU Ministry of Justice with overarching powers over many aspects of the legal regimes of Member States. In particular we oppose anything (such as the instant vote) that extends the remit of Eurojust and the parameters of its activities, especially where that introduces further regulation of the single market.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased to support the conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation of the Internal Market. I believe that this cooperation, within the limits of its mandates, can be an added value for the full harmonisation of the European internal market. For these reasons, I am in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ OHIM (Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market) is known to represent the official body carrying out procedures relating to Community trade marks and that the same adopted intellectual property rules apply to all Member States of the European Union. As such, in its domain, OHIM also represents the Agency of the European Community and the Industrial Property Office, with the main task of technical function when registering said industrial property right.  Eurojust, in turn, is a single body set up solely to encourage and improve the coordination of investigations and prosecutions between Member States' judicial authorities responsible for serious forms of cross-border or organised crime. Combating serious forms of cross-border and organised crime, including fraud and money laundering, are challenges for the EU and may also be linked to the use of Community trade marks.  The Memorandum of Understanding aims to foster additional cooperation between the two important EU bodies, significantly facilitating access to data and any other necessary action in response to these issues. This Memorandum of Understanding formalises the relationship and cooperation between the bodies mentioned and enables the necessary coordination of the activities of both bodies to be improved. That's why I supported this report.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Memorandum of Understanding between the Internal Market Harmonization Office and Eurojust is intended to strengthen the working order of these two bodies. Eurojust may enter into agreements with other institutions or agencies on the exchange of information, including personal data and on the posting of liaison officers to Eurojust.  I oppose the adoption of this text because it contributes to the strengthening of Eurojust, which is an embryo of European prosecutor's office and therefore an instrument to undermine the sovereignty of the French nation. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support a positive opinion on the adoption of the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. Such a memorandum will encourage cooperation between the two institutions without in any way impairing the protection of personal data, since the MoU does not include the exchange of operational information and data of persons whose identity can be identified. It is also significant and positive that any disputes between the two parties regarding the interpretation of the MoU will be addressed through consultations between both parties and not through arbitration by a third party.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – I support a report by fellow MEP Kostas Chrysogonos on the Council's draft implementing decision authorising Eurojust to conclude a Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust.  Particularly interesting articles are Article 3(5) which states that the exchange of information or experience secured from this Memorandum does not include the transmission of operational information, including information on identified and unidentified persons. Also, attention should be paid to Article 6. the Memorandum, which states that disagreements relating to the interpretation or application of the Memorandum of Understanding should be resolved through consultations and negotiations between the parties.  Since the purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding is to improve cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM, and it states that there is a will and willingness to develop strategic operations that will help them achieve their respectable goals, I agree with the conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding, as it will greatly contribute to better implementation of their tasks.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust aims to promote cooperation between the two parties with mutual respect for their respective mandates. Several provisions in the memorandum are noteworthy. I voted in favour of this report because the Memorandum of Understanding is in the common interest of both Eurojust and the OHIM and creates the basis for strategic cooperation that can help them achieve their respective objectives.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour because it is a purely technical procedure for setting up an information exchange system to improve the cooperation of these European bodies. We need to make it easier for information to flow more efficiently.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust. This is a memorandum concluded with a view to fostering strategic cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM and can thus contribute to better performance on both sides. In this sense, I believe that the conditions for such an instrument to be adopted by the Council are met.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted today to oppose approval of the enhancement of the relationship between Eurojust and OHIM. We have always opposed the existence of Eurojust as a proto-EU Ministry of Justice with overarching powers over many aspects of the legal regimes of Member States. In particular we oppose anything (such as the instant vote) that extends the remit of Eurojust and the parameters of its activities, especially where that introduces further regulation of the single market.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this memorandum, which aims to encourage cooperation between Eurojust and the Internal Market Harmonization Office in accordance with their respective mandates.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. 'This Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament 'on the proposal for a Council Regulation on methods and procedure for making traditional own resources and own resources based on VAT and GNI available and measures to meet the needs of the treasury', which I voted in favour of, is part of the new own resources legislative package which will enter into force at the beginning of 2016 (taking retroactive effect since 01/01/2014).  This deeply technical Regulation contains practical provisions on issues such as the establishment of traditional own resources, the retention of supporting documents, the rate applicable for GNI-based own resources, as well as making adjustments and other provisions relating to treasury management and uncollectable amounts. I also consider it important to take account of the need to establish effective rules on the availability of contributions to the Union budget by Member States, with the aim of enabling the Commission to properly manage its treasury operations. The report also underlines that the Union's own resources system is too complex and 'needs to be thoroughly reformed under the next multiannual financial framework', a statement with which I agree.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust as it promotes cooperation between the representatives of the two institutions and enables the objectives set to be achieved.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report on the Memorandum of Agreement between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. We understand that this technical procedure of agreement serves for exchanges of information between two spaces whose exchange of information, as EU institutions, is constitutionally guaranteed.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves the Memorandum of Agreement between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market. This Memorandum aims to promote cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in the fulfilment of their respective mandates. The report includes a section wherein the Memorandum shall not include the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person. In my view, this is an important aspect of data protection, so I voted in favour.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution voted on today formalises the conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust. The aim of the agreement is to strengthen cooperation between the two institutions in accordance with their mandates. Both Eurojust and the OHIM consider that the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding will ensure better implementation of their activities; That is why I voted in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The memorandum of understanding subject to this vote enhances further the involvement of EuroJust in the single market which I am against. So I voted against this resolution.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which proposes that the Parliament should give a favourable opinion on the Council implementing decision approving the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. I am confident that such a memorandum will improve the functioning of both Eurojust and of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of a Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. Particular attention is paid to Article 3(5) of the MoU, according to which 'the exchange of information or experience under this MoU shall not involve the transmission of operational information, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person. Another important provision is the article on dispute settlement. According to this, disputes concerning the interpretation or application of the MoU must be settled through consultations and negotiations between representatives of Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market, which excludes arbitration by any third party.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Eurojust is a body tasked with improving the effectiveness of national authorities responsible for investigation and law enforcement. It also helps to address serious forms of cross-border and organised crime and to ensure swift and effective judicial treatment of offenders.  In particular, with a view to exchanging information between competent authorities, Eurojust has the possibility to conclude memoranda of understanding. The report concerns the confirmation of the conclusion of a memorandum of understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust, which aims to encourage their cooperation.  The Memorandum states, inter alia, that the exchange of information or experience shall not cover the transfer of operational data, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person. I agree that such an approach to the protection of personal data is appropriate, but I remain concerned about the effective implementation of this provision in practice.  The Memorandum also contains an unusual provision relating to a case of serious non-compliance with the provisions of the Memorandum of Understanding or if the parties consider that this could happen in the future. In this case, each party has the option of suspending compliance with the memorandum. Since I therefore do not agree with all the provisions in the Memorandum and believe that they could jeopardise the coordination and cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM, I abstained in the vote on the report.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this proposal taking into account the judgments of the Court of Justice of the European Union dated 16 April 2015 and the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs. The purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in accordance with their mandates. I believe that communication and information sharing between the Internal Market Coordination Office and Eurojust needs to be improved, allowing for more successful and efficient further work.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust as it lays the ground for good cooperation in areas where OHIM and Eurojust interests overlap, such as in cyber-piracy.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The draft implementation of the decision formalises eurojust's conclusion for the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM), for which JURI is responsible, and Eurojust.  The purpose of the memorandum is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the internal market in accordance with their mandates. Eurojust and OHIM agreed to conclude the memorandum because, according to recital 6, they are "willing and ready to develop strategic cooperation that could help them achieve the appropriate objectives". This is a specific implementing measure, which the Council would adopt on Parliament's proposal, according to the provisions in force before the Lisbon Treaty. I support this proposal for a memorandum of understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust, as I believe it will facilitate ohim-Eurojust cooperation and will be able to more easily realise certain objectives such as cooperation between competent authorities, facilitating the implementation of international mutual legal assistance and harmonisation of markets.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it is mainly of a formal nature.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council decision approving the conclusion by Eurojust of a memorandum of understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. Eurojust may conclude agreements with the institutions, bodies or agencies and these agreements relate to the exchange of information, including personal data, and the secondment of officials to Eurojust. I welcome Article 3(5) of the Memorandum, which states that the exchange of information or experience does not cover the transfer of this operational data, including data relating to an identified or identifiable person. I support the report because it will contribute to better and effective performance of the tasks of both bodies.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust, as I believe that strengthening cooperation between these authorities, particularly in the area of the enforcement of intellectual property rights, is necessary and can increase the effectiveness of not only the two institutions in this area. Sharing the information and experience of the various institutions whose agendas are intertwined is certainly a step in a good direction.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is necessary to safeguard the personal data of natural persons in cases of exchange of information between Eurojust and OHIM.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The planned "implementing decision" gives the form of the "Memorandum of Understanding" between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM). The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate the cooperation of the two institutions in order to be able to function in accordance with the powers and responsibilities they have been given. As the document states, the aim is strategic cooperation. This decision is a specific implementing act which requires the approval of the European Council after consultation of the European Parliament.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report approving the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. This agreement is also important as closer relations will help Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market to carry out their own tasks better. This is in the common interest, so we must certainly support it.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Memorandum of Understanding between OHIM and Eurojust is necessary, especially in the context of OHIM undergoing a restructuring through the reform of the European trade mark award and administration system.  I believe that only through effective cooperation between the European institutions can we hope to achieve our common objectives, including in the area of combating crime involving two or more Member States.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text. The draft enforcement decision under consideration formalises Eurojust's conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Internal Market Harmonization Office, over which the Legal Affairs Committee has jurisdiction under Schedule VI of the European Parliament Regulation, and Eurojust. The aim of the memorandum is to encourage cooperation between Eurojust and the Office in accordance with their respective mandates.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of approving the conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market. Its aim has been to strengthen Eurojust’s capacity to work with the Office for Harmonisation and foster their strategic cooperation, particularly on exchange of information. The arrangement is in line with EU legislation according to which Eurojust may conclude agreements or working arrangements with the institutions, bodies and agencies set up by, or on the basis of, the Treaties.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The planned "implementing decision" gives the form of the "Memorandum of Understanding" between Eurojust and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM). The purpose of this Agreement is to facilitate the cooperation of the two institutions in order to be able to function in accordance with the powers and responsibilities they have been given. As the document states, the aim is strategic cooperation. This decision is a specific implementing act which requires the approval of the European Council after consultation of the European Parliament.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a Memorandum of Understanding between the Internal Market Harmonisation Office and Eurojust, which aims to strengthen cooperation between the two organisations in line with their powers so that together they can better carry out their tasks. I fully support the emphasis on the need to guarantee data protection, i.e. that the envisaged exchange of information does not contain data transfers relating to the identification or identification of a person.  In addition, a provision has been adopted that in the event of a major non-compliance with the provisions, this Memorandum may be provisionally suspended in order to conduct further negotiations and consultations. In my view, the decisions taken are a clear indication of the readiness of both parties to carry out their tasks, and therefore I voted yes.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. The purpose of the Memorandum is to promote cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in accordance with their respective powers.  It appears that Eurojust and OHIM have decided to sign a Memorandum of Understanding because they are willing to develop strategic cooperation that could help them to achieve their objectives. It can be concluded that Eurojust and OHIM agree that the conditions set out in the Memorandum contribute to better fulfilling their tasks. It follows that the memorandum is in the common interest of Eurojust and OHIM in its present form and should also be approved as such by the Council.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report on the Memorandum of Agreement between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. We understand that this technical procedure of agreement serves for exchanges of information between two spaces whose exchange of information, as EU institutions, is constitutionally guaranteed.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. It is a reminder that Eurojust is the premise of a European public prosecutor's office. The National Front therefore opposes anything that can strengthen its powers. I'm voting against it.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for an implementation decision would like to underline the conclusion of the Memorandum of Understanding with the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM), which aims to strengthen cooperation in accordance with their respective mandates. By concluding this memorandum, the two institutions are willing and ready to develop strategic cooperation that can help them achieve their objectives. Consequently, the Memorandum is an element of common interest for both institutions, Eurojust on the one hand, and OHIM on the other. I fully welcome this approach to clarifying the two institutions, whereby the exchanges of information provided for do not include the transmission of operational information, including data referring to an identified or identifiable person. Furthermore, the Council will have to exercise vigilance with regard to the implementation of the data protection guarantee provided for in Article 3(5) of the Memorandum.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft implementing decision in question formalises the conclusion by Eurojust of a Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) and Eurojust, which is the responsibility of the Committee on Legal Affairs, in accordance with Annex VI to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report on the Memorandum of Agreement between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. We understand that this technical procedure of agreement serves for exchanges of information between two spaces whose exchange of information, as EU institutions, is constitutionally guaranteed.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important to highlight the purpose of the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to foster cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM in compliance with their respective mandates. This cooperation is extremely important in the everyday work of these institutions and therefore as much as possible needs to be done in order to ensure even greater efficiency.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The objective of this memorandum of agreement is to increase cooperation between the two institutions in order to better achieve their respective objectives.  We are talking about an implementation measure which must be adopted by the Council after consulting Parliament and which has no problems. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this memorandum of understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust. I believe that this memorandum will improve the functioning of both institutions.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Memorandum of Understanding promotes cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM, in accordance with their respective mandates, strengthening the fight against serious crimes, including product contraption.  Eurojust and OHIM recognise that the terms of the Memorandum, including Article 6 thereof, contribute to a better performance of their functions.  We follow the advantages of such a memorandum and note that personal data is safeguarded.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contains several sensible proposals. However, the rapporteur's aim seems to be to bring about further centralisation. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution by which Parliament gave its assent to the Council's proposal. As Eurojust can conclude working arrangements with other institutions and agencies, which may relate, for example, to the exchange of information or the secondment of staff, I consider that this agreement with the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market will also help to strengthen their cooperation with each other and help to better fulfil their tasks within their mandates.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft implementing decision under consideration formalises the conclusion by Eurojust of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM), for which the Committee on Legal Affairs is competent in accordance with Annex VI to the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, and Eurojust. The aim of this Memorandum of Understanding is to foster cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM, in accordance with their mandates, in the areas of combating serious crimes, including product-related crimes. In view of our strong objections to both the harmonisation processes in the framework of internal market policy and eurojust, so that it means withdrawing national powers from the justice systems of each country, we voted against it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a European Parliament resolution on a Memorandum of Understanding between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and Eurojust, as I support strategic cooperation between Eurojust and OHIM. In accordance with the specific implementing provisions, they will achieve their objectives more successfully than those set out in their mandate.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Regulation regulates the EU's own resources, in particular VAT and GDP contributions. The aim of the amendments to the Regulation is to avoid haggling in this area which must be transparent. This review aims to ensure that Member States continue to contribute their contributions without delay, clarifying the rules on interests and other technical issues, for the sake of transparency and accuracy. That's why I voted for it.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report endorses the European Commission's proposal to amend Regulation 609/2014 known as "Clean Resource Decisions" setting out the rules for the provision of own resources and measures relating to cash requirements. The text specifies the categories of own resources, their methods of calculation, as well as the methods for paying contributions from Member States.  It also calls for more automation of Member States' contributions to the EU budget to avoid political negotiations.  Finally, the report calls for streamlining annual adjustments to adapt them to their own resources based on VAT and GNI and to simplify and reduce the budgetary burden on Member States and the EU budget. It ensures the proper management and operation of payments which are sometimes essential for certain economic sectors, this proposal also perpetuates the current system of own resources of the EU.  I abstained because the proposal perpetuates the system of own resources.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst there are certain positives in this report, I felt it necessary to oppose the report because of the three-twelfths principle which it supports. Furthermore, it supports measures which take away the rights of certain regulatory boards and ombudsmen of Member States.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because the Union must have its own resources in the best possible conditions and therefore the rules under which Member States make these own resources available to the Commission should be set. This regulation incorporates the rules for the provision of traditional own resources.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to amend Regulation No 609/2014, which ˗ to amend Regulation No 609/2014, incorporating a number of more technical questions and explanations. I support the proposals set out above to provide for effective rules to determine how Member States should make their contributions to the Union budget in a timely manner. It should be noted that the Commission has been given the opportunity to ask Member States to pay the third twelfth of VAT and GNI-based resources in the first half of the year in order to enable the Commission to reduce the greater proportion of payments made in previous years. It is important not only to provide for more timely payment incentives in order to increase the payment of late payments, but also to ensure proportionality by providing that the interest rate increase may not exceed the 20 percentage point threshold. I support the calls on the Commission to examine the recommendations on the methods of accounting for member states' national contributions to the Union budget, which are very diverse in order to facilitate comparison between Member States. I agree that the own resources system remains too complex and needs to be fundamentally reformed under the next Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This text calls for approval of the European Commission's proposal to amend Regulation 609/2014, known as "Own Resource Decisions" which sets out the rules for the provision of own resources and measures to meet cash requirements. In particular, it specifies the categories of own resources, their methods of calculation, as well as the terms of payment of Member States' contributions.  It is in order to reduce the risk of annual payment delays that the EU and Member States have faced in recent years (e.g. giving rise to an unprecedented volume of adjustments at the end of 2014) that it has been agreed to revise this procedure.  While the report recommends "automating" Member States' contributions to the EU budget to avoid political negotiations, it is mainly a matter of streamlining annual adjustments to own resources based on VAT and GNI in order to simplify and reduce the budgetary burden on Member States and to ensure good management as well as the proper functioning of payments.  I did not object to that.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I vote in favour of this dossier. In the context that several countries have not contributed to the EU budget (UK) or have rebates (up to 12 cases), the dossier urges payment in a timely manner to avoid added costs of arrears in regular payments, seeking to isolate from political debates (Brexit?) an agreement to contribute the own resources of which the European budget is endowed with a harmonised and formally appropriate procedure. Ultimately, it is a call of attention, without naming it, to the informal contribution of certain countries, precisely at a time when the budget is also seen as an insufficient resource to meet the Union's challenges.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report approves the Commission's proposal to amend Regulation 609/2014, known as "Clean Resource Decisions" which sets out the rules for the provision of own resources and measures to meet cash requirements.  Following the numerous annual payment delays faced by the EU and Member States in recent years, it was agreed, in a Commission proposal, to revise this procedure. The report also calls for "automating" the contributions of member states in the EU budget to avoid political conflicts over the timing of payments and limiting Member States' discretion over the timing of their additional contribution from GNI adjustments.  While this system seeks to streamline annual adjustments to own resources (VAT and GNI), this proposal perpetuates the EU's own resource situation. So I abstained.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union costs Italy 5.5 billion a year. Having noted that the contribution made by the Member States to Europe is already very high and almost entirely spent on financing crazy decisions that hit our citizens hard and put our businesses in crisis, I voted against this text, which aims to speed up the payment of contributions.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report. I would like to stress that I am opposed to giving the EU the right to tax. In this case, however, it is a question of reforming a pre-existing system of payments from the Member States for their VAT and GNI-based contributions to the Union budget.  In 2014, the ambiguities of the current system posed serious problems, with several Member States paying incorrect amounts either too much or too little. The reforms are intended to simplify and clarify calculation and payment methods so that similar problems can be avoided in the future. That is why I have voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In view of the imminent legislation on own resources in early 2016, it is necessary to amend the accompanying Regulation on methods and procedures for the making available of own resources by Member States. The report considers that the Commission's proposed amendment is appropriate to address the shortcomings of existing legislation in order to ensure that Member States make their contributions to the EU budget in a timely manner and to avoid political disputes over the timing of payments. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the Council Regulation on methods and procedures for the provision of VAT and GNI-based own resources and on measures to meet cash requirements, with minor amendments. In its report, Parliament notes that, as a general rule, Member States have so far been too late to pay all their VAT and GNI-based contributions to the Union budget, even in the context of a crisis and very severe fiscal constraints. However, in order to meet the need for cash, the provision and revision of Member States' contributions to the Union budget should not be subject to political negotiations, but should be a technical process. In this report, Parliament also invited it to report annually on the calculation and supporting data on the calculation and supporting data of the VAT and GNI balance adjustments, as well as on the dates and amounts of contributions transferred by The Member States to the Union budget, with a view to maximising transparency.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The legislation currently in force relating to Council Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom had to be revised at the end of 2014 due to the particularly high VAT and GNI adjustments found for each Member State. At the same time, Treaty 609/2014/EU, Euratom should be revised in the light of the experience of the 2014 adjustments. The European Parliament underlines the need for effective rules on the way in which Member States make their contributions available to the EU budget in a timely manner, as this will be when the Commission will be able to manage its coffers effectively. I support the opportunity afforded to the Commission to ask Member States to pay three to twelfths of VAT and GNI-based resources in the first half of the year, in order to enable the Commission to reduce a significant part of the previous year's payment arrears at the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the European Structural and Investment Funds and to reduce interest on late payment. The purpose of amending the methods for adjusting contributions is to avoid cases such as those of 2014. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report, which deals with the rules on making available own resources based on VAT and GNI. By changing the rules, the Commission wants to avoid any problematic situation related to technical calculations, such as the one in 2014 when member states had to provide additional funding for the EU budget due to recalculation.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for approval of the Commission's proposal to amend the regulation that sets the rules for the provision of own resources. In concrete terms, this text calls for the automaticisation of member states' contributions so that they are not the subject of political negotiations.  These proposals aim to reduce the delay in payment of these contributions by limiting member states' discretion in setting the timetable.  Although these measures contribute to the sustainability of the Union's current system of own resources, we cannot support the unprecedented budgetary gabegies of Member States' contributions. As such, France loses more than 9 billion euros each year between what it collects and what it gives to the European Union. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The own resources decision is the key legal instrument that sets out the main elements of the system, in this case the size of the Union budget.  The new provisions support the strengthening of the Union budget and the prevention of potential losses. The Member States must thus have opened an account on behalf of the Commission for their own resources at their treasuries or designate a body for that purpose. Furthermore, one of the provisions indicates the assurance that no fees or negative interest are charged for own resources accounts, precisely in order to avoid exposing the budget to various risks. It is also envisaged to rationalise the annual adjustments of VAT-based own resources and OF own resources based on VAT. This report provides concrete methods and procedures to meet the needs of the treasury and to avoid situations where the Union budget could be exposed to financial risks, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the Council Regulation on how member states make their own resources available. Many of the resources that Member States pay to the EU are based on VAT and gross national income. This Regulation arises from the (presumed) need to ensure the timely payment of these resources by The Member States. In practice, the proposal provides for the Commission to ask states to pay part of the resources as early as the first half of the financial year and a series of other measures in favour of faster payment of contributions from EU States. This measure, among other things, is the start of the work of the working group coordinated by Mario Monti on the reform of the own resources system. Our delegation considers it absolutely not a priority to make improvements to the management of the (huge) flow of money with which the Member States finance policies of which, to a very large part, we do not share aims and actions.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which was a purely technical report. It is a revision of the regulation to ensure that Member States deliver their contributions with no significant delay and it also clarifies interest rate rules and other technical issues. Moreover, it increases transparency and accuracy by reporting regularly on the calculation process regarding data for VAT and GNI adjustments. However, I wish to note my party’s concerns in relation to Ireland’s contribution to the EU budget. Whilst it is recognised that Ireland does contribute to the EU budget through the traditional own resources (customs duties) and there is an obligation to do so, this nonetheless does not negate our concerns with how the EU budget expenditure is financed by Member States and how moreover the EU budget is allocated each year. In addition, we have a number of concerns with the proposed financial transaction tax, environmental tax, etc., which we believe are intended to strip a Member State of its financial competencies.  As Irelands is set to become a net contributor to the EU budget, these concerns are set to become more pressing.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP will be voting against this report. There are certain positives in this report that relate to the fact that political (financial) bargaining should be refrained from regarding Member State contributions. There is a call to ensure that Member States pay 3/12th of GNI and VAT resources in the first half of the year to deal with the payment backlog of the previous year; this is directed towards the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and in particular the European Structural and Investment Funds. To boost the speed and efficiency of payments there is a strong point made to eliminate political interference. However, we do need this in order to question what is going on relating to GNI and VAT resources being submitted by Member States. The onus of management includes accounting procedures and practices indicating a uniformed approach to accounting and submitting of contributions. There is no way we can support such measures that take away the rights of our own British regulatory boards and financial ombudsman offices. There is also a call on the Commission to alter its proposal so that it fits in with Article 293(2) of the TFEU and Article 106(a) of the Euratom Treaty.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The dossier aims to introduce changes and clarifications of a predominantly technical nature with regard to the provisions currently in force on the budget. Although I am certainly in favour of a comprehensive reform of the system, making the mechanism simpler, more effective and more transparent, I have opted for abstention so as not to fully endorse a system such as the current one which is certainly unfair with regard to the calculation of contributions by the Member States.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and consider it positive. We believe that the proposed amendments to the methods applied to contribution adjustments are intended to avoid any incident similar to that which occurred in 2014. We believe that these contribution adjustments should be treated as automatically as possible in order to avoid political interference in the understood ways of financing the Union budget and to minimise the discretion left to Member States as to the timing of their additional contributions to the Union budget resulting from GNI adjustments.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The proposal to adopt the methods and procedure for the reimbursement of traditional own resources and own resources based on VAT and GNI concerns a very important area of rationalisation of the functioning of the European Union. As in the recent past there have been large discrepancies in the financial data of members and in the individual burdens to which each member has been asked to respond, it becomes apparent that any process of correcting malfunctions must be supported . That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. Regulation (EC) No 609/2014 on methods and procedures for making own resources available to Member States is part of the new own resources legislative package that will enter into force at the beginning of 2016 (applied retroactively from 1 January 2014). The technical regulation containing practical provisions on issues such as the establishment of traditional own resources, the retention of supporting documents, the rate applicable to the GDP-based own resource, the time frame for making them available and for making adjustments and provisions on liquidity management and non-recoverable amounts.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that an annual report on the calculations and data underlying the adjustments to vat and GNI balances should be submitted to Parliament, and whereas the Commission's proposal also contains amendments to the rules on interest, I believe it is necessary to provide for effective rules to ensure that Member States make timely payments of their contributions to the Union budget. I think the content of the report and its objective are satisfactory. I also think it would be useful if the corrections to contributions were to be managed as automatically as possible in order to avoid political interference with the already agreed methods of financing the Union budget and to minimise the margin of discretion left to the Member States as regards the deadlines for the payment of their additional contributions. From this point of view, I would like to vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I consider the Commission proposal as appropriate to address the shortcomings of the current Regulation and stress the need to avoid political disputes about the timing of payments.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Council proposal amending Regulation No 605/2014 on Euratom (European Atomic Energy Community) and I believe that effective rules should be established to ensure that Member States make timely payments of their contributions to the Union budget in order to enable the Commission to manage the overall budget effectively.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – This proposal on the methods and procedures for making available own resources by Member States is part of the new legislative package on own resources (OR) that will enter into force in the beginning of 2016. This is largely a technical Regulation that contains practical arrangements on issues like the establishment of traditional own resources, conservation of supporting documents, the applicable rate for the GNI-based own resource, the timing for making them available and for making adjustments and provisions concerning cash management and irrecoverable amounts. I support the proposal with special regards to the streamlining of the currently very complicated procedures for adjusting the VAT and GNI own resources for prior years. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the resolution is to approve some changes to the measures in force to date with regard to the Resources of the European Union. The functioning of the Union is based on a budget entirely financed from own resources. The own resources ceiling was maintained at 1.23 % of the gross national income (GNI) of the EU Member States. Today there are three categories of resources in the EU system: traditional own resources, vat-based own resource (VAT) and gross national income (GNI) own resources. The new measures should ensure the timely payment of contributions to the EU budget to enable more effective management of the treasurer. The calculation of Member States' contributions to the EU budget has not always been transparent, which is why I am in favour of a reform of the system that can make the mechanism simpler and clearer. Although several corrections have been made over time, such as the "British correction" obtained by Thatcher, they have certainly not helped to make everything more transparent. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Regulation regulates the EU's own resources, in particular VAT and GDP contributions. The aim of the amendments to the Regulation is to avoid haggling in this area which must be transparent. This review aims to ensure that Member States continue to contribute their contributions without delay, clarifying the rules on interests and other technical issues, for the sake of transparency and accuracy. That's why I voted for it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with methods and procedure for making available the traditional, VAT and Gross National Income based own resources and with the measures to meet cash requirements. The Commission aims to avoid any problematic situation linked to technical recalculations. For example at the end of 2014, due to the re-calculation, the UK and other Member States needed to provide additional resources to the EU budget, which led to an intense discussion within the Council. I voted in favour of this report as it is meant to avoid internal frictions, and I also supported the streamlining of the currently very complicated procedures for adjusting the VAT and GNI own resources for prior years.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This non-legislative report proposes the European Parliament's opinion to the Council on the revision of the regulation on the modalities and procedures for the provision of traditional own resources, the own VAT-based resource and the GNI-based own resource and measures to meet cash requirements, which will come into force in early 2016.  There are several reasons for the revision of this mainly technical regulation, starting with the need to apply the new procedure for the annual adjustment of resources specific to VAT and GNI, adopted at the end of 2014. The Commission is also proposing other minor revisions, such as the procedure for calculating interest on amounts made available late.  In particular, the report calls for greater transparency by giving the European Parliament access to information on calculations. Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP will be voting against this report. There are certain positives in this report that relate to the fact that political (financial) bargaining should be refrained from regarding Member State contributions. The onus of management includes accounting procedures and practices indicating a uniformed approach to accounting and submitting of contributions. There is no way we can support such measures that take away the rights of our own British regulatory boards and financial ombudsman offices. There is also a call on the Commission to alter its proposal so that it fits in with Article 293(2) of the TFEU and Article 106(a) of the Euratom Treaty.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Measures to encourage Member States to meet the deadlines for paying their contribution to the EU budget are important so that the Commission can effectively manage its cash flow and reduce late payments. That is why I supported this report.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for the Lewandowski and Deprez report, which is part of a parliamentary consultation procedure in which the rapporteurs call for greater clarity and transparency in the provision of own resources.  I the for the better of transparency thereby consider that a report on the calculation and the underlying data of the adjustment of the BALANCEs of VAT and GNI (gross national income levy) must be presented to Parliament every year.  The same goes for the dates and amounts of contributions made by Member States to the EU budget. Finally, I find the own resources system too complex, which is why substantive reform in the context of the next multi-year financial framework is needed.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for approval of the Commission's proposal to change the rules on the transfer of resources to the EU from member budgets. In specifying the methods of calculation and the methods of payment of contributions in particular, important points are addressed in this report. The aim is to simplify and reduce the budgetary burden of Member States' contributions to the EU. By adjusting more precisely the contributions requested, it allows these levies to be more in line with the real economic situation of the member countries. Nevertheless, if it lowers the levies, this report perpetuates this very important transfer that sovereign states are undergoing by a European Union which has harmed them for almost twenty years. Attached to the sovereignty of nation-states, I can only observe that too much money paid to the European Union is an illegitimate dime. The effective representation of the French people in European decisions is more than limited, so their taxation cannot be justified. That's why I abstained.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 No, I do not support this report. We all know that so far there have been no problems with member states' contributions, but on the other hand, we want to introduce stricter measures and increase interest on late payments, although there are none or almost none. Most countries have a different way of accounting for budget contributions, and we want them to be imported in a unified way. Let's make changes first in this regard and only then demand new measures. Yes, there are good things here, like the depolitiation of the budget, but that's not enough for me to support the report. That's why I voted against it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The existing procedure for the reimbursement of traditional own resources and own resources based on VAT and GNI of the Member States, despite the effort to amend it, remains complex to an excessive extent and needs to be fundamentally reformed in order to be able to meet the current requirements created by the critical situation in which the Union is located.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The legislation currently in force relating to Council Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom had to be revised at the end of 2014 due to the particularly high VAT and GNI adjustments found for each Member State. At the same time, Treaty 609/2014/EU, Euratom should be revised in the light of the experience of the 2014 adjustments. The purpose of amending the methods for adjusting contributions is to avoid cases such as those of 2014. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because it perpetuates the European Union's own resources.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to the amendment of the Regulation defining Member States' contributions to the EU budget, particularly those based on VAT and GNI. The proposed amendments are to speed up and make resources available in a timely manner, while also avoiding further adjustments as significant as those in recent years. The amendments clarify more technical aspects and increase transparency and accuracy in the calculation of national contributions.  Despite this generally positive sense, we have long advocated a more substantive change in national contributions to the EU budget, with a substantial increase in the eu budget, guaranteed from national contributions that take into account the relative wealth of each country (from its GNI), with a substantial increase in contributions from the countries with the highest GNI – those that have benefited the most from the single market and EU policies. The Community budget should have a redistributive role and should take real convergence and the promotion of economic and social cohesion as a priority, and therefore the limit of own resources should be increased. The current budget is far from allowing it. This profound change is not the subject of this report, but only some adjustments of an eminently technical nature to the current system. We abstained.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because, although I fully support the Commission's proposal on the subject of own resources, Parliament's report tends to politicise a strictly technical procedure.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report deals with rules on the provision of own funds and measures to secure cash. It shall include practical arrangements for setting traditional own resources, storing documents, administrative cooperation, applicable rates for own-account GNI, accounts to be held from own resources, timing for making them available and for the production of adjustments, and provisions on cash management and bad debts. The modification of the rules should avoid the situation that arose in 2014, when the United Kingdom and the other Member States had to make an additional contribution to the common budget of the European Union, which led to intensive discussions.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 If, after the monstrous Italian failure, a person like Mario Monti finds space in Europe by coordinating the work of the working group on the reform of the own resources system from which this proposal springs, it really means that the EU must be completely revolutionised.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because I believe that the existing procedure for the reimbursement of traditional own resources and own resources based on VAT and GNI in the Member States, even after the attempt to amend it, remains too complex and needs to be reformed from the outset in order to be able to meet the current requirements and critical conditions facing the Union.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the rules on making own resources available and the measures to meet cash requirements. It contains practical arrangements in respect of the establishment of traditional own resources, conservation of supporting documents, administrative cooperation, the applicable rate for the GNI-based own resource, accounts to be kept for own resources, the timing for making them available and for making adjustments and provisions concerning cash management and irrecoverable amounts. By modifying the rules, the Commission aims to avoid any problematic situation linked to technical recalculations. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The legislation currently in force relating to Council Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom had to be revised at the end of 2014 due to the particularly high VAT and GNI adjustments found for each Member State. The purpose of amending the methods for adjusting contributions is to avoid cases such as those of 2014. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the view that efficient rules on the arrangements for the timely transfer of State contributions to the Union budget are necessary, so that the Commission can effectively manage its treasury in order to achieve a further reduction in delays in payments from the previous year for the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the European Structural and Investment Funds , as well as interest on late payment.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on methods and procedures for the provision of traditional, VAT and GNI own resources, as well as measures to provide the necessary cash, as I believe that the technical proposals it makes to improve procedures are right and appropriate.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is important to define precisely when and how Member States must meet their individual financial obligations to the Commission. This is the only way to ensure good and, above all, efficient work.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this non-legislative consultation of Parliament which concerns a number of changes that were made to the system for VAT and GNI-based own resources contributions in response to UK Government requests. The changes were made in response to last year’s budget surcharge incident where a number of Member States were required to pay additional amounts based upon an adjustment to past GNI calculations.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Vote in favor of this dossier. In the context that several countries have not contributed to the EU budget (UK) or have rebates (up to 12 cases), the dossier urges payment in a timely manner to avoid added costs of arrears in regular payments, seeking to isolate from political debates (Brexit?) an agreement to contribute the own resources of which the European budget is endowed with a harmonised and formally appropriate procedure. Ultimately, it is a call of attention, without naming it, to the informal contribution of certain countries, precisely at a time when the budget is also seen as an insufficient resource to meet the Union's challenges.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which comes as a response to UK Government requests for the changes outlined in this report. After intense discussion within the Council, it would be great to see the Commission’s aims of avoiding any problematic situations linked to the technical recalculations of the methods and procedures which make available the traditional, Value-Added-Tax and Gross-National-Income-based own-resources.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the option granted to the Commission to ask Member States for the payment of 3/12th of VAT and GNI resources in the first half of the year, in order to allow the Commission to reduce a more important part of the previous year’s payment backlog in the European Agriculture Guarantee Fund and in the European Structural and Investment Funds, and to reduce default interest.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The legislation currently in force relating to Council Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom had to be revised at the end of 2014 due to the particularly high VAT and GNI adjustments found for each Member State. The purpose of amending the methods for adjusting contributions is to avoid cases such as those of 2014. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Own resources enable Brussels to finance itself, thus distancing itself from the Member States and gaining financial autonomy. This autonomy has always been something we have criticised, because this is how Brussels can bypass the interests of the Member States and impose economic and other policies on them. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to vote for this report as there is a need for efficient rules on how Member States make their timely contributions to the Union budget available in order to allow the Commission to manage its treasury effectively. I agree that these adjustments of contributions should be dealt with as automatically as possible to avoid political interference with the agreed ways of financing the Union budget and to limit to a minimum the discretion left to Member States as to the timing of their additional contributions resulting from GNI adjustments to the Union budget.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ On 14 September 2015 the Commission proposed an amendment to the legislative package on own resources agreed in May 2014, which would provide Member States with more time to pay for larger than expected adjustments in their VAT and GNI-based contributions to the EU budget by informing them earlier about bills. Interest rate on late payments would also be increased from 2% to 3.5% but would be capped at 20%. Furthermore, the amendment aims at increasing the amount of VAT and GNI-based contributions they can draw forward over a longer period of time. Though Parliament’s report contains good elements, it introduces elements which politicise the process, such as a call for a fundamental reform of the system of own resources. I therefore voted against it. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The legislation currently in force relating to Council Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom had to be revised at the end of 2014 due to the particularly high VAT and GNI adjustments found for each Member State. At the same time, Treaty 609/2014/EU, Euratom should be revised in the light of the experience of the 2014 adjustments. The European Parliament underlines the need for effective rules to ensure that Member States make their contributions available to the EU budget in a timely manner. Only then will the Commission be able to manage its coffers effectively. Parliament supports the possibility for the Commission to ask Member States to pay three to twelfths of VAT and GNI-based resources in the first half of the year, in order to enable the Commission to reduce a significant part of the previous year's payment arrears at the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the European Structural and Investment Funds and to reduce interest on late payment. The purpose of amending the methods for adjusting contributions is to avoid cases such as those of 2014. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and hope that these technical adjustments discourage future late payments.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report including the timely delivery of payments to beneficiaries of the European Union budget, aiming not only at increasing the incentives to pay on time by making more expensive any late payment but also at ensuring proportionality, by capping the maximum increase of the interest rate at 20 percentage points.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council regulation amending the Regulation on methods and procedures for making available traditional own resources and own resources based on VAT and GNI, and on measures to meet cash needs, as I think the own resources system is very complex and needs to be reformed.  It is also necessary to ensure the timely payment of Member States' contributions to the Union budget and to allow for a reduction in payment delays, by the Commission, for the previous year for individual funds. I also believe that accounting methods of recording contributions to the Union budget need to be uniformed so that Member States can be compared, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for approval of the European Commission's proposal to amend Regulation 609/2014, known as "Clean Resource Decisions" which sets out the rules for the provision of own resources and measures to meet cash requirements.  This report specifies the categories of own resources, their methods of calculation, as well as the methods of payment of member states' contributions. The report endorses the Commission's proposal while calling for more automation of Member States' contributions to the EU budget to avoid political negotiations.  The report therefore considers the Commission's proposal to be appropriate to fill gaps in the current regulations if necessary in order to ensure that Member States make their contribution to the EU budget.  This text aims to streamline annual adjustments to own resources based on VAT and GNI in order to simplify and reduce the budgetary burden on Member States and the EU budget and thus ensure the proper management and proper functioning of the payments sometimes essential for certain economic sectors, this proposal also perpetuates the current system of own resources of the EU.  I abstained.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I will be voting against this report. There are certain positives in this report and those relate to the fact that political (financial) bargaining should be refrained from regarding Member State contributions. There is a call to ensure that Member States pay 3/12th of GNI and VAT resources in the first half of the year to deal with the payment backlog of the previous year; this is directed towards the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and in particular the European Structural and Investment Funds. To boost the speed and efficiency of payments there is a strong point made to eliminate political interference. However, we do need this in order to question what is going on relating to GNI and VAT resources being submitted by Member States. The onus of management includes accounting procedures and practices indicating a uniformed approach to accounting and submitting of contributions. There is no way we can support such measures that take away the rights of our own British regulatory boards and financial ombudsman offices. There is also a call on the Commission to alter its proposal so that it fits in with Article 293(2) of the TFEU and Article 106(a) of the Euratom Treaty.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Gérard Deprez and Janusz Lewandowski on the provision of traditional own resources, the own VAT-based resource and the own resource based on GNI and other measures. Parliament calls for greater clarity and transparency in the European Union's own resources system, for example by determining when the amounts will be made available. In addition, Parliament calls in its report for greater access to relevant methods of calculation and information. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Revenue based on GNP and VAT is based on a mechanism that is too complex, costly and non-transparent. Simplification, as proposed here, is to be welcomed, as it minimises costs and also makes it clear and transparent to the Member States where what money is going. However, the report also provides for a third twelfth of VAT revenue to be paid to the Commission so that it can bridge arrears from these funds. It also aims to reduce the Member States' room for manoeuvre at the time of payments. I reject this and vote against this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal, as it is aimed at avoiding any problematic situation linked to technical recalculations.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Explanation of votes - resolution on traditional, amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 609/2014 on methods and procedures for the provision of VAT and GNI-based own resources and measures to meet cash needs The legislation currently in force relating to Council Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom had to be revised at the end of 2014 due to the particularly high VAT and GNI adjustments found for each Member State. At the same time, Treaty 609/2014/EU, Euratom should be revised in the light of the experience of the 2014 adjustments.
