The European Parliament underlines the need for effective rules on the way in which Member States make their contributions available to the EU budget in a timely manner, as this will be when the Commission will be able to manage its coffers effectively. Parliament supports the possibility for the Commission to ask Member States to pay three to twelfths of VAT and GNI-based resources in the first half of the year, in order to enable the Commission to reduce a significant part of the previous year's arrears at the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the European Structural and Investment Funds and to reduce interest on late payment. The purpose of amending the methods for adjusting contributions is to avoid cases such as those of 2014. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the primary objective of the proposal for a regulation is to make the rules on member states' contributions to the Union budget more effective. I have chosen to vote in favour of the proposal for a regulation because it is necessary to minimise the margin of discretion left to The Member States as regards the deadlines for the payment of their additional contributions to the Union budget resulting from GNI corrections. Finally, I believe that the proposed changes can prevent a similar incident from occurring in 2014.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on the modalities and procedure for making traditional own resources available, the own VAT-based resource and the GNI-based own resource and measures to meet cash requirements.  If it is to rationalise annual adjustments to own resources based on VAT and GNI to simplify and reduce the budgetary burden on Member States and the EU budget (especially at the end of the year) and thus ensure the proper management and smooth operation of the payments sometimes essential for certain economic sectors, this proposal perpetuates the current system of own resources of the EU.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Proposal to amend Council Regulation No 2012 609/2014 on the methods and procedure for making traditional own resources and own resources based on VAT and GNI available and on measures to meet cash needs are part of a new legislative package on own resources to be applied from 2016 to 2020.  It will also be retroactively applied from 1 January 2014. The amended Regulation will help improve transparency, as statistical corrections regarding Member States' contributions to the European Union budget will be published at the beginning of the year and will help define the amount and date for contributions. The collection of three twelfths of funds from Member States will be made possible in the first half of the year to relieve pressure due to delays in disbursements of funds in the area of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) and the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF). I supported the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation No 1999/2013. 609/2014.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union's annual budget for this year alone exceeded EUR 162 billion in terms of revenue. An absolute majority of these funds came from Member States: from various taxes, tariffs and other sources. The financing and co-financing of all programmes implemented by the EU takes place directly from these funds, so payments fully implemented in a time, stable and in line with commitments are essential for the effective implementation of Union policies in agriculture, regional policy, foreign affairs and other areas. In other words, the European Union depends on the Member States and the Member States themselves are dependent on the Union. And in order for this link to continue to exist effectively, it is also necessary, among other things, to adopt this regulation, which would amend the adoption last year. In order for our Member States and their citizens to be able to fully gain access to Community funds and other sources of co-financing of projects and programmes, Member States must first fulfil their budgetary payment commitments. Increasing clarity and active reform of the principles of replenishment and spending of the EU budget is a guarantee of effective implementation of Community policies.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposal submitted regulates the provision, calculation and adjustment of Member States' contributions to the Union budget so that the Commission can effectively manage its cash register and make payments to beneficiaries in a timely manner. In addition to technical adjustments concerning payment deadlines, measures against late payment are introduced.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1605/2002. 609/2014 on the methods and procedure for the return of traditional own resources and own resources based on VAT and GNI and on measures to address cash needs, because it is fully and well documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal which stresses the need for the timely delivery of payments to beneficiaries of the European Union budget.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new own resources legislative package, which will enter into force at the beginning of 2016, contains a Council regulation (No 609/2014) on methods and procedures for making own resources available to Member States. This is a technical regulation which is essential in order to regulate a number of issues of fundamental importance, since it therefore leads me to vote in favour of this report. These are, therefore, practical provisions on issues such as the establishment of traditional own resources, the retention of supporting documents, the rate applicable to the GDP-based own resource, the time frame for making them available and for making adjustments and provisions on liquidity management and non-recoverable amounts.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the report on the proposal for a Council Regulation on methods and procedures for making available traditional and VAT- and GNI-based own resources and on measures to address treasury needs. Efficient rules on the modalities for the timely transfer of State contributions to the Union budget are necessary so that the Commission can effectively manage its treasury. I also think it is very positive that a point should be made on the importance of punctuality in payments to beneficiaries of the Union budget, penalizing delays and ensuring proportionality.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. BNP and VAT-based revenues are based on a mechanism that is too complex, costly and non-transparent. Simplification, as proposed here, is to be welcomed, as it minimises costs and also makes it easier for the Member States to understand what money is going where. However, the report provides for a third twelfth of VAT revenue to be paid to the Commission in order to bridge the arrears and to reduce the Member States' room for manoeuvre in the period of payments. I therefore reject this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. By joining the European Union, each state commits to make a contribution to the common budget each year based on its wealth. The report before us sets out the modalities and procedures for making traditional own resources available (own VAT-based resource and GNI-based own resource) and measures to address cash requirements.  It sets out the practical arrangements for the recognition of traditional own resources, the retention of supporting documents, administrative cooperation, the rate applicable to the own resource based on GNI, the accounting to be kept for own resources, the timing of availability and regularizations, and provisions relating to cash management and bad amounts.  It is a technical text that does not go back to the calculation of the amount of "clean resource" contributions but only to their method of collection.  I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for approval of the European Commission's proposal to amend Regulation 609/2014, known as "Clean Resource Decisions" which sets out the rules for the provision of own resources and measures to meet cash requirements. This report specifies the categories of own resources, their methods of calculation, as well as the methods of payment of Member States' contributions.  The report endorses the Commission's proposal while calling for more automation of Member States' contributions to the EU budget to avoid political negotiations. The report therefore considers the Commission's proposal to be appropriate to fill gaps in the current regulations if necessary in order to ensure that Member States make their contribution to the EU budget. This text aims to streamline annual adjustments to own resources based on VAT and GNI in order to simplify and reduce the budgetary burden on Member States and the EU budget and thus ensure the proper management and proper functioning of the payments sometimes essential for certain economic sectors, this proposal also perpetuates the current system of own resources of the EU.  So I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a Council Regulation amending Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 609/2014 on the methods and procedure for making traditional own resources and own resources based on VAT and GNI available and measures to meet the needs of the treasury adopted the Commission's proposal with the amendments made. The need to establish clear and effective rules on the timely availability of contributions to the Union budget by Member States, so that the European Commission can properly manage its treasury operations, is one of the points underlined in this report, a position i also share. I voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution and the Commission proposal as it is essential that timely financial contributions are made by Member States to facilitate the effective management of its treasury.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The functioning of the EU is based on a balanced budget financed by own resources, i.e. traditional own resources, VAT-based resources (maximum 50% of the GNI of each EM) and those based on gross national income. The amount of this budget is capped at 1.23% of the total gross national income of the Member States. When a state becomes a member of the EU, it commits to pay its annual contribution in proportion to its wealth. In the event of a disproportionate payment, the Member State can benefit from a correction as is currently the case for Germany, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Austria and Sweden.  The report that was voted on is purely technical and does not deal with the calculation of the amounts of Member States' contributions in terms of own resources. It proposes, among other things, a number of clarifications and improvements, mainly technical in nature, reflecting the experience gained, notably with regard to the accounting of own resources, the management of the Commission's cash resources, the evaluation of GNI data by the Commission (Eurostat), the impact of criminal investigations on the identification and provision of traditional own resources and the disclosure of the amounts of traditional own resources that are uncollectable.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With some reservation, I voted in favour of the report on methods for making available own resources and measures to meet cash requirements, which deals with the rules on making own resources available and the measures to meet cash requirements. The report contains arrangements in respect of the establishment of traditional own resources, conservation of supporting documents and administrative cooperation, and provisions concerning cash management and irrecoverable amounts.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to the Council an amendment to Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 609/2014 on methods and procedures for the provision of traditional own resources based on VAT and GNI and on measures to meet cash needs. The amendment aims to introduce effective rules to ensure that Member States make their contributions available to the EU budget in a timely manner. It provides, inter alia, an opportunity for the Commission to ask Member States to pay between three and twelfths of VAT and GNI-based resources in the first half of the year. In its report, the Committee on Budgets recommends that Parliament approve the Commission's draft with amendments. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the rapporteur's position that the provision and adjustment of Member States' contributions to the Union budget should not be the subject of political negotiation, but should be a technical process to meet cash requirements. I support the need to establish effective rules on the timely provision of contributions to the Union budget by Member States in order to enable the Commission to properly manage its treasury operations. It should be noted that most Member States are paying, without significant delay, the total amount of their GNI and VAT-based contributions to the Union budget. For the rapporteur's foregoing, this proposal deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Deprez report calls for approval of the Commission's proposal to amend Regulation 609/2014, known as 'Own Resource Decisions', which sets out rules for the provision of own resources and measures to meet cash requirements, which will come into force in early 2016.  However, annual adjustment procedures for own resources based on VAT and GNI will no longer be applicable after it comes into force. However, in order to reduce the risk of annual payment delays faced by the EU and Member States in recent years (for example, resulting in an unprecedented volume of adjustments at the end of 2014), it was agreed, in a Commission proposal, to revise this procedure.  If it is to rationalise annual adjustments to own resources to simplify and reduce the budgetary burden on Member States and the EU budget (especially at the end of the year) and thus to ensure the proper management and proper functioning of the payments sometimes essential for certain economic sectors, this proposal also perpetuates the current system of own resources of the EU. So I abstained.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as I consider the Commission proposal as appropriate to address the shortcomings of the current regulation with the aim of ensuring that Member States make their contributions to the EU budget in a timely manner and to avoid political disputes about the timing of payments.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the modalities and procedures for making traditional own resources available, the own VAT-based resource and the GNI-based own resource, and measures to address cash requirements. This text, which was adopted by a large majority in the Committee on Budgets, underlines the need for a reform of the own resources system, which is too complex and unseparable.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report, as I think it is very important that the resources of the EU budget are provided by clear and unambiguous rules and that payments from the EU budget are disbursed on time. I support the committee's aim of pushing the deadline for possible budgetary adjustments from 1 December to the end of the year, thereby facilitating the financing of adjustments applied by national treasuries. I also consider the ambition to further reform the own resources system to be a positive development.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that lays out rules on how Member States make their timely contributions to the European Union budget available, thus allowing the Commission to effectively manage its treasury.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The provision and adjustment of Member States' contributions to the Union budget should not be subject to political transactions, but should be a technical process. The proposed changes to the methods for adjusting contributions aim to avoid a repeat of the 2014 case. The report also highlights the need for efficient rules on how Member States make their contributions available in a timely manner to the Union budget in order to enable the Commission to manage its cash effectively.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The Regulation makes traditional, VAT-based and GNI-based own resources more accessible, which will encourage more efficient political management of the EU budget.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report.  In particular, it is essential to allow Member States, under certain conditions, to defer payments and to transfer revised amounts of VAT resources and additional resources in instalments.  In this context, it is necessary to lay down rules governing how Member States should submit their contributions to the Union budget in a timely manner in order to enable the Commission to manage its treasury effectively. The objective of each country is to ensure the macroeconomic stability and economic development of the country. In order to help national treasuries to manage the financing of possible adjustments more effectively, the deadline for transmission of data should be moved and the date of submission of the amounts should be adjusted. This would facilitate member states' effective public finance policies and ensure their economic and financial stability.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP will be voting against this report. There are certain positives in this report that relate to the fact that political (financial) bargaining should be refrained from regarding Member State contributions. There is a call to ensure that Member States pay 3/12th of GNI and VAT resources in the first half of the year to deal with the payment backlog of the previous year; this is directed towards the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and in particular the European Structural and Investment Funds. To boost the speed and efficiency of payments there is a strong point made to eliminate political interference. However, we do need this in order to question what is going on relating to GNI and VAT resources being submitted by Member States. The onus of management includes accounting procedures and practices indicating a uniformed approach to accounting and submitting of contributions. There is no way we can support such measures that take away the rights of our own British regulatory boards and financial ombudsman offices. There is also a call on the Commission to alter its proposal so that it fits in with Article 293(2) of the TFEU and Article 106(a) of the Euratom Treaty.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I reiterate my opinion on the need to implement common and effective rules that guarantee the timely payment of each Member State's contributions to the Union and I vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Complementing the existing financial business model by introducing the regulations proposed in this proposal raises the quality of the level and clarity of communication between the Commission and the Member States regarding the financial obligations of the two parties. It contains practical arrangements with regard to the establishment of own resources, the preservation of supporting documentation, administrative cooperation, the current system of calculating contributions based on GDP, accounts to be kept for own resources, time measurements for disposal and for making adjustments and provisions relating to cash management and non-collectable amounts.  I support any move that represents a new step towards establishing a quality and transparent management of the European Union's finances and the relationship between financial institutions and obligations to Member States. The introduction of this regulation will facilitate the Commission's cash operations and thus eliminates the possibility of illogicality in the relationship between the available funds and obligations that the Commission has through various programmes. In addition, this regulation gives greater predictability of the system for Member States that will know exactly when and what amount of money they should pay into the common vault.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for approval of the Commission's proposal to amend Regulation 609/2014, known as 'Own Resource Decisions', which sets out rules for the provision of own resources and measures to meet cash requirements and which will come into force in early 2016. However, annual adjustment procedures for own resources based on VAT and GNI will no longer be applicable after it comes into force. However, in order to reduce the risk of annual payment delays faced by the EU and Member States in recent years (for example, resulting in an unprecedented volume of adjustments at the end of 2014), it was agreed, in a Commission proposal, to revise this procedure. If it is to rationalise annual adjustments to own resources to simplify and reduce the budgetary burden on Member States and the EU budget (especially at the end of the year) and thus to ensure that the sometimes essential payments for certain economic sectors are managed properly and functioning, this proposal also perpetuates the current EU's own resource system, which I oppose. So I abstained.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support giving the Commission the right to seek a share of funds from Member States on the basis of VAT and GNI so that it can reduce fund payment delays from the previous year and reduce default interest. In this regard, it is necessary to ensure administrative cooperation, storage of necessary documents, applyable ratio for GNI, time needed for adjustments and management of financial resources, etc. This will significantly facilitate cooperation between the EU institutions and reduced opportunities for conflict to seek additional funds.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – I support The Report of Representatives Deprez and Lewandowski on the amendment of the Methods and Procedure Regulation for the provision of traditional own resources and own resources based on VAT and GNI and on measures to meet cash needs.  Regulation 609/2014 is a key instrument of the European Union setting out the main elements of the system, such as a list of own resources and ceilings on commitment and payment appropriations. Amending this Regulation will simplify and cheapen the operations of the European Union. This report proposes amendments such as the release of fees and interest on accounts opened by Member States in the Commission's name, until they need to be paid by the Commission.  Also, for specific payment purposes from the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), the European Union will be able to ask Member States to pre-post monthly twelfths of their VAT and GNI-based own resources up to two months in the first quarter of the year. Thanks to these amendments, the Commission will pay less negative interest and pay agencies more quickly.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the methods and procedures for providing own resources to the European Union budget, because I believe that effective rules are in place for the ways in which Member States make contributions to the common budget. Only proper contributions can ensure the effective implementation of Union policies that benefit half a billion citizens. I also supported the auctioning of late payments. I firmly believe that changing the methods used to adjust countries' contributions will prevent a repeat of the situation in 2014, when the method was recalculating to mean a jump in their contribution for some countries. This whole process was accompanied by irrational anti-European comments, which greatly and wrongly damaged the Union in the eyes of citizens. I also firmly believe that the European Commission will look at how individual Member States charge or refer to contributions to the European budget and will seek to achieve harmonisation and increased transparency in this regard. It is time for the system of own resources of the European Union budget to be reformed. The current one is too complex and inflexible. It is not possible for Member States whose contribution is based on their gross domestic income and which accounts for the largest part of the resources of the European budget, by their negative attitude, to block the proper implementation of programmes that clearly have European added value.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the amendment of Regulation (EU) No 609/2014 meets the European Union's cash needs. This is largely a technical regulation containing practical provisions on issues such as the establishment of traditional own resources, the retention of supporting documents, the applicable rate for the GDP-based own resource, the timing for making them available and for making adjustments and provisions on liquidity management and non-recoverable amounts. The idea of amending this regulation was born at the end of 2014 because of the exceptionally high amounts of VAT and GNI-based own resources adjustments in the case of some Member States. In order to enable the Commission to manage its treasury effectively, it is necessary to provide for effective rules to ensure that Member States make timely payments of their contributions to the Union budget and to prevent a similar incident from occurring again as in 2014. I also hope that the Commission will draw up recommendations in this regard in order to allow for a smoother comparison between the Member States, given that the way in which the Member States manage their national accounts, with regard to contributions to the Union's budget, are profoundly different.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I approved this report because we are calling for more transparency regarding the availability of own resources, including calculation methods. This is an important element in improving our regulatory tool.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Council Regulation is intended to amend Regulation No 609/2014. This regulation is part of the own resources legislative package, which will enter into force on 1 January 2016 and will apply retroactively from 1 January 2014. It contains technical provisions relating to the clearance of traditional own resources, the retention of supporting documents, administrative cooperation, the rate applicable to GNI-based own resources, the preparation of an own resources accounting and the timetable for making them available and the introduction of adjustments, as well as provisions on treasury management and uncollectable amounts. These rules will now be revised, which, among other adjustments - such as ensuring that own resources accounts are free from negative charges and interest and the possibility of anticipating monthly twelfths - aims to rationalise annual adjustments to VAT and GNI-based own resources, in the light of experience gained under the 2014 adjustments made under an amendment to Regulation No 1150/2000, which will now no longer apply at the time of the entry into force of Regulation No 609/2014. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP will be voting against this report. There are certain positives in this report that relate to the fact that political (financial) bargaining should be refrained from regarding Member State contributions. There is a call to ensure that Member States pay 3/12th of GNI and VAT resources in the first half of the year to deal with the payment backlog of the previous year; this is directed towards the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and in particular the European Structural and Investment Funds. To boost the speed and efficiency of payments there is a strong point made to eliminate political interference. However, we do need this in order to question what is going on relating to GNI and VAT resources being submitted by Member States. The onus of management includes accounting procedures and practices indicating a uniformed approach to accounting and submitting of contributions. There is no way we can support such measures that take away the rights of our own British regulatory boards and financial ombudsman offices. There is also a call on the Commission to alter its proposal so that it fits in with Article 293(2) of the TFEU and Article 106(a) of the Euratom Treaty.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which stresses the need for effective rules governing how Member States make their contribution to the EU budget on time in order to enable the Commission to effectively manage its cash flow. The report also supports the Commission's ability to ask Member States to pay a third twelfth of VAT and GNI-based resources in the first half of the year, in order to enable the Commission to further reduce the payment delays of the previous year linked to the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the European Structural and Investment Funds , as well as late interest. The adopted text also stresses the importance of the amounts due to the beneficiaries of the EU budget being paid on time.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council regulation amending the Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 609/2014 on the modalities and procedure for making available traditional own resources and VAT and GNI-based own resources, as well as measures to meet cash requirements, as it provides for effective rules ensuring timely payment by Member States of their contributions to the Union budget and making any late payment more costly.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I vote in favour of this dossier. In the context that several countries have not contributed to the EU budget (UK) or have rebates (up to 12 cases), the dossier urges payment in a timely manner to avoid added costs of arrears in regular payments, seeking to isolate from political debates (Brexit?) an agreement to contribute the own resources of which the European budget is endowed with a harmonised and formally appropriate procedure. Ultimately, it is a call of attention, without naming it, to the informal contribution of certain countries, precisely at a time when the budget is also seen as an insufficient resource to meet the Union's challenges.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Regulation regulates the EU's own resources, in particular VAT and GDP contributions. The aim of the amendments to the Regulation is to avoid haggling in this area which must be transparent. This review aims to ensure that Member States continue to contribute their contributions without delay, clarifying the rules on interests and other technical issues, for the sake of transparency and accuracy. That's why I voted for it.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in nation states’ tax policies so I voted against this proposal.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which comes as a response to the UK Government requests for the changes outlined in this report. After intense discussion within the Council, it would be great to see the Commission’s aims of avoiding any problematic situations linked to the technical recalculations of the methods and procedures which make available the traditional, Value-Added-Tax and Gross-National-Income-based own-resources.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft LEGISLATIVE RESOLUTION of the EP on the proposal for a Council Regulation No 609/2014 on methods and progressively making available traditional own resources and vat and GNI-based own resources and on measures to ensure cash requirements. The proposal stresses the need for effective rules for the timely provision of Member States' contributions to the Union budget so that the Commission can effectively manage its cash register. It also supports the possibility granted to the Commission to ask Member States to pay a third twelfth of the VAT and GNI-based resources in the first half of the year, so that the Commission can reduce most of the outstanding payments for the previous year in the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the European Structural and Investment Funds and reduce default interest.  Adjustments to contributions should be dealt with as effectively as possible in order to avoid political interference in the agreed ways of financing the Union budget and to limit the possibility for Member States to decide on the deadlines for additional contributions resulting from GNI adjustments to the Union budget to a minimum.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this proposal as it leads to more efficient management of the Commission's budget and treasury.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report because the proposed amendments to the contribution adjustment methods are aimed at avoiding a similar problem as occurred in 2014. In the past, all Member States generally paid the full amount of their GNI and VAT contributions to the Union budget without further delay, despite the crisis and significant fiscal pressure. It is important to have effective rules on the timely payment of Member States' contributions to the Union budget so that the Commission can effectively manage its Treasury.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which addresses the shortcomings of the current regulation in place. The proposal on the ‘methods and procedures for making available the traditional, VAT and GNI-based own resources and on the measures to meet cash requirements’ aims to ensure Member States make their contributions to the EU budget in a timely manner and to avoid political disputes about the timing of payments.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ At the beginning of 2016, the Council Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom, will enter into force. On the same day, the Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No. 609/2014, relating to the rules on making own resources available and measures to meet cash needs. Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 2020/2013 609/2014 should be revised in line with the experience gained during the subsequent adjustment for 2014.  An amendment to the article intended to encourage timely payment by raising the cost of late payments has been proposed, but also to ensure proportionality by limiting the maximum possible interest rate increase to 20 percentage points. A report should be submitted to Parliament each year containing calculations for the adjustment of the VAT and GNI balances, the data on which those calculations are based, as well as the dates and amounts of payment of Member States' contributions to the Union budget. I support the Council's position, as I believe that the proposed amendments to the methods for harmonising contributions will avoid problems that occurred in 2014 and lead to greater transparency.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal. While I welcome a substantial part of the Commission's proposal, I reject the modified proposal tabled in the European Parliament, as this initially technical proposal has been significantly politicised.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council regulation amending the Regulation on the methods and procedures for making traditional own resources and VAT and GNI-based own resources available and measures to provide cash. The updated existing financial operating model by introducing the rules proposed in this proposal raises the level of quality and clarity of communication between the European Commission and the Member States in terms of the financial obligations of both parties. The report also contains practical arrangements for setting own resources and stresses the need to ensure payments to beneficiaries from the Union budget in a timely manner.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Own resources enable Brussels to self-finance, thus distancing itself from the Member States, and gaining financial autonomy. This autonomy has always been something that we have criticised as allowing Brussels to bypass the interests of the Member States and impose neoliberal economic policies on them. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The existing procedure for the reimbursement of traditional own resources and own resources based on VAT and GNI of the Member States, despite the effort to amend it, remains too complex and needs to be reformed from the outset in order to meet the current requirements of the union's critical situation.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The legislation currently in force relating to Council Decision 2007/436/EC, Euratom had to be revised at the end of 2014 due to the particularly high VAT and GNI adjustments found for each Member State. At the same time, Treaty 609/2014/EU, Euratom should be revised in the light of the experience of the 2014 adjustments. The European Parliament underlines the need for effective rules on the way in which Member States make their contributions available to the EU budget in a timely manner, as this will be when the Commission will be able to manage its coffers effectively. Parliament supports the possibility for the Commission to ask Member States to pay three to twelfths of VAT and GNI-based resources in the first half of the year, in order to enable the Commission to reduce a significant part of the previous year's payment arrears at the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the European Structural and Investment Funds and to reduce interest on late payment. The purpose of amending the methods for adjusting contributions is to avoid cases such as those of 2014.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree with the stated aim of making the system of making member states' budget contributions more efficient, thereby helping the Commission to manage its coffers better.  I consider it effective that the Commission will now be able to ask Member States to pay three to twelfths of VAT and GNI-based resources in the first half of the year in order to reduce the arrears of payments for some European funds in the previous year. It is of the utmost importance that both payments and payments to beneficiaries of the EU budget are made in a timely and effective manner.  I also agreed with the point that political interference in the agreed ways of financing the EU budget must be avoided. In addition, I supported the commission's request to examine and make recommendations for greater coherence in the national accounting of Member States' contributions to the EU budget.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Like its title, this report deals with the rules on making own resources available and the measures to meet cash requirements.  It contains practical arrangements in respect of the establishment of traditional own resources, such as the period for Member States to be making the payments, the applicable rate for the GNI-based own resource, the accounts to be kept for own resources, and provisions concerning cash management and irrecoverable amounts.  By modifying the rules, the Commission aims to avoid problematic situation linked to technical recalculations of the contributions to the European Union’s budget. Given the complexity of the European Union’s own resources system, setting in place more efficient rules on how Member States make their timely contributions to the European Union budget available is essential to allow the Commission to effectively manage its treasury. This report, which also highlights the curtail work of the High Level Group on Own Resources in delivering proposals for overcoming the deficiencies of the current system, will help us in making the own resources system more transparent and more efficient.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Deprez proposal. Let us stress the need for effective rules governing how Member States make their contribution to the EU budget on time in order to enable the Commission to effectively manage its cash flow. Parliament supports the Commission's ability to ask Member States to pay a third twelfth of VAT and GNI-based resources in the first half of the year, in order to enable the Commission to further reduce the payment delays of the previous year linked to the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the European Structural and Investment Funds as well as late interest.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 609/2014 on the methods and procedure for making available the traditional, VAT and GNI-based own resources and on the measures to meet cash requirements. According to it, the Commission should be able to ask Member States for the payment of 3/12th of VAT and GNI resources in the first half of the year, so that it can reduce a more important part of the previous year’s payment backlog in the European Agriculture Guarantee Fund (EAGF) and in the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF), and to reduce default interest. Among other things, the amendment aims at increasing the incentives for the Member States to pay on time by making more expensive any late payment. It however respects proportionality, by capping the maximum increase of the interest rate at 20 percentage points.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. On 12 June 2015, Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer programming' following redundancies in the regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusima, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois in the Regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusima, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois. Further information was added in accordance with Article 8(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013. The application shall comply with the requirements laid down in Article 13 of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 for the determination of the financial contribution from the EGF. The European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of a financial contribution of EUR 2 623 200 to be granted on the basis of an application submitted by Finland. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ In September this year, the Commission proposed to amend the legislative package on own resources agreed in May 2014. The amendments go towards allowing Member States a sufficient period of time where adjustments in their VAT and GDP are in contributions they pay into the European Union budget more than expected. I support this Commission proposal because I agree with the amendments that give Member States more time to thoroughly examine the relevant financial data before they make the payment. The Commission's task in this case is to inform member states in January of the payment they are required to make in July.  As this proposal of the Commission concerns only amendments to its own resources, the Council is only just consulting Parliament before making a final decision. However, Parliament is once again trampling over its powers and, in a purely procedural report, calls for fundamental reform of the system of own resources and for the creation of a very confusing system regarding the punishment of late payments. So I voted no.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the ways and procedures for making traditional VAT and GNI-based own resources available and the measures to provide cash. The Council Regulation on the means and procedures for making available the own resources provided by the Member States is part of a new legislative package on own resources, which will enter into force in early 2016.  This is largely a technical regulation. There are several reasons for this revision, and in particular the new procedure for annual VAT adjustment should also be considered in this Regulation. The aim of the act is to increase transparency and to improve Parliament's access to information.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I vote in favour of this dossier. In the context that several countries have not contributed to the EU budget (UK) or have rebates (up to 12 cases), the dossier urges payment in a timely manner to avoid added costs of arrears in regular payments, seeking to isolate from political debates (Brexit?) an agreement to contribute the own resources of which the European budget is endowed with a harmonised and formally appropriate procedure. Ultimately, it is a call of attention, without naming it, to the informal contribution of certain countries, precisely at a time when the budget is also seen as an insufficient resource to meet the Union's challenges.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal supports the possibility for the Commission to ask Member States to pay three to twelfths of VAT and GNI-based resources in the first half of the year, in order to enable the Commission to reduce a significant part of the previous year's payment arrears at the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund and the European Structural and Investment Funds and to reduce interest on late payment. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I vote in favour of this dossier. In the context that several countries have not contributed to the EU budget (UK) or have rebates (up to 12 cases), the dossier urges payment in a timely manner to avoid added costs of arrears in regular payments, seeking to isolate from political debates (Brexit?) an agreement to contribute the own resources of which the European budget is endowed with a harmonised and formally appropriate procedure. Ultimately, it is a call of attention, without naming it, to the informal contribution of certain countries, precisely at a time when the budget is also seen as an insufficient resource to meet the Union's challenges.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important to recognise this topic and acknowledge that the provision and adjustment of Member States’ contributions to the European Union budget should not be subject to political bargaining but should be a technical process to meet cash requirements. There is also a need for efficient rules on how Member States make their timely contributions to the European Union budget available, to allow the Commission to effectively manage its treasury. I also support the Commission proposal that, in order to prevent any losses for the European Union budget, each Member State ensures that the amounts it has credited to the own resources account is not reduced by any negative interest or other charges for the time it has to remain in the account.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a technical issue in which Parliament has decided to avoid entering into a political debate, adopting an amendment to improve transparency in access to information calculations and considering appropriate the rest of the text proposed by the Commission. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 This report deals with the provision of traditional own resources, VAT and GNI resources and measures to meet the need for cash. The European Commission wants to avoid any problems caused by technical recalculations. I therefore voted in favour of this report because it is intended to prevent internal frictions.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report speeds up the implementation of resources and proposes that the annual calculation of Member States' contributions to the EU budget should be delivered not only to the Member States but also to the European Parliament. We believe that a fair own resources system must be in line with the relative wealth of each country (from its GNI), so that the effort in the budget contribution is similar for all citizens of the different EU Member States, and there are still exceptions for some countries in calculating their contribution.  The Community budget should then have a redistributive role and should take real convergence and the promotion of economic and social cohesion as a priority, and therefore the own resources limit should be increased.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. BNP and VAT-based revenues are based on a mechanism that is too complex, costly and non-transparent. Simplification, as proposed here, is to be welcomed, as it minimises costs and also makes it easier for member states to understand what money is going where. However, the report provides for a third twelfth of VAT revenue to be paid to the Commission in order to bridge the arrears and to reduce the Member States' room for manoeuvre in the period of payments. I therefore reject this report.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is mainly financed by contributions from the Member States. It is important that these contributions are made to the Union budget on time, because only in this way can the Commission, as executive agency, balance its obligations under the approved budget. However, late payments from previous years have caused a build-up of outstanding payments in some funds. In addition to the problems caused by this delay to the beneficiaries of payments, the pressure on EU resources has also increased due to interest on late payments. The approved regulation should address this problem and, at the same time, create the conditions so that, in future, Member States have an incentive to pay their contributions on time.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to the amendment to the Regulation setting out the rules by which Member States make their own resources available to the Commission for the Budget of the European Union, particularly those based on VAT and GNI. The proposed amendments are to speed up and make resources available in a timely manner, after what happened during 2014 when the adjustments for 1995-2013 were very high. The proposed amendments also clarify interest rates and other more technical aspects, as well as increase transparency and accuracy by reporting adjustments, timely and regularly, to their calculation process and VAT/GNI data.  We believe that a fair own resources system must be in line with the relative wealth of each country (from its GNI), moving towards the effort in the budget contribution being similar for all citizens of the different EU Member States, and there are still exceptions for some countries in calculating their contribution. The Community budget should then have a redistributive role and should take real convergence and the promotion of economic and social cohesion as a priority, and therefore the own resources limit should be increased.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which withdraws the parliamentary immunity of Greek MEP Georgios Kyrtsos so that he can deal with the accusations made about him first and foremost, since these have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court has requested the lifting of Georgios Kyrtsos' immunity in connection with a possible legal action relating to an alleged offence. It is believed to be a complaint by the East Attica labour inspectorate for failing to pay part of the salary in 2013 of a former employee of two media companies run at the time by Georgios Kyrtsos. The alleged offence is apparently unrelated to Georgios Kyrtsos' MEP duties. The act of prosecution does not concern an opinion or vote cast by him in the performance of his MEP duties within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on EU privileges and immunities.  Therefore, it cannot be inferred that the underlying intent of the criminal proceedings is to interfere with the political activity of the Member, in particular because the act of prosecution dates back several years before taking up parliamentary office. So I voted for it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This was not a roll-call vote.  In the interests of democracy I wish to make it clear that I voted to waive the Parliamentary immunity of Mr Kyrtsos, for the reasons broadly explained in the report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of this Greek EPP MEMBER who is accused of not paying an employee before his election to the European Parliament in May 2014.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In the near-unanimous opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I have approved the lifting of parliamentary immunity requested by the Greek justice system with regard to Mr Kyrstos, which relates to a matter prior to his presence in the European Parliament.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this pleading for suspension of immunity. Our position is to abstain when we understand that there are signs of political persecution or the facts are not very clear. The functioning of the pleadings is concrete and requires a very determined case study. In this case, the data was clear and allowed a position of ours in favor.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to support this report, which dealt with the European Parliament's decision on the request to lift the immunity of Georgios Kyrstos, a Greek MEP. Mr Kyrstos is being sued following a complaint by the Eastern Attica Labour Inspectorate for non-payment of wages. According to the indictment, part of the 2013 salary of a former employee with two media companies of which Georgios Kyrstos was the manager at the time, was not paid. The latter has also waived his right to be heard. As can be seen, this alleged offence appears to have no connection to Mr Kyrstos' parliamentary duties in the European Parliament, but rather relates to his previous management duties of two media companies. In this case, Mr Kyrstos is neither prosecuted for an opinion issued, a vote or a political opinion within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on EU privileges and immunities. The criminal procedure does not seem to depend on a desire to harm the political activity of this Member (fumus persecutionis) and that is why I am in favour of the lifting of his immunity.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I took part in the vote on the Regner report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of The Immunity of Mr Georgios Kyrtsos since, after studying the high request by the Prosecutor's Office of the Supreme Court of Greece, the Committee on Legal Affairs has found that Georgios Kyrtsos is accused of not paying part of the salary of a former employee, an offence which has no relation to the position of Member of the European Parliament and there is no reason to suspect that the criminal proceedings are intended to harm the political activity of the deputy (fumus persecutionis), since the prosecution began several years before the deputy took possession of his seat.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has led Parliament to waive the immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos, a Greek Member of the European Parliament. Georgios Kyrtsos is accused of failing to pay part of the salary to one of her former employees before twitch a Member of the European Parliament and as head of two newspaper companies. The decision to waive immunity was taken by the European Parliament on the basis that there were no grounds for suspecting that criminal proceedings had been brought with the aim of undermining a Member's political activity, since prosecution proceedings had been initiated several years before the Member took up his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Georgios Kyrtsos is accused of failing to pay part of his former employee's salary when he was the manager of two media companies in 2013. This is a complaint from the Labour Inspectorate of Eastern Attica and it is the Greek Supreme Court that is behind the request to waive its parliamentary immunity. This alleged offence is unrelated to his mandate as an MEP since it was obviously committed when he was the manager of his company, that is, several years before he took office in the European Parliament. The act of prosecution therefore does not concern an opinion he expressed in the course of his parliamentary activity. Therefore, the intention of this procedure is not to interfere with its political activity. So I voted to lift his parliamentary immunity.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Revocation is requested on charges of non-payment by the MP as manager against a former employee. There does not appear to be any grounds for immunity under the Rules of Procedure.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos. Georgios Kyrtsos who is a Greek PPE MEP has been accused of non-payment of wages of one of his former employees. However, as the request relates to a time before he was an MEP and as there is no accusation of political prosecution and the normal waiver procedures have been applied, then I voted in favour of this procedure.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Georgios Kyrtsos is accused of failing to pay part of his salary by a former employee of the newspaper of which he was editor. The alleged offence does not in any way concern parliamentary activity and clearly has nothing to do with parliamentary activity and, moreover, Mr Syp he said that it was not a question of whether or not we should be able to do something about it. Kyrtsos has stated that he does not wish to avail himself of parliamentary immunity. I therefore voted in favour of the request for waiver of immunity.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the request for the waiver of my colleague's immunity.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The proposal to waive the immunity of Giorgos Kyrtsos concerns prosecutions brought against the MEP on issues that had arisen in the past and which are not related to his views or activities in the European Parliament. As the MEP himself considers that the accusations against him have no substance and since the procedure must proceed smoothly, I voted in favour of the waiver of immunity.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request to waive the immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos. The text under discussion sets out the EP's reasons for the request to waive the immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos. On 21 July 2015, the President announced in accordance with Rule 9(1) of the Rules of Procedure that he had received a letter from the Public Prosecutor's Office at the Supreme Court of Greece requesting the waiver of georgios Kyrtsos' parliamentary immunity. Having examined the documents, the committee decided to submit to the EP the decision to waive immunity, considering that the allegations clearly have no relation to the office of Member of the European Parliament, but relate to his previous position as manager of two newspaper publishers. Georgios Kyrtsos is accused of not paying part of the salary of one of his former employees of the newspaper publishing companies of which he was manager. Furthermore, there is no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the request to waive georgios Kyrtos' immunity as the unlawful actions were carried out before his candidacy.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – Parliamentary immunity is not a Member’s personal privilege but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament as a whole and of its Members. The case in question does not have a direct and obvious connection with the Member’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7. I thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The competent Greek authorities have requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos. The latter was in fact charged, and subject to criminal proceedings before the District Court in Athens, for failure to pay part of his salary to one of his former employees. Every citizen must be equal before the law, and I believe that every Member of Parliament is first and most of all a citizen, who has an obligation to appear before the law of his own State without any immunity. That is why I am voting in favour of the report.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which withdraws the parliamentary immunity of Greek MEP Georgios Kyrtsos so that he can deal with the accusations made about him first and foremost, since these have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The public prosecutor's office of the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic has requested the lifting of Georgios Kyrtsos' immunity. He had not paid two employees when, before his term as an MP, he was the leader of a press group. This offence predates his taking office. Moreover, it does not concern an opinion or vote cast by him in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. I voted in favour of respecting the proper functioning of justice when an inquiry is opened and does not undermine a parliamentarian's freedom of expression.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The committee responsible has, at the request of the Greek authorities, dealt with the waiver of immunity in accordance with Articles 6 and 7 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, and subsequently submitted a request for waiver of the immunity of the Member. Following a court decision by the Supreme Court of the Member State and following the committee's preparation of the case, I consider it appropriate to vote in accordance with the committee's request for waiver of immunity. I regularly vote in accordance with the committee responsible in immunity procedures, where it is reasonable and in accordance with the Rules of Procedure that cases be referred to the national judiciary unless there are political motives.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is not linked to an activity specific to the European Parliament.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report under consideration concerns the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos, which the Public Prosecutor's Office has requested from the Supreme Court of Greece, as part of a possible legal action relating to an alleged offence. The deputy is accused of not paying part of the salary of a former worker. The indictment concerns the 2013 salary portion of a former worker at two newspaper editing companies, of which Georgios Kyrtsos was manager at the time. Bearing in mind that the alleged infringement has nothing to do with georgios Kyrtsos' term of office as a Member of the European Parliament, but is related to his previous position as manager of two newspaper editing companies; whereas the judicial procedure does not concern opinions or votes expressed in the exercise of the mandate of the Member (concerned for the purposes of Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union) and that there is no reason to suspect that the intention behind the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis), since the process began a few years before the Member began his term of office , we voted in favour of the lifting of georgios kyrtsos' parliamentary immunity.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as there is no ground for discrimination or political persecution.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice. That is why I am voting in favour of the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The accusation relates to part of the 2013 salary of a former employee of two newspaper publishing firms, of which Georgios Kyrtsos was the manager at the time, and is directed at Georgios Kyrtsos as the former manager of those firms. Considering that the alleged offence clearly has nothing to do with the office of Georgios Kyrtsos as a Member of the European Parliament but is rather connected to his former position as manager of two newspaper firms, I supported the decision to waive the immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report regarding the waiving of immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos, given the alleged offence (non-payment of part of the salary of a former employee) is unrelated to the office of Mr Kyrtsos as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this immunity suspension plea. Our position is to abstain when we understand that there are signs of political persecution or the facts are not very clear. The functioning of the pleadings is concrete and requires a very determined case study. In this case, the data was clear and allowed a position of ours in favor.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Greek constitution stipulates that members of parliament may not be arrested, imprisoned or otherwise confined during their parliamentary term. This vote was to waiver this immunity and have the Member, Georgios Kyrtsos, take part in criminal proceedings. Given that the prosecution was initiated a number of years before the Member took his post, I have no reason to believe that these proceedings intend to undermine Georgios’s character.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos was decided by the fact that it is our duty to remove any obstacles to the investigation and to clear the path for the right and just decision to be made.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report regarding the waving of immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos who is accused of non-payment of part of the salary of one of his former employees. The accusation relates to part of the 2013 salary of a former employee of two newspaper publishing firms, of which Georgios Kyrtsos was the manager at the time, and is directed at Georgios Kyrtsos as the former manager of those firms. The alleged offence clearly has nothing to do with the office of Georgios Kyrtsos as a Member of the European Parliament but is rather connected to his former position as manager of two newspaper firms.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report according to the position adopted by my political group.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Georgios Kyrtsos' immunity because the alleged offence in question was committed while Mr Kyrtsos was the director of two journalistic companies, and is also unrelated to his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.  I believe that the veracity of this charge of not paying part of the salary to one employee will be best resolved with the competent institutions for the benefit of both parties. It is also important to add that Mr. Kyrtsos has waived his right to be heard.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Evelyn Regner's report on Georgios Kyrtsos' request for the lifting of parliamentary immunity. This procedure is a formality which, without deciding on the merits of the case, is intended to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The alleged offence appears to be unrelated to Georgios Kyrtsos' position as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather to his previous role as manager of two newspaper publishers. There is therefore no reason to believe that the underlying criminal proceedings are based on the intention to affect the political activity of the Member. That is why I am voting in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons of the proposal to waive the immunity.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Georgios Kyrtsos' parliamentary immunity. This colleague is accused of non-payment of part of the salary of one of his former employees. The charge therefore targets Mr Kyrtsos as a former business manager and not as an MEP. There is no reason to believe that the underlying intent of the criminal proceedings is to interfere with his political activity, since the act of prosecution dates back several years before he took office as a Member of Parliament.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted to waive this parliamentary immunity because the alleged offences (non-payment of an employee before the election of the MP) have nothing to do with the mandate.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The accused member dates back to before his mandate was created and it is therefore up to the Greek courts to decide his possible guilt or innocence.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Georgios Kyrtsos is a Greek member of the European People's Party and vice-president of the Delegation for Relations with the NATO Parliamentary Assembly and a member of the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee and the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect. The Public Prosecutor's Office of the Greek Supreme Court has requested the waiver of the Kyrtsos mp's immunity for the purpose of possibly bringing charges for an alleged crime for not paying part of the salary of one of the former employees while he was head of two newspaper publishing companies. I supported the request to lift the immunity of Mep Georgios Kyrtsos, as the alleged offence is not linked to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This request for waiver of members' immunity is based on a complaint by the Eastern Labour Inspectorate, from which it is apparent that Mr Kirtsos did not pay the full salary of an employee from his publishing houses in Greece in 2013. Obtaining a salary for the work done is one of the fundamental rights of any employee, so the waiver of the member's immunity was a stubborn justification. However, the only body that could resolve the nature and the real truth of this complaint, leading to a final conclusion and a verdict, is a court. The most important thing is to triumph right, and our work is to promote it.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos, following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to waive the immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos as the alleged offence clearly has nothing to do with the office of Georgios Kyrtsos as a Member of the European Parliament but is rather connected to his former position as manager of two newspaper firms.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this waiver of immunity. Georgios Kyrtsos is being prosecuted in Greece for an alleged offence dating back to 2013: he is accused by a former employee of not paying him part of his salary. This complaint dates back to before the beginning of Mr Kyrtsos' term and clearly has nothing to do with his mandate as an MEP. We have no evidence that the purpose of this complaint is to interfere with his work as a Member of Parliament, so we support his lifting of immunity.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has adopted a decision waiving the immunity of Mr Syod/80. Mr Kyrtsos, whom I support by voting in favour of Mr Regner's report. It must be borne in mind that there is no reason to assume that the underlying intention of the procedure is to prejudice the political activity of the Member, since the latter was initiated a few years before the beginning of the Member's term of office.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The alleged offence appears to be unrelated to Georgios Kyrtsos' position as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather to his previous role as manager of two newspaper publishers. There is therefore no reason to believe that the underlying criminal proceedings are based on the intention to affect the political activity of the Member. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report concerns the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of the Greek MEP, Georgios Kyrtsos. He is accused of failing to pay part of the salary of one of his former employees to two media companies, of which he was the manager at the time. Given that the facts date back to 2013, that is, a time when Georgios Kyrtsos was not an MEP, and so that labour law can be applied. I vote for the lifting of immunity

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court has requested the lifting of Georgios Kyrtsos' immunity in connection with a possible legal action relating to an alleged offence. It is believed to be a complaint by the Eastern Attica Labour Inspectorate for non-payment of part of the 2013 salary of a former employee of two media companies run at the time by Georgios Kyrtsos. The alleged offence is apparently unrelated to Georgios Kyrtsos' MEP duties. The act of prosecution does not concern an opinion or vote cast by him in the performance of his MEP duties within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on EU privileges and immunities.  Therefore, it cannot be inferred that the underlying intent of the criminal proceedings is to interfere with the political activity of the Member, in particular because the act of prosecution dates back several years before taking up parliamentary office. I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the corresponding articles of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Prosecutor's Office of the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic has requested the waiver of the immunity of MEP Georgios Kyrtsos in connection with possible legal action in connection with an alleged crime. According to the inquiry, the MP is accused of failing to pay part of the wages of one of their employees to the two newspaper publishing companies he once ran. As the Committee on Legal Affairs points out in its report, the offence allegedly committed is not related to georgios kyrtsos's mandate as a Member of the European Parliament, but to his previous activities as the head of two newspaper publishing companies, and there is no reason to believe that the criminal proceedings were initiated with a view to causing political damage to the Member, since it started several years before he became a Member, and therefore proposes to Parliament that Georgios Kyrtsos' immunity be suspended. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, after all the legal procedures required have elapsed, because the offence in question is not in any way related to the performance of the duties of a Member and that there is no evidence or suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, the intention to harm the Member concerned is politically impaired.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Following a complaint from the Greek labour inspectorate, the Supreme Court Prosecutor's Office requested the lifting of the immunity of MEP Georgios Kyrtsos. The latter is being prosecuted for failing to pay part of the 2013 salary of a former employee of press companies whose MEP was the manager. Since this alleged offence is unrelated to his duties as an MEP, that it occurred before he took office, and that, on the other hand, it is not politically motivated prosecutions, the Member cannot claim his immunity. So I decided to vote in favour of lifting immunity.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting georgios Kyrtsos' parliamentary immunity. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report according to the evaluation made by the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI).

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
