text: Writing. I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos. There was a complaint from the East Attica Labour Inspectorate for non-payment of wages. In this context, there may be a possible charge of an alleged offence.

name: n/a
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and i agree with what is called for in the report. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Following a complaint from the Greek labour inspectorate, the Supreme Court Prosecutor's Office requested the lifting of the immunity of MEP Georgios Kyrtsos. The latter is being prosecuted for failing to pay part of the 2013 salary of a former employee of a press company whose MEP was the manager. Since this alleged offence is unrelated to his duties as an MEP, that it occurred before he took office and that, moreover, these are not politically motivated prosecutions, I have decided to vote in favour of the lifting of immunity.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation to lift the immunity of my colleague Georgios Kyrtsos because, although prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or to vote in the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the European Union, he or she is not involved in the decision to revoke the immunity of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the alleged offence is clearly not in any relation to the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament, but concerns his or her function in two newspaper publishing companies to which he was headed at the time, there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis) , because it was launched before Mr. Kyrtsos became an MEP.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Mep Georgios Kyrtsos. I believe that the Greek Attorney-General should be allowed to carry out the appropriate investigations in order to determine whether or not there may be a charge of non-payment of part of the salary, relating to 2013, against a former employee of two newspaper publishing companies, of which Georgios Kyrtsos was the manager at the time. In any case, I would like to stress that my vote in favour of such a revocation does not involve a judgment as to the guilt or innocence of the Member.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In view of the circumstances and the facts alleged against this parliamentarian and which could not establish the existence of a fumus persecutionis in the context of the proceedings against him, the JURI Committee unanimously wished to recommend to the plenary that its parliamentary immunity be lifted. So I followed that advice.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 21 July 2015, the Public Prosecutor's Office before the Supreme Court of Greece requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos in the context of a legal action, in which the Member of the European Parliament is accused of not paying part of the salary of a former employee. Under Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. According to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, Article 8 of the Protocol does not apply in this case, since the alleged infringement has nothing to do with the mandate of Georgios Kyrtsos as an MEP, but is related to his previous position as manager of two newspaper editing companies. Accordingly, and on the basis of the JURI Committee report, I voted in favour of this Decision on the waiver of Georgios Kyrtsos' immunity.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a question of Greek internal justice, unrelated to Georgios Kyrtsos' membership.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr. Georgios Kyrtsos, so that the Hellenic justice can carry out his work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the alleged facts - non-payment of part of the salary of one of his former employees - are not related to the office of Deputy of Mr. Kyrtsos, because they are linked to his previous role as manager of press companies and are not motivated by the will to harm mp's political action.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to the request for waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos, which follows a request by the Public Prosecutor's Office to the Supreme Court of Greece, concerning a court case where the Deputy is accused of not paying part of the salary to a former employee of his in 2013, when he was manager of two newspaper editing companies , where she worked. In fact, this is an alleged infringement which is not directly related to Georgios Kyrtsos' warrant in the European Parliament and there are no well-founded and legitimate reasons to suspect that the legal action in question is intended to undermine the Political Activity of the Member, the conditions for the waiver of parliamentary immunity are gathered and, for that reason, I voted in favour of this request.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this pleading for suspension of immunity. Our position is to abstain when we understand that there are signs of political persecution or the facts are not very clear. The functioning of the pleadings is concrete and requires a very determined case study. In this case, the data was clear and allowed a position of ours in favor.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which withdraws the parliamentary immunity of Greek MEP Georgios Kyrtsos so that he can deal with the accusations made about him first and foremost, since these have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as I do not believe he should keep his immunity.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Greek constitution stipulates that members of parliament may not be arrested, imprisoned or otherwise confined during their parliamentary term. This vote was to waiver this immunity and have the Member, Georgios Kyrtsos, take part in criminal proceedings. Given that the prosecution was initiated a number of years before the Member took his post, I have no reason to believe that these proceedings intend to undermine Georgios’s character.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution granting the request to the Public Prosecutor's Office at the Supreme Court of Greece to waive the immunity of MEP Georgios Kyrtsos in connection with a possible action in relation to an alleged crime. An MEP is accused of not paying part of his salary to one of his former employees. MePs, within the meaning of Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the privileges and immunities of the EU, shall enjoy within the territory of their own State the immunities granted to members of the Parliament of that State. Since Article 62 of the Constitution of the Hellenic Republic provides that Members of Parliament may not be prosecuted, arrested, imprisoned or otherwise restricted during their term of office without the prior authorisation of parliament, it was necessary to waive the parliamentary immunity of a colleague so that law enforcement authorities would thoroughly investigate whether MEP Georgios Kyrtsos was guilty of the alleged offence of non-payment of a salary to a former employee.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported georgios Kyrtsos' request to lift his immunity, which was forwarded by the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Greek Supreme Court on 21 July 2015 in connection with a complaint by the East Attic Labour Inspectorate for non-payment of wages, and which was published at a plenary session on 9 September 2015. The Prosecutor's Office of the Greek Supreme Court has requested the lifting of the immunity of MEP Georgios Kyrtsos in connection with a possible lawsuit for an alleged crime apparently had nothing to do with Georgios Kyrtsos' position as an MEP, but was primarily linked to his former position as director of two news companies.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Committee on Legal Affairs adopted Evelyn Regner's report and unanimously recommended that the European Parliament lift georgios Kyrtsos's (EPP, EL) immunity. The prosecutor's office at the Greek Supreme Court has requested the waiver of the immunity of Mr. Kyrtsos, a member of the European Parliament, in connection with possible legal action related to the alleged crime. The charge against Kyrtsos relates to the non-payment of part of his salary for 2013 to a former employee of two journalism publishing houses, of which Georgios Kyrtsos was manager at the time.  Noting that the alleged infringement has nothing to do with Georgios Kyrtsos' office as a member of the European Parliament, but is linked to his former position as manager of two journalists' houses, the members consider that the prosecution does not concern the expressed views or votes in the performance of the duties of a member of the European Parliament in matters relating to the purposes of Article 8(1) TSR. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union.  In light of these considerations, I support the Recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs that Parliament lift Georgios Kyrtsos' immunity in order to determine whether he has committed the offence of which he is charged, and since the Committee found that there is no reason to suspect that the intention of the criminal proceedings is to damage the activity (fumus persecutionis) of a Member State, since the prosecution was initiated a number of years before the Member State took office.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given that georgios Kyrtsos' act under investigation should have occurred before he took office as a Member of the European Parliament, and therefore there is no clear link with the exercise of his mandate, I supported the proposal.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted to lift this parliamentarian's immunity so that he could defend himself in the courts of his country

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Mr Georgios Kyrtsos, a Greek MEP who is a member of the Group of the European People’s Party. The waiver was requested by the Prosecutor’s Office at the Supreme Court of Greece, in connection with possible legal action concerning an alleged offence. The accusation relates to the time when Mr Kyrtsos worked as a manager of two newspaper publishing firms and he allegedly failed to pay part of the 2013 salary to his former employee.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 A MEMBER of the European Parliament, Mr Georgios Kyrtsos, has been charged by his former employee who claims that the MEP did not pay him a portion of the salary to which he was entitled. The charge relates to a portion of the 2013 salary at two newspaper printing companies in which Representative Kyrtsos was a director during that period. Since the alleged event took place at a time when Kyrtsos had not yet started to serve his parliamentary term in the European Parliament, and that the event was not correlated with his or her performance of his parliamentary duties in the European Parliament, I voted in accordance with the decision of the JURI committee, i.e. in accordance with the decision of the JURI committee. immunity waiver.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported georgios Kircos' request for waiver of parliamentary immunity because the allegations relate to the functioning of the MEP before the election and the proceedings themselves had already begun at that time.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this pleading for suspension of immunity. Our position is to abstain when we understand that there are signs of political persecution or the facts are not very clear. The functioning of the pleadings is concrete and requires a very determined case study. In this case, the data was clear and allowed a position of ours in favor.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Georgios Kyrtsos' immunity was requested from the EP on 21 July 2015 by the Prosecutor's Office of the Greek Supreme Court in connection with a complaint of non-payment of wages by the East Athletic Labour Inspectorate. Kyrtsos is accused of failing to pay part of the salary of his former employee; the offence alleged is not related to georgios kyrtsos's mandate as a Member of the European Parliament, but to his previous activities as the head of two newspaper publishing companies, and the rapporteur therefore proposed the waiver of Kyrtsos' immunity. I voted for it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this pleading for suspension of immunity. Our position is to abstain when we understand that there are signs of political persecution or the facts are not very clear. The functioning of the pleadings is concrete and requires a very determined case study. In this case, the data was clear and allowed a position of ours in favor.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision on the request for waiver of the immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos. Georgios Kyrtsos is accused of non-payment of part of the salary of one of his former employees, but I agreed that the alleged offence clearly has nothing to do with the office of Georgios Kyrtsos as a Member of the European Parliament but is rather connected to his former position as manager of two newspaper firms.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted to lift georgios Kyrtsos' immunity so that he can defend himself before the Greek courts.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Mr Georgios Kyrtsos is accused of not paying part of a former worker's salary. Bearing in mind that the alleged infringement has nothing to do with Georgios Kyrtsos' mandate as a Member of the European Parliament, we voted in favour of the waiver of Georgios Kyrtsos' parliamentary immunity.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The alleged offence appears to be unrelated to Georgios Kyrtsos' position as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather to his previous role as manager of two newspaper publishers. There is therefore no reason to believe that the underlying criminal proceedings are based on the intention to affect the political activity of the Member. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report under consideration concerns the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos which the Public Prosecutor's Office has requested from the Supreme Court of Greece as part of a possible legal action relating to an alleged offence. Congressman Georgios Kyrtsos is accused of not paying part of the salary of a former worker of a company in which Kyrtsos was a manager. Bearing in mind that the alleged infringement has nothing to do with georgios Kyrtsos' term of office as a Member of the European Parliament, but is related to his previous position as manager of two newspaper editing companies; whereas the judicial procedure does not concern opinions or votes expressed in the exercise of the mandate of the Member of the European Parliament concerned for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, and that there is no reason to suspect that the intention underlying the legal action is to undermine the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis) , since the process began a few years before the Member began his term of office, we voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Georgios Kyrtsos.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which withdraws parliamentary immunity from Greek MEP Stelios Kouloglou so that he can deal with the accusations made about him first and foremost, since these have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic has called for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Stelios Kouloglou in connection with a possible legal action relating to a defamation charge. In 2010, Stelios Kouloglou is said to have made remarks in the press that urged some of Patras' prison staff while he was a journalist and a reporter. The alleged offence is apparently unrelated to Stelios Kouloglou's MEP duties and does not concern an opinion or vote cast by him in the performance of his parliamentary duties within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on EU privileges and immunities. There is no reason to believe that the underlying intent of the criminal proceedings is to interfere with the political activity of the Member, since the act of prosecution dates back several years before the parliamentary office took place. I voted for it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This was not a roll-call vote. In the interests of democracy I wish to make it clear that I did not vote to waive the Parliamentary immunity of Mr. Kouloglou. Whilst I accept many of the principles contained within the report, it appears that this relates to a criminal prosecution for libel. As a believer in freedom of speech, I struggle to defend the principle of such comments being criminal rather than civil matters. I make no comment as to whether or not the Committee on Legal Affairs is correct in its interpretation of Judgment No 1126/1994 of the Greek Supreme Court, in relation to whether or not this matter is now time-barred.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to lift the parliamentary immunity of this Greek Syriza MP who is accused of defaming prison staff before his election to the European Parliament.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. According to the unanimous opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I have approved the lifting of parliamentary immunity requested by the Greek court with regard to Mr Kouloglou, which relates to a matter prior to his presence in the European Parliament.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this pleading to suspend Mr Kouloglou's immunity. Stelios Kouloglou has accepted the suspension of his immunity and, as in all cases where this happens, our vote is to accept it, assuming, moreover, that there is no possible political persecution in this case and that the facts have nothing to do with his activity as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Parliament's decision on Stelios Kouloglou's request to waive his immunity. Mr. Kouloglou is being prosecuted by the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic for alleged defamation. The alleged incidents date back to 2010, when Mr. Kouloglou allegedly made comments in the press questioning the probity of certain members of Patras' prison staff. At the time of the incident, Mr. Kouloglou was a journalist, mainly in charge of the production of television reports. Given the circumstances, it must be noted that the alleged offence does not appear to be related to Stelios Kouloglou's duties as a Member of the European Parliament and does not appear to concern an opinion, opinion or vote cast by him in the performance of his duties. Therefore, there is no reason to believe that the underlying intent of the criminal proceedings is to harm its political activity. That is why I believe that the Greek justice system must be able to take its course and I am in favour of the lifting of this immunity.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I took part in the vote on the Svoboda report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending Stelios Kouloglou's immunity since, after considering the request made by the Prosecutor's Office of the Supreme Court of Greece, the Committee on Legal Affairs has found that Stelios Kouloglou is accused of libel and defamation against Patras prison staff, accusations that are unrelated to the position of Member of the European Parliament and that there is no reason to suspect that criminal proceedings are intended to harm the political activity of the deputy (fumus persecutionis), since the prosecution began several years before the deputy took possession of his seat.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has led Parliament to waive the immunity of Stelios Kouloglou, a Greek Member of the European Parliament. Stelios Kouloglou is accused of defamation and discrediting patra prison staff for allegations he allegedly made to the press in 2010 (at the time he was a journalist, mostly preparing television reports), referring to the integrity of certain Patra prison staff. Parliament decided to waive the immunity of Stelioso Kouloglou because there is no reason to suspect that criminal proceedings have been brought with a view to undermining the political activities of a Member (fumus persecutionis), given that the prosecution proceedings were initiated several years before the Member took up his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Stelios Kouloglou is accused of defamation for questioning the probity of certain members of Patras' prison staff in 2010 when he was a journalist in charge of producing television reports. The Greek Supreme Court is the source of the request to waive its parliamentary immunity. This alleged offence is unrelated to his mandate as an MEP since it was obviously committed when he was a journalist, that is, several years before he took office in the European Parliament. The act of prosecution does not concern an opinion he expressed in the course of his parliamentary activity. Therefore, the intention of this procedure is not to interfere with its political activity. So I voted to lift his parliamentary immunity.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Stelios Kouloglou is accused of defamation of patras prison staff. There does not appear to be any grounds for immunity under the Rules of Procedure.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Stelios Kouloglou. It should be noted that the MEP concerned is agreeing to the waiver and furthermore, the accusations relate to a time before he was an MEP. It relates to an allegation of defamation. However, the MEP has stated that the plaintiff withdrew the claim. Although, in order to stop the procedure of waiving of the immunity the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) needs a formal decision from the court which was due to take place in early December but could not take place. Having taken into account all of the facts, I voted in favour of this waiver.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Stelios Kouloglou has been charged with defamation of prison staff at Patras prison. The indictment refers to statements he made in 2010 in the press in his role as a television reporter – a role he held at the time. The claims relate to the behaviour of some members of the prison staff of Patras prison. Since the facts, as well as the alleged crime, take place before mr. Mr Kouloglou and they do not concern the exercise of his current duties, I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the request for the waiver of my colleague's immunity.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The proposal to waive the immunity of Stelios Kouloglou concerns prosecutions brought against the MEP on issues that had arisen in the past and which are not related to his activities in the European Parliament but to his previously professional occupation. The MEP himself considers that there is no contradiction in the accusation against him, and that is why he is calling for his immunity to be waived. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of the waiver of immunity.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request to waive the immunity of Stelios Kouloglou. The text under discussion sets out the EP's reasons for the request to waive the immunity of Stalios Kouloglou. On 7 August 2015, the President announced in accordance with Rule 9(1) of the Rules of Procedure that he had received a letter from the Public Prosecutor's Office at the Supreme Court of Greece requesting the waiver of stelios Kouloglou's parliamentary immunity. Having examined the documents, the committee decided to submit to the EP the decision to waive immunity, considering that the charges clearly have no relation to the office of Member of the European Parliament, but is instead linked to his previous profession as a television reporter. Mr. Kouloglou is accused of making statements to the press in 2010 about the probity of some staff at Patras prison, at a time when he worked as a journalist and produced mostly television reports. Furthermore, there is no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the request to waive stelios Kouloglou's immunity because the unlawful actions were committed before his election as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – Parliamentary immunity is not a Member’s personal privilege but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament as a whole and of its Members. The case in question does not have a direct and obvious connection with the Member’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7. I thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In European law, parliamentary immunity is a remnant of very old rules and represents a privileged legal situation granted to Members. The Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Community was initialled in April 1965 and provides for the application of this immunity to be discussed on a case-by-case basis. Today we are dealing with the case of Stelios Kouloglou, who has been accused of defamation of prison staff at Patras prison. The crime was committed when Kouloglou was a documentary filmmaker and journalist, and not during his time as an MEP since 2015, making it clear that immunity should not be granted to him. That is why I am voting in favour of the resolution.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which withdraws parliamentary immunity from Greek MEP Stelios Kouloglou so that he can deal with the accusations made about him first and foremost, since these have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The public prosecutor's office of the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic has requested the lifting of Stelios Kouloglou's immunity. He is in fact implicated in a defamation case, the facts having occurred when he was a journalist. This offence predates his taking office. Moreover, it does not concern an opinion or vote cast by him in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union. I voted in favour of respecting the proper functioning of justice when an inquiry is opened and does not undermine a parliamentarian's freedom of expression.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The committee responsible has, at the request of the Greek authorities, dealt with the waiver of immunity in accordance with Articles 6 and 7 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, and subsequently submitted a request for waiver of the immunity of the Member. Following a court decision by the Supreme Court of the Member State and following the committee's preparation of the case, I consider it appropriate to vote in accordance with the committee's request for waiver of immunity. I regularly vote in accordance with the committee responsible in immunity procedures, where it is reasonable and in accordance with the Rules of Procedure that cases be referred to the national judiciary unless there are political motives.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because the alleged facts are not linked to an activity specific to the European Parliament.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Stelios Kouloglou, requested by the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Hellenic Republic, in the context of a possible legal action relating to an alleged offence. The deputy is accused of libel and defamation of officials of patras prison. The accusation relates to statements allegedly made by Stelios Kouloglou to the press in 2010 about the integrity of some members of the staff of Patras prison, at a time when he was a journalist and produced mainly television reports. The alleged acts do not have a direct or obvious link with the performance of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament, nor do they constitute opinions or votes expressed in the performance of her duties as a Member. In this sense, and in accordance with the wishes expressed by the Member himself, we voted in favour of the lifting of parliamentary immunity. Although the applicant has, in the meantime, decided to withdraw the complaint, the end of the immunity suspension procedure needs a formal decision of the court, which was not the case in time for this plenary session because of the General Strike which took place in Greece. In other words, in practice, this case is closed and this vote is irrelevant.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must in no way lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice, and that is why I am voting in favour of the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Stelios Kouloglou.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The accusation relates to statements which Stelios Kouloglou is claimed to have made to the press in 2010 about the probity of certain members of the prison staff in Patras, at a time when he was a journalist chiefly producing television reporting. Considering that the alleged offence clearly has nothing to do with the office of Georgios Kyrtsos as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather is connected to his former position as manager of two newspaper firms, I supported the decision to waive the parliamentary immunity of Stelios Kouloglou.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report concerning the waiver of immunity of Stelios Kouloglou given the alleged offence is unrelated to this current role as MEP.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this pleading to suspend Mr Kouloglou's immunity. Stelios Kouloglou has accepted the suspension of his immunity and, as in all cases where this happens, our vote is to accept it, assuming, moreover, that there is no possible political persecution in this case and that the facts have nothing to do with his activity as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As things stood, the allegations that had been launched against Stelios Kouloglou could not be brought in front of a court because of the parliamentary immunity which is guaranteed to him under Greek law and his position as a Member of Parliament. Because these accusations and criminal proceedings were initiated long before the start of his mandate, I do not believe that they are intended to defame his character.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Stelios Kouloglou was decided by the fact that it is our duty to remove any obstacles for the investigation and to clear the path for the right and just decision to be made.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒  I supported this report which requests the waiver of immunity of Stelios Kouloglou, Member of the European Parliament, in connection with a possible legal action concerning an alleged offence. Stelios Kouloglou is accused of libel and defamation of prison staff in Patras. The accusation relates to statements which Stelios Kouloglou is claimed to have made to the press in 2010 about the probity of certain members of the prison staff in Patras, at a time when he was a journalist chiefly producing television reports.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report according to the position adopted by my political group.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Stelios Kouloglou's immunity, which lifts his parliamentary immunity, as it is an alleged offence committed before Mr Kouloglou became a Member of the European Parliament. In addition, Mr. Kouloglou waived his right to be heard, and it is not about expressing an opinion or voting in office. Therefore, I support this proposal.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Pavel Svoboda's report on Stelios Kouloglou's request for the lifting of parliamentary immunity. This procedure is a formality which, without deciding on the merits of the case, is intended to enable the judicial authorities to carry out their investigative work. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The alleged offence appears to be unrelated to Stelios Kouloglou's position as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather to his previous role as a television reporter. There is no reason to believe that the underlying criminal proceedings are based on the intention to interfere with the political activity of the Member, since it was initiated several years before the start of the Member's mandate.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive the immunity.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to lift Stelios Kouloglou's parliamentary immunity, considering that the charge relates to comments he allegedly made in the press in 2010 about the probity of certain members of Patras' prison staff at a time when he was a journalist. The prosecution is clearly not related to Mr Kouloglou's duties as an MEP. There is no reason to believe that the underlying intention of the criminal proceedings is to interfere with the political activity of the Member, since the act of prosecution dates back several years before taking office in the European Parliament.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MPs voted to lift this parliamentary immunity because the alleged offences (defamation of prison staff before the election of the MP) have nothing to do with the mandate.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. – The member's accusations date back to before his mandate was created and it is therefore up to the Greek courts to decide on his possible guilt or innocence.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. Stelios Kouloglou is a Greek member of the United European Left and Nordic Green Left Confederal Group and Vice-President of the Development Committee and Member of the Transport and Tourism Committee. The Greek Supreme Court's attorney's office has asked for the lawmaker's immunity to be lifted for possible criminal proceedings since he was accused of defaming and insulting prison staff in Patras in 2010.  I supported the request to lift the immunity of Greek MEP Stelios Kouloglou, because the offence he is accused of has nothing to do with his activities in the European Parliament.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Stelios Kologlou is a (former) Greek journalist whose request for waiver of parliamentary immunity is based on the fact that in 2010 there was publication of unverified news when he wrote an article about patra prison staff. The waiver of a Member's immunity is likely to lead to legal proceedings, during which it will also be concluded exactly what happened and for what reasons, as well as the adoption of a relevant verdict. I would like to add that the cornerstone of a journalist's work is not only simply to provide the public with some kind of information, but also to do so in the best possible way – without any exceptions. I therefore voted in favour, to a large extent, for the reason that the result would be cleared up, mr Kologlū fulfilled his professional duties fairly or not.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request to waive the parliamentary immunity of Stelios Kouloglou following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to waive the immunity of Stelios Kouloglou as the alleged offence clearly has nothing to do with the office of Stelios Kouloglou as a Member of the European Parliament but is rather connected to his former position as a television reporter.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this waiver of immunity. Mr. Kouloglou is being prosecuted in Greece on a charge of defamation. The allegations against him date back to 2010, when Mr. Kouloglou was a journalist. He is said to have made remarks about the probity of some of Patras' prison staff. The alleged offence does not appear to be related to Mr. Kouloglou's mandate as a Member of Parliament, the facts dating back several years before his election.  We allow his waiver of immunity.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of Mr Svoboda's proposal to waive the parliamentary immunity of Stelios Kouloglou because there is no reasonable reason to believe that there is an intention to prejudice the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis) with this measure, which was initiated a few years before the beginning of the Member's term of office.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The alleged offence appears to be unrelated to Stelios Kouloglou's position as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather to his previous role as a television reporter. There is no reason to believe that the underlying criminal proceedings are based on the intention to interfere with the political activity of the member (fumus persecutionis), since it was initiated several years before the start of the member's mandate. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report concerns the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of the Greek MEP, Stelios Kouloglou. He is accused of defaming Patras prison staff, following comments he allegedly made in the press in 2010 about the probity of certain members of those staff. Since at the time of the alleged events he was not an MEP but was working as a journalist in charge of the production of television reports and so that it is possible to shed light on this matter, I vote for the lifting of immunity.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic has called for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Stelios Kouloglou in connection with a possible legal action relating to a defamation charge. In 2010, Stelios Kouloglou is said to have made remarks in the press that urged some of Patras' prison staff while he was a journalist and a reporter. The alleged offence is apparently unrelated to Stelios Kouloglou's MEP duties and does not concern an opinion or vote cast by him in the performance of his parliamentary duties within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol 7 on EU privileges and immunities. There is no reason to believe that the underlying intent of the criminal proceedings is to interfere with the political activity of the Member, since the act of prosecution dates back several years before the parliamentary office took place. I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the corresponding articles of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Stelios Kouloglou.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Stelios Kouloglou.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Prosecutor's Office of the Supreme Court of the Hellenic Republic has requested the waiver of the immunity of MEP Stelios Kouloglou in connection with proceedings for defamation and defamation. The charge related to allegations that Stelios Kouloglou allegedly made to the press in 2010 about the integrity of certain employees of patras prison when he was working as a television reporter. As the Committee on Legal Affairs points out in its report, the offence allegedly committed is not related to Stelios Kouloglou's mandate as a Member of the European Parliament, but to his work as a television journalist of his time, and there is no reason to believe that the criminal proceedings were initiated in order to cause political damage to the Member, since it started several years before he became a Member, and therefore proposes to Parliament that Stelios Kouloglou's immunity be suspended. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deserves my vote in favour, after all the legal procedures required have elapsed, because the offence in question is not in any way related to the performance of the duties of a Member and that there is no evidence or suspicion that, at the origin of the criminal proceedings, the intention to harm the Member concerned is politically impaired.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Mr. Kouloglou is accused of making defamatory statements in 2010 about the probity of certain members of Patras' prison staff during his time as a journalist. The Greek prosecutor's office has therefore requested the lifting of his parliamentary immunity. The alleged facts are unrelated to his activity as an MEP, since they occurred before he took office, and the prosecutions were not driven by political reasons, so I decided to vote in favour of the lifting of immunity.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of Stelios Kouloglou. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report according to the evaluation made by the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI).

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Stelios Kouloglou. Mr Kouloglou has been charged with a possible offence. He was charged with defamation and defamation of prison staff in Patras.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur for his work and I align with what is called for in the report. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. Mr. Kouloglou is accused of making defamatory statements in 2010 about the probity of certain members of Patras' prison staff when he was a journalist. The Greek prosecutor's office has therefore requested the lifting of his parliamentary immunity. The alleged facts are unrelated to his work as an MEP - they occurred before he took office - and the prosecutions are not motivated by political reasons: I have decided to vote in favour of lifting immunity.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation to lift the immunity of my colleague Stelios Kouloglou, because although prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or voted in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote in the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the Code of Human Security. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the alleged offence is clearly not in any relation to the performance of his duties as a colleague of Kouloglou as a Member of the European Parliament, but is concerning his function as a journalist who was mainly involved in reporting for television, there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis) because it was initiated before Mr Kouloglou became a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - In order for MEMBERS as representatives of EU citizens to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity serves only as an instrument to protect them from politically motivated persecution. The purpose of parliamentary immunity is never to place MPs above the law, but serves their smooth and independent action. A report on the request to lift Stelios Kouloglou's immunity said Kouloglou was charged with defamation and insulting prison staff in Patras.  The charge relates to statements about the honesty of certain members of the prison staff at Patras that Stelios Kouloglou allegedly made to the media in 2010, when he was mainly involved in reporting for television as a journalist. Consequently, the Office of the Attorney General of the Supreme Court of Greece has requested the lifting of parliamentary immunity of MEP Stelios Kouloglou for possible initiation of criminal proceedings.  The alleged offence has nothing to do with Stelios Kouloglou's duty as a MEMBER of the European Parliament, but concerns his former position as a television reporter. Since that case of criminal prosecution is not related to the expression of an opinion or the vote of the Member of the European Parliament concerned in the performance of his or her duties within the meaning of Article 8(1) of the Code of Conduct, Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, I support this report.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Mep Stelios Kouloglou. I believe that the Greek Attorney-General should be allowed to carry out the appropriate investigations in relation to a possible legal action concerning a criminal offence. Stelios Kouloglou is accused of defamation of patras prison staff. The indictment relates to statements stelios Kouloglou made to the press in 2010 about the probity of some staff at Patras prison, at the time when he was working as a journalist and producing television reports.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In view of the circumstances and the facts alleged against this parliamentarian and which could not establish the existence of a fumus persecutionis in the context of the proceedings against him, the JURI Committee unanimously wished to recommend to the plenary that its parliamentary immunity be lifted. So I followed that advice.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. On 7 August 2015, the Public Prosecutor's Office before the Supreme Court of Greece requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Stelios Kouloglou in the context of a legal action, in which the Member of the European Parliament is accused of libel and defamation of officials of patras prison. Under Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. According to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, Article 8 of the Protocol does not apply in this case, since the alleged infringement has no relation to the mandate of Stelios Kouloglou as an MEP, but is related to his previous position as a television reporter. Accordingly, and on the basis of the JURI Committee report, I voted in favour of this Decision on the waiver of the immunity of Stelios Kouloglou.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. It is a question of Greek internal justice, unrelated to the status of Deputy of Stelios Kouloglou.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of Mr Stelios Kouloglou's immunity, so that the Hellenic justice could carry out its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the alleged facts - defamation by press against the prison staff of Patras - are not related to the office of Member of Parliament for Mr Kouloglou, as they are linked to his previous function as a television reporter. , and are not motivated by the desire to interfere with the MP's political action.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report concerning the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Stelios Kouloglou. This is a request made by the Public Prosecutor's Office to the Supreme Court of Greece, which concerns a judicial case in which the Deputy is accused of libel and defamation of officials of patras prison, and such statements allegedly made to the press occurred in 2010, at a time when Stelios Kouloglou was a journalist and made television reports. It is therefore a judicial process concerning conduct allegedly practised outside its mandate as an MEP. There is no reason to doubt the legitimate intention underlying this legal action, I considered that the conditions for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of my colleague Stelios Kouloglou were gathered.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this pleading to suspend Mr Kouloglou's immunity. Stelios Kouloglou has accepted the suspension of his immunity and, as in all cases where this happens, our vote is to accept it, assuming, moreover, that there is no possible political persecution in this case and that the facts have nothing to do with his activity as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which withdraws parliamentary immunity from Greek MEP Stelios Kouloglou so that he can deal with the accusations made about him first and foremost, since these have nothing to do with his activity as an MEP.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as I do not believe he should keep his immunity.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As things stood, the allegations that had been launched against Stelios Kouloglou could not be brought in front of a court because of the parliamentary immunity which is guaranteed to him under Greek law and his position as a Member of Parliament. Because these accusations and criminal proceedings were initiated long before the start of his mandate, I do not believe that they are intended to defame his character.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution granting the request to the Public Prosecutor's Office in the Supreme Court of Greece to waive the immunity of Member Stelios Kouglo, who is accused of libel and defamation of prison staff in Patras. The allegation relates to statements stelios Kouloglou allegedly made to the press in 2010 regarding the integrity of some members of prison staff in Patras while he was working as a journalist and devoted himself mainly to producing television news. MePs, within the meaning of Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the privileges and immunities of the EU, shall enjoy within the territory of their own State the immunities granted to members of the Parliament of that State. Since Article 62 of the Constitution of the Hellenic Republic provides that Members of Parliament may not be prosecuted, arrested, imprisoned or otherwise restricted during their term without the prior authorisation of parliament, it was necessary to waive the parliamentary immunity of a colleague so that law enforcement authorities would thoroughly investigate whether MEP Stelios Kougloa was guilty of libel and defamation of prison staff in Patras.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the request for the lifting of parliamentary immunity to Stelios Kouloglou, sent by the Office of the Attorney General of the Greek Supreme Court on 7 August 2015 in connection with the allegations of insult and defamation and which was published at a plenary session on 9 September 2015.  The alleged offence has nothing to do with Stelios Kouloglou's duty as a MEMBER of the European Parliament, but concerns his former position as a television reporter. The criminal prosecution case is not related to the expression of an opinion or the vote of the Member of the European Parliament concerned in the performance of his or her duties within the meaning of Article 8(1) of the Code of Conduct. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Office of the Attorney General of the Supreme Court of Greece, on 7 August 2015, requested the lifting of parliamentary immunity of MEP Stelios Kouloglou. The request came amid possible criminal proceedings on charges of insulting and defaming prison staff in Patras, when he was mainly involved in reporting for television as a journalist.  As Article 62 The Constitution of the Hellenic Republic dictates that Members of Parliament must not be prosecuted, arrested, imprisoned during their term of office and in no other way deprived of their freedom without parliament's prior approval, Parliament called on Members to come out on the issue of lifting their immunity. I support the request at first reading for the lifting of parliamentary immunity and privileges for MEP Stelios Kouloglou, as I believe the Supreme Court of Greece must investigate and determine whether a crime of insult and defamation has been committed.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliamentary privileges must under no circumstances lead to unequal and privileged treatment of Members vis-à-vis law and justice.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted to lift this parliamentarian's immunity so that he could defend himself in the courts of his country

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agreed to waive the immunity of Mr Stelios Kouloglou, a Greek member of the GUE-NGL Group. The reason is that he is accused of libel and defamation of prison staff in the city of Patras in Greece. The accusation relates to statements which Stelios Kouloglou is claimed to have made to the press in 2010 about the probity of certain members of the prison staff in Patras, at a time when he was a journalist chiefly producing television reporting.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 MeP, Mr Stelios Kouloglou, is accused of defaming prison staff in the town of Patras. The charge is related to statements allegedly made to the media by the mp in 2010 concerning the honesty of individual members of the prison staff at Patras. At the same time, Mp Kouloglou worked as a journalist, primarily on television. Since the statement made by a Member for the media occurred at a time when he had not yet started to serve his or her parliamentary term, and that that event did not correlate with his or her performance of his or her duties in the European Parliament, I voted in accordance with the decision of the JURI committee, i.e. immunity waiver.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I have denied the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Stelios Kuloglu on the basis that the allegations relate to the activities of an MEP before his election.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this pleading to suspend Mr Kouloglou's immunity. Stelios Kouloglou has accepted the suspension of his immunity and, as in all cases where this happens, our vote is to accept it, assuming, moreover, that there is no possible political persecution in this case and that the facts have nothing to do with his activity as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Stelios Kouloglou's immunity was waived on August 7, 2015 by the Prosecutor General's Office of the Greek Supreme Court in a case of defamation and defamation. Kouloglou allegedly made a statement in 2010 that violated the integrity of some employees of patras prison when he was a journalist. According to the rapporteur, the act is not related to Kouloglou's MANDATE in the EP and has therefore proposed the waiver of immunity. I voted for it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this pleading to suspend Mr Kouloglou's immunity. Stelios Kouloglou has accepted the suspension of his immunity and, as in all cases where this happens, our vote is to accept it, assuming, moreover, that there is no possible political persecution in this case and that the facts have nothing to do with his activity as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision on the request for waiver of the immunity of Stelios Kouloglou who is accused of libel and defamation of prison staff in Patras. I believe that the alleged offence clearly has nothing to do with the office of Stelios Kouloglou as a Member of the European Parliament but is rather connected to his former position as a television reporter.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted to lift stelios Kouloglou's immunity so that he can defend himself before the national court.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The deputy is accused of libel and defamation of officials at Patras prison. The accusation relates to statements allegedly made by Stelios Kouloglou to the press in 2010 about the integrity of some members of the staff of Patras prison, at a time when he was a journalist and produced mainly television reports. The alleged acts do not have a direct or obvious link with the exercise of the duties of a Member of the EP, nor do they constitute opinions or votes expressed in the performance of their duties as a Member of the EP.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The alleged offence appears to be unrelated to Stelios Kouloglou's position as a Member of the European Parliament, but rather to his previous role as a television reporter. There is no reason to believe that the underlying criminal proceedings are based on the intention to interfere with the political activity of the member (fumus persecutionis), since it was initiated several years before the start of the member's mandate. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses on the request for parliamentary immunity of Mr Stelios Kouloglou requested by the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Hellenic Republic in connection with a possible legal action relating to an alleged offence. The deputy is accused of libel and defamation of officials of patras prison. The accusation relates to statements allegedly made by Stelios Kouloglou to the press in 2010 about the integrity of some members of the staff of Patras prison, at a time when he was a journalist and produced mainly television reports. The alleged acts do not have a direct or obvious link with the exercise of the duties of a Member of the EP, nor do they constitute opinions or votes expressed in the performance of their duties as a Member of the EP. We voted in favour of lifting parliamentary immunity.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund to people who have become unemployed after the closure of European companies. I consistently vote against these unemployment benefits for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed should be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 2 623 200 following the dismissal of 1 603 workers in 69 companies operating in Finland, in division 62 of NACE Revision 2, Programming, consulting and other IT-related activities. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system. While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these workers in Finland, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report which aims to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following a request from Finland. This European Fund was set up to provide assistance to workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector, or by the changes in the economic structures of The Member States caused by globalisation and free trade. The aim here is to mobilise the Fund for 1,200 workers laid off by 69 companies in the computer programming sector in Finland.  I am therefore in favour of this aid for the retraining of these workers who are in fact suffering the disastrous consequences of European economic policy.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The Zanni report (EFDD) concerns the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help laid-off workers in Finland. As a reminder, this Fund can be mobilised to help workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector, or by the changes in the economic structures of The Member States caused by globalisation and free trade. A link must be made between layoffs and the economic and financial crisis.  In this case, a contribution of 2.636 million euros is requested for the reintegration into the labour market of 1,200 workers laid off by 69 companies in the computer programming sector in Finland. Finland is facing a competitiveness crisis linked to high labour costs and the impossibility of devaluing to counter competition from emerging countries, particularly in the telecommunications sector.  I voted for it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Finland, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I regret the establishment of this instrument at European level and I await the planned revision of the legal basis. Nevertheless, as this system is widely sought, I allow myself, on a case-by-case basis, the possibility of voting in favour of its mobilization.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF to assist Finland in supporting the return to the labour market of workers made redundant from 69 companies active in computer programming. The EGF is intended to provide a total amount of EUR 2 623 200. This will support 1 200 of the 1 603 redundancies. Redundancies have been made as a result of changes affecting Nokia in recent years, which have had a significant impact on the Finnish ICT sector. In the field of development and design of Nokia mobile phone operating systems, especially in the Oulu region, thousands of Finnish people have been employed, and these features are currently being transferred to countries outside Europe. Personalised services to be provided to redundant workers include counselling, employment and business services, training, wage subsidies, etc.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Opposed to this hypocritical system of the 'Globalisation Adjustment Fund', emblematic of a European Union that behaves like an arsonist, I nevertheless voted in favour of this report which proposes to release EUR 2.636 million to help 1,200 Finns find work after losing their jobs in the IT sector in crisis. These redundancies are indeed linked to the international competition in which the European Union continues to disarm companies and employees of our Member States. This request for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund echoes the one that was voted in July 2015 for former employees of Broadcom Communications Finland.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The difficulties faced by Nokia and competition from third countries have had a serious impact on employment in the ICT sector in Finland. From 2008 to 2014, the number of workers in the sector increased from 326,000 to 276,000. The Oulu region was particularly hard hit and in the spring of 2015, 1,500 ICT job seekers were still looking for work. I therefore supported the EGF's intervention to support the efforts of the Finnish authorities to facilitate their professional integration.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this dossier as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation to address the situation of dismissed workers, in this case in Finland in the computer sector. These are measures that would leave the workers concerned worse if they did not exist. The vote in favour, however, does not hide the view that such measures are 'bread for today and hunger for tomorrow', whereas the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Secondly, such an alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive and energy model, and not mechanisms that ultimately facilitate applicants (Member States and derived from the undertakings concerned) to dismantle sectors, without considering measures such as the repayment of subsidies received by companies, or the reporting of possible reopening in new territories that may contribute to the competitive devaluation.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to support this report, which aims to provide assistance to the 1,603 employees of 69 companies based in Finland in the information and communication technology sector. Once again, savage globalization is claiming the brunt of the victims and Finnish workers have paid the price for massive relocations of this sector to countries with lower labour costs, such as China, India or Taiwan. For example, in 2014 alone, the number of companies operating in the ICT sector in Finland decreased by 3%, or 1,500 people.  In the face of this increasing precariousness of workers across Europe, the Globalisation Adjustment Fund appears to be a meagre but necessary compensation, especially since Finland has been particularly affected by the crisis affecting the ICT sector. For example, in 2011, Nokia made large-scale redundancies, first laying off 1,000 people in Salo in 2012 and another 3700 at the end of 2012-early 2013; A further 600 layoffs took place in 2014 in the chip development industry.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported, with my vote, the mobilisation of the EGF to the value of EUR 2.6 million for 1 603 Finnish workers and 69 companies operating in the field of programming and IT consulting. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a very important tool for supporting citizens at this time of crisis, but the EU should focus on resolving the malfunctions of the internal market as a whole, rather than just caring for its victims.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which gives the green light to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to make a financial contribution of EUR 2 623 200 in response to Finland's request for redundancies made by 69 companies operating in DIVISION 62 rev. 2 of NACE ('Computer programming' consultancy and related activities) throughout the country.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported Parliament's support for the allocation of redundant workers from the European Globalisation Fund. Finland submitted an application for EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer Programming for financial support from the EGF following the dismissal of 1 603 employees from 69 companies across Finland operating computer programming and consultancy activities. Approximately 1 200 redundancies should benefit from this support. In recent years, the distribution of jobs in the ICT sector in the Union and other countries has changed to the detriment of the Union, in 2008. Finland's technology industry employed a total of 326 000 people, with 276 000 employees employed in such companies in 2014, resulting in an average reduction of 3 % of employees (10 000 employees) per year. These redundancies are due to changes affecting Nokia in recent years, which have had a significant impact on the Finnish ICT sector. In the field of development and design of Nokia mobile phone operating systems, thousands of Finnish residents have been employed and are currently being transferred to countries outside Europe.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. The Finnish application complies with the requirements laid down in Article 13 of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 for the determination of the financial contribution from the EGF. The Commission of the European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of the financial contribution to be made on the basis of an application submitted by Finland. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed report on the use of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. In this case, it is already the 17th role concerning the use of the Globalisation Fund from the EU budget for 2015. I am pleased that Finland is being given a good €2.6m from this fund, which it will allocate to help employees in the Finnish information and communication sector.  This was mainly due to the consequences of nokia's redundancies. The former telecommunications giant found itself in big trouble years ago. Thousands of people in Finland, particularly in the Oulu region, were employed in the development and design of Nokia mobile phone operating systems, before these jobs were relocated to countries outside Europe. The fund will be used to help laid-off workers. They will have mentoring measures, employment and business services, training, wage subsidies, travel allowances, accommodation and relocation costs. I am also pleased that funds will also be used to help start a business and promote entrepreneurship. However, I hope that in future similar cases will be as few as possible.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is useful for providing support to redundant workers and self-employed workers whose activities have ceased as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, either because of the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis or because of a new economic and financial crisis of a supra-regional nature. The Fund must be used to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market, updating their training and at the same time giving them financial support. It is therefore appropriate to mobilise the EGF in order to make a financial contribution to workers in companies that have suffered serious problems as a result of these phenomena.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal aims to provide Finland with a financial contribution of 2.636 million euros from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the dismissal of 1,200 employees by 69 companies in the it programming sector. This assistance is intended to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers.  These layoffs are directly related to the current economic crisis and unfair competition from emerging countries. Finland is also facing an unprecedented competitiveness crisis, mainly due to a particularly high labour cost.  On the one hand, this application meets the conditions for the granting of financial contributions from the WEF. On the other hand, we believe it is important to help finnish laid-off workers who are suffering, as in France, the disastrous consequences of savage globalisation. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in global trade practices resulting from globalisation. The fund is therefore intended to provide support to redundant workers, providing assistance for reintegration into the labour market and a number of related measures, including allowances and various incentives. Following the redundancy of 1,603 workers from 69 enterprises operating in the economic sector, Finland applied for the activities of making the custom software in order to obtain a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to support these workers. The Finnish authorities shall ensure compliance with the principles of equal treatment and non-discrimination with regard to access to the proposed actions and shall ensure that the Union's financial contribution from the EGF will comply with the Union's procedural and substantive state aid rules. I believe that it is important to provide financial support and improve the possibilities of people made redundant to have access to a job, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this intervention by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The case relates to the redundancy of 1603 workers by 69 companies in the it programming and consultancy sector in Finland. 1200 workers should benefit from the intervention. The financial contribution that will be made will amount to approximately EUR 2.6 million. The origin of this employment crisis stems from the Nokia case, the events of which affected an entire production sector affected, among other things, by a massive phenomenon of relocation to Asia. The figures allocated will, among other things, be used to initiate mentoring, training, recruitment incentives, start-up grants and incentives for entrepreneurship.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Parliament has decided to accept Finland's request for intervention from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help employees of Computer Programming, which is heavily affected by the employment consequences of globalisation. The amount of aid amounts to 2,623,200 euros. Dismissed employees will receive training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job.  Finland's request is justified given the significant global competition in it advisory and programming. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 1603 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation by FI/Computer programming, a company operating in the IT sector. In recent years, the distribution of employment in information and communication technologies (ICT) between the Union and other economies has changed to the detriment of the EU. In 2014, the technology sector in Finland employed 276,000 people, compared with a total of 326,000 workers in 2008, which corresponds to an average annual decrease of about 3% (10,000 workers). The events behind the redundancies are linked to the Nokia case. The development and design of operating systems for Nokia mobile phones gave work to thousands of Finns. Unfortunately, these functions have been relocated to countries outside Europe, further aggravating the problem of ICT unemployment in regions with high unemployment. The aim of the Fund is to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of these redundant workers through personalized accompanying measures. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit from this fund because of the lack of support from local institutions.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with an application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The European Globalisation Fund (EGF) is a Commission programme that provides training and employment supports to redundant workers. However, I wish to note with concern that millions of euros earmarked for redundant workers from the EGF is set to be returned unspent to the Commission. Up to EUR 3 million could be left unspent with 60% of that being returned to Brussels.
