This is absolutely unacceptable and highlights the Irish Government’s lack of action or care on such vital funding issues. This apathetic and incompetent attitude is unacceptable.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Finland submitted an EGF application for the redundancies of 1 603 employees.  As a result of this, Finland is entitled to EUR 2 623 200 million to deal with the redundancies, which in total are costing EUR 4 372 000 million. This allocation contributes towards 60% of the cost. The application was finalised on the 6 November 2015.  The ICT industry employed 326 000 employees and in 2014 this amount declined to 276 000; the blame is directed towards the massive decline in sales relating to Nokia electronic communications and competition from Asian nations that produce similar communication products. Mobilisation of the workforce and access to British jobs will form part of the package. The European jobs mobility portal known as EURES will be used to access the British jobs market.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We agree and support the report. We note that Finland is planning seven types of measures for redundant workers covered by this application: (i) guidance measures and other preparatory measures, (ii) employment and business services, (iii) training, (iv) salary grants, (v) business start-up subsidies (vi) guidance to entrepreneurship and services for young entrepreneurs, and (vii) allowances for travel, overnight and removal costs. The report welcomes entrepreneurship support measures, which take the form of business start-up grants, and entrepreneurship guidance measures and services for young entrepreneurs, and considers that these measures should be provided in combination to participants. In particular, the measures proposed to create new businesses to help promote entrepreneurship and services for young entrepreneurs are welcomed.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at Finland's request is a legitimate move aimed at addressing the problems caused by ever-changing conditions in the context of global competition. As this Globalisation Adjustment Fund is by definition aimed at supporting population groups facing labour problems as a result of globalisation, I believe that this proposal has a reasonable basis and we must support it for the benefit of workers in specific regions of Finland. That is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of Finland. This measure refers, within the framework of the 2015 budget, to the mobilisation of the Fund for a total amount of EUR 2,623,200. The request is based on the professional relocation of 1,200 of the 1,603 redundant workers to 69 companies operating in the economic sector classified in NACE Rev. 2 Division 62 (Programming, IT consultancy and related activities) in different NUTS 2 regions across Finland. It should be noted that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. One of the causes of the crisis is developments in Recent Years at Nokia, which have had a significant impact on the ICT sector in Finland. The development and design of Nokia mobile phone operating systems was working for thousands of Finns, particularly in Oulu, but these functions have now been relocated to non-European countries.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which came from the Commission on 6 November 2015, for the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland to facilitate the reintegration into employment of workers made redundant in 69 Finnish companies. A mobilisation of the EGF fund amounting to EUR 2,623,200 has been requested. The Commission has concluded, in accordance with all the applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation, that the application fulfils the conditions for a financial contribution from the Fund, and I would like to vote in favour of granting aid to workers from a State within the EU. I believe that we must protect European citizens and workers, as far as we can.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this application as I believe it is important that we support those who lost their jobs in the area with retraining, upskilling and diversification.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use every means at its service to react, in particular as regards the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 2 623 200 for Finland with the aim of supporting the 1603 workers made redundant in 69 companies in the consultancy sector and activities related to computer programming.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created in order to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows. The employment crisis in question and the consequent impacts on the labour market are attributable to developments in recent years in the Nokia company. Indeed, while the development and design of Nokia mobile phone operating systems has been important employment opportunities for thousands of Finnish people for years, these activities have now been relocated to countries outside Europe. This profound change has deprived many citizens of their ICT jobs in Finland.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – In recent years the distribution of ICT sector employment between the European Union and other economies has developed to the detriment of the EU. The events giving rise to these redundancies are the developments affecting Nokia in recent years, which have had a major impact on the ICT sector in Finland. The ICT sector used to employ thousands of Finnish people, while now these functions have been transferred to countries outside Europe. The European Globalisation Fund measures recommended will seek the reintegration of redundant workers into employment through occupational guidance, training, retraining and job search. I thus voted in favour of this report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EGF is an instrument born of an agreement between the European Parliament and the Council for the reintroduction into the world of work of staff who have suffered the effects of the global crisis. For Finland, it was decided to allocate EUR 2 623 200 to support 1 200 workers who have been made redundant. The information received from Finland on the situation in the country was immediately clear and in line with the standards required. I welcome the procedure put in place by the Commission in relation to the request for the EGF to facilitate reference in the world of work, with the granting of European Fund grants to the Finnish State, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 2 623 200 following the dismissal of 1 603 workers in 69 companies operating in Finland, in division 62 of NACE Revision 2, Programming, consulting and other IT-related activities. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these workers in Finland, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. In recent years, the distribution of employment in the ICT sector in the EU and other economies has changed adversely. Although the volume of this sector has increased worldwide, there has been a decline in Europe as businesses and services have moved to China, India, Taiwan and other destinations outside Europe.  The Finnish authorities point out that the steps leading to the redundancies include the changes that have been made by Nokia in recent years, which have had a significant impact on the ICT sector in Finland. In Finland, thousands of people have previously been involved in the development and design of operating systems for Nokia mobile phones, especially in Oulu, while these tasks have now been organised outside Europe. On 6 November 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from 69 companies in nace rev. 2 sector 62 ("Computer programming, consultancy and related services") in several NUTS level 2 regions in Finland. The EP report adopted today, which I voted in favour of, welcomes, inter alia, the fact that the Finnish authorities have offered a wide range of measures to redundant workers and welcomes measures to support entrepreneurship.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report deals with a specific European Globalisation Adjustment Fund application in Finland following 1 603 redundancies in the computer programming sector. Funding will aid 1 200 persons who were made redundant to find employment through various measures including re-training. I believe that workers who become redundant due to global economic trends, which they have no control over, need to be given the help they require to find alternative employment as soon as possible. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ There is no such thing as public money, so it is essential that EU expenditure is closely scrutinised on the basis of value for money for taxpayers and I do not believe the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an efficient tool that offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into labour market. The United Kingdom Government has never availed itself of funding under the EGF due to its inefficiency and I believe it is time that money spent under the EGF was put to better use. For these reasons I cannot support this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes the mobilization of EUR 2,623,200 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for the benefit of the 1,200 licensees in the computer programming sector in Finland between July 2014 and April 2015. The WEF helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalization or the global economic and financial crisis. The EGF has a maximum annual budget of 150 million euros for the period 2014-2020.  Considering that one of the aims of the European Union budget is to promote the transition of sectors in decline towards a more sustainable economic model, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Finland submitted an EGF application for the redundancies of 1 603 employees.  As a result of this, Finland is entitled to EUR 2 623 200 million to deal with the redundancies, which in total are costing EUR 4 372 000 million. This allocation contributes towards 60% of the cost. The application was finalised on 6 November 2015.  The ICT industry employed 326 000 employees and in 2014 this amount declined to 276 000; the blame is directed towards the massive decline in sales relating to Nokia electronic communications and competition from Asian nations that produce similar communication products. Mobilisation of the workforce and access to British jobs will form part of the package. The European jobs mobility portal known as EURES will be used to access the British jobs market.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), which is designed to support employees suffering the consequences of globalisation. With this vote, we are helping, to the tune of 2,623,200 euros, nearly 1,600 employees made redundant in Finland in the information technology sector.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. This demand for MOBILIZATION of the EGF comes in a highly competitive sector, where technological developments and even technological disruptions require extremely rapid adaptations with highly efficient research and development. This economic intelligence seems to have been lacking in the Nokia Group, which, in the absence of anticipating competition from other telephony giants, has led to a significant number of subcontractors and start-ups that framed the flagship. Thousands of Finns have had their work transferred to non-European countries resulting in a number of layoffs.  This report highlights the precautions to be taken in the retraining measures proposed to workers. The measures funded must aim to improve the prospects for job seekers so that they can enter the labour market in the future.  However, in addition, I also wonder about the operation of the EGF, which is particularly interesting and useful, but which takes place in the past and in too long a time frame. I would like to raise the issue of the conditions, particularly tax conditions, which preside over the establishment of such activities. I ask, in view of the ongoing changes in the issue of globalisation, that further reflection be given to all the eligibility criteria.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to help reintegrate workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade and the victims of the financial crisis. The application in question, submitted by Finland, relates to redundancies in the information technology sector. Indeed, in recent years, the distribution of employment in the ICT sector between the EU and other economies has come at the expense of the EU. While volume in this sector is increasing globally, it has declined in Europe as businesses and services are relocated to China, India, Taiwan and other non-European destinations. In 2014 alone, the number of companies operating in the ICT sector in Finland decreased by 3% (or 1,500 people).  The aim is to help 1,603 sacked employees in 69 companies in different regions of Finland. The aid will amount to EUR 2,623,200 and will help to co-finance active labour market measures focusing on job search assistance, training, career reorientation, etc. This request has received my support and the support of the European Parliament.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund concerned the decision to allocate aid to Finland to alleviate the competitiveness crisis it is experiencing. A true admission of the failure of globalization, this Aid Fund was necessary here. Indeed, Finland, because of its low competitiveness due to high labour costs and the fact that it cannot devalue its currency, suffers from globalisation. Its telecommunications sector, in the face of competition from third countries, has been particularly hard hit. Twenty-nine Finnish companies have laid off more than 1,200 workers in this sector. The Fund could help reintegrate them to the tune of 2.6 million euros. Although opposed to supranational financial mechanisms, I can only observe the disasters of globalization on the employment and quality of services offered. While this fund is only a palliative, it tends to correct some difficult situations. So I voted for this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for me and my political group is not a good investment and good value for money. I vote against this fund in principle, as I have done now.  In this case, more than EUR 2 million is given for the reintegration of 1200 Finnish workers into the labour market, through training, etc. Yes, the EU must support growth, push policies that create jobs, but this fund is not the most appropriate.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. On 12 June 2015, Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer programming' following redundancies in the regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusima, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois in the Regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusima, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois. Further information was added in accordance with Article 8(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013. The application shall comply with the requirements laid down in Article 13 of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 for the determination of the financial contribution from the EGF. The European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of a financial contribution of EUR 2 623 200 to be granted on the basis of an application submitted by Finland. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. It is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures, and so I voted in favour of this application. I regret that the UK Government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, particularly in the light of the Swedish National Audit Office's analysis, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it aims to help a European company.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application concerns 1 603 workers made redundant in the consultancy and activities related to computer programming in Finland. The redundancies occurred in 69 companies, with Microsoft Mobile accounting for almost half (778). In recent years, ICT employment has fallen sharply in the EU as companies and services move to countries such as China, India, Taiwan and other destinations outside Europe.  These effects were felt especially in Finland where the entire electronics industry was severely affected.  In total, 69 software companies ended up laying off workers during fall 2014 and spring 2015.  Northern Ostrobótnia is a region with a high unemployment rate (higher than the national average). Redundancies also affect workers over the age of 50, a group struggling to find new jobs. We have supported mobilising this aid for laid-off workers. However, this fund is nothing more than limited support for those affected by the liberalisation of world trade. Measures are needed to halt the course of neoliberal policies which have once again led to this outcome.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I do not consider this measure to be a useful tool for developing policies that promote growth and the creation of new jobs, nor capable of giving a comprehensive answer with regard to workers made redundant in the labour market.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission on budgetary discipline and having regard to the Council Regulation, as well as the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, I support the allocation of a financial contribution of EUR 2 623 200 to Finland. This particular application concerns 1200 out of a total of 1603 redundancies. The redundancies occurred in connection with developments at Nokia in recent years, which have had a significant impact on the ICT sector in Finland. The development and design of operating systems for Nokia mobile phones employed thousands of people in Finland, mainly in Oulu, and now these activities have been moved to countries outside Europe.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the 1,603 workers of 69 IT programming and consultancy companies in Finland.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The plenary voted on a report giving the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in Finland The application relates to 1 603 redundancies (almost half of them relate to Microsoft Mobile Oy) in 69 enterprises operating in the area of computer programming/consultancy in several Finnish regions within the reference period 30 July 2014 to 30 April 2015. The EGF funding of EUR 2 623 200 will contribute to help around 1 200 redundant workers via different types of measures such as coaching, employment and business services, training, subsidies, start-up grants, etc. The redundancies were caused by the major structural changes in the electronics industry. I therefore supported mobilisation of the EGF.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer programming, Finland. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization which, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process, there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalisation or the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote concerns Finland's request for the allocation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, an instrument set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The request concerns 1,200 of the 1,603 workers made redundant as a result of the relocation of the telecommunications industries to non-European countries. Having received a positive opinion from the committees involved and from the EGF working group, I voted in favour of mobilising this fund in support of workers in difficulty.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: request from Finland – EGF/2015/005 FI/computer programming, as I consider the Globalisation Fund instrument to be inefficient and in need of reform.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Europe has benefited from and will continue to benefit from the ongoing globalisation. We must consistently support citizens who have become unemployed as a a rising part of international competition in reintegrating into the labour market.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in response to an application from Finland, given the application fulfils the standard eligibility criteria set down by the EGF Regulation and no special derogation was necessary. This mobilisation was triggered following 1 603 redundancies in 69 enterprises across the whole of Finland.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of this dossier as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation to address the situation of dismissed workers, in this case in Finland in the COMPUTER sector. These are measures that would leave the workers concerned worse if they did not exist. The vote in favour, however, does not hide the view that such measures are 'bread for today and hunger for tomorrow', whereas the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Secondly, such an alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive and energy model, and not mechanisms that ultimately facilitate applicants (Member States and derived from the undertakings concerned) to dismantle sectors, without considering measures such as the repayment of subsidies received by companies, or the reporting of possible reopening in new territories that may contribute to the competitive devaluation.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There were 1 603 redundancies in 69 enterprises operating in the area of computer programming and consultancy in many Finnish regions. This number of redundancies over a short amount of time can only be attributed to a movement of demand away from these enterprises, either due to these services being provided elsewhere or a loss of interest in this industry. And I do not suspect that it is the latter. The EGF is something that the Tories want to see abolished for ideological reasons. All this while there have been various opportunities for the UK to apply for this funding, with the most recent example being the closure of the steel industry in the UK. I voted in favour of this request because we should show solidarity with the workers of Finland, because it is without a doubt that workers in the UK will need to access these funds, and the EGF can help those who are made redundant by the effects of globalisation and without much cost to the UK Government.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Finland submitted an EGF application for the redundancies of 1 603 employees.  As a result of this, Finland is entitled to EUR 2 623 200 million to deal with the redundancies, which in total are costing EUR 4 372 000 million. This allocation contributes towards 60% of the cost. The application was finalised on 6 November 2015.  The ICT industry employed 326 000 employees and in 2014 this amount declined to 276 000; the blame is directed towards the massive decline in sales relating to Nokia electronic communications and competition from Asian nations that produce similar communication products. Mobilisation of the workforce and access to British jobs will form part of the package. The European jobs mobility portal known as EURES will be used to access the British jobs market.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In recent years the distribution of ICT sector employment between the European Union and other economies has developed to the detriment of the European Union. Whereas in 2008 the technology industry employed a total of 326 000 people in Finland, the number of people employed by such companies in 2014 was 276 000, which corresponds to an average decline per year of about 3% (10 000 workers). It should be pointed out that the events giving rise to these redundancies are the developments affecting Nokia in recent years, which have had a major impact on the ICT sector in Finland. That is why I have voted for this report.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. On 12 June 2015, Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer programming' following redundancies in the regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusima, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois in the Regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusima, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois. Further information was added in accordance with Article 8(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013. The application shall comply with the requirements laid down in Article 13 of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 for the determination of the financial contribution from the EGF. The European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of a financial contribution of EUR 2 623 200 to be granted on the basis of an application submitted by Finland. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is our consistent practice to vote in favour of releasing funds from the globalisation adjustment fund because they certainly constitute a kind of support for laid-off workers. However, we always make it clear that for us all these are not sustainable measures to protect workers. For us, an industrial policy must be long-term, state-supported and ensure that support for workers is not fragmented, as is the case here. The State's strategy should be based on long-term plans for continuing education and retraining of workers in various key areas of state investment.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this application for assistance for EUR 4 372 000 from the EGF for some 1 603 workers made redundant from the computer programming and consultancy sector across the autumn of 2014 and spring of 2015. The redundancies concerned 69 enterprises with almost half of them occurring in Microsoft Mobile. The ICT sector, while growing globally, has been badly affected by globalisation across the EU and particularly in Finland where in 2008, the technology industry employed a total of 326 000 people but the number of people employed by such companies in 2014 was 276 000 equalling an average decline of about 3% or 10 000 workers annually. The previous decisions of Nokia and Microsoft towards offshoring, closing down production and stopping development work in Finland has had a significant impact on downstream providers and the Finnish software industry in general. The assistance will go towards providing the redundant workers with job-seeking training, individual job coaching, vocational re-education and training in sectors with high employment and start-up grants and the promotion of entrepreneurship among other supports.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote for this report because in recent years the distribution of ICT sector employment between the Union and other economies has developed to the detriment of the Union and underlines that while in 2008, the technology industry employed a total of 326 000 people in Finland, the number of people employed by such companies in 2014 was 276 000, which corresponds to an average decline per year of about 3 % (10 000 workers). The events giving rise to these redundancies are the developments affecting Nokia in recent years, which have had a major impact on the ICT sector in Finland. Whereas developing and designing operating systems for Nokia mobile phones used to employ thousands of Finnish people, these functions have now been transferred to countries outside Europe. These redundancies will further aggravate the unemployment situation in the ICT sector in regions struggling with a high unemployment rate. The proposed measures, which aim at creating new businesses, will foster entrepreneurship and services for new entrepreneurs.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Finland had applied for assistance to a distressed computer company. This should be done by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; this is nothing more than a euphemistic expression for subsidies. I believe that it is up to the companies themselves to compete in the global market for computer programming. When the German companies Zuse, Nixdorf, Triumph-Adler, Siemens, Telefunken withdrew from the computer business, no one helped them either. It was a matter of course for me to vote against it with my colleagues from alfa! Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, or by the thraw of the global financial and economic crisis, as a result of globalisation, and by self-employed persons who have ceased their activities as a result of another global financial and economic crisis. On 12 June 2015, Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer programming' following redundancies in the regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusima, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois-ja Itä-Suomi in Finland. Further information was added in accordance with Article 8(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013. The application shall comply with the requirements laid down in Article 13 of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 for the determination of the financial contribution from the EGF. The European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of a financial contribution of EUR 2 623 200 to be granted on the basis of an application submitted by Finland. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on Finland’s computer programing industry enabling an EGF contribution for the workers made redundant in that sector.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13. An interinstitutional agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial management, submitted by Finland, after 1 603 workers were made redundant in 69 companies.  I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund needs to be mobilised as soon as possible and work on the reintegration of workers into the labour market. The conditions referred to in Article 4(1) of the EGF Regulation are met, therefore Finland, in accordance with that Regulation, is entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 2 623 200. Globalisation has led to serious difficulties in individual Member States, and in this regard I believe that the European Union needs to have adequate mechanisms in place to mitigate the consequences of such situations and to help the countries concerned.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The Zanni report (EFDD) concerns the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help laid-off workers in Finland. This Fund can be mobilised to help workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector, or changes in the economic structures of Member States caused by globalisation and free trade. A link must be made between layoffs and the economic and financial crisis.  The aim is to make a contribution of 2.636 million euros for the reintegration into the labour market of 1,200 workers laid off by 69 companies in the computer programming sector in Finland. Finland is facing a competitiveness crisis linked to high labour costs and the impossibility of devaluing to counter competition from emerging countries, particularly in the telecommunications sector.  This post-aid mechanism is beneficial, even if it only wipes out the disastrous economic policy imposed by the EU. I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Finland submitted an EGF application for the redundancies of 1 603 employees.  As a result of this, Finland is entitled to EUR 2 623 200 million to deal with the redundancies, which in total are costing EUR 4 372 000 million. This allocation contributes towards 60% of the cost. The application was finalised on the 6 November 2015.  The ICT industry employed 326 000 employees and in 2014 this amount declined to 276 000; the blame is directed towards the massive decline in sales relating to Nokia electronic communications and competition from Asian nations that produce similar communication products. Mobilisation of the workforce and access to British jobs will form part of the package. The European jobs mobility portal known as EURES will be used to access the British jobs market.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Marco Zanni's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at Finland's request for sacked employees. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, established in 2006, helps people who have lost their jobs. This fund will release for this case an envelope of 2,623,200 euros for 1,603 sacked employees. This amount will be used to fund training, counselling or hiring bonuses to encourage the recruitment of these laid-off workers. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of payments from the Adjustment Fund to Finland. The IT industry has been subject to major upheavals, which have resulted in the falling of many jobs. These jobs must be preserved, and I think the proposed measures will be helpful.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. Finland has applied for assistance to a distressed computer company under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). The ALFA rejects this instrument on the grounds of principle. In this way, tasks are to be carried out first of all at Member State level in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. The EU will not be responsible until this leads to improvement and simplification. It is not apparent that payments from the European Globalisation Fund (EGF) meet these requirements. Moreover, this instrument tends to support large companies, while small firms do not benefit, although they also face the challenges of globalisation. That is why I voted against the motion.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. On 12 June 2015, Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer programming' following redundancies in the regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusima, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois-ja Itä-Suomi in Finland. Further information was added in accordance with Article 8(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013. The application shall comply with the requirements laid down in Article 13 of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 for the determination of the financial contribution from the EGF. The European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of a financial contribution of EUR 2 623 200 to be granted on the basis of an application submitted by Finland. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support to people losing their jobs due to globalisation. This report, concerns the case of 1 603 redundancies from Finland. Finland is specialised in computer software industry and its small enterprises are severely affected by the globalisation and international crisis. I voted in favour of this report, since the aim of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is to respond to the massive delocalisation that Finland is facing in the sector of ICT.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we all know, the major structural changes in world trade and the economic crisis are greater for workers, and the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) plays a leading role in this context. Finland applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following 1,603 redundancy payments made in 69 companies. In view of the fact that the request for assistance meets the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, I have decided to vote in favour of the report, which offers concrete help to these workers in difficulty.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Finland to support the reintegration into the labour market of laid-off workers in 69 companies in the IT sector. The Finnish authorities claim that the redundancies in question are rooted in Nokia's developments in recent years, which have had a major impact on the IT sector in Finland. While the development of computer systems for this company gave work to thousands of Finns, these activities have now been transferred to non-European countries.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MEPs voted for the allocation of 2.636 million euros, as it aims to help 1,200 workers made redundant in Finland in the IT sector to reintegrate into the world of work.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help laid-off workers in Finland. The Globalization Adjustment Fund can be mobilised to provide assistance to workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector, or changes in the economic structures of Member States caused by globalisation and free trade. A link must be made between layoffs and the economic and financial crisis.  In this case, the aim is to generate a contribution of EUR 2.636 million for the reintegration into the labour market of 1,200 workers laid off by 69 companies in the computer programming sector in Finland.  Indeed, Finland is facing an unprecedented competitiveness crisis linked to high labour costs and the impossibility of devaluing to counter competition from emerging countries, particularly in the telecommunications sector.  While this post-aids mechanism may appear to be a compassionate step to compensate for the EU's disastrous economic policies, it seems essential to the retraining of workers who do not have to suffer the consequences of these policies. So I logically voted for this text.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. 'Globalisation is inevitable and goes hand in hand with the opening of new markets, with international competition, with economic growth and with job creation. The flip side of this is job losses in less competitive sectors. The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament understands the objectives of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), but also pays attention to the taxpayer who pays the bill. Moreover, social policy should be primarily a competence of the Member States. A European transfer union is not a panacea to tackle unemployment. In particular, structural reforms are needed to return to economic growth. The MEPs of the N-VA have therefore abstained from voting on this matter.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. On 6 November, the Finnish authorities submitted the application for the EGF financial contribution on 12 June 2015, and on 6 November the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilizing the EGF for Finland to support nearly 1,200 dismissed workers.  Both Parliament and the Commission agree that all established criteria are met. EGF funding is earmarked for a wide range of measures for laid-off workers, including measures to support entrepreneurship, start-up aid and entrepreneurship guidance measures and services for new entrepreneurs. I would point out that the Finnish authorities confirm that eligible measures are not assisted by other Union financial instruments and I also stress that the financial contribution of the EGF will comply with the Union's procedural and substance rules on public aid. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. Finland had applied for assistance to a distressed computer company. This should be done by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; this is nothing more than a euphemistic expression for subsidies. I believe that it is up to the companies themselves to compete in the global market for computer programming. When the German companies Zuse, Nixdorf, Triumph-Adler, Siemens, Telefunken withdrew from the computer business, no one helped them either. It was a matter of course for me to vote against it with my colleagues from alfa!

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 One company's problems cannot be solved by taking money from more successful competitors and employees and redistributing it elsewhere.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported MEP Marco Zanni's report to provide funding from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for surplus workers in the IT sector in Finland. Although this industry is growing, production in Europe is falling due to countries such as China and Taiwan allowing cheaper labour and lower costs.  In June this year, Finland requested the mobilisation of a 2.6m-euro Fund to help 1 603 redundanlist workers. The requested funds will be earmarked for activities to assist laid-off workers in the recruitment process, education and training, and entrepreneurship and self-employment.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 with the aim of providing assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the effects of globalisation processes. In particular, in this case, a vote was held to provide financial assistance to 1 200 finnish former employees out of 69 companies for eur 2,623 million. As one can understand, first of all, this applies to those people who lost their jobs in connection with Nokia's decision to transfer a number of professional functions abroad, particularly to Asian countries, and in general, not the very favourable period of conjuncture faced by the company. The EGF is one of a number of EU mechanisms aimed at overcoming unemployment, returning workers to the labour market and, consequently, strengthening the economies of the Member States of the Community through increasing the competitiveness of their citizens and improving their skills.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In June 2015, Finland applied for support for the reintegration into the labour market of 1200 of the 1603 redundancies in 69 enterprises operating in the economic activity – computer programming, consultancy and related services in several NUTS level 2 regions covering the whole of Finland. The redundancies were linked to developments at Nokia in recent years, which have had a significant impact on the ICT sector in Finland. The application qualifies for a financial contribution from the EGF, which was established to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade.  The mobilisation concerns a total amount of EUR 2 623 200 from the EGF in favour of Finland.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, because it is, in my view, complete and well documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to mobilise funds for Finnish ICT workers made redundant because of the decline of Nokia.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this mobilization of the EGF, as I had already done in the EMPL committee. This mobilization will allocate EUR 2.636 million for the reintegration of 1,200 laid-off workers in the IT sector in Finland. We support this aid to workers who are suffering the consequences of Brussels policies and the international competition in which the EU is taking us.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland, in order to facilitate the reintegration into employment of workers made redundant in 69 companies operating in different regions throughout Finland. The European Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of the economic and financial crisis, and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. It is therefore necessary to ensure that the Fund supports the stable reintegration into the labour market of redundant individual employees affected by the consequences of structural changes in world trade flows.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of Mr Zanni's report. The proposal, seventeenth in last year's budget, relates to the mobilisation of the EGF Fund, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. It involves mobilising a total of EUR 2,623,200 for 1,200 of the 1,603 Finnish workers made redundant.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote in favour of mobilizing the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Finland to support the return to the labour market of laid-off workers in 69 ICT-related enterprises. The Finnish authorities say that the facts that have led to such redundancies are the changes that affected Nokia in recent years, which have had an impact on the country, so from the EU we must support these workers to find new job opportunities soon.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. A large number of workers are suffering from the consequences of far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns. The assurances given by the Finnish authorities are far-reaching and trustworthy. The proposal seems to be a tried and tested means of protecting workers. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This umpteenth case of mobilization of the European Globalisation Fund (FEAM) is once again symbolic of the evils of the European Union's industrial and trade policy. In the Union's new language, it is a question of addressing the "potential negative consequences" of free trade policy in order to better accompany it.  Sixty-nine Finnish SMEs had to shut down and lay off a total of 1,603 employees. Microsoft's 2011 takeover of Nokia has led to a wave of layoffs in subcontracting companies. This year again, we were presented with another case of a company specializing in the design of mobile and electronic products. Finland, which has a long-standing expertise in electronics and it in general, is being hit hard by relocations in this sector.  The rapporteur notes the slump and relocations to Asia, but does not criticise the EU's policy to say the least permissive with social dumping practices with devastating effects on jobs and SMEs in Europe. In the end, the FEAM therefore fulfils its role as a "relocation aid". However, I abstain so as not to deprive Finnish workers of this fund.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Zanni report (EFDD) concerns the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help laid-off workers in Finland. This Fund can be mobilised to help workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector, or changes in the economic structures of Member States caused by globalisation and free trade. A link must be made between layoffs and the economic and financial crisis.  The aim is to make a contribution of 2.636 million euros for the reintegration into the labour market of 1,200 workers laid off by sixty-nine companies in the computer programming sector in Finland. Finland is facing a competitiveness crisis linked to high labour costs and the impossibility of devaluing to counter competition from emerging countries, particularly in the telecommunications sector.  This post-aid mechanism is beneficial, even if it only wipes out the disastrous economic policy imposed by the EU. I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Created to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of structural change in world trade patterns, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund may be the subject of a mobilisation procedure in the event of a positive assessment of an application. I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland, as the Finnish authorities have provided all the necessary guarantees for the procedure in question.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the Union’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 1 200 workers in the computer programming sector in Finland due to the global financial and economic crisis.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Employment in ICT in Finland fell by 3% (approximately 10,000 workers) between 2008 and 2014, mainly due to Microsoft's acquisition of former nokia telephony leader for 5.4 billion euros, and the relocation of such companies specializing in programming, consulting and other IT activities to China, India and other non-European countries.  It is our duty to accede to Finnish demand by mobilising EUR 2.636 million to help reintegrate the 1,200 laid-off workers in this sector. Solidarity is one of the Values of the Union. I welcome the initiative of Finland, which did not wait for the mobilization of this Fund to help its workers by launching the implementation of personalised services on 1 August 2014.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund serves to support workers of Member States who have been made redundant or have ceased their gainful employment due to changes in the structure of world trade as a result of globalisation. In the case of Finland, workers in the information and communication technology sector have been made redundant, mainly as a result of Nokia's slump in the country.  The application fulfils all the conditions for its compliance, so I agree with the decision to approve the proposal. The financial contributions will be used by the country to provide seven types of measures for redundant workers.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund 2015/005 Computer Programming, from Finland. The redundancies were caused by the major structural changes in the electronics industry. The application relates to 1 603 redundancies in 69 enterprises operating in the area of computer programming/consultancy in several Finnish regions. The EGF funding of EUR 2 623 200 will contribute to helping around 1 200 redundant workers via different types of measures such as coaching, employment and business services, training, subsidies, start-up grants, etc.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to support workers affected by major structural changes in world trade and made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis and to support their reintegration into the labour market. Finland has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 1 603 redundancies from 69 companies in the 'Computer Programming, Consultancy and Related Services' sector. Finland envises seven types of measures for the dismissed workers covered by the aid: (i) consultancy and other preparatory measures, (ii) employment and business services, (iii) training, (iv) payment allowances, (v) start-up aid, (vi) incentives to start a business and services for new entrepreneurs, (vii) reimbursement of travel, accommodation and removal expenses. 1 200 redundant workers are expected to participate in the measures.  In its report, the Committee on Budgets notes that the request meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation and therefore proposes that Parliament approve the granting of a financial contribution from the EGF of EUR 2 623 200 to be granted on the basis of an application submitted by Finland. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns.  On 6 November 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Decision on mobilising the EGF in favour of Finland in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from 69 companies operating in the economic sector classified in NACE Rev. 2 division 62 ('Consultancy and related computer programming activities')(14) in several NUTS level 2 regions(15) , which cover the whole of Finland. I am voting in favour of this proposal on mobilising a total amount of EUR 2 623 200 from the EGF in favour of Finland. It concerns 1 200 of the 1 603 workers made redundant.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Zanni report concerns the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help laid-off workers in Finland. In this case, the aim is to generate a contribution of EUR 2.636 million for the reintegration into the labour market of 1,200 workers laid off by 69 companies in the computer programming sector in Finland.  Indeed, Finland is facing an unprecedented competitiveness crisis linked to high labour costs and the impossibility of devaluing to counter competition from emerging countries, particularly in the telecommunications sector.  While this post-aids mechanism may appear to be a compassionate step to compensate for the EU's disastrous economic policies, it seems essential to the retraining of workers who do not have to suffer the consequences of these policies. So I voted for it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Labour MEPs have always voted in favour of EGF applications and these applications are no different. It is also worth noting that opportunities for the UK to claim from this fund may arise in the near future and the EGF could help those made redundant and wider communities affected by large shocks to the local economy. In addition, the EGF can do this whilst minimising the cost to the UK Government.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF). Between July 2014 and April 2015, 1,603 employees were laid off from 69 IT companies in Finland. The aim is to mobilise 2.6 million euros to help support these employees.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, established in 2006, helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalisation (business closures, relocation). It is intended to intervene in the event of mass redundancies in a particular sector or by a company with at least 500 employees and has a budget of 150 million euros for the period 2014-2020.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported mr Zanni's report, as I believe that the rapid mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the benefit of 1,200 workers made redundant at Computer Programming, a Finnish technology company, is desirable. I believe it is essential that, on the basis of the principle of solidarity between countries, the European Union intervenes in support of Eu ropean citizens in difficulty.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As shadow rapporteur I voted for this report that will bring an EGF contribution of EUR 2 623 200 to 1 603 workers made redundant in the ICT sector of Finland.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. – With the Globalisation Fund, the European Union has a budgetary instrument that provides financial support to workers affected by the far-reaching global structural changes in world trade patterns. This fund starts exactly where society needs it most, which is why I would have voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In Finland, a large number of people have become unemployed due to changes in NOKIA, with the Fund supporting them in their return to the labour market.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report and support the proposal for financial support for a Finnish company.  Support for redundant workers is necessary. It must be dynamic and accessible as quickly and effectively as possible. It should be noted that the ICT sector was at the heart of the region's economy. The high number of redundancies has had a particularly negative impact on employment levels and the local economy and has had dire social consequences. It is therefore necessary to help redundant workers to change their qualifications, create a business or find a new job as soon as possible.  It is to be welcomed that the Finnish Government acted expeditiously and itself began to provide services tailored to individual needs for the affected workers, without waiting for a decision on egf support. It should be noted that the financial support provided will help to re-plan and implement career measures, have led to retraining and improvement of job search skills.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Finland submitted an EGF application for the redundancies of 1 603 employees.  As a result of this, Finland is entitled to EUR 2 623 200 million to deal with the redundancies, which in total are costing EUR 4 372 000 million. This allocation contributes towards 60% of the cost. The application was finalised on 6 November 2015.  The ICT industry employed 326 000 employees and in 2014 this amount declined to 276 000; the blame is directed towards the massive decline in sales relating to Nokia electronic communications and competition from Asian nations that produce similar communication products. Mobilisation of the workforce and access to British jobs will form part of the package. The European jobs mobility portal known as EURES will be used to access the British jobs market.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis of recent years has significantly changed the structural characteristics of world trade. In Europe, efforts have been made to remedy this by setting up a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which aims to provide additional support to workers who have suffered most from these changes. Convinced that this is one of the most appropriate means by which Europe expresses its support for disadvantaged groups of workers, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Finnish economy has suffered a major blow with the development of the ICT sector in countries rich in low labour and a liberal and deregulated labour legislation system. The combination of such preconditions on the labour market and easy access to cheap raw materials has enabled the rapid positioning of foreign companies on the world market. As a consequence, job losses occur in countries whose labour legislation or dependence on raw materials induse higher operating costs.  Finland's ICT sector has suffered a major blow with the closure of Noquia, with cumulative staff cuts in the ICT sector worrying. I support this request for disbursement of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as there are 1 603 workers and the requested amount is EUR 2 623 000. A fee of EUR 1 636 per worker can help to adapt to the new living situation in the short term, and in the total amount available to the fund, the total amount represents the minimum part.  In this way, we show solidarity towards Finland, and especially towards its inhabitants. We must show unity in mutual help and perseverance in promoting the spirit of communion. This case is part of the systemic problem of adapting the European economy to new global developments, and it is essential to show unity in efforts to protect EU citizens throughout the process.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Zanni report concerns the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help laid-off workers in Finland. In this case, the aim is to generate a contribution of EUR 2.636 million for the reintegration into the labour market of 1,200 workers laid off by 69 companies in the computer programming sector in Finland.  Indeed, Finland is facing an unprecedented competitiveness crisis linked to high labour costs and the impossibility of devaluing to counter competition from emerging countries, particularly in the telecommunications sector. If this post-fact aid mechanism is never just a sad compassionate problem to compensate for the disastrous economic policies of the EU, it seems essential to the retraining of workers who do not have to suffer the consequences of these policies. So I voted for it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support redundancy workers and the self-employed who ceased their activity due to major structural changes in globalisation-in-the-world trade flows, due to the protracted global financial and economic crisis mentioned in Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 546/2009(3) or due to the new global financial and economic crisis, and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, I support the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund within the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 in order to provide EUR 4 372 000 in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations with a view to reintegration into the labour market for as many as 1 603 workers in 69 companies working in the programming industry in Finland.  Member States should show solidarity with each other when necessary and the Commission must assist them in doing so in order to spend the funds in the most equest and transparent way.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I agree with MEP Marco Zanni's report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund submitted by Finland. In the European Union, the recession has hit the information and communication sector hard, in particular the electronics industry sector in Finland, whose large number of IT companies have shifted their operations to countries with a cheaper labour price and as a result a large number of Finnish citizens have lost their jobs.  As many as 1 603 Finnish citizens lost their jobs in the computer programming sector between 30 July 2014 and 30 April 2015. The reason for the layoffs is the massive move of businesses operating in the said sector to countries with lower labour prices such as China and India. In the Helsinki region alone, 737 workers were laid off.  As a result, the intervention criteria were met and Finland acquired the right to use the globalisation adjustment fund. The proposed measures include encouraging entrepreneurship through company start-up grants, subsidising wage benefits and free training that will reduce unemployment in the sector.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in relation to Finland's EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer Programming application to make a financial contribution to the ICT (Information and Communication Technologies) sector. This application was made following 1,603 redundancies by 69 companies. In recent years, the software production sector has experienced serious difficulties due, in particular, to relocation to non-European countries, a cessation of production and a break in development activities. Some companies have been forced to close their production plants and restructure their workforces, resulting in a large number of redundancies. I hope that the mobilisation of the EGF, amounting to EUR 2 623 200, will prove to be a decisive instrument for supporting these workers and a valuable aid for companies affected by the crisis in the computer programming sector.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this mobilization of almost 2.5 million euros. The process of globalisation has opened Up European markets to international competition, leading to economic and structural changes for our companies. The EU has set up a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to mitigate the effects of globalisation on European economies, but especially on workers. Also, it was important to mark European solidarity with this country and this company.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Finland submitted an EGF application for the redundancies of 1 603 employees.  As a result of this, Finland is entitled to EUR 2 623 200 million to deal with the redundancies, which in total are costing EUR 4 372 000 million. This allocation contributes towards 60% of the cost. The application was finalised on 6 November 2015.  The ICT industry employed 326 000 employees and in 2014 this amount declined to 276 000; the blame is directed towards the massive decline in sales relating to Nokia electronic communications and competition from Asian nations that produce similar communication products. Mobilisation of the workforce and access to British jobs will form part of the package. The European jobs mobility portal known as EURES will be used to access the British jobs market.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. During this session, I voted in favour of Finland's request for a financial contribution under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (WEF) following layoffs in the ICT (information and communication technology) sector.  Unfortunately, in recent years, several companies in this sector in Europe have been relocated to China, India, Taiwan and other non-European destinations.  The case of Finland is even more dramatic since between 2008 and 2014, the technology industry in Finland saw its number of workers decrease by 50,000 people. In 2014 alone, the number of companies operating in the ICT sector in Finland decreased by 3%, to 1,500 people.  In view of these elements, it seemed to me quite normal to give Finland a financial contribution under the WEF in order to help the many workers in this sector. The amount raised would be EUR 2,623,200, or 60% of the total cost of the proposed shares.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Recent developments that have affected Nokia in recent years and which concern, inter among others, the relocation of the development and design functions of Nokia mobile phones operating systems to countries outside Europe, have had a strong impact on the Finnish economy, especially in the important information and communication technology sector. As a result of these problems at Nokia, 1 603 workers were laid off from a universe of 69 companies operating in the economic sector of consulting and computer programming activities. To cope with this high level of redundancies in this sector, Finland has applied for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, totaling €2 623 200 to support the reintegration of redundant workers into the labour market. Having met this application in the necessary conditions for mobilising the fund and being channelled entirely into supporting the newly unemployed - in particular for coaching, employment and business services, training, recruitment grants and entrepreneurship - I have given my vote in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Finland, as the request for assistance meets the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation. Finland will receive a total of EUR 2,623,200 in aid to promote the reintegration into working life of 1,063 workers made redundant by 69 Finnish companies.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this dossier as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation to address the situation of dismissed workers, in this case in Finland in the computer sector. These are measures that would leave the workers concerned worse if they did not exist. The vote in favour, however, does not hide the view that such measures are 'bread for today and hunger for tomorrow', whereas the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Secondly, such an alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive and energy model, and not mechanisms that ultimately facilitate applicants (Member States and derived from the undertakings concerned) to dismantle sectors, without considering measures such as the repayment of subsidies received by companies, or the reporting of possible reopening in new territories that may contribute to the competitive devaluation.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 2 623 200 following the dismissal of 1 603 workers in 69 companies operating in Finland, in division 62 of NACE Revision 2, Programming, consulting and other IT-related activities. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these workers in Finland, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK does not receive money from this fund so in principle I voted against this.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There were 1 603 redundancies in 69 enterprises operating in the area of computer programming and consultancy in many Finnish regions. This amount of redundancies over a short amount of time can only be attributed to a movement of demand away from these enterprises, either due to these services being provided elsewhere or a loss of interest in this industry. And I don’t suspect it is the latter. The EGF is something that the Tories want to see abolished for ideological reasons. All this while there have been various opportunities for the UK to apply for this funding, with the most recent example being the closure of the steel industry in the UK. I voted in favour of this request because we should show solidarity with the workers of Finland, because it is without a doubt that workers in the UK will need to access these funds, and the EGF can help those who are made redundant by the effects of globalisation and without much cost to the UK Government.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was established to provide support to workers made redundant and to self-employed persons who have ceased their activities due to serious structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, the continuation of the global financial and economic crisis or the new global financial and economic crisis, and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. On 12 June 2015, Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF as a result of redundancies in 69 companies operating in the computer programming, consultancy and related services sector. Finland's request was for a financial contribution of EUR 2,623 million, which would have been for 1200 out of a total of 1603 redundancies. Redundant workers are to receive staffing services consisting of seven types of measures – expert advice and other preparatory measures, employment and entrepreneurship services, training, wage subsidies, start-up grants, business support and services for new entrepreneurs, and contributions to travel, overnight and moving costs.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. Finland had applied for assistance to a distressed computer company.
