This should be done by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; this is nothing more than a euphemistic expression for subsidies. I believe that it is up to the companies themselves to compete in the global computer programming market. When the German companies Zuse, Nixdorf, Triumph-Adler, Siemens, Telefunken withdrew from the computer business, no one helped them either. It was a matter of course for me to agree with my colleagues from the ALFA on the other hand!

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Finland has highlighted the complicated situation of workers in the information and communication technology sector who face difficulties in finding their jobs during the economic crisis and current global trend. Thanks to their personal approach, the proposed programme will help them find a way to successfully apply in the current labour market. The project will be co-financed by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF).

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this proposal as the European Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade flows or the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  Finland submitted an EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer programming application for an EGF financial contribution after 1 603 workers were made redundant in 69 companies operating under Section 62. classification of economic activities NACE Revision 2 (Computer programming, consulting and related services), and since the requirement meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation, I supported it.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund which will provide much needed financial contributions following the cuts in the Finnish ICT sector. 1 603 workers in the ICT sector were made redundant in 69 enterprises across Finland and the funding granted from the EU will aim to support those affected through, for example, coaching and preparatory measures, employment and business services, training, pay subsidies, start-up grants, steering towards entrepreneurship and services for new entrepreneurs, and allowances for travel, overnight and removal costs.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Finland submitted an EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer Programming application on 12 June 2015. The application concerns 1 603 workers made redundant in the economic sector classified in SECTION 62 of the NACE Rev. 2 (Computer programming, consulting and related activities).  Redundancies occurred in the Länsi-Suomi (FI19), Helsinki-Uusimaa (FI1B), Etelä-Suomi (FI1C) and Pohjois Itä-Suomi (FI1D) regions of NUTS 2. A total of 69 companies laid off workers, and Microsoft Mobile Oy laid off almost half of the total number of redundancies (778 of them). At the same time as submitting this proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF, the Commission will submit a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council to transfer eur 2 623 200 to the relevant budget line. I support this proposal because I consider it essential to support redundant and self-employed workers who have ceased their activity. The EGF should therefore be mobilised to help these workers re-enter the labour market.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I find the redistribution of money for job creation counterproductive.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds: the role of Finland - FI/Computer Programming. Globalisation brings many advantages, but it also brings many pitfalls. In the information and communication sector, the employment distribution has been growing in recent years to the detriment of the European Union at the expense of other economies, while in Finland employment in this sector decreases by around 3 % each year. In particular, the region where this sector has historically been the main support pillar of the economy has been affected by the redundancies. I support the granting of a financial contribution of EUR 2 623 200 to offer assistance to the workers made redundant as soon as possible.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, I do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies, nor do I believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore I voted against.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is our consistent practice to vote in favour of the amounts released from the globalisation adjustment fund because they certainly constitute a kind of support for laid-off workers. However, we always make it clear that, for us, they are not sustainable measures to protect workers. For us, an industrial policy must be long-term, state-supported and ensure that support for workers is not fragmented, as is the case here. The State's strategy should be based on long-term plans for continuing education and retraining of workers in various key areas of state investment.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. On 12 June 2015, Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer programming' following redundancies in the regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusima, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois-ja Itä-Suomi in Finland. Further information was added in accordance with Article 8(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013. The application shall comply with the requirements laid down in Article 13 of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 for the determination of the financial contribution from the EGF. The European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of a financial contribution of EUR 2 623 200 to be granted on the basis of an application submitted by Finland.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Nokia has low batteries and Finland goes into recession again. The collapse of a giant that billed 4% of the country's GDP and today finds itself with little skills and innovations to compete in the smartphone market. We in the M5S support and voted in favour of the call for the mobilisation of the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of changes in world trade and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. We welcome the fact that the Finnish authorities have proposed a wide variety of measures for redundant workers and we believe that finland's request fulfils all the conditions for obtaining a financial contribution.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The current report concerns the mobilisation of the EU Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for a total amount of EUR 2 623 200 for the 1 603 workers made redundant in 69 enterprises operating in regions covering the whole of Finland. The EGF aims to enable a rapid, efficient and flexible response to emergency situations I therefore welcome the speedy evaluation period for this application, which was less than five months. I also welcome the measures taken by the Finnish Government to use this application for providing redundant workers with coaching and training, pay subsidies, start-up grants, and other means that steer towards entrepreneurship. I view that as an important step to tackle the decline in the ICT sector Finland has experienced in the past years. The EGF is an important legislative and budgetary instrument the Union has to provide additional support to workers across the Union, who are suffering from the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis and to assist their reintegration into the labour market. For this reason I voted in favour of this current report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to provide support to laid-off and self-employed workers who are out of work due to major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalisation, the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis or a new global financial and economic crisis, and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. So I voted in favour of that plan.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Finland submitted its application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in June 2015 in order to deal with redundancies in its information technology sector. Finland argues that employment in its ICT sector shrunk as a result of businesses and services relocating to China, India, Taiwan and other non-European countries. While in 2008 the technology industry employed a total of 326 000 people in Finland, the number of people employed by such companies in 2014 was 276 000. In 2014 alone, the number of staff in Finnish ICT companies was reduced by 3 % or 1 500 people. I supported the mobilisation of the fund, which will provide Finland with EUR 2 623 200. The contribution will be used to improve opportunities for the jobseekers to find new employment.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the thraw of the global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. On 12 June 2015, Finland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer programming' following redundancies in the regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusima, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois-ja Itä-Suomi in Finland.  Further information was added in accordance with Article 8(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013. The application shall comply with the requirements laid down in Article 13 of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 for the determination of the financial contribution from the EGF. The European Parliament therefore supported by a large majority the disbursement of a financial contribution of EUR 2 623 200 to be granted on the basis of an application submitted by Finland. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against Finland's request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the computer programming sector with a total amount of €4.3 million, of which €2.6 million should be from the Fund. While in principle I support the idea of taking measures to help economic growth and job creation, I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not a valid instrument to achieve these objectives.  While this sector is on the rise globally, there have been redundancies across Finland of 1,603 workers made redundant in different companies. In Europe, including Finland, the computer sector is in decline due to the relocation of businesses and services to non-European countries such as China, India and Taiwan. This clearly shows that the proposed measures cannot help Finland in the long term in reducing the unemployment rate or recovering the sector in question - the same can only be achieved by reducing bureaucratic barriers and tax burdens.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 Report on The Use of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: the role of Finland – EGF/2015/005, as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is intended to support workers who have become redundant as a result of major structural changes in global trade flows resulting from globalisation, the ongoing global financial and economic crisis or the new global financial and economic crisis.  The Fund also applies to self-employed persons who have abandoned their activity for the same reasons, as well as to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. This was also the case with the Finnish application.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this dossier as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation to address the situation of dismissed workers, in this case in Finland in the computer sector. These are measures that would leave the workers concerned worse if they did not exist. The vote in favour, however, does not hide the view that such measures are 'bread for today and hunger for tomorrow', whereas the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Secondly, such an alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive and energy model, and not mechanisms that ultimately facilitate applicants (Member States and derived from the undertakings concerned) to dismantle sectors, without considering measures such as the repayment of subsidies received by companies, or the reporting of possible reopening in new territories that may contribute to the competitive devaluation.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The Globalization Adjustment Fund can be mobilized to provide assistance to workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector, or changes in the economic structures of Member States caused by globalisation and free trade. Finland is also facing an unprecedented competitiveness crisis linked to high labour costs and the impossibility of devaluing to counter competition from emerging countries, particularly in the telecommunications sector.  While this post-aids mechanism may appear to be a compassionate step to compensate for the EU's disastrous economic policies, it seems essential to the retraining of workers who suffer the consequences of these policies. I voted for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The current proposal would help 1 603 redundant workers to reintegrate into the labour market. I voted in favour of the request, of course.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this dossier as it promotes funds aimed at compensating for and establishing compensation measures in cases of relocation to address the situation of dismissed workers, in this case in Finland in the computer sector. These are measures that would leave the workers concerned worse if they did not exist. The vote in favour, however, does not hide the view that such measures are 'bread for today and hunger for tomorrow', whereas the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Secondly, such an alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive and energy model, and not mechanisms that ultimately facilitate applicants (Member States and derived from the undertakings concerned) to dismantle sectors, without considering measures such as the repayment of subsidies received by companies, or the reporting of possible reopening in new territories that may contribute to the competitive devaluation.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree with the decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Finland to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in 69 enterprises. The conclusions showed, in accordance with all applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation, that the application meets the conditions for a financial contribution from the EGF and the Finnish authorities have provided all necessary assurances. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and this decision refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 2 623 200 from the EGF for Finland. It concerns 1 200 out of 1 603 workers made redundant.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a fund that has been created to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes due to global market changes. This is the 17th request made within the 2015 budget and is trying to respond to the situation in Finland, which has seen a large decline in the number of employees in the technology sector as a result of the crisis in the telecommunications sector, especially in relation to Nokia. Any action to help European citizens in such a situation is welcome, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of such mobilisation.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I have chosen to support this proposal. Given the large number of redundancies in Finland in the ICT sector, mainly as a result of the reforms at Nokia in recent years, I believe these measures are appropriate, so that entrepreneurship in Finland can be promoted and the finns affected can quickly switch to a new job.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The redundancies are located in the regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusimaa, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois-ja Itä—Suomi.  In recent years, the distribution of employment in the ICT sector between the EU and other economies has evolved negatively for the EU as companies and services have been transferred to countries such as China, India, Taiwan and other destinations outside Europe. These effects were felt especially in Finland where the entire electronics industry was severely affected, culminating in Nokia's announcement in 2011. In these circumstances, the consultancy sector and related computer programming activities continued to strive to remain competitive globally, even though the main recipient of its services had disappeared.  Redundancies also affect workers over 50 years of age, a group that finds it difficult to find new jobs, and more than 50% of these workers may be unemployed for long-term by June 2016.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. A large number of workers are suffering from the consequences of far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns. The assurances given by the Finnish authorities are far-reaching and trustworthy. The proposal seems to be a tried and tested means of protecting workers. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - Application from Finland – EGF/2015/005 FI/Computer Programming. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important European support tool for workers affected by the effects of globalisation. The countries of the European South, which also face the biggest problem, should make the most of the provisions of this Fund.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report on the application to mobilise the Globalisation Adjustment Fund by the Finnish company Computer programming. Although I believe that people who have lost their jobs as a result of globalisation changes in world trade need to be helped, not to mention the situation in which we count the redundancies to hundreds, the Globalisation Adjustment Fund is not, in my opinion, the right means. While the Fund itself provides funding for active measures to help redundant workers to be employed, there are no in-depth analyses of the impact of the aid granted from the Fund, which would give sufficient comparative results and, where there are evidence that the success of the Fund and thus the success of redundant workers in finding a new job vary, in the range of 4 % to 86 %, the conclusions signalling that workers have the best chance of being employed, even if it were not for measures financed by the Fund. On the contrary, workers with lower education, older age or living in an area with fewer job opportunities have the least chance. I therefore believe that the fund does not create sufficient added value and, with the help of the funds currently being spent on the fund, we would be able to find more effective solutions for redundant workers.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application concerns 1 603 workers made redundant in the consultancy sector and related activities of computer programming. The redundancies are located in the regions of Länsi-Suomi, Helsinki-Uusimaa, Etelä-Suomi and Pohjois-ja Itä—Suomi. The redundancies occurred in 69 companies, with Microsoft Mobile accounting for almost half (778). Northern Ostrobótnia is a region with a high unemployment rate (higher than the national average). In Uusimaa, at the end of February 2015, the unemployed accounted for 11% of the workforce. In the reference period, 49 software companies resorted to cooperation negotiations in the Uusimaa region, and it is estimated that 1 681 jobs were needed.  The total contribution requested to the EGF amounts to EUR 2 623 200 (60 % of total costs). We agree with the mobilisation of this aid, but we still point out that this fund represents only limited support for those targeted by the consequences of the liberalisation of world trade, and measures are needed to halt the course of neoliberal policies which have once again led to this outcome.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – I voted for this report because I support the idea of promoting innovation and growth through more accessible and more efficient trademark registration systems for all European citizens. In the Union, a trade mark may be registered either at national, country or Union level. This report implies coexistence and complementarity between national and European trademark systems in order to make them more efficient for businesses in reducing costs and complexity and shortening the time it takes to register such trademarks. It will also increase predictability and legal certainty.  This Commission initiative does not involve a new system, but a modernisation and harmonisation of the trade mark registration system. I support this agreement, which supports most of the interests of users. However, we must be cautious about its implementation and ensure that it does not lead to high procedural costs for citizens of various countries of the Union.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to reformulate the EU Trade Marks Regulation, as well as the Directive relating to the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. This report and the following are parts of a renewal package for the entire trademark system at European level. The basic functioning of the trademark system is as follows: a producer of a good or service who intends to protect the name and general characteristics of his product has to register his mark at both national and European levels, defining the essential name and characteristics of his product. This registration allows the producer or company to be protected against copying, counterfeiting or non-authorization. The purpose of this report is to harmonise, through a Regulation, the way in which trade marks are registered at European level. Among other aspects, it provides for a significant reduction in the cost of online registration fees. The report contains positive aspects, but also others that raise reserves, such as the blocking system, which does not exclude generic medicines. That's why I abstained.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The Council adopted its position at first reading on the reform of the European trademark system.  The proposed reform includes a lower level of taxes, the establishment of a compensation mechanism allowing Member States to recover the costs of setting up services and procedures related to the application of the EU trademark, as well as the rationalisation of various technical provisions and closer cooperation between the Office and national offices. It must be noted that there has been an increase in the grounds for refusing appellations of origin and geographical indications, thus allowing greater protection for the economic operators concerned. There has also been an increase in the absolute reasons for refusing appellations of origin, geographical indications, traditional mentions for wines, guaranteed traditional specialties and plant rights.  This text streamlines the operation of the Office. It allows for lower costs and costs for economic operators as well as greater protection. I voted against the proposal to reject the Council's position tabled by the EFDD group.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the proposal to reject the Council position, and against the creeping European Union involvement in intellectual property rights.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it facilitates the registration of a trademark in the European Union and aims in particular to better combat counterfeiting.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to ˗ reform of the trade mark registration system. The transformation would make this registration cheaper, faster and more predictable. In April this year, the Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and The new rules agreed with the Council of the EU will, at the same time, enable the relevant authorities to confiscate counterfeits transhipped through EU territory. The updated rules retain the possibility to register a trade mark either in a specific EU country or throughout the Union and offer simpler registration and the possibility of registering new brands such as sound. At the same time, the renewal fees for brand registration are being reduced.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the recommendation for the second reading of the Council's position at first reading. The JURI committee recommended that Parliament approve the Council's position at first reading without making any amendments. There is no final vote at second reading and the plenary vote was only on a rejection amendment tabled by the EFDD group. I voted against this amendment because I believe that the Council's position is moving in the right direction.  Indeed, in addition to a welcome rationalisation of the procedures and operation of OHMI (Office for the Harmonization of the Internal Market) in consultation with national bodies, this text allows for lower costs and costs for economic operators as well as greater protection for both producers and consumers.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have endorsed this Council proposal, which aims to promote innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems more accessible to businesses across the EU and more efficient, making them less complex and cheaper but also faster, more predictable and legally safer.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on this report on trade marks in the EU. We understand that it is essential to protect the business fabric with a brand system that meets new challenges and accelerated globalization. But we also understand that, in this context where it is not clear what the system of blocking certain products could be – assuming, moreover, that large companies would never have problems but small businessiers would, we cannot vote in favour of giving a blank cheque to a system that needs some points clarified.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of updating the protection of European trade marks, which seeks to promote the fight against counterfeiting and facilitate the registration of new teachings on the market. It is a set of measures already provisionally agreed between Parliament and the Member States, which promote the harmonisation of national and European trademark registration systems. These new rules will give greater protection to users and at the same time we have safeguarded freedom of expression, the right to parody or artistic freedom, as well as access to medicines in developing countries. The legislative amendment also proposes greater efficiency in the registration of trademarks, cheaper for SMEs, as well as changes in the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (OHIM), which will be renamed the European Union Intellectual Property Office.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the rejection amendment tabled by the EFDD group on the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading on the reform of the European trademark system. This reform includes a proposal for a directive, which brings with it measures that benefit our businesses, such as a lower level of tax, or the establishment of a compensation mechanism allowing Member States to recover the costs of setting up services and procedures related to the application of the European Union's trademark.  In addition, the absolute grounds for refusal will be extended to appellations of origin, geographical indications, traditional mentions for cities, guaranteed traditional specialties and plant breeding rights, as well as the extension of grounds for refusal to appellations of origin and geographical indications; this allows for better protection for the economic operators concerned, which is a good thing. Finally, the Commission's text is in the direction of streamlining the Agency's operating procedures, which allows for lower costs and costs. I could therefore only oppose the amendment rejecting the EFDD group and support the Council's position.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The main objective of this proposal is to drive innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems more accessible and efficient across the EU.  The revision of the Community Trade Mark Regulation, (EC) No 207/2009, which is the only current legal instrument in terms of intellectual property rights controlled at European level, aims to adapt terminology, computerise application procedures and register a European trade mark, to increase legal certainty by clarifying the rules and to create an appropriate framework for cooperation between the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (OHIM) and national offices, so that common tools are developed in accordance with Article 290 TFEU. That is why I voted in favour of this Recommendation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported parliament's amendment of EU legislation on the EU trade mark. Council Regulations established in 2009 a specific framework for the protection of trade marks in the European Union, which provides for the protection of trade marks at European Union level in parallel with trade mark protection at Member State level under national trade mark schemes. Experience gained since the establishment of the Community trade mark system has shown that union and third-country undertakings have adopted the system and have become a successful and viable alternative to trade mark protection at Member State level and a system that complements this protection. However, national trade marks continue to be necessary for undertakings which do not wish to protect their trade marks at Union level or which are unable to obtain Union-wide protection, but which are able to obtain national protection without hindrance.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objective of the proposal is to promote economic growth and innovation by improving the efficiency and access to trade mark registration. The revision of the Regulation is in order to align the terminology of the legislation with the language of the Treaty of Lisbon for decentralised agencies in the Union and to rationalise and simplify the system and application of the European trade mark procedure, to provide new frameworks for cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies in accordance with Section 290 TSI.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposed resolution, as it is an extremely demanding and important document which, on the one hand, highlights the complex area of counterfeiting or copyright infringement and, on the other hand, the creation of competitiveness, innovation and, at the same time, simplification of procedures. The latter is often quite difficult to achieve, at the same time it is about finding and penalising law breakers and simplifying procedures. As one of the key issues in this legislation, I would like to highlight the simplification of procedures and their price underpipment, thus improving access for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the driving force of the European economy. It's a good thing we listened to them.  I would also like to see this resolution become a good brand for both the European Parliament and Europe as a whole.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. OHIM (Office for Internal Market Harmonization) is an EU agency responsible for managing trademark and design registration systems in the 28 Member States. Its aim is to ensure uniform protection of trademarks, designs and designs throughout the Union. In addition to streamlining the procedures and operation of OHMI (Office for the Harmonization of the Internal Market), this text allows for a reduction in the costs and costs associated with registering the European Union trademark for economic operators as well as their greater protection (strengthening cases of refusal of a trademark in case of confrontation with previous rights (names of origin , geographical indications, traditional mentions)). I voted in favour of this text by voting against the rejection amendment tabled by another political group.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The provisions introducing the control of goods in transit in order to combat counterfeiting, which are currently not permitted by EU legislation, are an important legislative innovation that will help to strengthen the filtering system on goods arriving from non-European areas.  The updating of the legislation on small consignments and the one on the management of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (which will become the EU Intellectual Property Office) together with the use of financial resources deriving from European trade mark registration fees will be useful in defending the quality and work of Italian and European companies, combating counterfeiting and the illegal introduction of poor quality foreign products , and to protect the intellectual property rights of European citizens from the misappropriation of persons outside the common market.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. It is a question of voting on the sole rejection amendment, tabled by the EFDD group, on the reform of the Community trademark system. It aims to adapt the terminology to the requirements of the Lisbon Treaty and provides for a lower level of taxes as well as the establishment of a compensation mechanism allowing Member States to recover the costs associated with procedures under the application of the European Union brand. Moreover, this reform has the merit of contributing to the rationalisation of costs and to the improvement of cooperation between the Office and the national offices.  In addition, this text is intended to protect certain sectors of activity that derive their revenues from a particular know-how often linked to a geographical origin. One thinks in particular of the winemakers who will benefit more from this reform. So I voted against the rejection amendment.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Protecting the Community market from the penetration of counterfeit goods, in particular as regards internet sales, is an essential element for the Community market. The proposal seeks to strengthen cooperation between the European Union Intellectual Property Office and the offices of the Member States, which will allow the Agency to coordinate projects in the interest of the Union.  Transparency of information towards purchasers is also desirable, so that they are aware of the measures they can take against counterfeit goods affecting their union trade marks. The importance of this communication and collaboration has been demonstrated during the conclusion of several normative acts and commitments within the Union, and its efforts have been felt from the perspective of intellectual rights holders, their assets benefiting from greater protection throughout the Union. In order to strengthen the protection of registered trade marks and to combat counterfeiting of goods more effectively, without prejudice to WTO rules, in particular freedom of transit, the contractor holding a registered trade mark must be able to prevent third parties from importing goods into the territory of the Union, where those goods do not have authorisation and where they are identical to a registered European trade mark , or that purpose I can only support.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Please note that the final vote is not taken at second reading. In this case, therefore, we are only voting on the proposal to reject the EFDD Group. A majority of MEMBERS of the EP are required to reject the Council's position. Abstention vote.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 207/2009 on the Community trade mark, amending Commission Regulation (EC) No 2868/95 laying down detailed rules for the implementation of Council Regulation (EC) No 40/94 on the Community trade mark and repealing Commission Regulation (EC) No 2869/95 on the fees payable to the Office for harmonisation of the internal market (trade marks and designs). I believe that the agreement reached is important because it introduces the control of goods in transit, which is currently not permitted by Community legislation, in order to combat the occurrence of counterfeiting. But there's more. With the modernisation of the EU trade mark framework, businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises, will finally be able to count on a clear, simple, affordable registration system for the management and protection of their innovative industrial goods. In short, with the introduction of these provisions, Europe is once again doing what it should always do, namely putting the needs and interests of end users at the centre.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position subject of this report. Firstly the purpose of the report is to implement a Regulation amending and modernising the Trade Mark regime operated by the EU.  Secondly the Regulation would extend and enhance the ‘Europeanisation’ of Trade Mark law and will allow for the further accretion of power over intellectual property issues by the EU. UKIP believes that all intellectual property matters should be the preserve of the United Kingdom Parliament deciding the nature of the Trade Marks regime exclusively in the British interest.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report positively, with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Council Regulation on the Community trade mark.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal for rejection tabled by the EFDD Group which, if adopted, would have rejected the Council's position and closed the procedure. The main objective of the proposal is to foster innovation and economic growth through more accessible and efficient trade mark registration systems across the Union. The revision of the Regulation aims to adapt the terminology of the Treaty of Lisbon and the provisions of the common approach on decentralised bodies of the Union and to streamline procedures for applying for and registering a European trade mark, in order to increase legal certainty by clarifying the provisions and establishing a suitable framework for cooperation between the OHIM and the national offices for the development of common instruments and to bring the framework into line with Article 100a of the Treaty. 290 TFEED.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the proposed changes to the government structure of the Office for Harmonisation of the Internal Market are excessive in order to improve the performance of the institution in question: the changes should be mainly in the composition of the management team and in the selection of the executive director of the agency. The changes envisaged in the report are not in line with my thinking to improve the efficiency of the system. I voted against because following the measures set out in the report would not make the field in question any better and more efficient, and I think that we must do otherwise.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The main objective of the proposal is to foster innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems all over the EU more accessible and efficient. The revision of the Regulation aims to adapt the terminology of the Lisbon Treaty and the provisions to the Common Approach on Union decentralised agencies, to streamline procedures to apply for and register a European trademark, to increase legal certainty by clarifying provisions, to establish an appropriate framework for cooperation between OHIM and national offices for developing common tools, and to align the framework to Article 290 TFEU.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament voted, on 25 February 2014, the proposal for a Regulation amending Council Regulation (EC) No 207/2009 on the Community trade mark, which aims to simplify and update trade mark legislation at both national and EU level, and to make the registration of trade marks in the EU less costly, faster, more reliable and more predictable, while also increasing legal certainty for trade mark owners. This proposal consists of a regulatory package comprising a recast of Directive 2008/95/EC, which approximates member states' trade mark legislation, a revision of Regulation (EC) No 207/2009, which also contains provisions on the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market, as well as a revision of Regulation (EC) No 2869/95 on the fees payable to the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market.  I support this report approving the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the Regulation on the Community trade mark, thus following the long-awaited revision of the trade mark system in Europe.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the recognition and registration of trademarks is an incentive for innovation and economic growth. Clear rules will increase legal certainty and create better instruments for cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national trade mark protection bodies.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report and I am in favour of this new Regulation on the European Trade Mark, which aims to promote innovation and economic growth, making registration systems more accessible and efficient in the EU. I am particularly in favour of streamlining the procedures for applying for and registering a trade mark. I am sure that this new instrument will certainly serve to strengthen the competitiveness of the market.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The main objective of the proposal is to foster innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems all over the EU more accessible and efficient. The revision of the Regulation aims to adapt the terminology of the Lisbon Treaty, to streamline procedures to apply for and register a European trademark. This is an important measure to increase legal certainty by clarifying provisions, to establish an appropriate framework for cooperation between OHIM and national offices and to develop common protection tools. Our common goal is to establish an effective trademark system making the registrations accessible to SMEs and start-ups as well. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As is well known, the Community trade mark system allows companies to mark their products and services in the same way throughout the European Union. After the close of negotiations on 25 April 2015, a compromise was reached on the legislative proposal to amend the Community Trade Mark Regulation 207/2009. The compromise provides for: a rule on goods in transit that will ensure the fight against counterfeiting (one of the main points has been to ensure the regular transit of generic medicines to developing countries); compensation for expenditure incurred by national IP offices under the overall EU trade mark system (to which up to a maximum of 15% of the EU Office's budget is allocated); greater protection for consumers (who can buy products via the Internet outside the EU without running the risk of goods not being delivered to them as they are introduced into the EU in breach of trademark rights). Finally, the compromise provides for greater protection for traditional specialities guaranteed. I am voting in favour, recognising the benefits that this will bring in all the countries involved, including the reduction of costs and the complexity of procedures.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to reformulate the EU Trade Marks Regulation, as well as the Directive relating to the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. This report and the following are parts of a renewal package for the entire trademark system at European level. The basic functioning of the trademark system is as follows: a producer of a good or service who intends to protect the name and general characteristics of his product has to register his mark at both national and European levels, defining the essential name and characteristics of his product. This registration allows the producer or company to be protected against copying, counterfeiting or non-authorization. The purpose of this report is to harmonise, through a Regulation, the way in which trade marks are registered at European level. Among other aspects, it provides for a significant reduction in the cost of online registration fees. The report contains positive aspects, but also others that raise reserves, such as the blocking system, which does not exclude generic medicines. That's why I abstained.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament approved the Council's position at first reading aimed at reforming EU legislation on the Community trade mark. Community trade mark reform also adopts the terminology of the Treaty of Lisbon, and the term Community trade mark is replaced by an EU trade mark. More substantially, however, is the part of the reform in which a directive is adopted on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks; it also aims to simplify administrative procedures and trade mark registration and make the reform cheaper and more accessible. The EU expects the changes to have a positive impact on economic growth and increase the spirit of innovation. I voted in favour of the adoption of the Council position in Parliament.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report in question approves the Council’s reading on the changes being proposed to the EU’s Community Trade Mark Regulation, which represents the only current legal instrument in terms of intellectual property rights that are managed at EU level.  The most notable changes include changing references to ‘Community trademarks’ into ‘European Trade Marks’ and changing ‘The Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market’ (OHIM) to ‘European Union Intellectual Property Agency’. The revision also gives more clarity in terms of criteria for protectable marks, widening the definition, and takes measures against ordering and sale of counterfeit goods, notably via the internet. As these changes further safeguard intellectual property rights I voted in favour of this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe and support the rapporteur's view on the overall objective of the review proposed by the European Commission when it comes to the Community trade mark, namely: modernising the trade mark system in Europe, limiting divergences between the provisions of the existing regulatory framework and improving cooperation between trade mark offices.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to make trademark registration cheaper, faster and more reliable for businesses. This text proposes to revise EU legislation in this area in order to further streamline and harmonize national and European trademark registration procedures and to modernise registration requirements, for example by facilitating the registration of new types of trademarks (e.g. sounds).  In particular, the text proposes a significant reduction in taxes, a rule on the balance of goods in transit in order to ensure the fight against counterfeiting and the establishment of a general compensation mechanism, aimed at counteracting the expenditure related to national offices under the European branding system.  Considering that this report is an additional trade tool to promote and defend European products around the world, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position subject of this report. Firstly the purpose of the report is to implement a Regulation amending and modernising the Trade Mark regime operated by the EU.  Secondly the Regulation would extend and enhance the ‘Europeanisation’ of Trade Mark law and will allow for the further accretion of power over intellectual property issues by the EU. UKIP believes that all intellectual property matters should be the preserve of the United Kingdom Parliament deciding the nature of the Trade Marks regime exclusively in the British interest.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a modernisation of existing trademark registration schemes in the European Union. These measures will bring the practices of the Internal Market Harmonization Office (OHMI) together with those of the member states' national offices with a view to greater clarity and efficiency.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. In deciding to review its system of protecting EU "brands" for its businesses, particularly SMEs, the EU has just corrected a legal vacuum in its legislation. Customs authorities will now be able to ban goods with a REGISTERed EU-registered mark without authorisation. These new rules will also allow for cheaper, faster registration, and will ensure better legal certainty.  This modernization of the Community trademark system was essential to face too often unfair competition from non-EU companies.  This responds to a growing expectation of the "brands" themselves, to be better protected throughout Europe. In 2012, for example, 107,900 applications were made, double those registered 10 years earlier by the European Trademark Office. As a reminder, the branded products industry directly accounts for 21% of employment in Europe and 34% of European GDP.  Finally, it should be noted that generic medicines will be exempted under the WTO TRIPS agreements allowing them to benefit from a specific regime, which is in line with our international commitments to developing countries.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European brand. This regulation is essential for the competitiveness of the Union. While maintaining the coexistence of the European Union brand and national brands and respecting the principle of subsidiarity, the scheme provides for harmonization and simplification of trademark filing procedures. The adoption of this legislative package will modernise trademark law, adapt it to the internet world and make trademark registration easier, faster and cheaper in the European Union. Not to mention the strengthening of anti-counterfeiting means, a real cornerstone of the new system. Trademark holders will now be able to oppose the introduction of products from third countries within the EU when these products bear, without authorisation, a mark that is identical to the duly registered European trademark.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report examined the second reading recommendation of the reform on the European trademark system. By harmonising Member States' trademark laws, this report, already approved by the Commission at first reading and unchanged, proposes many changes. By changing the terminology, in accordance with the Lisbon Treaty, by lowering taxes and by setting up a system of reimbursement of costs put forward by the Member States for the implementation of this european Union brand, this report is rather encouraging. Moreover, the increased protection of appellations of origin, traditional mentions for wines or even guaranteed traditional specialties, is a long-awaited measure and supported by the National Front.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the objective of harmonising trade mark registration systems to ensure compatibility and complementarity. Such modernisation is necessary and vital to improve effective implementation. Modernising terminology, streamlining different applications and registration procedures, and improving cooperation are key to improving the current state of play. However, the budgetary issue remains a cause of political division. The return of the significant budget surplus of the OHIM back to the EU budget, no matter in what form, I consider an unnecessary, insignificant and hypocritical decision taken solely by the Ec. This is not a decision that the EC can make on its own. In fact, I believe that this money should be sent back to the national intellectual property offices for the development and promotion of the trademark system. In fact, this money will only be used for these purposes. Therefore, I am deeply concerned as to why these funds should go to the EC budget at all.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote in favour of the amendment. The amendment proposes rejecting the Council's position on the harmonisation of the laws of the Member States on trade marks and intellectual property rights, as (a) this does not adequately fill the existing legal gaps and, (b) the attempt to fully harmonise the legislation of all Member States in the long term leads to the flattening of the specificity of each of them and consequently to the homogenisation sought by the EU's powerful.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objective of the proposal is to promote economic growth and innovation by improving the efficiency and access to trade mark registration. The revision of the Regulation is in order to align the terminology of the legislation with the language of the Treaty of Lisbon for decentralised agencies in the Union and to rationalise and simplify the system and application of the European trade mark procedure, to provide new frameworks for cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies in accordance with Section 290 TSI.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The main objective of the Commission is the Commission in the proposals put forward to promote innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems across the EU more accessible and efficient. The purpose of the revision of the Regulation is to adapt the terminology of the Treaty of Lisbon, to simplify procedures for the application and registration of a European trade mark and to strengthen legal certainty in the clarification provisions, to establish an adequate framework for cooperation between OHIM and national offices for the development of common tools, and to align the reference framework with Article 290 TFEU. It is necessary to update our legislation to make the trademark protection system cheaper, faster, more accessible and more reliable, combating counterfeits and making it easier to register new teachings in the market. All this is necessary, because we must update our legislation and adapt it to the times we live in.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it lowers costs for economic operators.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of these reports is the recast of the Community Trade Mark Regulation and the Directive relating to Member States' trade mark legislation. They are part of a renewal package of the entire brand system at European level. The basic operation of the marking system is as follows: A producer of a good or service that intends to protect the name and general characteristics of its product must register its marks at both national and European levels. To do so, you must register your trade mark in the national and European registers, defining the name and essential characteristics of your product. Each type of product is affected to a "class" of products. This registration allows the producer or company to be protected against copying, forgery, non-legitimate or unauthorized use. This report aims, in particular, at harmonising through a regulation on how trade marks are registered and protected at European level. Among other things, a significant reduction in the cost of online registration fees is envisaged to register trademarks. The report contains positive aspects, but also others that give us reservations – such as the blocking system (which does not exclude generic medicines).

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Knowing that the defence of industrial and enterprises marks are important, but also being very suspicious and careful with the broadening possibilities of blocking goods through customs procurement our shadow I believed that it was preferable to abstain on the whole package.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Community trade mark regulation 207/2009 is the only existing legal instrument as regards intellectual property rights, which is managed at European Union level. The main objective of the proposal in question is to foster innovation and economic growth by make registration of trade mark systems across the EU more accessible and efficient. The revision of the Regulation aims at adapting terminology, simplifying the procedures applicable to the registration of a European trade mark, increasing legal certainty of regulations, creating an appropriate framework for cooperation between OHIM and national authorities for the development of common instruments. This system is already in operation, but it should work more efficiently and better with the current modernisation. The trade mark package is a key legal instrument to combat counterfeiting of products. Our priorities concern the preservation of public health, safety and jobs, as well as the promotion of fundamental rights. The European Parliament has also achieved lower fees of up to 37%, less bureaucracy, more efficiency and a system that benefits trademark users.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting with an atension on the proposal to reject the EFDD Group, the text of the agreement brings improvements, but there are still many developments that we hope for in order to be able to give our firm support to the text.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the EU Trademark Recommendation because it proposes to reject the Council's position on the harmonisation of the laws of the Member States on trade marks and intellectual property rights, as (a) it does not adequately fill the existing legal gaps and (b) the attempt to fully harmonise the legislation of all Member States in the long term leads to a leveling of the specificity of each of them and consequently to the homogenisation sought by the EU's strong.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Trade Marks package represents a key legal tool in order to fight against counterfeiting of products. It will foster innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems all over the EU more accessible and efficient.  The system is already in place, but with the current modernisation it will be better functional. Our priorities must be to preserve public health, safety and jobs, and to defend fundamental rights. Parliament also achieved lower fees of up to 37%, less bureaucracy, more efficiency and a system that benefits the users of trade marks. I welcome the fact that the agreement found on goods in transit will ensure the smooth transit of generic medicines to developing countries. I believed that we secured a more effective way of combatting counterfeiting whilst at the same time ensuring that legitimate trade interests are not adversely affected.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objective of the proposal is to promote economic growth and innovation by improving the efficiency and access to trade mark registration. The revision of the Regulation is in order to align the terminology of the legislation with the language of the Treaty of Lisbon for decentralised agencies in the Union and to rationalise and simplify the system and application of the European trade mark procedure, to provide new frameworks for cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies in accordance with Section 290 TSI.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objective of the proposal is to promote economic growth and innovation by improving the efficiency and access to trade mark registration. The revision of the Regulation is in order to align the terminology of the legislation with the language of the Treaty of Lisbon for decentralised agencies in the Union and to rationalise and simplify the system and application of the European trade mark procedure, to provide new frameworks for cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies in accordance with Section 290 TSI.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 REFORM OF THE EU label is an important tool to support growth, increase competitiveness and protect European excellence. This reform will make it easier and cheaper to take a number of measures relating to trade marks at both national and European level, such as the registration of a trade mark or its consultation. Great strides are also being made in the fight against counterfeit products and in the fight against organised crime. With my vote, I wanted to give clear support to the Council's position.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. After three years of intensive negotiations, the European Parliament concludes the major reform of business brands, a long-awaited measure that modernises Europe's ability to act for growth, global competitiveness and innovation. As the Swedish rapporteur Cecilia Wikstrom also pointed out in this House, this is achieved mainly thanks to the patient mediation work of the Italian Presidency of the EU, which a year ago, at the most delicate moment of the negotiations, managed to lay the foundations for an agreement that advances protections and protections in favour of European products, integrating more and more the various national actions to promote trademarks. An important achievement therefore to defend the "made in", which goes hand in hand with many other acquisitions gained in recent months to favor small businesses, innovative realities and to expand the possibilities of investments.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU trade mark today, as I welcome, on the one hand, the name change of the previous 'Community brand' and, on the other hand, I support measures such as this, which help family businesses and small and medium-sized enterprises in the EU to better protect their ownership rights, innovations and ideas.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. A trade mark will make it much faster to register a brand in the future. At the same time, there is more protection for the owner, as control is significantly simplified. For me, this is a clear example, which shows the benefits of joint European cooperation.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Community Trade Mark Regulation which aims to foster innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems all over the EU more accessible and efficient. The system is already in place, but with the current modernisation it will be better functional. The Trade Marks package represents a key legal tool in order to fight against counterfeiting of products, including in my region of the West Midlands. Our priorities concern preserving public health, safety and jobs, as well as defending fundamental rights. Parliament also achieved lower fees of up to 37%, less bureaucracy, more efficiency and a system that benefits the users of trade marks.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on this report on trademarks in the EU. We understand that it is essential to protect the business fabric with a brand system that meets new challenges and accelerated globalization. But we also understand that, in this context where it is not clear what the system of blocking certain products could be – assuming, moreover, that large companies would never have problems but small businessiers would, we cannot vote in favour of giving a blank cheque to a system that needs some points clarified.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative proposal because, although the system is already in place, it will function better with the current modernisation developments. The Trade Marks Package is an important legal tool in the fight against the counterfeiting of products. This regulation will be less bureaucratic, more effective and will greatly benefit the users of trade marks.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I and my colleagues in UKIP voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position subject of this report. Firstly the purpose of the report is to implement a Regulation amending and modernising the Trade Mark regime operated by the EU.  Secondly the Regulation would extend and enhance the ‘Europeanisation’ of Trade Mark law and will allow for the further accretion of power over intellectual property issues by the EU.  UKIP believes that all intellectual property matters should be the preserve of the United Kingdom Parliament deciding the nature of the Trade Marks regime exclusively in the British interest.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against the Recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 207/2009 on the Community trade mark and Commission Regulation (EC) No 2868/95 implementing Council Regulation (EC) No 40/94 on the Community trade mark, and repealing Commission Regulation (EC) No 2869/95 on the fees payable to the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (Trade Marks and Designs). I think that Parliament’s main targets have been achieved. The trade mark system will be modernised, the agreement will respect and strengthen the dual system of national and European trade mark protection by building on best practices and respecting the principle of subsidiarity.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objective of the proposal is to promote economic growth and innovation by improving the efficiency and access to trade mark registration. The revision of the Regulation is in order to align the terminology of the legislation with the language of the Treaty of Lisbon for decentralised agencies in the Union and to rationalise and simplify the system and application of the European trade mark procedure, to provide new frameworks for cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies in accordance with Section 290 TSI.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although there was no vote in plenary on the two reports of the Committee on Legal Affairs, as the ordinary legislative procedure concerning the trademark regulation is in the second reading process, we voted against the amendment of the Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy (EFDD) Group which essentially called for the rejection of the two reports and the closure of the whole process of reforming the legislative framework for trademark registration. As ACPL, we supported the legislative process because we believe that it broadens measures to protect domestic products and preserves the name and specific characteristics of products from imitations and their illegal sale within Community borders.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal of the Council.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The idea of this proposal is to make the systems for the protection of trademarks (logos, etc.) in the various Member States compatible, with each other and with the European Office for Harmonisation (OHIM). This is a sensible approach in a common internal market. It respects the principle of subsidiarity and promotes competition among producers. Consumer protection is taken into account through the recognition of trade marks. This legislation goes in with the directive on the states of the united states on trademarks, which I have voted in favour of. However, the implementation of this part, namely the reform of OHIM, is not what I want. In particular, In my view, fees for the registration of trademarks should only cover the costs of them. In practice, however, OHIM makes profits from excessive fees, which are also directly allocated to the EU budget. That is why I cannot vote in favour of this proposal and have abstained. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States' trade mark legislation has already been partially harmonised by Directives 89/104/EEC and 2008/95/EC.  The aim of the current legislation is to modernise the existing provisions by amending outdated legislation. The amendments aim at increasing legal certainty and clarifying the scope and restrictions. 2. Further approach to national regulations.  3. Promote cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies. This initiative is also part of the Community trade mark package.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ My group has concerns relating to the possibility of this legislation impeding the legitimate trade in generic medicines.  I accordingly supported the amendment to reject the agreement.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation that will implement the Councils Regulation (EC) No 40/94 on the Community trade mark.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted against the EFDD amendment because it rejects the Council's position. As I fully support the recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending the Community Trade Mark Council Regulation and the Commission Regulation on the implementation of the Community Trade Mark Council Regulation and the repeal of the Commission Regulation on the fees payable to the Internal Market Harmonisation Office (trade marks and designs) of Ms Wikström, the amendment is not acceptable to me.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The Council adopted its position at first reading on the reform of the European trademark system. This reform contains a proposal for a directive to standardising Member States' trademark laws and a parallel proposal to amend the EU trademark regulation (EC) No. 207/2009. The proposed reform includes a lower level of taxes, the establishment of a compensation mechanism allowing Member States to recover the costs of setting up services and procedures related to the application of the European Union brand, as well as the rationalisation of various technical provisions and closer cooperation between the Office and national offices. It is noticeable that there has been an increase in the grounds for refusal of appellations of origin and geographical indications, thus allowing greater protection for the economic operators concerned. There has also been an increase in the absolute reasons for refusing appellations of origin, geographical indications, traditional mentions for wines, guaranteed traditional specialties and plant rights.  This text streamlines the operation of the Office and allows for lower costs and costs for economic operators as well as greater protection. I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position subject of this report. Firstly the purpose of the report is to implement a Regulation amending and modernising the Trade Mark regime operated by the EU.  Secondly the Regulation would extend and enhance the ‘Europeanisation’ of Trade Mark law and will allow for the further accretion of power over intellectual property issues by the EU. UKIP believes that all intellectual property matters should be the preserve of the United Kingdom Parliament deciding the nature of the Trade Marks regime exclusively in the British interest.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I rejected the deletion amendment on the European trademark text. I believe that this text, which aims, among other things, to strengthen the fight against counterfeiting, is necessary. Trademark owners must have the means to oppose the introduction of products from outside the European Union when these products take on the characteristics of a registered European trademark because counterfeiting contributes to weakening our European businesses and endangers citizens.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from voting on this report. I consider many of the points raised to be useful, but a whole commodity drawing in the EU is not very useful.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the review of the regulation as with the modernisation the system will be better functional. The Trade Marks package represents a key legal tool in order to fight against counterfeiting of products. Its main objective is to foster innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems all over the EU more accessible and efficient.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The idea of this proposal is to make the systems for the protection of trademarks (logos, etc.) compatible in the various Member States. This is a sensible approach in a common internal market. It respects the principle of subsidiarity and promotes competition among producers. Consumer protection is taken into account through the recognition of trade marks. This legislation goes in with the directive on the states of the united states on trademarks, which I have voted in favour of. However, the implementation of the part concerning the reform of the European Harmonisation Office (OHIM) is problematic. In particular, In my view, fees for the registration of trademarks should only cover the costs of them. In practice, however, OHIM makes profits from excessive fees, which are also directly allocated to the EU budget. That is why I cannot vote in favour of this proposal and I abstained.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The aim of the revision of the regulation is to simplify the procedures for applying for and registering a European trade mark and to increase legal certainty in this area. Given that the quality and certainty of trade mark registration systems in the Community area can make a major contribution to innovation and economic growth, I have decided to support Mrs Wikstrom's recommendation.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative package to overhaul trademark law, which is crucial for innovation and the fight against counterfeiting in Europe. We have achieved a significant reduction in the fees for registering trademarks in the EU and the introduction of simplified and harmonised procedures for the benefit of our companies. But the cornerstone of this reform remains the strengthening of anti-counterfeiting means, as trademark holders can now oppose the introduction of products from third countries on EU territory when these products bear, without authorisation, a mark identical to the duly registered European mark. Therefore, without going against our obligations in international trade, we have thus sent a strong message: we must protect ourselves from counterfeit goods that weaken our businesses and endanger our fellow citizens.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I am in favour of reforming the European trademark system. The proposed new system includes a lower level of taxes, the establishment of a compensation mechanism allowing Member States to recover the costs associated with setting up services and procedures related to the application of the European Union brand, as well as the rationalisation of various technical provisions and the tightening of cooperation between the Office and national offices.
