This text, in addition to streamlining the Procedures and Operation of the Office, allows for lower costs and costs for economic operators as well as greater protection. That is why I voted against the rejection amendment tabled by the EFDD group.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In the first place, we must highlight the increasing harmonisation in the laws of the Member States on trade marks. Secondly, at European level, the excellent work carried out by OHIM, the institution responsible for the registration and administration of Community trade marks, must be emphasized. This report arises due to the need for a consistent and high-quality branding system. For this reason, a comprehensive evaluation is essential in order to achieve greater cooperation between OHIM and national offices.  Among the many objectives set out in this report is: - On the one hand, to clarify the scope and limitations of trade mark rights by improving the provisions of the Trade Mark Directive, the thus increasing the legal certainty of users. - On the other hand, establish a legal basis to promote convergence and the development of common tools between OHIM and the offices of Member States. I consider it necessary to adopt these measures in order to promote greater efficiency in the functioning of the trademark system, so that it meets the demands of companies of various sizes, different markets and geographical needs.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)

In practice, however, OHIM makes profits from excessive fees, which are also directly allocated to the EU budget. That is why I cannot vote in favour of this proposal and have abstained.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As the European Union and its institutional predecessors evolved, the level of integration between Member States was achieved over time that the need for a common commercial representation in terms of trade marks emerged, so that both europeans themselves and the inhabitants of the rest of the world could understand which goods came from our community. To a large extent, it can also be classified as a distinctive quality stamp. The EU trade mark enables companies from our Member States to register their trade marks at Union level, not just at national level. As EU law is increasing every year, there is a need for gradual reform and functional facilitation of various aspects. This Regulation will reform previous EU trade mark-related regulations to facilitate their receipt and change, settle various disputes, facilitate cooperation and legal compatibility between national and supranational institutions, potentially leading to an increase in the efficiency of the community as a whole and also to increased competitiveness.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council and the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. It is therefore necessary to take account of the fact that, in the case of the Commission,it is not complete and substantiated, and because it is not complete and substantiated, and because of the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech on 14/12/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that we got first reading agreement on the Community trade mark.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this rejection amendment and, although there was no final vote on this recommendation for second reading, I am in favour of this reform.  This reform includes a proposal for a directive to bring Member States' laws closer together on trademarks, as well as a parallel proposal to amend the EU trademark regulation.  This reform will streamline the Procedures and Operation of the Office, lower the costs and costs of economic operators, and provide greater protection for these operators.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not feel able to vote in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position on how to implement the Regulation on the Community trade mark, as I believe that we need more negotiation between the various political groups.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of Mrs Wikstrom's proposal, which I am voting in favour of, is to foster innovation and economic growth through more accessible and efficient trademark registration systems across the EU. These systems must therefore be able to ensure greater legal certainty and to establish a suitable legal framework for cooperation between the OHIM and the national offices.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, there is no objection to the report, but the improvements are not clear. Moreover, the necessity of the project is questionable. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. A brand is used to distinguish a company's products and services. Member States' trademark laws were partially harmonised by directive in 1988 and codified in 2008. In parallel with national trademark systems, an autonomous unit rights registration system has been created which has the same effects throughout the Union. The Council has strengthened the means to protect European products. For this it extends the absolute grounds of refusal to the appellations of origin. The same goes for geographical indications, traditional mentions for wines, and guaranteed traditional specialties. And even for the right to give a name on a plant. and plant-based rights. However, generic drugs are not clearly excluded from the fight against counterfeiting. So even if these measures may facilitate the establishment of solidarity protectionism in the future, I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Council adopted its position at first reading on the reform of the European trademark system. This reform contains a proposal for a directive to standardising Member States' trademark laws and a parallel proposal to amend the EU trademark regulation (EC) No. 207/2009. The proposed reform includes a lower level of taxes, the establishment of a compensation mechanism allowing Member States to recover the costs of setting up services and procedures related to the application of the European Union brand, as well as the rationalisation of various technical provisions and closer cooperation between the Office and national offices.
