This text streamlines the operation of the Office and allows for lower costs and costs for economic operators as well as greater protection. I therefore vote against the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have presented my vote in agreement with the recommendation for second reading of the Council's position at first reading on the Community trade mark regulation. The Community trade mark system and OHIM have been around for more than 15 years and it is therefore necessary to review existing rules in order to adapt it to the current reality.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as its main objective is to foster innovation and economic growth by cutting bureaucracy and red tape in relation to trademark registration systems all over the EU.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Beyond this second reading vote, I am in favour of this reform of the Community trademark system in the name of better protection of trademarks against counterfeiting, efficiency, cost reduction, etc. Above all, it is a question of promoting innovation and economic growth by ensuring that trademark registration systems are more efficient and accessible to businesses throughout the Union and, on the other hand, making them less complex and less expensive, faster, more predictable and legally safer.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the motion for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 207/2009 on the Community trade mark. At the same time, I support the strengthening of innovation and economic growth by facilitating and streamlining access for businesses to trade mark systems in Europe by reducing costs and reducing complexity, faster procedures, greater legal certainty and better protection against counterfeiting.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the EU Trade Mark, because in my opinion this legislation aims at fostering innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems all over the EU more accessible and efficient. The system is already in place, but with the current modernisation it will be better functional. The revision of the regulation aims to adapt the terminology, to streamline procedures to apply for and register a European trademark, to increase legal certainty by clarifying provisions, to establish an appropriate framework for cooperation between OHIM and national offices for developing common tools, and to align the framework to art 290 TFEU. The Trade Marks package represents a key legal tool in order to fight against counterfeiting of products, preserve public health, safety and jobs, as well as defending fundamental rights.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has submitted a proposal to Parliament and the Council for the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Commission Regulation (EC) No 2869/95. On 25 February 2014, Parliament established its first reading position on the proposal. In its recommendation, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that Parliament agree at second reading with the Council's position at first reading, thereby making the regulation legal in accordance with the Council's position. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I advocate reducing divergences in the trade mark system in Europe and that the European Union trade mark system and national trade mark systems coexist in a complementary relationship.  I believe it is essential to ensure that trademarks enjoy the same protection in accordance with the legal systems of all Member States. In line with the broad protection conferred on EU trade marks which enjoy prestige in the Union, broad protection should also be granted at national level to all trade marks enjoying prestige in the Member State concerned. I would stress that trade mark systems in the Union will need to be modernised in order to meet the increased demands of those concerned for faster, better quality and more rational trade mark registration systems. By making brand systems more efficient, we will be reducing costs, bureaucracy and complexity for businesses, which could mean increased innovation and economic growth.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns an amendment to reject the EFDD group from a text to validate the Council's position on the reform of the European trademark system.  This position includes a proposal for a directive harmonising Member States' trademark laws and a parallel proposal to amend the Eu's trademark regulation (EC) 207/2009 to comply with the requirements of the Lisbon Treaty. This system provides for a lower level of taxes, the establishment of a compensation mechanism allowing Member States to recover the costs associated with setting up services and procedures related to the application of the European Union brand (5% of the Office's annual revenues and the possibility of doubling the percentage in the event of a large budget surplus) etc. The text extends the reasons for absolute refusal of PDO and PGI to traditional mentions for wines, to guaranteed traditional specialties and to plant breeding rights, thus allowing greater protection of the economic operators concerned. I voted against the amendment to reject this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Office for the Harmonisation of the Internal Market (OHIM), which has existed since 2013. This legislation is designed to ensure the ongoing effectiveness of OHIM as an agency, with particular emphasis on the user-friendliness of the system, and ensuring ongoing parliamentary representation on OHIM’s governing board.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the final adoption of the draft reform of European trademark law, introduced by the Commission more than two years ago. The aim is to make European companies more competitive by implementing simplified, harmonised and less costly procedures for registering a trademark. This reform will also strengthen the defences of trademark holders by allowing them to oppose the introduction of products from third countries when they carry, without authorisation, a mark identical to the duly registered European trademark.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A key aspect of the proper functioning of the market is that consumers can obtain, in a clear and effective way, the information necessary for their purchasing decisions; and at the same time, that companies do not have to suffer undue additional costs in order to operate on the market. This is all the more so in the case of the Single European Market, since one of the fundamental aspects of European productions is their recognition and uniqueness in brands and geographical indications. That is why I voted in favour of the text today, which – thanks in part to the intensive work of the Italian Presidency of the EU Council, which has developed a precise political and technical framework within which this legislative revision has been incorporated – finally clarifies the issue of trade marks. Firstly, by renaming the Office for harmonisation of the internal market as the EU Intellectual Property Agency and clearly defining the different scope of trade marks and geographical indications. Clarity goes hand in hand with a reduction in the cost of registering trade marks at EU level and the adoption of precise rules and controls against counterfeiting, in particular for goods in transit, in order to better protect the excellence of our products.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation that will repeal the Commission’s Regulation (EC) No 2869/95 regarding the fees payable to the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (Trade Marks and Designs).

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP-Council agreement at 2nd reading, which concludes the two-and-a-half-year legislative process. This results in a compromise which means simplifying the administrative process for processing trade mark applications and reducing the cost of obtaining a trade mark. The agreement reached will encourage firms to increase their competitiveness in the EU internal market, thus promoting cross-border trade within the EU. Last but not least, the agreement creates the conditions to facilitate the fight against counterfeit goods in the EU and to reduce the volume of counterfeit goods flowing through the EU.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the EC proposal is to promote innovation and economic growth by making trade mark registration systems across the EU more accessible. In an increasingly competitive environment, increasing the number of trade mark applications at both national and EU level, as well as increasing the number of trademark users, shows their crucial role in terms of market success and commercial value. This development was accompanied by growing expectations from stakeholders to improve the quality of trade mark registration systems, which are more consistent, accessible to the public and technologically updated. The European Parliament approves the Council's position at first reading and instructs its President to sign the act after verification of the proper implementation of all procedures.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I agree with the position put forward to modernise the branding system.  It should be noted that the trade mark strengthens the consumer's relationship with goods and services.  The EU must be effective. It is therefore necessary not only to determine the rights of trade mark proprie reso dosers, but it is also essential to ensure the protection and effective protection of such rights in the event of an infringement. A unified procedure should be used to simplify the policy of using trade marks across Europe.  In particular, trade mark registration systems need to be more accessible and effective across the EU. Innovation and economic growth need to be promoted. It should be noted that the importance of trade marks in both domestic and regional and international trade only increases every year. It is therefore essential that businesses are reduced administrative burdens and legal certainty is ensured.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position subject of this report. Firstly the purpose of the report is to implement a Regulation amending and modernising the Trade Mark regime operated by the EU.  Secondly the Regulation would extend and enhance the ‘Europeanisation’ of Trade Mark law and will allow for the further accretion of power over intellectual property issues by the EU. UKIP believes that all intellectual property matters should be the preserve of the United Kingdom Parliament deciding the nature of the Trade Marks regime exclusively in the British interest.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanking the rapporteur for her work, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒In addition to protecting the trade mark at national level, the European Union offers all nationals and legal entities of its Member States the possibility to protect the Community trade mark. A European Union trade mark is a community trade mark of 28 Member States valid in the European Union as a whole and its scope cannot be geographically limited to some Member States only.  Simultaneous protection of products in all EU countries with only one trade mark registration is the first and greatest advantage of obtaining a Community trade mark. The Community trade mark also brings many benefits in trade and the transfer of goods – reduces costs, increases speed and legal certainty. Due to the importance that Community trade mark registration has, I agree that procedures for applying for registration need to be streamlined in order to facilitate and shorten the registration process for applicants, which is now taking too long.  I support this report with amendments that contribute to adapting terminology and reducing legal ambiguities, and I think it is necessary to further inform citizens about the opportunities at their disposal and the benefits that registering a Community trade mark brings them.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns an amendment to reject the EFDD group from a text to validate the Council's position on the reform of the European trademark system. This position includes a proposal for a directive harmonising Member States' trademark laws and a parallel proposal to amend the Eu's trademark regulation (EC) 207/2009 to comply with the requirements of the Lisbon Treaty. This system provides for a lower level of taxes, the establishment of a compensation mechanism allowing Member States to recover the costs associated with setting up services and procedures related to the application of the European Union brand (5% of the Office's annual revenues and the possibility of doubling the percentage in the event of a large budget surplus, etc.). The text extends the reasons for absolute refusal of PDO and PGI to traditional mentions for wines, to guaranteed traditional specialties and to plant breeding rights, thus allowing greater protection of the economic operators concerned. I voted against the amendment to reject this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The amendment to community trademark regulation will allow further progress in the fight against product counterfeiting and a greater level of protection of consumer rights, public health and safety. At the same time, the risk of the trade mark adversely affecting diversified trade interests and needs has been eliminated and easier transport of generic medicines from the Union to developing countries has been ensured.  I support these changes because their intention is to stimulate economic growth and innovation through a more accessible and efficient trademark registration system through simplification and refinement of regulation and fostering greater cooperation between national and European levels.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I support the recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1009/2013. 207/2009 on community trade mark and Commission Regulation (EC) No 207/2009 2868/95 on the implementation of Council Regulation (EC) No 2868/95. 40/94 on the Community trade mark and the repeal of Commission Regulation (EC) No 40/94. 2869/95 on fees payable to wikström's Office of Harmonisation in the Internal Market (trade marks and designs). The European Union trade mark serves to protect individuals and companies' intellectual property exclusively across the European Union.  The aim of this proposal is to modernise the outdated provisions in Council Regulation 207/2009 on the Community trade mark, thereby simplifying the application and registration of an EU trade mark, addressing key financial balance problems within the EUTM system, stepping up innovation by improving the accessibility of trade mark systems in Europe and increasing their efficiency and effectiveness for businesses in the context of reducing costs and complexity and increasing speed, achieving greater legal certainty and better protection against counterfeiting.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In addition to national trade mark systems, Council Regulation (EC) No 40/94 has created a separate system for the registration of unitary rights with equal effect throughout the EU. It was in this context that the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) responsible for the registration and management of Community trade marks was set up. I voted in favour of this initiative because the main common objective is to promote innovation and economic growth through more accessible and more efficient trademark registration systems across the EU in terms of lower costs, less complexity, faster, greater predictability and legal certainty.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against rejecting the texts submitted by the Council. An agreement has finally been reached and it is our duty to support it, in order to advance legislation and reflection.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position subject of this report. Firstly the purpose of the report is to implement a Regulation amending and modernising the Trade Mark regime operated by the EU.  Secondly the Regulation would extend and enhance the ‘Europeanisation’ of Trade Mark law and will allow for the further accretion of power over intellectual property issues by the EU. UKIP believes that all intellectual property matters should be the preserve of the United Kingdom Parliament deciding the nature of the Trade Marks regime exclusively in the British interest.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to modernise the rules on trademarks to facilitate the registration of trademarks in the European Union and, above all, to better combat counterfeiting. The European rules on trademarks, logos or symbols that distinguish a company's products or services, were established some 20 years ago. So it was time to adapt them. From now on, procedures will be shorter and lighter to support businesses, including SMEs. Also, thanks to lower taxes, the cost of registration is expected to fall significantly. The new rules also ensure that the fight against counterfeit products in Europe is strengthened, which I welcome.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to promote innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems more accessible and efficient across the UNION.  Through this vote, we are proceeding with the reform of trademark law which will significantly reduce the costs of registering trademarks in the European Union as well as the implementation of simplified and harmonised procedures.  Finally, this reform will mainly strengthen our anti-counterfeiting capacity. Trademark holders will now be able to oppose the introduction of products from third countries within the EU when these products bear, without authorisation, a mark identical to the European mark that has been registered previously. It is therefore a question of strengthening our competitiveness and ensuring the safety of consumers.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. –We abstained in the vote on this report on trade marks in the EU. We understand that it is essential to protect the business fabric with a brand system that meets new challenges and accelerated globalization. But we also understand that, in this context where it is not clear what the system of blocking certain products could be – assuming, moreover, that large companies would never have problems but small businessiers would, we cannot vote in favour of giving a blank cheque to a system that needs some points clarified.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. The advantages of a Community trade mark are obvious: a single registration applied for online in a language is valid in all EU Member States. It thus guarantees the proprietor of the trade mark his rights in all current and future Member States of the European Union at a reasonable cost. Fees were an important aspect of the discussion with the Council. We in Parliament have managed to reduce them so that the Community brand is a success. We have also managed to combat piracy effectively with the Community trade mark, thereby creating greater security for European consumers and industry. I therefore voted in favour of the report today and i am pleased that we have taken another important step towards the completion of the internal market.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to reformulate the EU Trade Marks Regulation, as well as the Directive relating to the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. This report and the following are parts of a renewal package for the entire trademark system at European level. The basic functioning of the trademark system is as follows: a producer of a good or service who intends to protect the name and general characteristics of his product has to register his mark at both national and European levels, defining the essential name and characteristics of his product. This registration allows the producer or company to be protected against copying, counterfeiting or non-authorization. The purpose of this report is to harmonise, through a Regulation, the way in which trade marks are registered at European level. Among other aspects, it provides for a significant reduction in the cost of online registration fees. The report contains positive aspects, but also others that raise reserves, such as the blocking system, which does not exclude generic medicines. That's why I abstained.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion to reject the original proposal. As I am against the EU bringing in legislation in this area.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative proposal because, although the system is already in place, it will function better with the current modernisation developments. The Trade Marks Package is an important legal tool in the fight against the counterfeiting of products. This regulation will be less bureaucratic, more effective and will greatly benefit the users of trade marks.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I approve of the agreement reached between the Council and the EP on the modification of the European trade mark. The main objective of this proposal is to foster innovation and economic growth by making the trade mark registration system more accessible and efficient. The adaptation of this Directive will adapt terminology, harmonise registration procedures and clarify concepts will also increase legal certainty. Among other things, the name 'European Union trade mark' is introduced here and the Office for These Cases is renamed the Intellectual Property Office of the European Union. Member States will also be able to set their fees in such a way as to guarantee coexistence and additionality between the European trade mark and the system of national trade marks. Cooperation with national authorities is particularly important in order to bring the instruments and presentations closer together. At national level, these modifications should also improve the structure of trade mark management and make administrative procedures more applied more quickly. The system currently in practice will be modernised and more functional. The European trade mark package is a key tool for combating counterfeiting of products. At the same time, the financial and administrative costs of establishing a trade mark will be reduced for entrepreneurs. I therefore believe that this system will become more accessible to its users.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In 2013, the Commission proposed a new branded package of measures. The reform should aim at upgrading and streamlining existing legislation to ensure that trade mark registration systems across the EU become more accessible and efficient for businesses.  This would make the process less complex, reduce costs and improve the speed of the procedure. The registration process would thus be more predictable and would also provide greater legal certainty. Nevertheless, I believe that in the new package of measures concerning trade marks, there is a high risk that they jeopardise the movement of legitimate medicines across borders.  The most controversial are thus the provisions of the draft regulation and directive aimed at combating counterfeit products. I believe that consumer protection comes first and that trade marks should not be used as an obstacle to the smooth transit of generic medicines through the EU into developing countries. International non-proprietary names (INN) are particularly important here, such as world-renowned generic names for active substances in pharmaceutical preparations.  I believe that the area is not yet properly regulated and that the new brand package requires corrections. For the sake of the above, I voted in plenary to support an amendment calling for the recommendation to be rejected.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The idea of this proposal is to make the systems for the protection of trademarks (logos, etc.) in the various Member States compatible, with each other and with the European Office for Harmonisation (OHIM). This is a sensible approach in a common internal market. It respects the principle of subsidiarity and promotes competition among producers. Consumer protection is taken into account through the recognition of trade marks. This legislation goes in with the directive on the states of the united states on trademarks, which I have voted in favour of. However, the implementation of this part, namely the reform of OHIM, is not what I want. In particular, In my view, fees for the registration of trademarks should only cover the costs of them. In practice, however, OHIM makes profits from excessive fees, which are also directly allocated to the EU budget. That is why I cannot vote in favour of this proposal and have abstained.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Promoting the proper functioning of the Single Market is one of the EU's priorities. In a globalised world, brands are becoming increasingly important. Of course, protecting them is also important. It is important for an efficient single market to provide entrepreneurs with uniform protection throughout the EU.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Community Trade Mark and Commission Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013. 2868/95 on the implementation of Council Regulation (EC) No 2868/95. 40/94 on the Community trade mark and the repeal of Commission Regulation (EC) No 40/94. 2869/95 on fees payable to the Office of Harmonisation in the Internal Market (trade marks and designs) taking into account the recommendation for the second reading of the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which is a codification taking into account changes made to other pieces of legislation, including the report on the Community Trade Mark.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The objectives of the proposal for a regulation are to simplify eu trade mark application and registration procedures and to modernise and improve the current provisions by amending outdated provisions, improving legal certainty by clarifying the provisions and eliminating ambiguities. The aim of the audit is to adapt Regulation No 1000/2013. 207/2009 Treaty of Lisbon.  An appropriate framework should be established for cooperation between the Internal Market Coordination Office (OHIM) and national offices in order to promote convergence of practices and the development of common tools. A compromise has been reached with regard to the provisions on goods in transport, whereby the right to prevent goods from entering eu territory expires if the declarant or holder of the goods can prove before the competent court that the trade mark holder has no right to prohibit the placing on the market of the country of destination. I voted against the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Community trade mark. The aim of this report is to modernise trade mark rules to facilitate registration in the European Union and, above all, to combat counterfeiting more effectively. In addition to the protection of trade marks at national level, the European Union offers all citizens and legal persons from the Member States the possibility of protecting the Community trade mark. A trade mark is a trade mark of a community of 28 Member States and is valid in the European Union as a whole and its scope cannot be geographically limited to certain Member States. I support this report with amendments that contribute to adapting terminology and reducing legal uncertainty, and I believe that further information is needed for citizens about the possibilities available to them and the benefits of registering a Community trade mark.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although there was no vote in plenary on the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs as the ordinary legislative procedure concerning the trademark regulation is in the second reading procedure, we voted against the amendment tabled by the Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy (EFDD) political group, which essentially called for the report to be rejected and for the whole process of reforming the legislative framework for trademark registration to be closed.  As ACPL we have supported the legislative process as it broadens measures to protect domestic products, preserving the name and specific characteristics of products from imitations and their illegal sale within Community borders.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The amendment proposes to reject the Council's position on the harmonisation of the laws of the Member States on trade marks and intellectual property rights, since: (a) this position does not adequately fill the existing legal gaps, and (b) the attempt to fully harmonise the laws of the Member States leads in the long term to the leveling of the specificity of each of them and, consequently, to the homogenisation sought by the EU's powerful.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objective of the proposal is to promote economic growth and innovation by improving the efficiency and access to trade mark registration. The revision of the Regulation is in order to align the terminology of the legislation with the language of the Treaty of Lisbon for decentralised agencies in the Union and to rationalise and simplify the system and application of the European trade mark procedure, to provide new frameworks for cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies in accordance with Section 290 TSI.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This vote involves the final adoption at second reading of the legislative package on the Community trade mark, the only legal instrument in terms of intellectual property rights that is managed at European level. We voted in favour because we consider the compromise reached acceptable as additional rules have been included to ensure the fight against counterfeiting by ensuring the legitimate interests of traders. With regard to small consignments, the new text deleted the provision that allowed the proprietor of the brand to block the delivery of products purchased by citizens via the Internet outside the European Union (only in the event that the final buyer does not act in the commercial field). Finally, the resolution adds new protection for products with a typical geographical indication.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European trade mark must guarantee, in this order: reducing red tape, reducing waiting times, reducing costs, increasing the protection measure and guaranteeing validity in the European trademark system.  I support the reform of the European trade mark-making and administration system, but I also believe that we must pay particular attention to the system of legislative harmonisation at Member State level. We must strive to move at the same pace and intervene at european Commission level when we see that harmonisation is not moving forward properly.  I voted for the form presented by the European Parliament and the Council because we need a coherent and unified trademark management system at European Union level as quickly as possible.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. On Tuesday, the European Parliament voted for more effective brand legislation. We want to make business life easier by making trademark registration simpler, faster, more reliable but also cheaper. A strengthening of the means to combat counterfeit goods will also be put in place. Finally, we have ensured that the free movement of generic drugs is not impeded.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending the Council Regulation (EC) No 207/2009 on the Community trade mark and Commission Regulation (EC) No 2868/95 implementing Council Regulation (EC) No 40/94 on the Community trade mark, and repealing Commission Regulation (EC) No 2869/95 on the fees payable to the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (Trade Marks and Designs). The purpose of these changes is to foster innovation and economic growth by making the EU trade mark registration systems more accessible, especially for small and middle size enterprises. The systems' efficiency should be enhanced among other measures by streamlining procedures to apply for and register a European trade mark, by increasing legal certainty and by promoting convergence of practices and developing common tools across the EU member states.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objective of the proposal is to promote economic growth and innovation by improving the efficiency and access to trade mark registration. The revision of the Regulation is in order to align the terminology of the legislation with the language of the Treaty of Lisbon for decentralised agencies in the Union and to rationalise and simplify the system and application of the European trade mark procedure, to provide new frameworks for cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies in accordance with Section 290 TSI.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the European Union trade mark report, which aims to harmonise trade mark registration systems in all Member States and ensure the coexistency and complementarity of the EU trade mark registration system and member states.  While I believe that a European Commission initiative aiming to modernise existing decisions is justified, as well as an attempt to increase the efficiency of trade mark systems in terms of lower costs and simplification and increasing speed, predictability and legal certainty, I believe that the proposal also contains many controversial problems unfavourable for Member States.  First of all, I believe that the budget surplus of the Office for Harmonisation in the internal market should be forwarded to state intellectual property offices so that the trade mark system can be developed and promoted in the Member States. In addition, I believe that in some Member States the proposed changes would not lead to a reduction in overall costs, but on the contrary - there would be high costs of initiating opposition proceedings, appeals or applications for annulment, and these costs would be highly unfavourable for businesses.  Therefore, I did not support this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I did not support the EUTM reports – recommendation for second reading – as the most highlighted issue of goods in transit remains open and inexplicable. This is why the EES political group did not support the proposal.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on this report on trade marks in the EU. We understand that it is essential to protect the business fabric with a brand system that meets new challenges and accelerated globalization. But we also understand that, in this context where it is not clear what the system of blocking certain products could be – assuming, moreover, that large companies would never have problems but small businessiers would, we cannot vote in favour of giving a blank cheque to a system that needs some points clarified.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament’s main targets have been achieved. The trade mark system will be modernised, not revolutionised, as it is already a well-functioning system. The agreement will respect and strengthen the dual system of national and European trade mark protection by building on best practices and respecting the principle of subsidiarity. Parliament achieved lower fees of up to 37%, less bureaucracy, more efficiency and a system that benefits the users of trade marks.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. In addition to adapting terminology to the requirements of the Lisbon Treaty, the proposed new system includes a lower level of taxes, the establishment of a compensation mechanism allowing Member States to recover the costs associated with the implementation of services and procedures related to the application of the European Union brand (5% of the office's annual revenues and the possibility of doubling the percentage in the event of a large budget surplus) as well as rationalisation technical provisions and closer cooperation between the Office and national offices. It should be noted that the absolute grounds for refusal to appellations of origin, geographical indications, traditional mentions for wines, guaranteed traditional specialties and plant breeding rights, as well as the extension of reasons for refusal to appellations of origin and geographical indications, thus allowing greater protection for the economic operators concerned, are extended. I therefore voted against the rejection amendment tabled by the EFDD group.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Amending Council Regulation (EC) No 207/2009 on the Community trade mark and Commission Regulation (EC) No 2868/95 implementing Council Regulation (EC) No 40/94 on the Community trade mark, and the plenary voted in plenary on a Council position at first reading with a view to adopting Commission Regulation (EC) No 2869/95 repealing Commission Regulation (EC) No 2869/95 on fees payable to the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (trade marks and designs); following the position of the S&D Group, I voted against.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on this report on trade marks in the EU. We understand that it is essential to protect the business fabric with a brand system that meets new challenges and accelerated globalization. But we also understand that, in this context where it is not clear what the system of blocking certain products could be – assuming, moreover, that large companies would never have problems but small businessiers would, we cannot vote in favour of giving a blank cheque to a system that needs some points clarified.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The main objective of the proposal is to increase innovation and economic growth by trying to make EU trademark registration systems more accessible and efficient. The revision of this Regulation aims to adapt legal terminology to the Lisbon agreement, to increase legal certainty by establishing provisions in this area, as well as to establish a framework cooperation agreement between OHIM and national trademark and patent offices. We are therefore talking about a report which reflects all the concerns of users in this area, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of this legislation. This legislation will help ensure OHIM, the Office for the Harmonization of the Single Market is more user-friendly. OHIM is responsible for providing trade mark and design protection throughout the European Union. This will streamline procedures for individuals and small businesses ensuring respect for their intellectual property rights this works towards protecting these groups and ensuring the rules help rather than hinder them from getting proper redress.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted against this proposal. The European Parliament's objectives, namely more efficiency, less bureaucracy and less costs, have already been achieved

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The brand system is used to protect branded products. To this do so, a mechanism is created that allows companies and Member States to block, through custom tools and the execution of custom procedures, the transit of goods from third countries that are supposedly counterfeited.  The possibilities for such implementation are reinforced in this proposal. This can be considered positive for European industries. However, one of our concerns is that generic drugs are not clearly excluded from this possibility, despite the mobilisation of associations such as MSF.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, there is no objection to the report, but the improvements are not clear. Moreover, the necessity of the project is questionable. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mrs Cecilia Wikström's EU trademark report. It is good that a compromise has been reached between all the European institutions.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have long been in favour of measures to promote innovation and economic growth, one of these measures is this proposed regulation. I support simplifying the procedures for registering a trade mark and thus increasing legal certainty. In this proposal, I also consider the changes concerning the management of the Office for Harmonisation and Budgetary Affairs to be positive.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the report is the recast of the Community Trade Mark Regulation as well as the Directive relating to Member States' trade mark legislation. The stated objective is 'to modernise trade mark registration procedures as well as move from a Community approach to the EU approach (in line with the implementation of the Lisbon Treaty)'. In principle, this reform will facilitate changes to the nomenclature of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market, facilitate procedures, strengthen the fight against contraption and clarify the form of trade mark registration. For example, it will reduce the cost of online registration fees to register brands from €950 to €850 at EU level. In this way, we voted against rejecting the Council's position.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to reformulate the Community Trade Mark Regulation and the Directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. This report and the following are parts of a renewal package for the entire trademark system at European level. The basic functioning of the trademark system is as follows: a producer of a good or service who intends to protect the name and general characteristics of his product has to register his mark at both national and European levels, defining the essential name and characteristics of his product. This registration allows the producer or company to be protected against copying, counterfeiting or non-authorization. This report aims, through the Directive, to approximate national registration systems. Among other aspects, it provides for the simplification of the trademark registration process. As a whole, these reports contain positive aspects, but also some negative ones, such as blocking systems, which do not exclude generic drugs, despite alerts from organizations such as Doctors Without Borders. That's why I abstained.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The Council has adopted its position on the reform of the European trademark system. The reform proposal renews the definition of a mark by removing the requirement for graphic representation, to allow the registration of marks of new forms, such as sound marks, movement marks of holograms without potentially excluding olfactory or taste marks. The brand sign should be represented in a clear, precise, distinct, intelligible way. The text also lists grounds for refusal or nullity regarding the mark. There is also the right for Member States to decide to carry out checks on relative grounds of refusal of office, the establishment of an administrative procedure before each national office to oppose the registration of a trademark on the basis of relative grounds and the establishment of an administrative procedure before each national office in respect of the forfeiture or nullity of a trademark. This text protects innovation and allows greater protection for economic operators, especially with regard to PGIs.  I voted against the rejection proposal tabled by the EFDD group.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the proposal to reject the Council position, and against the creeping European Union involvement in intellectual property rights. If anything, I oppose this measure more strongly than the previous one because this seeks to harmonise the law of Member States.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this proposal because it supports a Council directive to harmonise the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the amendment which called for the rejection of this proposal, that is to say in favour of the Council's position which seems to me to be going in the right direction, both for producers and for consumers.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have endorsed this Council proposal, which aims to promote innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems more accessible to businesses throughout the UNION and more efficient, making them less complex and less expensive but also faster, more predictable and legally safer.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on the report on the approximation of the laws of the Member States in the field of trade marks. We understand that, as in the case of text A8-0354/2015, the clarification of the system is insufficient as regards the blocking of property. However, we understand that the will of the dossier is positive, as long as it is proceeding towards regulation that simplifies the regulatory multiplicity of trademarks. We hope that, in any event, future reports to approximate the legislation of the Member States in the field of trademarks will have as their starting point the multiplicity of the dispute within all regions.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of updating the protection of European trade marks, which seeks to promote the fight against counterfeiting and facilitate the registration of new teachings on the market. It is a set of measures already provisionally agreed between Parliament and the Member States, which promote the harmonisation of national and European trademark registration systems. These new rules will give greater protection to users and at the same time we have safeguarded freedom of expression, the right to parody or artistic freedom, as well as access to medicines in developing countries. The legislative amendment also proposes greater efficiency in the registration of trademarks, cheaper for SMEs, as well as changes in the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (OHIM), which will be renamed the European Union Intellectual Property Office.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to the rejection amendment tabled by the EFDD group on the recommendation of the JURI Committee to adopt the Council's position on the reform of the European trademark system. The redesign of the directive will facilitate better protection for all brands in the EU, notably by proposing a new definition of a brand that removes the requirement for graphic representation, which will allow the registration of trademarks of new forms such as sound marks; an adaptation to the current technological reality, especially as this is framed by the requirement of a sign represented in an intelligible and sustainable way. It is a framework that promotes transparency and access to brand understanding for all. Moreover, the proposed directive clearly establishes the grounds for refusal or nullity concerning a mark, such as the absence of distinctiveness. Finally, Member States have the possibility of deciding to carry out checks on relative statutory grounds, the establishment of an administrative procedure before each national office to oppose the registration of a trademark on the basis of relative grounds, and recognition of national competences which, on the other hand, promotes innovation.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This Recommendation is aimed at amending the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks, which aims to complement the Community Trade Marks Regulation by harmonising national rules on trade marks. In order to achieve such harmonisation of national and European trade mark systems, EU trade mark provisions will also apply in national trade, thus aligning the Regulation and the Directive and bringing Member States' regulations closer together.  The main objective of this Recommendation is to drive innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems more accessible and efficient across the EU. That is why I voted in favour of this Recommendation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to approximate the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. Directive 2008/95/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council needs to make certain amendments, in the interests of clarity, which should be recast. That Directive harmonised in 2008 the essential provisions of substantive trade mark law which, as was considered to have had a direct impact on the functioning of the internal market, as they constituted obstacles to the free movement of goods and the freedom to provide services within the Union.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States' trade mark legislation has already been partially harmonised by Directives 89/104/EEC and 2008/95/EC.  One of the aims of the current legislation is to modernise existing provisions by amending outdated legislation. The amendments aim at increasing legal certainty and clarifying the scope and restrictions. The other task is to further approach national regulations. Another objective is to promote cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies. This initiative is also part of the Community trade mark package.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed recommendation, as it is an extremely demanding and important document which, on the one hand, highlights the challenging area of counterfeiting or copyright infringement and, on the other hand, the creation of competitiveness, innovation and, at the same time, simplification of procedures. The latter is often quite difficult to achieve, at the same time it is about finding and penalising law breakers and simplifying procedures. As one of the key issues in this legislation, I would like to highlight the simplification of procedures and their price underpipment, thus improving access for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the driving force of the European economy. It's a good thing we listened to them.  I also hope that this report will also become a good brand for both the European Parliament and Europe as a whole.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. The redesign of the Directive bringing Member States' trademark laws closer together aims to facilitate the uniform registration, administration and protection of trademarks in the EU. This text promotes innovation (a new definition of a brand removing the requirement of a graphic representation thus allowing the creation of sound marks, movement marks, holograms, etc.) while allowing greater protection for economic operators especially French (strengthening cases of refusal of a brand in case of confrontation with previous rights (names of origin, geographical indications, traditional mentions) ). I voted in favour of this text in the Committee on Legal Affairs. I therefore voted in favour of this text by voting against the amendment to reject the text tabled by another group.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The laws of the Member States must be adapted to the new EU legislation for the protection of trademarks and the fight against counterfeiting. The fight against illegality and the protection of the intellectual property of European citizens from the undue appropriation of those outside the common market will be all the more effective as they are actively supported by the Member States and by the correct adaptation of national regulations, with a view to harmonisation and cooperation for the common defence of the quality of production and work of European companies.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. It is a question of voting on the sole rejection amendment, tabled by the EFDD group, on the reform of the Community trademark system. It must bring national laws together and contribute to the protection of trademarks in the European Union. The text also proposes to give a new definition of a mark by removing the requirement of a graphic representation. From now on, a brand will be able to define itself through its sound characteristic or even olfactory and taste, thus allowing better framing of intellectual property. However, the sign will have to be represented in a clear and distinct manner. While promoting innovation, this text also helps to better protect economic actors who derive their income from a particular know-how often linked to a geographical origin. One thinks in particular of the winemakers who will benefit more from this reform. So I voted against the rejection amendment.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Some objectives of the European Union can only be achieved through uniform regulation through community-wide construction, and one of those objectives is the protection of registered Community trade marks and the protection of the Community market against the penetration of counterfeit goods. The Union framework needs legislative coherence with regard to intellectual property rights, which is necessary in order to be able to better protect these rights and for any citizen of the Union to be able to exploit them, regardless of which Member State they are in. The aim is to strengthen cooperation between the European Union Intellectual Property Office and the offices of the Member States so that the assets of intellectual property rights holders are protected throughout the Union. For these reasons, I support increased protection of registered trade marks and a more effective fight against counterfeiting of goods, without prejudice to WTO rules, in particular freedom of transit, and support this harmonisation by voting in favour.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote.  It should be borne in mind that the final vote is not taken at second reading. In this case, therefore, we are only voting on the proposal to reject the EFDD Group. A majority of MEMBERS of the EP are required to reject the Council's position.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position on this issue. Firstly, this report would have approved the issuing of a Directive to the United Kingdom to pass laws implementing the approved new legislation. In particular the Directive has as a substantial purpose, the Europeanisation and harmonisation of Trade Mark law and thus would enable the EU to consolidate its power over this important aspect of intellectual property and remove yet more control over it from Member States.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I agree and support the report positively with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States on trade marks.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the proposal for a recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. Although this proposal is theoretically aimed at modernising what is applicable at European level to trademarks, I believe that it concerns very delicate business protection issues and that a very thorough dialogue is needed to achieve the desired results, which has not happened. That is why I decided to vote against it.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal for rejection tabled by the EFDD Group which, if adopted, would have rejected the Council's position and closed the procedure. Parliament has proposed some changes in the governance of the OHIM, in particular in the composition of the Management Board and the selection of the Executive Director of the Agency. As regards goods in transit, the measure in question establishes the right of the proprietor of a registered trade mark to oppose the introduction of products from third countries into the territory of the Union when those goods bear an unauthorised trade mark, which is identical to the validly registered Community trade mark. This provision shall not apply if the final destination of the goods is a country outside the territory of the Union and if the holder cannot prove that his is validly registered in the country of final destination.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against Cecilia Wikstrom's report because I consider the measures explained in the report to improve the product market in the EU to be inappropriate. The proposal underlines the fact that the owner of a European trade mark may object to the entry into the Union of a product from a third country that can compete with the home brand. I think that this is an exaggerated measure, which closes relations with third countries too much, and the Eu ropean Union absolutely must take care of European products in the first place, but this must not, in my view, preclude relations with non-European states in trade matters.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The idea of the proposal is to make trademark registration across the EU more accessible and efficient. This is to be done by increasing legal certainty by clarifying provisions and establishing better cooperation between OHIM (Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market) and national offices. The laws of the MS relating to trademarks were partially harmonised by Directives 89/104/EEC and 2008/95/EC. The proposal will further that harmonisation. Ireland broadly supports the measures contained within the proposals, which were generally welcomed by our stakeholders, as it was considered that they would constitute positive developments from the perspective of the likely business interests in Ireland, as it is believed that innovative export oriented companies require a predictable and consistent legal and regulatory environment across Europe within which they can exploit the competitive advantage of their intellectual property rights, without undue expense and onerous administrative burden.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the new rules will, on the one hand, provide greater legal certainty for manufacturers and brand owners and, on the other hand, will better protect the consumer who trusts in brands. To this end, procedures must be adapted and modernised at both European and nation state level. This report is an important step in the right direction.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report. The Directive will make a significant contribution to the approximation of trade mark laws and, in particular, to modernising and improving the current provisions in force which are obsolete in relation to current market requirements, increasing legal certainty. It will also facilitate cooperation between the various competent national and European actors.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The national laws of the Member States relating to trademarks were partially harmonised by Directives 89/104/EEC and 2008/95/EC. The aim of this recast Directive is to modernise and improve the existing provisions of the current Directive by amending outdated provisions, increasing legal certainty and clarifying trademarks rights in terms of scope and limitations and by facilitating cooperation between national trademark offices and the OHIM. A coherent trademark protection at EU level is an important tool to foster innovation, thus I voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to reformulate the Community Trade Mark Regulation and the Directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. This report and the following are parts of a renewal package for the entire trademark system at European level. The basic functioning of the trademark system is as follows: a producer of a good or service who intends to protect the name and general characteristics of his product has to register his mark at both national and European levels, defining the essential name and characteristics of his product. This registration allows the producer or company to be protected against copying, counterfeiting or non-authorization. This report aims, through the Directive, to approximate national registration systems. Among other aspects, it provides for the simplification of the trademark registration process. As a whole, these reports contain positive aspects, but also some negative ones, such as blocking systems, which do not exclude generic drugs, despite alerts from organizations such as Doctors Without Borders. That's why I abstained.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The second legal instrument adopted under the Community or EU trade mark reform is a directive on the approximation of the laws applicable to trade marks in the Member States. The regulation, which is another part of the reform, applies to Community trade marks and, through that Harmonisation Directive, the EU legislature supports European innovation and economic growth. The Directive makes the provisions concerning trade marks more transparent, increasing legal certainty. The Directive also aims to bring the substantive law and procedures applicable to national trade marks closer together, thereby facilitating their alignment with the EU trade mark system. Simpler cooperation between member states' trade mark offices and the EU harmonisation and internal market office envisaged in the Directive will also contribute to a more efficient functioning of the internal market. Thanks to the reforms, European SMEs can work cheaper and more simply with a better legal and administrative framework.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with a directive about Laws of Member States relating to trade marks. It is meant to complement the Community Trade Mark Regulation, by harmonising national rules on trade marks. In order to harmonise EU and national trade mark systems, the provisions of EU trade marks will also apply to national trade marks. The main objective of the proposal is to foster innovation and economic growth by making trade mark registration systems all over the EU more accessible and efficient. These are all measures that further protect trade marks and foster innovation, which I am all in favour of, hence I supported the outcome of this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that this revision of the Directive which harmonises certain aspects of trade mark law of the Member States of the European Union and which has existed for more than 20 years provides an opportunity to learn from the best practices identified and to further strengthen the harmonisation measures adopted by national trade mark offices with regard to substantive and procedural aspects of trade mark law.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to make trademark registration cheaper, faster and more reliable for businesses. It proposes an overhaul of EU directives for the harmonisation of national trademark laws, in order to modernise current provisions and strengthen legal certainty while clarifying trademark rights. The text also seeks to improve cooperation between national offices and the Internal Market Harmonization Office (OHMI). An agreement has also been reached on goods in transit, giving the holder of a registered trademark the right to object to the importation of goods from third countries within the Territory of the European Union when an unauthorized mark identical to the duly registered European mark is affixed to those products. This right does not apply if the final destination of the products is not a Member State of the Union and the trademark holder is unable to prove that the trademark is validly registered in the final destination country. Considering that this report is an additional trade tool to promote and defend European products around the world, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position on this issue. Firstly, this report would have approved the issuing of a Directive to the United Kingdom to pass laws implementing the approved new legislation. In particular the Directive has as a substantial purpose, the Europeanisation and harmonisation of Trade Mark law and thus would enable the EU to consolidate its power over this important aspect of intellectual property and remove yet more control over it from Member States.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal to revise the 2008 directive, bringing national trademark laws closer together. This proposal includes amending outdated provisions, further aligning national procedures with the Community trademark system and creating a legal basis for cooperation between the Internal Market Harmonization Office (OHMI) and the national offices of Member States.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. In deciding to review its system of protecting EU "brands" for its businesses, particularly SMEs, the EU has just corrected a legal vacuum in its legislation. Customs authorities will now be able to ban goods bearing, without authorisation, a registered trademark at EU level. These new rules will also allow for cheaper, faster registration, and will ensure better legal certainty.  This modernization of the Community trademark system was essential to face too often unfair competition from non-EU companies.  This responds to a growing expectation of the "brands" themselves, to be better protected throughout Europe. In 2012, for example, 107,900 applications were made, double those registered 10 years earlier by the European Trademark Office. As a reminder, the branded products industry directly accounts for 21% of employment in Europe and 34% of European GDP.  Finally, it should be noted that generic medicines will be exempted under the WTO TRIPS agreements allowing them to benefit from a specific regime, which is in line with our international commitments to developing countries.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support this proposal. It has managed to focus and preserve some of the most important issues, focusing on enhancing consumer and rightholder protection compatible with national legal systems, good management of the OHIM and improving competitiveness. It is very important to focus on these issues if we want an effective system of cohabitation and complementarity between European and national trademark systems.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote in favour of the amendment. The amendment proposes rejecting the Council's position on the approximation of the laws of the Member States on trade marks, as (a) it does not adequately fill the existing legal gaps and (b) the attempt to fully harmonise the legislation of all Member States in the long term leads to a leveling of the specificity of each of them and, consequently, to the homogenisation sought by the EU strong.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States' trade mark legislation has already been partially harmonised by Directives 89/104/EEC and 2008/95/EC.  The aim of the current legislation is to modernise the existing provisions by amending outdated legislation. The amendments aim at increasing legal certainty and clarifying the scope and restrictions. 2. Further approach to national regulations 3. Facilitate cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies. This initiative is also part of the Community trade mark package.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The trade mark package submitted by the Commission, consisting of two legislative proposals, aims to improve and modernise the existing provisions of the current Directive, as well as to achieve a greater approximation of national trade mark laws and procedures, and to facilitate cooperation between national offices and OHIM.  It is worth noting issues relating to the effects of the mark on private imports in the case of small shipments, the transit of goods in the EU (in particular generic medicines), limitations on the effects of EU trade marks (e.g. on fundamental rights), the future name of the Agency and its government, cooperation between the Agency and the Intellectual Property Offices of the various Member States , the use of financial resources and the general approach to the Commission's proposal, which includes 63 different delegations of the legislative branch in the proposal for a Regulation.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is in the direction of better trademark protection.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of these reports is the recast of the Community Trade Mark Regulation and the Directive relating to Member States' trade mark legislation. They are part of a renewal package of the entire brand system at European level. The basic operation of the marking system is as follows: A producer of a good or service that intends to protect the name and general characteristics of its product must register its marks at both national and European levels. To do so, you must register your trade mark in the national and European registers, defining the name and essential characteristics of your product. Each type of product is affected to a "class" of products. This registration allows the producer or company to be protected against copying, forgery, non-legitimate or unauthorized use. This report aims, in particular, through the Directive, to bring national registration systems closer together. Among other things, the registration process for trade marks is envisaged. Taken together, these reports contain positive aspects, but also others that give us reservations – such as the blocking system (which does not exclude generic medicines, despite calls from organisations such as Médecins Sans Sans Sans Fronteiras).

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure because it guarantees greater protection for consumers and rightholders for the sale of small shipments via the Internet, strengthens cooperation between Member States and OHIM and improves the competitiveness of companies.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Knowing that the defence of industrial and enterprise marks are important,  but also being very suspicious and careful with the broadening possibilities of blocking goods through customs procurement our shadow I believed that it was preferable to abstain on the whole package.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The recast directive is intended to complement the Regulation on the so-called 'Green Paper'. european Union trade mark by harmonising national trade mark rules. It is part of the same package as the regulation and was negotiated together. In order to harmonise the national systems of European Union trade marks, the provisions of european Union trade marks will also apply to national trade marks, thereby bringing the Regulation into line with the Directive and the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. The main objective of the proposal is to promote innovation and economic growth.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the proposal to reject the EFDD Group, the text of the agreement brings improvements, but there are still many developments that we hope will be able to give our firm support to the text.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks because it proposes to reject the Council's position on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks, as (a) it does not adequately fill existing legal gaps and (b) the attempt to fully harmonise the legislation of all Member States in the long term leads to the flattening of the specificity of each of them and, consequently, to the homogenisation sought by the EU's powerful.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report relating to trademarks.  I am glad to see that this report aimed to defend consumer rights and protection, reduce counterfeit products, enhance governance and generate innovation and competitiveness. In a welcome change, the EU has finally cut some red tape for businesses.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This Directive aims at approximating EU countries' laws relating to trade marks, in order to foster the free movement of goods and services and free competition within the internal market. This approximation concerns the fundamental rules on trade marks acquired by registration. EU countries retain the right to organise the procedural aspect and the protection of trade marks acquired through use.

Facilitate cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies. This initiative is also part of the Community trade mark package.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour once I considered the positions of the different EU institutions and bearing in mind the need to provide us with a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. This proposal will make it much easier to register European brands in the future. At the same time, the protection and control of existing brands will be significantly improved. This is an important step for me, which has my full support.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on laws of Member States relating to trade marks. This is a recast of the original file, simply a codification to take into account changes made to other pieces of legislation, including the report regarding the Community Trade Mark.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on the report on the approximation of the laws of the Member States in the field of trade marks. We understand that, as in the case of text A8-0354/2015, the clarification of the system is insufficient as regards the blocking of property. However, we understand that the will of the dossier is positive, as long as it is proceeding towards regulation that simplifies the regulatory multiplicity of trademarks. We hope that, in any event, future reports to approximate the legislation of the Member States in the field of trademarks will have as their starting point the multiplicity of the dispute within all regions.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with a directive about laws of Member States relating to trade marks. It is meant to complement the Community Trade Mark Regulation, by harmonising national rules on trade marks. In order to harmonise EU and national trade mark systems, the provisions of EU trade marks will also apply to national trade marks. The main objective of the proposal is to foster innovation and economic growth by making trade mark registration systems all over the EU more accessible and efficient. These are all measures that further protect trade marks and foster innovation, which I am all in favour of, hence I supported the outcome of this report.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position on this issue. Firstly, this report would have approved the issuing of a Directive to the United Kingdom to pass laws implementing the approved new legislation. In particular the Directive has as a substantial purpose, the Europeanisation and harmonisation of Trade Mark law and thus would enable the EU to consolidate its power over this important aspect of intellectual property and remove yet more control over it from Member States.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States' trade mark legislation has already been partially harmonised by Directives 89/104/EEC and 2008/95/EC. Objectives of the current legislation: 1. Modernisation of existing provisions by amending outdated legislation. The objective of the amendments is to increase legal certainty and to clarify the rules with regard to scope and restrictions. 2. Further approach to national regulations.  3. Promote cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies. This initiative is also part of the Community trade mark package.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Although there was no vote in plenary on the two reports of the Committee on Legal Affairs, as the ordinary legislative procedure concerning the trademark regulation is in the second reading procedure, we voted against the amendment of the Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy (EFDD) Group which essentially called for the rejection of the two reports and the closure of the whole process of reforming the legislative framework for trademark registration.
