As acpl, we have supported the legislative process as it broadens measures to protect domestic products, preserving the name and specific characteristics of products, from imitations and their illegal sale within Community borders.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal of the Council.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The idea of this proposal is to make the systems for the protection of trademarks (logos, etc.) in the various Member States compatible, with each other and with the European Office for Harmonisation (OHIM). This is a sensible approach in a common internal market. It respects the principle of subsidiarity. This directive will increase competition among producers and take account of consumer protection through the recognition of trade marks. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive that will identify trade mark laws in Member States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted against the EFDD amendment because it rejects the Council's position. As I fully support the recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on the harmonisation of Member States' trade mark legislation on Ms Wikström's trade marks, the amendment is not acceptable to me.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The Council has adopted its position on the reform of the European trademark system. This reform contains a proposal for a directive to standardising Member States' trademark laws and a proposal to amend the EU trademark regulation (EC) 207/2009.  The reform proposal renews the definition of a mark by removing the requirement for graphic representation, to allow the registration of marks of new forms, such as sound marks, movement marks of holograms without potentially excluding olfactory or taste marks. The brand sign should be represented in a clear, precise, distinct, intelligible way. The text also lists grounds for refusal or nullity regarding the mark. There is also the right for Member States to decide to carry out checks on relative grounds of refusal of office, the establishment of an administrative procedure before each national office to oppose the registration of a trademark on the basis of relative grounds and the establishment of an administrative procedure before each national office in respect of the forfeiture or nullity of a trademark. This text protects innovation and allows greater protection for economic operators, especially with regard to PGIs. I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position on this issue. Firstly, this report would have approved the issuing of a directive to the United Kingdom to pass laws implementing the approved new legislation. In particular the directive has as a substantial purpose, the Europeanisation and harmonisation of trade mark law and thus would enable the EU to consolidate its power over this important aspect of intellectual property and remove yet more control over it from Member States.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I rejected the deletion amendment on the text on the reconciliation of Member States' trademark laws because I believe that this text is legitimate. The aim of harmonising state trademark laws is to strengthen legal certainty and clarify standards. Better cooperation between national offices and the Intellectual Property Protection Office is to be supported. With this text the European Parliament has achieved the sharp reduction in the registration costs of European trademarks and the simplification and harmonisation of procedures. National offices will also receive financial compensation.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from voting on this report. I consider many of the points raised to be useful, but a whole commodity drawing in the EU is not very useful.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is simply a codification to take into account changes made to other pieces of legislation.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The idea of this proposal is to make the systems for the protection of trademarks (logos, etc.) compatible in the various Member States, with each other and with the European Office for Harmonisation (OHIM). This is a sensible approach in a common internal market. It respects the principle of subsidiarity. This directive will increase competition among producers and take account of consumer protection through the recognition of trade marks. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States' trade mark legislation has already been partially harmonised by Directives 89/104/EEC and 2008/95/EC.  The aim of the current legislation is to modernise the existing provisions by amending outdated legislation. The amendments aim at increasing legal certainty and clarifying the scope and restrictions. 2. Further approach to national regulations 3. Facilitate cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies. This initiative is also part of the Community trade mark package.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is on the recast on the community registered trademarks. The aim of this report is to modernise the procedures for the registration of marks, as well as the shift from a community approach to an EU approach. This report will also block the transit of goods from third countries which are counterfeited. However, the generic medicines are not excluded from this blockage. I voted against this report, because I am very suspicious and careful with the broadening possibilities of blocking goods.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative package to overhaul trademark law, which is crucial for innovation and the fight against counterfeiting in Europe. We have achieved a significant reduction in the fees for registering trademarks in the EU and the introduction of simplified and harmonised procedures for the benefit of our companies. But the cornerstone of this reform remains the strengthening of anti-counterfeiting means, as trademark holders can now oppose the introduction of products from third countries on EU territory when these products bear, without authorisation, a mark identical to the duly registered European mark. Therefore, without going against our obligations in international trade, we have thus sent a strong message: we must protect ourselves from counterfeit goods that weaken our businesses and endanger our fellow citizens.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I am in favour of reforming the European trademark system, so I voted against the rejection amendment tabled by the EFDD group. The reform aims to facilitate the registration, administration and uniform protection of trademarks in the European Union. It gives a new definition of a mark by removing the requirement of a graphic representation to allow the registration of marks of new forms, such as sound marks, movement marks of holograms without potentially excluding olfactory or taste marks. There is also the right for Member States to decide to carry out checks on relative grounds of refusal of office, the establishment of an administrative procedure before each national office to oppose the registration of a trademark on the basis of relative grounds and the establishment of an administrative procedure before each national office in respect of the forfeiture or nullity of a trademark. This text promotes innovation and allows greater protection for operators.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. We are currently in an environment of increasing competitiveness in which brands play a crucial role in the market. Within this framework, it is worth noting the success of the creation of OHIM, as it has greatly strengthened the EU's competitiveness.  This report aims to make trademark registration systems across the EU more accessible and efficient for businesses through cost reduction. It is therefore necessary to simplify the processes of application and registration of a European trade mark.  To this end, the EU aims to establish an appropriate framework for cooperation between OHIM and national offices, in order to promote the convergence of OHIM practices and to develop common tools that promote greater speed and clarity in the process.  I strongly support this report, as establishing accessible and efficient trademark registration systems across the EU will foster innovation and economic growth.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The idea of this proposal is to make the systems for the protection of trademarks (logos, etc.) in the various Member States compatible, with each other and with the European Office for Harmonisation (OHIM). This is a sensible approach in a common internal market. It respects the principle of subsidiarity. This directive will increase competition among producers and take account of consumer protection through the recognition of trade marks. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As in the case of an EU trade mark, where one of the tasks of the new regulation is to standardise the compatibility of transnational and national systems, this directive referred primarily to the promotion of the compatibility of the policies relating to trade marks in different Member States. One interesting aspect of the new directive is the possibility of eliminating the existence of a trade mark after 5 years of its total non-udation. In history, there are few cases where trademarks (including political parties) are re-revived in the hands of other owners. This directive will standardise this system at EU level to make the re-registration of trade marks easier across the Union. Another important aspect is the fight against counterfeiting of trade marks, which relates in particular to medical medicinal products. It is one thing to buy illegally produced trousers or a radio receiver – this may, of course, be not very desirable, but illegal medicines or food can cause quite serious damage to human health. In other words, the adoption of the new directive was not only logical but also necessary: the defence of consumer rights must always be one of the most important aspects of the policy aspects of our Member States and of the Union as a whole.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks, because I believe that it is neither complete nor substantiated, but also for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech of 14/12/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased we were able to agree at first reading the proposal to approximate the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this rejection amendment and, as with the previous vote, I am in favour of this reform, although there is no final vote. This redesign aims to bring Member States' trademark laws closer together to facilitate the registration, administration and uniform protection of EU trademarks. This text will promote innovation and allow greater protection for economic operators.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt that I did not vote in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position on the approximation of Member States' laws on trade marks, as I believe that greater negotiation between the various political groups would be necessary.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of Mrs Wikstrom's proposal. With this proposal, important and essential changes have been made to the governance of the OHIM. These are changes to the composition of the Management Board and the selection of the Executive Director of the Agency. With regard to goods in transit, on the other hand, a compromise has been found consisting in the assurance of the right of the proprietor of a registered trade mark to oppose the introduction of products from third countries into the territory of the Union, when those goods bear an unauthorised mark identical to the validly registered Community trade mark. This rule does not apply in two cases: if the final destination of the goods is a country outside the European Union and if the holder cannot prove that his is validly registered in the country of final destination.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, there is no objection to the report, but the improvements are not clear. Moreover, the necessity of the project is questionable. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The new Trademark Directive aligns the main procedural rules on trademark registration in Member States with those of the EU trademark system. Registered trademarks should thus enjoy the same protection in the legal systems of all Member States. This text will facilitate the establishment of solidarity protectionism. Nevertheless, I note that generic drugs are not clearly excluded from this directive. That's why I abstain

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This reform contains a proposal for a directive to standardising Member States' trademark laws and a proposal to amend the EU trademark regulation (EC) No. 207/2009. The reform proposal renews the definition of a mark by removing the requirement for graphic representation, to allow the registration of marks of new forms, such as sound marks, movement marks of holograms without potentially excluding olfactory or taste marks. The brand sign should be represented in a clear, precise, distinct, intelligible way. The text also lists grounds for refusal or nullity regarding the mark. There is also the right for Member States to decide, to carry out checks on relative grounds of refusal of office, the establishment of an administrative procedure before each national office to oppose the registration of a trademark on the basis of relative grounds and the establishment of an administrative procedure before each national office in respect of forfeiture or nullity of a trademark. This text protects innovation and allows greater protection for economic operators, especially with regard to PGIs.  I therefore vote against the rejection proposal.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have presented my vote in agreement with the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading on the adoption of a directive bringing member states' trade mark legislation closer to. It aims to simplify and update trade mark legislation, both at national and EU level, and to make registration of trade marks in the EU less costly, faster, more reliable and more predictable, while also increasing legal certainty for trade mark holders.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it follows on from Commission Directives 89/104/EEC and 2008/95/EC where Member State laws were partially harmonised in relation to trademarks.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. This redesign is positive and targeted to make brand protection easier, cheaper and more effective. It is therefore a question of streamlining registration procedures, modernising legislation, increasing legal certainty, grooming existing texts, promoting cooperation between Member States, strengthening the fight against counterfeit goods in transit on EU territory, etc. All this makes me say that we are stronger working together and that we have a constant need for "better Europe" in a globalised world.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the final agreement reached on the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks (Recast Directive), which is meant to complement the Community Trade Mark Regulation, by harmonising national rules on trade marks. The main objective of the proposal is to foster innovation and economic growth by making trademark registration systems all over the EU more accessible and efficient.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has submitted a proposal to Parliament and the Council on the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. On 25 February 2014, Parliament established its first reading position on the proposal. In its recommendation, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that Parliament agree at second reading with the Council's position at first reading, thereby making the directive legal in accordance with the Council's position. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to revise the directive bringing Member States' laws closer together on trademarks in order to facilitate the registration, administration and uniform protection of trademarks in the EU. The aim is to give a new definition of the brand taking into account technological developments (removing the requirement for graphic representation to allow the recognition of sound marks, such as olfactory marks, etc.). However, the sign must be represented in a clear, precise, distinct, easily accessible, intelligible, durable and objective manner. Reasons for denying trademarks are listed exhaustively (lack of distinctiveness, or with respect to conflicts between the trademark and prior rights, and it should be noted that the absolute grounds for refusal to be refused appellations of origin, etc.) are extended.  States will be able to carry out checks on relative grounds of refusal of office, set up an administrative procedure before each national office to oppose the registration of a trademark on the basis of the relative grounds and the establishment of an administrative procedure before each national office regarding the forfeiture or nullity of a trademark. I voted against the amendment to reject this text, which promotes economic innovation and allows for greater protection, in particular, of PGI.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the final adoption of the draft reform of European trademark law, introduced by the Commission more than two years ago. The aim is to improve the competitiveness of European companies by introducing simplified, harmonised and less costly procedures for registering a trademark. This reform will also strengthen the defences of trademark holders by allowing them to oppose the introduction of products from third countries when they carry, without authorisation, a mark identical to the duly registered European trademark.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Intended as a complement to the EU trade mark regulation, this directive on legislation – on which I voted in favour – has as its main objective the harmonisation of national rules on trade marks. Quite simply, the regulatory provisions for the EU label will also apply at national level. This will have the effect of increasing legal certainty for businesses and consumers, in addition by lowering EU-wide registration costs for businesses, which will have more resources for investment. We must not forget, in fact, that protecting intellectual property means guaranteeing citizens correct information on the products they are buying and companies returning in particular on investment in research and development. Indeed, a more accessible system of trademark registration at EU and national level promotes innovation and growth, protects European production excellence and – ultimately – is a, albeit limited, further step in support of skilled employment. For this legislative text and for the text on the EU label, we must underline the intense and arduous work of the Italian Presidency of the EU Council, which – in conjunction with the representatives of the European Parliament – has led to an agreement on the main political and technical issues, paving the way for the closure of the agreement.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this proposal for a directive which modernises the trade mark regulation more functionally at Community level. The measure, which has become necessary in order to harmonise European and national systems on trade marks, will also apply at Member State level by attempting to approximate the regulations that the various States have so far put in place. This directive is important to us because it will promote innovation and economic growth by creating a single system for registering trademarks, which is efficient and accessible from all over the EU. In the same way, it will contribute to the fight against trademark counterfeiting, which is an essential tool for safeguarding our high standards for the protection of consumer health, workers' rights and respect for human rights.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive to approximate the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have abstained from voting on this report. The aim of the report is to make the registration of trade marks more cost-effective, faster and more reliable. This includes the confiscation of counterfeit goods in transit in the EU, which is made possible by new rules. The report is very good in principle, but I do not have a few points to support it.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled.  Trade mark registration systems must be simplified and of higher quality. They need to be more compatible with each other and be publicly accessible and in line with technological progress. It is therefore essential that the trade mark registration systems of EU Member States be harmonised. The measures provided for in the report would make these systems more efficient, cheaper, simpler, faster, more predictable and more legal certainty. Greater attention must be paid to the protection and management of trade marks. There is a need to reduce the inconsistencies in the current regulatory framework and to remove existing barriers and burdens on businesses. The laws of the Member States relating to trade marks must be more compatible with the Community trade mark system. Efforts must therefore continue to harmonise national trade mark legislation and procedures more closely. It is also essential to improve cooperation between the services responsible for trade marks.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position on this issue. Firstly, this report would have approved the issuing of a Directive to the United Kingdom to pass laws implementing the approved new legislation. In particular the Directive has as a substantial purpose, the Europeanisation and harmonisation of Trade Mark law and thus would enable the EU to consolidate its power over this important aspect of intellectual property and remove yet more control over it from Member States.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur for her work and I align with the position expressed earlier by voting against.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the adoption of this proposal as it introduces clearer ways to facilitate the registration, management and protection of trade marks on the European market. This way, the convergence of national systems towards meeting several of the main objectives of the European Union and the common market is achieved, namely to stimulate growth, competitiveness and competitiveness.  With this move, the European Union is embarking on a widespread market challenge, which is the suppression of the trade in pirated goods. Clearly declaring products according to all necessary specifications (geographical origin, production methods, traditional characteristics) raises the protection of consumer rights to a higher level.  Greater approximation of national trade mark laws and procedures should be encouraged with a view to becoming more consistent with the common trade mark system, by adding appropriate rules and necessary categories of product labelling, reducing the cost of product registration, introducing a trade mark information system at Union level and achieving greater legal certainty for producers and consumers.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to revise the directive bringing Member States' laws closer together on trademarks in order to facilitate the registration, administration and uniform protection of trademarks in the EU. The aim is to give a new definition of the brand taking into account technological developments (removal of the requirement of graphic representation to allow the recognition of sound or olfactory marks for example). However, the sign must be represented in a clear, precise, distinct, easily accessible, intelligible, durable and objective manner. Reasons for denying trademarks are listed exhaustively (lack of distinctiveness, conflicts between the trademark and prior rights, extension of absolute grounds for refusal to appellations of origin, etc.). States will be able to carry out checks on relative grounds of refusal of office, set up an administrative procedure before each national office to oppose the registration of a trademark on the basis of the relative grounds and the establishment of an administrative procedure before each national office regarding the forfeiture or nullity of a trademark. I voted against the amendment to reject this text, which promotes economic innovation and allows for greater protection, in particular, of PGI.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. In addition to trademark protection before the national offices of the Member States of the European Union, it is also possible to protect the Community trade mark. A Community trade mark (or Community Trade Mark, abbreviated CTM) is valid in all Member States of the European Union and the registration procedure for such a trade mark is carried out by the Office for Harmonization in Internal Market (OHIM) based in Alicante, Spain.  A Community trade mark applies to the European Union as a whole and it is not possible to geographically limit the scope of protection to only some member states. In addition, a trade mark is often a cheaper alternative than protecting against, for example, the originality of a product. Amending Community trademark regulation will allow further progress in the fight against product counterfeiting and a greater level of protection of consumer rights, public health and safety.  I support these changes because their intention is to stimulate economic growth and innovation through a more accessible and efficient trademark registration system through simplification and refinement of regulation and fostering greater cooperation between national and European levels.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 A trade mark serves to distinguish a company's products and services. It is through the brand that a company can attract and retain customers, creating added value and economic growth. I voted in favour of this initiative to recast the directive because it aims to achieve important objectives: to modernise and improve the existing provisions by amending obsolete provisions, increasing legal certainty and clarifying trade mark rights in terms of scope and limits; to achieve greater approximation of national trade mark laws and procedures in order to make them more consistent with the Community trade mark system; to facilitate cooperation between the offices of the Member States and the OHIM (Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market) to promote the convergence of practices and the development of common instruments, by creating a legal basis for such cooperation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against rejecting the texts submitted by the Council. An agreement has finally been reached and it is our duty to support it, in order to advance legislation and reflection.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council position on this issue. Firstly, this report would have approved the issuing of a Directive to the United Kingdom to pass laws implementing the approved new legislation. In particular the Directive has as a substantial purpose, the Europeanisation and harmonisation of Trade Mark law and thus would enable the EU to consolidate its power over this important aspect of intellectual property and remove yet more control over it from Member States.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to modernise the rules on trademarks to make it easier to register trademarks in the European Union and, above all, to better combat counterfeiting. The European rules on trademarks, logos or symbols that distinguish a company's products or services, were established some 20 years ago. So it was time to adapt them. From now on, procedures will also be shorter and lighter in order to support businesses and especially SMEs. Also, thanks to lower taxes, the cost of registration is expected to fall significantly. The new rules also make sure to strengthen the fight against counterfeit products in Europe, good news!

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the revision of the directive on Member States' trademark legislation. Member States' legislation had only been partially harmonised by Directive 89/104/EEC and 2008/95/EC, and the proposed revision aims to modernise and improve the current provisions, achieve optimal harmonisation of national laws and procedures and promote cooperation between national offices and OHIM.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on the report on the approximation of the laws of the Member States in the field of trade marks. We understand that, as in the case of text A8-0354/2015, the clarification of the system is insufficient as regards the blocking of property. However, we understand that the will of the dossier is positive, as long as it is proceeding towards regulation that simplifies the regulatory multiplicity of trademarks. We hope that, in any event, future reports to approximate the legislation of the Member States in the field of trademarks will have as their starting point the multiplicity of the dispute within all regions.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to reformulate the Community Trade Mark Regulation and the Directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. This report and the following are parts of a renewal package for the entire trademark system at European level. The basic functioning of the trademark system is as follows: a producer of a good or service who intends to protect the name and general characteristics of his product has to register his mark at both national and European levels, defining the essential name and characteristics of his product. This registration allows the producer or company to be protected against copying, counterfeiting or non-authorization. This report aims, through the Directive, to approximate national registration systems. Among other aspects, it provides for the simplification of the trademark registration process. As a whole, these reports contain positive aspects, but also some negative ones, such as blocking systems, which do not exclude generic drugs, despite alerts from organizations such as Doctors Without Borders. That's why I abstained.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to amend the Business Trade Mark Directive because I am convinced that it is important to develop common instruments in order to improve cooperation between member states and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (UMAI). The changes voted on today are very significant, mainly because they will bring greater clarity and legal certainty and contribute to the fight against counterfeiting. In addition, this report calls for a simplification of procedures, greater consumer protection, better competitiveness of European businesses and a reduction in costs for all users.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion to reject the original proposal as I am against the EU bringing in legislation in this area.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Recast Directive is supposed to complement the Community’s Trade Mark Regulations by harmonising national rules on trade marks, and is a part of the same package as the regulation. The priorities that Labour MEPs had for this legislative proposal concerned defending human rights, preserving public health and safety as well as conserving jobs. For me this means guaranteeing a better deal for the people of the West Midlands and I believe that these laws will achieve this. Furthermore, the European Parliament was also able to achieve lower fees – by up to 37%  – and made a system that not only benefits the users of trade marks but has lowered the bureaucratic burden and made it far more efficient.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Directive on the convergence of laws of the Member States in the field of trade marks because I believe that unification on this issue will contribute to greater clarity of trade marks across the European Union. This modification of the Directive brings a number of improvements aimed at increasing legal certainty and clarifying the scope of the lawful use of member countries' trade marks. This brings the system closer to the way a European trade mark is applied at national level and also facilitates mutual communication between European and national authorisation authorities.  Under this scheme, trade marks should be easier to register and protect within all Member States. The conditions under which the applicant will be able to register the mark will also be clearer. The Directive provides examples of signs that can be considered as a trade mark and also mentions clear reasons why registration can be refused or declared invalid. On the other hand, the Member State retains the right to decide whether to open an investigation into the refusal of registration. It will also be possible to use trademarks in your business name. These and other measures are also needed to make European products and businesses more competitive vis-à-vis third countries.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In 2013, the Commission prepared a new package of measures reforming the legislative regulation of trademarks. The reason for reforming this area was, in particular, the desire to better clarify the right acquired through the registration of the trade mark and also to better define the limitations of that right.  The new package of measures also includes a reduction in trade mark fees covering all 28 Member States, sets out improved, more efficient and harmonised registration procedures and advocates enhanced protection against counterfeits, particularly as regards goods in transit through EU territory. The latter poses a worrying problem, as this provision risks jeopardising the flow of legal medicines through the EU into developing countries.  In particular, the international non-proprietary names (INN) which are officially non-proprietary or generic names of a particular pharmaceutical substance certified by the World Health Organisation (WHO) could be an obstacle to the smooth transit of generic medicines.  Ensuring consumer protection is of paramount importance in this area, which, in my opinion, could seriously undermine the new brand package. In the absence of adequate regulation of the area and the necessary corrections in the reformed package of trademark-specific measures, I voted in plenary in favour of the adoption of an amendment refusing to accept the recommendation.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The idea of this proposal is to make the systems for the protection of trademarks (logos, etc.) in the various Member States compatible, with each other and with the European Office for Harmonisation (OHIM). This is a sensible approach in a common internal market. It respects the principle of subsidiarity. This directive will increase competition among producers and take account of consumer protection through the recognition of trade marks. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The amendment of trade mark legislation aims to improve cooperation between national authorities and the central European Trade Mark Office. More efficient work between these institutions will contribute to better conditions within the European Single Market.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I supported this proposal because the act was accepted in accordance with the position of the Council and the Committee on Legal Affairs. It is important to modernize and repair the existing commissions of the current directive by amending outdated commissions, increasing legal certainty and justifying patent rights in terms of scope and limitations. This will correct some of the ambiguities that now exist and facilitate further interpretation.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The objectives are to modernise and improve the current provisions of Directive 2008/95 by amending outdated provisions to take account of the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, thereby improving legal certainty and clarifying trade mark rights in terms of their scope and limitations.  Better coherence between national trade mark legislation and related procedures should be achieved in order to better align with the EU trade mark system. The Office of the Member States and the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market (OHIM) should facilitate cooperation in order to promote the levelling of practices and the development of common tools by establishing a legal basis for this cooperation. I voted against the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. The aim of this proposal is to make trade mark registration more accessible and effective in the European Union. This must be done by increasing legal certainty, by clarifying provisions and establishing better cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national offices. The clear labelling of products with all the necessary specifications – geographical origin, production methods and traditional characteristics – ensures a higher level of protection of consumer rights.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The main function provided for in the relevant Regulation is essentially the registration and certification of products at national and Community level, so that the producer or seller preserves the name and specific characteristics of his product, from their imitations and illegal sale within Community borders.  As acpel we supported the legislative process as it expands measures to protect domestic products, adding a series of court decisions and reducing the cost of registration. However, we maintain our concerns about issues relating to the full harmonisation of national and Community legislation, particularly when these affect key sectors of the economy such as trade and in particular for smaller states such as Cyprus.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The amendment proposes to reject the Council's position on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks, since: (a) this position does not adequately fill the existing legal gaps, and (b) the attempt at full harmonisation of the laws of the Member States leads in the long term to the flattening of the specificity of each of them and, consequently, to the intended homogenisation.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States' trade mark legislation has already been partially harmonised by Directives 89/104/EEC and 2008/95/EC.  The aim of the current legislation is to modernise the existing provisions by amending outdated legislation. The amendments aim at increasing legal certainty and clarifying the scope and restrictions. 2. Further approach to national regulations 3. Facilitate cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies. This initiative is also part of the Community trade mark package.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European trade mark legislation needs coherent harmonisation throughout the European Union. I appreciate the definition of the European trade mark in this directive. I believe that we need greater protection of intellectual rights throughout the European Union, and I also believe that the Member States must apply expeditiously the principles laid down by the Council and Parliament. At the same time, I am a firm supporter of the simplification of the procedures for granting trademark rights to European citizens. Member States must harmonise their national legislation by the first deadline (2019) in order to finally finally finally complete a single European area for the recognition, protection and administration of trade marks.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported adoption of this report as it foresees the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to bring closer the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks. I believe that increasing transparency and clarity of the procedures is crucial for supporting innovation and the development of European SMEs.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Member States' trade mark legislation has already been partially harmonised by Directives 89/104/EEC and 2008/95/EC.  The aim of the current legislation is to modernise the existing provisions by amending outdated legislation. The amendments aim at increasing legal certainty and clarifying the scope and restrictions. 2. Further approach to national regulations 3. Facilitate cooperation between the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market and national agencies. This initiative is also part of the Community trade mark package.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on member states' trade mark laws, as I believe that coexistence and complementarity between trade mark systems in the European Union and the Member States should be ensured. I strongly support increasing consumer protection and protecting rightholders to sell small consignments online, and the proposed provisions will modernise and improve existing provisions.  In this way, I believe that the legal certainty and clarity of the scope and limitations of the legislation of the trade mark system will be increased and that cooperation and coherence between the offices of the Member States and the European Union in this area should be facilitated. Since I believe that this simplification and harmonisation of laws and practices could greatly contribute to greater competitiveness of European Union companies, I voted to adopt this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I did not support the reports on member states' trade mark legislation (recast), as the most raised issue of goods in transit remains open and inexplicable. This is why the EES political group did not support the proposal.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on the report on the approximation of the laws of the Member States in the field of trade marks. We understand that, as in the case of text A8-0354/2015, the clarification of the system is insufficient as regards the blocking of property. However, we understand that the will of the dossier is positive, as long as it is proceeding towards regulation that simplifies the regulatory multiplicity of trademarks. We hope that, in any event, future reports to approximate the legislation of the Member States in the field of trademarks will have as their starting point the multiplicity of the dispute within all regions.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament’s main targets have been achieved. The trade mark system will be modernised, not revolutionised, as it is already a well-functioning system. The agreement will respect and strengthen the dual system of national and European trade mark protection by building on best practices and respecting the principle of subsidiarity. Parliament achieved lower fees of up to 37%, less bureaucracy, more efficiency and a system that benefits the users of trade marks.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The redesign of the Directive bringing Member States' trademark laws closer together aims to facilitate the uniform registration, administration and protection of trademarks in the EU. The redesign proposal gives a new definition of a trademark by removing the requirement of graphic representation to allow the registration of trademarks of new forms. Also listed, exhaustively, are the grounds for refusal or nullity concerning the mark itself, notably the absence of distinctiveness, or regarding conflicts between the mark and previous rights, and it should be noted that the absolute grounds for refusal to appellations of origin, geographical indications, traditional mentions for wines, guaranteed traditional specialties and plant breeding rights, as well as the extension of grounds for refusal to appellations of origin and geographical indications greater protection for the economic operators concerned.  I therefore voted against the rejection amendment tabled by the EFDD group.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The plenary voted on a Council position at first reading with a view to adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to trade marks (recast). Following the S&D Group's position, I voted against.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on the report on the approximation of the laws of the Member States in the field of trade marks. We understand that, as in the case of text A8-0354/2015, the clarification of the system is insufficient as regards the blocking of property. However, we understand that the will of the dossier is positive, as long as it is proceeding towards regulation that simplifies the regulatory multiplicity of trademarks. We hope that, in any event, future reports to approximate the legislation of the Member States in the field of trademarks will have as their starting point the multiplicity of the dispute within all regions.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The laws of the Member States in the field of trade marks were partially harmonised by Directive 89/104/EEC and Directive No 2008/95/EC. The recasting of this Directive aims to modernise and improve the provisions of the current Directive by creating outdated provisions, increasing legal certainty and clarifying trademark rights in terms of their scope and limitations, as well as achieving greater approximation between national trade mark laws and their procedures and facilitating cooperation between national offices and OHIM. I therefore consider it necessary to vote in your favour.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted against this proposal. After all, the Objectives of the European Parliament, namely more efficiency, less bureaucracy and less costs, have already been achieved.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of these reports is the recast of the Community Trade Mark Regulation and the Directive relating to Member States' trade mark legislation.  The basic objective is to modernise trade mark registration procedures as well as move from a Community approach to the EU approach (in line with the implementation of the Treaty of Lisbon). The goal is not only to modernize the brand system, but also to make it more accessible and efficient in its operation. The defense of industrial brands and companies is important, but it is also very important to be careful about the possibility of abuse of dominant position that these brands provide.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, there is no objection to the report, but the improvements are not clear. Moreover, the necessity of the project is questionable. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Harmonisation of trade mark regulations is, in my opinion, necessary for the effective functioning of pan-European corporations, which are one of the key elements of the European economy. The proposed directive, together with the Community trade mark regulation, contributes to this, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of the report is the recast of the Community Trade Mark Regulation and the Directive relating to Member States' trade mark legislation. The stated objective is "to modernise the procedures for the registration of trade marks, as well as to move from a Community approach to the EU approach (in line with the implementation of the Treaty of Lisbon)". In principle, this reform will facilitate changes to the nomenclature of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market, facilitate procedures and strengthen the fight against contraption and clarify the way trade marks are registered. For example, it will reduce the cost of online registration fees to register brands from €950 to €850 at EU level. In this way, we voted against rejecting the Council's position.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in North-East Atlantic Fishing Grounds, of which the EU is a Contracting Party, aims to ensure the long-term conservation and optimal use of fishery resources in the North-East Atlantic and to bring sustainable, environmental and social benefits. Pursuant to that Convention and the recommendations adopted by the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission ( CPANE), control and enforcement measures may be taken concerning the fishing grounds concerned. The purpose of this proposal is to amend Regulation (EU) 1236/2010 in order to incorporate into EU law the amendments to the Scheme approved in the UNATHING. The main changes introduced by these Recommendations concern the conformity of the Regime with the FAO Agreement on Port State Measures to Prevent, Discourage and Eliminate IEDNR Fishing, as well as the clarification that any vessel participating in a transhipment operation in the regulatory area as a receiving vessel shall communicate the landing port regardless of w;disembarkation at a port located within or outside the Convention area. Taking into account the matter, and that it seeks to change legislation already adopted, we voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is based on the observation that States are increasingly being relied upon to combat illegal fishing because flag states do not effectively control fishing operations. States may take the following measures: obligations to notify prior to entry to the port; restrictions on port entry and fish landings or transfers; restrictions on supplies and services Documentation requirements to be provided Inspections Establishing a blacklist of ships; trade measures and sanctions.  The purpose of this text is to implement recommendations from the Northeast Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAC) to make the fight against illegal fishing more efficient. It therefore insists on the position of the states of the landing port, which is better able to monitor fishing vessels. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote should be taken not as an opposition to action to ensure adequate fish stocks, but as a vote against EU seizure of the sovereignty of Member States over territorial waters.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it is intended to ensure the long-term conservation and optimal use of fisheries resources in the Northeast Atlantic area, so as to bring economic, environmental and social benefits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, the purpose of which is to amend Regulation (EU) No 1236/2010 in order to incorporate into Union law the recommendations of the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAFC). The main amendment to the Regulation concerns the harmonisation of the fao agreement control system on measures relating to port State competences in order to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. The measures introduced by this amendment will ensure the long-term conservation and optimal exploitation of fisheries resources in the North-East Atlantic region, thereby ensuring sustainable results for both the environment and society.  New measures which should have already been included in Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 establishing a Community control system ensuring compliance with the rules of the common fisheries policy are also included.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The recommendations of the Northeast Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAC) are being implemented to improve the fight against illegal fishing. How? Relying primarily on the services of the State of the Landing Port, better able to monitor ships, than those of the flag state. I voted in favour of this common-sense proposal.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The main change in this text, which I have approved, is to align the fisheries control regime with FAO's agreement on port state measures to prevent, thwart and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregued fishing. The measures foreseen by this amendment will ensure better long-term conservation and the optimal use of fisheries resources in the Northeast Atlantic region, generating environmentally and socially sustainable benefits.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted IN FAVOUR because the proposal aims to improve legislation already adopted which seeks to ensure better long-term conservation and optimal use of fishery resources in the North-East Atlantic area, providing social and sustainable benefits for the environment.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report which focuses on the transposition of the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission. The main amendment to the Regulation concerns the conformity of the control regime with the FAO Agreement on Port State Measures to Prevent, Discourage and Eliminate IDNR Fishing.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have chosen to support this text, which aims in particular to combat illegal fishing by controlling measures when landing in a port of a Member State. I am pleased that, through this text, there is growing confidence in the port states to combat illegal fishing, while flag states have little effective control over the operations of fishing vessels flying their flags. Furthermore, Mr Christensen's report gives port states the opportunity to take common-sense measures such as: the requirement for prior notification of port entry or the use of designated ports; restrictions on port entry and fish landings or transfers; restrictions on supplies and services documentation requirements, etc. Common-sense protectionist measures include recommendations from the Northeast Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAC) to improve the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Christensen report is balanced and unseeded. The fight against illegal and unregulated fishing is an important goal both for the protection of our market and for the health of our citizens. For these reasons, I supported this text, which implements new measures to combat these phenomena through a system of control of competences under the port state.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report updates the rules of EU Regulation 1236/2010 on multilateral cooperation in North-East Atlantic fishing grounds to incorporate into EU law amendments to the control and enforcement regime adopted by the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NSCL). This committee adopted throughout 2012 and 2013 a number of amendments, including those aimed at preventing, discouraging and eliminating illegal, unregulated and undeclared fishing; hence the need to amend the above-mentioned Regulation. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports parliament's amendment to the regulation establishing a system of control and enforcement applicable to the Convention on Multilateral Cooperation in the North-East Atlantic Fisheries. For example, one of the amendments concerns the imposition of port State measures to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. The amendments also clarify that transhipment vessels participating in a transhipment operation in the Regulatory Area must notify the port of landing, regardless of whether the landings are in a port within or outside the Convention Area.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also support the proposed recommendation concerning changes to the control system for fishing in the North East Atlantic. The amendments are the result of the recommendations adopted by the North-Atlantic Fisheries Commission, which have become binding on the Contracting Parties to that Commission, including the EU.  The amendments relate, to the greatest extent, to measures to tackle illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, which entered into force on 1.7.2015 and to measures relating to vessels involved in transhipment activities. The latter will already be obliged to report on the port of landing when loading the cargo, whether or not it is carried out in a port within or outside the Convention Area.  The adaptation of the relevant EU legislation is necessary, as the date of 1 May 2015 is already missed, and I agree with the rapporteur that delaying the procedure by table of amendments would be pointless.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on the control and enforcement system applicable in Northeast Atlantic fisheries. This proposal aims to complement the Northeast Atlantic Fisheries Regulation with a view to modernising and progressing and speeding up the overall process.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Given that it is a matter of acting more effectively against illegal fishing, which endangers the level of fish stocks in the North-East Atlantic area, and that the proposed provision to carry out controls at landing ports rather than relying on the vigilance of flag states is better able to effectively combat this illegal fishing, I voted for it.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal is aimed at amending Regulation (EU) No 1236/2010 in order to implement the NEAFC (North-East Fisheries Commission)15/2013 and 9/2015 recommendations, which have been adopted with the full support of the EU. The main change is the alignment of the scheme with the FAO agreement on port state measures to prevent, deter and eliminate INTA fishing. The other change clarifies that vessels involved in a transhipment operation in the regulatory area communicate the port of landing, regardless of whether it is a port inside or outside the convention area. In addition, the notification procedures for port state control of foreign fishing vessels are modified in order to adapt them to a modern web-based ICT application, managed by the NEAFC Secretariat.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to transpose the recommendations of the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAC) into European law in order to effectively combat illegal fishing and preserve fisheries resources in this area. To achieve these objectives, it is planned to rely on the states of the landing port whose authorities are better able to monitor the operations of the ships. This measure is intended to fill the gaps in flag states that, by definition, cannot effectively control the activities of the vessels in question.  This report clearly responds to the shortcomings that existed in the current legislation. Documentation requirements, inspections and the establishment of a blacklist of vessels will give authorities the tools to effectively combat illegal fishing. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a system of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation for Fisheries in the North-East Atlantic brings new measures to monitor and monitor compliance in relation to fishing activities in the North-East Atlantic. The main amendments introduced by this proposal concern new measures to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing falling within the competence of the port State, as well as to integrate port State control notification procedures on foreign fishing vessels into a technological application, to the detriment of the traditional paper system. The European Union is a Contracting Party to the Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation for Fisheries in the North-East Atlantic, and is therefore a concern for the Union's structures to ensure the long-term conservation and rational use of fish resources in the North-East Atlantic area. I believe that a sustainable approach to these types of resources and the generation of social benefits is needed, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The main amendment to Regulation (EU) No 1236/2010 concerns the alignment of the FAO agreement on measures concerning the port state's competence control system in order to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing. I am voting in favour.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in North-East Atlantic Fisheries (CPANE), of which the European Union is a contracting party, aims to ensure the long-term conservation and optimal use of fisheries resources in the North-East Atlantic area, in order to bring economic, environmental and social benefits. The CPANE's recommendations are binding and must be transposed into EU law. This report incorporates into EU law the changes to the control regime adopted by the CPANE in its recommendation 15/2013 and its recommendation 9/2014 as amended by Recommendation 12/2015, which have become binding on the contracting parties of the CPANE and therefore on the European Union. Since the amended version of the recommendation should have come into force on 1 July 2015, I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal without amendments in order to speed up the adoption process.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1236/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a control and coercion regime applicable in the area of the Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in the North-East Atlantic Fisheries. Illegal, undeclared and unregulated (IUU) fishing creates distortions of competition, as well as lead to a depletion of fish stocks. It is therefore our responsibility to eliminate any form of loophole that allows illegal operators to take advantage of their activities. The Union must take action to preserve fish stocks as best it can. With the adoption of this report, Parliament has indicated the way forward.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report which contained a number of important provisions. Specifically, there were progressive provisions in the context of countering IUU fishing and better scrutiny of super trawlers, also known as freezer factory vessels. Moreover, there were important provisions which acknowledged both the environmental and economic-social aspects of fisheries and for these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Whilst UKIP are in favour of building fish stocks, we oppose the EU signing international agreements like a sovereign nation.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal is aimed at amending Regulation (EU) No 1236/2010 in order to transpose into Union law the changes to the regime adopted in the recommendations of the Neafc (North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAFC)). The main amendment to the regulation concerns the alignment of the FAO agreement on measures concerning the port state's competence control system in order to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing. I voted in favour because the measures will ensure better long-term conservation and optimum use of fishery resources in the North-East Atlantic area, producing lasting environmental and social results.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of this report. The main amendment to Regulation 1236/2010 concerns the alignment of the regime control system in the FAO Agreement on measures falling within the competence of the port State to prevent, deter and eliminate IUU fishing. The measures envisaged by this amendment will ensure better long-term conservation and optimal use of fisheries resources in the North-East Atlantic area, providing sustainable benefits, both from an environmental and social point of view. Bearing in mind that the entry into force of the amended form of the Recommendation should have taken place by 1 July 2015, the rapporteur decided not to propose amendments in order to speed up, as far as possible, the approval process.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 1236/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a control and enforcement system applicable in the Convention area for future multilateral cooperation in the fisheries sector in the North-East Atlantic. This report concerns the improvement of existing rules with a view to the optimal exploitation of fishery products in the North-East Atlantic region. Indeed, as there has already been a corresponding vote which has been positively accepted and as there are no serious concerns about its results, I believe that it does achieve its objective and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. The Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in the North-East Atlantic Fisheries, to which the Union is a contracting party, is intended to ensure the long-term conservation and optimum use of fishery resources in the North-East Atlantic area, with lasting environmental and social benefits. Control and coercion measures may be taken in relation to the fishing activities concerned in order to ensure the application of the Convention and the recommendations adopted by the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAFC). Parliament therefore welcomes the transposition into EU law of the recommendations adopted under the NEAFC. Considering that entry into force should have taken place by 1 July 2015, the EP decided not to table amendments, in order to speed up the adoption process as much as possible.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I share the objective of ensuring the long-term conservation and optimal use of the fishery resources of the area in question. Among others, the main change made by the recommendation is the alignment of the scheme with the FAO agreement on port state measures to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing. I am in favour of this proposal because I believe it is fundamental and very important to go against any kind of unfair practice within our Union and, in addition, the changes will ensure better long-term conservation and the optimum use of fishery resources in the North-East Atlantic. By voting in favour, I also want to help ensure lasting environmental and social results.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in North East Atlantic Fisheries to which the European Union is a Contracting Party aims to ensure the long term conservation and optimum utilisation of the fishery resources of the North East Atlantic area, providing sustainable, environmental and social benefits.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The amendment to Regulation (EU) No 1236/2010 concerns the alignment of the FAO agreement on measures concerning the port state's competence control system in order to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, undeclared and unregulated fishing. In addition, with the change, new electronic control systems will be introduced which will make these procedures more effective, safer and able to have precise information in real time. I have decided to support this proposal because the measures that will be taken will ensure better long-term conservation and the optimum use of maritime resources in the North-East Atlantic area, producing lasting results also from the environmental and social aspects.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The EU is a Contracting Party of the Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in North East Atlantic Fisheries. This scheme proposes a better long-term conservation and optimum utilisation of fishery resources in the area of the Northeast Atlantic, bringing lasting results under environmental and social aspects, thus I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal is aimed at amending Regulation (EU) No 1236/2010 on the alignment of the FAO agreement on measures concerning the port state competence control system. The main objectives of this proposal are to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal fishing, to ensure better long-term conservation and to optimise fishing resources in the North-East Atlantic area. I am voting in favour, hoping for lasting environmental and social results.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in North-East Atlantic Fishing Grounds, of which the EU is a Contracting Party, aims to ensure the long-term conservation and optimal use of fishery resources in the North-East Atlantic and to bring sustainable, environmental and social benefits. Pursuant to that Convention and the recommendations adopted by the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission ( CPANE), control and enforcement measures may be taken concerning the fishing grounds concerned. The purpose of this proposal is to amend Regulation (EU) 1236/2010 in order to incorporate into EU law the amendments to the Scheme approved in the UNATHING. The main changes introduced by these Recommendations concern the conformity of the Regime with the FAO Agreement on Port State Measures to Prevent, Discourage and Eliminate IEDNR Fishing, as well as the clarification that any vessel participating in a transhipment operation in the regulatory area as a receiving vessel shall communicate the landing port regardless of w;disembarkation at a port located within or outside the Convention area. Taking into account the matter, and that it seeks to change legislation already adopted, we voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report in question gives Parliament’s recommendations on the Commission’s proposal on the Convention on future cooperation in North-East Atlantic fisheries. During its annual meeting in March, the North East Atlantic Fisheries Commission adopted a number of recommendations. These included amendments on communication of transhipments and of port of landing, on the infringement procedures and on port state control of foreign fishing vessels. Through this report such recommendations will become EU law. I believe that such changes will make for a better system and hence I have voted in favour of it.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this legislative report is to incorporate the recommendations of the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAC) into EU law law. As part of the Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in the Northeast Atlantic Fisheries, to which the European Union is a contracting party, the CPANE makes recommendations to ensure the long-term conservation and optimal use of fisheries resources in the North-East Atlantic area. At its annual meetings in 2012, 2013 and 2014, the CPANE adopted a series of recommendations to implement a port-level control and enforcement regime for transshipment and landing activities, control of foreign fishing vessels and infringement procedures. Having become binding on the members of the CPANE, the Union must incorporate these measures into its law. Sharing the recommendations, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst we are in favour of building fish stocks, we oppose the EU signing international agreements like a sovereign nation.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to transpose into EU law the control and coercion regime adopted by the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAC), of which the Union is a contracting party. These measures are effectively intended to ensure the optimal use of fisheries resources and their long-term conservation within the Northeast Atlantic region.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the conservation and optimal use of fisheries resources in the North-East Atlantic focuses in particular on aligning the current regime with FAO's agreement on illegal fishing. In particular, by transferring control of the state's fishing activities to the port state where it is based, this report calls for more precise control.  Indeed, many fishing vessels fly the flag of a country that only remotely controls the activities of a boat established far from it. By allowing ports, which can effectively control ships, this report encourages more pragmatism. Attached to a reasoned exploitation of fisheries resources, and therefore to a genuine effective control of fishing activities, I voted for this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report as it concerns the proposal to transpose various measures already available in EU legislation. It is important that fisheries ensure sustainable economic, environmental and social benefits. As these measures are already directly applicable to The Member States, the Regulation rightly provides more legal certainty as regards commercial fish activities in the North-East Atlantic.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. We are voting in favour of this report because it is moving in the right direction and resolving issues that actually arise in these fishing areas.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission proposes to incorporate the recommendations of the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAFC) into EU fisheries legislation as to the rules for Atlantic fishing activities. In accordance with epp guidelines, I voted in favour of approving the text of the political agreement. It is clear that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. Justified steps to maintain them will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it strengthens the fight against illegal fishing.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to amend eu rules transpose the control and enforcement measures adopted by the North-East Atlantic Fisheries Commission (NEAFC). The Convention for Multilateral Fisheries Cooperation in the North-East Atlantic to which the EU is a Contracting Party aims to ensure long-term conservation and optimal use of fisheries resources in the North-East Atlantic area. To ensure the implementation of this Convention and the recommendations adopted by NEAFC, control and enforcement measures may be adopted. In 2010, the EU transposed into its law the control and coertion regime adopted by NEAFC. In 2012 and 2013, NEAFC adopted recommendations amending the control and enforcement regime to align it with the FAO Agreement on Port State Measures to prevent, prevent and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing. The measures envisaged by this amendment aim to "ensure better long-term conservation and optimal use of fisheries resources in the North-East Atlantic area, with lasting results expected from an environmental and social point of view. Given the issue at hand and bearing in mind that we are dealing with a proposal to amend legislation already adopted, which improves it, we voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
