text: in writing. – The EU Treaty provides that the Union's action on the international stage must be guided by the principles which have inspired its own creation, development and enlargement, and which it seeks to advance in the wider world, including democracy, the rule of law, the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity. The EU must respect and promote those principles in its external action as well, including its common commercial policy. Suspending exceptional trade measures can ensure that swift action can be taken in the event of serious and systemic violations of the fundamental principles of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. The EU needs to remain committed to supporting Bosnia and Herzegovina's European prospects and looks to the political leadership of the country to pursue reforms aimed at promoting functional institutions as well as ensuring equal rights for all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are in a stalemate. Three rounds of negotiations between the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina were not enough to reach an agreement: contrary to the EU method, Bosnia and Herzegovina believes that it cannot increase preferences for the amount of traditional trade and argues that it could only do so in the face of further concessions from the EU. The stalemate that has thus been created and which is damaging the EU's commercial interests has prompted the Commission to demand that the extension of the autonomous trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina should not be automatic, but subject to this country's acceptance of the method used by the EU for the adaptation of the Interim Agreement. Once Bosnia and Herzegovina and the European Union have agreed, signed and provisionally implemented an agreement on the adjustment of trade concessions, preferences for Bosnia and Herzegovina will be re-established. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Previously, Bosnia signed an Association and Stabilisation Agreement with the EU that excluded fifteen agricultural products as sensitive products for Bosnia and Herzegovina. If Bosnia now accepts the trade review proposed by this Resolution, these fifteen sensitive agricultural products will be liberalized. Therefore, aware of the importance of limiting trade interference by the EU in third countries, especially those in situations of particular instability or immersed in political, social or economic processes of radical significance to its people, such as Bosnia and Herzegovina, I voted against this Resolution in order to continue to maintain the protection of these agricultural products.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade liberalisation between the EU and the Western Balkan countries in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina will be achieved through several stabilisation and association agreements and an interim agreement. Following Croatia's accession to the EU in 2013, Bosnia and Herzegovina has so far not agreed to adapt the Interim Agreement in the light of the traditional preferential trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina under the Central European Free Trade Agreement linking the two countries before 1 July 2013. All CEFTA Member States in the Western Balkans, with the exception of Bosnia and Herzegovina, have approved the methodology for amending EU trade agreements following EU enlargement and have concluded negotiations to amend their agreements with the EU.  After three rounds of negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, no agreement was reached. Contrary to the EU methodology, Bosnia and Herzegovina considers that it would not be able to increase its benefit for the volume of traditional trade. According to Bosnia and Herzegovina, this could only happen if the EU provided further concessions.  In the light of the stalemate and the damage to the Union's commercial interest, the Commission proposes not to automatically extend the autonomous trade measures granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina, but to make the extension dependent on bosnia and herzegovina adopting a methodology for adjusting the Interim Agreement. In the European Parliament, this proposal has been approved, together with a few amendments.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP notes that the EU has a track record of economic bullying against countries that refuse to politically obey it. Bosnia is no exception and we feel that the EU should not be using trade as a political weapon.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text, which proposes several changes to the initial regulation of autonomous trade measures (AMMs) between the Union and Bosnia and Herzegovina. This text will thus benefit both parties because it proposes to extend the system of preferences granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina until 2020 while introducing a clause to safeguard human rights.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The liberalisation of trade between the EU and the countries of the Western Balkans is ensured through a series of stabilisation and association agreements, as well as an interim agreement in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Commission's proposal suggests making three main changes to Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009: the extension of the current preferences until the end of 2020, the introduction of the so-called 'human rights clause' in the ATM Regulation and the possible suspension of autonomous trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important for Bosnia and Herzegovina to adapt the interim agreement to preferential trade with Croatia following croatia's accession to the European Union. In this respect, I believe it is important for the parties involved to take account of each other's interests in order to reach an agreement acceptable to both EU Member States and CEFTA signatory countries.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Relations between the European Union and Bosnia and Herzegovina are governed by an interim trade agreement pending the entry into force of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement currently being ratified. As such, Bosnia enjoys trade preferences in addition to "autonomous trade measures", trade concessions unilaterally granted by the EU, allowing almost all exports to enter the UNION without tariffs or quota restrictions.  Following Croatia's accession to the European Union in 2013, Bosnia was required to adapt its international agreements. However, Sarajevo has still not made this adjustment and therefore does not fulfil its obligations to the Union.  That is why the European Union has chosen to suspend its trade preferences. These will be restored when discussions between the EU and Bosnia result in an agreement taking into account Croatia's accession to the Union.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report wanted to extend exceptional trade measures for countries being integrated into the European Union. It was Bosnia that was concerned. By thus perpetuating the aid granted to the Balkans and especially Bosnia, the European Union wishes to keep alive its idea of one day ensuring that Bosnia joins the Union. Firmly opposed to an enlargement of the Union and its traffic space, I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report ending the application of exceptional trade measures to Bosnia and Herzegovina.  All other Balkan countries have already adapted the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Croatia's accession to the EU. Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet done so, so before the end of the year its privileges in this respect must be withdrawn.  The future European integration of the countries in the area is necessary and can only lead to the much-desired stability of the Balkans, but in this case Bosnia and Herzegovina is called upon to adapt the interim agreement to preferential trade with Croatia after the latter's accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013. and cefta members.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against because the granting of privileges to countries that in practice have nothing to do with European values finds us vertically opposed.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it is in line with the planned accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is an element of pressure and interference on Bosnia and Herzegovina. In line with what has been the process of enlargement of the EU to the east, and in particular in the Balkan region, the EU seeks to impose on these countries neoliberal policies and guidelines, in this case free trade. The threat of suspension of unilateral trade preferences opens another chapter in the process of eu interference and destabilisation in the region, wanting to impose on Bosnia and Herzegovina the acceptance of the Interim Preferential Trade Agreement, as had already been agreed with Croatia following croatia's accession to the EU on 1 July 2013, framed in the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA). The document is quite enlightening when it states that these conditions "should be accepted as a boost to accelerate the transition from the political and socio-economic reforms highlighted in the 'pact for growth'" with a view to "compliance by the western Balkan countries, the Copenhagen criteria and the acquis communautaire". From the foregoing, we voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because I believe it is necessary to introduce clauses that suspend the application of exceptional trade measures in the event of serious violations of the fundamental principles of human rights. I hope that the authorities in Bosnia-Herzegovina will implement reforms aimed at promoting efficient institutions and ensuring equal rights for the three peoples living on their territory.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 We have liberalised trade between the European Union and the Western Balkan countries through a number of Stabilisation and Association Agreements. In the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina, through the Interim Agreement and Kosovo, as well as the whole region, the agreements are based on autonomous measures. By assessing the proposal, the European Commission has made three major changes to the basic Regulation (EC 1215/2009). In particular, it extends the current preferences until the end of 2020 by introducing a human rights clause into the Autonomous Trade Measures Regulation and the possible suspension of autonomous trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016. The last point relates in particular to the fact that no agreement could still be reached with Bosnia and Herzegovina on an interim agreement taking into account preferential traditional trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. 12012 I am abstaining from suspending trade preferences in Bosnia because, as you know, Bosnia is not a problem for our production system, but it is quite clear that the text contains many considerations that we cannot agree with, such as the principles and rules laid down for future trade relations.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because the granting of privileges to countries that in practice have nothing to do with European values finds me strongly opposed.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has granted Autonomous Trade Measures (ATM) since 2000 to the Western Balkan countries. These are unilateral preferences which allow unlimited duty-free access to the EU. The ATMs will expire after December 2015. The Commission proposes to extend them until the end of 2020 for Serbia, Kosovo, Albania, FYROM, Montenegro, and Bosnia and Herzegovina. The proposal includes a human rights clause, which is important for us. Previously, it was not possible to suspend trade preferences in the event of systemic breaches of human rights and the rule of law.  Because of Croatia's accession to the EU it is necessary to adapt the trade part of the Stabilisation and Association Agreements in force. These negotiations have been concluded with all Western Balkan countries, except Bosnia and Herzegovina, where they remain blocked. To increase leverage the Commission proposal includes a provision to suspend the ATMs for Bosnia as of 1 January 2016 if by then no solution has been found. The annual loss for Bosnia and Herzegovina is estimated not to be economically critical but it is a politically symbolic point. I supported this approach in order to get Bosnia to engage in the negotiations while stressing the need for a mutually acceptable solution.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal to extend autonomous trade measures for the western Balkan countries and territories participating in the stabilisation and association process for a further five years, i.e. until 31 December 2020, is to be welcomed. This preferential trading system has contributed to an increase in EU imports of Western Balkan products. In 2013, the EU was the region's largest trading partner, with both imports (72.7%) and exports (81.8%) Area. These trade preferences, together with existing bilateral agreements, support economic integration with the Union and thus contribute to the political stability and economic development of the region. These measures should be understood in the broader context of EU policy for the Western Balkan countries, the ultimate aim of which is to bring these countries closer to the Union. The suspension of Bosnia and Herzegovina's trade preferences should be seen as an incentive to resolve the current differences with the Union in relation to the adjustment of the interim EU Agreement. It is hoped that the new authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina will be able to resolve this unfinished issue, taking advantage of the positive momentum of the new EU approach adopted by the Foreign Affairs Council on 15 December 2014 for the country.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Croatia's accession to the EU on 1 July 2013, Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet agreed to adapt the interim agreement to take account of its traditional preferential trade with Croatia under the Central European Free Trade Agreement, which linked the two countries since before 1 July 2013. After three rounds of negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, it has not been possible to reach an agreement. Against the EU methodology, Bosnia and Herzegovina believes that it could not increase its preferences for all traditional trade. According to Bosnia and Herzegovina, it could only do so if the EU offered it new concessions.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 on exceptional trade measures applicable to countries and territories participating in or linked to the Stabilisation and Association Process of the European Union and suspending its application with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina. Bearing in mind that while there is a unilateral preferential regime in favour of the Western Balkans with autonomous trade measures provided for in the free trade agreements, three rounds of negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina have not been sufficient to reach an agreement, given that the country considers increasing preferences for the amount of traditional trade only with further concessions from the EU. I believe that the objective of the proposed amendments, namely the introduction of the use of delegated acts for decisions on the suspension of preferences in the event of non-compliance with the conditions, is necessary for the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina to agree on the adaptation of the Interim Agreement following Croatia's accession. Despite the EU's real commitment, the countries involved have faced a number of challenges that I share as they are the most effective instrument for ensuring stability in the region and ensuring the social integration that is crucial in the Union.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the suspension of special trade measures relating to Bosnia and Herzegovina, as it maintains the long-term accession scenario as proposed by Parliament – but at the same time recalls the immovable rules and conditions that must be adhered to in the long term.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. An extension of the Autonomous Trade Agreement is only possible if Bosnia and Herzegovina recognises the terms of an interim agreement. Only after a trade adjustment can existing trade concessions from the EU be reintroduced.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, because of Croatia's accession to the EU it is necessary to adapt the trade part of the Stabilisation and Association Agreements in force. These negotiations have been concluded with all Western Balkan countries, except Bosnia and Herzegovina, where they remain blocked. The trade preferences run out at the end of the year for all Western Balkan countries if this report on their extension does not pass. I supported the suspension of exceptional trade measures with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina in order to encourage it to sign up to conclude negotiations on the Stabilisation and Association Agreement.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted AGAINST this report because Bosnia and Hezergovina are being required to put in place measures to adapt to European standards as was done with Bulgaria or Romania but, unlike these, the prospect of EU membership is not immediate – not even credible. The clause that makes the preferential trade agreement subject to human rights is welcome, but insufficient to support the text.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since 2000 the EU has granted the countries of the Western Balkans autonomous trade measures, and that includes Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Commission has proposed to extend the autonomous trade measures until the end of 2020, otherwise they will expire at the end of this month. After long negotiations with the Council and Commission, regarding which I should thank the rapporteur, Maria Bettini Goffredo, for committing so much of her time, we now have reached an agreement. I voted in favour of this codecision procedure, firstly because I believe that there should be a stable majority in support of the outcome of the interinstitutional negotiations. Furthermore, the inclusion of a human rights clause in this proposal is a massively important part of the text.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP notes that the EU has a track record of economic bullying against countries that refuse to politically obey it. Bosnia is no exception and we feel that the EU should not be using trade as a political weapon.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 introducing exceptional trade measures for countries and territories participating in or linked to the European Union’s Stabilisation and Association process and suspending its application with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina. I agree on the suspension of exceptional trade measures with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina because it would be preferable for this agreement to be adopted after the new Europol Regulation has entered into force, following the new enhanced procedure and abiding by the rigorous new provisions and safeguards.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒  I supported this report as the proposal to extend the autonomous trade measures for Western Balkan countries and territories participating in the Stabilisation and Association Process (SAP) for another five years should be welcomed. This preferential trade regime has contributed to an increase in Western Balkan exports to the EU. The EU was, in 2013, the region’s largest trading partner both in terms of imports (72.7%) and exports (81.8%). Together with the bilateral agreements in place, these trade preferences support economic integration with the EU and hence foster political stability and economic progress in the entire region. These measures should also be seen in the wider context of our policies regarding the Western Balkan countries, our ultimate goal being to bring them closer to the EU. The suspension of the trade preferences for Bosnia and Herzegovina should be seen as an incentive to resolve the current disagreement with the EU over the adaptation of the Interim Agreement.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the accession of Croatia to the EU on 1 July 2013, Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet agreed to adapt the Interim Agreement in order to take into account the preferential traditional trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina under the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA) which linked the two countries before 1 July 2013. I voted in favour of this report on the suspension of special commercial measures concerning Bosnia and Herzegovina until its acceptance of the Interim Agreement.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 1215/2009 on the imposition of extraordinary trade measures for countries and territories participating in or related to the Stabilisation and Association Process of the European Union and the suspension of its application with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina, as BiH has not yet accepted the adjustment of trade preferences granted under the Interim Agreement in order to take into account traditional preferential trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina under the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA).  As a result, the Croatian economy, in the changed circumstances resulting from its accession to the EU, has millions in losses. If the EU and BiH do not sign and start provisionally applying the agreement on the adjustment of trade preferences under the Stabilisation and Association Agreement and the Interim Agreement, the privileges granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina should be suspended from 1 January 2016, unfortunately having negative economic consequences. Once BiH and the EU sign and begin provisionally applying the agreement on the adjustment of trade preferences under the Interim Agreement, these privileges should be reintroduced.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Report on the proposed regulation amending regulation (EC) 1215/2009 introducing preferential trade measures for participating countries and territories linked to the EU's stabilization and association process and suspending its application with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina. Brussels wants to give Bosnia the means to comply with the requirements for EU membership. However, Bosnia has always been disrupted by infighting, and moreover is grimly known for having a mafia well established on its soil. We are therefore totally opposed to its accession. So I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP notes that the EU has a track record of economic bullying against countries that refuse to politically obey it. Bosnia is no exception and we feel that the EU should not be using trade as a political weapon.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 With my vote, I supported the lifting of the visa requirement for short stays of citizens of selected ACP Group partner countries and the United Arab Emirates in the European Union. This measure concerning exclusively safe countries with an excellent level of cooperation with European countries will increase the interest of non-European tourists in visiting EU countries. At the same time, reciprocal visa waiver for short stays will greatly facilitate travel by Union citizens to the countries concerned.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Parliament's proposal goes beyond the Commission's demands and provides for very far-reaching concessions to Bosnia and Herzegovina. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. The outcome of the negotiations is a success for Parliament, as it managed to secure the procedure with delegated acts for suspension of trade preferences upon activation of the human rights clause.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the launch of the Stabilisation and Association Process with the Western Balkans in 1999, there was not any agreement regarding the EU and Bosnia, Herzegovina. This is the first agreement regarding trade with those countries. I voted against this report, since it does not find both parties satisfied with the conclusion of the negotiation rounds. However, one positive thing in the report is that for once, delegated acts concern human rights violations, as well as providing to suspend trade if there is any human rights violation.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Despite Croatia's accession to the European Union, Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet agreed to adapt the Interim Agreement to take account of traditional trade. The European Union has tried to promote a new agreement on several occasions, but unfortunately the desired result has not been achieved. In view of this, I have chosen to vote in favour of suspending exceptional trade measures with regard to Bosnia-Herzegovina.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the suspension of exceptional trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina. Regulation 1215 adopted in 2009 gave exceptional trade benefits until 31 December 2015 to the Balkans in general and Bosnia in particular, particularly pending the signing of a contract for Bosnia's accession to the European Union. The Union wishes, through this vote, to help Bosnia and, above all, to keep alive the possibility of Bosnia's accession. Bosnia is a state in almost permanent political crisis where a major mafia is established. I am therefore totally opposed to its accession.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MEPs voted against the text as it extends the exceptional asymmetrical liberalisation of trade between the EU and Bosnia until the end of 2020, while at the end of 2020, while at the end of the country's internal affairs.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The exchange of goods between the EU and the Western Balkan countries was agreed through Stabilisation and Association Agreements. The European Commission's proposal concerns the extension of the preferential trade regime until the end of 2020 with a purpose of continuing to support BiH's EU integration and thus ensuring its political and economic stability. I supported Representative Bettini's report and the amendments attached. Croatia strongly advocates the European path of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but BiH must respect the International Agreements and Notices of the Commission and take into account Croatia's membership in the EU as soon as possible and enable a duty-free regime with the Republic of Croatia.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 For more than two decades, the European Union has been implementing efforts focused on the gradual integration of the Western Balkan countries with our community. Trade is undeniably one of the primary areas where such processes usually take place, so there has been an interim agreement between the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina for a long time, thanks to which both parties have the possibility to export their extensive list of goods in both directions without any tariffs or other restrictions. In this case, the case is that, almost two and a half years ago, Croatia joined the European Union. Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as other central European countries are parties to the Central European Free Trade Agreement. The other members have agreed to a system developed by the EU, within which any free trade agreements with third countries have to be synchronised with this fact, following a further enlargement of the Union. The EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina have long been unable to reach a consensus on this adaptation due to bosnia and herzegovina's objections.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU liberalises trade with the Western Balkan countries through the Stabilisation and Association Agreements and, in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina, through the Interim Agreement. At the same time, since 2000, the EU has granted these countries unilateral preferences that allow unlimited duty-free free access for most products to the EU.  The Commission proposal on the table modifies three amendments to the basic Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009: – extending the current preferences until the end of 2020. democracy and the rule of law by a beneficiary country, – possible suspension of autonomous trade arrangements for Bosnia and Herzegovina as of 1 January 2016 in relation to the country's opposition to the modification of the Interim Agreement to take account of preferential traditional trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina on the basis of the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA), which brought the two countries together until 1 July 2013.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the adoption of this Report I urge Bosnia and Herzegovina to adapt trade concessions granted under the Interim Agreement on trade and trade-related matters with the EU to take into account the accession of Croatia.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. This report suggests maintaining the exceptional trade measures currently in place between the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina. The extension of these measures is primarily aimed at keeping alive the idea of Bosnia and Herzegovina joining the European Union. We strongly oppose this enlargement to the east of the European Union and the accession of that country.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 on trade measures applicable to the countries and territories participating in the Stabilisation and Association Process of the European Union and suspending its application in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Commission's proposal proposes to make three essential changes to this regulation: extension of the current preferences until the end of 2020, introduction of the so-called human rights clause, possible suspension of autonomous trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016. The overall objective of these proposed changes is to strengthen the EU's effective and concrete commitment to the European integration of the countries and territories covered by the Regulation by granting unilateral trade preferences.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission extended the benefits of Regulation 1215 of 2009 for countries in the Western Balkan region until the year 2020. These are tariff preferences in particular. The EU countries therefore had to agree on the regulation of their tariff preferences, with the exception of Bosnia and Herzegovina, where the Commission rightly proposed suspending these benefits from January 2016, until an agreement has been reached. I am therefore voting in favour of my colleague's report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal goes beyond the Commission's demands and makes far too much concessions to Bosnia and Herzegovina. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Trade between the EU and the countries of the Western Balkans is liberalised by a number of Stabilization and Association Agreements (ASA) and an Interim Agreement (AI) in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In addition, Kosovo (which is not yet the subject of an ASA) and the entire region benefit from autonomous trade measures (MCA), granted by the EU since 2000. MCAs are a unilateral preferential regime in favour of the Western Balkans. The report proposes to extend current preferences until the end of 2020 with the exception of Bosnia-Herzegovine, for which the Commission proposes that the MCAs should not be automatically extended but be subject to Bosnia and Herzegovina's agreement on the EU's methodology for adapting the interim agreement. The agreement provides for the liberalisation of 15 products considered sensitive to their economies by Bosnia. I vote against this text which purports to impose liberalism by force and blackmail on third countries.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Report on proposed regulation amending Regulation (EC) 1215/2009 introducing preferential trade measures for participating countries and territories linked to the Eu-stabilisation and association process and suspending its application with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina. Brussels wants to give Bosnia the means to comply with the requirements for membership. However, Bosnia has always been disrupted by infighting, and moreover, grimly known for having a mafia well established on its soil. We are therefore totally opposed to its accession. So I voted no.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal to extend autonomous trade measures in favour of the western Balkan countries and territories participating in the stabilisation and association process (ASE) for a further five-year period until 31 December 2020 was welcomed. It should also be noted that Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 does not provide for any possibility of temporarily suspending the granting of exceptional commercial measures in the event of serious and systematic violations of the fundamental principles of human rights, democracy and the rule of law by its beneficiaries, and it is therefore appropriate to introduce this possibility. I presented my concordant vote.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as the preferential trade regime currently in place between the European Union and the Western Balkans has resulted in an increase in exports from the Western Balkans to the EU. A further five-year extension of the Autonomous Trade Measures confirms the EU’s commitment to the future European integration of the Western Balkans. It is crucial that we view the suspension of this agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina as an incentive to resolve the ongoing disagreement with the EU.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has agreed to suspend the application of exceptional trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina. Indeed, since Croatia's accession, Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet adapted its trade concessions with the new accession country. The European Union therefore wishes to temporarily suspend the preferences granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina. Although it is a privileged partner of the European Union in a significant number of sectors, it is imperative that Bosnia and Herzegovina respect Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to grant autonomous trade measures (ATMs) for the Western Balkan Countries. They are unilateral preferences which allow for unlimited duty-free access to the EU. These ATMs will expire after December 2015. The Commission proposes to extend the ATMs to the end 2020 for Serbia, Kosovo, Albania, FYROM, Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament has approved today the outcome of the interinstitutional negotiations on the amendment of the Regulation concerning the Autonomous Trade Measures for the Western Balkans. I welcome in particular the introduction of the possibility to temporarily suspend preferential trade measures in case of systematic violations of human rights. To this purpose the use of delegated acts is foreseen which guarantees the full involvement of the European Parliament in the process.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has submitted a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council suspending the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 as regards Bosnia and Herzegovina.  Trade between the EU and the Western Balkan countries will be liberalised in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina through several stabilisation and association agreements and an interim agreement. Following Croatia's accession to the EU on 13 July 2013, Bosnia and Herzegovina has so far not agreed to adapt the Interim Agreement to take account of the traditional preferential trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina under the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA) linking the two countries before 1 July 2013. As a result, the preferential quotas set out in the Interim Agreement in 2008 for 27 EU Member States are now used by 28 Member States. After three rounds of negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, no agreement was reached. The Commission therefore proposes not to automatically extend the autonomous trade measures granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina. As soon as Bosnia and Herzegovina and the EU agree, sign and provisionally apply the Agreement on the adjustment of trade preferences, the benefits granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina will be re-applied. In its report, the Committee on International Trade recommends that Parliament adopt the Commission's proposal with amendments. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on Future Multilateral Cooperation in Fisheries of the North-East Atlantic aims to ensure the long-term conservation and optimal use of fisheries resources in the Northeast Atlantic area. I consider it important to transpose into EU law the recommendations adopted within neafc, in particular the alignment of the scheme with the FAO agreement on port state measures to prevent, prevent and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing (IUU fishing).  I believe that these measures will allow long-term conservation and optimal use of fisheries resources in the Northeast Atlantic area, providing lasting environmental and social advantages. I endorse the rapporteur's position on short adoption deadlines which hinder the legislative work of Parliament and the Council and undermine the legislative quality.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council aims to amend Regulation (EC) 1215/2009 which granted exceptional commercial benefits until 31 December 2015 to the Balkans in general and Bosnia in particular, particularly pending the signing of a Contract for Bosnia's accession to the EU. The EU is now considering, through this vote, helping Bosnia and, above all, maintaining Bosnia's possibility of EU membership. Being opposed to the accession of this country in a permanent state of political crisis and where endemic corruption reigns, I decided to vote against this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution calling for the suspension of the exceptional trade measures granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina. Recognised as a potential candidate for EU membership in 2003, Bosnia and Herzegovina signed a stabilisation and association agreement on 16 June 2008 under which it accepted the terms of EU membership.  This agreement has been in effect since June 1, 2015. Since Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet agreed to adapt the trade concessions granted to it under this agreement, the preferences granted to that country should be suspended from 1 January 2016.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We strongly vote for this measure suspending ATM measures against Bosnia and Herzegovina. In fact, following Croatia's accession to the European Union, it was necessary to review the trade part of the association and stabilisation agreements concluded with the blockade of the countries of the Western Balkans. Unfortunately, however, the negotiations opened to this end with Bosnia are still at a standstill. The suspension of the ATM measures will enter into force on 1 January 2016 and, while not causing significant economic losses for Bosnia, it affects the Government of Sarajevo politically and symbolically.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Trade between the EU and the Western Balkan countries is liberalised through a number of Stabilisation and Association Agreements (SAA) and an Interim Agreement (IA) in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I have voted for this report on the European Union’s Stabilisation and Association process and suspending its application with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina until Bosnia and Herzegovina accept the EU methodology regarding the adaptation of the Interim Agreement.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. As Bosnia and The Duchy approach to the EU, it is important that they continue with their reforms. It is positive to inclusion of the human rights clause in the Trade Measures Regulation.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. In view of the current situation, I believe that Bosnia and Herzegovina should be temporarily subject to the suspension of autonomous trade measures. This is an effective and equitable tool, the purpose of which is not to punish. This measure should encourage Bosnia and Herzegovina to restart negotiations.   In particular, the dispute over the adaptation of the Interim Agreement following Croatia's accession to the EU must be resolved as soon as possible. Bosnia and Herzegovina must agree to the EU methodology for adapting the Interim Agreement. Continuous monitoring and transparency must be carried out in order to address this problem as soon as possible.  Bosnia and Herzegovina must fulfil all the conditions laid down, taking into account further future plans. It is also essential that the proper implementation of human rights is ensured.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP notes that the EU has a track record of economic bullying against countries that refuse to politically obey it. Bosnia is no exception and we feel that the EU should not be using trade as a political weapon.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have read carefully the amendments made to the draft report under discussion here and I thank all my colleagues for their work. I agree with you on the general principle that emerges from this: the process of eu membership of any country cannot ignore the progress of respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. There is no doubt that I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the suspension of the application of special trade measures with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina due to the fact that it is necessary for Bosnia and Herzegovina to adapt its methodology for calculating traditional trade to the European Union. The efforts expressed by Bosnia and Herzegovina in systematic reforms and adaptation to European legislation must be the same in all areas.  The demand for special treatment is contrary to the fundamental logic of the European Union in the category of competition and equal market access. Although this measure affects the economy of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the European Union, it is necessary to work on further arrangements that will establish a different system of preference for traditional trade. As a mandatory party to the Interim Agreement, Bosnia and Herzegovina must fully assume all obligations of that agreement.  I hope this will encourage the Bosnian and Herzegovinian authorities to accept the adjustment of trade preferences granted under the Interim Agreement in order to take into account traditional preferential trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina under the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA).

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council aims to amend Regulation (EC) 1215/2009 which granted exceptional commercial benefits until 31 December 2015 to the Balkans in general and Bosnia in particular, including pending the signing of a Bosnian accession contract to the EU.  The EU is now considering, through this vote, to continue to help Bosnia and, above all, to maintain Bosnia's possibility of EU membership. As I am opposed to the accession of this country in a permanent state of political crisis and where endemic corruption reigns, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the proposal to suspend extraordinary trade measures regarding Bosnia and Herzegovina, which mainly related to the possibility of duty-free exports of certain food products from BiH to the EU that occurred due to BiH's refusal to adjust its Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) to Croatia's accession to the EU, which has been going on for two and a half years.  By leaving the CEFTA market, Croatia temporarily lost its right to preferential duties. This provision is most affected by the domestic food industry and agriculture, which export 45% of their total production to that market. EU membership has changed export conditions and the 20 most important Croatian agricultural food products exported to BiH in 2014 are subject to the full duty rate. As far as statistics are concerned, 660 million euros in financial assistance was received by BiH from the EU in the previous budget period alone (2007-2013), while on the other hand Croatia lost 220 million euros in the first 6 months of EU membership alone due to BiH's refusal to adjust its SSP.  All other CEFTA members have already adapted their SSP to Croatia's accession to the EU and this is an opportunity for the new authorities in BiH to prove their commitment to the European path. Croatia had to do the same when Slovenia and Hungary joined the EU in 2004.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – I support the report of my colleague Goffred Maria Bettini. I agree with the Commission's proposal to extend autonomous trade measures to countries participating in the Stabilisation and Association Process to the EU by 31 December 2020. All analyses confirm that a preferential trade regime empowers the economies of the candidate countries to join and encourages an increase in overall trade activities with the EU.  It is the European Union that is by far the largest trading partner of the Western Balkan countries, in terms of imports (72.7 %) exports (81.8%). In this regard, these measures are a continuation of the consistent foreign policy efforts that are driving the western Balkan countries' rapprochement with EU membership. Together with my Croatian counterparts in the EP, I continually call on the authorities in BiH to reach an agreement with the Commission on the adaptation of the SSP, given Croatia's membership in the EU in order to maintain traditional trade between the Republic of Croatia and BiH.  Enough time has passed to adapt, and the opinion of the Foreign Affairs Committee is that BiH should take advantage of the EU's new political approach and avoid the possibility of suspending preferential trade measures from 1.1.2016. Encouraging are the latest signals from the Stabilisation and Association Council that indicate BiH's readiness to make the required trade adjustments to the SAA, which are an important step for the credible submission of BiH's application for EU membership, which is what Croatian MEPs strongest advocate.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The method by which the European Union amends trade agreements following the accession of a state is based on the concept of traditional trade between the new member of the Union and the country that signed the trade agreement with the EU. All the countries of the Western Balkans have signed the Cefta (Central European Free Trade Agreement), accepting this method and concluding negotiations for the amendment of their agreements with the EU, with the exception of Bosnia and Herzegovina. After three rounds of negotiations, Bosnia and Herzegovina did not reach an agreement. The country considers that it cannot change tariff preferences for traditional trade and would change them only in the face of further concessions from the EU. For this reason, my vote in favour of the temporary suspension of trade measures is due to the fact that this stalemate has already caused a number of damage to the EU's commercial interests and to the process of European integration. I therefore hope that an agreement can soon be reached between the parties to avoid the suspension of preferences for Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the suspension of exceptional trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina. Trade between the EU and the countries of the Western Balkans is liberalised by a number of Stabilization and Association Agreements (ASA) and an Interim Agreement (AI) in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In addition, the region benefits from autonomous trade measures (MCA). Three changes have just been made by the European Commission. First, current preferences will be extended until the end of 2020. A major development is that a "human rights clause" has been introduced and allows preferences to be suspended in the event of serious and systematic violations of fundamental principles of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. Finally, a possible suspension of the MCAs for Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016 will be possible until an interim agreement to take account of traditional preferential trade between Bosnia and Croatia has been taken into account. As a result of this blockage and the damage to the Union's commercial interests, I would argue that the MCAs with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina should not be automatically extended.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP notes that the EU has a track record of economic bullying against countries that refuse to politically obey it. Bosnia is no exception and we feel that the EU should not be using trade as a political weapon.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report while calling for respect for democratic principles, the rule of law and human rights, as well as the protection of minorities, to ensure that the accession process can progress.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Trade between the European Union and the Balkan countries is guaranteed through a series of stabilisation and association agreements. In view of the fact that Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet agreed to adapt the Interim Agreement to take account of traditional preferential trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina within the framework of the Central European Free Trade Agreement, I think it would be appropriate to vote in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No Council Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 on exceptional trade measures applicable to countries and territories participating in or linked to the Stabilisation and Association Process of the European Union and suspending its application in respect of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted AGAINST this report because Bosnia and Hezergovina are being required to put in place measures to adapt to European standards as was done with Bulgaria or Romania, but unlike in the case of these, the prospect of EU membership is not immediate , not even credible. The clause that makes the preferential trade agreement subject to human rights is welcome, but insufficient to support the text.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Previously, Bosnia signed an Association and Stabilisation Agreement with the EU that excluded fifteen agricultural products as sensitive products for Bosnia and Herzegovina. If Bosnia now accepts the trade review proposed by this Resolution, these fifteen sensitive agricultural products will be liberalized. Therefore, aware of the importance of limiting trade interference by the EU in third countries, especially those in situations of particular instability or immersed in political, social or economic processes of radical significance to its people, such as Bosnia and Herzegovina, I voted against this Resolution in order to continue to maintain the protection of these agricultural products.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text voted on today concerns the suspension of the extension of unilateral trade preferences to Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Latter, as one of the countries of the Western Balkans participating in the Stabilisation and Association Process (SAP) with the EU, would have unrestricted access to the European market in the absence of duties. However, having not yet agreed to adapt the SAP agreement to take account of Croatia's annexation to the Union, such exceptional measures could be suspended.  I am of the opinion that Bosnia and Herzegovina should see this interruption as an incentive to resolve current trade disputes, in order to enjoy the benefits of integration with the EU like the other Balkan states, to which autonomous trade preferences have been extended for a further five years. In the hope that the country will take advantage of this decision to clarify some outstanding issues with the European Union, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote as I do not believe the EU should be involved in trade.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since 2000 the EU has granted the countries of the Western Balkans autonomous trade measures, which includes Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Commission has proposed to extend the autonomous trade measures until the end of 2020, otherwise they will expire at the end of this month. After long negotiations with the Council and Commission, which I should thank the rapporteur Maria Bettini Goffredo for committing so much of her time towards, we now have reached an agreement. I voted in favour of this codecision procedure, firstly because I believe that there should be a stable majority in support of the outcome of the interinstitutional negotiations. Furthermore, the inclusion of a human rights clause in this proposal is a massively important part of the text.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade between the EU and the Western Balkan countries has been liberalised through a number of Stabilisation and Association Agreements and, in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina, through an Interim Agreement. In addition, the entire Western Balkans region benefits from the autonomous trade measures granted by the EU since 2000.  These one-sided preferences allow unlimited duty-free free access for most products to the EU. In the proposal under review, the Commission presented three main amendments to the basic Regulation. The first concerns the extension of the current preferences until the end of 2020, the second concerns the introduction of the so-called human rights clause in the Autonomous Trade Measures Regulation, and the third concerns the possible suspension of autonomous trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016. At present, the negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina have not produced any agreement, so it defines a number of conditions for entitlements to preferential agreements, such as compliance with the definition of 'originating products', the obligation for beneficiary countries to refrain from introducing new duties or charges in respect of products originating in the EU, preventing the risks of fraud in trade relations.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Countries participating in the stabilisation and integration process into European structures must demonstrate respect for the principles of democracy, the rule of law, the protection of human rights and minorities in accessible processes. However, if serious and systematic violations are constantly taking place, the EU is forced to take action and certain definitions.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Trade between the European Union and the Western Balkan countries is liberalised by measures within the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) and the Interim Agreement in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina. These unilateral trade measures allow duty-free access to the European Union for certain products.  Therefore, I support the extension of trade measures for the countries of the Western Balkans, which are both an important economic and integration tool of these countries, with the exception of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In the case of BiH, it is necessary to take into account Croatia's accession to the Union and the subsequent need to adapt the Interim Agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina.  Therefore, I expect that bosnia and herzegovina's political leadership will soon harmonise the Interim Agreement, and that Bosnia and Herzegovina will continue to enjoy trade preferences.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU's policy towards the Western Balkan countries is defined in the Stabilisation and Association Process. BiH signed a Stabilisation and Association Agreement in 2008, agreeing to the conditions for EU membership. Since then, the Interim Agreement on Trade and Trade Issues with Bosnia and Herzegovina has been applied until the ratification process of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement is completed. Council Regulation No 2013/2013 1215/2009 provides for an asymmetric liberalisation of trade between the Union and the countries concerned and the territory of the Western Balkans, granting them the benefits of extraordinary and unrestricted duty-free access to the Union market by 31 December 2015. It is proposed to extend the duration of Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013. 1215/2009 until 31 December 2020. I agree with this proposal because I consider that extending the duration of the regulation would give sufficient time to comply with the preferences granted under Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013. 1215/2009 with those provided for under the Stabilisation and Association Agreement.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as I support all initiatives for trade liberalisation.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Council Regulation imposing exceptional trade measures on countries and territories participating in or related to the Stabilisation and Association Process of the European Union and suspending its application to Bosnia and Herzegovina. I support the suspension of the application of specific trade measures in relation to Bosnia and Herzegovina due to the fact that Bosnia and Herzegovina must harmonise the calculation methodology. Bosnia and Herzegovina's efforts to reform and adapt its legislation to European legislation must be the same in all areas.  I hope that this will encourage the authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina to accept adjustments to the trade concessions granted under the interim agreement in order to take into account preferential traditional trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina under the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA).

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is impossible to grant privileges to countries that in practice have nothing to do with European values.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report and the proposal for treaty amendments therein, because I believe it can fundamentally help to fulfil the conditions for the European integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I consider it appropriate that, in order to further adapt to the conditions of accession, the EU, along with other Western Balkan countries, will, with extended effect until 2020, offer unilateral trade preferences to Bosnia and Herzegovina, but I also agree that the differences in the implementation of the Interim Agreement should be resolved as soon as possible between the two parties. This is the aim of the proposal for an amendment, by allowing the unilateral benefit to be suspended from 1 January 2016 in the event of non-compliance with the necessary conditions.  I also think it is right that the amendment introduces democratic rights under European standards into the terms of the agreement through a 'human rights clause', thereby bringing the agreement more into line with the accession criteria according to the Copenhagen criteria. From the EP resolution, I hope that, as a result, the Government of this important Balkan partner country will also take swift and effective measures in these areas to ensure that the criteria for accession are met as quickly as possible.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Over the last 20 years, Bosnia and Herzegovina has made significant efforts to be among the developed, peaceful and democratic states of the world as soon as possible. The Community shall support the European perspectives of Bosnia and Herzegovina, including its membership of the European Union.  To make this possible, however, it is essential to fulfil certain conditions, including, in particular, ensuring respect for democratic principles, the rule of law, human rights and the protection of minorities. It is also important that the Authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with the support of the European Commission, take decisive action to implement as soon as possible and effectively the provisions of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, which entered into force on 1 June 2015.  I trust that internal reforms and close cooperation with the European Union will enable Bosnia and Herzegovina to achieve its ambitious goals.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has always had cordial relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, a country in which it has been involved since its independence was declared. One of the decisive areas for the country's development and stabilisation is free trade. In this respect, the EU has concluded an Interim Agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina since 2000, which constitutes a unilateral preferential regime whereby it benefits from unlimited duty-free access in the EU for most products, especially agricultural products.  The Commission is currently proposing three main amendments to the agreement by extending the current preferences in order to provide time to align preferences with those provided for in the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, the introduction into the agreement of the 'human rights' clause, which allows the suspension of preferences in the event of serious violations and the possible suspension of the agreement from 1 January 2016, if the agreement is not adapted for the inclusion of Croatia in preferential practices. The current report accepts these amendments, which it nuances to make the agreement conditional on respect for the principles of democracy and the rule of law, effective economic reforms, regional cooperation with other Western Balkan countries and the strengthening of the administrative institutions of the Bosnian state. In conclusion, the current document is an important step forward.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Trade between the EU and the countries of the Western Balkans is liberalised by a number of Stabilization and Association Agreements (ASA) and an Interim Agreement (AI) in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In addition, Kosovo (which is not yet the subject of an ASA) and the region as a whole have benefited from autonomous trade measures (MCA) granted by the EU since 2000. These unilateral preferences allow unlimited duty-free access to the EU market for most products. Unlike ASAs, in which preferences are granted by both parties, THE MCAs constitute a unilateral preferential regime in favour of the Western Balkans. The changes proposed in the text suit me.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In the case of this report, the vote was postponed. Parliament adopted several amendments to it and referred it back to the responsible Committee on International Trade. The amendments focus on the adaptation of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s Interim Agreement with the EU and its progress towards accession. The original Commission proposal concerns Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009, which relates to trade preferences between the EU and the Western Balkan countries, including Autonomous Trade Measures (ATMs) granted to it by the EU since 2000. The Commission proposed several changes to it, one of them being the possible suspension of ATMs for Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016. Following the accession of Croatia to the EU, Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet adapted its Interim Agreement with the EU in order to take into account the preferential traditional trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Referring to damage of EU’s commercial interests, the Commission proposed that a prolongation of ATMs to Bosnia and Herzegovina would not be automatic, but should depend on Bosnia and Herzegovina accepting the EU methodology regarding the adaptation of the Interim Agreement.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 President, the purpose of the Report ˗ to give the beneficiary countries additional time to bring the concessions granted to them by the basic Regulation with those granted to them with the Stabilisation and Association Agreement and/or the interim agreement. After three rounds of negotiations, no agreement could be reached with Bosnia and Herzegovina. Contrary to the EU methodology, Bosnia and Herzegovina considers that it cannot increase its preferences to the level of traditional trade. In view of the situation without a solution and damage to the EU's commercial interests, the Commission quite rightly proposes that the automatic application of trade measures to Bosnia and Herzegovina should not be extended automatically, but should depend on Bosnia and Herzegovina's acceptance of the EU methodology for adapting the Interim Agreement. It is therefore necessary to take new legal decisions as soon as possible. I also decided to support the report for this reason.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ As an MP from Croatia, a Member State which in this legislative proposal of the European Commission at first reading, concerning the prolongation of the duration of extraordinary trade measures for the territory of the Western Balkans, has a direct link and interest, I supported this proposal.  The extension of the measures was not granted for Bosnia and Herzegovina, since it also depends on the adjustment of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement to the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, in the way that other countries of the Western Balkans have already done so. In the event that the same does not happen by the time this legislative proposal is passed, the privileges granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina will be suspended from 1.1.2016. At the moment when these assumptions are nevertheless fulfilled by Bosnia and Herzegovina, trade privileges will be automatically reinstated.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the suspension of exceptional trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina, as it is also essential that Bosnia and Herzegovina take decisions on the adjustment of trade concessions granted under the Interim Agreement on trade and trade matters with the EU following croatia's accession. It must do so as soon as possible, otherwise preferences for Bosnia and Herzegovina could be suspended from 1 January 2016.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted AGAINST this report because Bosnia and Hezergovina are being required to put in place measures to adapt to European standards as was done with Bulgaria or Romania, but unlike in the case of these, the prospect of EU membership is not immediate , not even credible. The clause that makes the preferential trade agreement subject to human rights is welcome, but insufficient to support the text.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU wants through this vote to help Bosnia, but above all to safeguard Bosnia's possibility of accession to the EU. We are totally opposed to its accession. I vote AGAINST this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Trade liberalisation between the EU and the Western Balkan countries in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina will be achieved through several stabilisation and association agreements and an interim agreement. The purpose of extending the current preferences is to give the beneficiary countries time to harmonise the preferences granted under the basic Regulation and the preferences granted under the Stabilisation and Association Agreements and the Interim Agreements. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted AGAINST this report because Bosnia and Hezergovina are being required to put in place measures to adapt to European standards as was done with Bulgaria or Romania, but unlike in the case of these, the prospect of EU membership is not immediate , not even credible. The clause that makes the preferential trade agreement subject to human rights is welcome, but insufficient to support the text.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – This provision allows the suspension of preferences in cases where any beneficiary country seriously and systematically infringes the fundamental principles of human rights, democracy and the rule of law.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the suspension of exceptional trade measures to Bosnia and Herzegovina and of the position of the European Parliament in this matter. With this decision we addressed the topics of: 1) Prolongation of the current preferences until the end of 2020, where the aim of the prolongation is to give the beneficiary countries additional time to align the preferences. We introduced the so-called ‘human rights clause’ in the ATM Regulation that allows for a suspension of preferences in case of serious and systematic violations of fundamental principles of human rights, democracy and the rule of law by any of the beneficiary countries. And we address the possible suspension of ATMs for Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016. I believe this was necessary because after three rounds of negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, no agreement could be reached. As a result of this stalemate and the damage to EU commercial interests, the Commission proposes that a prolongation of ATMs to Bosnia and Herzegovina would not be automatic, but should depend on Bosnia and Herzegovina accepting the EU methodology regarding the adaptation of the Interim Agreement.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I support the suspension of exceptional trade measures with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina. This suspension should be seen as a means of persuading Bosnia and Herzegovina to resolve the dispute between that country and the European Union on the adjustment of the interim agreement as soon as possible.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Trade between the European Union and Bosnia and Herzegovina is currently governed by an interim agreement characterized by asymmetry in favour of the latter, particularly for sensitive agricultural products. From the EU's point of view, Croatia's accession to the EU on 1 July 2013 was a game-changer and the Commission called on Bosnia to open up its markets more.  In the midst of the economic and social crisis, for initially political reasons, Bosnia refused, because of the weakness of its economy (high unemployment, large chronic trade deficits, toxic "aid" from the IMF...).  In the name of a so-called "prejudice to the union's commercial interests", the Commission, rather than helping a fragile country in the midst of a political, economic and social crisis, wants Bosnia to bend through trade retaliatory measures.  I voted against this unbearable blackmail.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report confirms what has been the process of European integration in the Balkan countries, in particular through the granting of unilateral trade preferences. It is, in essence, a document which seeks to open another chapter in the process of interference and destabilisation of the European Union in that region, wanting to impose on Bosnia and Herzegovina the acceptance of the Interim Preferential Trade Agreement, as already agreed with Croatia following its accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013, framed in the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA). In this regard, the document is quite enlightening when it states that the conditions "must be accepted as an impetus to accelerate the transition from the political and socio-economic reforms highlighted in the 'pact for growth'" with a view to "compliance by the western Balkan countries, the Copenhagen criteria and the acquis communautaire".

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The proposal goes beyond the Commission's demands and makes far too much concessions to Bosnia and Herzegovina. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's adopted position confirms the EU's determination to increase pressure on Bosnia and Herzegovina, which makes its willingness to negotiate mutual trade with Croatia further concessions from the EU. The approved resolution is a warning to Bosnia and Herzegovina that its stubborn stance may lead not to greater concessions, but, on the contrary, to the suspension of preferential trade measures by the EU. It is a strong signal to the Government of this Balkan country that, while the EU supports its inclusion in its area, it will only comply with the rules and agreements in force.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the suspension of the implementation of emergency trade measures with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina. The suspension of trade preferences for Bosnia and Herzegovina should be seen as an incentive to resolve the current dispute with the EU over the adjustment of the interim agreement.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report confirms what has been the process of European integration in the Balkan countries, in particular by granting unilateral trade preferences. It is, in essence, a document which seeks to open another chapter in the process of interference and destabilisation of the European Union in that region, wanting to impose on Bosnia and Herzegovina the acceptance of the Interim Preferential Trade Agreement, as already agreed with Croatia following its accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013, framed in the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA). In this regard, the document is quite enlightening when it states that the conditions "should be accepted as an impetus to accelerate the transition from the political and socio-economic reforms highlighted in the 'pact for growth'" with a view to "compliance by the western Balkan countries, the Copenhagen criteria and the acquis communautaire". By the foregoing, vote against.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – I support the conclusion of this agreement, as there is a clear need for Europol to cooperate with the United Arab Emirates. The United Arab Emirates is becoming increasingly relevant in the fight against organised crime, as it is becoming a growing hub for economic and financial crime. The profit from these criminal activities, such as VAT fraud, money laundering, was reinvested in the United Arab Emirates and prominent criminals involved in these frauds sought to take refuge there.  However, I would like to say that I would have expected, in solidarity with the European Union, and given that the United Arab Emirates has asked us for a short-stay visa, so visa liberalisation with the European Union, to have voted against it, as the United Arab Emirates has refused to take refugees in this wave of refugees coming to Europe.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also supported Parliament's position because it was an expression of Parliament's position on the Council's proposal. It is an international agreement and is approved by the Council. However, I considered it essential to highlight a few moments in the approval of this agreement. Indeed, the United Arab Emirates is a meek of financial crime in the region, and it is very important to cooperate with that state in preventing this very crime, for its effective investigation. I am glad that this strategic agreement will be concluded and therefore approved. At the same time, I would like to point out that the agreement does not concern the transfer of personal data, because it is indeed a very sensitive matter, and I am glad that the Council and European diplomacy have acted very cautiously on this matter. So, on my part, nothing prevented me from supporting this proposal for Parliament's position.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against terrorism and crime in its most serious forms now more than ever requires clear rules and cooperation between strict international bodies. According to the current Europol decision, the Council is the body responsible for establishing international agreements with third states or international organisations, after consulting Parliament. The proposal put forward by the rapporteur, Mr Mussolini, calls for the establishment of a new form of cooperation between Europol and the United Arab Emirates. The creation of forms of cooperation with the United Arab Emirates for better management of or prevention of crime in the territory is absolutely essential. On 26 November, however, the negotiations for an amendment to the JHA Regulation establishing Europol were concluded and will soon enter into force. I have therefore chosen to abstain because I believe it would be appropriate to wait for the new rules to enter into force before entering into new cooperation agreements.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.
