This cooperation would be based on exchanges of information that may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on methods of crime prevention, participation in training activities, as well as the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations, but not the exchange of personal data.  This cooperation is motivated by the fact that the United Arab Emirates is increasingly home to white-collar criminals who practice financial and economic crime (VAT fraud, money laundering, etc.).  To the extent that the fight against international criminals must be a priority, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. I support the proposal to conclude a strategic cooperation agreement with the United Arab Emirates, as evidence suggests the growing importance of this country in the field of fighting organised crime. The exchange of expertise, analysis, information on ongoing investigations, etc. are important elements of international cooperation in the fight against financial fraud. In addition, such an agreement would exclude the exchange of personal data so that there is no problem with their protection.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I support MEP Alessandra Mussolini's report on the Council's draft implementing decision authorising the European Police Office (Europol) to conclude a strategic cooperation agreement in the fight against serious crime and terrorism between the United Arab Emirates and Europol.  The peculiarity of this strategic contract is that it excludes the exchange of personal data. Information on specific findings, situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on the course of criminal investigations, trainee activities and assistance and support in individual criminal investigations will be exchanged. In my view, there is a clear operational need for cooperation between Europol and the United Arab Emirates, especially as the UAE is becoming an increasingly powerful factor in the fight against organised crime.  I support this strategic cooperation with the United Arab Emirates, as this will be additional support in the fight against financial malfeasance and will contribute to international cooperation in the field of investigations of financial malfeasance and other criminal activities.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that europol's strategic cooperation agreement with the United Arab Emirates is a very important step towards further strengthening international coordination in the fight against financial and other crime. Concerns about the protection of personal data are not appropriate in this case, as the agreement excludes their exchange. The information shared will include, for example, expertise, investigative procedures, advice on specific investigations, strategic analyses or general situation reports. I am convinced that cooperation with the United Arab Emirates in the fight against organised crime will become increasingly important.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Council Decision 2009/371/JHA, it is for the Council to approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements between europol and third countries or international organisations after consulting the European Parliament. Such agreements may concern the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. According to Europol, the United Arab Emirates is becoming increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, as the country is becoming an increasingly important hub for financial and economic crimes. Proceeds from criminal activities have been reinvested in the United Arab Emirates and the most prominent criminals involved in financial fraud have sought refuge in the country. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that cooperation between the parties can provide important concrete support for the fight against financial fraud and help to strengthen international cooperation on financial investigations and other relevant criminal matters.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I am pleased to have been able to express myself on this strategic agreement. We must strengthen our cooperation with the United Arab Emirates in the prevention and fight against terrorism and crime. Our countries have a great interest in developing their relations in this area, because unfortunately terrorism and crime know no borders.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP commends the UAE for its role in fighting extremism and notes the strong ties that exist between the UK and the UAE. We abstained because we feel that the UK Government, and not Europol, should be the body that oversees UK intelligence and data sharing with third countries.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement provides for strategic cooperation between Europol and the United Arab Emirates. Such a strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data and is why, in the present case, the issue of data protection is not relevant. The information exchanged may include expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on both criminal investigation processes and crime prevention methods, training activities, advice and support in certain criminal investigations. According to Europol, the United Arab Emirates is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, as they are increasingly becoming a platform for economic and financial crime.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I have decided to approve the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the agreement on strategic cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism between the United Arab Emirates and Europol.  The terms of cooperation governed by the strategic agreement provide for exchanges of information that may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, participation in training activities, and the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations. It should be noted that there is no provision in the strategic agreement for the exchange of personal data.  The Council now give its approval for the approval of this strategic agreement, knowing that the Europol Board of Directors approved it on 13 May 2015.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates provides for a greater exchange of information that can integrate expertise on important topics to combat organised crime.  Joint work between Europol and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) is key to combating global economic and financial crime, which, although it does not choose countries or borders, prefers the fastest-expanding economies as the initial gateway to the system and where liquidity levels are higher, such as the UAE. It therefore seems important to me to support this legislative resolution, as this Agreement should result in a direct contribution against financial fraud, as well as to the promotion of international cooperation in the field of economic and financial research and other relevant criminal issues.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the conclusion of the agreement on strategic cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism between the United Arab Emirates and Europol, as I believe it is of fundamental importance to increase the security of citizens and combat all forms of organised crime at both European and transnational level. This agreement will make it possible to carry out more specific and accurate investigations through the exchange of information which will serve to prevent and prevent the emergence of terrorist acts. The European Union's objective is to develop strategic plans capable of eradicating terrorism and ensuring the best protection for its citizens.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against it, firstly because we consider it a waste to approve this strategic cooperation agreement now, because the Council and the European Parliament are currently negotiating a new Regulation for Europol (2013/0091 (COD)), in which the procedure for concluded international agreements, as well as the relevant provisions and guarantees for the protection of the personal data of European citizens will be significantly amended. We believe that it would be preferable for this international cooperation agreement to be adopted after the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation. On the other hand, we are against this report as it underlies the double standards governing eu foreign policy with regard to the fight against terrorism in its cooperation agreements with countries such as the UAE. The EU is the second largest arms dealer in the region, weapons that have often ended up in the hands of rebel groups or terrorist groups. Consequently, we consider it hypocritical to support strategic cooperation agreements with the United Arab Emirates in the fight against terrorism if at the same time the EU arms sale is working to strengthen these terrorist groups.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it, firstly because we consider it a waste to approve this strategic cooperation agreement now, because the Council and the European Parliament are currently negotiating a new Regulation for Europol (2013/0091 (COD)), in which the procedure for concluded international agreements, as well as the relevant provisions and guarantees for the protection of the personal data of European citizens will be significantly amended. We believe that it would be preferable for this international cooperation agreement to be adopted after the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation. On the other hand, we are against this report as it underlies the double standards governing eu foreign policy with regard to the fight against terrorism in its cooperation agreements with countries such as the UAE. The EU is the second largest arms dealer in the region, weapons that have often ended up in the hands of rebel groups or terrorist groups. Consequently, we consider it hypocritical to support strategic cooperation agreements with the United Arab Emirates in the fight against terrorism if at the same time the EU arms sale is working to strengthen these terrorist groups.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal concerning the approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates because I believe that it is of major importance in the fight against international organised crime and terrorism.  According to the provisions of the agreement, the information exchanged should include specialist knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results and information on criminal investigation procedures. In addition, information on crime prevention methods, training activities, the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations should also be included. This agreement excludes the exchange of personal data.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this as I believe this should be done on a bilateral basis not via the EU.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Earlier we voted on a visa waiver of 90 days with the UAE for EU citizens, this represented an important step towards enhancing our cooperation and relations with Abu Dhabi. While it is regrettable that the Parliament has only been given a consultative role, it is an important sign of approval from this place, nevertheless.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution approving the conclusion by Europol of an agreement between the United Arab Emirates and the European Police Office (Europol) on strategic cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism. The United Arab Emirates currently plays an important role in the fight against organised crime, as the country is becoming a growing hub for economic and financial crime. Proceeds from crime, such as value added tax fraud or money laundering, are being reinvested in the United Arab Emirates, and key perpetrators involved in these scams are also resorting to this country. Therefore, the information to be exchanged under this Agreement can be very important in individual criminal investigations and in the fight against financial fraud.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. In accordance with the applicable Council Decision on Europol (2009/371/JHA), agreements on international cooperation with third countries or international organisations may be concluded, after approval by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament.  Such agreements may include the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or confidential information. This report concerns the proposed approval of the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates (UAE). There should be clear operational needs for this cooperation, as Europol considers that the US is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime.  The UAE is becoming an increasingly important hub for economic and financial crime, where revenues derived from crimes such as value added tax fraud, evasion and money laundering are re-imposed. I have no doubt that the need for cooperation is justified, but I nevertheless express my concerns about the degree of protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the country with which this agreement is to be concluded.  However, I also dispute the report for procedural reasons. I believe that, by approving this agreement, we should wait until the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation (2013/0091 (COD)), which, among other things, substantially re-renews agreements between third countries and international organisations and Europol. For the sake of the above, I voted against the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The United Arab Emirates is becoming an important centre of economic and financial crime. Strategic cooperation with Europol is therefore operationally necessary as it will facilitate and strengthen international cooperation in the field of financial investigations and other relevant criminal matters.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this proposal for a resolution because I believe that the European Union should actively address and prevent serious crimes and terrorism issues. This strategic cooperation with the United Arab Emirates enables the European Union to acquire the necessary data to combat terrorism and serious crime while helping the United Arab Emirates prevent terrorism and serious crime on its own territory.  The implementation of this resolution is expected to lead to further cooperation to step up the fight against financial fraud, and contribute to strengthening international cooperation in financial investigations and other relevant areas.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report proposing approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates. Through information exchange such as specialist knowledge, general situation reports, results of strategic analysis, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime-prevention methods, training activities, and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations we have the chance to make significant improvements in the tackling of economic and financial crime.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. On 30 November 2009, the Council adopted a Decision (2009/934/PUP) setting a list of third states (including the United Arab Emirates) and the organisations with which Europol concludes agreements. However, the agreement does not include the exchange of personal data, so the issue of data protection is not relevant in this case.  The information exchanged is related to specialist knowledge, general situational reports, strategic analysis results, information on the criminal investigation procedure, information on crime prevention methods, etc. Europol's operational needs with the United Arab Emirates were assessed to be clearly operational in order to fight organised crime more strongly.  I support the Council Decision on the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates, as I believe that due to the cross-border nature of many criminal activities and organised crime groups, enhanced regional and international cooperation should be established to better respond to Member States' requests for police and judicial cooperation.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal as I support cooperation between the UAE and Europol.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of an agreement on strategic cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism between the United Arab Emirates and the European Police Office (Europol) by Europol. The United Arab Emirates is increasingly important in the fight against organised crime, and cooperation between the European Union and the UAE is very important in the fight against organised crime. By concluding this agreement, we will strengthen and improve international cooperation in the field of financial investigations and other relevant criminal matters. I support the Council's decision on the conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement with Europol and the United Arab Emirates, as I believe that, due to the cross-border nature of many criminal activities and organised crime groups, we need the establishment of enhanced regional and international cooperation.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report concerns Europol's promoted strategic cooperation with the United Arab Emirates in the fight against serious crime and terrorism, but does not address key issues of EU-UAE relations. Unfortunately, at the same time as the EU concludes cooperation agreements with the Gulf countries to combat terrorism, it continues to be the second largest arms supplier in the region even though there is a heap of information that these weapons end up in the hands of extremist fundamentalist groups. Also, on a number of issues, the conclusion of this cooperation, on the basis of the relevant Council Decision of 2009, ignores the fact that a new Europol regulation is currently being consulted. This new regulation is expected to significantly alter the procedure for concluding such international agreements as well as the provisions on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Any strategic cooperation agreement between the EU (Europol) and the UNITED STATES is devoid of logic. The United States is a centre of economic and financial crime, a haven for criminals in economic crimes, and their banking system invests in profits from VAT fraud and intra-Community hidden trade fraud. So far, the UAE has operated outside the logic of prosecuting economic criminals and crimes, and their performance is far from, as the rule of law, far from Western-style states and Christian societies.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's non-objection to the agreement between Europol and the authorities of the United Arab Emirates, which provides for strategic cooperation in the pursuit of terrorism and other serious forms of international crime.  I have considered the fact that the focus of economic and financial crime, including money laundering, tax evasion, etc., has recently shifted towards the Gulf region. Extensive data exchange and professional cooperation with the authorities of the countries concerned are essential for effective action against this type of crime, which also plays a major role in the financing of international terrorism.  At the same time, I think it is right that the Europol-UAE agreement does not cover the exchange of personal data and should therefore not raise concerns about the enforcement of EU data protection standards and rules.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The draft Implementing Decision of the Council concerning the agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates on strategic cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism is an extremely important action, especially in the context of the recent events in Paris. This agreement aims to improve the exchange of operational, strategic or technical information, including personal and classified information.  In a globalising world, no country or international organisation is able to fight terrorism on its own. That is why it is so important to start combating terrorism at source, that is, in places where radical ideas and plans for later action can be born.  I am convinced that we need more agreements similar to those concluded with the United Arab Emirates. It is through such cooperation that the European Union will be able to fight terrorism effectively.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has in recent years supported a policy of cooperation with the United Arab Emirates in areas of common interest. These include the fight against organised crime and international terrorism. The situation of this country in a very important region in terms of supporting and financing terrorist networks and criminal groups promoting illicit trafficking requires the conclusion of a comprehensive agreement to combat these negative phenomena. Europol's work in this area has increased substantially in recent years, thanks to the strengthening of cooperation between Member States and the adoption of specific policies at European level. The conclusion of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates involves regular exchanges of operational, strategic, technical or classified information, with the exception of personal data, on the general situation, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigations, methods of crime prevention, training activities and advice in certain criminal investigations. There is now a clear operational need for this agreement, especially with regard to value added tax fraud, intra-Community fraud with shell companies and money laundering.  Even if the agreement reached by the Council has to be reassessed after the adoption of European legislation on Europol, the current report can be adopted.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The proposal under consideration is for the approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates. Since this type of strategic agreement excludes the exchange of personal data, the issue of data protection is irrelevant in this case. The information exchanged may include expert opinions, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on methods of crime prevention, as well as training activities or advice and support in the context of specific criminal investigations.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Strategic cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism between the United Arab Emirates and Europol, and voted in favour of the cooperation. Such agreements between Europol and third countries have the objective of supporting and strengthening action by the competent authorities of the Member States and their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more Member States, and may concern the exchange of operational, strategic or technical information, including personal data and classified information.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Dear President – (DE) Mr President, As a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I fully supported the report on several issues of interest to citizens' security.   This proposal concerns the proposal to approve the Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates. This strategic agreement is important in the fight against terrorism. Information could be exchanged in the areas of expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and methods of crime prevention. Prevention on these issues is essential and its role in the fight against organised crime is becoming increasingly important.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I support Europol's Strategic Cooperation Agreement with the United Arab Emirates as it will enable the exchange of information including special knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigations and procedures, information on crime prevention methods, participation in trainings and trainings, advice and support in individual criminal investigations, and many other positive security aspects. Since Europol was established in 1992 with the aim of preventing and combating organised international crime and terrorism in the European Union, and since Europol's fundamental task is precisely to support national police authorities in the individual Member States of the Union through the collection, analysis and coordination of information and the coordination of operations, I consider such and similar agreements to be positive , sometimes of crucial importance.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on Strategic Cooperation in the Fight against Serious Crime and Terrorism between the United Arab Emirates and Europol by helping to combat financial fraud, strengthening it and contributing to improving international cooperation in the field of financial investigations and other relevant criminal matters.  Agreements on international cooperation with third countries or international organisations may be concluded only after they have been approved by the Council after consulting the European Parliament. Such agreements may relate to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or confidential information.  The Operational Cooperation Agreement shall also cover the exchange of personal data. This proposal concerns the proposed approval of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates. Such strategic cooperation excludes the exchange of personal data, so the issue of the protection of personal data is irrelevant in this case.  The data exchanged could include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and methods for crime prevention, training activities and advice and support for individual criminal investigations.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against it, firstly because we consider it a waste to approve this strategic cooperation agreement now, because the Council and the European Parliament are currently negotiating a new Regulation for Europol (2013/0091 (COD)), in which the procedure for concluded international agreements, as well as the relevant provisions and guarantees for the protection of the personal data of European citizens will be significantly amended. We believe that it would be preferable for this international cooperation agreement to be adopted after the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation. On the other hand, we are against this report as it underlies the double standards governing eu foreign policy with regard to the fight against terrorism in its cooperation agreements with countries such as the UAE. The EU is the second largest arms dealer in the region, weapons that have often ended up in the hands of rebel groups or terrorist groups. Consequently, we consider it hypocritical to support strategic cooperation agreements with the United Arab Emirates in the fight against terrorism if at the same time the EU arms sale is working to strengthen these terrorist groups.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The adoption of a strategic agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates is a good news that I strongly welcome.  Any measure that can improve security, tax fraud and money laundering have my full support in this Parliament.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Europol wants to conclude an agreement with the United Arab Emirates on strategic cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism. The terms of cooperation governed by the strategic agreement provide for exchanges of information that may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, participation in training activities, and the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations. There is no provision in the strategic agreement for the exchange of personal data, which would be unacceptable to us. According to Europol, the United Arab Emirates is increasingly becoming a haven for financial and economic offenders (VAT fraud, money laundering, etc.). So I'm voting for this text.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the decision on the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of a strategic cooperation agreement to combat serious crime and terrorism with the United Arab Emirates, as such collaboration is needed in order to be more effective in preventing and combating serious forms of crime. This strategic agreement involves an exchange of specialised knowledge, reports on the general situation, information on criminal investigation procedures and methods of crime prevention, as well as counselling and support activities in certain criminal investigations. The exchange of personal data is not provided for in the new cooperation framework. I believe that this agreement is a first step in strengthening cooperation in the fight against organised crime, in particular of a financial and economic nature. The United Arab Emirates has become a centre of financial and economic crime in recent years, as the main criminals involved in fraud have sought refuge there. Therefore, in view of the current situation of instability that characterises this area, I believe that there is a need to support and strengthen the actions of the competent authorities and to cooperate with them in the prevention of organised crime, terrorism and in the fight against these phenomena through an exchange of strategic and technical information.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the current Council Decision on Europol, the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, must approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third countries or international organisations. This proposal is aimed at adopting a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates. Europol appears to have a clear operational need to cooperate with the UAE. According to Europol, the UAE is playing a growing role in the fight against organised crime as the country increasingly becomes a hub for economic and financial crime. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against it, firstly because we consider it a waste to approve this strategic cooperation agreement now, because the Council and the European Parliament are currently negotiating a new Regulation for Europol (2013/0091 (COD)), in which the procedure for concluded international agreements, as well as the relevant provisions and guarantees for the protection of the personal data of European citizens, will be significantly amended. We believe that it would be preferable for this international cooperation agreement to be adopted after the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation. On the other hand, we are against this report as it underlies the double standards governing eu foreign policy with regard to the fight against terrorism in its cooperation agreements with countries such as the UAE. The EU is the second largest arms dealer in the region, weapons that have often ended up in the hands of rebel groups or terrorist groups. Consequently, we consider it hypocritical to support strategic cooperation agreements with the United Arab Emirates in the fight against terrorism if at the same time the EU arms sale is working to strengthen these terrorist groups.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'It seems to me appropriate to wait for a new agreement for a new agreement under the new Europol Regulation which gives a stronger role to the European Parliament. That is why I voted against this proposal.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have always been critical of the establishment of Europol since its inception (July 1999). We have always denounced potential stun stuns of individual freedoms through the manipulation of personal data. This organisation, formed outside of any parliamentary or judicial scrutiny, reflects more broadly the democratic deficit of this European Union. It is deeply hypocritical to maintain cooperation agreements with the United Arab Emirates on the fight against terrorism, while the EU is the second largest arms exporter in the region. While journalists, research reports and other studies (including NGOs) show that these same weapons are currently being sold to fundamentalist and terrorist rebel groups, the stated objective of this report is to fight these same groups. The UAE is a leading financial backer of terrorism (with Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Qatar).

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This is an exclusively strategic cooperation. This cooperation can help to combat financial crime. It could also be helpful in its approach to combating terrorism and other serious crime. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to increase the security of European citizens in the face of a new terrorist threat from Daesh supporters, it is necessary to improve the conditions for operational cooperation between Europol and the United Arab Emirates. He is an important player in the Middle East, without which the threats of terrorists cannot be effectively countered. At the same time, the United Arab Emirates is increasingly becoming a target country for the legalisation of income from economic and other organised crime. However, the proposed strategic framework for cooperation between Europol and the UAE does not include the exchange of personal data, which is why I supported this resolution.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on strategic cooperation to combat serious crime and terrorism between the United Arab Emirates and Europol, because I hope that the conclusion of this agreement will help and strengthen the fight against financial fraud and contribute to strengthening international cooperation against crime.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support cooperation with the United Arab Emirates as it would help in the fight against financial fraud, as it is this country that is gradually becoming an important hub for economic and financial crime. Proceeds of crime, such as value added tax fraud and money laundering, have been reinvested in the UAE and key offenders involved in these scams have taken refuge in that country. Such action must be vigorously confronted.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to propose the establishment of a cooperation agreement between Europol and the United Arab Emirates. The information exchanged may include expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyses, information on both criminal investigation processes and crime prevention methods, training activities, advice and support in certain criminal investigations. If, on the one hand, europol does not have the authority or competence to act on behalf of the Member States in this matter, on the other hand, it is considered at least cynical to propose that the European Union - the second largest arms exporter to the Middle East region - and the United Arab Emirates - arms supplier to "terrorist" groups - will be in a position to engage in some serious and consistent "combat" against "serious crime" and "terrorism". This report covers the support this country gives to terrorist groups. By the foregoing, vote against.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity to highlight an issue connected with infrastructure in Scotland, in particular the current closure of Scotland’s most important strategic asset: the Forth Road Bridge. On Thursday, 4 December 2015, Scotland’s key link route, connecting north and south, was closed due to a structural problem: a 20 mm crack in a load-bearing link. It is estimated that this critical piece of Scottish transport infrastructure may reopen on 4 January 2016, weather permitting. Obviously, this key piece of strategic infrastructure is the responsibility of the Nationalist government in Edinburgh, but due to the economic impact this is having on Scottish businesses, commuters and other residents, I would like to call on the Commission for any action and assistance it may bring to Scotland at this critical time.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of Amendment 59 because I believe that hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, is not a technology we should be pursuing at European level. Apart from anything else, we have just concluded a climate deal in Paris which seeks to limit CO2 emissions into the atmosphere. So it seems to me, therefore, nonsensical to want to invest in new technology to extract fossil fuels by fracking. Apart from the public health and the environmental risks such as possible leakage of methane, further production of CO2 and the possible leakage of benzene into watercourses, it seems to me that, from an economic perspective, fracking is no longer promising. Indeed I wonder if it ever was, even in the US. Finally, I want to say that I fully recognise and support that the energy mix for any Member State is primarily a matter for that Member State. But it is my strongly-held view that, from an environmental and public health perspective, and now an economic perspective, fracking should not be part of our energy mix in the EU.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it was just important to me that this report was not militant, that it did not try to ban something that can actually produce positive results in some areas. I do not want to question the importance of scrapping on the environment, in any case there are areas where it can take place without relative impacts on health and the environment. But when it comes to energy security, this is one of those enduring tasks of the European Union, and it is essential to me that the other european union procedures follow or fulfil the five pillars on which energy security must stand. These must be secure energy supplies, I insist that decarbonisation, a competitive economy and affordable energy sources must be an essential part of them. Under these conditions, I will, of course, continue to support the creation of this Energy Union and energy security in the European Union.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, Member States have committed themselves to achieving cooperation on the establishment of a European Energy Union, with the aim of creating an environmentally friendly electricity grid. The debate on this subject, however, sees a clash between different interests and approaches of a predominantly political nature. The different needs and points of view expressed have made the discussion of the dossier rather complex, leading in some cases to procedural forcing and the approximate treatment of certain subjects. To the extreme are those who consider the environmental and health externalities of citizens caused by the use by industries of highly polluting and harmful materials to be negligible. On the other hand, those who consider environmental policy, energy policy and industrial policy inseparable, for example by arguing for the need to use the circular economy more intensively. I voted against because I believe in the need to reduce the costs of industry and its use of polluting materials in the name of environmental protection.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it contains the wickers to transform our energy model according to the agreements reached last weekend at COP21. Since socialist banking, we have managed to lead a majority that has once again spoken out in favour of more ambitious binding climate and energy targets, a 40% reduction in CO2 emissions, 30% renewables and 40% energy efficiency. Following this vote we encourage the Council and the Commission to take a step forward and to commit to defending the objectives proposed by Parliament. Thanks to our input, the report sets the way for ensuring citizens access to energy at affordable prices, boosts self-consumption from renewable energy sources and proposes clear measures to combat energy poverty.  The report also recognises the potential of the renewables sector as a competitive factor and as an engine of innovation and job creation in Europe, a sector that we are committed to defending.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that the future of the European energy market goes through a decentralized and sovereign generation and distribution model, based on public control, energy efficiency and the use of local energy sources (such as renewables, but also traditional fossil resources with adequate technological and financial support). The approach of this proposal, in line with the Commission itself, is very different: it is committed to gigantic infrastructure and the inevitable concentration of European energy production in an oligopoly. This will delve into the use of dangerous technologies such as nuclear and fracking (which I oppose) and a wasteful and predatory energy resource policy (as seen in the requirements regarding TCI and Neighbourhood Policy).

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Referring to the Commission's package on the European Energy Union, Parliament sets out its position on this in this resolution. In principle, I share the view that the EU should strive for a reduced dependence on individual energy suppliers (security of supply) and fundamentally rethink energy efficiency and treat it as an independent energy source. With regard to nuclear energy, I am in favour of a transnational phase-out of nuclear power, so that the end of the nuclear age can actually be achieved. I regret, however, that the text does not take into account an amendment that is important to me, which deals with the negative effects of fracking on the climate and the environment and on public health. That is why I abstained in the final vote. Since I believe that fracking is not a promising technology and, beyond environmental and health risks, investment and development costs are too high, Member States should refrain from exploring and extracting shale gas.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The compromises adopted resulted in a relative weakening of the report on its Liberal component. Regarding its ecological aspect, ambitions have been revised upwards.  On the other hand, the ITRE committee voted to strengthen the provisions on the TTIP as well as on the anti-Russian component. A denunciation of the russian-German Nord Stream pipeline project was added.  However, a lively debate is not about to be closed between the Greens and EFDD, on the one hand, EPP and ECR, on the other, on two issues. The substance of the disagreement is shale gas and nuclear.  I voted against, because of the end of regulated tariffs, the creation of an artificial market that will deprive us of long-term contracts, indispensable industrial policy instruments, also because of the umpteenth attacks on Russia to promote the importation of Qatari and American LNG.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against a fundamentally flawed report. I wish to draw attention to the fact that my vote to support an EFDD amendment on nuclear energy was because I oppose EU funding for such activities, and should not be taken in any way as opposition to nuclear power as part of a wider energy basket for those Member States which choose to use it.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it aims to reduce the European Union's dependence on energy imports, by integrating their energy markets, by improving security of supply, by making the best use of existing and renewable sources.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text as opposed to our partnership with Russia as it is in favour of the disastrous Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP, ex-TAFTA). This is indeed a harmful text which intends to give the EU more and more powers, even as this machine that has become more and more mad is fighting more and more clearly against the vital interests of the peoples of the Old Continent.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. At a time when COP 21 has led to ambitious and necessary targets, I supported this resolution in which Parliament reaffirms its commitment to the 2030 climate and energy targets of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 40%, increasing the share of renewable energy in the European energy mix to 27% and increasing energy efficiency by 30%. Parliament also stresses that the Energy Union should adopt a comprehensive approach focused on various aspects such as achieving a fully integrated internal energy market, security of supply, better use of EU energy resources, limiting energy demand, reducing greenhouse gas emissions mainly through renewable energy sources and an EU-wide organised carbon market , as well as research and innovation in the energy sector. It also stresses the obvious fact that citizens should be at the heart of the Energy Union and benefit from safe, sustainable and affordable energy and calls for being associated with all the work of the Energy Union.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. The Energy Union is without a doubt the most important policy package of this legislature.  All the vital policy areas come together here: economy, energy, environment, climate, employment, security.  We need to make major strides in legislation in the coming year to increase the share of renewable energy, reduce energy consumption through greater energy efficiency, and ensure security of gas supply.  In 2016, we also need to take important steps to develop a balanced ETS system, which will allow us to further reduce CO2 emissions, but also pay sufficient attention to the competitiveness of our energy-intensive companies.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against climate change, which was the subject of the recent UN Paris conference, is one of the key issues for the foreseeable future. The European Union's action can only be directed towards strengthening international choices, towards an energy transaction based on the progressive abandonment of fossil fuels. My vote in favour of the Gróbarczyk report is based on the conviction that energy policy choices are crucial to supporting the EU's long-term competitiveness and reducing its energy dependence on exporting countries. The aim must be a new energy model for Europe, based on reduced demand, energy efficiency and renewable energies. We must strive for a genuine EU energy foreign policy, focusing on the transparency of future agreements with third countries and security of supply. The stability of the new energy system will necessarily depend on the involvement of businesses and citizens, including through the creation of new investment opportunities in the energy sector.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the Gróbarczyk report because we do not share the European Commission's vision of the Energy Union. Energy should not be the subject of financial benefits but should be regarded as a common good and the cornerstone of the fight against climate change. There are no proposals in this report to solve the problem of energy poverty affecting four million people in the Spanish State. The report is highlighted by its clear support for nuclear energy, which seriously jeopardizes our safety and our environment. In addition, it leaves the door open to hydraulic fracturing.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the European Energy Union, which is essential. Above all, I would like to highlight the section which refers to the public's concern about hydraulic fracturing and the consequences that this technique can have on climate, the environment and public health, so this hydraulic fracturing activity must comply with the strictest standards in these areas. In addition, Member States intending to use it must comply with the 2014 Commission Recommendation on minimum principles for the exploration and production of hydrocarbons using high-volume hydraulic fracturing.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I strongly opposed this text, which carries within it one of the flagship projects of the Juncker Commission, namely a European Energy Union, that is, the killing of the sovereign competence of the Member States to make strategic choices for their nation on their energy mix, thereby undermining their levers of influence on the geopolitical scene. Of course, the report, written by a rather sovereignist ECR Member of Parliament, attempts to modulate the Commission's ambitions, notably by not resuming its idea of transforming the Energy Regulators Cooperation Agency into an integrated agency with the power to injunction and sanction. However, in addition to the fact that the report is very favourable to the most polluting companies - including the exploitation of shale gas and oil, the text is also a new charge against Russia, at a time when it is an indispensable and strategic ally in the fight against Islamist terrorism. Finally, it is a text that clearly announces the proposal of this Energy Union to American interests, since it calls for this area to be integrated into the TTIP, already the main threat to the interests and well-being of the European peoples.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is very partisan and calls on the Member States to cede their energy sovereignty in favour of a European centralism which has not only always proved inefficient, but which has always been very disadvantageous to our territories and our citizens. For all these reasons, I voted against.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the report. Firstly, this is an expansion of the EU and in some environmental cases it may be okay, but the EU Energy Union aims to squeeze electricity prices, create an internal market and shift skills from member states to the EU. In addition, it advocates the extraction of shale gas and the continued subsidies of nuclear power. I will never support initiatives that only look to the market without highlighting the need for energy efficiency and renewable energy.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it contains the wickers to transform our energy model according to the agreements reached last weekend at COP21. Since socialist banking, we have managed to lead a majority that has once again spoken out in favour of more ambitious binding climate and energy targets, a 40% reduction in CO2 emissions, 30% renewables and 40% energy efficiency. Following this vote we encourage the Council and the Commission to take a step forward and to commit to defending the objectives proposed by Parliament. Thanks to our input, the report sets the way for ensuring citizens access to energy at affordable prices, boosts self-consumption from renewable energy sources and proposes clear measures to combat energy poverty.  The report also recognises the potential of the renewables sector as a competitive factor and as an engine of innovation and job creation in Europe, a sector that we are committed to defending.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union report provides a balanced summary of the steps that could bring Europe closer to a European energy policy for consumers.  The report confirms that the aim of European energy policy is to strengthen security of supply and to increase energy efficiency at an affordable price. This requires, where necessary, the building of new infrastructure, further unifying the market and forcing the application of legislation. The report anticipates that the completion of the Energy Union can increase Europe's competitiveness on the international stage and create new jobs, for example through technological research development, innovation promotion and investment in energy efficiency. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed extremely comprehensive report on the transition to a European Energy Union, and I would also like to express my congratulations to the rapporteur and the Commissioner for his remarkable achievement in achieving the environmental objectives in the negotiations on the Paris climate agreement. I consider it important that part of the report, which talks about greater use of renewable energy sources in South-East Europe, but also that countries themselves have a duty to provide their own energy mixes, thus making it easier to avoid energy poverty. In practice, this means that people cannot pay for electricity because of low incomes, high energy prices or low quality buildings.  It is therefore the task of the states to strike the right balance between the different sources of energy, so that final electricity prices can still be sustainable for households and industrial consumers. Appropriate regulation can also help to reduce the price of energy, at European level in the form of ACER, based in Ljubljana, Slovenia. The latter must provide adequate resources for effective work that brings great benefits for European citizens.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the light of recent international developments and the objectives agreed in Paris during COP21, the transition to an Energy Union based on security of energy supply, on an increasingly integrated and sustainable energy market, remains one of the European Union's highest priorities. I very much welcome the report voted on today, which represents an important step towards the construction of an increasingly secure and resilient European energy system, outlined on the basis of ambitious objectives aimed at the fundamental transition to a new energy model, based on the progressive decarbonisation of the economy.  In line with the socio-economic and environmental challenges facing us, increasing internal energy integration, accompanied by increasing efficiency in the use of resources, is the fundamental means of reducing the Union's excessive dependence on supply from third countries, while also placing ourselves in line with the principle of diversification of energy sources, which is also of primary importance for ensuring our security and competitiveness in this area. On the other hand, much remains to be done and we must act consistently; That is why I can only endorse the concern expressed by this Parliament about the doubling of Nordstream, which operates in the opposite direction to these principles.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. In my work on the Consumer Protection Board, I am committed to as much energy efficiency as I can to improve sustainability, but also to create additional benefits for consumers. The ability to choose an energy operator and the ability to review the state of energy resources are a key priority in my Delivering Energy to Consumers report.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. In view of the anti-Russian nature of this document (Russia is called an "unreliable partner", it supports the pipeline projects bypassing Russia and proposes to ban Gazprom from entering the distribution market in Europe) and its very pro-American positioning (it calls for the inclusion of energy in the PTCI negotiations), I consider that this text is totally at odds with my geopolitical orientations. In addition, it pushes for the creation of a liberalized energy market by advocating the removal of regulated tariffs from monopolies and long-term contracts in favour of highly speculative market prices, which I consider harmful. For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The development of renewable energy sources is crucial to making the EU's energy independence achievable. At present, the Union and its Member States import more than half of all the energy they consume: dependence on imports is excessive for crude oil (over 90%), natural gas (66%) and coal (72%). In 2013 the total turnover of imports was more than 400 billion euros, of which about 40% was used for heating and maintenance of buildings (of private citizens, industrial and public). This consumption accounts for 60% of EU gas imports. Reducing the Union's energy demand and developing renewable energies are essential elements in achieving energy independence and in meeting the targets set with COP21 in Paris.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report deals with the establishment of the Energy Union, desired by the European Commission, which is chaired by Jean-Claude Juncker. The text is in stark contrast to the Energy Union's strategic framework of 25 February 2015 on two points. Firstly, it reminds us that the choice of the energy mix is the responsibility of the Member States and not of the Commission. Secondly, the rapporteur calls for fossil fuels to be subsidised as well. However, we cannot endorse proposals to include energy in the transatlantic free trade treaty. Moreover, the rapporteur is clearly in favour of the exploitation of shale gas and oil, which is nevertheless harmful to the environment. Finally, the report points out that Russia is not a sufficiently reliable partner and that Gazprom should therefore be denied access to the distribution market in Europe and support pipeline and pipeline projects to bypass Russia. However, we absolutely do not share the Atlanticist line of this report. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report entitled 'Towards a European Energy Union' raises the question of the global challenges facing the European Union's energy system and stresses the need to develop a strategy aimed at enhancing energy security, sustainability and accessibility. Thus, the achievement of these objectives is achieved in view of ensuring security of energy supply and reducing emissions, especially since the EU's energy targets by 2030 include a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from 1990 levels. Furthermore, other dimensions to be achieved in order to build a safe and sustainable energy system aim to complete a fully integrated internal energy market at EU level, reduce energy consumption, which will lead to a reduction in energy imports and pollution and, last but not least, to continue research and innovation projects. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I believe that a joint effort by all Member States is needed to make energy safe, sustainable and accessible to the citizens of the Union.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The aim of the Energy Union is in fact to deprive the Member States of their last remaining strategic sovereignty: that of being able to determine the energy mix freely, as laid down in Article 194 TFEI. Measures such as a collective bargaining mechanism, the unification of key contractual clauses, or ex-ante and ex-post interventions by the Commission (in practice: a veto power) on intergovernmental agreements with third countries are an open violation of Article 194 itself.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 THE EP Resolution of 5 February 2014 calls for the adoption of three binding targets: a 40 % energy efficiency target, a renewable energy target of at least 30% and a target for reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40% compared to 1990. The latter underpins the development of the decarbonisation dimension of the Energy Union and is the most ambitious contribution to international climate change negotiations aimed at concluding a binding agreement on climate change at THE UNNUSC's COP 21, Paris, December 2015. I support a multidimensional approach in the 2030 climate and energy policy framework, based on mutually reinforcing, coordinated and coherent targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, renewable energy sources and energy efficiency. I consider crucial the role of a transparent, open, robust and inclusive system of governance for 2030, ensuring the implementation of the objectives in a transparent and democratic manner, guaranteeing the regular exchange of information, the submission of reports and ensuring the full participation of the EP through the ordinary legislative procedure.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on a European Energy Union. Global challenges such as fluctuating energy prices exacerbated by our dependence on certain countries and global warming will not be sufficiently addressed in isolated national policies. We need an efficient and interconnected European energy sector.  A European Energy Union will enable a more competitive energy sector to offer European citizens a service tailored to their needs. By cooperating in this area, we will be able to reduce our dependence on third-party energy-producing countries. It is also by investing in the search for new energies that we will achieve this goal.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on progress towards a European Energy Union 2015/2113 (INI), as I consider the European Energy Union to be the next institutional and political challenge. Indeed, the European Union is being strengthened by the conclusion of the historic Conference Agreement (COP 21) on climate change, but the cost of non-Europe and the current existence of economic, regulatory and administrative barriers to energy consumption are well known, which do not protect and indeed exacerbate energy poverty. I therefore agree with what is stated in the report and stress the importance of achieving the right balance of the objectives set out, as well as a resilient and secure ecosystem, with the emphasis on the key role of the issues: emissions trading (ETS); the necessary introduction of an emissions test under real driving conditions; the decarbonisation of the transport, sea and land aviation sector, which are still excluded from binding commitments; the reintroduction of waste into the economy as a raw material for a real circular economy.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The European Commission is determined to revise the ETS and the allowance system in order to distribute the available allowances in a more efficient way. We in UKIP are against this proposal as we reject a revision of the damaging EU ETS system. We believe that the EU Commission should recognise that the entire EU energy project has failed, causing higher energy prices in all Member States. It has caused job losses, plant closures and a massive outflow of industry and investment outside the EU.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, the content of which I believe reflects a good balance between the need to create a single energy market based on cleaner and cheaper energy, and the need to let Member States control and guide their nuclear policies.  In view of the union's current energy fragmentation, which is holding back its competitiveness and independence, I note in particular two points of this report: the 10% interconnection target for European electricity and the categorical rejection of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline project, which, by creating a certain energy dependency on Russia, would be at odds with the European strategy of diversifying sources of supply. Finally, this report proposes a reasonable compromise on shale gas, aimed at establishing sufficient guarantees in terms of compliance with environmental standards when producing this type of hydrocarbon. While diversification of sources of supply is to be a horizon, strong environmental and public health safeguards must be maintained.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The energy market should be a full-fledged component of the EU internal market, fully functioning, competitive and secure. Current fragmentation of national energy markets creates obstacles for more competitiveness and raises concerns over energy security in Europe. For that reason I voted in favour of this report. On the other hand, I cannot agree with raising the energy efficiency targets high above the level agreed on the Member States level which is, in my opinion, a well-balanced and realistic compromise.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support and agree with the content of the report on the creation of a European Energy Union. We believe in the need to strengthen Euro-Mediterranean cooperation on gas, electricity, energy efficiency and renewable energy sources and we call on the Commission to speed up the creation of the Euro-Mediterranean gas platform. We believe that the backbone of the future Energy Union must be a fully functioning, interconnected internal energy market to provide safe, protected, fairly distributed, socially and environmentally responsible, efficient, competitive, affordable and sustainable energy in fully functional, secure and resilient transmission networks. Today, the Eastern Mediterranean is an important prospect for the EU in the energy sector. The discovery of natural gas deposits in the region and the creation of a strong energy alliance between Cyprus, Israel, Greece and Egypt must be exploited directly by the EU. The EU has before it an important challenge-perspective and a possibility offered by the Eastern Mediterranean. It is up to the EU to make immediate use of the Eastern Mediterranean because that is the only way Europe will start to implement the vision of the European Energy Union and energy dependence.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the road to a European Energy Union is a debate of particular importance for all Member States. Although it contains positive elements in terms of sources and the energy production process, it does not treat the issue of energy as an area that concerns society as a whole. On the other hand, the attempt to impose central decisions leads to the weakening of the voice of states and thus to the strengthening of powerful companies that will seek to impose their interests. That's why he thinks I'm the opposite, and I've decided to abstain.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The draft report deals with different dimensions of the European energy strategy. Particular attention is paid to aspects relating to energy security, such as the need to diversify energy sources and supply routes, and to the initiatives necessary to achieve the completion of the internal energy market.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on what the EU energy project should be between now and the next few decades. The report mentions the Commission's draft which I wholely agree with in aiming for 'A framework strategy for a resilient energy Union'. The common objective of the union as a whole must be, in my view, to develop energy strategies in the light of the long-term objective of achieving a reduction in greenhouse gases of 80-95% by 2050, and before the 40% reduction by 2030. I believe that the European basis on these issues must be energy security, and each Member State, on the basis of its potential, the environment, knowledge and economic costs and needs, must commit itself to achieving the objectives. I also support the report in urging the Commission to facilitate the effective use of current EU funding schemes in this area.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report reacts to the Commission’s communication on a European Energy Union. The draft report addresses several dimensions of the strategy. Particular emphasis is put on aspects relating to energy security, such as the need to diversify energy sources and supply routes. It also refers to initiatives necessary to accomplish the completion of the internal energy market.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. European energy policy should ensure the functioning of the energy market, security of energy supply, promote energy efficiency and energy savings, and develop renewable energies and promote the interconnection of energy networks. The existence of 28 energy hangers, the high level of total energy imports (53%), in particular oil and natural gas, and the dependence of some states on a single supplier put the EU in a situation of vulnerability and supply breakdowns in the face of political and trade divergences. I support the Gróbarczyk Report as it urgently considers the creation of a genuine resilient Energy Union with a future-oriented climate change policy, based on the transition to an efficient sustainable energy system, with smart and interconnected infrastructures, renewable energy and better use of Europe's energy resources.  Particular attention should be paid to the decarbonisation of our economy and the setting of binding climate and energy targets by 2030, as well as a strong focus on research and innovation in order to take the lead in energy technologies. To put citizens at the heart of the energy union is to give them safe, sustainable and affordable energy sources!

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted for this report because I am in favour of creating a sustainable energy environment, as far as energy security is concerned, naturally seeking to reduce prices, and in order to achieve the climate objectives. I am of the opinion that the Energy Union must become an engine of growth and investment, especially for the revision of the energy label, because we must give consumers a clear, precise idea of what information and savings for citizens will actually be.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Energy Union can ensure that Europe has secure, affordable and climate-friendly energy. In this report particular emphasis is put on aspects relating to energy security, such as the need to diversify energy sources and supply routes. It also refers to initiatives necessary to accomplish the completion of the internal energy market, which became of core importance with regard to the outcomes of the Paris Agreement on climate change. This agreement demonstrates a new global cooperation on climate change with all countries agreeing to progressively ramp up ambition to decarbonise and build climate resilience and gives clarity on direction of travel in the global energy transition. The Energy Union can serve as an important basis to reach these goals, and thus I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Gróbarczyk report frames the Juncker Commission's macro-initiative for an energy union. The report sets out diametrically opposed views that see on the one hand the forces that deny climate change, the generation with fossil fuels, even highly polluting (coal) and unconventional (shale gas, oil from tar sands), support the large mining and generation industry. On the other extreme are those who consider energy policy inseparable from the fight against climate change, who aim to reduce the impact of energy costs through the circular economy, who see renewable energies as the main objective for the energy transition, who are opposed to nuclear fission and who favour energy efficiency as their primary source, reduced demand, decentralised production and self-consumption. The rapporteur has not hesitated to use procedural instruments (for example, a series of linked splits which have completely reversed the meaning of one of our amendments, on nuclear energy) which are very close to impropriety, and which have been experienced with deep bitterness by various political groups. In view of the somewhat controversial report, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that the future of the European energy market goes through a decentralized and sovereign generation and distribution model, based on public control, energy efficiency and the use of local energy sources (such as renewables, but also traditional fossil resources with adequate technological and financial support). The approach of this proposal, in line with the Commission itself, is very different: it is committed to gigantic infrastructure and the inevitable concentration of European energy production in an oligopoly. This will delve into the use of dangerous technologies such as nuclear and fracking (which I oppose) and a wasteful and predatory energy resource policy (as seen in the requirements regarding TCI and Neighbourhood Policy).

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Energy Union will have many economic and sustainability benefits across the EU. As far as energy security is concerned, it will make the EU less dependent on external sources and will be able to make energy agreements more transparent; It will also help create new jobs, make European industries, transport systems and the construction sector more sustainable and decarbonised. Finally, it will reduce energy costs for households. In the resolution, which I voted in favour of, the European Parliament supports the Commission in taking measures to achieve the Energy Union through adequate investment in strategic infrastructure and in promoting innovation and modernisation; the strengthening of regional cooperation and, in particular, Mediterranean cooperation; the promotion and dissemination of best practices at local level across the EU and greater policy coordination.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's report was made to the European Commission's 'Towards a European Energy Union'. Parliament's report focuses on the security of energy supply, including the diversification of energy sources and energy supply routes.  An important point in the development towards the Energy Union is the coordination of the process with forward-looking climate policy, an issue which was dealt with more closely by the Committee on the Environment in the form of an opinion. I agree with parliament's wording that the main pillars of the Energy Union are energy efficiency, renewable energy, the most efficient use of European energy sources and smart infrastructure. Bearing in mind the needs of Europe's citizens and businesses, it will be necessary to establish a regulatory framework that contributes to economic growth and job creation, while at the same time displaying more and more cost-effective and environmentally friendly measures.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the Parliament's response to the Commission's Energy Union strategy, one of the key political priorities of the Juncker Commission. The strategy and Parliament's report is divided in to the five key dimensions of energy security, a fully-integrated internal energy market, energy efficiency, decarbonisation of the economy and research, innovation and competitiveness. I have been heavily involved in the legislative process devising the Energy Union and as I subscribe to the main tenants behind the drive (energy security, access to sustainable energy, addressing energy poverty amongst others) I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support this report as it stands, it proposes weakening the role of national governments in their own energy management, for example requiring the Commission to participate in all national negotiations with non-EU countries on energy deals. There is no need for Commission participation in these negotiations. Additionally, the call for binding national targets on renewables and energy efficiency would prevent individual countries from reducing emissions in a way that reflects their own energy needs. What countries in Europe need are fully liberalised energy markets that will bring down the high energy prices that consumers and businesses are having to live with. This report is not the answer to those problems and I so I voted against it.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Commission needs to step up its research efforts on the better use of Europe's energy resources and to mitigate the environmental impact, with a view to sustainable economic growth, job creation, industrial competitiveness and, in particular, the achievement of the EU's long-term climate and energy objectives.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 18 April 1951, the Treaty of Paris was signed, establishing one of the founding pillars of the European Community and the future Union, the ECSC, and establishing for the first time in history a shared management of coal and steel resources. Today, more than 60 years later, in a changed context, there is still a need to complete an energy Union as well. I am convinced that the report adopted is an important step towards a European Energy Union because it defines ambitious measures to achieve greater energy savings and efficiency, the development of renewable energies, and above all it recalls the need for strategic coordination at European level for the diversification of energy sources and their supply routes. In particular, on this last point, I endorse the position expressed in the text and express my concern at the proposal to double the capacity of the Nordstream gas pipeline: a unilateral decision that could have detrimental effects on the Union's energy security. The achievement of a single, harmonious and safer European energy area must go through shared and coordinated energy choices and policies at European level. Only in this way will it be possible to guarantee a future of greater energy stability and independence for European citizens.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing.
