This initiative report presents the European Parliament's recommendations to build an efficient Energy Union, capable of providing citizens and businesses with sufficient energy at a competitive price. This report reacts to the Commission's communication last February on the Energy Union. It stresses the importance of diversifying energy sources and supply routes. While recalling the competence of Member States on the energy mix, the European Parliament stresses the need to complete the implementation of the internal energy market, as well as the measures necessary to achieve this objective.  The introduction of a voluntary system for the purchase of energy together is one of the flagship proposals aimed at reducing the energy bill of Europeans. Today, for example, we buy our gas two or three times more expensive than our major economic partners, starting with the United States and China.  Considering that this report recalls the European Parliament's ambition in energy matters and that it provides concrete solutions to strengthen European competitiveness, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission is determined to revise the ETS and the allowance system in order to distribute the available allowances in a more efficient way. We in UKIP are against this proposal as we reject a revision of the damaging EU ETS system. We believe that the EU Commission should recognise that the entire EU energy project has failed, causing higher energy prices in all Member States. It has caused job losses, plant closures and a massive outflow of industry and investment outside the EU.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Energy Union because it needs to be accelerated. Indeed, I note that the electricity and gas markets are still not functioning optimally. Lack of interconnections, lack of regional cooperation and cross-border trade: the internal market needs to be rapidly strengthened!  At the same time, more and more renewable energy sources are coming into the grids, making the organization more complex. It is therefore urgent to respond to the complexity of energy management with a real European strategy by focusing on the so-called "smart" management of networks. The Juncker Energy Plan has financed many projects and this must continue, especially for heating and cooling, which are the main energy consumption point in the European Union.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union report provides a balanced summary of the steps that could bring Europe closer to a European energy policy for consumers. The report confirms that the aim of European energy policy is to strengthen security of supply and to increase energy efficiency at an affordable price. This requires, where necessary, the building of new infrastructure, further unifying the market and forcing the application of legislation. The report anticipates that the completion of the Energy Union can increase Europe's competitiveness on the international stage and create new jobs, for example through technological research development, innovation promotion and investment in energy efficiency. As a member of the Hungarian delegation from the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I agree with a number of the proposals contained in this report, including those stressing the importance of the role of our Assembly on all the legislative proposals of the Energy Union package, the association of industries in the development of the energy production chain of tomorrow, the strengthening of Euro-Mediterranean cooperation on gas, electric energy and European energy networks. Furthermore, I reiterate my commitment to research and innovation issues, which are central to ensuring security of supply and combating the greenhouse effect.  With regard to fracking technologies, I would remind you that they are not, as carbon energy, a sector of the future. I advocate the abrupt non-questioning of nuclear power in order to move towards a sustainable energy mix and not to call into question important balances in terms of security. Finally, I recall the need to support the ITER research programme.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Europe imports 53% of the energy it consumes. It costs him more than a billion euros a day. I supported this report recommending a number of measures that will help reduce the cost of energy bills, decarbonise the European economy and reduce Europe's dependence on imported fossil fuels. This is a major project for the European Union.  The Energy Union must provide EU citizens with safe, sustainable and affordable energy. Building it will certainly require concerted efforts on the part of Member States to reduce their dependence on energy imports, integrating their energy markets, improving security of supply, making the best use of existing and renewable sources and moderating demand, but it is essential to move beyond this framework where 28 regulations and as many energy packages coexist in order to be more efficient and secure the EU's energy future.  My group has played an important role in ensuring the efficiency of energy and renewable energy in the future European energy package. We have laid the groundwork for a much more comprehensive and ambitious approach to the integration of energy systems and solutions.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome the opportunity to address what is a very important issue for consumers and businesses across Europe. Making better connections in terms of energy supply and innovative storage solutions holds inherent benefits for a higher quality of life and economic prosperity within societies across the Member States.  There are, however, several factors that I feel we should keep in mind at this time. First of all, I would caution against an expansion of energy resources to Eastern Europe and our external neighbours before proper attention has been given to solidifying our own market. For instance, in my own constituency, we see very much a rural-urban divide. There are agri-food businesses based in the west of the province that stand to bring growth to the local economy, however are not able to access affordable energy or connect to the grid for electricity or wind power. The EU has a role to play in this sense, and I would urge the institutions to continue to support the PCIs that have been selected in the United Kingdom and Northern Ireland to help meet these challenges.

name: Ian Duncan and Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. – Conservatives welcome much of the ambition behind the Energy Union given the current fragmented nature of energy policy at the EU level. It must help drive the completion of the internal energy market – without fully liberalised markets our energy supplies will be less secure and more expensive.  Conservatives, however, voted against the report as it did not reflect the Council’s agreement on the 2030 climate and energy strategy from October 2014 – which agreed on a requirement for a 40% cut in emissions, without binding national renewable and efficiency targets. We believe that this technology neutral framework will allow the UK reach its emission reduction goals in a way that is cost effective and tailored to our own specific needs.  Furthermore we are concerned at calls within the report for Member States to negotiate intergovernmental energy deals jointly and/or mandate the Commission to participate in all Member State negotiations with third countries on such agreements. While we have sympathy with countries that are unduly vulnerable to a single supplier over long-term energy contracts, we do not support a one-size-fits-all approach that provides the European Commission with a role that is neither needed nor requested by all Member States.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I can't afford to support the report. There are an awful lot of things in it that, to put it mildly, bother me. There is constant talk of renewable sourcing and energy efficiency, but nowhere is there any mention of PPS, which is proven clean and as cheap as possible. We do not comment on this energy and try to reject it as one possible step towards stopping dependence on one country or another when it comes to energy dependency. And here in this document remains open the question of fracking. This is a method of extracting fossils, which already almost 100% proven to be harmful and expensive. It should therefore not be allowed within the Community. The report speaks only of Nord Stream, it is already quite clear that Turkish Stream will not take place, is it not time to talk again about building South Stream, but, of course, by our requirements.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against the report because we believe that it fails to respond and provide solutions to the Union's major energy problem, while at the same time not avoiding anchorages and aggressive rhetoric towards third countries.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union report provides a balanced summary of the steps that could bring Europe closer to a European energy policy for consumers.  The report confirms that the aim of European energy policy is to strengthen security of supply and to increase energy efficiency at an affordable price. This requires, where necessary, the building of new infrastructure, further unifying the market and forcing the application of legislation. The report anticipates that the completion of the Energy Union can increase Europe's competitiveness on the international stage and create new jobs, for example through technological research development, innovation promotion and investment in energy efficiency. As a member of the Hungarian delegation from the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. This report follows on from the Saudargas report, which was dealt with in the first half of 2015, which was a failure. The Gróbarczyk report focuses on the Commission communication COM(2015)0080 and is part of the Juncker strategy for an energy union entitled 'A framework strategy for a resilient Energy Union, accompanied by a forward-looking climate change policy'. The amendments to the text of the report, as presented, contain a number of strongly conflicting positions, ranging from financial support for nuclear power and non-conventional energies – shale gas – to the lack of a position on decarbonisation, to the circular economy, which has decarbonisation and renewable energy as objectives for a genuine energy transition. Unfortunately, it has not been possible to influence the text in such a way that funding for nuclear power and non-conventional energy can be limited or cancelled. Nor has it been possible to ensure that the European Parliament takes a clear stand in favour of a gradual decarbonisation of our economy. I voted against.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on the original text of paragraph 134 because I understand that the text is not clear and induces a false answer, especially for those who, like me, understand that shale gas extraction should be halted in favor of cleaner alternative energy sources. Amendment 80 also abstained because the text is not clear as to its objectives. I say, however, my total opposition to the nuclear option.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "This report is an important position of the European Parliament, calling, inter alia, for energy diversification, completion of the internal energy market, improvement of energy efficiency and energy savings, increased use of renewable energy sources, more active use of European energy resources, better interconnections between Member States, and renovation of infrastructure networks and buildings. Access to safe and environmentally friendly energy is one of the crucial issues for europe for the future. We need an energy system that favours renewable energy and makes europe less dependent on imports from uncertain partners.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it excludes Russia as a strategic energy supplier to European countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The so-called "European Energy Union" is a custom-made project of the major European monopolies in the sector, and it is certainly not disproportionate to say that documents such as this report are, in essence, its specifications. The energy sector is liberalised and privatised in the various Member States and then says that energy must be accessible to all and that energy poverty must be combated. Will there be greater contradiction? The liberalisation of this sector, within the framework of the single market, has served as the establishment of transnational private monopolies that colonise markets by accumulating prodigious profits, while energy prices for consumers and micro, small and medium-sized enterprises reach unaffordable values. The disparity in energy access and prices is growing. Only a public energy sector, in ownership and management, can guarantee energy prices accessible to the population and maintain sovereignty in the definition of national energy strategies. The appropriate response to improving energy efficiency, diversification of sources, progress in renewables, combating energy poverty, among other challenges, require public, democratic, energy sector, energy production and distribution planning and control. Something that this report cannot and does not want to reflect. Contrary. We voted against it.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The energy security of the European Union and its Member States is a strategic policy. However, energy security goes hand in hand with reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The Energy Union Framework Strategy on Climate Change reflects the 5 pillars of the Energy Union and the policies implemented under these pillars must contribute to ensuring security of energy supply, decarbonisation, long-term sustainability of the economy and ensuring affordable and competitive energy prices. It must also take an uncompromising approach in areas such as achieving a fully integrated internal energy market and further making the best possible use of energy resources, followed by reducing greenhouse gas emissions, reducing energy demand, as well as expanding renewable energy sources. Support for research and innovation in this area is also essential in order to achieve leadership in energy technologies.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report that would like to create the Energy Union. In short, the aim is in fact to deprive the Member States of their last remaining strategic sovereignty, namely that of being able to determine the energy mix freely. The implications of this act are obvious and highly dangerous.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because it fails to respond and provide solutions to the major energy problem facing the Union and because it does not avoid anchorages and aggressive rhetoric towards third countries.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as a one-size fits all approach to energy will not work. I welcome the key objectives of energy security and competitiveness. However, the EU should seek a flexible approach and allow Member States to decide on their own energy mix. Parliament should seek to fully liberalise the energy market and not to bind Member States in restrictive targets.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D)
text: Writing. The report on a European Energy Union has many positive aspects that we welcome. The adoption of the amendments on binding energy and climate targets for 2030 and the rejection of any financial support for nuclear energy by EU funds is particularly pleasing. Unfortunately, the report not only lacked a clear rejection of the use of nuclear energy, but in some places there was even talk of the development of nuclear energy. As the SPÖ EU delegation aims to phase out nuclear power in Europe in both the medium and long term, we were therefore unable to support the report and voted against it in the final vote.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The two initiative reports ‘Towards a European Energy Union’ and ‘Achieving 10% electricity interconnection’ present important elements for creating a more secure, sustainable and competitive energy market. Creating a fund for modernisation, additional measures to protect consumers, and supporting regional cooperation projects between the operators of distribution networks for electricity and gas are important goals. Given the current context regarding our dependence on energy from external factors, achieving a fully integrated internal market, security of supply, energy efficiency and optimal use of the energy resources of the European Union, as well as ensuring support for research and innovation would maximise the benefits for new industries and for new technologies, while ensuring protection and support for labour and for traditional industries.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union report provides a balanced summary of the steps that could bring Europe closer to a European energy policy for consumers.  The report confirms that the aim of European energy policy is to strengthen security of supply and to increase energy efficiency at an affordable price. This requires, where necessary, the building of new infrastructure, further unifying the market and forcing the application of legislation. The report anticipates that the completion of the Energy Union can increase Europe's competitiveness on the international stage and create new jobs, for example through technological research development, innovation promotion and investment in energy efficiency. As a member of the Hungarian delegation from the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I believe it is essential to ensure the functioning of the energy market and the security of energy supply, as well as to promote energy efficiency, energy savings and advances in renewable energy, and to promote the interconnection of energy networks, which are of particular relevance to the Iberian Peninsula. Similarly, it is of particular importance to continue the fight against climate change, significantly reducing emissions of polluting gases, ensuring the energy supply of EU Member States and ensuring an energy mix that allows energy prices that make the European economy globally competitive.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it contains the wickers to transform our energy model according to the agreements reached last weekend at COP21. Since socialist banking, we have managed to lead a majority that has once again spoken out in favour of more ambitious binding climate and energy targets, a 40% reduction in CO2 emissions, 30% renewables and 40% energy efficiency. Following this vote we encourage the Council and the Commission to take a step forward and to commit to defending the objectives proposed by Parliament. Thanks to our input, the report sets the way for ensuring citizens access to energy at affordable prices, boosts self-consumption from renewable energy sources and proposes clear measures to combat energy poverty.  The report also recognises the potential of the renewables sector as a competitive factor and as an engine of innovation and job creation in Europe, a sector that we are committed to defending.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. In order to be strong and secure, the European Union must first of all be free. Freeing itself from any dependence, especially if it is labile or unreliable, on gas and energy supplies and making the Member States and the Union itself independent of the dangerous risks of interruptions of supply for political purposes is a priority to which Europe must respond immediately. This is just one of the reasons that led me to appreciate with great impetus the excellent work carried out by my colleague Flavio Zanonato, shadow rapporteur for the S&D Group in the report "on progress towards a European Energy Union" which I support favorably, while reserving the right to reject the pro-nuclear notes for consolidated and deep personal convictions. Security, integration of the European energy market, decarbonisation, research and competitiveness, I believe are ambitious but indispensable objectives for responsible, sustainable, free and forward-looking growth in Europe.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on progress towards a European Energy Union as European energy security defends both the security of Europe and the sovereignty of its countries and makes important improvements in efficiency. Also considering that the EU is heavily dependent on energy imports from Russia, a highly reliable partner that uses its energy sources as a political weapon, we must strongly create a system that protects European energy industries from unfair imports from third countries and develops a single market to reduce overall costs and improve the competitiveness of the EU economy. Furthermore, I fully shared the vision of a system for the exchange of energy sources between the European Union and the United States, following developments and good research, with the aim of creating a global renewable energy sharing network. Therefore, it is only by favouring more financial resources for the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER) that we can think of fulfilling, correctly, the vision of concrete unity on which the European Union is founded among all the Member States.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the road to a European Energy Union, as I consider the project to be a very important one if we are to guarantee our citizens a secure, affordable, independent and sustainable energy supply in the long term. Europe has not done its homework here, partly because of national blockades. I also stress that the path to a common energy policy can only work on a road that abandons carbon-rich energy production and nuclear energy and waits for fracking to be properly ruled out. No country should be forced into fracking.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The own-initiative directive, on which Mr Marek Gróbarczyk was the rapporteur, is a balanced proposal. This is an attempt to show the Commission and the Council the best compromise without succumbing to the unreal 'ambitions' of 'defending' the climate. I fully support it, hoping that it will form the basis for the drafting of legislative directives.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The Energy Union ensures that Europe continues to play a leading international role in competing with other countries. At the same time, it will make a decisive contribution to the achievement of the climate targets. Citizens will also benefit from a European energy market as electricity prices fall.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I strongly believe that the Energy Union, if properly implemented, will ensure the energy transition to a clean, renewable future, while putting citizens centre-stage and ensuring a secure, stable and affordable energy system.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. Mr Grobarczyk's report is somewhat contradictory. On the one hand, and I strongly support it, he claims that energy policy is an eminently strategic area on which the independence and sovereignty of States depends and which is therefore their responsibility. On the other hand, it proposes, in order to ensure the energy security of these same states, procurement policies at European level, i.e. the negation of these same notions of sovereignty and independence. Add to this an anti-Russian burden, a pro-American tropism, particularly in favour of the inclusion of the sector in the transatlantic treaty negotiations, the unwavering support for the internal energy market - that is, its total liberation and delivery to private operators, including non-European ones - and the multiplication of very inventive means to break what is left of public service in this field - personal production , deregulation of tariffs... and it will be understandably that once again I voted against a report on energy in this Chamber. For security, whether internal, external or energy, Europe is not a solution: it is one of the causes of the problem.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the Gróbarczyk report because we do not share the European Commission's vision of the Energy Union. Energy should not be the subject of financial benefits but should be regarded as a common good and the cornerstone of the fight against climate change. There are no proposals in this report to solve the problem of energy poverty affecting four million people in the Spanish State. The report is highlighted by its clear support for nuclear energy, which seriously jeopardizes our safety and our environment. In addition, it leaves the door open to hydraulic fracturing.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission is determined to revise the ETS and the allowance system in order to distribute the available allowances in a more efficient way. We in UKIP are against this proposal as we reject a revision of the damaging EU ETS system. We believe that the EU Commission should recognise that the entire EU energy project has failed, causing higher energy prices in all Member States. It has caused job losses, plant closures and a massive outflow of industry and investment outside the EU.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Energy Union is extremely important for European citizens, for European industry and for the establishment of new jobs, especially in the renewable energy sector. I voted for the report as a whole, given the importance of the substance of this report. I voted for Amendment 59 because I believe that the use of hydraulic fracturing has serious consequences for the environment and human health. I opposed Amendment 65, because increasing the targets of climate and energy targets for 2030 is impossible for many member States to achieve.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D)
text: Writing. The report on a European Energy Union has many positive aspects that we welcome. The adoption of the amendments on binding energy and climate targets for 2030 and the rejection of any financial support for nuclear energy by EU funds is particularly pleasing. Unfortunately, the report does not clearly reject the use of nuclear energy, and in some places there is even talk of further development of nuclear energy. Since the SPÖ-EU delegation aims to phase out nuclear power in Europe in both the medium and long term, we were unable to support the report and voted against it in the final vote.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I strongly believe that the Energy Union, if properly implemented, will ensure the energy transition to a clean, renewable future, while putting citizens centre-stage and ensuring a secure, stable and affordable energy system.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. The construction of an Energy Union must be accelerated. Achieving the 20% energy efficiency improvement target by 2020 unfortunately seems difficult to achieve because too many Member States are not taking this huge project seriously enough and are still blocking the necessary investments in this area. The Juncker plan has funded many projects. This must continue, especially for heating and cooling, which are the main energy consumption point in the European Union. Finally, in the electricity and gas markets, they are still not functioning optimally. Lack of interconnections, lack of regional cooperation and cross-border trade: the internal market needs to be rapidly strengthened! At the same time, more and more renewable energy sources are coming into the grids, making the organization more complex. It is therefore urgent to respond to the complexity of energy management with a real European strategy by focusing on the so-called "smart" management of networks.  Much remains to be done. Future carbon market reform will be essential for future investment direction and to strengthen our industrial base.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on Towards a European Energy Union because I strongly believe that European energy Union is a key pillar in the EU long-term energy strategy. It sets an important cornerstone for a fully open and free common energy market, ensuring compliance with the highest environmental and efficiency standards while stimulating economic competitiveness.  It is also of utmost importance for some countries, including my home country, that are heavily dependent on suppliers outside the EU. In close cooperation Member States will have access to the cleanest and most cost effective sources of energy without being exposed to politically and economically unreliable third country suppliers.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it contains the wickers to transform our energy model according to the agreements reached last weekend at COP21. Since socialist banking, we have managed to lead a majority that has once again spoken out in favour of more ambitious binding climate and energy targets, a 40% reduction in CO2 emissions, 30% renewables and 40% energy efficiency. Following this vote we encourage the Council and the Commission to take a step forward and to commit to defending the objectives proposed by Parliament. Thanks to our input, the report sets the way for ensuring citizens access to energy at affordable prices, boosts self-consumption from renewable energy sources and proposes clear measures to combat energy poverty.  The report also recognises the potential of the renewables sector as a competitive factor and as an engine of innovation and job creation in Europe, a sector that we are committed to defending.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union report provides a balanced summary of the steps that could bring Europe closer to a European energy policy for consumers.  The report confirms that the aim of European energy policy is to strengthen security of supply and to increase energy efficiency at an affordable price. This requires, where necessary, the building of new infrastructure, further unifying the market and forcing the application of legislation. The report anticipates that the completion of the Energy Union can increase Europe's competitiveness on the international stage and create new jobs, for example through technological research development, innovation promotion and investment in energy efficiency. As shadow reporter of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of this report and am proud that the report was adopted by a large majority.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report includes a series of deficiencies and negative reports. References to the need to achieve a common European energy policy and to strengthen the Commission's role in transnational and trade agreements are, of course, aimed at promoting the interests of the EU's dominant circles and limiting the sovereignty of states inside and outside the EU, easing national flexibility in the formulation of efficient and multidimensional transnational energy relations. On the other hand, however, we have succeeded in voting in favour of amendments that we have tabled which are of particular importance to Cyprus and the interests of society and peoples, amendments which express the need to transform the Eastern Mediterranean into a gas hub following the recent discoveries of deposits in the region. Our fixed position is for energy to be a public social good. To achieve this, it is necessary to ensure the existence of enhanced state control, public infrastructure and international cooperation, which will be carried out on the basis of mutual benefit, parity and solidarity and not subsequently energy planning serving geopolitical purposes.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as the EU imports more than half of all the energy it consumes. Its import dependency is particularly high for crude oil (more than 90 %), natural gas (66 %) and hard coal (72 %), and the total import bill is more than EUR 400 billion in 2013. The goal of a resilient Energy Union with an ambitious climate policy at its core is to ensure the transition to a new energy model which empowers households and businesses to produce and consume secure, sustainable, competitive and affordable energy. Long-term stable regulatory framework is needed to create economic growth and jobs and ensure the EU's leading role in these areas. The Energy Union should be a new energy model for Europe, based on strong cross-cutting legislative grounds and strong objectives.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. A European energy market is an important initiative that could potentially promote the competitiveness and energy security of the European economy. The report was initially balanced and reasonable. However, it has been significantly worsened by many amendments. For example, technology openness and neutrality have been abolished and replaced with arbitrarily defined, one-sided regulatory objectives. I firmly believe that Parliament must be guided by Council decisions when it came to targets, rather than arbitrarily proposing high objectives that are difficult to achieve. Member States should know better what is realistic and feasible and what is not. Because the report has taken on a monodimensional and anti-technology form through the numerous amendments, I have chosen to vote against the report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union report provides a balanced summary of the steps that could bring Europe closer to a European energy policy for consumers.  The document underlines that the aim of European energy policy is to strengthen security of supply and to increase energy efficiency at affordable prices. This requires, where necessary, the building of new infrastructure, further unifying the market and forcing the application of legislation. The report anticipates that the completion of the Energy Union can increase Europe's competitiveness on the international stage and create new jobs, for example through technological research development, innovation promotion and investment in energy efficiency. As a member of the Hungarian delegation from the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In my constituency we are, in the words of the East of England Energy Group, “unique” as we include energy producers across a diverse range including nuclear, gas and renewables. My region is key to Britain keeping the lights turned on. Indeed 60 per cent of the offshore wind in the UK comes from just off the East of England coastline. In Norfolk alone, up to 5000 Megawatts in planned capacity could be unlocked within the next 15 years, by three new offshore projects that would come from a meshed grid project in the North Sea. In my work as a local MEP, I have specifically backed a European project to create a North Sea grid for trading renewable energy, as well as the project to host a new gas interconnector. Therefore I deeply welcome the proposals in today's vote which will support the building of interconnectors between the UK and nine other EU countries and the creation of a North Sea electricity grid which will reduce electricity prices, increase energy security and promote renewable energy. It will also create thousands of permanent, high-skilled, UK jobs, many which will be for my constituency.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst there was much in this report to commend it, this House retains its nuclear obsession. Nuclear power is expensive and dangerous and should have no role in the long term development of EU energy policy. Accordingly, on balance, I could not support the report as a whole.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report regarding the creation of a resilient Energy Union with a forward-looking climate change policy based on a transition towards a sustainable, forward-looking energy system with energy efficiency, renewable energy and best use of Europe’s energy resources.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The Energy Union is an exceptionally ambitious project. I would like to encourage the Commission and the Council to develop the project in a concrete direction and to find a consensus between the often very different points of view of the Member States. There are understandable passions in energy policy. The consumption and production methods of the Member States differ quite a lot.  In climate change mitigation, energy production is absolutely central. We should be open to new energy production methods and spend enough money on developing more environmentally friendly technologies. Each method of production has an environmental impact. Reducing them must be the starting point for everything.  At the same time, thinking must be based on increasing energy efficiency and reducing energy consumption. The energy efficiency of industry, housing and transport must continuously improve. Negawatti is the best watt. The energy production system shall be so decentralised and diversified that malfunctions or problems with the availability of a single fuel do not jeopardise the functioning of the system. Each country should secure its own energy supply while being part of a wider European entity.  Member States must take advantage of their own environmentally friendly strengths, be they biomass, wind, waves or sun. The Paris agreement points the way out of fossil fuels. You have to have the courage to walk, even if it's not going to be easy. European confidence and the capacity of electricity transmission networks are measured not on a beautiful summer's day, but on winter frosty days, when imports poo and unexpected equipment disruptions fall on top.  The Energy Union will not be built in a day, a month, a year, hardly even a decade. It must be seen as part of a development in which EU countries build new and more sustainable energy infrastructure in small steps, every day.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for an EP resolution on the "Towards a European Energy Union" initiative, as the EU needs to proceed with an ambitious plan to create an Energy Union. The European Union needs to have energy independence and protect energy security given the volatile geopolitical environment. Energy independence is the basis for preserving the democratic stability and independence of EU countries.  The basis of the future Energy Union must be a fully functioning and connected internal energy market delivering secure, reliable, fairly distributed, socially and environmentally responsible, efficient, competitive, affordable and sustainable energy through fully functioning, secure and resilient energy transmission networks, as well as reducing energy demand.  I agree with the main pillars on which the future of the European energy strategy should be based, such as ensuring security of energy supply, decarbonisation, long-term economic sustainability and achieving affordable and competitive energy prices. The objectives of the Energy Union should be aligned with the objectives related to reducing harmful climate change.  Energy efficiency and competitiveness, lowering energy prices, increasing investment in innovation, encouraging advanced technologies, aiming for renewable energy sources, contributing to the competitiveness of the European economy, which is also linked to the employment situation, should be pursued. Direct "benefits" for citizens with the availability of cheaper energy are also important.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The compromises adopted resulted in a relative weakening of the report on its Liberal component. Regarding its ecological aspect, ambitions have been revised upwards.  On the other hand, the ITRE committee voted to strengthen the provisions on the TTIP as well as on the anti-Russian component. A denunciation of the russian-German Nord Stream pipeline project was added.  However, a heated debate is not about to be closed between the Greens and EFDD on the one hand, EPP and ECR on the other on two issues. The substance of the disagreement is shale gas and nuclear.  I voted against, because of the end of regulated tariffs, the creation of an artificial market that will deprive us of long-term contracts, indispensable industrial policy instruments, and redundant attacks against Russia to promote the importation of Qatari and American LNG.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The European Commission is determined to revise the ETS and the allowance system in order to distribute the available allowances in a more efficient way. My colleagues and I are against this proposal as we reject a revision of the damaging EU ETS system. We believe that the EU Commission should recognise that the entire EU energy project has failed, causing higher energy prices in all Member States. It has caused job losses, plant closures and a massive outflow of industry and investment outside the EU.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Marek Grebarczyk's report on a European Energy Union. The aim is for Europe to reduce its energy dependence and to promote the use of renewable energies to ensure a sustainable and competitive future. To do this, the Union must, among other things, increase the interconnection between its Member States and diversify its supplies. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D)
text: Writing. The report on a European Energy Union has many positive aspects that we welcome. The adoption of the amendments on binding energy and climate targets for 2030 and the rejection of any financial support for nuclear energy by EU funds is particularly pleasing. Unfortunately, the report not only lacked a clear rejection of the use of nuclear energy, but in some places there was even talk of the development of nuclear energy. As the SPÖ-EU delegation aims to phase out nuclear power in Europe both in the medium and long term, we were therefore unable to support the report and voted against it in the final vote.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Many proposals are worthy of support and offer great opportunities for energy producers and consumers, but there are some points that I cannot agree with.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I strongly believe that the Energy Union, if properly implemented, will ensure the energy transition to a clean, renewable future, while putting citizens centre-stage and ensuring a secure, stable and affordable energy system.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. A European energy market is an important initiative that could potentially promote the competitiveness and energy security of the European economy. The report was initially balanced and reasonable. However, it has been significantly worsened by many amendments. For example, technology openness and neutrality have been abolished and replaced with arbitrarily defined, one-sided regulatory objectives. Because the report has taken on a monodimensional and anti-technology form through the numerous amendments, I have chosen to vote against the report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union report provides a balanced summary of the steps that could bring Europe closer to a European energy policy for consumers.  The report confirms that the aim of European energy policy is to strengthen security of supply and to increase energy efficiency at an affordable price. This requires, where necessary, the building of new infrastructure, further unifying the market and forcing the application of legislation. The report anticipates that the completion of the Energy Union can increase Europe's competitiveness on the international stage and create new jobs, for example through technological research development, innovation promotion and investment in energy efficiency. As a member of the Hungarian delegation from the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Some amendments to the report would have made it considerably more balanced, but unfortunately they were not voted on, so I chose to abst. If the stated objective is for European citizens to have stable and cheap access to clean energy, the construction of the South Stream gas pipeline through Bulgaria should have been supported. Nuclear power plants should not have been shut down either, because they produce electricity without absolute carbon dioxide, and even radiating materials are released into the atmosphere not by nuclear power plants, but by coal plants. At today's technological level, renewable energies are not a real alternative to basic power plants, but they are locally important, of course. If we do not want to miss out permanently on clean and economical energy, it is worth studying the new results, the already operational 4th generation nuclear power plant reactor, which can produce energy from cheap by-products of uranium enrichment.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 Parliament's opinion on the Energy Union takes good note of the link between climate change and the measures needed in the energy sector. I am pleased that the report adopted by Parliament takes account of the benefits of district heating and biofuels. Parliament's position also takes the right view in favour of the development and expansion of district heating networks and on the use of various clean (renewable) technologies for heating. We have extensive district heating networks and clean technology in Finland, so the trend is heading in the right direction for us. It called for a shift from coal and gas to better security of supply biomass and pointed out that biomass based on sustainable forest management can contribute to achieving the 2030 climate and energy targets. In the spring, the Commission will publish a heating and cooling strategy. In addition to energy saving potential, it must again take into account the aid for the energy use of biomass in the exit from fossil fuels.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of an initiative report on the Energy Union, one of the ten priorities set by Jean-Claude Juncker at the beginning of his mandate. The report supports the development of renewable energy, without skewering nuclear energy for The Member States that wish to do so. The aim will be to move towards an integrated internal energy market that is at the forefront of research and innovation, particularly in terms of energy efficiency, when Europe is already a world leader in renewable energy, with 40% of patents and 1.2 million jobs in this sector. As we wished to remind the European Commission, it is equally important to have more sophisticated and demanding anti-dumping means to protect our European energy industries.  Finally, I believe that the Emissions Trading System (ETS) needs to be reformed in depth, it must be designed in a more realistic way, in order to enable us to effectively combat carbon leakage to third countries, which is constantly increasing.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the European Energy Union. First of all, this report is geared in favour of polluting companies: it proposes in particular the exploitation of shale gas and oil, under the name "unconventional energy sources". Second, it is anti-Russian, notably by denouncing Russia as an unreliable partner, by fully supporting Russia's gas pipeline projects and bypass pipelines. This text is also pro-American. Indeed, it calls for energy to be included in the TTIP.  This text also supports the Commission's thesis of the creation of a liberalised energy market. This means the elimination of regulated tariffs, monopolies and long-term contracts, in favour of market prices, speculative spot markets and widespread interconnection.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MEPs voted against this energy text because, firstly, it increases the competences of the European Union, secondly, it is foolishly anti-Russian, thirdly, it paves the way for the TAFTA Treaty.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it contains the wickers to transform our energy model according to the agreements reached last weekend at COP21. Since socialist banking, we have managed to lead a majority that has once again spoken out in favour of more ambitious binding climate and energy targets, a 40% reduction in CO2 emissions, 30% renewables and 40% energy efficiency. Following this vote we encourage the Council and the Commission to take a step forward and to commit to defending the objectives proposed by Parliament. Thanks to our input, the report sets the way for ensuring citizens access to energy at affordable prices, boosts self-consumption from renewable energy sources and proposes clear measures to combat energy poverty.  The report also recognises the potential of the renewables sector as a competitive factor and as an engine of innovation and job creation in Europe, a sector that we are committed to defending.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. While it is true that the European Union has energy standards at European level, in practice there are twenty-eight countries with twenty-eight national regulatory frameworks. That is why this report emerges: to achieve an integrated energy market. In this way, the aim is to increase market efficiency through more efficient use of energy production facilities across the EU, as well as to guarantee affordable prices for consumers.  Among the many measures proposed, we can find a new framework for consumers in which, for example, consumers will be able to buy energy freely and smoothly from an undertaking in another Member State.   In terms of renewable energy, we highlight the enormous progress made by the EU, as it is on track to reach its 20% renewable energy target in its energy mix by 2020. In my opinion, this report is of great importance because it is necessary to create an internal energy market characterized by its homogeneity and the integration of renewable energy into the market.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. A European energy market is an important initiative that could potentially promote the competitiveness and energy security of the European economy. The report was initially balanced and reasonable. However, it has been significantly worsened by many amendments. For example, technology openness and neutrality have been abolished and replaced by arbitrarily defined unilateral regulatory objectives. I firmly believe that Parliament must be guided by Council decisions when it came to targets, rather than arbitrarily proposing high, hard-to-reach targets. Member States should know better what is realistic and feasible and what is not. Because the report has taken on a monodimensional and anti-technology form through the numerous amendments, I have chosen to vote against the report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union project does not respect the individual energy needs of individual states and, under the pretext of solidarity, seeks to disadvantage some.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the 'Towards a European Energy Union' initiative, as we need to be aware that rural communities across the EU are suffering significant consequences from poor energy connectivity. Strengthening the single market and establishing an Energy Union are the EU's objectives that will result in more competitive Member States and ensure the growth and development of the economy.  The basis of the Energy Union must be a fully interconnected internal energy market delivering safe, affordable, socially and environmentally responsible energy. Such an idea requires a functional and secure infrastructure for energy transmission. The ultimate goal is to provide sustainable, efficient and equitable access to gas and electricity.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Energy independence is undeniably the one that must be promoted by any country in the world. Unfortunately, the European Union has to import most of the crude oil used (90%), natural gas (66%), as well as coal (72 %). I would like to note that the EU is also heavily dependent on the import of the same conventional and rare metals. , 40% for fossil fuels, 11% for hydropower. What is interesting is that EU companies hold around 40% of all the global technology patents for renewable energy, which play a minimal role in the same greenhouse gas emissions. In other words, while our countries are currently heavily dependent on importing energy sources and non-renewable energy sources and this dependence may increase as much as possible in the coming decades, diversifying the sources of the imports concerned and the much more intensive transition to renewable energy sources are policies that our Member States and the Union as a whole must not undeniably implement.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the road to a European Energy Union because it is neither complete nor documented, but also for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech of 14/12/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report. The Energy Union must provide EU citizens with secure, sustainable and affordable energy.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Despite some positive points such as the recall of the national prerogative to choose the energy mix or the maintenance of fossil fuel subsidies, we oppose this text. Indeed, his anti-Russian and pro-American approach displeased us, in particular his request to include energy in the TTIP and his denunciation of Russia as an "unreliable" partner.  This text calls for an end to regulated tariffs, the creation of an artificial market that will deprive us of long-term markets, and promotes the importation of Qatari and American shale gas. That is why we strongly oppose it.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union's energy policy aims to promote and ensure the functioning of the energy market, security of energy supply, energy saving, energy efficiency, the development of renewable energies, and also to intensify the interconnection of energy networks. It is therefore necessary to ensure a stable regulatory framework, aimed at building an Energy Union to implement energy and climate objectives, ensuring a level playing field between European energy producers and third countries, including a wide application of a revised Emissions Trading System (ETS).

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, which I support by voting in favour, reacts to the Commission communication on the creation of a European Energy Union. The draft report, in fact, focuses on the various important aspects relating to energy security, including the need to diversify energy sources and types of supply, as well as on the initiatives necessary to achieve the completion of the internal energy market.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The Framework Strategy for a Resilient Energy Union with a forward-looking climate policy presented by the European Commission is a good starting point for moving towards the objectives we have set ourselves in EU energy policy.  We want it to be a policy that will help achieve the objectives we have set ourselves in reducing polluting emissions and make us less dependent on the outside world, as well as to make a clear bet on interconnections to protect, above all, the most energy-vulnerable regions and countries.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The EU energy strategy, which runs until 2030, aims to create a genuine European Energy Union with a secure energy market and supply while increasing energy efficiency through the interconnection of national networks, which will gradually be homogenised, leaving behind the present variations. The promotion and exploitation of the eastern Mediterranean deposits serves the purpose of the independence of sources of supply. The five aspects of this strategy are energy security, an integrated internal energy market, energy efficiency, dependence on the carbon economy and the promotion of healthy competition and research. Through these objectives, the EU will be able to provide its citizens with a modern energy supply system that takes into account the needs and challenges of today's society with regard to climate change and environmental destruction. The exploitation of renewable energy sources to avoid the use of coal is another welcome objective that can be achieved through the Energy Union. I am in favour of this resolution because achieving energy independence will promote the competitiveness of the European market with many important economic, social and political benefits for the future of the European economy and for the well-being of citizens.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. For my part, there can only be agreement on plans for a European Energy Union if there is a clear rejection of nuclear energy. This is not the case in this report. I therefore reject this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in in favour of this report as it aims to strengthen the security of energy supply and increase energy efficiency at an affordable cost.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The aim of the report is to create "a more economically and physically integrated single energy market" that "could lead to significant efficiency gains". It is therefore, as always, a matter of liberalising the sector 'since in many Member States consumers have too little choice between suppliers'. And this should be done by "promoting competition" to "reduce prices". With just a few days to go until the end of COP 21, all environmental commitments have disappeared and the report encourages and supports "the exploitation of conventional indigenous oil and gas resources in the North Sea, the Eastern Mediterranean or the Black Sea".  Finally, in geopolitical digressions, the rapporteur dares to write that Russia "has proven to be an unreliable partner and is using its energy supplies as a political weapon" even as it continues to supply gas to Ukraine, which has nevertheless stopped all payments.  I am voting against this text, which does not measure the energy issues in Europe.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The compromises adopted resulted in a relative weakening of the report on its Liberal component. Regarding its ecological aspect, ambitions have been revised upwards.  On the other hand, the ITRE committee voted to strengthen the provisions on the TTIP as well as on the anti-Russian component. A denunciation of the russian-German Nord Stream pipeline project was added.  However, a heated debate is not about to be closed between the Greens and EFDD on the one hand, EPP and ECR on the other on two issues. The substance of the disagreement is shale gas and nuclear.  I voted against, because of the end of regulated tariffs, the creation of an artificial market that will deprive us of long-term contracts, indispensable industrial policy instruments, and redundant attacks against Russia to promote the importation of Qatari and American LNG.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I welcome the European Council's proposal to achieve a minimum level of electrical interconnection between Member States of 15% by 2030. It is essential to end energy isolation, with so-called energy islands. The Iberian Peninsula can play a decisive role in establishing a European Energy Union. I voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The need to diversify energy sources and supply routes within the EU has become of paramount importance to ensure energy security. I chose to support this report as it looks at addressing these issues as well as putting initiatives in place for the completion of the internal energy market.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The Paris Environmental Agreement is the most ambitious, compelling and most hopeful agreement ever to reduce global warming. With this agreement, nearly 200 countries have taken a final step towards the low-carbon economy. The report also reflects this same ambition: 'Towards a European Energy Union'.  In recent years, the vulnerability to the disruptions in the supply of energy to Europe has been explicitly addressed on a number of occasions. Today, half of the EU depends on the goodwill of foreign partners for half of all the energy it needs. This dependence makes energy the Achilles tendon of our society and economy. After all, an unreliable foreign supplier can shut down the energy supply at any time.  Moreover, our dependence on conventional fossil fuels is far too great. Developing a European energy security that ensures sovereignty and environmental objectives is a priority for a strong economic and political position.  That is why I support the ambitions of this report, which explicitly opt for energy efficiency, renewable energy and the development of innovative environmentally friendly energy sources, because a common greening of the European energy market will also have a positive impact on new employment.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the Energy Union can bring real and tangible benefits to all Member States, I welcome the report entitled 'Towards a European Energy Union' and consider it important that the Energy Union Framework Strategy has created a new impetus for the transition to a low-carbon, secure and competitive economy. Given that the European Union spends around EUR 400 billion each year on energy imports, I consider it essential to reduce this dependence by diversifying the sources, suppliers and transport routes of both electricity and nuclear fuel, but above all natural gas. As a result of geopolitical events, when tensions between Russia and Ukraine persist and when we see persistently low oil prices affecting energy markets around the world, energy security is still literally the theme of the day. It is all the more necessary to seek a safe and effective solution and to ensure that the European Union is united on the world stage. In this context, the sensitive point for the Slovak Republic is competitiveness in pursuing the objectives as well as maintaining existing transit routes, which should also respect new projects, including the controversial Nord Stream 2 pipeline.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report ‘Towards a European Energy Union’, which is Parliament’s response to the Commission Energy Union strategy, one of the key political priorities of the Juncker Commission. The strategy and Parliament’s report is divided into the five key dimensions of energy security, a fully-integrated internal energy market, energy efficiency, decarbonisation of the economy and research, innovation and competitiveness. Energy Union must ensure the energy transition to a clean, renewable future, while putting citizens centre-stage and ensuring a secure, stable and affordable energy system. I also think that Member States’ competences in term of energy trading should be safeguarded, allowing such Member States to establish or deepen their relations with third country partners in the field of energy, of course in full compliance and in line with EU legislation.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the European Parliament's own-initiative report on the Energy Union. It calls for a series of measures to help reduce europe's high energy costs, reduce dependence on imported fossil fuels and further decarbonise the economy. I particularly welcome the fact that my group's amendments on binding energy and climate targets for 2030 (40% CO2 reduction, 30% renewable energy sources and 40% energy efficiency) have been adopted by the European Parliament.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Energy Union is one of the most ambitious undertakings of the EU. It is not a single piece of legislation, but an ongoing project that in the short to medium term will see the roll-out of directives, regulations, strategies and cooperation procedures on energy issues between Member States. The aim is to create an integrated system that will make energy more secure, affordable and climate-friendly for European citizens and businesses. In this context, the European Parliament presented its proposal on how to set the Energy Union in motion. Parliament’s report tackles complex issues such as technological choices, compatibility with climate objectives, diversification of energy resources and the governance of the Energy Union. The report had my vote as I believe it presents a balanced and comprehensive set of recommendations that the Commission and the Member States should follow, if the Energy Union is to deliver on its promises.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union is one of the juncker commission's most important announced strategic goals. The report of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy strongly supports both this and the main objectives pursued in doing so, such as the safe supply of cheap energy to European citizens, the realisation of energy poverty, competitive energy prices for the development of European industry, energy saving, the achievement of ambitious environmental targets previously announced, in particular the radical reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and a sharp reduction in the EU's energy dependency.  It takes into account the decisions and declarations taken in this area, faces the main difficulties in achieving the Energy Union and proposes a resolution of the European Parliament on a number of related issues, which could further guide the way in which the strategic objectives are achieved. I was pleased to vote in favour of this report as a demanding contribution to one of the Union's main strategic objectives.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Under Article 194 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, European energy policy must ensure the functioning of the energy market, security of energy supply, promote energy efficiency and energy savings. I am voting in favour of this report which aims to increase energy security by reducing dependence on Russia, improving energy efficiency through a strong focus on renewable energy and deepening the European market for energy interconnections, notably by improving The Iberian links to France. We must therefore diversify the sources of supply, established routes and typology of energy production and support people and entrepreneurs to provide their homes or companies with better environmental conditions, as well as to invest effectively in electric cars and innovative methods of electric production.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the European Energy Union includes some laudable objectives such as the desire to retain the national prerogative to choose the energy mix, or the non-resumption of the idea of a transformation commission of the Agency for the Cooperation of Regulators, etc.  However, this report is eminently anti-Russian: Russia is described as an unreliable partner, it supports pipeline projects to circumvent Russia, it wants to de facto ban Gazprom from accessing the distribution market in the European Union... It is therefore a largely pro-American text in favour of TTIP. However, journalistic revelations showed that the TTIP negotiations largely favoured US energy exports and that European negotiators were subject to the US energy lobby.  This ideological relationship is therefore in a way that is not favourable to the interests of consumers since it prefers to sacrifice low-cost energy (end of regulated prices) because of its origin and will prefer the importation of energy from unsavory countries (Qatar ...).  So I voted against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I strongly believe that the Energy Union, if properly implemented, will ensure the energy transition to a clean, renewable future, while putting citizens centre-stage and ensuring a secure, stable and affordable energy system.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this particularly balanced text, which calls for the implementation of a genuine Energy Union. While it recalls the competence of Member States in the composition of their energy mix, the report supports the development of renewable energies, but also the exploitation of conventional hydrocarbons and nuclear energy. It does not express a principled opposition to unconventional energies, particularly shale gas. It calls on the Commission to toughen anti-dumping measures to protect European energy industries.  At the institutional level, he insists that everything in the energy union's domain should be a matter of ordinary legislative procedure and therefore fully involve Parliament. Finally, on a very positive note, it calls on the Commission to report annually to Parliament on the implementation of the Energy Union using detailed indicators.  If I voted for this text, I opposed some of its provisions which presented Russia as an "unreliable partner". These terms only strengthen the deterioration of relations between the EU and Russia, at a time when our producers and consumers continue to suffer from the sterile escalation of reciprocal sanctions.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report regarding European energy policy that should ensure the functioning of the energy market, promote energy efficiency and savings and the development of renewable energy, ensure security of energy supply and promote the interconnection of energy networks.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in support of one of the European Union's most important policies, namely energy policy, which aims to ensure the security of energy supply, promote energy efficiency, energy saving and the development of renewable energy, and promote the interconnectivity of energy networks, as Member States' energy mixes remain very diversified. It is clear that ensuring a better economically and physically integrated energy market could lead to significant gains for Member States. In this respect, as the document suggests, Member States must support the development of well-integrated and competitive regional electricity and gas markets, ensuring the adequacy and flexibility of the energy system and covering all parts of the Union. I also welcome the report's proposal to take into account the development of the long-term energy strategy, taking into account the target of an 80-95% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because I believe that concrete steps must be taken both to create an Energy Union and not to take steps that undermine these efforts. For this reason, I have expressed my opposition to the proposed doubling of the capacity of the Nordstream pipeline and, on the contrary, I am convinced of the need to look for solutions that do not have a negative impact on energy security and diversification of supply. I would welcome the creation of a mechanism strengthening the Commission's role in the negotiations concerning energy supply involving one or more of the Member States and third countries, including the preliminary assessment of commercial gas supply contracts. Only a common procedure for negotiating gas supply contracts can lead to a supply system that is favourable and sustainable for the EU as a whole.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I would have voted against this report in the European Parliament. The draft resolution on the Energy Union deals with voluntary joint negotiation of contracts for the purchase of energy in third countries. It also sets ambitious and evidence-based network targets for 2030 – which, in my opinion, are too far-sighted.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Europe is stronger both externally and internally when it has a single energy market. It is important to diversify energy sources in the EU and to build energy sources between them. It is necessary to ensure that energy dependency is not used as a political tool.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report.  In particular, the exclusion of EU countries and regions from the internal energy market must be removed as a first time. A voluntary mechanism should also be developed to enable EU countries to buy energy resources together.  It is essential to ensure that the same approach is taken when negotiating with third countries and that the Role of the Commission is strengthened. The Commission should carry out ex ante and ex post evaluations and draw up a list of positive and negative terms of the agreements. The EU energy efficiency target after 2020 should be binding. It is also essential that the EU respects its own reduction of at least 40% by 2030. It should be noted that energy is a social asset for society and therefore the issue of energy poverty should be focused on the issue of energy poverty and concrete measures to address this problem should be taken as soon as possible.  Given the importance of nuclear energy, Member States wishing to implement new projects should be treated in a favourable way.  Particular attention must be paid to increasing the capacity of the Nordstream pipeline and the potential negative impact on the EU as a whole. Attention should also be paid to hydraulic fracturing, which is risky and has a negative impact on the climate, the environment and public health. The exploration and exploitation of shale gas should therefore be refrained from exploration for and exploitation of shale gas.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission is determined to revise the ETS and the allowance system in order to distribute the available allowances in a more efficient way. We in UKIP are against this proposal as we reject a revision of the damaging EU ETS system. We believe that the EU Commission should recognise that the entire EU energy project has failed, causing higher energy prices in all Member States. It has caused job losses, plant closures and a massive outflow of industry and investment outside the EU.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 My role as a member of the ENVI and ITRE Committee always pushes me to be active and reflective on energy. At present, more than ever, I want to defend the importance of sustainable energy for environmental protection and to support all possible investments in this sector. For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Europe imports 53% of its gross inland energy consumption and I believe energy security, such as the need to diversify energy sources and supply routes, is a vital part of building a strong and sustainable European Energy Union. The completion of the internal energy market, which could bring net economic benefits for Europe of between EUR 16 and 40 billion each year, requires various initiatives to be accomplished. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ It is known that the EU, but also Croatia depends on energy imports. Croatia imports 45% of electricity, according to HEP data. The Croatian electricity system and the national company HEP are obsolete, both technologically and conceptually and look more and more like dinosaurs that will die out in the near future along with the fossil fuels it uses. There is a lack of investment, and what few existing investments are directed again into a further increased dependence on imports of fossil energy.  According to Eurostat, Croatia has relatively low prices for households and even lower electricity prices for the industry. However, this rare and immediate market advantage for our industry may be jeopardised by poor investment. Croatia's national company must adapt to the Energy Union by investing in the energy capacities available on its territory. Investing in renewable sources and in the sector where Croatia has the most untapped potential – the sun – can make the national company a guarantor of a fair social price for electricity for households in the future. The attainment of the objective of increasing the interconnection of the electricity system across Europe to at least 10 % enables the placement of desirable energy from renewable sources produced in Croatia on the Market of Europe, ensuring the energy self-reliance of the state and the conditions for exporting electricity produced to other parts of the Union.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the European Energy Union includes some laudable objectives such as the desire to retain the national prerogative to choose the energy mix, or the non-resumption of the idea of a transformation commission of the Regulator Cooperation Agency, etc.  However, this report is anti-Russian in a rather primad way: Russia is described as an unreliable partner, it supports pipeline projects to circumvent Russia, it wants to de facto ban Gazprom from accessing the distribution market in the European Union... It is therefore a largely pro-American text from the perspective of the TTIP. However, revelations in the press showed that the TTIP negotiations largely favoured US energy exports and that European negotiators were subject to the US energy lobby.  This ideological relationship is therefore in a way that is not favourable to the interests of consumers since it prefers to sacrifice low-cost energy because of its origin and will favour the importation of energy from unsavory countries (e.g. Qatar). So I voted against this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I welcome the strategy to establish an Energy Union and free energy transfer as a common good. A coordinated and coherent approach at Union level will make it easier and more recent to achieve our common, rather ambitious energy goals.
