In the course of this process, we need to take into account the national circumstances of all Member States, as well as their potential to implement the necessary reforms and provide them with our full support. We can discuss the Energy Union in many contexts; in the context of energy independence, diversification, efficiency and sustainability. But in times of increasing security challenges surrounding the European Union, the context of energy security is particularly significant. That is why I am especially pleased that 3 Croatian projects were included in the European energy security strategy: the LNG terminal on Krk, the Ionian-Adriatic pipeline, and the Hungary-Croatia Reverse Stream, cross-border projects of significant influence for the region, but also europe in general. The political reality is that, in addition to security, energy has also become an oxygen for democracy, so it is the right time to upgrade the political integration of the European Union with that of energy. The European Union needs an integrated market that will be more stable than the price of a barrel of oil.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I agree with the report on MPs Gróbarczyk's 'Towards a European Energy Union' initiative. The European Union is the largest energy importer in the world. Of the 28 members, 6 depend on only one energy supplier, making them extremely vulnerable. For this reason, the European Energy Union should ensure energy stability, competitiveness on the world market and decarbonisation for the purpose of environmental protection.  I believe that the Energy Policy of the European Union must be adopted in line with climate policy, and therefore I stand for the EU to become more independent in energy supply, especially through renewable energy sources, thus implementing a plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 80-95% by 2050. According to an estimate by the European Commission, as much as 75% of European housing is energy inefficient and in many situations citizens do not have sufficient choice of energy suppliers.  Therefore, I support structural investments to increase efficiency, such as subsidies for energy renovation of facilities, which would result in a decrease in demand and I also urge each Member State to correct their legal frameworks for the purpose of achieving these objectives, and with the help and suggestion of the European Parliament.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I am very pleased that an important report on the Energy Union has been achieved in the European Parliament. European countries need to move away from fossil fuel-based energy and move more progressively towards setting an efficient energy mix with regard to the environment and sustainable development. This, together with the requirement to integrate energy markets, increase security of supply and reduce consumption, constitutes the basis of the Energy Union, which should, in the first place, lead to a reduction in dependence on energy imports. The Energy Union will not only help us transform the economy into a more environmentally friendly and low-carbon economy, but will have a positive impact on industry, transport, lower energy prices for households and consumer protection. At the same time, it will lead to the creation of new jobs.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Europe is facing rising energy demand, high prices, supply problems and, at the same time, must reduce the environmental impact of the energy sector. That is why we need a clear EU energy strategy. The Commission, through the submission of plans for a European Energy Union, aims to guarantee citizens and businesses safe, accessible and environmentally friendly energy. The climate and energy targets set by the EU executive will seek to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, obtain some of the energy from renewable sources and improve energy efficiency. Therefore, aware of the enormous importance of the energy sector and the implementation of an ambitious European strategy, I have decided to vote in favour of this report and I hope that all Member States will be able to contribute to the achievement of the objectives set out in it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it has several decisive and important aspects for me. In particular, I am talking about the desire to bring down the price of energy and to do what we can to be less and less dependent on imports. To do this, we should create a single energy market that should go through a voluntary common purchasing mechanism. I make a solemn appeal to our governments, as I had done on several occasions when I was responsible for representing the EPP in the negotiations in Parliament on the future of industrial policy.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. The report on a European Energy Union has many positive aspects, which I welcome. The adoption of the amendments on binding energy and climate targets for 2030 and the rejection of any financial support for nuclear energy by EU funds is particularly pleasing. Unfortunately, we SPÖ MEPs in the report clearly reject the use of nuclear energy, and in some places there is even talk of further development of nuclear energy. Since the SPÖ-EU delegation aims to phase out nuclear power in Europe in both the medium and long term, we were unable to support the report and voted against it in the final vote.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission is determined to revise the ETS and the allowance system in order to distribute the available allowances in a more efficient way. We in UKIP are against this proposal as we reject a revision of the damaging EU ETS system. We believe that the EU Commission should recognise that the entire EU energy project has failed, causing higher energy prices in all Member States. It has caused job losses, plant closures and a massive outflow of industry and investment outside the EU.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. I have spoken in favour of the report on the Energy Union because it proposes concrete and ambitious measures to build a fully integrated European energy market.  In COP 21, the energy sector should meet greenhouse gas reduction targets by supporting decarbonized energy and improving existing technologies to reduce energy consumption. We must support renewable energy sources and energy efficiency measures with the extension of regulatory measures or financial incentives, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which will have to play its full role in decarbonising energy. Furthermore, the development of energy production and distribution infrastructure and the interconnection of Member States' networks would reduce our dependence on our historical suppliers, end the isolation of some Member States from the European energy market and strengthen the security of supply of the European Union. Energy independence, efficiency and security will be the winning triptych of the European Energy Union.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The vote of this report today in plenary allowed me to express my unconditional support for the amendments which believe that the use of hydraulic fracturing (i.e., shale gas) in the European Union entails risks and adverse effects on the climate, the environment and public health, and jeopardises the achievement of the EU's long-term decarbonisation objective. I consider that the ability of unconventional fuels to meet the EU's energy demand in the future being limited and their exploitation requiring significant investment and costs, hydraulic fracturing is not a technology of the future, and I have therefore, together with others, urged Member States not to engage in any shale gas exploration or exploitation.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On a matter as comprehensive and complex as the Energy Union, and very specifically on this own-initiative report - with which I generally agree - I underline some aspects that I consider relevant (bearing in mind the Commission communication entitled "A framework strategy for a resilient Energy Union with a forward-looking climate change policy"). From the outset, the absolute need to bring the Energy Union to fruition, in order to establish a genuine pan-European energy community - with estimated savings for consumers of 12 to 40 million/year (2030) - and to ensure binding targets on energy efficiency, technological and nuclear neutrality. Secondly, the importance of fully integrating the Iberian Peninsula into the internal electricity market. Recognizing "that the projects currently included in the list of infrastructure projects of common interest are not sufficient to achieve the European goal of connecting the Iberian Peninsula and Continental Europe", this resolution sends a clear message of support to the Madrid Declaration, signed on 04/03/2015 between Spain, France and Portugal. Finally, the importance of having a common foreign energy policy perfectly coordinated and in line with the Common Foreign and Security Policy.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which votes on the Commission's communication on the Energy Union. This text stresses in particular the aspects related to energy security and the need to diversify energy sources and supply routes. It is important that EU states work together to reduce their dependence on energy imports; to do so, actions will have to take place by integrating their energy markets, improving security of supply, using their existing and renewable sources and managing demand. The security and competitiveness of energy supply will be central to the Energy Union.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the European Energy Union because I believe it is essential to develop and ensure the functioning of the energy market at European level. The Member States must work to create an integrated internal energy market, both from the regulatory point of view and from the point of view of interconnections; to increase security of supply both through diversification of supply, for example by exploiting recent discoveries in the Mediterranean basin, and through the development of internal sources; ensure energy efficiency and promote the development of renewables by integrating them into the market in a balanced way. A genuine Energy Union is at the basis of European growth and reindustrialisation.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the Gróbarczyk report because we do not share the European Commission's vision of the Energy Union. Energy should not be the subject of financial benefits but should be regarded as a common good and the cornerstone of the fight against climate change. There are no proposals in this report to solve the problem of energy poverty affecting four million people in the Spanish State. The report is highlighted by its clear support for nuclear energy, which seriously jeopardizes our safety and our environment. In addition, it leaves the door open to hydraulic fracturing.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. The Energy Union is one of the key policy projects of the Juncker Commission. Energy is one of the most expensive in Europe and security of supply and diversification are a constant issue due to the multiple crises in the Middle East and Ukraine. It is therefore important for the EU to press ahead with the completion of the internal energy market and to develop an efficient energy supply system. On the question of the energy mix, I am in favour of an examination of fracking. In my view, the use of nuclear energy should also be left to the Member States as an option. Overall, the report, which required tough negotiations, is so balanced that I was able to agree.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report entitled 'Towards a European Energy Union' because it addresses a number of specific aspects that are important for the implementation of the reform of the Energy Community towards the establishment of the internal energy market and the so-called European Energy Union. In addition to key themes of energy security, efficiency, support for research and innovation or investment in infrastructure, the report also highlights the social aspects of the energy market, including the consideration of end-consumers or the need to address the issue of energy poverty and the strengthening of vulnerable consumers.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I believe that the future of the European energy market goes through a decentralized and sovereign generation and distribution model, based on public control, energy efficiency and the use of local energy sources (such as renewables, but also traditional fossil resources with adequate technological and financial support). The approach of this proposal, in line with the Commission itself, is very different: it is committed to gigantic infrastructure and the inevitable concentration of European energy production in an oligopoly. This will delve into the use of dangerous technologies such as nuclear and fracking (which I oppose) and a wasteful and predatory energy resource policy (as seen in the requirements regarding TCI and Neighbourhood Policy).

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not wish to see the EU write any more legislation than could hinder the UK Energy market. EU energy policy has been a huge failure.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe strongly that the Energy Union will ensure the transition to a clean and renewable future, while putting citizens centre-stage and ensuring a stable, secure and affordable energy system. If implemented correctly. Overall I am pleased with the outcome of the vote and I'm glad to see the resolution adopted with such a large majority.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In February 2015, the European Commission came up with a proposal to create a European Energy Union, which should primarily address energy security, the introduction of technical and administrative barriers, or respect for climate objectives. Although some progress has already been made in these areas, I think that we have many outstanding challenges ahead of us, as evidenced by the report presented. I voted in favour of the resolution because I support the idea of a single European Energy Union based on solid cross-cutting legislative bases and strong objectives. I also share the vision presented and the new strategy because there is currently no single market for energy in Europe and that the resulting fragmentation of EU energy markets is very damaging to Europe's competitiveness and energy security. As an MEP representing the Slovak Republic and living in eastern Slovakia, I am very sensitive to the annual problems with energy supply during the winter months, which have been and are linked to the crisis situation in Ukraine. I expect a good integrated and competitive regional electricity and gas markets from the European Energy Union to ensure the adequacy and flexibility of an energy system covering all parts of the Union.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European energy policy ensures the functioning of the energy market and security of energy supply. It also promotes energy efficiency, energy saving, the development of renewable energy sources and the interconnection of energy networks. The creation of a strong Energy Union must be based on a sustainable, forward-looking energy system.  In order to maximise energy efficiency, the European Parliament has already twice called for binding climate and energy targets for 2030. These requirements also contain a report, which includes a number of good concrete proposals.  As such, I can highlight the requirement of a 40 % increase in energy efficiency, a limitation of the increase in the global average temperature to a maximum of 2 °C and recognition of the inadequacy of hydraulic fracturing. However, it is also necessary to be aware of the importance of nuclear energy, which is one of the most important in the European energy system, as it causes less CO2 emissions.  The final report no longer contains a tendency to promote nuclear energy, and some key amendments (moratorium on hydraulic fracturing, amendments to TTIP) were adopted in plenary, which led me to abstain in the vote on the report on the European Energy Union.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. A European energy market is an important initiative that could potentially promote the competitiveness and energy security of the European economy. The report was initially balanced and reasonable. However, it has been significantly worsened by many amendments. For example, technology openness and neutrality have been abolished and replaced by arbitrarily defined unilateral regulatory objectives. I firmly believe that Parliament must be guided by Council decisions when it came to targets, rather than arbitrarily proposing high objectives that are difficult to achieve. Member States should know better what is realistic and feasible and what is not. Because the report has taken on a monodimensional and anti-technology form through the numerous amendments, I have chosen to vote against the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must work together on a common energy policy. This is the way to increase energy security and the efficient use of renewable energy sources. If we really want it to work, solidarity and understanding must prevail between the Member States. The Nordstream2 project is contrary to the principles of the Energy Union and must therefore be rejected.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report, as the creation of a resilient Energy Union with advanced climate policy needs to be based on the transition to a sustainable and advanced energy system, underpinning energy efficiency, renewable energy, optimal use of European energy resources and smart infrastructure.  Achieving economic growth, creating new jobs and delivering an EU leadership role in these areas requires a long-term and stable regulatory framework. The Energy Security Strategy must include cost-effective measures to reduce energy demand and equally effective measures to overcome major and imminent disruptions and must include solidarity and coordination mechanisms to protect and strengthen energy production, smart energy transmission and distribution infrastructure and connecting lines.  Therefore, EU trade policy should aim to increase energy security in accordance with Article 194 of the TFEU, diversify energy sources and reduce dependence on a single external supplier or one supply point, while respecting the relevant division of competences laid down in the Treaty.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. According to Article 194 of the TFEU, European energy policy ensures the functioning of the energy market, ensures security of energy supply, promotes energy efficiency and energy savings, and promotes the interlinkage of energy networks. As the setting of energy consumption structures in the Member States remains within their national competence, the energy consumption structure remains highly diverse. In May 2014. In its Energy Security Strategy [8], the Commission said the EU is still vulnerable to external energy shocks and called on policymakers at national and EU level to clear up elections related to reducing our dependence on certain fuels, energy suppliers and supply routes. The Energy Union is based on this strategy.  I support the 'Towards a European Energy Union' initiative, as the spirit of solidarity in energy matters is explicitly mentioned in the Treaty and is at the heart of the Energy Union. Common energy approaches can strengthen all parts of the European Union. Member States, transmission system operators, the energy industry and all other stakeholders should work together to ensure a high level of energy security for European citizens and businesses.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal. I agree with some parts of the Energy Union, particularly with regard to the breaking of regulatory barriers. However, the European Parliament's proposal calls in many places for an increase in the regulatory burden, with calls, in particular, for climate targets to be tightened up to be meaningless and ultimately counterproductive.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report towards the European Energy Union. I believe that it is essential to ensure the functioning of the energy market, security of energy supply, promotion of energy efficiency, energy saving and progress in renewable energy sources, and that interconnection of energy networks should be promoted. I welcome the call for the European Commission and the Member States to ensure that all legislative proposals forming an Energy Union are dealt with in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure. This will give us full involvement in the process of accepting it, thus ensuring effective democratic control. Member States, transmission system operators, the electricity economy and all other stakeholders should cooperate. This will ensure a high level of energy security for citizens and businesses.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Thanks to the vote in favour of the amendments tabled mainly by GUE/NGL, the report contains some very positive references. It is stressed that energy is a public social good and calls on the EU to promote concrete measures to tackle energy poverty. It is also stressed that everyone must be guaranteed equal access to energy, affordable prices for consumers, energy isolation must be lifted and strategic links and energy infrastructures promoted for the benefit of citizens. Particularly important is the reference to the need to exploit the important natural gas reserves of the Eastern Mediterranean and to create a Mediterranean gas hub with increased LNG capacity to enhance our energy security. However, the report also contains a number of negative reports which we cannot ignore. It proposes the delegation of increased powers to the Commission with regard to transnational and trade agreements to the detriment of the sovereign rights of the Member States, promotes nuclear energy and proposes that a separate chapter on energy be included in the TTIP agreement. For these reasons we have chosen abstention.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report fails to respond and provide solutions to the major energy problem for the Union and does not avoid anchorages and aggressive rhetoric towards third countries.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union report provides a balanced summary of the steps that could bring Europe closer to a European energy policy for consumers.  The report confirms that the aim of European energy policy is to strengthen security of supply and to increase energy efficiency at an affordable price. This requires, where necessary, the building of new infrastructure, further unifying the market and forcing the application of legislation. The report anticipates that the completion of the Energy Union can increase Europe's competitiveness on the international stage and create new jobs, for example through technological research development, innovation promotion and investment in energy efficiency.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the concrete proposals made by the motion for a resolution will bring us closer to the Energy Union, so I voted in favour of it. I agree that the Energy Union should adopt a common approach to achieve a fully integrated internal energy market, security of supply, best use of EU energy resources, reduction of energy demand and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. R&D and innovation must play a major role in this process.  In my opinion, the focus of the Energy Union should not be on governments, but on the people for whom safe, sustainable and affordable energy must be provided. Currently, some governments continue to support fossil or nuclear developments for visible or invisible reasons, but the funds for them should be spent on renewable energy production.  Although nuclear energy is not fossil energy, safety issues such as safety issues and the storage of spent fuels still encourage many Member States to switch to renewable energy instead. It should be pointed out that the transition to renewable energy is necessary not only for environmental reasons, but also because it would save billions of euros at global level.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted against the report, even though it contains many positive elements on renewable energy and energy efficiency that are largely due to our work in the ITRE Committee: in particular, for the first time there is the notion that investments in energy efficiency are as important as investments in energy infrastructure. The report calls for the hidden and outsourced costs of energy to be calculated during impact assessments (hidden nuclear and fossil fuel costs are very high; renewable costs are practically non-existent) and reiterates the European Parliament's binding 2030 targets on emissions, energy efficiency and renewables, while the EU Council is content with non-binding and low-profile targets. However, the negative elements dominate in this report. In particular, too much space is given to nuclear power and fossil fuels. The EU's energy security is mistakenly matched by the construction of infrastructure to import fossil fuels, whereas it would only be achieved if the EU were able to produce most of the energy it needs: it should necessarily be energy from renewable sources, given that the EU is low in fossil deposits while nuclear energy, in addition to being dangerous, presupposes the import of uranium, which the EU does not have.

name: Paul Tang (S&D)
text: Written. 'The choice to abstain as a PVDA member in the vote on paragraph 32 of this resolution is based on two considerations.  Firstly, this paragraph is merely positive about the opportunities that an energy chapter in TTIP can bring to the EU, without mentioning the concerns, reservations or conditions to be set for such a chapter. An energy chapter of the trade treaty with the Americans should also be concerned about environmentally polluting products such as shale gas and tar sands oil.  Secondly, the Americans' shielding of their fossil fuels from the world market is one of the EU's offensive interests in the negotiations. If TTIP can ensure that Europe gains access to the US oil reserves, it will make Europe less dependent on the Middle East and Russia for its oil and gas. This paragraph did not address the concerns of the Labour Euro delegation, but we do not wish to reject the inclusion of an energy chapter in TTIP, so reason to abstain.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is one of the most energy-efficient actors in the world. For this reason, Member States are constantly searching for new energy sources, with the greatest efficiency possible. This can be achieved better within a European Energy Union, which provides a framework for coordinating Member States' energy policies. The European Commission's strategy for the implementation of the Energy Union is based on the five dimensions of energy security, the integrated common energy market, energy efficiency, decarbonisation of the economy and research-innovation.  While, from the point of view of ensuring energy security, diversification of sources is imperative, in terms of energy efficiency and decarbonisation of the economy, consideration should be given to achieving more ambitious renewable energy targets and gradually reducing the use of pollutant fuels. Particular attention must be paid to research and innovation in this area, because we need the best solutions that support our citizens.  Achieving an integrated common energy market at European level will create the framework for achieving competitive and favourable prices for both small and large consumers for the benefit of all of us.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report ‘Towards an European Energy Union’. The Energy Union is one of the most important projects which would, in the long run, ensure energy security and independence of the EU. The report calls for higher energy efficiency, increased use of renewables, diversification of supply, more active use of European energy resources, proper energy connectors between Member States, renovation of infrastructure networks and buildings. Of particular importance is to undertake further actions to build a fully integrated, synchronised and well-functioning internal energy market based on a market approach as well as solidarity and coordination mechanisms. I voted in favour of all compromises approved by the ITRE Committee and I also voted in favour of those compromises concerning recognition of nuclear energy as one of the important contributors to the low-carbon European energy mix. I however did not support amendments calling for binding energy efficiency targets. I also voted against Amendment 59 on shale gas.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ensuring a cohesive and coherent response to energy security and the fight against climate change is our first objective, which is why I welcome the Commission's initiative on the Energy Union. With this vote, Parliament has shown consistency, reiterating the need to set binding targets for environmental protection, also thanks to the driving force coming from COP21 in Paris and reaffirming the urgent need for greater investment in low-carbon infrastructure and new technologies. European energy and climate strategies must continue to be complementary and must consequently be combined with innovation and research for the benefit of consumers and businesses.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union report provides a balanced summary of the steps that could bring Europe closer to a European energy policy for consumers.  The report confirms that the aim of European energy policy is to strengthen security of supply and to increase energy efficiency at an affordable price. This requires, where necessary, the building of new infrastructure, further unifying the market and forcing the application of legislation. The report anticipates that the completion of the Energy Union can increase Europe's competitiveness on the international stage and create new jobs, for example through technological research development, innovation promotion and investment in energy efficiency. As a member of the Hungarian delegation from the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Dear President – (DE) Mr President, although I am not happy with all the amendments adopted by Parliament on this issue, I voted definitively in favour of the report because the creation of a European Energy Union is a good objective for the future.  European energy policy must ensure the functioning of the energy market and security of energy supply, as well as promote energy efficiency. The development of renewable forms of energy and the interconnection of energy networks should be encouraged. A project on the EU's future electricity market model is needed to promote long-term supply-based investments that are more market-oriented.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the efforts of the rapporteur of this report on its own initiative, who is trying to give Parliament a position regarding the future perspective of the Energy Union. I agree with the provision that it should be based on a common energy market which should, if necessary, be supported by a solidarity mechanism towards those Member States of the Union suffering as a result of the dominance of one energy supplier. I also support the view that the European Union's energy strategy should be based on making full use of all available energy resources, which would ultimately contribute to the objective of reducing the Union's dependence on coal. I am satisfied with the final proposal for a text that does not contain an attempt by certain groups within Parliament to increase the Union's 2030 renewable energy targets by resusciting them legally binding on all Member States. I also hold positive a compromise amendment that highlights concerns about the environmental impact of shale gas, but does not call for a ban on shale gas extraction, nor for new Union legislation in this segment. I also support the objectives in the report that lead to greater flexibility for The Member States of the Union in the decision-making segment on how to reduce their emissions. So I voted in favor.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report to the European Energy Union, as European energy policy ensures the functioning of the energy market and security of energy supply in accordance with Article 194 TFEU and promotes energy efficiency, energy saving, the development of renewable energy sources and the interconnection of energy networks. That is why we must stare at an efficient energy union and ensure energy independence.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Energy Union report, although some of the provisions of the document raised questions. Such questionable provisions included the torpedo of the construction of Nord Stream 2. I am of the view that the attitude towards Nord Stream 2 is too politicised, and this fact prevents Members from making a weighted decision. We do not like Russia as a gas supplier, but the fact is that the alternative to Russian gas – in the necessary quantity and at reasonable prices – Europe does not have and will not be in the near future. It was the constant misunderstandings with Ukraine that led to the construction of Nord Sream 1. If, because of short-sighted policies in Europe, gas shortages are to arise, prices will start to rise. So it is not necessary to take these issues lightly – there is also a need for pragmatic considerations in politics.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the Gróbarczyk report because we do not share the European Commission's vision of the Energy Union. Energy should not be the subject of financial benefits but should be regarded as a common good and the cornerstone of the fight against climate change. There are no proposals in this report to solve the problem of energy poverty affecting four million people in the Spanish State. The report is highlighted by its clear support for nuclear energy, which seriously jeopardizes our safety and our environment. In addition, it leaves the door open to hydraulic fracturing.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 My former colleague Marek Gróbarczyk did a very good job on the Energy Union report and managed to negotiate a balanced text at the ECR. Personally, I consider the Energy Union to be an important project and the approved report contains a number of important points. Unfortunately, amendments that distort the original balance have also passed in plenary, and I am thinking in particular of binding targets for energy efficiency for The Member States. Therefore, I could not support the report as a whole in the final vote.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. A European energy market is an important initiative that could potentially promote the competitiveness and energy security of the European economy. The report was initially balanced and reasonable. However, it has been significantly worsened by many amendments. For example, technology openness and neutrality have been abolished and replaced by arbitrarily defined unilateral regulatory objectives. I firmly believe that Parliament must be guided by Council decisions when it came to targets, rather than arbitrarily proposing high objectives that are difficult to achieve. Member States should know better what is realistic and feasible and what is not. Because the report has taken on a monodimensional and anti-technology form through the numerous amendments, I have chosen to vote against the report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Future of Europe is also linked to its energy policy. A good mix of energy sources have to be found and we should avoid being dependent on a few specific countries for gas for example. Renewable energies should be prioritised and in Spain the investments in it should be protected and secured. This is not the case today. When thinking energy mix, we should also keep in mind the importance of the Paris Agreement, adopted by 195 governments on Saturday 12 December at 19:30, is the first legally binding international agreement in which all countries have a shared obligation for taking concrete action to combat climate change and to keep global temperature rise within safe limits.  This historic climate agreement gives a clear signal that the world has taken an irreversible step towards a low carbon economy. Individuals, governments and businesses must now start implementing the agreement. Only national policies and new investments priorities can give the Paris outcome legs. This has to be kept in mind when deciding our future energy mix and electricity sources.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report deals with the establishment of the Energy Union, a key topic of the Juncker Commission's programme. The document contains some positive points, notably the partly Eurosceptic tone of the report recalling, for example, the national prerogative to choose the energy mix. But too many points remain prohibitive. This report: is oriented pro polluting companies and proposes in particular the exploitation of shale gas and oil, under the name "unconventional energy sources"; denounces Russia as an unreliable partner; unqualified support for Russia's gas pipeline and bypass projects; supports the proposal, contained in the communication, for control from the outset of the negotiation of gas agreements by the European Commission; De facto prohibits Gazprom from accessing the european distribution market; devotes a full paragraph to denouncing Russia's monopoly on the supply of certain Member States; calls for energy to be included in the TTIP. This text also supports the Commission's thesis of the creation of a liberalised energy market. This means the elimination of regulated tariffs, monopolies and long-term contracts, in favour of market prices, speculative spot markets and widespread interconnection. I therefore vote AGAINST the adoption of this report.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is currently the world's largest energy importer, importing 53% of the energy it consumes, for an annual cost of around EUR 400 billion. Old energy infrastructure, poor integration of energy markets, lack of coordination of national energy policies generally lead to consumers and businesses not benefiting from a wide range of options or lower prices. Thus, electricity prices are more than twice those in the US and Russia and 20% higher than those in China. Climate change is added to non-competitive energy prices and extremely high dependence on third-country suppliers, together jeopardising the sustainability of the European energy system. Improving energy interconnections between Member States and modernising infrastructures would help to limit energy dependency and the risk of supply disruptions. Moreover, building a common energy market would facilitate access to energy markets across national borders. This would provide safe and sustainable sources of energy as well as affordable prices for citizens and businesses within the EU. I therefore voted in favour of the Report entitled 'Towards a European Energy Union'.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union should adopt a common approach, focusing on dimensions such as the completion of a fully integrated internal energy market, security of supply, best use of EU energy sources, reduction of energy demand, reduction of greenhouse gases, essentially based on renewable energy sources and the EU-wide carbon market, and research and innovation aimed at gaining leadership in energy technology; stresses that citizens should be at the heart of the Energy Union, for whom secure, sustainable and affordable energy must be provided. I voted in favour of the full report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the Gróbarczyk report because we do not share the European Commission's vision of the Energy Union. Energy should not be the subject of financial benefits but should be regarded as a common good and the cornerstone of the fight against climate change. There are no proposals in this report to solve the problem of energy poverty affecting four million people in the Spanish State. The report is highlighted by its clear support for nuclear energy, which seriously jeopardizes our safety and our environment. In addition, it leaves the door open to hydraulic fracturing.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree that a common energy market must be the cornerstone of the Energy Union and that the Energy Union must provide EU citizens with secure, sustainable and affordable energy. Renewables not only reduce import dependence, but also play a crucial role in improving air quality and creating jobs and growth. There is also a need to make the best use of existing national and cross-border energy infrastructure in order to use energy effectively and strengthen security of supply. In this very important and comprehensive document we also called on Member States and the Commission to seek for better interaction and coordination of national and European research programmes, especially in the fields of energy, transport, ICT and construction, in order to ensure that priority is given to common challenges such as increasing energy efficiency by not focusing only on the heating sector but also on cooling, promoting small-scale renewable energies, reducing greenhouse gas emissions as well as increasing energy security and developing new renewable energy sources, and to maximise the market uptake of new technologies.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a strategic report that touches on important aspects of the Energy Union such as energy security, the need to diversify energy sources and supply routes or the initiatives needed to complete the domestic energy market. After important work in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, a text has been obtained with broad commitment and an important political message. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. 'The report makes it clear that we need a European and regional approach to connecting energy networks between member states. This is necessary to cope with fluctuations in renewable energy. Our delegation is also committed to energy efficiency. The best and cheapest kilowatt hour is the one that is not used. The resolution is on this line. The transition to a real market system for energy is necessary. To do this, market-distorting subsidies and taxes must be extinguished as quickly as possible.  Parliament approved higher targets for renewable energy, efficiency and greenhouse gases. The delegation voted against this in order to honour the agreement between the Member States. Although certain elements are not in line with our views, the overall package sends a clear signal on how the energy union should be formed.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I see the added value of a European energy union. This can only benefit European citizens. That is why I voted in favour of this report. On the nuclear aspect, however, I think it is necessary that nuclear research can still be subsidised.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted against this report by the European Parliament entitled 'Towards a European Energy Union'. The EU's fundamental energy policy guidelines are in complete contradiction with the modest progress achieved at COP 21 in Paris. Following the Commission's proposal for an Energy Union, this resolution follows the same guidelines: the use of nuclear energy and fossil fuels, low ambition in promoting renewable energy, capture and storage of CO2. One of the few real positives is the demand for a binding 40% energy efficiency target, which is necessary but insufficient on its own. This is a far cry from any climate ambition in which the energy issue would be integrated; we remain in a mercantile approach giving pride of place to the large energy groups, ignoring any energy-based approach as a public good.  Energy poverty and moderation of energy consumption are barely taken into account. We therefore remain in continuity, far from any ambitious energy policy, capable of responding to the fight against global warming.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The so-called "European Energy Union" is based on the privatisation and liberalisation of national energy sectors. We are well known what has led to the liberalisation of this sector within the framework of the single market, with the establishment of transnational monopolies that exploit energy consumption markets by accumulating prodigious profits, while energy prices for consumers and micro, small and medium-sized enterprises are increasingly at an affordable level in energy access and prices. Only a public energy sector of the State, in ownership and management, will guarantee energy prices accessible to the population and the maintenance of sovereignty in the definition of national energy strategies. Responding to improved energy efficiency, diversification of sources, progress in renewable energy, adequate use of each country's endogenous potential, security of supply, reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, among others, require public, democratic planning and control of the energy sector, energy production and distribution.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. For my part, there can only be agreement on plans for a European Energy Union if there is a clear rejection of nuclear energy. This is not the case in this report. I therefore reject this report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As my own constituents in the North-West of England have been hit by the floods of Storm Desmond, the EU must do all it can to invest in sustainable energy, and in the fight against climate change.  EU energy policy must refocus from centring on fossil fuel to focusing on renewables, energy efficiency and intelligent infrastructure. There must be urgent action on energy poverty, which the European Commission must lead by presenting a communication on energy poverty in Europe, accompanied by an action plan to fight against it. If properly implemented, the Energy Union – the framework for upcoming legislation on energy – will ensure the energy transition to a clean, renewable future, putting the interests of consumers first and ensuring a secure, stable, affordable energy system.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is the Parliament's response to the European Commission Energy Union Strategy. I voted in favour of this report as I strongly believe that the Energy Union, if properly implemented, will ensure the energy transition to a clean, renewable future, while putting citizens centre-stage and ensuring a secure, stable, affordable energy system.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the road to a European Energy Union because I believe that Europe needs a sustainable energy landscape based largely on energy efficiency, renewable energy and intelligent infrastructure. The important thing is to mobilise the resources immediately so that the necessary infrastructures that are needed in this direction can be built quickly.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament today approved the report 'Towards an Energy Union', a dossier which I followed as shadow rapporteur for the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Socialists. I am extremely pleased that the report has been shared in plenary by a large majority and, in my opinion, the text is a full success for my parliamentary group. I find the consolidated market truly balanced where it focuses decisively on renewable sources and energy efficiency, relaunches its commitment to a fully integrated market while paying particular attention to carbon leakage and to ensuring competitive and uniform prices in all Member States. In particular, I agree with the condemnation of the doubling of the Nord Stream gas pipeline, a project that seriously endangers the security of Europe's energy supplies and isolates Ukraine from the European gas distribution network.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A solidarity-based approach to energy trading in the European Union is crucial for our future. Not only the economic one, for which the price of energy and its availability is extremely important, but also for its political dimension and the EU's independence from pressure from key suppliers, including Russia, on individual Member States. I agree that it is extremely important to strive for greater efficiency in the use of available energy raw materials. Resource efficiency is a guarantee of a low price for the final customer and a way to reduce energy waste. I fully support the call to exploit the potential of the ESI Funds in the process of modernising the European economy in the area of energy production and transport. If the text adopted in the ITRE Committee were to be voted on, I would have no doubt that I would support it. Unfortunately, the amendments that have been proposed and adopted have changed this very sensible report, which takes into account the interests of all Member States, into another tool to stigmatise and pressure m.in. Poland to give up coal as a basic energy resource. I do not agree with such an ideologically motivated approach and pushing for solutions that will result in job losses and rising energy prices. Once again, Europe is putting the economic security of its citizens at stake when it comes to climate commitments. I voted against this report.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report "Towards a European Energy Union" because I believe that its current lack of existence corresponds to the fragmentation of the Union's energy markets and is extremely detrimental to Europe's competitiveness and security. As such, I believe that the political and legislative package on which the creation of a European Energy Union is based will be important for the development of a European energy market, which will have as central priorities the focus on renewable energy, the guarantee and diversification of the Union's energy supply, the strengthening of energy sovereignty, the increase in energy efficiency and the progressive decarbonisation of the economy and social organisation models and the focus on innovation and research to put the Union on the frontier of energy transition leadership. However, for it to continue to lead the energy transition, political intelligence, mobilisation of citizens and businesses, regulatory flexibility, convergence of efforts between the 28 Member States and the ability to attract investment are needed. This is the only way to establish a robust and credible European energy market, less dependent, innovative and aligned with the challenges of the planet's sustainability.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The so-called "European Energy Union" is a custom-made project of the major European monopolies in the sector, and it is certainly not disproportionate to say that documents such as this report are, in essence, its specifications. The energy sector is liberalised and privatised in the various Member States and then says that energy must be accessible to all and that energy poverty must be combated. Will there be greater contradiction? The liberalisation of this sector, within the framework of the single market, has served as the establishment of transnational private monopolies that colonise markets by accumulating prodigious profits, while energy prices for consumers and micro, small and medium-sized enterprises reach unaffordable values. The disparity in energy access and prices is growing. We voted against it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The report was born with a strongly pro-nuclear imprint but with a considerable effort, we in the 5 Star Movement managed to ensure that the final text had more ambitious European targets in favour of renewable energy and energy efficiency. Furthermore, thanks to an amendment by the 5-Star Movement, the European Parliament has deleted from the document that part of the text granting EU funding for nuclear power. The report has no legislative value. It is, however, an important policy document which will weigh on the EU's energy choices and which affirms the will of the European Parliament. I therefore voted against the report as a whole, because no other content has been deleted which we consider unacceptable. In fact, the text states that renewable, fossil and nuclear sources should be considered and promoted in the same way according to the concept of 'technological neutrality'. Furthermore, the problem of security and energy independence is solved by promoting the construction of massive infrastructure, such as gas pipelines, so that the EU is able to import fossil energy from as many suppliers as possible. These are concepts with which I do not agree, and I voted for them.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on towards the European Energy Union, as energy malnutrition is one of the EU's most fatal shortcomings. Energy today divides the European political scene even more than it links, because it is the national egoisms that come to the fore in this area.  The European Union needs an ambitious and strong Energy Union. It is therefore important to implement the concept of the energy community quickly and to include other neighbouring countries, e.g. Norway. For Europe's future, a low-carbon economy is a necessity, because the only so-called clean energy will save us from dependence on Russian gas and Arab oil.  Particular emphasis should be placed on the divezication of energy sources and supply routes. We must focus on more affordable and secure energy supplies and better governance, where the European Parliament must also play its part. A fully integrated internal energy market could save consumers (by 2030) between €12 billion and €40 billion a year.  The 10% electricity interconnection target by 2020 is a valuable step in the right direction, and we must help Member States that are not yet achieving this and are heavily isolated from the internal electricity market. When the EU "speaks with one voice" in the field of energy and frees itself from this energy dependency, we will also be a major player on a global scale in the policy field.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, today the longest interconnector in Europe is being designed, between south-east Northumberland and Norway. Using a sub-sea cable, energy generated from renewable sources will be transferred between our countries, and it is a blueprint for Europe on how renewables can be traded as part of the Energy Union. The proposed Energy Union offers key opportunities for us in the North—East, firstly because we have the manufacturing knowhow needed to deliver from oil and gas industries to renewables, and secondly because we understand the North Sea. But funding new low-carbon technologies such as carbon capture storage is crucial if we want to meet our climate and energy commitments, particularly those taken in Paris last week: projects like the Teesside Collective. George Osborne’s slashing of national renewables in CCS funding represents short—termism incarnate. Energy Union is the opposite. It is about investment and jobs long-term, and that is why I supported the reports today.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, but there are one or two issues I would like to highlight. Firstly, the report says that the ambitious energy targets should be agreed by the regions. This is very important because a one-size-fits-all approach to reaching the 10% target certainly will not work everywhere. It is important that we have demand-led targets, rather than generating capacity targets, as this could mean that we would have over-building of infrastructure in certain regions.  Secondly, this report clearly references the need to use Best Available Technology (BAT) and this clearly means that undergrounding should be part of the mix. Indeed, it mentions the need for local acceptance, which is crucial to ensure that we can meet our interconnector targets. Otherwise projects can face long delays and planning appeals, and the cost will often exceed the original higher cost of undergrounding. Finally, the process of conducting transparent assessments when leading to the list of projects of common interest is crucially important and should be carried out on a cost—neutral basis at arm’s length from the promoters.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of an intensive electrification system for the industrial sector is essential and indispensable for a complete energy transition. The Eriksson report aims to create a European electricity grid for 2020 that is in harmony with recent technological development in the field of generation, consumption and finally transmission. The report focuses on the enormous potential of renewable energies and their indisputable benefits, but notes that the results obtained so far are conditioned by a strong discontinuity of the organisational network. Achieving an interconnection of the European electricity grid will undoubtedly make it possible to strengthen the exploitation of these resources, to solve the problem of structural discontinuity and to obtain greater benefits. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, despite considering the energy interconnection between the Member States of the Union positive, because in the specific case of Spain, interconnection with France is being used as a false measure to solve the crisis in the renewables sector. Interconnection is a necessary measure to be able to modulate the differences between the different countries of the Union, producing potentially more resilient systems thanks to its network configuration. However, in Spain, the Government is hiding in interconnection to deny the impact that its retroactive reform of regulation is having on the renewable energy sector. Another problem point of the interconnection between Spain and France is the making available and increasing dependence on the import of French nuclear energy, inhibiting the development of an energy model that allows it to be abandoned. That is why I abstained in the final vote on this report.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report on electricity interconnection. I particularly welcome that the report stresses explicitly that Projects of Common Interest (PCI) must be developed in a more transparent and accountable manner and crucially take into account economic, social and environmental impacts. It further underlines that public awareness and support is essential and projects should be coherent with local acceptance. The current proposal for the North-South Interconnector on the other hand, ignores the issue of needing local acceptance. Whilst Sinn Féin recognise the need for better electricity connections across the island, communities from both the North and South of Ireland have expressed their strong concerns and rejection of any proposed overhead pylon connection. Sinn Féin stands with these concerned local communities and demands that any electricity connection along the North-South Interconnection is undergrounded.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Without the cross-border free flow of energy, there can be no real internal energy market in the EU. Against this background, the reshaping of the electricity market, which is the subject of this resolution, is a right and important step in this direction. To this end, the formation of electricity networks is essential, which both promotes the spread of renewable energies and lowers electricity prices in Europe.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on achieving the 10% interconnection target in the electricity sector. It outlines the prospects for a European electricity grid ready for 2020. On the whole, this text recalls the reality that Member States are best able to deal with the problem of energy poverty in the Union. In addition, this text recalls the exclusive competence of states to define the energy mix.  So I voted for it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In voting against this measure, I note that the proposed interconnection target would cost in the region of EUR 40 billion.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it encourages the creation of a better interconnection of electricity grids, both for renewable energy. This crucial step must help us achieve our climate goals and make Europe more competitive with cheaper electricity.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. As long as interconnection does not mean interdependence but rather a lever of power and an increase in our autonomy, I am in favour of it. I regret, however, that we want to involve Turkey at the same time as we are trying at all costs to cut ourselves off from our natural strategic partner, Russia.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have endorsed this resolution which welcomes the Commission's communication and strategy, which are a positive step towards achieving the 10% interconnection target in the electricity sector and improving the functioning of the Union's internal electricity market. Parliament affirms that renewable energy, improved energy efficiency, a sustainable energy mix that generates energy savings and an internal energy market for the free flow of energy are important means of ensuring a stable, safe, independent, inclusive, transparent and competitive energy system at EU level, which promotes the creation of quality jobs and wealth in a sustainable, forward-looking economy. The resolution also stresses that electricity interconnection is one of the preconditions for the completion of an internal integrated electricity market, which, if properly designed, will achieve our climate targets, including the EU's objective of becoming a leader in renewable energy.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the Eriksson report because interconnection can be an obstacle to the development of renewable energy in Spain and facilitates the sale of nuclear energy from France to Spain. The text – apart from some cosmetic paragraphs – does not place this prospect of interconnection of electricity networks within the framework of renewable development and energy transition. It first aims to achieve an integrated internal electricity market, in fact ruling out any public control over energy production. In addition, this report promotes PCIs (projects of common interest). These projects pose a threat to the environment and are based on a hypercentralized, opaque production model that favors large companies. We therefore consider that, in a situation other than the electricity sector, where renewables are better extended and implemented and the sector is more democratic, decentralized and under public supervision, interconnection would be a desirable objective, but we do not believe that their implementation at the present time will achieve these objectives on its own or with the limited measures detailed in this regard in the report.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. From this Parliament we are continually talking about the importance of moving towards a true European market for more integrated, competitive and sustainable energy. However, we still find that some countries have a strong energy dependence on imports, outdated infrastructure and very low electricity interconnections. I supported this initiative report on achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target because it is absolutely necessary to end the above and with the situation of clear discrimination that some countries face because of their geographical situation, that is the case in Spain. The energy interconnection with France, and therefore with the rest of Europe, will not only allow us to participate in the European energy market, but consumers can benefit from better prices. In addition, competition between electricity operators would be expanded and the promotion of the dominant position of electricity companies would be limited, which would certainly help tackle fraud such as the recent Spanish company Abengoa.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to support the work done by the rapporteur in this report, as well as by the shadow rapporteurs. I have not followed my group in Amendments Nos 4 and 5, which refer to the importance of the Commission Communication in achieving the 10% target, for which it will be necessary to urgently mobilisation all efforts at all levels. In addition, I voted against the amendment that the projects included in the first PIC list were not sufficient to achieve the interconnection target by 2020. From my point of view, the projects included in the current PIC list are not sufficient.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report builds on the previous report follows the European Commission's strategy to achieve the 10% interconnection target in the electricity sector. The report recognises that electricity interconnection is one of the preconditions for the completion of an integrated internal electricity market. The report encourages the Commission to assess the potential of a 'one-stop shop' at EU level. On the positive side, however, the report also insists that the list of projects of common interest be drawn up in a more transparent and responsible manner. Assessments should be comprehensive, including in terms of economic, social and environmental impacts, and should be carried out by qualified experts acting independently of project proponents. In view of the uncertainties surrounding this report, I have decided to abstain.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Eriksson report is acceptable, based on the Council's unanimous decision in 2014 to achieve a level of cross-border interconnectivity between electricity grids of 10% by 2020. I therefore intended to support it with my vote.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has made Parliament express its position on how the European electricity network should be complied with by 2020. Parliament notes in the report that electricity interconnections are one of the most important conditions for achieving our climate change objectives, including the EU's objective of becoming a leader in renewable sourcing, and improving the EU's geopolitical position through greater energy security and independence and reducing energy isolation, and reducing the possibility of energy bottlenecks. Increased capacity of the European network will enable us to develop a strategy that will lead to a more flexible and robust network, better prepared for a wide range of changes and bottlenecks, and will enable more and more energy from renewable sources to be infused into the European network. Parliament's report also seeks to draw the Commission's attention to information and communication technologies as information and communication technologies become increasingly important in electricity networks, increasing cyber threats to the security of electricity systems, and therefore asks the Commission to assess the risks to the safety of the electricity system and, if necessary, to draw up an action plan to combat threats.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is a response to the Commission Communication "Achieving the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks". The report welcomes the achievement of the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks. It stresses that the interconnection of energy networks is a prerequisite for the achievement of an integrated internal electricity market, which, if properly designed, can help Europe achieve its climate objectives. I agree with the report's comment that the lengthy authorisation procedure makes it very difficult to build new high-voltage pipelines. It is important for Member States to facilitate faster procedures. The report strengthens the regional approach when linking markets. Hungary, the electricity interconnection index is 29% – i.e. far above the 10% target for interconnection – and thus does not mean a new obligation for the country. I agree with the principles and directions set out in the report, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I am convinced that the proposed report is an important step towards greater energy efficiency in the EU, as well as its reduced dependence on external resources. I agree that a fully integrated internal electricity market would facilitate electricity trading, it would also increase security and reduce the instability of electricity prices.  The latter would thus benefit citizens who would pay less for electricity consumption than improve the efficiency and competitiveness of European industry and businesses in the global economy. Annual savings go into billions, so serious work needs to be done to make the electricity market as connected as possible. In this regard, I also welcome the role of the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER), which can play a major role in achieving savings in this area. The Agency, which is based in Slovenia, has been struggling with human resources and financial hardship for a long time, and I join the report's call to provide the necessary resources for ACER, especially enough staffing. Only in this way will it be able to carry out the tasks set out in the legislation of a qualitative way.  ACER should also strengthen its role in coordinating cross-border regulatory matters, while making it mandatory to work together with national regulatory authorities.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target is an important step for the wider Project of the Union of European Energy Markets. The achievement of the Energy Union wants efficient and solidarity instruments, and better interconnection responds to the need to ensure that the common objectives from which we all benefit, a stronger and more resilient network, are achieved. It is not only a question of taking advantage of cheap electricity and lower prices for businesses, but also of strengthening a network that frees up synergies capable of consolidating the internal system and removing its imbalances. In this respect, interest is in the elimination of the various energy islands (Poland, Great Britain, the Iberian Peninsula). A balanced approach, a transparent process and a commitment to maintaining high levels of ambition are indispensable in a project that aims to ensure stability, competitiveness and growth. I support this report, which, by combining the economic and geopolitical dimension, outlines a strategy for strengthening the Union.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Cheaper energy for consumers, more transparent accounting, and more choices are key determinants that I support.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Most EU Member States have outdated and poorly integrated internal electricity grids with one another. At present, the Union still has to achieve the modest target of 10% cross-border interconnection of electricity networks set out in the Europe 2020 document.  A European electricity grid would mean a price reduction of at least EUR 2 per MWh, security of supply close to 100%, greater capacity to deal with cyber or war attacks on the electricity grid (today resilience to possible such acts is too low) and other concrete benefits, such as reducing the volatility of electricity prices to the benefit of citizens and the competitiveness of European industry and businesses in the global economy , together with an estimated saving for European consumers of between EUR 12 billion and EUR 40 billion per year by 2030.   We therefore call on the European Commission to encourage investment in the best available techniques which offer considerable financial benefits throughout the life cycle of the networks, save time and play a technological driving role in the long term and carry out a general review of the technical and management system of the European electricity grid.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the preparation of Europe's electricity grid for 2020 underlines the importance of a forward-looking policy in which the Union assumes to increase the level of electricity interconnection to 10% by 2020. This objective is a valuable one, which establishes a safe and sustainable direction of the electricity system. At the moment, 12 Member States located mainly on the periphery of the Union remain below the 10% threshold of the interconnection target, being isolated from the internal electricity market.  I was in favour of this report because a joint effort is needed to support Member States whose low level of connectivity prevents the completion of the internal electricity market from meeting this objective. As a result, an assiduous determination is needed to achieve the goals set and an intensification of work in the groups approved on this issue.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 In October 2014, the Council unanimously set a target of achieving 10% cross-border interconnectivity of the electricity grid by 2020 (and 15% by 2030), in order to complete the internal energy market and improve energy security in the EU. This objective (political, not based on scientific basis) is in itself acceptable. It has to be said that the lack of interconnectivity actually affects only a few member states (basically always the usual: energy islands) to which priority will be given. Despite the vote in favour, it is worth pointing out two concerns first of all: 1) the objective of interconnectivity is intended as a prodromic to the achievement of the Energy Union, which we oppose at its root (see Gróbarczyk report); 2) In general, THE EU's energy policy is "polluted" by climate policy: the pursued model of "energy austerity" is an obstacle to reindustrialisation and, therefore, to the prospects for economic growth, moreover with no environmental compensation (in absolute terms, global CO2 emissions will not decrease, allow and not allow CO2 to be a problem). Vote.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 10 % electricity interconnection target first set in 2002 on the basis of the electricity generation capacity at the time must be achieved by 2020. The 10 % target does not reflect the amount of electricity transferred between countries or its quality, such as the availability of existing interconnection infrastructure or existing national infrastructure between interconnections. There are still 12 Member States, mainly located in the regions on the periphery of the EU, which still remain below the 10% threshold, and are therefore strongly isolated from the internal electricity market.  I support the EP resolution motion because I believe that renewable energy, energy efficiency and the sustainable energy mix that generateenergy savings and lead to an internal energy market that allows free energy flow are important means for a stable, independent, secure, transparent, inclusive and competitive energy system in the EU that generates quality jobs in a sustainable future-oriented economy. I consider the creation of such a system and the elimination of energy islands as a major political priority of the European Union.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the report on 'Achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target - A European electricity grid ready for 2020', as I consider the achievement of the 10% electricity interconnection target and the improvement of the functioning of the internal electricity market in the EU to be strategic; all key issues for achieving a secure, independent, inclusive, transparent and competitive Energy Union. There is an absolute need for an integrated approach to this issue, with a view to strengthening national networks in order to be able to make full use of the capacity of interconnections and in order to make the best use of existing interconnection lines and the capacity of existing national infrastructures. The frequent congestion of transmission networks may be associated with cross-border lines but also due to the weakness and obsolescence of internal networks and the limited availability of national networks.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP reject the EU Commission proposal on the achievement of a 10% electricity interconnection target which is designed to facilitate the use of expensive renewables. We oppose EU climate and energy policy that is one of the most expensive and yet unsuccessful policies the world has ever seen. We oppose expensive renewables and believe that Member States should favour the exploitation of indigenous energy, including fossil fuel.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proper functioning of the internal energy market also involves interconnections that guarantee electricity security within the Union, especially in the cross-border areas most exposed to energy crises. Having an interconnected network in Europe is essential, as it ensures a safe, sustainable and lower-cost energy. In 2002, the Union set itself the objective of achieving 10% energy interconnection by 2020, which, unfortunately, is not likely to be achievable for 12 Member States. These are mostly more isolated countries than the single energy market. There have been a number of delays, both because of the lengthy authorisation procedures, especially for high-voltage lines, and because of the lack of funds.
