This last difficulty could, however, be overcome through the use of the Connecting Europe Mechanism, a financial instrument which should, as Requested by Parliament, pay particular attention to projects aimed at addressing the most serious shortcomings in the current integrated electricity market. In the report adopted, the Commission is also urged to consider the use of the EIB and other financial instruments to achieve the Community objective. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is quite rightly stressed in the report that Europe's energy system has evolved since 2002, when the 10% electricity interconnection target was first set, bearing in mind that renewable energy sources have been developed across the continent. In this context, the 15% target, based on installed power for 2030, should not be left alone and should be carefully and thoroughly assessed to ensure that it is fit for purpose, and is relevant and feasible. They are also important: (a) the implementation in national and EU policy of the 'priority for energy efficiency' principle and more demand-side measures, (b) the development of decentralised renewable energy sources and related smart grids, (c) national decisions on the energy mix, taking into account the EU's long-term climate and energy objectives; , inter alia, at household and municipal level, (e) the use of the best available technologies on a case-by-case basis, (f) the recognition of individuals as consumer producers in the energy system and (g) the creation of clear incentives to invest in networks. We therefore support the report.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on achieving the 10 % electricity interconnection target – Making Europe's electricity grid ready for 2020 is a positive attempt to complete the interconnection of Europe's electricity networks. As part of the wider objective of upgrading European infrastructure for 2020, while using more environmentally friendly elements, I think it should be supported. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. Parliament recognised the 10% interconnection target as an important step in the right direction and stressed that interconnectivity was one of the basic prerequisites for the completion of the internal electricity market. In parliament's view, particular attention should be paid to projects addressing the most significant gaps in the Union's integrated electricity market. Parliament also considered that the purely quantitative target of 10% should not be isolated, because accessibility to interconnections and networks is also necessary to ensure that interconnection devices work in practice.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal aimed at preparing a common European electricity grid in 2020. I am very close to environmental and energy issues, I would like to see a European energy system optimised with renewable energies, greater energy efficiency and a sustainable energy mix leading to energy savings, as well as an internal energy market that allows energy to move freely. These conditions are important for creating a stable and safe energy system. In particular, I am of the opinion that electricity interconnection is one of the basic prerequisites for completing an integrated EU internal electricity market which, if well defined, will help to achieve the climate objectives that I particularly care about; in particular, there is talk of a strategic principle that should lead to a more resilient and robust network, able to respond better to all forms of disruption and change. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report recognises the 10% interconnection target as an important step in the right direction. It stresses that interconnectivity is one of the key preconditions for completing the internal electricity market. With regard to those Member States that have not yet reached 10%, the report states that more should be done to assist them.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The existence of an internal market for free movement of energy and the increase of renewable sources and energies and an optimal level of energy efficiency are fundamental challenges for the EU to have a stable, secure energy system dependent on a sustainable and future-oriented wealth-creating economy. Electrical interconnection is one of the essential preconditions for the completion of an integrated internal energy market that goes beyond any purely economic and geopolitical vision, but is based on a strategic principle of a more resilient and robust network, environmentally friendly and capable of dealing with all kinds of disturbances. I support the Eriksson report because it considers it important to achieve the 10% target by 2020 and that, in addition to the quantitative target, progress is made in the free access and availability of interconnections, which are indispensable for the removal of remaining barriers to market functioning. I deplore the behaviour of some Member States in pursuing these principles by blocking the interconnection of networks on the grounds of protectionism of their market by provoking energy islands, such as the Iberian Peninsula, whose capacity with continental Europe is too small and the current projects of common interest are not sufficient to achieve the interconnection target by 2020.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it is important for the proper functioning of the internal energy market to improve electricity interconnection, removing bottlenecks in the grid, building new transmission lines and developing new local smart grids. A fully integrated internal electricity market would increase security and independence from other countries, reducing the volatility of electricity prices to the benefit of citizens and the competitiveness of European industry and businesses in the global economy.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – Europe needs greater energy security and independence to reduce energy isolation and the possibility of perturbations in the energy system. This proposal recognises the 10% interconnection target as an important step in the right direction. It stresses that interconnectivity is one of the key preconditions for completing the internal electricity market. Special attention must be given to projects that address the most significant gaps in the integrated EU electricity market. To reach these goals we need a holistic approach at EU level, as the EU has to ensure accessible electricity market and facilitate a decentralised energy system. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Eriksson report gives an opinion on the achievement of the minimum 10% target for electricity interconnections proposed by the committee, and seeks to form a position on this by placing it within the main axes of the European Union's energy and infrastructure policy. The intensive electrification project of our industrial system is essential for the energy transition, therefore for the fight against climate change and towards energy independence. It is essential to actively guide the evolution of the European electricity grid, making it intelligent, highly interconnected and open to the technological evolution that is taking place both on the generation side and on the consumption and transmission side itself. A network without a high degree of interconnection cannot fully exploit the potential offered by renewables. The essential problem with such a general political objective, 'one size fits all', is that even if it signals the right direction to move, it does not take into account the territorial, geographical and energy diversity of the Member States. However, I think the report is a good one, and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, despite considering the energy interconnection between the Member States of the Union positive, because in the specific case of Spain, interconnection with France is being used as a false measure to solve the crisis in the renewables sector. Interconnection is a necessary measure to be able to modulate the differences between the different countries of the Union, producing potentially more resilient systems thanks to its network configuration. However, in Spain, the Government is hiding in interconnection to deny the impact that its retroactive reform of regulation is having on the renewable energy sector. Another problem point of the interconnection between Spain and France is the making available and increasing dependence on the import of French nuclear energy, inhibiting the development of an energy model that allows it to be abandoned. That is why I abstained in the final vote on this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is in response to a Commission communication describing measures needed to meet the agreed target to ensure all Member States have in place sufficient electricity interconnectors with neighbouring countries with capacity to export/import at least 10% of their electricity generation capacity. It was a target originally set by EU Heads of State and Government in 2002 and should be reached by 2020. Keeping in mind Malta’s issues in relation to access to energy, and also in view of the recent switching on of the Malta-Sicily interconnector it is in Malta’s interest that such an issue keeps on being given priority on an EU level, hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the need to set a future electricity interconnection target on the basis of the EU's long-term climate objectives, as well as a sustainable energy system to which the European Union aspires.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report presents the European Parliament's recommendations for a European electricity grid, as part of the European Commission's proposals on the Energy Union last February.  In this text, MEPs make the 10% electricity interconnection target one of the preconditions for the completion of the internal electricity market. The report proposes to increase the EU's support for the lagging Member States in this area, paying particular attention to projects that address the failures of the EU's most important integrated electricity market.  As such, it points out that a fully integrated internal electricity market could save European consumers between 12 and 40 billion euros each year by 2030. Beyond a purely quantitative target of 10%, the text reminds us that the accessibility of interconnections and networks must be guaranteed for interconnections to work. Considering that this report is balanced and that it provides concrete solutions for the purchasing power of European citizens and the competitiveness of European businesses, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP reject the EU Commission proposal on the achievement of a 10% electricity interconnection target which is designed to facilitate the use of expensive renewables. We oppose EU climate and energy policy that is one of the most expensive and yet unsuccessful policies the world has ever seen. We oppose expensive renewables and believe that Member States should favour the exploitation of indigenous energy, including fossil fuel.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The development of interconnection in the electricity sector is an important step in achieving a fully integrated internal electricity market. However, this integrated market would facilitate energy trade within the European Union, thus increasing market stability and security while reducing the volatility of electricity prices. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this initiative report entitled Achieving the 10% interconnection target in the electricity sector - A European electricity grid ready for 2020.  Indeed, it makes a contribution to the debates on the reorganisation of the energy market, and in particular on the need to develop electricity interconnections within the Member States and between Member States.  Such an internal market would facilitate electricity trade and increase security while reducing price volatility for citizens and the competitiveness of European businesses in our global economy. European consumers could save between 12 and 40 billion euros each year by 2030.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report is a response to the Commission Communication "Achieving the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks". The report welcomes the achievement of the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks. The report emphasises that the interconnection of energy networks is a prerequisite for achieving an integrated internal electricity market, which, if properly designed, can help Europe achieve its climate objectives. The report notes that the lengthy authorisation procedure makes it very difficult to build new high-voltage lines; and calls on the Member States to facilitate faster procedures. Furthermore, the report strengthens the regional approach when linking markets. Hungary, the electricity interconnection index is 29% – i.e. far above the 10% target for interconnection – and thus does not mean a new obligation for the country. I agree with the principles and directions laid down in the report, and as a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I fully share the objectives of this report - to make a step point and call for accelerated measures to improve the interconnection of electricity grids in Europe. This interconnection is necessary given the very characteristics of electricity - a non-storeable fluid - requiring consumption where the needs may be, depending on the circumstances, away from the place of production. This is a prerequisite for "profitable" renewable energy production facilities, whether industrial or from consumers/producers. This is a necessity to ensure the energy security of the European continent.  This is why financial incentives must be given to limit investment risks (The Juncker Plan and EFSI, dedicated taxation) in sustainable, "smart" and connected technologies. In doing so, the competences of national authorities must also be respected; not to destabilize existing networks by wanting to co-exist two principles that are difficult to reconcile - energy independence and openness to competition. Similarly, this interconnection must not ignore the interests of citizens. It must serve climate objectives but also the values of public service such as accessibility, which involves connecting all territories and reducing energy bills.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report proposing several measures, including better interconnection of electricity networks, in order to gradually build a real European electricity grid. Investing in the integration of the European electricity market could reduce prices by at least 2 euros per MWh and save nearly 40 billion euros a year by 2030.  This interconnection is crucial, both to achieve our climate targets and to make Europe more competitive with cheaper electricity. The 10% interconnection target by 2020 is a very valuable contribution to the implementation of the Energy Union, but this target is only achievable if all Member States achieve it at the same time.  It will therefore be necessary to work with the twelve Member States which remain below the 10% electricity interconnection target and are therefore largely isolated from the internal electricity market. It also seems to me essential that the EU set ambitious complementary interconnection targets for 2030, based on evidence and approved by the regions.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ I fundamentally agree with the premise of supporting better connections across Europe in terms of access to, and the supply of, electricity.  These efforts have the potential to break down barriers to cross-border trade by supporting local businesses to internationalise through swifter, reliable and affordable energy supply. In aiming for a far-reaching expansion and consolidation of the electricity market, however, we must not forget about those in countries where supply is well established, but who still struggle to access electricity affordable for their homes and businesses. I think in particular of households and businesses in rural Northern Ireland, many of whom simply want the resources and support to set up home or their enterprise in their local, rural community. These are individuals who have faced clear challenges in recent years to connect to the grid. I know there are coordinated efforts being made by my colleagues in the Northern Ireland Executive to bridge these gaps, however I do feel there is more to be done at Westminster, and indeed within the EU institutions, to send a message that the overarching vision of a continent interconnected is more pertinent than protecting grassroots communities.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not support this report. There is no way to support something that recommends linking electricity network infrastructure with the Republic of Turkey and North Africa. In no way should the Union cooperate with countries that openly support one terrorist structure or another. It has been proven that in recent times the only thing North Africa exports is terrorists, and the only thing it imports is an illegal weapon. Even at some point this changes, it is unlikely that the electricity produced by them is energy efficient and meets the environmental requirements and standards that the EU strictly tries to impose.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against this report because it gives too many powers to the Commission, because it brings out to almost peer-to-peer countries outside the Union which, as is especially the case with Turkey, are also hostile to Member States, and, finally, because it does not even ensure the achievement of the objective of energy security for the Member States of the Union.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report is a response to the Commission Communication "Achieving the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks". The report welcomes the achievement of the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks. The report emphasises that the interconnection of energy networks is a prerequisite for achieving an integrated internal electricity market, which, if properly designed, can help Europe achieve its climate objectives. The report notes that the lengthy authorisation procedure makes it very difficult to build new high-voltage lines; and calls on the Member States to facilitate faster procedures. Furthermore, the report strengthens the regional approach when linking markets. Hungary, the electricity interconnection index is 29% – i.e. far above the 10% target for interconnection – and thus does not mean a new obligation for the country. I agree with the principles and directions laid down in the report, and as a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. This report, which focuses on the Commission communication 'Achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target - A ready-made electricity grid for 2020' is one of the main axes of the European Union's energy and infrastructure policy. Creating the optimal conditions to be able to fully electrify our industrial system is a key element towards energy transition, decarbonisation and the fight against climate change. Interconnection, therefore, seems essential to allow technological evolution and infrastructure choices that must create the conditions for making full use of energy produced from renewable sources. Interconnection projects, however, must take into account spatial and geographical variables that characterise the Member States and should, when choosing projects, have an approach that respects the sensitivities of the inhabitants of the places involved, just as they must take into account the results of environmental impact assessments. In essence: interconnections, yes, but not at all costs and above all respecting the rules that are often trampled underfoot by the interests generated by the high costs of these projects. I voted in favour.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. It is imperative to arrive, in the short term, and as a minimum goal in terms of interconnections, to 10% of installed generation capacity, as well as to 15% by 2030. This priority brought together the consensus of the European Commission, the Council and this Parliament in the previous parliamentary term. I am therefore sorry that, in a way, the Eriksson report, which is under discussion today, seems to call this priority into question. We have persistently seen the maintenance of what is a market failure, in the resolution of which we have an obligation to engage politically, without yielding to vested interests, which for years or even decades have prevented adequate integration of the energy market. Not to do so would be to condemn several Member States to their peripheral condition, not only of energy but also economic. I therefore voted in favour of the amendments which point to ways to strengthen that objective.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The advantages of creating interconnections between electricity networks enabling interoperability between the various Member States are important, for all the potential reasons pointed out in this resolution. However, as a significant part of the costs of interconnections, as well as the systems associated with them in each State, it is borne by the consumers of those States, it is essential to be careful that the potential benefits come to fruition and outsof potential losses. It is therefore necessary that, as the objectives are set, the effects of the resulting actions are judiciously heavy. Issues which this report unfortunately does not deepen. Portugal, which has been diligently applying the EU's energy guidelines, has supported and bears the heavy costs of this application, but still does not see the proposed benefits, especially in the price that costs it electricity – and which has a hard impact on households and businesses, especially mSMEs. It would be important to correct the distortions that have been observed and to protect consumers and economies, especially those most in need of stimulus. It will be necessary to be careful that interconnections and market mechanisms will not render useless investment in renewable energy (the surpluses of French nuclear will certainly be more competitive), and that it is not national consumers who strongly subsidize these renewable energies so that they are competitive on the European market.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because improving electricity interconnections will lead to an increase in security of energy supply and a strengthening of the internal market.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Electricity interconnection is one of the basic preconditions for completing the European Union's integrated internal market in electricity, which will help achieve the European Union's climate objectives, including the objective of leading the field of renewables, and improve the geopolitical position of the European Union, including through increased energy security and independence. A fully integrated internal electricity market would also facilitate electricity trading and balancing services, increase security and reduce the volatility of electricity prices, not only for the benefit of European industry in the global economy, but also for the benefit of citizens, so that European consumers could save BETWEEN EUR 12 and 40 billion per year by 2030.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report, which unanimously set a target of achieving 10% cross-border interconnectivity of the electricity grid by 2020 (and 15% by 2030). It has to be said that the lack of interconnectivity actually affects only a few member states (essentially always the usual: energy islands), to which priority will be given.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because I believe that it gives too many powers to the Commission, because it brings out to almost peer countries outside the Union that, as is especially the case for Turkey, are also hostile to Member States, and because it ultimately does not ensure the achievement of the objective of energy security for the Member States of the Union.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is in response to a Commission communication describing measures needed to meet the agreed target to ensure all Member States have in place sufficient electricity interconnectors with neighbouring countries with capacity to export/import at least 10% of their electricity generation capacity. It was a target originally set by EU Heads of State and Government in 2002 and should be reached by 2020. Some eight Member States are still to meet the target. We need strong political support and new measures to ensure Europe’s electricity network is properly connected in order to avoid Member States being isolated, ensure a true internal energy market as part of the Energy Union and bring down the costs of integrating renewable energy into the grid.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report is a response to the Commission Communication "Achieving the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks". The report welcomes the achievement of the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks. The report emphasises that the interconnection of energy networks is a prerequisite for achieving an integrated internal electricity market, which, if properly designed, can help Europe achieve its climate objectives. The report notes that the lengthy authorisation procedure makes it very difficult to build new high-voltage lines; and calls on the Member States to facilitate faster procedures. Furthermore, the report strengthens the regional approach when linking markets. Hungary, the electricity interconnection index is 29% – i.e. far above the 10% target for interconnection – and thus does not mean a new obligation for the country. I agree with the principles and directions laid down in the report, and as a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the conviction that it is essential to ensure the 10% electricity interconnection target between EU Member States in order to improve the functioning of the EU's internal electricity market. Renewable energy, increased energy efficiency and a combination of sustainable energies with a view to energy savings and an internal energy market are important for the EU to have a stable, secure, independent, inclusive, transparent and competitive energy system that generates quality and wealth jobs within the framework of a sustainable future-oriented economy.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Improving interconnections is a key and essential step towards achieving greater energy security and lower energy prices for European businesses and citizens. This is an essential element of the Energy Union, from which we expect a major contribution to the economy and employment.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I welcomed this own-initiative report, which, in addition to the Energy Union strategy, recognises that electricity interconnection is one of the key prerequisites for completing an internal electricity market in the EU. The text we voted on sets an ambitious target, which will help to achieve important climate commitments, including that of the EU to become a leader in the renewable energy sector, to improve the EU's geopolitical position through increased energy security and independence, as well as to reduce energy isolation and the possibility of disruption of energy systems.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the achievement of the 10% electricity interconnection target – preparing the European electricity grid for 2020, as I find it politically embarrassing to speak of an Energy Union when our borders have a permeability of just 2%. Even the target of 10% by 2020 is still too low from this point of view.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 According to Eurostat data, electricity consumption in kWh per capita in EU countries varies widely. Commissioner Cañete's statement that there is energy overproduction in Europe is statistically correct. However, the problem is its uneven distribution, which is not only due to the lack of interconnections. Cross-border concoctors are not in a position to solve this problem completely. Only future trans-European networks connecting East and West will improve the energy efficiency of peak power, and those connecting North and South will make the use of RES (wind in the North and solar power in the South) important in Europe. The lack of holistic network projects pushes back the vision of a genuine, forward-looking electricity market in Europe ad calendas graecas. When planning reliable interconnections within the EU itself, we must not cut ourself off from the energy systems of our neighbours. Given that the links between national systems are only the first, but not the most optimal, step towards EU energy solidarity, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The European electricity grid is an important part of a European Energy Union. It is precisely for this reason that states must be supported in integrating them into a common internal market. The internal energy market offers many advantages and its implementation must be pursued consistently.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as we need strong political support and new measures to ensure Europe’s electricity network is properly connected in order to avoid Member States being isolated, ensure a true internal energy market as part of the Energy Union and bring down the costs of integrating renewable energy into the grid.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. The interconnection of networks is not in itself a bad thing, for example to allow the export of surplus electricity production to neighbouring countries for the mutual benefit of the States concerned. The european Union's use of money to finance such projects with a real transnational dimension does not seem entirely abnormal either. The problem is that all this is part of the ideological project of the European Energy Union, which I oppose, and which obliges States to have a minimum interconnection percentage of 10%, of which I find difficult to grasp the economic relevance. The report also calls for increased financial resources and powers for the coordination agency of national energy regulators, ACER. He wants the agency to become a supervisory body and be able to make binding decisions for these regulators, such as a ban on favouring domestic consumers in the event of a supply problem. The Europe of Brussels has already demonstrated - currency, borders, trade policy... - its inadequacy, even its capacity for nuisance, when it claimed to act in place of states in areas related to national sovereignty. Let's not add any more.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the Eriksson report because interconnection can be an obstacle to the development of renewable energy in Spain and facilitates the sale of nuclear power from France to Spain. The text – apart from some cosmetic paragraphs – does not place this prospect of interconnection of electricity grids within the framework of renewable development and energy transition. It first aims to achieve an integrated internal electricity market, in fact ruling out any public control over energy production. In addition, this report promotes PCIs (projects of common interest). These projects pose a threat to the environment and are based on a hypercentralized, opaque production model that favors large companies. We therefore consider that, in a situation other than the electricity sector, where renewables are better extended and implemented and the sector is more democratic, decentralized and under public supervision, interconnection would be a desirable objective, but we do not believe that their implementation at the present time will achieve these objectives on its own or with the limited measures detailed in this regard in the report.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted In favour of this report as we need strong political support and new measures to ensure Europe’s electricity network is properly connected in order to avoid Member States being isolated, ensure a true internal energy market as part of the Energy Union and bring down the costs of integrating renewable energy into the grid.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP reject the EU Commission proposal on the achievement of a 10% electricity interconnection target which is designed to facilitate the use of expensive renewables. We oppose EU climate and energy policy that is one of the most expensive and yet unsuccessful policies the world has ever seen. We oppose expensive renewables and believe that Member States should favour the exploitation of indigenous energy, including fossil fuel.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. Our European energy market is gradually being established despite the obstacles it faces. One of these barriers is the lack of interconnections. However, we need it to make the energy market more flexible, and to ensure high security of supply, both within a Member State and between Member States through cross-border mesh zones.  Existing interconnections must be strengthened and used to the maximum of their capacity. Cost-benefit analyses should be used to compare different projects. It is also important to ensure that investors have a favourable framework for sustainable investment. More long-term contracts in the electricity market are needed to secure investment and encourage investment.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I see the Commission communication and strategy as a positive step towards achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target and improving the functioning of the internal electricity market in the EU.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report is a response to the Commission Communication "Achieving the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks". The report welcomes the achievement of the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks. The report emphasises that the interconnection of energy networks is a prerequisite for achieving an integrated internal electricity market, which, if properly designed, can help Europe achieve its climate objectives. The report notes that the lengthy authorisation procedure makes it very difficult to build new high-voltage lines; and calls on the Member States to facilitate faster procedures. Furthermore, the report strengthens the regional approach when linking markets. Hungary, the electricity interconnection index is 29% – i.e. far above the 10% target for interconnection – and thus does not mean a new obligation for the country. I agree with the principles and directions laid down in the report, and as a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote for this report because the 10% target which is to be achieved by 2020 is recognised as a valuable target and an important step in the right direction. With regards to those Member States that have not yet reached 10%, the report states that more should be done to assist them. Special attention must be given to projects that address the most significant gaps in the integrated EU electricity market.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In October 2014 the European Council requested that all Member States achieve interconnection of at least 10% of their installed electricity production capacity by 2020, meaning that 10% of electricity produced could possibly be transported to neighbouring countries, thus improving energy security and boosting the internal market. The report agrees with the general idea but it states that the 10% target could seem arbitrary and is not applicable to all Member States. It therefore proposes a more methodical approach based on the market dynamics and geographic considerations of the different countries. I agree with this position, as well as with the emphasis the report places on regional cooperation, and this is why I have voted in favour of it. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report is a response to the Commission Communication "Achieving the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks". The document welcomes the achievement of the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks. It stresses that the interconnection of energy networks is a prerequisite for the achievement of an integrated internal electricity market, which, if properly designed, can help Europe achieve its climate objectives. The lengthy approval process makes it very difficult to build new high-voltage lines. Member States should therefore seek to facilitate faster procedures. The document also aims to strengthen the regional approach when linking markets. Hungary, the electricity interconnection index is 29% – far above the 10% target for interconnection. Thus, it does not mean another obligation for the country. I agree with the principles and directions laid down in the report, and as a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report notes that offshore wind in the North Sea has the potential to generate 8% of Europe’s power supply by 2030, and much of this capacity is in Scottish waters. Scotland, however, has to operate within an irrational UK energy framework and transmission charges are prohibitively high for Scottish producers. Once again a Tory government at Westminster cuts Scotland off from the European mainstream.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report regarding electricity interconnection, which is one of the key preconditions for completing an integrated internal electricity market, which will help to improve the EU’s geopolitical position through greater energy security and independence and to achieve our climate objectives, including the EU’s aim to be the leader in renewables.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's report on the achievement of the 10% electricity interconnection target - the preparation of the European electricity network for 2020, as the creation of a physical interconnection of the energy network between EU members is one of the basic processes for creating an energy union.  The process requires several phases, long-term realisation with large investments that, apart from Member States, should be secured by the EU and the EIB. All advantages for Member States, the economy and citizens mentioned in the creation of the Energy Union can also be taken into account as advantages due to the electricity interconnection.  In addition to the 2020 plan, which needs to reach 10% of interconnections, steps and targets for further connectivity of the EU electricity network after 2020 should already be clearly prepared, taking into account the different levels of connectivity that exist in different REGIONS of the EU. It is particularly important to point out that this report also supports the inclusion of western Balkan countries that are not yet members of the EU.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on achieving the 10% interconnection target in the electricity sector. This report outlines the prospects for a European electricity grid ready for 2020. Overall, this text recalls the reality that Member States are best able to address energy poverty in the Union. In addition, this text recalls the exclusive competence of states to define the energy mix.  I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I rejected the EU Commission proposal on the achievement of a 10% electricity interconnection target which is designed to facilitate the use of expensive renewables. My colleagues and I oppose an EU climate and energy policy that is one of the most expensive and yet unsuccessful policies the world has ever seen. We oppose expensive renewables and believe that Member States should favour the exploitation of indigenous energy, including fossil fuel.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Peter Eriksson's report entitled "Achieving the 10% interconnection target in the electricity sector - A European electricity grid ready for 2020". This report makes a contribution to the debates on the reorganisation of the energy market, and in particular on the need to develop electricity interconnections within Member States and between Member States. It thus underlines the importance of reaching 10% interconnection between Member States in the electricity market, which is necessary to finalise the internal electricity market.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report recognises the importance that interconnectivity can bring to European energy markets. Thanks to its price zone with Germany, Austria is particularly benefiting from increased interconnectivity. However, the 10% target set, based on the watering can principle, must be applied to all countries without any basis for doing so. A targeted approach would be more appropriate, which is why I am abstaining from this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as we need strong political support and new measures to ensure Europe’s electricity network is properly connected in order to avoid Member States being isolated, ensure a true internal energy market as part of the Energy Union and bring down the costs of integrating renewable energy into the grid.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report is a response to the Commission Communication "Achieving the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks". The report welcomes the achievement of the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks. The report emphasises that the interconnection of energy networks is a prerequisite for achieving an integrated internal electricity market, which, if properly designed, can help Europe achieve its climate objectives. The report notes that the lengthy authorisation procedure makes it very difficult to build new high-voltage lines; and calls on the Member States to facilitate faster procedures. Furthermore, the report strengthens the regional approach when linking markets. Hungary, the electricity interconnection index is 29% – i.e. far above the 10% target for interconnection – and thus does not mean a new obligation for the country. I agree with the principles and directions laid down in the report, and as a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. "Unfortunately, this is not a well-done report, but in some of its elements there is imagination, so I chose to abst. In energy and energy networks, it is necessary to work with plans agreed over a number of decades. It is not viable to make hasty decisions along the lines of lobbying interests and political strife, ignoring the interests of citizens.  Serious analyses should be carried out to establish the direction and capacity of network connections, because unjustified burdens should not be borne on consumers and taxpayers. They'd bear the cost of the pompous plans. Expanding networks to insecure external infrastructures threatens to cause the system to collapse.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – The 10% interconnection target, to be achieved by 2020, is a further step towards the completion of the internal energy market. I have therefore decided to support Mr Eriksson's report. To date, several Member States have not achieved the objective we have set ourselves, but I agree with the rapporteur that interconnection objectives should be agreed by the regions and set on the basis of different parameters, taking into account the different variables and situations.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for the report on 'a European electricity grid ready for 2020'. National Front MEPs supported Amendments 3, 4 and 5, which point out, among other things, that Member States have exclusive jurisdiction to define the energy mix. This report is an overall positive thing for France.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MEPs voted in favour of this energy text because it is positive for France.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union is constantly making efforts to make the common energy market the most integrated, competitive and sustainable in the world. We can see the fruits of this integration by lowering wholesale electricity prices, which means expanding the range of options for consumers and, in turn, that energy suppliers have to offer better services at more affordable prices in order to compete with other suppliers.  This report aims to ensure affordable, safe and sustainable energy through an interconnected network. Specifically, the aim is to achieve the target of 10% interconnection. Among the many other benefits that this interconnected network would provide, we highlight increased security of supply in Europe, lower prices in the internal market, increased competition and support for sustainable development. However, in order to achieve these benefits, regional cooperation needs to be further intensified.   For all these reasons, I believe that the interconnection of electricity markets should be a priority for the European Union, together with a future-proof climate policy.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 These matters are not to be decided by the EU, it should be up to individual electricity companies or Member States to the extent to which they have interconnected networks with their neighbours.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Greater energy efficiency and sustainable development of the energy sector that will ensure savings, renewable energy and the functioning of the internal market are priorities for the European Union and all its institutions. A stable, independent and competitive energy system will also result in job creation, innovation and growth and development of the economy. The development of such a system requires a higher level of electricity connectivity, smart grids and a new market model. Twelve Member States, mainly those at the EU's external borders, have not achieved 10 per cent of electricity connectivity set as a target by 2020. The European electricity system is undergoing a period of change and we are looking forward to concrete legislative proposals announced by the Commission for the second half of 2016.           I supported MeP Józef Gróbarczyk's report, as an integrated internal electricity market would facilitate electricity trade and reduce the volatility of electricity prices for the benefit of citizens. By 2030, it is estimated that European citizens could save between €12 billion and €40 billion annually.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Electricity has actually become a vital part of everyday life today. There are undeniably many places in the world where they are not, but if taken away here in the European Union, life would come to a great end precisely because an absolute majority of all aspects of life depend on electricity: from light to the possibility of charging mobile phones. Consequently, given the already existing degree of inter-integration in a number of other areas, achieving the 10% target for grid interconnections is a perfectly logical wish. Although this 10 % was originally planned to be achieved as early as 2005 ... If one country faces electricity problems for some reason, another will be able to help it. Many progress of this kind is already quite common: on the basis of the Commission's report in February this year, only Spain, Romania and Cyprus will remain below 10% in 2020. Ireland and the United Kingdom, Italy, Poland, Romania as well as Cyprus and Malta are currently on this list. It would, however, be necessary to note one very important aspect, both in terms of achieving this electricity interconnection target and, in general, the reform of the electricity grid. The eastern coast of the Baltic Sea, where the three Baltic states are located, is quite closely connected to the territory of the Russian Federation for historical and geographical reasons – in particular, here is a significant example of the Kaliningrad region.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target in order to make Europe's electricity grid ready for 2020, because I do not think it is a complete and documented report. I am also voting against the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech of 14/12/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal. Fully integrating the EU electricity market could cut bills by at least EUR 2 per MWh, and thus save users up to EUR 40 billion a year by 2030, but to achieve this EU countries need to invest EUR 150 billion to interconnect their national grids.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's strategy is welcomed, which represents a positive step towards achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target and improving the functioning of the internal electricity market in the EU.  Electricity interconnection is one of the key prerequisites for completing an integrated EU internal electricity market aimed at achieving the eu's climate objectives and reducing the long-term energy insulation that the EU is pursuing. Renewable energy, greater energy efficiency and an internal energy market are therefore important means of achieving a stable, secure and competitive energy system in the EU.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of Mr Eriksson's proposal, which recognises the 10% interconnection target as an important step as interconnectivity is one of the key prerequisites for the completion of the internal electricity market. The report also stresses that the purely quantitative 10% target should not be isolated. In fact, ensuring that interconnectors work in practice requires accessibility for interconnections and networks.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My support for the report in which MEPs are calling for greater efforts to interconnect electricity grids between all Member States, which will in the end lead to significant improvement and savings for consumers. In addition, improving electricity interconnection is key to boosting renewable energy and thus moving towards climate change targets, as well as making Europe more competitive through lower electricity prices.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Part of the EU's energy targets for the coming years is, among other things, the achievement of 10% electricity interconnectivity between Member States which will create an internal energy market with multiple economic and geopolitical consequences. An internal electricity market will help strengthen regional cooperation by giving greater autonomy to the EU and improving its geopolitical position. At the same time, a modern and well-structured network will be able to provide high-quality services while taking into account environmental protection and the exploitation of renewable energy sources. Understanding the beneficial effects of an integrated electricity system on the Member States but on the European citizens themselves, I am in favour of the resolution. Such a system will be able to offer more security and resilience to the various changes and interruptions in supply but also stabilised reduced prices with the direct effect of saving European consumers money. The EU's 10% interconnection target by 2020 is important to address current problems including the low capacity of existing national infrastructures and the time-consuming licensing process (aimed at avoiding isolation of Member States, in particular remote islands) but also to achieve a single energy market as an integral part of the Energy Union.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report recognises the importance of interconnectivity in energy markets. However, the proposal would lead to further centralisation, which I strongly disagree with. I therefore do not agree with this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it recognises the 10% interconnection target as an important step in the right direction and that interconnectivity is one of the key preconditions for completing the internal electricity market.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Twelve Member States are still insufficiently connected to the EU electricity market (Italy, Ireland, Romania, Portugal, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, the United Kingdom, Spain, Poland, Cyprus and Malta). In 2002, the European Council adopted a target of at least 10% interconnection of the electricity grid in 2005. In 2007, it postponed the achievement of this target until 2020.  Interconnected networks provide energy security, maintain affordable prices and increase the share of renewable energy as part of the decarbonization process. The main tool to achieve this 10% target is the creation of "common infrastructure projects" financed by the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI).  Nevertheless, all this is part of the "Energy Union" which aims to liberalise the sector more widely. Also I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report focuses on achieving the 10% interconnection target in the electricity sector. This report outlines the prospects for a European electricity grid ready for 2020. Overall, this text recalls the reality that Member States are best able to address energy poverty in the Union. In addition, this text recalls the exclusive competence of states to define the energy mix.  I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The electrical interconnection is one of the essential preconditions for the completion of an integrated internal energy market. In this context, it is essential to strengthen the interconnection between the Iberian Peninsula and the rest of Europe, allowing the region to participate fully in the internal electricity market. I would also stress the important role that the Iberian Peninsula region can play in establishing and creating a genuine European Energy Union, in particular through the key role of renewable energy development. I voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it makes important steps to create interconnectivity in relation to the internal electricity market. It ensures that Member States, such as Malta, which have not reached the 10% target gain special assistance in addressing the most significant gaps in the integrated EU electricity market.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Europe can strengthen its independence from foreign energy suppliers by developing a finely integrated network of electricity highways across Europe. This strategy of interconnectivity ensures energy supply. In addition, the existing European energy stocks are used optimally and we develop an internal energy market that is better aligned. In this way, we are more resilient to all kinds of distortions and an internal energy market improves pricing, which in turn benefits the strength of European companies. The development of energy hubs and energy highways will ensure that the growing share of energy from renewable energy sources is used more efficiently. With the increasing number of energy consumers generating energy from environmentally friendly energy sources locally and in remote areas, it is essential not to lose energy generated. Wind turbines in the North Sea will generate more than 8% of total electricity needs by 2030. Then it is necessary to make that energy available all over Europe. That is why I support in this report the commitment to systematically synchronise and expand the electricity connection with the 'outer areas' of the European Union, so that in the long run all countries have access to an internal electricity market.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since europe's ageing energy infrastructure, poorly integrated energy markets – especially cross-border ones – and uncoordinated national energy policies often mean that consumers and businesses cannot benefit from wider choice or lower energy prices, I welcome the report on achieving a 10% electricity interconnection rate, i.e. information on the preparation of European electricity networks for 2020. In a situation where wholesale electricity prices in the EU are now 30% higher than in the US and even more than 100% for gas, improving energy interconnections between Member States and modernising infrastructure can improve energy affordability and the competitiveness of its prices.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on making Europe’s electricity grid fit for 2020, because I believe that the new measures will ensure that Europe’s electricity network is properly connected in order to avoid Member States being isolated, ensure a true internal energy market as part of the Energy Union and bring down the costs of integrating renewable energy into the grid.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ An interconnected European Electricity System would bring electricity prices down, reduce productivity losses in the commercial and industrial sectors and stimulate the growth of the European renewable energy industry. For these reasons, the European Council established that Member States should reach an electricity interconnection target of at least 10% of their installed capacity with their EU neighbours. In light of this goal, the European Parliament drafted a report that highlights a list of issues that are crucial for the achievement of this target. These refer to the need for a faster permitting process for high voltage lines, better targeted investment and improved Member State cooperation at regional level. I do believe this report has the right focus and therefore my vote was in favour.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy reflects, in particular, the Communication from the European Commission entitled 'Achieving the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks', which welcomes it as a positive step towards achieving the 10% energy interconnection target and the more efficient functioning of the internal EU electricity market. It sees interconnection of networks as a means of creating an internal energy market that allows the free movement of energy.  It emphasises that interconnection of networks is a strategic principle which allows not only a more efficient management of the inevitable disruptions, but also the increasing interconnection of energy from renewable sources into the European energy system.  It points out that a fully integrated internal market for electricity would increase safety and reduce fluctuations in electricity prices, saving European consumers an estimated EUR 12-40 billion per year by 2030.  It recalls that a pan-European interconnection of networks could lead to a reduction in the price of electricity by at least EUR 2 per megawatt hour, while at the same time allowing Europe to cover most of its electricity load from renewable energy sources. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Renewable energy, increased energy efficiency and a sustainable energy mix lead to energy savings that improve the quality of life of citizens and the competitiveness of European businesses. The free movement of energy and the future completion of the Energy Union are important means for the EU to have a stable, secure and independent energy system. I am voting in favour of this report for safeguarding the energy interconnections between the Iberian Peninsula and France in order to support renewable energy in the region and to allow the Iberian Peninsula to participate fully in the internal electricity market. I recall the Madrid declaration, signed on 4 March 2015, and the creation of a High Level Group for South-West Europe on the interconnections that are important steps to increase the interconnection of the region and I urge the European authorities to support this future energy interconnection decisively for Portugal's development. I urge the countries of the region to support the development of their considerable renewable energy potential and to facilitate the sector's access to the integrated European market.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as we need strong political support and new measures to ensure Europe’s electricity network is properly connected in order to avoid Member States being isolated, ensure a true internal energy market as part of the Energy Union and bring down the costs of integrating renewable energy into the grid.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report on European energy policy. The text recommends the development of electricity interconnections within the EU and sets a target of 10% interconnection by 2020. The aim is to ensure that European citizens have a safe, sustainable and affordable supply of energy based on solidarity and trust. I approved this text and in particular supported the recall of the competence of States in determining the composition of their energy mix.  On the other hand, I deplore the words used in recital Q, which call Russia into question and regard it as "an unreliable partner that uses its energy supplies as a political weapon". This provision is not likely to soothe relations between the EU and Russia. It encourages the sterile rise of sanctions, which I strongly oppose.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the ERIKSSON report on a European electricity grid ready for 2020. The report acknowledges that the 10% electricity interconnection target is an important step in the right direction. It stresses that interconnection is one of the main preconditions for the completion of the internal electricity market. With regard to Member States that have not yet reached the 10% target, the report says that more needs to be done to assist them. Particular attention must be paid to projects that address the biggest failures in the EU's integrated electricity market. In addition, the report stresses that the purely quantitative target of 10% should not be limited to the fact that interconnections and networks are also needed to ensure that interconnections work.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on the strategy to achieve the 10% electricity interconnection target and improving the functioning of the internal electricity market in the EU.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that improving the functioning of the EU's internal electricity market and achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target must be one of the priorities of the European Community in the next period. In this respect, as the document suggests, the Commission must encourage investment in the best available technologies which, while more costly, offer considerable long-term financial advantages. I also welcome the report's proposal to propose to the European Commission to make every effort to avoid coupling being established at group level of Member States and to promote coupling at EU level, including all Member States and their neighbours, in particular countries participating in the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP).

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report on my own initiative, because electricity interconnection is not only one of the basic conditions for the completion of the EU's integrated internal electricity market, but will also contribute to meeting the climate targets and, last but not least, to strengthening energy security and stability in the event of energy supply disruptions. Given the Commission's estimate that EUR 35 billion will be needed to reach the 10% target in all Member States by 2020, the maximum use should be made of EU financial instruments, in particular the CONNECTING Europe Facility, part of which should be earmarked for electricity projects. Funding should focus on projects that increase interconnections in 12 Member States in peripheral areas of the EU that are not yet below the 10% electricity interconnection target.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Achieving the 10% electricity interconnection objective and improving the functioning of the internal electricity market is an important objective for a stable, secure, independent, inclusive, inclusive and competitive energy system in the EU, and the interconnection of electricity networks must be a political priority.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. From this Parliament we are continually talking about the importance of moving towards a true European market for more integrated, competitive and sustainable energy. However, we still find that some countries have a strong energy dependence on imports, outdated infrastructure and very low electricity interconnections. I supported this initiative report on achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target because it is absolutely necessary to end the above and with the situation of clear discrimination that some countries face because of their geographical situation, that is the case in Spain. The energy interconnection with France, and therefore with the rest of Europe, will not only allow us to participate in the European energy market, but consumers can benefit from better prices. In addition, competition between electricity operators would be expanded and the promotion of the dominant position of electricity companies would be limited, which would certainly help tackle fraud such as the recent Spanish company Abengoa.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report.  Interconnection of electricity markets is essential to ensure security of energy supply. I support the 10% target for total electricity connections. At the same time, however, it is essential to encourage individual regions to agree more ambitious, scientifically proven interconnection targets by 2030. It should be noted that a fully integrated electricity market will ensure more reliable and secure electricity systems. Electricity grids will be able to better manage the growing amount of energy from renewable sources. It will also allow consumers to make savings and make more choices.  Particular attention must be paid to regional cooperation, in particular the Baltic Sea region. It is essential to ensure that up to this region acts as an equal participant in the governance of the single European electricity market and system.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP reject the EU Commission proposal on the achievement of a 10% electricity interconnection target which is designed to facilitate the use of expensive renewables. We oppose EU climate and energy policy that is one of the most expensive and yet unsuccessful policies the world has ever seen. We oppose expensive renewables and believe that Member States should favour the exploitation of indigenous energy, including fossil fuel.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 While reiterating the greater commitment that the more peripheral European Member States must make to achieving the 2020 target of 10% of electricity interconnections and certainly the support that Europe will be able to give these states in achieving this goal, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ It is known that the EU, but also Croatia depends on energy imports. Croatia imports 45% of electricity, according to HEP data. The Croatian electricity system and the national company HEP are obsolete, both technologically and conceptually and look more and more like dinosaurs that will die out in the near future along with the fossil fuels it uses.  There is a lack of investment, and what few existing investments are directed again into a further increased dependence on imports of fossil energy. According to Eurostat, Croatia has relatively low prices for households and even lower electricity prices for the industry. However, this rare and immediate market advantage for our industry may be jeopardised by poor investment. Croatia's national company must adapt to the Energy Union by investing in the energy capacities available on its territory. Investing in renewable sources and in the sector where Croatia has the most untapped potential – the sun – can make the national company a guarantor of a fair social price for electricity for households in the future.  The attainment of the objective of increasing the interconnection of the electricity system across Europe to at least 10 % enables the placement of desirable energy from renewable sources produced in Croatia on the Market of Europe, ensuring the energy self-reliance of the state and the conditions for exporting electricity produced to other parts of the Union.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I welcome everything that has been done to achieve greater electricity interconnection, as it is a precondition for achieving an integrated internal electricity market, and thus a precondition for achieving the EU's climate goals, increasing energy efficiency, strengthening the sustainability of the economy, creating a more resilient European grid and for easier trade in electricity. However, many Member States have not yet met the 10% target, which is particularly problematic, as experts are already warning that much more ambitious targets will need to be set in the coming period.  Furthermore, there is a need to address the frequent stitching of transmission networks in order to ensure maximum exploitation of existing infrastructures and to ensure a distribution-quality network. In addition, the whole process of cooperation on electricity needs to be made more transparent through greater involvement of Parliament and to define priority projects of common interest.  As regards Croatia, it should be noted that it abounds in exceptional, not fully exploited, renewable energy potentials and that we need to do more to achieve cooperation within South East Europe on electricity and gas connectivity.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I agree with the report on the achievement of the 10% electricity interconnection target - the preparation of the European electricity network for 2020 by Eriksson. Interconnection of the electricity system brings many benefits, such as increased reliability of the electricity system, a better price of electricity in the internal market, decarbonization of the energy mix and sustainable development of the energy system.  By achieving this objective, the European Union will reduce its energy dependence on imports, thereby strengthening its negotiating position with respect to third countries. I note that benefits must be ensured for end-users, not just wholesale customers. Also, more interconnections will facilitate new investments and allow the renewables industry to grow more. Electricity interconnection is one of the key tools for the EU to achieve its climate goals and become the world's leading renewable energy power.  For these reasons, I am in favour of achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target by 2020. By realizing this goal, it is estimated that by 2030 citizens could save between $12 billion and $40 billion.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am convinced that renewable energy, higher energy efficiency and a sustainable energy mix will lead to energy savings and the establishment of an internal energy market that will allow the free flow of energy, ensuring a stable, secure and, above all, competitive EU energy system. In my opinion, 10% electricity interconnections will make European industry and trade more competitive in the global economy and, above all, the internal electricity market will benefit all EU consumers. Of course, I am aware that the 10% interconnection target is an important step in the right direction, but by 2030 there is a need to agree on more ambitious complementary interconnection targets based on trade flows, operational peaks and weaknesses to be approved by the regions. And I will be happy if these projects are eligible for specific funding under the Connecting Europe Facility and the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Energy infrastructure is high on the European energy agenda. An interconnected European energy network is essential to ensure Europe's energy security, to strengthen competition in the internal market, thereby making prices more competitive, and to help achieve the objectives that the European Union has committed itself to achieving in the field of decarbonisation and climate policy. This communication examines how to achieve the 10% target for electrical interconnections by 2020. The objectives on which the text focuses are: improving the situation in the 12 Member States with an interconnection level of less than 10% (Ireland, Italy, Romania, Portugal, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, the United Kingdom, Spain, Poland, Cyprus and Malta); projects under the Regulation on Trans-European Energy Networks (TEN-E) and the Connecting Europe Mechanism (CEF), which will contribute to the achievement of the interconnection objective; financial instruments to support electricity interconnection projects; ways of strengthening regional cooperation. For all the reasons listed above, I voted in favour of this resolution and I hope that the interconnection of electricity markets will be a political priority for the European Union to be pursued at all levels in the years to come.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The interconnection of electricity grids is a major issue, especially for our companies. I was able to see this when I visited the site at the inauguration of the France-Spain Electric Interconnector (INELFE) on the Franco-Spanish border. Spain is a country that remains isolated in terms of interconnection.  On the other hand, we also sometimes need to sell or buy more electricity, depending on the season. Also, this new interconnection will be important, but will not meet all of our objectives or solve all our problems. For it must be useful to the two countries on a par, without leading to fierce competition. On these points, the report provides some leads, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP reject the EU Commission proposal on the achievement of a 10% electricity interconnection target which is designed to facilitate the use of expensive renewables. We oppose EU climate and energy policy that is one of the most expensive and yet unsuccessful policies the world has ever seen. We oppose expensive renewables and believe that Member States should favour the exploitation of indigenous energy, including fossil fuel.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. The interconnection of networks is essential to the development of a European energy market, as demonstrated by the report on the mechanism for interconnection in Europe, of which I was a co-partner.  With this in mind, I supported the report on achieving the 10% interconnection target in the electricity sector by 2020. This threshold, which would strengthen the integration of the European electricity market, will be achieved in particular by the use of innovative financial tools, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Cooperation within the various European regions will also be crucial in coordinating the development of cross-border networks, which is the second focus of the report. Better interconnection would reduce both the price of electricity and its volatility, which would be beneficial not only for the competitiveness of European industry but also for the purchasing power of European citizens who should see their electricity bills fall.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. The target of 10% interconnection in the electricity sector by 2020 must be met. A plurality of benefits will result, of course energy, but also economic, climatic or geostrategic. Of these benefits, what would be the case for European consumers? The figures circulating indicate that a fully integrated internal electricity market would save European consumers between 12 and 40 billion euros a year by 2030. For this reason, electricity interconnection is a prerequisite, especially since, for the consumer, suitable investments in interconnection could reduce electricity prices by at least 2 euros/MWh.  However, as evidenced by the fact that efforts must be continued, 12 Member States remain below target. These efforts must be supported and strengthened, in particular to ensure that the necessary investments of $150 billion are committed, but also to ensure that ambitious complementary interconnection targets are set and achieved by 2030.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament was invited to vote on a report on the European electricity grid for 2020. In this report, Parliament recognises in particular that the 10% electricity interconnection target is one of the preconditions for the completion of the internal market for integrated electricity.
