The benefits of this market could be numerous, including increased security and reduced price volatility. The figure of at least 2 euros/MWh is also mentioned in the report.  While this 10% target to be achieved by 2020 is a key objective, in the medium term and certainly by 2030, it is necessary to set ambitious, evidence-based and regionally approved complementary interconnection targets.  It is now important that the Commission and the Member States provide strong political support and approve the proposed energy network in the North Sea region.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Like the resolution on the Energy Union, this own-initiative report, which I voted in favour of, also wishes to support a Commission position - in this case, the position expressed in the Commission communication entitled "Achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target − Preparing the European electricity grid for 2020". Like the rapporteur, I also believe that this interconnection target is an important step in the right direction and is a key step towards achieving an integrated European energy market in the future. I would like to stress, on the other hand, that qualitative targets are also as important or more important than quantitative targets - and I am referring in particular to the compatibility of interconnectors and national networks themselves and their accessibility. This position of the European Parliament, too, stressing the importance of significantly increasing the interconnection between Spain, France and Portugal "considers that the Madrid declaration, signed on 04/03/2015, and the creation of a High Level Group for South-West Europe on interconnections are important steps to increase the interconnection of the region", thus the full participation of the Iberian Peninsula in the internal electricity market - a statement made by the rapporteur, with which he could no longer agree!

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union is the world's largest importer of energy with 53% of its energy worth 400 billion euros per year. I supported this report which calls for more investment in the integration of the European electricity market, which could reduce prices and save money. These include investing in grid interconnection, which is one of the main preconditions for the completion of the internal electricity market, and focusing on projects that address the biggest failures in the EU's integrated electricity market.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the achievement of the 10% target for electricity interconnections in order to complete the path taken by the European Union to create and develop an internal energy market. The creation of a European electronic network by the year 2020 will make it possible to achieve a competitive, efficient and secure energy system.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the Eriksson report because interconnection can be an obstacle to the development of renewable energy in Spain and facilitates the sale of nuclear energy from France to Spain. The text – apart from some cosmetic paragraphs – does not place this prospect of interconnection of electricity grids within the framework of renewable development and energy transition. It first aims to achieve an integrated internal electricity market, in fact ruling out any public control over energy production. In addition, this report promotes PCIs (projects of common interest). These projects pose a threat to the environment and are based on a hypercentralized, opaque production model that favors large companies. We therefore consider that, in a situation other than the electricity sector, where renewables are better extended and implemented and the sector is more democratic, decentralized and under public supervision, interconnection would be a desirable objective, but we do not believe that their implementation at the present time will achieve these objectives on its own or with the limited measures detailed in this regard in the report.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, despite considering the energy interconnection between the Member States of the Union positive, because in the specific case of Spain, interconnection with France is being used as a false measure to solve the crisis in the renewables sector. Interconnection is a necessary measure to be able to modulate the differences between the different countries of the Union, producing potentially more resilient systems thanks to its network configuration. However, in Spain, the Government is hiding in interconnection to deny the impact that its retroactive reform of regulation is having on the renewable energy sector. Another problem point of the interconnection between Spain and France is the making available and increasing dependence on the import of French nuclear energy, inhibiting the development of an energy model that allows it to be abandoned. That is why I abstained in the final vote on this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on electricity interconnection and the achievement of a European electricity grid for 2020.  Since 2002, the Union has been committed to achieving a stable, independent, inclusive and transparent internal electricity market in order to ensure security of supply, the use of renewable sources and the competitiveness of the electricity industry for the benefit of European citizens. A fully integrated internal market will facilitate trade and services in the electricity sector by reducing price volatility, create jobs in a sustainable economy through investment in the best technologies, and help reduce energy dependency and isolation.  However, I believe that a uniform target of 10% interconnection risks being misleading and not adapted to the different market dynamics or geographical situations of all Member States. The objectives must not be established unambiguously, but on the basis of the specific circumstances of each country. On the other hand, I consider regional cooperation to be of fundamental importance as a means of achieving interconnection throughout Europe.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I disagree with the Commission's proposal to have a 10% electricity connection target, which cost tax payers up to 40bn euro.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together, with my Socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of this own initiative report because I believe that strong political support and new measures are needed to guarantee that the electricity network of Europe is properly connected and that no member state is isolated. With eight Member States still yet to meet the target of having at least 10% of their electricity generation capacity able to be exported and imported with it neighbouring countries, we need a more integrated energy market. This report calls for exactly that: a truly integrated internal energy market - as part of the Energy Union - which would bring down the costs of integrating renewable energy into the grid.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because I consider the interconnection of electricity networks and the modernisation of infrastructure to be a fundamental pillar of the completion of the EU's integrated internal market in electricity. Although cross-border trade in electricity between most EU Member States has increased recently, as has the use of interconnectors, I believe that it has far from reached its full potential. I consider it extremely important that we continue with this strategy that has been launched, because Europe needs electricity interconnection, it needs an integrated internal market in electricity, which will facilitate electricity trading, increase security and reduce volatility in electricity prices for the benefit of citizens and the competitiveness of European industry and businesses. I appreciate that there has traditionally been a high level of security of energy supply in Europe (also due to the reliability of our networks) compared to other regions of the world, but the recent crisis in Ukraine and the associated risks to security of energy supply have revealed to us what the EU can gain from well-integrated and interconnected energy markets in the event of crises.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Renewable energy, increased energy efficiency and a sustainable energy mix are a key tool for a robust, secure, independent, inclusive, transparent and competitive EU energy system.  Electricity connectivity brings energy savings and an internal energy market that allows the free movement of energy. This, in turn, we gain high-quality jobs and wealth in a sustainable economy. 25. 2. 2015, as part of the energy package of measures, the Commission has also set a strategy for achieving the 10% cross-border electricity interconnection target and improving the functioning of the EU internal electricity market.  The report largely welcomes the 10% electricity interconnection target, but, on the other hand, points out that the objective does not always reflect the market situation and is not based on scientific evidence. The objective does not describe either the amount of electricity flowed between Member States or its quality and is not appropriate for all Member States.   The report therefore calls on the Commission to start a technical debate as soon as possible. I agree that increasing cross-border energy will not be beneficial without strong integration of markets and TSOs. As the report contains concrete and meaningful comments on the achievement of the 10% electricity interconnection target and because the preparation of the electricity network has significant environmental, economic and geopolitical advantages, I voted in plenary.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'A better connection between member states is needed not only to improve the EU's geopolitical energy position, but also to achieve climate and energy objectives. The aim of connecting at least 10% of electricity production to the networks in other Member States is therefore a step in the right direction. The Greens want targets to be set in advance for specific regions based on scientific research. Additional qualitative parameters, such as greater transparency and involvement of local actors and civil society organisations in 'Projects of General Interest', are also needed. Furthermore, the best available technologies should be used to minimise the impact on the environment.  With 17% interconnectivity, Belgium is one of the most connected EU countries. 4 projects are in the pipeline, including the Stevin plan to ensure that offshore wind farms can be connected to the fixed grid. But 12 Member States have not yet reached the 10% target. I voted in favour of this report and the recommendations contained herein. The EU needs to achieve a better, tailor-made and smart interconnection of electricity networks between countries. Only this will make it possible to make the switch to renewable energy.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The integration of the electricity market and its efficient use is in the interest of every citizen. The preparation of European electricity networks is a step within the European Energy Union.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report, as renewable energy, greater energy efficiency and a sustainable energy mix leading to energy savings and an internal energy market with free flow of energy are important ways to achieve a stable, secure, independent, inclusive, transparent and competitive energy system for the EU, creating high-quality jobs and achieving betterment in a sustainable, forward-looking economy.  The benefit of significantly increasing the interconnection of the European network goes well beyond the economic and geopolitical dimension. It is a strategic principle that should result in a more resilient and stronger network, better prepared for various types of modifications and disruptions. It also allows an increasing share of renewable energy to be effectively integrated into the European grid.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The 10% target was originally set in 2002 on the basis of installed electricity generation capacities that existed at the time. The 10% electricity interconnection target due by 2020 is an important and significant step in the right direction.  A fully integrated internal electricity market would facilitate electricity trade and balancing services. It would increase security and reduce the volatility of electricity prices for the benefit of citizens and the competitiveness of European industry and businesses in the global economy, as it is estimated that European consumers could save between €12 billion and €40 billion annually by 2030. The Commission estimates that €35 billion needs to be allocated to reach the 10% target in all Member States by 2020. I support the establishment of a European electricity network for 2020, as I think it will contribute to achieving our climate goals, including the EU's objective of taking a leading role in renewable energy.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the proposal. While I welcome all efforts to connect the electricity market in the EU, these efforts should lead to the removal of regulatory barriers and not to the introduction of a new burden, in the form of mandatory and arbitrary targets for connecting electricity networks.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the achievement of the 10% electricity interconnection target – the preparation of the European electricity network for 2020. The existence of an internal energy market that allows the free movement of energy and an increase in energy efficiency and a sustainable energy mix will contribute to a strong, secure, independent and transparent competitive EU energy system that creates high-quality jobs and wealth in a sustainable, forward-looking economy. The 10% cross-border electricity interconnection target to be achieved by 2020 is an important step in the right direction.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the importance of interconnections to the internal energy market, but also rightly recognises that targets for achieving interconnection must be relevant and reflect the specific circumstances of Member States.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is our firm position that removing the energy isolation in which many EU states and regions are located from the major energy networks must be one of the priorities of the Union's energy policy. This report stresses the need to strengthen poor infrastructure and promotes measures to achieve this objective, even giving weight to the need to support more states such as Cyprus which are still a long way from reaching the target of 10 % electricity interconnection by 2020. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report gives too many powers to the Commission, highlights to almost peer-to-peer countries outside the Union which, especially in the case of Turkey, are also hostile to Member States and, finally, does not guarantee the achievement of the objective of energy security for the Member States of the Union.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report is a response to the Commission Communication "Achieving the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks". The report welcomes the achievement of the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks. The report emphasises that the interconnection of energy networks is a prerequisite for achieving an integrated internal electricity market, which, if properly designed, can help Europe achieve its climate objectives. The report notes that the lengthy authorisation procedure makes it very difficult to build new high-voltage lines; and calls on the Member States to facilitate faster procedures. Furthermore, the report strengthens the regional approach when linking markets. Hungary, the electricity interconnection index is 29% – i.e. far above the 10% target for interconnection – and thus does not mean a new obligation for the country.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which makes proposals on an important part of the development of the Energy Union. The report underlines that the 10% interconnection target for interconnection of energy networks is a useful goal by 2020 and an important step towards a common energy system. The report regrets that 12 Member States, mainly located on the periphery of the Union, do not meet the 10% target for interconnection of electricity networks and are thus largely isolated from the internal market for electricity. I believe that this isolation will not help to create an Energy Union.  I share the view that, in the medium term and in the perspective of 2030, it is absolutely necessary for the regions to agree on ambitious and fact-based complementary interconnection targets.   I agree that renewable energy, a sustainable energy mix resulting in better energy efficiency and energy savings, as well as an internal energy market that allows energy to flow freely, are important tools for a stable, safe, independent, inclusive, transparent and competitive energy system in the Union. This creates high-quality jobs and wealth in a future-oriented, sustainable economy.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Electricity interconnections between Member States are an essential project for the European energy transition and the fight against climate change. An interconnected electricity grid open to technological evolution is essential to mitigate and compensate for the structural discontinuities of renewable energies. Without this structure we would not be able to make the best use of the potential of renewable energies. The report sets itself the objective of achieving the minimum 10% of the electricity interconnection. For us 5 Stars is a goal that goes in the right direction for this reason we voted in favour, although it is a percentage that does not consider the territorial, geographical and energy characteristics of the Member States. We would have been more satisfied with the final text if my and Mr Borrelli's amendments, which provided that the evaluation and quantitative objectives of interconnection projects were based on scientific evidence, had passed.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We cannot talk about energy security in the current geopolitical context in the eastern part of the European Union without the Member States achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target. We need serious investment projects both to achieve this target by 2020 and to move to 15% in 2030, as well as for energy storage infrastructures and facilities by the time when the level of interconnectivity and, by implication, market integration is sufficiently high. In economic terms, an adequate level of interconnection translates into savings of up to EUR 40 billion per year by 2030, and the benefits will be felt by large consumers and households alike. We are talking about an energy union, but without taking advantage of the opportunities to develop cross-border energy markets, we will remain at the current stage of fragmentation. Furthermore, we will fail in an attempt to take advantage of the energy resources specific to each Member State and we will continue to pay import bills which entail high energy prices for industry and for individual consumers.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As a shadow rapporteur for the report ‘Achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target’ I am deeply convinced that well-designed and functioning electricity interconnection is one of the key preconditions for completing an integrated internal electricity market in the EU. I consider the 10% interconnection target as a valuable step in this respect. Therefore I supported all compromises approved by the ITRE Committee and I voted in favour of the report.  I would like to emphasize few points of this report which are of high importance to me. Although the 10% interconnection target is important, it describes neither the quantity of electricity flowing between countries nor the quality, such as regards the availability of the existing interconnection infrastructure or of the existing national infrastructure. The report is therefore calling for thorough impact assessment and targets which will be evidence-based and also complementary regional targets in 2030 horizon. We should be able to identify the real needs of the market and needs of the EU Member States, thorough IA and evaluation of the current infrastructure. Last but not least, the approach towards the interconnections and the national grids has to be balanced.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The own-initiative report is a response to the Commission Communication "Achieving the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks". The report welcomes the achievement of the 10% target for interconnection of energy networks. The report emphasises that the interconnection of energy networks is a prerequisite for achieving an integrated internal electricity market, which, if properly designed, can help Europe achieve its climate objectives. The report notes that the lengthy authorisation procedure makes it very difficult to build new high-voltage lines; and calls on the Member States to facilitate faster procedures. Furthermore, the report strengthens the regional approach when linking markets. Hungary, the electricity interconnection index is 29% – i.e. far above the 10% target for interconnection – and thus does not mean a new obligation for the country. I agree with the principles and directions laid down in the report, and as a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. In 2014, the European Council called on Member States to achieve interlinkages of at least 10 % of their installed electricity generation capacity by 2020, meaning that each Member State should have electrical cables allowing at least 10 % of the electricity generated by their power plants to be transported within borders to neighbouring countries. I consider this call to be extremely positive as it has the potential to enable electricity to move more freely within union borders, thereby improving the energy security of the internal market and automatically reducing prices for final consumers. This report received my support because it goes towards this Council proposal, while correctly detecting the fact that the 10% target is quite arbitrary and debatable given the specific circumstances in each individual Member State of the Union. Instead, the report emphasises the importance of regional cooperation (e.g. the Adriatic-Ionian Pipeline), seeing it as a crucial element for strengthening the Union's energy connectivity, which I fully agree with. A positive element in it is the call for shortening the procedures for obtaining permits, since the same often causes significant delays in the creation and development of important projects.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the preparation of the European electricity network for 2020, as I believe that the European Union can gradually be energy independent only through integration. The report recognises the 10 per cent interconnection target as an important step in the right direction.  It stresses that interconnection is one of the key preconditions for completing the internal electricity market. With regard to Member States that have not yet reached ten per cent, the report states that more needs to be done to help them. Particular attention should be paid to projects addressing the most important gaps in the EU's integrated electricity market.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the Eriksson report because interconnection can be an obstacle to the development of renewable energy in Spain and facilitates the sale of nuclear energy from France to Spain. The text – apart from some cosmetic paragraphs – does not place this prospect of interconnection of electricity grids within the framework of renewable development and energy transition. It first aims to achieve an integrated internal electricity market, in fact ruling out any public control over energy production. In addition, this report promotes PCIs (projects of common interest). These projects pose a threat to the environment and are based on a hypercentralized, opaque production model that favors large companies. We therefore consider that, in a situation other than the electricity sector, where renewables are better extended and implemented and the sector is more democratic, decentralized and under public supervision, interconnection would be a desirable objective, but we do not believe that their implementation at the present time will achieve these objectives on its own or with the limited measures detailed in this regard in the report.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The benefits of interconnectivity is a strategic principle that should lead to a more resilient and robust network, and better prepared to distributed effectively the energy from renewable sources in the European network.  What we demand is that these connections are made correctly, with respect to all the territory and the landscape through which these energy infrastructures passes through. That will eliminate the "energy islands" in Europe, such as the Spanish State, and enable to lower the energy costs that citizens and companies are paying for the energy because of the inefficiency of the government of this Member State, especially when it deals with the solar panel companies.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Energy efficiency can lead to energy savings, leading to an internal energy market that allows free energy flow. These are important means for a European energy system that becomes more stable, independent and competitive and would create high-quality jobs. One of the most important aspects of the report is that investments in necessary interconnection projects, which have a great pan-European significance, could reach EUR 150 billion by 2030, stressing that electricity prices could be reduced by at least EUR 2/MWh and Europe could cover some of the energy needs from renewable energy resources. The report points out, among other things, that Central and South-Eastern Europe has a vast potential for renewable resources that is largely untapped.  I voted in favour of this report because there is a need for cooperation and coordination on the long-term planning and construction of a regional network infrastructure, given that dependence on energy imports, especially those in the Baltic region, which is still in sync with Russia's electricity system, must be significantly reduced.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Renewable energy, a sustainable energy mix resulting in better energy efficiency and energy savings, and an internal energy market that allows the free flow of energy are important tools for a stable, secure, independent, inclusive, transparent and competitive energy system in the Union, creating high-quality jobs and wealth in a future-oriented, sustainable economy. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against the Eriksson report because interconnection can be an obstacle to the development of renewable energy in Spain and facilitates the sale of nuclear energy from France to Spain. The text – apart from some cosmetic paragraphs – does not place this prospect of interconnection of electricity grids within the framework of renewable development and energy transition. It first aims to achieve an integrated internal electricity market, in fact ruling out any public control over energy production. In addition, this report promotes PCIs (projects of common interest). These projects pose a threat to the environment and are based on a hypercentralized, opaque production model that favors large companies. We therefore consider that, in a situation other than the electricity sector, where renewables are better extended and implemented and the sector is more democratic, decentralized and under public supervision, interconnection would be a desirable objective, but we do not believe that their implementation at the present time will achieve these objectives on its own or with the limited measures detailed in this regard in the report.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, colleagues, I was pleased to vote for the adoption of the report on achieving 10% electricity interconnection in the EU. Although this objective seems too small for the large objectives of creating an integrated energy market, it reflects the current realities of the Union's energy. Twelve Member States on the periphery of the EU are still isolated from the internal electricity market. I support the regional approach of working to increase connectivity between neighbouring countries, which can more correctly determine which links are the most priority and have the greatest effect on their energy security and on the single regional electricity market. Projects of common Community interest in the field of electricity infrastructure should therefore also be prioritised on a regional basis. Central and South-Eastern Europe needs more cooperation and coordination in the construction of regional network infrastructure to make the best use of both existing large electricity production capacity and huge and largely untapped renewable energy potential. However, I note that the criterion of connectivity relative to installed capacity in the Member States is unilateral and does not reflect the objectives of energy security and a single energy market and more parameters should be picked in the future to track energy connectivity in the EU.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree that we have to make a positive step towards achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target and improving the functioning of the internal electricity market in the EU. I acknowledge that renewable energy, increased energy efficiency and a sustainable energy mix leading to energy savings and an internal energy market that allows energy to flow freely are important means for a stable, secure, independent, inclusive, transparent and competitive energy system for the EU, which generates high-quality jobs and wealth within a future-oriented sustainable economy. In this document we addressed the target of 10% electricity interconnection, a holistic approach that needs to be applied, the role of ACER, the importance of regional cooperation and a view beyond 2020. I also agree that a fully integrated internal electricity market would facilitate the electricity trading and balancing services, increase security and lower the volatility of electricity prices to the benefit of citizens and the competitiveness of Europe’s industry and business in a global economy, as it is estimated that EUR 12-40 billion could be saved annually by European consumers by 2030.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. This report stresses the need to boost interconnectivity in order to achieve a European energy market. Promoting the interconnectivity between the Iberian Peninsula and the rest of the EU countries is a key issue for Spain. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was in favour of this report as we need strong political support and new measures to ensure Europe’s electricity network is properly connected. A linked-up energy system could also bring potential gains in terms of the price of energy. Integration will encourage efficiency by allowing the cross border sharing of best practice and creating a more unified energy grid will encourage supply security by promoting alternative energy sources. We cannot afford to carry on our dependency on the dwindling supplies of fossil fuels.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. The strategic advantage of interconnectivity should lead to a more resilient and independent European network. Moreover, increased interconnectivity will enable us to better distribute energy from renewable sources throughout the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In connection with the report on the Eupower Union, the European Parliament adopted another initiative report for the development of the interconnection of the European electricity grid in 2020. Launched in 2002, the aim of this resolution is to achieve a 10% level of electricity grid interconnection by 2020. The interconnection project is expected to reduce the energy isolation of some Non-trans-border state networks and improve the security of energy supply. The aim would also be to reduce the European Union's dependence on energy imports, but it is clear in reality that this dependence is growing, particularly in the area of fossil fuels. The resolution strengthens the powers of the European regulatory authority and the networking of national regulators. Admit. But it is also proposed, in the usual ultra-liberal logic, to phase out regulated energy prices and to support market mechanisms to determine electricity prices but also infrastructure investments. As a text with no legislative significance, full of contradictions, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The great design of an internal energy policy should be to contain the costs for the consumer, limiting the not necessary investment and the subsidy to the various types of production.  It is essential that European energy policy in the near future contributes to correcting the distortions that have been observed. Although we follow some of the purposes set out in the motion for a resolution, as well as most of the concerns listed therein, we insist on the protection of consumers and economies, especially those most in need of stimulus.  It is necessary to be careful that interconnections and market mechanisms do not render useless the investment made in RES, because the surpluses of French nuclear production will certainly be much more competitive, and that it is not the national consumers who strongly subsidise the RES, so that it is competitive in terms of the European market.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report recognises the importance of interconnectivity in energy markets. However, the proposal would lead to further centralisation, which I strongly disagree with. I therefore do not agree with this report.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Improving the interconnection of electricity networks is an important condition for maintaining the stability of electricity supply under conditions of increasing the share of renewable energy sources. The performance of sources such as solar and wind power plants depends on the weather. However, the size of the European Union guarantees that unfavourable conditions will never negatively affect the whole territory of the EU. It is therefore important to meet the electricity interconnection targets of the Member States so that they can ensure the smooth transfer of electricity produced from sources to consumers. It is also important for consumers that the better the interconnection of networks, the better the electricity market works, and this contributes to significant cost savings.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I believe that achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target and improving the functioning of the internal electricity market in the EU will have multiple benefits for all European citizens.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the 10% report on the achievement of electricity interconnection between neighbouring Member States. I think that efforts to reduce dependence on third-country electricity suppliers, who are often unreliable, are very important at the moment. In this way, too, the European Union should increase its energy self-sufficiency, which will be very important in times of unforeseen supply crises. At the same time, such a link will contribute to improving the internal market, the free movement of energy and, ultimately, hopefully, will bring consumers not only a greater sense of security, but also lower electricity prices. On the other hand, I believe that the needs and specificities of individual states should be taken more into account when setting connectivity targets, and these should then be reflected in interconnection plans on the basis of a methodological approach.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report "Achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target – preparing the European electricity grid for 2020" because I believe that electricity interconnection is one of the essential preconditions for completing an internal energy market, without which there can be no Energy Union. The internal energy market will certainly contribute to the Union achieving climate objectives, in particular on renewable energy, and improving its geopolitical position through increased energy security and independence, helping to reduce the energy isolation of certain regions. The 10% target to be achieved by 2020 is a valid target and an important step in the right direction and can be used as a mandatory criterion for the validation of national energy programmes. However, not being an appropriate objective to the real situation of the 28 energy markets, more efforts will be needed to help countries whose low level of interconnection limits the completion of the internal electricity market, as is the case in the Iberian Peninsula. It is therefore important that the Commission considers the establishment of complementary regional targets and that the suitability of the 15% target for 2030 is assessed.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The advantages of creating interconnections between electricity networks enabling interoperability between the various Member States are important, for all the potential reasons pointed out in this resolution. However, as a significant part of the costs of interconnections, as well as the systems associated with them in each State, are borne by the consumers of those States, it is essential to be careful that the potential benefits come to fruition and outsof potential losses. It is therefore necessary that, as the objectives are set, the effects of the resulting actions are judiciously heavy. Issues which this report unfortunately does not deepen. It will be necessary to be careful that interconnections and market mechanisms will not render useless investment in renewable energy (the surpluses of French nuclear will certainly be more competitive), and that it is not national consumers who strongly subsidize these renewable energies so that they are competitive on the European market.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: –   Mr President, I was also pleased to support this report on  microfinance, particularly as I was the shadow rapporteur for my group, ALDE, when we concluded negotiations on the very first tranche of microfinance facilities some years back. Microfinance is for those whom the banks reject, the people to whom the banks say no. That is why I support the call to the Commission to focus its efforts to improve access to microfinance for potentially excluded persons, and that includes: the unemployed, young people, those who have low skills, people with disabilities, and, crucially, migrants and refugees. Indeed, I was very pleased to see that the votes on migrants and refugees were carried because they will often find themselves at the bottom of the list.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on the EU micro-credit facility for micro-enterprises. The vote focused on Parliament's views on the audit report produced by the Commission on the implementation of micro-credit. These credits are intended to act as a means of helping the long-term unemployed, young people, refugees and other groups into the labour market, by offering microcredit when setting up businesses. It is basically a good idea, but basically not something that should be dealt with at European level. Member States should themselves be responsible for their labour market and social policies. Since both the Commission's review report and Parliament's approach to this were characterised by an opposite assessment, I chose to vote against.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The "Progress Microfinance" tool has been approved within the Europe 2020 strategy, with the clear aim of facilitating access to microcredit for the establishment of a new business or the development of an existing one. However, the beneficiaries of this instrument are intermediaries. Indeed, the EU provides guarantees and loans to various microcredit institutions, with the aim of increasing their willingness to lend and finance micro-enterprises. Through progress microfinance, the EU fully achieves its social and employment policy objectives, indirectly funding small businesses while allowing the creation of new jobs. The tabling of a number of amendments, which were discussed and then adopted in committee, also called for greater publicity of the instrument and the methods of access, which are still little known to European citizens. I voted in favour because I believe that Progress Microfinance, at a time of crisis such as the current one, can be an important resource for not only small entrepreneurs, but also workers.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Access to microfinance is an essential measure of support for economic recovery, provided that appropriate macroeconomic policies are developed (which means, first of all, ending austerity measures). Despite the absence of a holistic approach, the report places an appropriate emphasis on the difficulties in working the European microfinance programme, which often does not reach its final beneficiaries. This diagnosis (which I share) and the emphasis on the social impact of these appropriations have inclined me to vote in favour.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. In 2010, the EU launched the Progress Microfinance Facility, worth a total of EUR 205 million, to ensure a chance for socially and financially disadvantaged people to build a viable existence. Progress is intended to make it easier for these people to start micro-enterprises and to promote these micro-enterprises in a targeted manner. This review report, after half the term, paints a positive picture. Progress can help to achieve the employment objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, including in the context of an economic crisis. I think this instrument makes a lot of sense because it helps, among other things, unemployed, socially weak and also young people, who otherwise have little chance of getting credit, to set up businesses and thus generate employment themselves. Progress supports micro-enterprises, which are a large part of European employers. It is about helping people to help themselves. Progress thus fills a significant social and employment gap.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The Schulze report presents some interesting proposals. The aim of this text is to provide the European Union with a microfinance instrument that will help disadvantaged populations and micro-enterprises in difficulty.  Unfortunately, behind these good intentions lie ideological motives that are obvious when reading the report in detail. Gender egalitarianism is once again highlighted with the desire to impose ratios of women entrepreneurs. Then, of course, there is the issue of immigrants. These are clearly defined as potential customers of these microfinances.  Moreover, the report is very vague about the budgets that will be mobilised: by whom, how, for whom? As far as taxpayers' money is concerned, it is necessary to have a clear idea of the effectiveness of this instrument in terms of jobs created in particular. That is why I voted against this project.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose further EU spending.  However laudable microfinance might be, the principle of subsidiarity would suggest that such matters can be better dealt with – and doubtless, less bureaucratically – by Member States (or even local administrations).

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to increase access and availability of microfinance for people who have lost or are at risk of losing their jobs or who have difficulty entering or returning to the labour market, as well as for people facing the threat of social exclusion or vulnerable people who are in a disadvantaged position in terms of access to the conventional market and who want to start or develop their own micro-enterprise.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to ˗ assess the implementation of the Progress Microfinance Facility. Micro-credit is provided not only in developing countries, but also in Europe. In Europe, however, they are primarily a social policy instrument to provide opportunities for people in social difficulties. There are other funding opportunities to promote SMEs and innovative ideas. I agree that the EU concept of micro-credit should be revised and adapted to today's realities. This also applies to the maximum amount of credit that may not be sufficient in all EU countries. It is important that the possibility for non-banks to be microcredit intermediaries should be made available in all Member States. Expert support in the preparation of the business plan and in the verification and monitoring of the business idea should be financed under the Employment and Social Innovation Programme.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This microfinance project is interesting in that it supports the freedom to undertake and helps to create jobs. However, his proven ideological goals pervert him and make him lose all his interest in me. Another text that promotes gender theory, immigrationism, etc. The worrying lack of budgeting for the draft alone justified me voting against this text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The EU created the European Microfinance Instrument Progress in 2010 with an overall budget of 205 million euros to offer socially and financially disadvantaged people in Europe the opportunity to build a decent life.  The instrument is currently only available in 22 of the 28 Member States, due to the diversity of levels of development of national economies within the Union, the varying level of market interest and the regulatory conditions in force. The Commission has drawn up an interim report on the instrument, which is still valid until 2016. In its resolution on this report, Parliament notes that the impact in terms of job creation has been lower than expected, although it must be acknowledged that many beneficiaries would have been completely excluded from the credit market in the absence of microcredits. It also calls for a reduction in the number of rejected cases, a favour of social enterprises and for the EIF to cooperate with microfinance intermediaries. Finally, it calls on Member States to raise awareness of the programme's activities.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report focuses on the implementation of the European Microfinance Instrument Progress, a fund aimed at improving the capacity of intermediaries to increase the number of projects to offer microfinance and to ensure loans on favourable terms for borrowers. We voted in favour because, with caveats, the fund is an instrument that supports economic and social innovation and this report reinforces the public assessment of the social achievements of funding and a more focused approach to social and territorial cohesion. In addition, the report assesses the implementation of this fund and the impact of microfinance on EU societies, which we consider essential. Positive aspects include: expanding geographical scope, improving gender balance in access to microfinance, accessing potentially excluded clients (so that people who do not have access to credit can develop their initiatives and that SMEs can increase their investment capacity) or the possibility of non-bank intermediaries entering the microcredit market without relying on an associated bank.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. U2012 We share the general objectives of this microcredit system, both for the contribution to European employment in the form of jobs created in new enterprises (almost 85% are micro-enterprises) and for strengthening the social orientation for which we are betting. This instrument at the service of entrepreneurs should be particularly sensitive as a lever for incorporating female talent into the economy and play an important role in integrating refugees and immigrants into the labour market.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Once again, European parliamentarians are starting with good intentions to create ideological relationships. For example, the Schulze report seeks to provide the Union with a microfinance instrument, particularly for disadvantaged populations or micro-enterprises in difficulty. If this will is right, the objectives of the text depart from this need to carry dogmatic ideas. Thus, in addition to the latent egalitarianism that proposes to impose ratios of women entrepreneurs in future programmes - as if they were not able to achieve such positions on their own - the report reveals the logic of social dumping that underlies the ultra-liberal vision behind European integration, since the reception of migrants is highlighted by considering them as potential microfinance clients. Moreover, nothing is clear about the funding of this project. If I am in favour of an instrument that allows the social integration of the unemployed or people with disabilities, once again those who are truly in a precarious situation are left out in favour of the other, always a priority over us.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although my colleague's report contains ideas that we can support, I do not agree with the inclusion of asylum seekers and migrants among the beneficiaries of the microfinance access tool. Microcredit should first and foremost be designed to support the entrepreneurship of European citizens, especially the most sensitive groups, such as young people. That is why I voted against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report deals with the implementation of the 2013 European Microfinance Instrument Progress. This instrument, launched in 2010, serves to increase the availability of microcredits – loans below EUR 25 000 – for the creation of small businesses and support for entrepreneurship among those with difficulties in accessing financing through the regular financial system. This instrument was replaced in 2014 by one of the three axes that make up the so-called European Programme for Employment and Social Innovation (EaSI), which has been launched with the new EU financial programming period 2014-2020. It was an instrument specially dedicated to unemployed and/or disabled people, to obtain financing that would allow them to carry out an autonomous or business economic activity of self-employment or even the creation of more jobs. That report therefore calls on the Commission to follow the lines of microfinance and social entrepreneurship in the Progress programme. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has taken Parliament's position on the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility. The aim of this measure is to improve the access and accessibility of microfinance to persons who have lost or may lose their jobs or who are difficult to enter or return to the labour market, as well as those at risk of social exclusion, or vulnerable persons who do not have favourable conditions to access the services of the normal credit market, and those who wish to set up or further expand their very small businesses, including self-employment. Parliament stressed the importance of a financial instrument such as the microfinance facility in order to set up new businesses during the financial crisis, to promote job creation and to ensure access to finance for unemployed people, disadvantaged and micro-enterprises. Notes, however, that the impact on job creation was less than initially expected, despite the fact that many beneficiaries would not have had access to credit on the market at all if there had been no microcredit option. Parliament also regrets the large number of rejected microfinance applications and the still significant gaps in the microfinance market, despite the increase in the number of micro-credit recipients. Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to carry out a more in-depth study of the reasons for rejecting these applications and to find ways of solving the problems.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The original objective of the creation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility was to support growth and jobs and to combat social and financial exclusion. The own-initiative report on the implementation of the instrument, which has been a pilot project since 2010, has identified a number of shortcomings. The project failed to meet its main objective: its impact on job creation was less than expected, despite the fact that without microcredit, many beneficiaries would have been completely squeezed out of the credit market. Of all the businesses supported by the facility, 44% operated for less than a year and only 56% operated the following year. The creditworthiness or ability to do business of persons affected by long-term unemployment should not be overestimated when using this instrument. It is also regrettable that the 2013 Commission report on the implementation of the instrument is very general and contains no specifics.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the Progress Financial Instrument, which supports a micro-payment system for the eu's financially and socially disadvantaged citizens. This can have very positive effects for the local economy and helps disadvantaged people to live a decent life. The Progress instrument is socio-politically oriented and provides access to micro-loans for the creation of micro-enterprises, which are not directly funded but allow eu micro-credit intermediaries participating in the programme to take more credit, as progress improves their credit rating with the refinancing option.  It is therefore an important and effective instrument for achieving the EU's employment and social objectives. Demand for micro-grants is also growing, especially among people who are unable to obtain funds in the normal banking sector, so programmes such as Progress are the easiest way to raise funds.  Unfortunately, the instrument is not yet in place in all EU Member States, but I hope it will be soon, as it really helps to improve the social and labour market situation. So far, 13,252 microcredit cases worth EUR 124.6 million have been approved. I also believe that that instrument could be linked to the so-called 'the same' as the one. the Juncker Fund to achieve even greater impacts and more sustainable jobs.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this report on the implementation of the European Microfinance Instrument. Microfinance is not only an economic, but above all an instrument of social policy.  Microfinance focuses on vulnerable groups with difficult access to finance and the labour market, which contributes to reducing unemployment and social exclusion. However, I must express my scething and say that this document comes a few years too late in the procedure.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Progress is the microfinance tool activated by the European Union. Its nature as an instrument of social policy is (and must remain) a priority over economic policy. Progress is in fact focused on target groups to which the economic system has not so far paid sufficient attention: people who have been unemployed for a long time, recipients of social assistance, migrants, people who work in the informal economy or live in disadvantaged rural areas, and women. With Progress alone, 13,252 micro-credits were disbursed in 2014 alone for a total volume of 124.6 million euros. It is an effective tool that is clearly superior to traditional social welfare systems because it allows you to activate the benefits, to bring them to a condition of autonomy that puts them back in the socio-economic context of their territory, thus lightening the welfare burdens of their country of origin, putting them back in play and improving their personal esteem and confidence in their abilities. We must support this instrument and take it as a positive example to be promoted in the Member States.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Progress Microfinance Facility was created with the aim of giving socially and financially disadvantaged people in Europe the chance to build a decent living. This instrument has a social policy dimension and facilitates access to microcreditfor the establishment and support of micro-enterprises, giving microcredit providers participating in the programme more loans in the EU. The effects of granting these microcredits are reflected in the fight against poverty and also in the reintegration into the labour market. Furthermore, Progress has a positive impact in achieving the EU's employment and social policy objectives under the EU 2020 strategy by supporting vocational advice and training programmes, unlocking entrepreneurial potential and encouraging the establishment of micro-entrepreneurs. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Progress is a valuable and effective tool for supporting disadvantaged groups of people and promoting entrepreneurship, setting up SMEs and implementing innovative ideas that bring added value to the community.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The report contains some very welcome suggestions. Unfortunately, it is sprinkled with references to perfect gender equality (incomprehensible and discriminatory) and to refugees, asylum seekers and migrants, who undermine its goodness. In particular, there is no justification for the fact that illegal immigrants (such are asylum seekers and migrants, until proven otherwise) are to be included among the beneficiaries of the instrument.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Instrument. The recent financial crisis has shown how important it is to have financial instruments such as Progress in order to create new businesses, promote employment and ensure that the unemployed, disadvantaged people and micro-enterprises have access to finance. Microcredit can therefore be understood as an instrument of social policy intended to offer a chance to those in a difficult social situation. However, as the report has pointed out, the spread of Progress is still limited in the European Union. The Commission and the Member States should therefore set up contact points to promote knowledge of this instrument among potential beneficiaries and citizens in general and to raise awareness of the existence of the instrument, the advantages it offers and the methods of access, especially in peripheral regions. The report emphasised these elements and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls to expand the scope and increase the funding and reach of this EU programme. It calls on the Commission to view refugees and asylum seekers as a target group for this money and that this instrument contributes to the EU’s ‘added value’.  While in principle we fully support small business and want to help micro-enterprises gain access to loans, we cannot support this measure which is not very well known and barely used by UK businesses. It effectively takes money off British taxpayers to hand out to businesses in poorer EU countries. The only people who should decide how we spend taxpayers’ money and create legislation to help SMEs are our own elected and accountable national government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that the Progress mechanism can generally be described as a success. If sufficient financial resources are made available, even higher demand could be met. 13 252 microcredits worth EUR 124.6 million were granted, slightly below the target of EUR 142.4 million. Euro. Moreover, many, although not all, of the target groups concerned have been covered. The target ratio of 40:60 women and male entrepreneurs has almost been achieved (37% of beneficiaries are women), although not all credit intermediaries have drawn up specific programmes for the establishment of enterprises by women. This is significantly higher than the rate recorded on average in the EU. However, in this case a balanced quota should be pursued. The sustainability of the jobs created is still difficult to assess at present, because many Progress appropriations were allocated less than a year ago. It is, however, important to ensure that the success of micro-enterprises in the market is monitored after the expiry of the duration of the credit.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Today's vote on the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility is a welcome attempt to find solutions to the economic crisis that has hit European states in recent years. Although it is not a final solution, I voted in favour as it does provide an opportunity to promote innovative ideas and develop entrepreneurship.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. With the creation in 2010 of the Progress Microfinance Instrument for a global volume of EUR 205 million, the European Union took its cue from the positive effects on the local economy achieved in developing countries by granting micro-credits to offer socially and economically disadvantaged people the opportunity to start a business that offers them a living. Progress is currently only available in 22 of the 28 Member States, which is due to the different degree of development of European economies, the different market interest and the legal framework. The Progress microfinance tool has a social approach and facilitates access to microcredit for the establishment or development of micro-enterprises. The instrument does not directly finance micro-enterprises, but allows EU microfinance operators participating in the programme, so-called intermediaries, to grant more loans due to the improvement in credit quality caused by the possibility of refinancing themselves through Progress.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because the creation of this instrument in 2010, with a global volume of EUR 205 million, led the EU to bring positive effects to developing countries by granting micro-credits to socially and economically disadvantaged people. The instrument facilitating access to microcredit for the establishment or development of micro-enterprises is only available in 22 out of 28 Member States. I think it is important for the Progress instrument to focus on the target groups to which the economic system has not so far paid sufficient attention: the unemployed, the recipients of social assistance, immigrants, members of ethnic minorities, people who work in the informal economy or live in disadvantaged rural areas. I think that, in order to improve this instrument further, it is important that the granting of credits is granted in all 28 Member States, it should be possible to grant financial and staff support for the development of an entrepreneurial plan, as well as the verification of the commercial idea and the accompaniment to its implementation. I find all these points in the documentation, which is why I can vote in favour of this report.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Union’s microfinance facility was created to build on the positive impact microloans have had on local economies in developing countries. In this context, EUR 205 million has been made available to boost small businesses.  The facility does not directly finance micro-enterprises, but rather enables participating microcredit providers, so-called intermediaries, to increase their lending, thanks to improved guarantees based on refinancing under Progress Microfinance. The facility helps people to realise their potential as entrepreneurs, develop new skills through training and monitoring, and find jobs.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2010 the European Union created the European Microfinance Instrument "Progress", with the aim of ensuring that socially and economically disadvantaged people have an opportunity to build decent income. Progress is an important and effective instrument for achieving the EU's employment and social policy objectives under the Europe 2020 strategy: a significant number of new jobs are generated by newly established companies. Almost 85% of these jobs are created by micro-enterprises. In this way, there is a strong demand for microcredits by parties of people who are unable to obtain a loan in the traditional banking sector. Progress helps to unleash entrepreneurial potential, to find new skills through training and mentoring, to enable people to return to the labour market and live with dignity and autonomy. Microcredits should be seen as a social policy tool to give people who are in a difficult social situation an opportunity. The maximum amounts of microcredit/loans to be accessed should be rethought as they may not be sufficient in all EU countries. I support this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Progress, created in 2010, is a microfinance tool through which the European Union has taken its cue from the positive effects achieved in developing countries by granting micro-credits to offer socially and economically disadvantaged people the opportunity to start a business in Europe as well. Progress is primarily an instrument of social policy, in that it was created to offer a chance to those in a difficult social situation, and only secondly an instrument of economic policy. I am in favour of the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Instrument as I believe it is important and effective in achieving the EU's social and employment objectives within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy. It will facilitate access to microcredit for the establishment or development of micro-enterprises, thus providing a significant number of new jobs. In addition, Progress plays an important role in integrating or re-entering the labour market, unlocking entrepreneurial potential, acquiring new skills through training and support mentoring.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Union’s microfinance facility was created to build on the positive impact microloans have had on local economies in developing countries. In this context, EUR 205 million has been made available to boost small businesses. This facility does not directly finance micro-enterprises, but rather enables participating microcredit providers, so-called intermediaries, to increase their lending. This facility helps people to realise their potential as entrepreneurs, develop new skills through training and monitoring, and find jobs. This important facility is aimed at target groups such as the unemployed, those claiming social security benefits and people who cannot get conventional bank loans. This important measure fosters EU objectives in support of innovation, research and development, entrepreneurship, growth, and employment, thus I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Progress is an instrument that allows union microfinance operators, the so-called intermediaries, to grant more loans due to the improvement in credit quality, determined by the possibility of refinancing themselves. It is an important and effective instrument for achieving the EU's social and employment objectives under the Europe 2020 strategy. In fact, newly established enterprises generate a significant number of new jobs. Micro-enterprises create almost 85% of these jobs. There is relatively high demand for microcredit from people who are unable to obtain a loan in the classical banking sector, as for this sector they represent a category of beneficiaries associated with prohibitive costs. Progress allows you to re-enter the labour market, unlock entrepreneurial potential, acquire new skills through supportive training and mentoring, and help people live independently and with dignity. For banks, microcredit is expensive and unprofitable and its marketing is therefore unattractive. We have also called for this instrument to be encouraged, developed by ensuring greater publicity and information on how to access it; intensify partnerships with non-bank actors. Fully in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Access to microfinance is an essential measure of support for economic recovery, provided that appropriate macroeconomic policies are developed (which means, first of all, ending austerity measures). Despite the absence of a holistic approach, the report places an appropriate emphasis on the difficulties in working the European microfinance programme, which often does not reach its final beneficiaries. This diagnosis (which I share) and the emphasis on the social impact of these appropriations have inclined me to vote in favour.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the European Progress microfinance instrument is to increase access to microfinance and its availability for those who have lost or are at risk of losing their jobs or have difficulty entering or re-entering the labour market, as well as increasing access to microfinance and their availability for micro-enterprises and the social economy. I voted in favour of this resolution because, in times of financial crisis, I am convinced that this instrument is of crucial importance for the creation of new businesses, the promotion of employment and the protection of the unemployed, the disadvantaged and so that micro-enterprises have access to finance.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the fact that the European Commission must focus its efforts to improve access to microfinance for potentially excluded customers, such as migrants, refugees, the long-term unemployed, young people, low-income people, low-skilled workers and people with disabilities who currently do not benefit from the instrument.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report aims to set up the European microfinance instrument. With an overall budget of 205 million euros and intended to help micro-enterprises, this instrument draws on the positive results of microcredit policy in developing countries. This program does not directly finance micro-entrepreneurs but allows the microcredit companies that participate in it to grant more loans on advantageous terms, for a maximum of 25,000 euros per beneficiary.  Considering that this programme aims to unlock entrepreneurial potential in Europe and contributes to the strengthening of vocational training throughout the career, I voted for it.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls to expand the scope and increase the funding and reach of this EU programme. It calls on the Commission to view refugees and asylum seekers as a target group for this money and that this instrument contributes to the EU’s ‘added value’.  While in principle we fully support small business and want to help micro-enterprises gain access to loans, we cannot support this measure which is not very well known and barely used by UK businesses. It effectively takes money off British taxpayers to hand out to businesses in poorer EU countries. The only people who should decide how we spend taxpayers’ money and create legislation to help SMEs are our own elected and accountable national government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European "Progress" instrument aims to facilitate access to micro-credits for vulnerable people, such as the unemployed, low-income people or young people, for the creation or development of micro-enterprises. With this vote, I supported this instrument, which aims to lift people out of poverty and improve the social inclusion of vulnerable people.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The european Progress microfinance facility, which receives financial contributions from the Union and the European Investment Bank and is managed by the European Investment Fund (EBA) and expects additional funding from private investors, was originally intended to support growth and jobs and combat social and financial exclusion. The own-initiative report on the implementation of the instrument, which has been a pilot project since 2010, has identified a number of shortcomings. In the course of the vote, with a few exceptions, I followed the people's party position. It was unable to meet its main objective: its impact on job creation was less than expected, despite the fact that without microcredit, many beneficiaries would have been completely squeezed out of the credit market. Of all the businesses supported by the facility, 44% operated for less than a year and only 56% operated the following year. The creditworthiness or ability to do business of persons affected by long-term unemployment should not be overestimated when using this instrument. It is also regrettable that the Commission's 2013 report on the implementation of the instrument is very general and contains no specifics. Nevertheless, making this instrument part of solving the migration crisis in 2015 is a very irresponsible, vain fantasy, given the qualifications of migrants and their competitiveness in the labour market, their competences and the complete lack of statistics and impact assessments on this.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. In seeking to provide the European Union with an instrument for the microfinance of disadvantaged people, this report is part of an unfortunate ideological line. Indeed, while the principle of microcredit is quite commendable, the programmes concerned that will benefit from this instrument are biased and oriented. While this instrument could be used for social integration through work, it could just as well be used for pro-immigration policies or actions supporting utopian discourses on gender theory. Attached to the proper use of public funds and the foreseeable inefficiency in the real economy of these measures, I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support any funding from Europe, especially now that my country is experiencing great economic difficulties and a very large number of Bulgarians live on the brink of poverty. I am surprised that only 1000 Bulgarians have managed to find work under the Progress programme, which is why I welcome the desire to improve accessibility to microfining. I supported this report, although there are worrying things, such as the fact that some of the target groups are immigrants and ethnic minorities, which puts them in a privileged state, as always, but I like that here we are also striving to reach the long-term unemployed and people living in the country, as well as those who work in the informal part of the economy. If we can reach the latter a little bit, it will be a great victory for us and the whole Union. This is the path for growth of the EU economy, not direct access, but loans to business, which leads to high added value.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against this report because, although it refers to a very important support mechanism, it nevertheless tries to make illegal immigrants the target group of this mechanism, rather than being interested in the problems of European citizens.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The european Progress microfinance facility, which receives financial contributions from the Union and the European Investment Bank and is managed by the European Investment Fund (EBA) and expects additional funding from private investors, was originally intended to support growth and jobs and combat social and financial exclusion. The own-initiative report on the implementation of the instrument, which has been a pilot project since 2010, has identified a number of shortcomings. In the course of the vote, with a few exceptions, I followed the people's party position. It was unable to meet its main objective: its impact on job creation was less than expected, despite the fact that without microcredit, many beneficiaries would have been completely squeezed out of the credit market. Of all the businesses supported by the facility, 44% operated for less than a year and only 56% operated the following year. The creditworthiness or ability to do business of persons affected by long-term unemployment should not be overestimated when using this instrument. It is also regrettable that the Commission's 2013 report on the implementation of the instrument is very general and contains no specifics. Nevertheless, making this instrument part of solving the migration crisis in 2015 is a very irresponsible, vain fantasy, given the qualifications of migrants and their competitiveness in the labour market, their competences and the complete lack of statistics and impact assessments on this.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal due to the positive effects of the granting of microcredits under the Progress microfinance instrument, which ends in 2016. Progress is the only EU financial instrument that relies solely on the social conditions of applicants rather than promoting entrepreneurship and innovation in the European business fabric, focusing on supporting socially and economically disadvantaged people in Europe (unemployed, young people, the elderly) helping them to get out of their situation by providing microcredits that would enable them to set up their own businesses.
