Taking into account the positive results of a key instrument for EU employment and social policy, and taking into account the fact that a new microfinance programme has been established for the 2014-2020 cycle (EaSI microfinance axis) based on progress' positive experience, it can be concluded that the programme has met its objectives and therefore received my vote in favour.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 This report dealt with the financing of business start-ups on the basis of the European Progress microfinance instrument. The instrument is not working very optimally today and the changes highlighted in the report, including facilitating access to these credits for people far from the labour market, are a good one.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it favours the reception of migrants.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Microfinance is the set of financial services for individuals and SMEs with reduced access to bank credit and associated services. In the EU this instrument has been used in policies of job creation, social inclusion and gender equality. This report assesses the implementation of Progress (launched in 2010) and its impact. The use of microcredit has been limited, with a high number of unapproved projects; information on this mechanism does not reach its potential beneficiaries; effectiveness in territorial cohesion is questionable. The report aims to address these weaknesses. Training of those involved, greater territorial dispersion and greater focus on cohesion, information related to the projects and evaluation processes of the program – are some of the issues addressed. The emphasis placed on microcredit solutions, entrepreneurship, etc., as a way to solve unemployment, exclusion, inequality and the economic crisis is fallacious and dangerous, because it is unaccountable to states. This does not invalidate that there may be support for the creation or reinstatement of companies, but without limiting real solutions to social problems. The report does not emphasize microfinance as an absolute solution. In this sense, we voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. Progress has proved over the years to be a useful tool for setting up and developing small businesses, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: Written. We Moderates are sceptical that the EU has a microcredit facility. However, it is important for the European Parliament to give reasonable and balanced views on how the decision is implemented once it has been taken. That is why we have voted in favour of the report.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 By creating a progress microfinance facility totalling €205 million, the European Union has achieved positive effects in alleviating poverty in developing countries. At the same time, it has given socially and financially disadvantaged people in Europe the opportunity to make a decent living. Progress is available in 22 of the 28 Member States, but this is due to different levels of economic development, different market interests as well as regulatory conditions. Progress has a social dimension and facilitates access to microcredit to set up and support micro-enterprises. It also helps to return to the labour market and acquire new skills through training and mentoring, and enables people to lead a responsible and dignified life. According to the definition in force, microcredit may not exceed EUR 25 000.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because, although I agree with the policy on microcredit, this report has been exploited by inserting special mentions for asylum seekers and migrants.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is negative despite the fact that this report refers to a very important support mechanism, because it seeks to make illegal immigrants the target group of this mechanism instead of caring about the problems of European citizens.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe we have to stress the importance of micro-financing in general and for vulnerable groups in particular as well as the importance of good conduct on the part of microcredit providers, sound data collection and non-financial support for beneficiaries. I would like to underline the importance of the Facility, especially in times of crisis, in its role of enabling unemployed and disadvantaged people to have access to financing, and to emphasise that given the current migration and asylum crisis in particular, micro-financing can act as an important support for refugees and migrants entering the EU labour market. Micro-financing is not only an economic but first and foremost a social policy instrument. Due to its focus on vulnerable groups with difficult access to financing and the labour market it contributes to reducing unemployment and social exclusion. The provision of microcredits must follow the rules of good conduct and be complemented by non-financial support for beneficiaries.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The original objective of the creation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility, which receives financial contributions from the Union and the European Investment Bank and is managed by the European Investment Fund (EBA) and expects additional funding from private investors, was originally intended to support growth and job creation and to combat social and financial exclusion. The own-initiative report on the implementation of the instrument, which has been a pilot project since 2010, has identified a number of shortcomings. In the course of the vote, with a few exceptions, I followed the people's party position. It was unable to meet its main objective: its impact on job creation was less than expected, despite the fact that without microcredit, many beneficiaries would have been completely squeezed out of the credit market. Of all the businesses supported by the facility, 44% operated for less than a year and only 56% operated the following year. The creditworthiness or ability to do business of persons affected by long-term unemployment should not be overestimated when using this instrument. It is also regrettable that the Commission's 2013 report on the implementation of the instrument is very general and contains no specifics. Nevertheless, making this instrument part of solving the migration crisis in 2015 is a very irresponsible, vain fantasy, given the qualifications of migrants and their competitiveness in the labour market, their competences and the complete lack of statistics and impact assessments on this.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Progress microfinance is currently only available in 22 of the 28 Member States. This is due to the different levels of development of European national economies, different market interests and different legal conditions. The Progress Microfinance Facility has a social policy dimension and aims to facilitate access to microcredit aimed at setting up or promoting micro-enterprises. Progress is an important and effective tool to achieve the EU's employment and social objectives under the Europe 2020 strategy. The Progress tool helps people to (re)enter the labour market, unlock entrepreneurial potential, acquire new skills through training and mentoring, and give people dignity by enabling them to take responsibility for their own destiny. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the conviction that microcredits can have a significant economic impact on the EU. Progress is an important and effective tool for achieving EU objectives in the areas of employment and social affairs under the 2020 Strategy, as it is aimed at the unemployed and the long-term unemployed, beneficiaries of social assistance, immigrants, members of ethnic minorities, people active in the informal economy or residents of disadvantaged rural areas , and women. There is no doubt that Progress is a success, but, with adequate financial endowment, it would even be possible to meet significantly higher demand.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I can only support with my vote the resolution on an important instrument such as progress in microfinance. I am convinced that it is our duty, as Members of the European Parliament, to support economic growth, development, social inclusion and new opportunities for young people and the most disadvantaged groups by all means at our disposal. Progress is all this, a possibility offered to those who had a dream of micro-enterprises, but not access to the means to realize it. A good example that Europe's first commitment, especially in times of economic crisis, is to improve people's lives, involve them and increase employment.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility today, as I believe this EU initiative is a successful project, which has already enabled people who want to start up or expand their own small business to have easier access to credit. Progress promotes employment and social inclusion through entrepreneurship and self-employment in Europe and is closely aligned with existing instruments to promote microfinance in the European Union. At the same time, the report identifies and identifies the need for change in order to work even more efficiently with Progress.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The programme supports micro-enterprises in developing and training staff in a targeted manner. This is not only an important step for the development of individual companies, but also has a great social significance.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility given its vital role in providing access to financing for groups in society who usually struggle to do so. The EPMF has granted EUR 124.6 million to people who would not normally have access to financing.  I also welcome the European Parliament report’s call for a better social impact reporting and targeting of vulnerable groups.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report focuses on the implementation of the European Microfinance Instrument Progress, a fund aimed at improving the ability of intermediaries to increase the number of projects to offer microfinance and to ensure loans on favourable terms for borrowers. We voted in favour because, with caveats, the fund is an instrument that supports economic and social innovation and this report reinforces the public assessment of the social achievements of funding and a more focused approach to social and territorial cohesion. In addition, the report assesses the implementation of this fund and the impact of microfinance on EU societies, which we consider essential. Positive aspects include: expanding geographical scope, improving gender balance in access to microfinance, accessing potentially excluded clients (so that people who do not have access to credit can develop their initiatives and that SMEs can increase their investment capacity) or the possibility of non-bank intermediaries entering the microcredit market without relying on an associated bank.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own initiative report because we need to have a more effective implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility (EPMF). The EPMF has granted EUR 124.6 million to people who would not normally have access to financing. Its effectiveness in the case of disadvantaged groups is less clear, and that is why I welcome the European Parliament report’s call for a better social impact reporting and targeting of vulnerable groups

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls to expand the scope and increase the funding and reach of this EU programme. It calls on the Commission to view refugees and asylum seekers as a target group for this money and that this instrument contributes to the EU’s ‘added value’.  While in principle we fully support small business and want to help micro-enterprises gain access to loans, we cannot support this measure which is not very well known and barely used by UK businesses. It effectively takes money off British taxpayers to hand out to businesses in poorer EU countries. The only people who should decide how we spend taxpayers’ money and create legislation to help SMEs are our own elected and accountable national government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday, December 15, I voted in favour of the report on the microfinance instrument for microenterprises, Progress, which aims to give a boost to those who want to embark on the entrepreneurial adventure but lack the means to carry out their projects.  With a budget of 24.3 million euros for the period 2014-2020, PROGRESS funds microcredit organizations to offer loans of less than 25,000 euros to microentrepreneurs wishing to start or develop a business. This instrument contributes to the reintegration into the labour market of certain groups, such as the long-term unemployed or people from remote rural areas, who generally struggle to access financing opportunities from conventional banks. It is a great tool that promotes entrepreneurship and supports the development of growth and employment in Europe.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe microfinance contributes to meeting the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy and can lift people out of poverty and unemployment, give them dignity and enhance cohesion in communities by improving social inclusion and minimising social divergences

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The european Progress microfinance facility, which receives financial contributions from the Union and the European Investment Bank and is managed by the European Investment Fund (EBA) and expects additional funding from private investors, was originally intended to support growth and jobs and combat social and financial exclusion. The own-initiative report on the implementation of the instrument, which has been a pilot project since 2010, has identified a number of shortcomings.  It failed to meet the main objective of the new instrument: its impact on job creation is less than expected, despite the fact that without microcredit, many beneficiaries would have been completely squeezed out of the credit market. Of all the businesses supported by the facility, 44% operated for less than a year, and only 56% of businesses operated the following year. The creditworthiness or ability to do business of persons affected by long-term unemployment should not be overestimated when using this instrument. It is also regrettable that the Commission's 2013 report on the implementation of the instrument is very general and contains no specifics. Against this background, making this instrument part of solving the migration crisis in 2015 is a very irresponsible, vain attitude, given the qualifications of migrants, their competitiveness in the labour market, their competences and the complete lack of statistics and impact assessments.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The zero results of this mechanism have been made clear at least through the criticism made of it in the process of discussing the report. However, we have decided to support the mechanism because it is one of the few cases where very small businesses are given an opportunity to finance themselves, so that the economy can move again at local level.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report due to the fact that the aim of the European Progress Microfinance Facility created in 2010 with total funding of EUR 205 million, is to give socially and financially disadvantaged people in Europe a chance to build a decent life. Progress Microfinance is currently available in only 22 of the 28 Member States. The reasons for this incomplete coverage are the varying degrees of economic development, varying degrees of market interest and the current legislative basis in each country. The facility helps people to realise their potential as entrepreneurs, develop new skills through training and monitoring and find jobs. Since the facility is aimed at target groups such as the unemployed, those claiming social security benefits, immigrants and people who cannot get conventional bank loans, it is primarily a socio-political instrument, providing loans of up to EUR 25,000.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Progress Microfinance Facility aims at increasing the availability of loans below EUR 25,000 for implementing or developing small businesses by enabling microcredit providers in the EU to increase lending by issuing guarantees. The Commission’s Implementation Report states that the number of signatories, most of which are from Southern and Eastern Europe, has increased and describes the profiles of the recipients. Parliament’s own-initiative report makes further recommendations on how the results can be improved, and since my group and I are satisfied with its contents, which included a number of valuable amendments, I have voted in favour of it. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I agree with the rapporteur that progress is primarily a social policy instrument, not an economic one. I am of the opinion that its target groups have been well defined and that it has the potential for real support in the professional activation of vulnerable and socially excluded groups. Unfortunately, I believe that we do not yet have reliable data on the effectiveness of the instrument so far in terms of job creation, business development and reaching out to minority groups. It is important to prepare appropriate indicators for such an assessment in the future. Better evaluation opportunities will certainly provide a good basis for possible changes and increased support efficiency.  In addition, in the future it is worth focusing on increasing the effectiveness of the instrument in the field of social economy. It is a branch of the economy that has great added value for society as a whole and fits well with the Europe 2020 targets. I therefore believe that it is worth considering changes to the rules for the application of the instrument, such as the increase in the limit of microcredit available by the rapporteur proposed by the rapporteur, so that it is more widely used to support the establishment and functioning of social enterprises.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The european Progress microfinance facility, which receives financial contributions from the Union and the European Investment Bank, managed by the European Investment Fund (EBA) and expects additional funding from private investors, was originally intended to support growth and jobs and combat social and financial exclusion. The own-initiative report on the implementation of the instrument, which has been a pilot project since 2010, has identified a number of shortcomings. In the course of the vote, with a few exceptions, I followed the people's party position. It failed to meet its main goal: its impact on job creation was less than expected. Despite the fact that without microcredit, many beneficiaries would have been completely squeezed out of the credit market. Of all the businesses supported by the facility, 44% operated for less than a year and only 56% operated the following year. The creditworthiness or ability to do business of persons affected by long-term unemployment should not be overestimated when using this instrument. It is also regrettable that the Commission's 2013 report on the implementation of the instrument is very general and contains no specifics. Nevertheless, to make this instrument part of the solution to the migration crisis that will be emerging in 2015 is a very irresponsible, vain fantasy.' This may be particularly true in view of the qualifications and competitiveness of migrants in the labour market, their competences and the complete lack of statistics and impact assessments on this.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report and in particular support the clauses highlighting that microfinance should be available beyond SMEs.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that will implement a social policy instrument with which to give people in difficult social situations a chance.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the implementation of the European Progress microfinance instrument, as it aims to increase the availability and availability of microfinance to people who have lost their jobs, risk losing their jobs or have difficulties entering the labour market. It is important that the programme gives opportunities to groups of citizens who are particularly vulnerable and marginalised as regards employment as a result of their situation.  Given that the geographical area covered by the instrument in the EU remains limited, as it is only 22 of the 28 Member States, the Commission should make greater efforts to address this. It is necessary to further investigate the data on the results of the program, its results, in particular the newly created jobs, and create additional mechanisms to make the program more used, more accessible and fewer rejected requests.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is to provide the Union with a microfinance instrument to help disadvantaged populations and micro-enterprises in difficulty. Nevertheless, and unfortunately, gender egalitarianism is once again highlighted with the desire to impose ratios of women entrepreneurs, not to mention the issue of immigrants. These are clearly defined as potential customers of these microfinances.  It is also very vague about the budgets that will be mobilised: by whom, how, for whom? As far as taxpayers' money is concerned, it is necessary to have a clear idea of the effectiveness of this instrument in terms of jobs created in particular.  I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls to expand the scope and increase the funding and reach of this EU programme. It calls on the Commission to view refugees and asylum seekers as a target group for this money and that this instrument contributes to the EU’s ‘added value’.  While in principle I fully support small business and want to help micro-enterprises gain access to loans, I cannot support this measure which is not very well known and barely used by UK businesses. It effectively takes money off British taxpayers to hand out to businesses in poorer EU countries. The only people who should decide how we spend taxpayers’ money and create legislation to help SMEs are our own elected and accountable national government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Sven Schulze's report on the implementation of the European Microfinance Progress instrument. Progress supports microfinance for the creation or development of a business by financing microcredit organizations. 124.6 million euros were allocated in 2015. However, the Progress instrument can be further improved and the maximum amount of 25,000 euros increased to support companies in the social economy.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome the report by Mr. Schulz. Indeed, microfinance has proved to be a useful tool in promoting self-employment among people who have lost their jobs as well as in helping micro-enterprises to have access to credit in times of crises. However, the microfinance market is still very fragmented in the EU with very different regulations. In many European countries, such as my country Greece, microfinance is the monopoly of banks. Only regulated banks may engage in micro-lending and there is no specific regulation for the sector. So banks have the monopoly but target groups of microfinance —unemployed, disadvantaged people—differ from those of banks. Moreover, as the report highlights, micro-credits are linked to the provision of support services to beneficiaries, again something that it is not usually within the remit of a bank. This has led to a strange situation where microfinance and the EU tools –Progress and the new EaSI- are not fully working in a country, Greece, where —with an unemployed rate above 25%— is so badly needed. We support the report's call to investigate possibilities for non-bank intermediaries to enter the microcredit market without a partnering bank".

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. As the microfinance facility facilitates access to microcredit for micro-enterprises for the start-up and access to support, I agree with this report.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The microcredits as alternatives to traditional bank loans which include  high transaction costs and extensive bureaucracy, have proven to be an efficient tool in developing countries. This  enables the local population  to start their own businesses and develop local entrepreneurship, despite of scarce resources.  Since 2013, also in the EU, the Progress Microfinance Facility has made available  EUR 205 million to boost development of small businesses. True, the facility does not directly finance micro-enterprises. It rather enables and encourages participating microcredit providers, the intermediaries, to extend and increase their lending capacity, thanks to improved guarantees based on refinancing under the facility. This tool, aimed to encourage emergence of micro-enterprises and self-employment, in particular among people hit by unemployment, carries the valuable message of helping people to help themselves. As a rule, these people would not be able to qualify for  traditional banking loans; therefore providing such microcredit options is a must. In order to involve a wider range of people who need microcredits, the rules have to be clear and simple, avoiding as much as possible unnecessary bureaucracy. This applies both for the intermediaries, as well as for the applying micro-businesses and self-employed people.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EPMF has granted EUR 124.6 million to people who would not normally have access to financing. Its effectiveness in the case of disadvantaged groups is less clear, and that is why I welcome the European Parliament report’s call for a better social impact reporting and targeting of vulnerable groups.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The original objective of the creation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility, which receives financial contributions from the Union and the European Investment Bank and is managed by the European Investment Fund (EBA) and expects additional funding from private investors, was originally intended to support growth and job creation and to combat social and financial exclusion. The own-initiative report on the implementation of the instrument, which has been a pilot project since 2010, has identified a number of shortcomings. In the course of the vote, with a few exceptions, I followed the people's party position. It was unable to meet its main objective: its impact on job creation was less than expected, despite the fact that without microcredit, many beneficiaries would have been completely squeezed out of the credit market. Of all the businesses supported by the facility, 44% operated for less than a year and only 56% operated the following year. The creditworthiness or ability to do business of persons affected by long-term unemployment should not be overestimated when using this instrument. It is also regrettable that the Commission's 2013 report on the implementation of the instrument is very general and contains no specifics. Nevertheless, making this instrument part of solving the migration crisis in 2015 is a very irresponsible, vain fantasy, given the qualifications of migrants and their competitiveness in the labour market, their competences and the complete lack of statistics and impact assessments on this.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report evaluates the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility, which is a framework of financial services to persons and small enterprises lacking access to banking and related services. It does not finance micro-entrepreneurs itself but enables microfinance providers (‘intermediaries’) participating in the program in the EU to grant more loans.  It is deplorable that, in times of economic crisis, the impact of this instrument on employment creation and on social and territorial cohesion was less than initially expected. Hence, this report stresses the need to strengthen the efficiency of the facility by improving information and data about this instrument, by enlarging its geographical scope, by providing a simplified access to its beneficiaries and to potentially excluded clients. Therefore, I voted in favour.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility and supported amendments highlighting the value of this instrument for the inclusion of women, immigrants and refugees in the labour market.  The integration of these groups into the labour market is important not only from the perspective of social cohesion and justice, but also from an economic perspective. Women are underrepresented in the labour market and overcoming barriers to market access requires increased flexibility, independence in organisation and working time, in which microfinance instruments can be very helpful. Thanks to the Progress instrument, women's professional potential, entrepreneurship, competences and talents can be developed and exploited on the labour market. The same applies to migrants and refugees, more than 15% of whom have tertiary education and a much higher proportion of business experience; each month of delay in their entry into the labour market increases the social security burden on Member States and worsens the situation of migrants themselves and their families. I therefore support the use of this instrument to integrate refugees and migrants into the labour market, but I am opposed to making migrants awaiting asylum the main recipient of the programme, because, for example, because of the unclear legal situation, they would not be able to properly use these funds and act in accordance with the objective for which the microfinance instrument was set up.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Progress microfinance tool aims to facilitate access to microcredit for the creation or development of micro-enterprises. This instrument is perfectly combined with the need to improve credit quality, since, although it does not directly finance companies, it allows operators to grant more loans. Its function is therefore twofold because it will make a strong contribution to the creation of many micro-enterprises and facilitate access to microcredit for existing ones. This is a fundamental instrument at a time of difficulty, and I believe that facilitating small businesses can help them to start again after the crisis.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the implementation of the European Microfinance Progress instrument. This text aims to provide the Union with a microfinance instrument for disadvantaged populations or micro-enterprises in difficulty.  If this project seems interesting to me, in the sense that it supports freedom of enterprise and aims to create jobs in Europe, it appears from reading the text in question that more ideological objectives are also being pursued. Indeed, gender egalitarianism is clearly targeted, considering ratios of women entrepreneurs in future programmes, and welcoming migrants, considering them as potential clients of microfinance.  In addition, funding for this project is not clearly defined. Several funds and programs are cited, without clearly specifying their functions and contributions. Finally, the lack of efficiency (disappointing results in terms of jobs created) and information on beneficiaries are highlighted several times.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MEPs voted against the text because it gives way to the Union's usual whims: support for migrants, feminism exacerbated, devotion to the Brussels Commission. It is a pity because the initial objective of the text - to enable the unemployed and disadvantaged to access the microfinance of their projects - was interesting.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with subsidies of this type or with the favouritism of some groups at the expense of others.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Progress is a significant and effective instrument for achieving the EU's employment and social policy objectives under the 2020 Strategy, however, it is currently present in only 22 Member States. The reasons for incomplete coverage are varying degrees of economic development, market interest and current legislative bases in each member state.  I supported mep Sven Shultze's report and the recommendation to continue implementing Progress, as I believe that microcredit in Europe should be seen primarily as an instrument of social policy that gives people in difficult social situations the opportunity to use other available mechanisms.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The economy of any country is usually based on small to medium-sized enterprises, which is why one of the most effective methods of eradicating poverty, especially in South Asian countries, has been micro-crediting the population for decades. Thanks to this, the people themselves are given a sufficiently effective tool to get out of poverty, while helping their loved ones, neighbours and other fellow citizens. The fight against global poverty, especially in developing countries, has for many years been one of the primary aspects of the European Union's foreign policy, particularly in Asia and Africa. But the point is that poverty is still present here in Europe. The introduction of the European Progress Microfinance Facility and planned support are therefore undeniably one of the most effective instruments of the relevant EU policy within it. More than 13 thousand micro-loans have already been provided for a total amount of almost EUR 125 million. Given the credit restructuring guarantees provided by the EPM, and the frequent reluctance of 'classical' banks to provide this type of loans, the further support and expansion of the EPMB for all 28 EU Member States (currently due to only 22 national characteristics) are very important steps to be promoted alongside all others geared towards reducing poverty among Europeans.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Progress Microfinance Facility targets the most vulnerable social groups – the unemployed, social benefit recipients, immigrants, members of national minorities, persons working in the informal economy or living in rural areas and women. Progess refinancing facilitates access to microcredit to set up and support micro-enterprises. This allows these groups to join the labour market and thus lead a full life. In the future, this instrument needs to be more focused on employing young people and reducing the administrative complexity of the requirements in obtaining it. At the same time, it is necessary for the EC to raise awareness of this instrument.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from voting on the report on the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility because it is neither complete nor documented. I also refer to the speeches I gave in detail in my speech of 14/12/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution which ‘Stresses the importance of a financial instrument such as the Facility in times of financial crisis in creating new undertakings, promoting new employment and ensuring that unemployed, disadvantaged people and microenterprises have access to financing, while mitigating the risk for MFIs’.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it.  We recognise that this is an interesting subject since this principle of microcredit encourages entrepreneurship and job creation, but it is perverted by egalitarian amendments and by the pathological need to include migrants in all European texts, even those who have no connection with them.  We also condemn the lack of budgeting to shed light on the real costs and benefits of this instrument. Finally, the poor results observed lead us to vote against it.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Instrument. The aim of the facility is to increase access to microfinance and their availability for people at risk of social exclusion or those who are at a disadvantage in terms of access to the credit market and who wish to start or develop their micro-enterprises. It is of the utmost importance that we have a financial instrument, such as Progress, to create new businesses, to promote employment and to guarantee all categories of recipients to whom the economic system has not paid adequate attention access to finance.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The "Progress microfinance" instrument was created in 2010 for a total of EUR 205 million. The granting of micro-credits has favoured the economy in developing countries by giving them the opportunity to start up their own businesses. The instrument does not directly finance micro-enterprises, but allows EU micro-finance operators, so-called intermediaries, to grant more loans because of the improvement in credit quality caused by the possibility of refinancing themselves through Progress. Given the economic and social importance of this instrument, I am voting in favour of Mr Schulze's proposal.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. It is important to have a microfinance instrument such as Progress in the EU. During its first years of operation it has proven useful, but also some deficiencies that need to be corrected. I therefore support the report of this Parliament in which we make a number of assessments which we hope will be take into account in order to improve the effects of this instrument and which can reach places or sectors where it is not being implemented.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. As the microfinance facility facilitates access to microcredit to create or promote micro-enterprises, and given that almost 85% of all new jobs are created in micro-enterprises and that they are often unable to obtain credit in the traditional banking sector, as they are a prohibitively costly target group for them, the report is generally to be welcomed. Unfortunately, at the same time, the report calls for unjustified preference for women over men. It also calls for a 'equal quota of entrepreneurs'. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR)
text: in writing. – Conservatives voted in favour of this report. We believe that SMEs and microenterprises represent a huge opportunity for growth and job creation and will support any initiatives that help them do this. We believe that the implementation of this facility in many Member States has contributed to economic growth and social inclusion, and has enabled worthy entrepreneurs to get their projects off the ground.  Conservatives’ guiding principle is that any proposal or initiatives derived from the EU which has an impact on citizens’ lives, both in terms of financial cost and quality of life, must reflect the principle of ‘EU added value’. We believe that this facility complements initiatives already in place in the Member States, for example in the UK – the British Business Bank.  Conservatives will always support initiatives that give hard working people, disadvantaged groups and other target groups, including female entrepreneurs, opportunities to become economically active. We support and welcome innovative ways that create real policy outcomes and represent a shift in how the EU budget is spent.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The granting of microcredits has its origins in South Asia and Latin America, where the first microcredit initiatives began more than forty years ago. The positive effects on the local economy of developing countries in the fight against poverty have inspired the European Union, which created the European Microfinance Instrument Progress in 2010, with an overall budget of 205 million euros. This instrument has a social dimension and aims to facilitate access to microcredits for the creation or development of micro-enterprises. It does not directly finance micro-entrepreneurs, but it does allow EU microfinance intermediaries participating in the programme to grant more loans thanks to a higher credit rating enabled by the possibility of refinancing with the instrument.  However, I do not share the unthinking enthusiasm of some for microcredit, which in many cases replaces redistribution programmes and generates significant profits for lending institutions because of the exorbitant interest rates they charge.  Since the issue of interest rates is not mentioned in the report, I prefer to abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The Schulze report aims to provide the Union with a microfinance instrument for disadvantaged populations or micro-enterprises in difficulty.  If we find this project interesting, in the sense that it supports the freedom to undertake and aims to create jobs in Europe, it appears from the text in question that more ideological objectives are also being pursued. Indeed, gender egalitarianism is clearly targeted, considering ratios of women entrepreneurs in future programmes, and welcoming migrants, considering them as potential clients of microfinance.  In addition, funding for this project is not clearly defined. Several funds and programs are cited without clearly specifying their functions and contributions. Finally, on several occasions, the lack of efficiency and information about beneficiaries is highlighted. So I voted against this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Progress Microfinance Facility aims to provide economically and socially disadvantaged people in Europe with an opportunity, whether it is for the creation of new businesses, for the promotion of new jobs or to ensure that the unemployed and micro-enterprises can access finance. This European instrument is important for achieving the Union's employment and social policy objectives, and I therefore voted in favour of this report on its implementation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it makes funding available for microenterprises, allowing entrepreneurs to create employment, training and economic growth.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The economic situation is pushing us to strengthen financial instruments, including the creation of new businesses. In this regard, access to microfinance can play a significant role. Even if the results on job creation are below our expectations, this mechanism still represents significant benefits because many would not have been able to access credit in the absence of microcredits. So it's about perfecting that mechanism. In order to do this, it is necessary to guarantee greater publicity of this instrument and to broaden its geographical and sectoral scope so that it can cover all activities within the Union.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Micro-financing is not only an economic but first and foremost a social policy instrument, therefore I voted in favour of the report on implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility due to its focus on vulnerable groups with difficult access to financing and the labour market, which will further contribute to reducing unemployment and social exclusion in Europe.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In 2010, for the period up to 2016, the EU set up a Progress Microfinance Facility totalling EUR 205 million to give disadvantaged Europeans a chance to create decent living conditions by facilitating access to microcredit for the creation or promotion of micro-enterprises. Progress has proven to be an important and effective tool to achieve the EU's employment and social objectives under the Europe 2020 strategy, according to a report by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Thanks to newly established companies, a significant number of new jobs are created and around 85% of these jobs are created within micro-enterprises. The report points out that microcredit in Europe should be seen primarily as a social policy instrument in order to give people in difficulty a chance, as there are other support options available to promote SMEs and innovative ideas. It emphasises the need to rethink the EU definition of microcredit and to adjust it to the current situation. Finally, it proposes to continue the Progress microcredit programme. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Progress Microfinance Facility was set up in 2010 with the aim of ensuring that socially and economically disadvantaged people in Europe have an opportunity to build decent income. It is important to stress that Progress has a social dimension and facilitates access to microcredit with a view to creating or supporting micro-enterprises and is an important and effective instrument for achieving the European Union's employment and social policy objectives under the Europe 2020 strategy. I would like to unsee the social benefits that Progress offers, in particular to help (re)enter the labour market, to unleash business potential, to find new skills through the training and supervision granted and to allow people to live with dignity and autonomy. I advocate the continuation of Progress, its availability in all Member States, and that initiatives and funding available for the granting of microcredit to innovative startups run by young people should be doubled in order to support young entrepreneurship and technological innovation.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Schulze report on the implementation of the European microfinance instrument "Progress" aims to provide the Union with a microfinance instrument aimed at disadvantaged populations or micro-enterprises in difficulty.  If the objective is laudable and widely agreed, the substance of the case is more murky. Indeed, the report does not hide its ideological objectives such as gender equality (while poverty has no gender...), the reception of migrants (the latter are seen as potential clients of microfinance), etc.  Moreover, the funding of this project is unclear to say the least. This project should focus more on social integration through work, as well as access to business credit, rather than getting lost in dusting. The lack of budgeting, as well as certain objectives contrary to my views, are sufficient reasons for me to oppose this project. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EPMF granted EUR 124.6 million to people who would not normally have access to financing. Its effectiveness in the case of disadvantaged groups is less clear, and that is why I welcome the European Parliament report’s call for a better social impact reporting and targeting of vulnerable groups.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the European Microfinance Instrument Progress. This instrument funds microcredit organizations that provide loans of less than 25,000 euros to project holders for the creation or takeover of a business.  Since its launch in 2010, it has already delivered 13,252 microcredits in Europe worth 124.6 million euros. In France, three organizations are entitled to receive European Progress funds and have local networks in the regions: ADIE, Initiative France and Créa Sol.  I have approved this text, a provision of which calls on Member States to raise Progress's awareness.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In 2010 the European Union created the Progress Microfinance Facility, with total funding of EUR 205 million, the aim being to give socially and financially disadvantaged people in Europe a chance to build a decent life. I have voted for this report that will implement the European Progress Microfinance Facility.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Micro-loans enable people who are socially and financially disadvantaged in Europe to create their own livelihoods by setting up or promoting micro-enterprises.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report.  Progress is a highly effective tool for providing support to disadvantaged people to return to the labour market and integrate into society. Such persons are given opportunities to take up business and also contribute to job creation.  It should be noted that difficulties in accessing finance are one of the main obstacles faced by novice entrepreneurs.  In view of the positive impact of this measure on employment and social inclusion, the availability of microfinance needs to be increased. I believe that it is appropriate to revise the concept of microcredit to adapt it to today's realities. In order to facilitate access to micro-credits, the list of target groups should be broadened to include the long-term unemployed, young people, low-income, low-skilled workers and people with disabilities. However, refugees and asylum seekers should not be included in this list.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls to expand the scope and increase the funding and reach of this EU programme. It calls on the Commission to view refugees and asylum seekers as a target group for this money and that this instrument contributes to the EU’s ‘added value’.  While in principle we fully support small business and want to help micro-enterprises gain access to loans, we cannot support this measure which is not very well known and barely used by UK businesses. It effectively takes money off British taxpayers to hand out to businesses in poorer EU countries. The only people who should decide how we spend taxpayers’ money and create legislation to help SMEs are our own elected and accountable national government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The granting of micro-credits has given European citizens most in need the opportunity and the opportunity to start their own businesses to ensure their dignified existence. I believe that Europe must continue its efforts to unleash the hidden entrepreneurial potential of its citizens and to stimulate innovation. For these reasons, I am in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – In my work and activities as a member of the European Parliament, among other initiatives, I fully support the efforts in the spheres of entrepreneurship and SMEs development and growth. That is why I support the European microfinance facility as a socio-political instrument that helps people to realise their potential as entrepreneurs, develop new skills through training and monitoring, and find jobs. In Bulgaria, micro-loans are helping hundreds of entrepreneurs, especially in the agriculture sector.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Microcredit is often the only way for small businesses to reach start-up capital or funding for development and additional employment. The importance of financial instruments such as Progress is therefore particularly great and I think we need to be more permissive in assessing their performance only through the prism of longevity of the work of companies financed by them. The availability of microfinance should certainly be increased and this could be achieved by mitigating microcredit criteria.  Instruments such as Progress need to be promoted more strongly and cover wider geographical and economic areas. It is a good thing that the report warns that the instrument needs to take into account the added value of projects in regions with severe and persistent natural or demographic disadvantages, especially in today's situation of microfinance market gap and limited availability of microfinance.  I join the call on the Commission to provide access to microfinance to potentially excluded groups of beneficiaries such as young, long-term unemployed and especially women.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the implementation of the European microfinance instrument "Progress" aims to provide the Union with a microfinance instrument aimed at disadvantaged populations or micro-enterprises in difficulty.  If the objective is laudable and widely agreed, the substance of the case is more murky. Indeed, the report does not hide its ideological objectives such as gender equality (while poverty has no gender...), the reception of migrants (the latter are seen as potential clients of microfinance), etc.  Moreover, the funding of this project is unclear to say the least. This project should focus more on social integration through work, as well as access to business credit, rather than getting lost in dusting. The lack of budgeting, as well as certain objectives contrary to my views, are sufficient reasons for me to oppose this project. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the continuation of a microfinance programme that is particularly important for vulnerable groups and acts as a social policy instrument in terms of reducing unemployment and social exclusion. At the same time, it is also important to ensure non-financial forms of assistance, transparency in the operations of microcredit providers and a quality data collection system. The European Agenda on Employment and Social Innovation includes the importance of microfinance and social entrepreneurship and fixes the shortcomings of the last programme, making it worth supporting.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I agree with the report on the implementation of MPs Schulze's Progress microfinance instrument. The Progress microfinance instrument was established in 2010 by the European Commission to support microfinance through various instruments, in particular guarantees and funded instruments. By 31 March 2014, more than 20,000 recipients had received microcredits, amounting to €182 million.  Microcredit providers (public and private entities, including banks and non-banking institutions) play a key role in achieving the Progress microfinance target of allocating €500 million to final recipients. The objectives of this project are to increase the availability and availability of microfinance to people who have lost their jobs or are at risk of losing their jobs or have difficulties entering the labour market, as well as persons at risk of social exclusion or vulnerable people who are disadvantaged in terms of access to a conventional credit market and who want to set up or develop their own businesses, including self-employment.  Also, microfinance is one of the essential tools that contributes to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives. For these reasons, I consider this instrument to be extremely important, especially in times of crisis, in providing access to finance for unemployed vulnerable people who would not otherwise have access to conventional sources of credit.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 From the social democrat's point of view, this is a very important microfinance facility that enables reintegration into the labour market, unlocking entrepreneurial potential, embracing new skills through accompanying training and counselling, and enabling people to take their own lives and ensure a dignified existence. It is important to mention that the Progress microfinance facility is primarily a social policy instrument and only then an economic instrument. It focuses on the target groups that have so far been neglected in our economic system: the (long-term) unemployed, welfare recipients, immigrants, members of ethnic minorities, those active in the informal economy or living in disadvantaged regions, and women. In my opinion, the provision of microcredit is meaningful from an economic and social point of view, because financial support for a person seeking to become independent is more advantageous for state institutions than spending on social benefits for the unemployed and, moreover, serves as a springboard for citizens to do business. Moreover, the figures prove the functionality of this instrument, which is why I will be happy if EFSI funds are made available to micro-enterprises as well.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the creation of the Progress microfinance instrument in 2010, the European Union, through the granting of micro-credits, offers socially and economically disadvantaged people the opportunity to start an activity that offers them economic opportunities. The European definition of microcredit should, however, be rethought and adapted to the current situation. The same applies to the maximum amount of the loan, which is currently set at EUR 25,000 and which may not be sufficient in some Member States of the Union. In addition, non-bank entities should also be allowed to act as microcredit intermediaries in all Member States. It should be possible to grant financial support under EaSI (European Employment and Social Innovation Programme) to assist experts in the development of an business plan, as well as for the verification of the business idea and support in its implementation (training and mentoring). I voted in favour of these suggestions, which I hope will be taken into account by the Council and the Commission.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it draws a very precise assessment of "Progress". This microfinance instrument has demonstrated its strengths, but also its weaknesses. Now it's up to us to make the right decisions, not on substance but on form. I want to talk in particular about improving assistance for microcredit borrowers and specifically their training, supervision and support.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls to expand the scope and increase the funding and reach of this EU programme. It calls on the Commission to view refugees and asylum seekers as a target group for this money and that this instrument contributes to the EU’s ‘added value’.  While in principle we fully support small business and want to help micro-enterprises gain access to loans, we cannot support this measure which is not very well known and barely used by UK businesses. It effectively takes money off British taxpayers to hand out to businesses in poorer EU countries. The only people who should decide how we spend taxpayers’ money and create legislation to help SMEs are our own elected and accountable national government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Progress Instrument aims to increase access to microfinance for people who have lost or are at risk of losing their jobs, who are struggling in the labour market or who face a threat of social exclusion. It is therefore a useful lever to fight poverty and unemployment. The figures show that 60% of people were unemployed or inactive at the time they applied for microcredit at Progress.   It is therefore necessary to support this instrument and to seek to improve its action. The resolution makes a plurality of proposals for this purpose, which I think are right, which is why I have supported this text. These proposals concern the improvement of access to the instrument, the targeting of the targeted groups, the complementarity of Progress with other EU instruments, among others. It is also necessary to increase the visibility of this instrument, to accompany it with training in entrepreneurship, and to extend its geographical scope. Progress is to grant 46,000 microcredits by 2020, amounting to 500 million euros. We need to make sure that is achieved.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this instrument is to increase access to and availability of microfinance to people who have lost or are at risk of losing their jobs, to people who have difficulty entering or re-entering the labour market, as well as those facing the threat of social exclusion or are in a vulnerable or disadvantaged situation with regard to access to the conventional credit market and who wish to create or continue to develop their own micro-enterprises, in particular self-employed work. This is an essential tool for increasing access to and availability of microfinance for micro-enterprises and thereby boosting the social economy.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Today I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the European Microfinance Instrument Progress. Microfinance is an important issue in that it contributes to the achievement of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, particularly in terms of social inclusion and the reduction of social inequalities. As a result, the European Progress microfinance instrument is important because it increases access to this microfinance.  This instrument can therefore be a real breath of fresh air for people who have lost or are at risk of losing their jobs, for those who are having difficulty entering or returning to the labour market, etc. With this support, these people will be able to try to start or develop their own micro-enterprise.  While this instrument has already proved its relevance, I remain convinced that it is the duty of the Member States to create points of contact in order to make it better known to potential beneficiaries and citizens in general. I also regret that this instrument does not finance a large number of social enterprises.  As this instrument will end in 2016, I can only hope that the EASI (EU Programme for Employment and Social Innovation) will take over to support microfinance and social entrepreneurship in Europe.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After identifying the positive effects on the local economy from the granting of microcredits to combat poverty in developing countries, in 2010 the EU created the European Progress Microfinance Instrument, with the main objective of ensuring that the most economically and socially disadvantaged citizens have an opportunity to create their own source of income. This financing, which, although not intended to directly support micro-enterprises, but so-called intermediaries, aims to increase their access to loans through improved guarantees. This possibility not only helps enable potential entrepreneurs but also contributes to the development of new skills through the training/monitoring of these citizens. With this instrument as unemployed target groups, citizens claiming social security benefits, immigrants or people who cannot obtain conventional bank loans, is an important socio-political instrument as it lends up to EUR 25 000.  This progress implementation report, which I voted in favour of, demonstrates that it is an important and effective tool for achieving the EU's employment and social policy objectives, but that, as described in the report, it lacks greater visibility and more detailed implementation reports from the Commission.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report focuses on the implementation of the European Microfinance Instrument Progress, a fund aimed at improving the capacity of intermediaries to increase the number of projects to offer microfinance and to ensure loans on favourable terms for borrowers. We voted in favour because, with caveats, the fund is an instrument that supports economic and social innovation and this report reinforces the public assessment of the social achievements of funding and a more focused approach to social and territorial cohesion. In addition, the report assesses the implementation of this fund and the impact of microfinance on EU societies, which we consider essential. Positive aspects include: expanding geographical scope, improving gender balance in access to microfinance, accessing potentially excluded clients (so that people who do not have access to credit can develop their initiatives and that SMEs can increase their investment capacity) or the possibility of non-bank intermediaries entering the microcredit market without relying on an associated bank.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 Access to microfinance is an essential measure of support for economic recovery, provided that appropriate macroeconomic policies are developed (which means, first of all, ending austerity measures). Despite the absence of a holistic approach, the report places an appropriate emphasis on the difficulties in working the European microfinance programme, which often does not reach its final beneficiaries. This diagnosis (which I share) and the emphasis on the social impact of these appropriations have inclined me to vote in favour.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Progress microfinance tool aims to help those who have difficulty accessing the credit market to obtain funding of up to EUR 25 000.  Progress, which benefits from Union funds, does not directly finance entrepreneurs, but allows certain EU microcredit providers (public or private banking institutions, non-bank bodies and non-profit microcredit providers) to increase credit activity through the issuance of guarantees, thus sharing the risk of loss. Thanks to this instrument, those who want to start a small and medium-sized business are guided and instructed by financial intermediaries, who, in addition to granting credit, provide specific technical assistance for each beneficiary.  In this respect, provision has been made for the creation of a website and database to disseminate information on how to access microcredit and on the financial intermediaries selected, in order to enable a wider public to benefit from this instrument. In view of the many advantages, I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I am against any extra funding for this facility.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own initiative report because we need to have a more effective implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility (EPMF). The EPMF has granted 124.6 million euros to people who would not normally have access to financing. Its effectiveness in the case of disadvantaged group is less clear and that is why I welcome the European Parliament's report's call for a better social impact reporting and targeting of vulnerable groups.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution because I consider the European Microfinance Facility Progress to be an extremely effective way of supporting the emergence of new firms or helping the unemployed to re-engage in the main economic activity, either as self-employed or as small business owners. Although the original target of EUR 142.4 million has not been achieved, I consider it a success that 13 252 microcredits worth EUR 124.6 million have been allocated to applicants, and thanks to this instrument, positive results have been achieved in many developing countries. I agree with the rapporteur that Progress can generally be described as a success, but we should already focus more efforts today on improving access to microfinance for potentially excluded clients, such as migrants, refugees, the long-term unemployed, young people, low-income people, low-skilled workers and people with disabilities who are not currently benefiting enough from the instrument. In the future, I expect progress microfinance to be more flexible, comprehensible, awareness of and promotion of access opportunities.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I very much welcome the adoption of the report by my PPE colleague and EMPL committee, Sven Schulze, on the Progress microfinance facility. The microcredit system has worked very well, both in developing and developed countries. Its founder, Muhammad Yunus, was rightly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for it. I particularly underline the social character of microcredits, as small business is a way out of social exclusion. Here, however, the European programme has some weaknesses. Its effectiveness is not so clear-willed precisely in relation to disadvantaged sections of the population and the social economy. Refugees are certainly disadvantaged groups, but I could not support their inclusion among the target groups of the programme. These people are not yet in a position to apply for microcrecreage. I consider such a request to be an empty gesture. Unfortunately, progress is currently only available in 22 Member States, which should change. I am glad that my country, the Czech Republic, is one of them. Although some of our amendments have not been tabled and the above reference to refugees as the target group of the programme has remained in the report, I have decided to support the text as a whole.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The aim of the microfinance facility is to increase the availability and access to microfinance for persons who have been left out of a job or at risk. It is also intended for persons who have difficulty (re)entering the labour market and for persons at risk of social exclusion.  A microfinance facility can also help vulnerable people who are left behind in accessing a conventional credit market and who wish to set up or further develop their own micro-enterprise, including the self-employed. I agree that financial instruments such as the Progress instrument are extremely important during the financial crisis. They enable the creation of new businesses, promote new jobs and provide access to finance for the unemployed, disadvantaged and micro-enterprises.  The report identifies shortcomings that have been identified through the use of this type of financial instrument. It therefore calls on the Commission to provide more advertising and information on the microfinance facility and different access to it. It is necessary to increase its geographical scope, to encourage microfinance intermediaries to implement specific strategies, etc.  The report also states that consideration should be given to adapting to the current circumstances of the European definition of micro-rems. As microfinance can help people out of poverty and unemployment, can give them dignity and strengthens cohesion between communities by increasing social inclusion and reducing social disparities, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Progress microfinance is one of several microfinance programmes. This programme increases the availability of microcredit intended for the establishment and development or development of small enterprises. I think it is also important to support small and medium-sized enterprises in this way, and it is in this respect that I see the validity of this instrument.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. Microfinance can be an effective tool for greater social inclusion. This is particularly true of people who have been marginalised by unemployment and are no longer granted loans. However, microfinance is not yet having the desired effect in creating new jobs. We therefore call on the European Commission to include social indicators in the impact assessment. In order to do this, the question must be asked what kind of jobs are being created here in the first place. The reality is that 44% of supported entrepreneurs had to give up after one year. We do not need cosmetics on the unemployment rate, which is achieved by creating precarious, precarious jobs. To this end, the question of who is currently excluded from the support measures needs to be clarified. Microfinance must also focus on particularly disadvantaged groups such as the long-term unemployed, refugees and young people. The issue of equality between women and men must also be taken into account. Existing instruments, such as the European Structural Funds and the Programme for Employment and Social Innovation, must be coordinated. After all, no one needs fine brochures on European funding if the money does not arrive where it is needed.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation abstained in voting on this report. It believes that a European microfinance facility can be very useful in the fight against social exclusion and welcomes a European policy that supports activation strategies. The N-VA delegation fully supports initiatives that give oxygen to SMEs and facilitate their design and development. However, the stumbling block in this report is that 'refugees, asylum seekers and migrants' are identified as the particular target group of the funding facility, on which the Commission should focus in particular on its efforts. This could mean that the aforementioned groups - whose (long-term) stay is very uncertain - have access to social support from day one. The N-VA delegation is wary that this could set a precedent for further, immediate claims on all kinds of social allowances.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the implementation of this decision, as the aim of the instrument is to improve the ability of intermediaries to increase the number of potential activities to initiate employment by creating quality jobs, growth and social inclusion in local communities. There are indications that microfinance could be one of the elements to help companies go from a grey economy to a business with the status of declared economic activity.  I would emphasise the importance of a financial instrument, such as an instrument during the financial crisis to open new businesses, promote new employment and ensure access to finance for the unemployed, disadvantaged and microentergies, and mitigate the risks borne by microfinance intermediaries. I also call on the Commission to step up the promotion of the instrument and provide more information on it, as well as how it can be accessed.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Progress Microfinance Facility (EPMF) has granted EUR 124.6 million to people who would not normally have access to financing. Its effectiveness in the case of disadvantaged groups is less clear and that is why I welcome the European Parliament’s report calling for better social impact reporting and targeting of vulnerable groups.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. The European Microfinance Instrument Progress 2020 was established with the aim of increasing the availability and availability of microfinance of microentergies and the social economy. The aim is to benefit from the instrument in the EU22 by paying out 46 000 micro-loaners by 2020, amounting to around €500 million.  84% of beneficiaries applying for microcredit belonged to the 25-54 age group and 36% of recorded undertakings receiving the loan were women (significantly higher than the Union average). Microfinance in this way can lift people out of poverty and unemployment, give them dignity and increase cohesion in communities by improving social inclusion and reducing social disparities. I fully support the Council's position at first reading and underline the importance of the instrument, especially in times of crisis, as it provides easier access to the financing of unemployed and vulnerable people. Also, this type of microfinance, given the current crisis related to migration and asylum, can serve as a fundamental support for refugees and migrants entering the EU labour market.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report because I do not agree with supporting business for taxpayers' money, as this is counterproductive. Nor does it change much about the fact that, in this case, taxpayers are 'only' liable for business loans, as this again ultimately means crowding out more efficient market investments with less efficient investments guaranteed by taxpayers.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility. During the financial crisis, the Progress financial instrument is important because it enables the creation of jobs, new businesses and provides access to finance for the unemployed, disadvantaged and micro-enterprises. I welcome the call for Member States to develop a microfinance sector and to enable it to be expanded in order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, helping people out of poverty and unemployment and contributing to greater social inclusion and strengthening cohesion between communities by reducing social disparities.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The zero results of this mechanism have been made clear at least through the criticism made of it in the process of discussing the report. However, we have decided to support the mechanism because it is one of the few cases where micro-enterprises are given an opportunity to finance themselves, so that the economy can move again at local level.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report, although it refers to a very important support mechanism, nevertheless seeks to make illegal immigrants a target group of this mechanism instead of being interested in the problems of European citizens.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Progress Microfinance Facility is an important financial support tool that can help lift people out of poverty and unemployment by providing them with a dignified life. This instrument was created for people who have lost or are at risk of losing their jobs, as well as for those who have difficulty entering or returning to the labour market and are interested in obtaining access to microfinance. As indicated in Parliament's report, thousands of EU citizens have already benefited from the instrument. It is particularly attractive for women who often find it difficult to return or enter the labour market.
