The functioning of the Progress instrument is not without its shortcomings, which are largely due to complex procedures for granting support, instability or a low degree of coordination between the instrument and Union funds. Nevertheless, this instrument should be regarded as a success for the EU and its accessibility should be even wider, which is why I voted in favour of the EP report.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Microfinance directly contributes to reducing poverty and restoring efficiency and balance in poor communities in the EU. I support this principle, provided that it complies with the principles set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. The criteria that we must follow in applying the European microfinance instrument must be primarily social. It is therefore imperative that the rate of microfinance support of the social economy continues to be increased.  Last but not least, I appreciate that, for the coming period, access for SMEs, especially those sponsored by young people or women, must be easier and more friendly. Let us not forget that, so far, most of the applications for funding on eIF instruments could not be approved by the Commission. Excessive bureaucracy is just one of the reasons why the road from idea to finance is so long and arduous. Our job is to facilitate young people's access to finance and help create business incubators within communities, which can thus emerge from the vicious circle of economic non-performance. I add that the field of tourism could be better represented in the financing instruments and encouraged to develop.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which stresses the importance of the Progress Microfinance Facility. Inspired by the success of microloans in developing countries, the EU created it in 2010 with total funding of EUR 205 million and it currently operates in 22 out of the 28 Member States. It is primarily a social policy instrument for a target group to which loans are considered risky and costly by banks. The report calls on the Commission and the Member States to raise awareness of the Microfinance Facility among potential beneficiaries, to encourage more research into microenterprises, their needs and their survival rates and to better measure the social impact of the Facility.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The microfinance tool in Europe must certainly be preserved and encouraged. The Progress programme has proved its usefulness over the years and needs to be strengthened each year with an adequate budget. The social approach and easy access to microcredit for the establishment and development of new businesses is laudable, and it should also be stressed that this initiative allows (re)integration into the labour market, the development of entrepreneurial potential, the acquisition of new skills through training and support for people to live independently and with dignity. Throughout Europe, social economy companies work by involving disadvantaged groups and giving dignity back to the individual, and we reaffirm with this report our commitment to full employment.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The european Progress microfinance facility, which receives financial contributions from the Union and the European Investment Bank and is managed by the European Investment Fund (EBA) and expects additional funding from private investors, was originally intended to support growth and jobs and combat social and financial exclusion. The own-initiative report on the implementation of the instrument, which has been a pilot project since 2010, has identified a number of shortcomings. In the course of the vote, with a few exceptions, I followed the people's party position. It was unable to meet its main objective: its impact on job creation was less than expected, despite the fact that without microcredit, many beneficiaries would have been completely squeezed out of the credit market. Of all the businesses supported by the facility, 44% operated for less than a year and only 56% operated the following year. The creditworthiness or ability to do business of persons affected by long-term unemployment should not be overestimated when using this instrument. It is also regrettable that the Commission's 2013 report on the implementation of the instrument is very general and contains no specifics. Nevertheless, making this instrument part of solving the migration crisis in 2015 is a very irresponsible, vain fantasy, given the qualifications of migrants and their competitiveness in the labour market, their competences and the complete lack of statistics and impact assessments on this.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report on the implementation of the European Progress microfinance instrument aimed at facilitating access to loans of less than €25,000 to start or support microentergies.  I think this instrument is extremely useful given that its positive effects on the local economy are visible, and I strongly support its focus on groups that otherwise receive too little attention in the economy, such as the long-term unemployed, people receiving social assistance and people living disadvantaged in rural areas.  While this instrument does not mean direct financing of undertakings but provides microfinance services through intermediaries and has granted €13 252 microcredits worth €124.6 million, and I believe this report will further improve access to microfinance for potentially excluded users. Finally, I voted for this report, as the Progress microfinance instrument helps ensure the return of the unemployed to the labour market, realise entrepreneurial potential, acquire new skills through training and mentoring, and ultimately provide dignity.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the report on the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility. We are living in a time when the economic and financial crisis has significantly increased the rates of poverty and also social exclusion. We are facing long-term unemployment and youth unemployment. Microcredit is not only a matter for developing countries, it is also a key contributor to business start-ups in Europe. Microfinance makes an important contribution to achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. The Progress financial instrument is crucial for that part of our economy that has been hardest hit by the situation in which we live.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report focuses on the implementation of the European Microfinance Instrument Progress, a fund aimed at improving the capacity of intermediaries to increase the number of projects to offer microfinance and to ensure loans on favourable terms for borrowers. We voted in favour because, with caveats, the fund is an instrument that supports economic and social innovation and this report reinforces the public assessment of the social achievements of funding and a more focused approach to social and territorial cohesion. In addition, the report assesses the implementation of this fund and the impact of microfinance on EU societies, which we consider essential. Positive aspects include: expanding geographical scope, improving gender balance in access to microfinance, accessing potentially excluded clients (so that people who do not have access to credit can develop their initiatives and that SMEs can increase their investment capacity) or the possibility of non-bank intermediaries entering the microcredit market without relying on an associated bank.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The Schulze report aims to provide the Union with a microfinance instrument for disadvantaged populations or micro-enterprises in difficulty. If we find this project interesting, in the sense that it supports freedom of enterprise and aims to create jobs in Europe, it appears from reading the text in question that more ideological objectives are also being pursued. Indeed, gender egalitarianism is clearly targeted, considering ratios of women entrepreneurs in future programmes, and welcoming migrants, considering them as potential clients of microfinance. In addition, funding for this project is not clearly defined. Several funds and programs are cited without clearly specifying their functions and contributions.  This instrument could therefore be useful, particularly through social integration through work (unemployed, disabled people), access to credit for the most insecure entrepreneurs, and the creation of sustainable jobs - especially in these times of austerity and banking difficulty. However, the populations mentioned, the lack of budgeting and the poor results highlighted force me to oppose this project. So I'm voting against it.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The objective of the microfinance instrument is to improve the conditions for obtaining loans and to facilitate financing for people who wish to open or develop their own micro-enterprise, including self-employment, and which would otherwise otherwise not be eligible. This tool has been used in the past in 22 Member States. Thus, 60% of the people who benefited were either unemployed or inactive at the time of the microcredit application, and 36% of registered entrepreneurs supported with loans were women. Next, the overall objective of the instrument is to grant 46 000 microcredits by 2020, which is around EUR 500 million. Mobilisation of such an instrument is extremely important, especially in times of financial crisis, as it allows for the creation of new businesses, the promotion of employment and the guarantee of access to finance for the unemployed and disadvantaged. Furthermore, in the current context of the migration crisis and asylum seekers, microfinance can be essential support for migrants and refugees entering the EU labour market. I therefore voted in favour of the Report on the implementation of the European Progress microfinance instrument.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Microfinance contributes to achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy; whereas microfinance can help people break out of poverty and unemployment, restore their dignity and enhance cohesion in communities by improving social inclusion and minimising social imbalances. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report focuses on the implementation of the European Microfinance Instrument Progress, a fund aimed at improving the capacity of intermediaries to increase the number of projects to offer microfinance and to ensure loans on favourable terms for borrowers. We voted in favour because, with caveats, the fund is an instrument that supports economic and social innovation and this report reinforces the public assessment of the social achievements of funding and a more focused approach to social and territorial cohesion. In addition, the report assesses the implementation of this fund and the impact of microfinance on EU societies, which we consider essential. Positive aspects include: expanding geographical scope, improving gender balance in access to microfinance, accessing potentially excluded clients (so that people who do not have access to credit can develop their initiatives and that SMEs can increase their investment capacity) or the possibility of non-bank intermediaries entering the microcredit market without relying on an associated bank.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree that microloans work in Europe, as well as in developing countries. The Progress Microfinance Facility is primarily a social policy instrument and only secondarily an economic policy instrument. It focuses on target groups whose role in the economy has previously received too little attention: (long-term) unemployed people, people on benefit, immigrants, ethnic minorities, people working in the informal economy or living in disadvantaged rural areas, and women.  Progress Microfinance is currently available in only 22 of the 28 Member States. The reasons for this incomplete coverage are the varying degrees of economic development, varying degrees of market interest and the current legislative basis in each country. I believe Progress Microfinance helps to provide a way (back) into the labour market, release entrepreneurial potential, acquire new skills through training and mentoring, and give people dignity by enabling them to take responsibility for their own lives.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about an instrument that helps people develop their potential as entrepreneurs and develop new skills through training and that facilitates their search and job finding. This tool is intended for those who cannot have conventional credits, so it is very useful to give opportunities to those who need it most. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Progress Microfinance Facility (EPMF) has granted EUR 124.6 million to people who would not normally have access to financing for small scale business ventures. However, its success in targeting the most disadvantaged groups is less clear, which is why I backed this call for better social impact reporting. It is vital that the disadvantaged have access to this kind of finance and it needs to be targeted where it can do the most social good. Financing has been a real issue for micro-businesses since the financial crash and it is vital that these businesses which can do so much for their local communities can flourish.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility because it aims to help the less well-off to work. This facility will help people in Europe to undertake, learn new skills and find a job.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We value this program and are by strengthening this microfinance mechanism. Unfortunately, the potential of this programme is not properly exploited. This is largely due to a common problem in EU programmes - the lack of information and ways to support stakeholders. It is often those who are less excluded who hold the information and end up benefiting from this possibility of applying for microcredit. We agree with the logic of the report, which does not emphasize the solution of microfinance as an absolute solution to solve social and economic problems, as many emphasize.  This logic is fallacious and dangerous - it puts social equity and development policies in the hands of the greatest or lesser success of individuals, without holding states from their functions accountable. Microfinance yes, but without replacing the social functions of states.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. As the microfinance facility facilitates access to microcredit to create or promote micro-enterprises, and given that almost 85% of all new jobs are created in micro-enterprises and that they are often unable to obtain credit in the traditional banking sector, as they are a prohibitively costly target group for them, the report is generally to be welcomed. Unfortunately, at the same time, the report calls for unjustified preference for women over men. It also calls for a 'equal quota of entrepreneurs'. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Micro-loans are primarily a tool of social assistance in European conditions. It is a support that also strengthens the responsibility of its beneficiaries, improves their motivation, desire to work, and for many, micro-loans become the first step on the road to economic autonomy. The target groups include, in particular, the unemployed, social benefits recipients, immigrants, marginalised members of national minorities, as well as people doing unpaid work, for example in the household or in the care of others. The functioning of this instrument undoubtedly still has reserves, but I support its continued functioning and the gradual improvement of its effectiveness and accessibility.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the implementation of the European Progress Microfinance Facility, which is primarily a social policy tool that facilitates access to microcredit for the establishment and support of micro-enterprises. The European market is currently facing significant problems and the demand for microcredit from people who are unable to obtain loans from the traditional banking sector is greater than ever.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the microfinance facility and gave it my vote all the more so because some of the complementary proposals proposed by me were adopted. I believe that progress is a very important instrument, especially for small entrepreneurs, but also for disadvantaged groups, such as the unemployed, the disabled or the socially excluded, who are unlikely to succeed in a normal bank applying for a loan. And although only one bank has so far provided such microcredit in Slovakia, which has set the conditions so that the majority of applicants were from the boards of already established entrepreneurs, I believe that it is necessary to give the chance to obtain microcredit not only for them, but precisely for disadvantaged groups of the population. And although micro-credit providers may be concerned about providing micro-loans to this target category, I believe that, thanks to this report containing many recommendations, the situation will soon change and Slovakia will also follow in the results of the microfinance facility to the Member States where progress has proved to be very successful.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Microfinance is the set of financial services for individuals and SMEs with reduced access to bank credit and associated services.  In so-called developed countries, in particular in the EU, this instrument has been used in policies for job creation, social inclusion and gender equality, notably through the European Progress Microfinance Instrument, launched in 2010, which funds credit intermediaries to increase the number of projects and improve the conditions under which credit accessors can obtain such loans. This instrument aims to distribute 46000 microcredits by 2020, with a total budget of EUR 500 million. This report assesses the implementation of Progress and its impact on the EU. The use of microcredit has been limited and there has been a large number of projects that have not been approved; information on this mechanism does not reach its potential beneficiaries; its effectiveness in territorial cohesion is questionable, whereas the instrument covers only 20 countries; there are many sectors that are part of the exclusion map that do not use this mechanism. We agree with this assessment and we voted in favour of the report.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I abstained in the vote on this report because, although I believe that the latter has positive aspects, it also seems to me that the opportunity to support the different organisational forms of fishermen and fishermen has been missed, and the opportunity has also been missed to start taking action in favour of small artisanal fisheries , such as still collecting that accidental catches are outside TACs in inland waters in autonomous communities.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Technical measures and multiannual plans are the most appropriate instruments for achieving the objective of maximum sustainable yield in the common fisheries policy. The aim of these measures is to avoid catches of juveniles and other accidental catches, which can cause damage to the marine environment. An essential point of the reform of the CFP is the differentiation of European legislation on a geographical basis, providing for rules in accordance with the specificity of places such as the Baltic, the Mediterranean and the Atlantic. The presentation of a number of amendments underlined the need to simplify the measures and maintain an approach based on respect for ecosystems. I voted in favour because I consider the protection of the environmental and marine heritage to be a priority for European policies.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the final vote on this own-initiative report because even collecting ideas that we introduced – such as that by-handed fishing within the inland waters of the Member States and their regions must be outside the TAC; ideas we share, such as the simplification of legislation or the participation of fishermen in the design of fisheries policies, does not take sufficient account of specific measures for small fishermen and artisanal fishing and aims to strictly link the management of technical measures and multiannual plans to the CFP.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which provides a structure for technical measures and multi-year plans.  Indeed, this report follows a consultation on technical measures initiated in 2005, to which the professionals interviewed had responded by expressing several requests such as the adaptation of technical measures to fisheries, the adaptation of technical measures to the obligation to disembark or the implementation of technical measures that are not contradictory. This text therefore goes in the right direction because it takes into account the demands of fishing professionals and makes it possible to simplify the technical measures of the CFP by adapting them to each type of fishery.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. For almost thirty years now, European regulations in the fishing sector have been characterized by a complex and illegible legal pile-up, making its application very difficult.  Gabriel Mato's report calls for a simplification of the rules that satisfy fishermen, who call for adaptation of technical measures to fisheries, adaptation of technical measures to the landing obligation and technical measures that are not contradictory.  These requests are legitimate, so I voted for this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I oppose the structure of the common fisheries policy, I suspect that the aspirations of this non-legislative resolution might make this awful policy slightly less bad in practice. I therefore chose to abstain rather than vote against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it aims to ensure the long-term conservation and optimal use of fisheries resources for sustainable fishing in Europe.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to structure the technical measures and multiannual plans of the CFP. One of the objectives of the 2013 CFP reform is to achieve maximum sustainable yield. Technical measures and multiannual plans are the main conservation measures for this purpose. However, since 2009, very little progress has been made in the adoption of legislative acts concerning both technical measures and multiannual plans. I support the proposals set out above to develop these plans rapidly, to increase the effective involvement of stakeholders in their preparation and development, and to adopt them as soon as possible. I agree that future technical measures must be simple and clear so that fishermen can understand them more easily. They should, as far as possible, be adapted to the specificities of each species and to each region. It is important that more fishermen are involved in the decision-making process, including all the smallest aspects of technical measures. In addition, incentives must be provided to ensure that those measures are implemented.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This text aims to simplify and adapt technical measures to each fishery, by regionalising these measures as part of the multi-year plans. This corresponds to the requests expressed by industry professionals who responded to the consultation launched by Alain Cadec in June 2015. So I voted in favour of this rationalization, which seems to me to be going in the right direction.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The complexity and diversity of the technical measures of the Common Fisheries Policy, as well as the fact that they are divided among many different regulations, have contributed to making their implementation difficult for fishermen. Similarly, the effectiveness of the multi-year plans adopted between 2002 and 2009 has been uneven.  This report, which I have supported, therefore considers that in order to ensure the implementation of the objectives of this common policy, future technical measures should be simplified, included in a clearly structured legal framework and developed on the basis of sound peer-reviewed scientific advice.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained because, while the rapporteur argues that technical measures should be simple and clear so that they can be easily understood by fishermen and adapted to the specific needs of each type of fishing and region, and calls for participation in decision-making by fishermen, we understand that the Spanish fisheries sector is currently going through enormous difficulties. These difficulties are most evident in small-scale and artisanal fisheries and this report does not include any solution or proposal to respond to the difficulties of these fisheries subsectors.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported Mr Mato's report, with which I have worked on behalf of my group. In view of the new proposal that the European Commission is preparing on technical measures, it was important to adopt this report before the end of the year. It says that such measures should take into account the phenomenon of illegal fishing, which often involves the illegal use of fishing gear. I voted against the reference to gillnets as some of them are used properly, especially in artisanal fishing.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which, if it does not go far enough in responding to the demands of fishing professionals, still provides for a simplification and rationalisation of regulations.  Indeed, technical measures have been piling up like a millefeuille for 30 years, adding ever more complexity and constraints for fishermen. The Mato report therefore goes in the right direction by seeking to simplify these technical measures and seeking to adapt them to each fishery, in particular by regionalising technical measures within the framework of the multi-year plans. It is regrettable that the European Commission does not intend to regionalise these technical measures, but I am nevertheless pleased that rationalisation and simplification are planned, which will notably reduce the number of regulations without affecting conservation standards.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the report precisely addresses some very critical points of the current common fisheries policy (CFP), the current system of fisheries management remains over-bureaucratised to the detriment of its operators. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Technical measures and multiannual plans are the main tools to achieve the objectives of the 2013 CFP reform. Dispersed in more than thirty regulations, they constitute a complex, heterogeneous and disorganized system of provisions, which must be updated and simplified by ensuring a level playing field in practical application and control and surveillance activities. The Commission has not yet submitted its proposal, although it concluded in May 2014 a public consultation on a 'new framework of technical measures in the reformed CFP' whose conclusions are in line with our demand for a general and simplified framework of technical measures, containing the general objectives and minimum common standards to be applied across the EU. We strongly support management through multiannual plans that provide legal certainty and management stability. We also understand that this figure is the ideal instrument for the adoption of technical measures of a regional nature that adapt to the peculiarities of each area. Our position is the adoption of a basic general framework for the whole Union detailing the specificities in each regional plan. For all these considerations, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has made Parliament express its position on the implementation of the Common Fisheries Policy. The report expresses concern that progress has been made in the area of the 2009 legislative acts on technical measures and multiannual plans. The report recalls that one of the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy is to restore and maintain a level of populations of fish species that can ensure maximum sustainable yield, taking an ecosystem and selectivity approach, and that technical measures and multiannual plans are one of the main means of achieving these objectives. Parliament called for a review of technical measures to achieve the objectives of the CFP, to improve selectivity, to minimise discards and to minimise the environmental impact of fishing, to simplify existing rules and to broaden the scientific framework.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. As these technical measures imposed on the fishing trades have become complex and very directive over the years, the simplification envisaged in this text seems to me to be welcome. However, I would have a preference for regionalisation of these measures, unlike the European Commission. The main thing being for the moment simplification, I voted for this text.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This own-initiative report deals with technical measures implementing the CFP. Most of our group's amendments have been adopted. In particular, we call for a sound scientific approach to improving the conservation and sustainable exploitation of resources, we want to minimise the impact on the marine environment, we want to combat INTA fishing, we want to ensure support for fishermen, in particular for traditional and small-scale sustainable fishing practices, with training, innovation and research tools, and with the involvement of all stakeholders in the decision-making process.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. In the face of the complexity of the guidelines that constrain fishermen's activity, this report aims to simplify and regionalise technical measures within the framework of multi-year plans. The professionals wanted to adapt the technical measures to the landing obligation and the fisheries while rationalizing them so that they were no longer at odds with each other.  However, even if the European Commission intends to make a series of simplifications, notably by reducing the number of regulations, it is unlikely to regionalise these technical measures. This text is a good move, although the Commission will have the final say. So I voted for this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2013 Reform of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) included among its objectives the achievement of maximum sustainable production, applying an ecosystem approach. The main instruments with which these objectives can be achieved are technical measures and multiannual plans. However, despite the advantages of these two instruments, insignificant progress has been made since 2009. The multiannual plans encountered an interinstitutional deadlock and the technical measures showed a need for legislative damage. The new common fisheries policy brings an improvement to these two instruments. Technical measures are thus based on three series of geographically distinct measures that are transposed into specific sets of rules, and the multiannual plans aim to manage the main species of fishing interest, integrating concrete measures to implement them. Given the importance of these instruments in the common fisheries policy, I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. The resolution (not a legislative text) gives a merciless picture of the complex regulatory framework underlying fishing activity in the EU; the heterogeneity of technical measures and multiannual management plans gives operators a very complicated system (especially with regard to the Mediterranean basin, a real critical issue) with which to deal. While appreciating the references in the text relating to these critical issues, the desire for greater regionalisation of the rules and the elimination of codecision for regional measures (which would apply to those common to the three basins), a position of abstention is recommended, since there is insufficient guarantee that these bodies will be accepted in the future in the reform of the CFP. , also counting that, in the meantime, the "technical" obstacles aimed at (missed) species conservation objectives have severely penalised the sector.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The new Common Fisheries Policy will be accompanied by a new framework of technical measures, which should be proposed by the Commission in early 2016. The aim is to adapt the technical measures to the objectives of the new PCP. Technical measures regulate fishing conditions, including fishing gear characteristics (e.g. mesh size), minimum catch size, or fishing areas. The initiative report prepared by Gabriel Mato sets out Parliament's vision for future negotiations on this new framework of technical measures. It stresses the following points: - simplification of technical measures in order to put an end to the successive stacking of conflicting regulations; - adapting technical measures to the regional specificities of fisheries;  - adapting the regulatory framework to the new management logic imposed by the obligation to disembark all catches; - fishermen's participation in the technical measurement process; - adoption of multi-year management plans for different areas and species. I agree with these objectives, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report in favour of the new common fisheries policy (CFP) in order to simplify future technical measures and eliminate contradictions and redundancies in the current CFP. Future technical measures should be part of a clearly structured legal framework and should be designed on the basis of sound scientific data subject to review. In addition, in order to facilitate the implementation of CFP rules and to improve the acceptance and compliance of CFP rules by the fisheries sector, it is necessary to involve fishermen more in the decision-making process, in particular in advisory councils, and to offer them incentives such as support through the EU Maritime and Fisheries Policy Fund and other instruments for innovation and training. Finally, I believe that we need a review of technical measures to improve selectivity, minimise discards and the impact of fishing on the environment, and modernise control and fishing techniques, with the sustainable use of innovative fishing gear.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The CFP as it currently stands and the provisions contained within this report, call for the reduction of what little unilateral capacity Member States have to intervene and co-ordinate on such matters. This is unacceptable, specifically because the fisheries policy to date in the EU has dismally failed to protect the fishing industry.  Moreover, the report makes little to no reference to small scale and artisanal fisheries, most of which have suffered greatly under the CFP. I am very supportive of the general ecological principles behind the management plans but due to the reasons outlined above. I had no choice but to abstain on this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I abstained because, although UKIP believes the entire Common Fisheries Policy is systemically flawed, it would not be right to stand against calls and plans for minor, mitigating changes.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Technical measures and multiannual plans are the most important tools the EU has for fisheries management. The aim of the technical measures is to avoid accidental catches and impacts on the marine environment. Some important amendments tabled by our delegation have been introduced into the final text. These include references to the importance of simplifying and regionalising technical measures, which must always be consistent with the real objective of the Regulation on technical measures, namely the minimisation of accidental catches and impacts on the marine environment; the need for specific measures to improve selectivity and minimise accidental catches by highlighting the problem of accidental catches of cetaceans; the importance of the review of technical measures being carried out in accordance with the best available scientific advice and an ecosystem-based approach. I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the opinion of 11 July 2013 of the European Economic and Social Committee, Article 294(7) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, as well as the recommendation for second reading of the Committee on Legal Affairs, we support the Council's position at first reading.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The main objective of the report on a new Common Fisheries Policy is to improve fishing techniques and to try to simplify the legislative framework. Some of the aspects of the report are correct, but the absence of provisions to improve the position, capabilities and income of professionals in the sector has led me not to vote in favour of the report.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The European Commission will present in January a proposal for a regulation on the revision of technical measures, which will be based on the need to adapt the existing regulatory framework to the objectives of the new common fisheries policy (CFP). This report precedes the Commission's proposal and includes precise indications and suggestions on future technical measures and future multiannual fisheries plans (conservation measures). The aim of the technical measures is to avoid catches of juveniles and other accidental catches. At present, these measures are spread over more than thirty regulations and constitute a complex set of provisions that are often inconsistent and sometimes contradictory. This report proposes simplifying and rationalising these measures, which should be placed in a clear legal framework and designed on the basis of sound scientific foundations. The Commission's text on technical measures should therefore contain a number of general proposals valid for the entire Community fleet, to which should be added specific measures for certain fishing areas, including the Mediterranean Sea.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Gabriel Mato's report on the search for a new common fisheries policy and consequently for technical measures and multiannual plans in this regard. One of the objectives of the 2013 CFP reform was to achieve maximum sustainable yield (MRI) through the application of an ecosystem-based approach. Technical measures and multiannual plans, as conservation measures, are the main means of achieving these objectives. The purpose of the eleven multiannual plans is to manage the main species of interest to fisheries. It is important, in my view, to protect and protect Europe's fishing heritage with rules and reforms aimed at achieving the basic objectives of the sector. This fisheries sector is an important sector of the European economy and must therefore be protected. I think the report is correct in terms of the way in which it aims to achieve its objectives, and that is why, according to the general line taken by my political group, I support the rapporteur's text by voting in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The common fisheries policy was reformed in 2013 so as to get the maximum yields of fish whilst also being sustainable.  The best way to achieve this is through technical measures and multiannual plans. The report proposes technical measures are introduced to prevent catches of juveniles and other by catches. Multiannual plans are concerned with the levels of fishing of a particular stock. There are 11 multiannual plans in the EU and they have to include a maximum sustainable yield target and a deadline for achieving it, discard ban and compulsory landing implementation provisions, remedial safeguards and review clauses. The report calls for fishermen to be closely involved in the decision making process. European commission is expected to present in early 2016 the proposal for a New Framework for Technical Measures and this report is pre-empting that.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome Mr Mato's report on a new structure for technical measures and multiannual plans. I am convinced that we need to simplify and rationalise technical measures, which aim to prevent catches of juveniles and other by-catches in order to preserve the maritime heritage. This will help to make future measures simple and clear in order to facilitate their understanding by fishermen, who should be more involved in the decision-making process. As far as possible, these measures should adapt to the specific characteristics of each fishery and region.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – My vote in favour of this report is based on the understanding that special consideration should be given to the treatment of the Mediterranean as a special case on the basis on recent study on technical measures which omitted the Mediterranean from the scope of this regulation being ‘too complex’. This consideration is also based on the livelihood of families who depend on this sector. I reckon that decisions on the minimum conservation reference sizes should be simplified in order to remove any contradiction and/or duplication contained in a clearly structured legal framework and based on solid scientific data.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the reform of the common fisheries policy in May 2014, the Commission concluded a public consultation on a "new framework of technical measures". Technical measures and multiannual plans are the most important instruments we have for fisheries management. There is a lack of consistency in technical measures. The aim of the technical measures is to avoid accidental catches and impacts on the marine environment. In principle, the system is based on three regulations which follow a geographical logic (Baltic, Mediterranean and Atlantic and other waters). Through amendments, they were adopted in committee and incorporated into the final text: the importance of simplifying and regionalising technical measures, which must always be consistent with the real objective of the regulation on technical measures; consistency with the objectives of the CFP and the Marine Strategy Framework Directive 2008/56/EC; the need for specific measures to improve selectivity and minimise accidental catches by highlighting the problem of accidental catches of cetaceans; the importance of the review of technical measures being carried out in accordance with the best available scientific advice and the ecosystem-based approach. In view of these fundamental elements, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the final vote on this own-initiative report because even collecting ideas that we introduced – such as that by-handed fishing within the inland waters of the Member States and their regions must be outside the TAC; ideas we share, such as the simplification of legislation or the participation of fishermen in the design of fisheries policies, does not take sufficient account of specific measures for small fishermen and artisanal fishing and aims to strictly link the management of technical measures and multiannual plans to the CFP.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the reform in the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). The CFP is a set of rules for managing European fishing fleets and for conserving fish stocks, the policy is based on the idea of a common resource which gives equal access to EU waters and fishing grounds, thus allowing fishermen to compete fairly.  The CFP promotes and works towards sustainable fishing, thus safeguarding the fish population and the productivity over the long term. A new structure for technical measures and multiannual plans will ensure the sustainability of the fishing sector and would aid the community to reach its main objectives as stated in the CFP Reform. The EP's own-initiative report gives a first idea about its position on the key aspects of a new Regulation. As I strongly believe in the importance of sustainable fishing and the harmonisation of the fishing sector I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I have some reservations about a lack of focus in parts of this report, I am happy to support the overall direction of this file. Following the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, a review of the rules for technical measures is desperately needed to accommodate the two new elements of the CFP, the landing obligation and regionalisation. Conservative MEPs are always calling for better implementation of EU policies, and almost nowhere is that more necessary than in the CFP.  A number of the changes suggested in this report would be very welcome when the Commission publishes its legislative proposals, particularly greater involvement of fishermen in decision making and better support for fishermen in terms of innovation, training and equipment that can help them minimise discards. Better use of scientific evidence in managing fish stocks is also critical. There is still much work to be done in improving the implementation of the Common Fisheries Policy, and this report is a welcome step in the right direction.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the new FRAMEWORK regulation of the CFP on technical measures must be formulated in a clear manner, which will require a significant effort to clarify.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report is part of the implementation of the Reform of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) adopted in 2013. Focusing on the goal of maximum sustainable yield (MMR), the new PCP applies inventory management at the biomass size, breeding stocks and fishing mortality levels.  Both technical and multi-year plans are the main conservation tools to achieve these goals.  In view of the Commission's proposal for early 2016 on a new framework for technical measures, this report sets out the European Parliament's priorities in this area.  Aimed at addressing the problem of catching juveniles and other bycating fish, the report stresses the importance of regional conservation cooperation through multi-year plans. It also advocates a closer association of fishermen in the decision-making process, including in the development of technical measures. Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because, although we believe the entire Common Fisheries Policy is systemically flawed, it would not be right to stand against calls and plans for minor, mitigating changes.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the revision of the technical measures of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). Simplifying the measures of this legislative framework and strengthening cooperation in certain areas are essential to achieving the CFP's objectives of minimizing accidental catches and the impacts of fishing on the marine environment.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union has had a new common fisheries policy for the past year. This must lead to more sustainable fishing, ensuring the reproduction and conservation of species and protecting an important economic sector for many Member States, including France.  Traditional fishing techniques are recognized and will be preserved. Preservation of fisheries resources and an end to releases - more than a quarter of catches are wasted each year - are critical to the future of small-scale, artisanal and coastal fishing. For France, Europe's first maritime interface, this new common fisheries policy should be a real asset.  However, the complexity and diversity of technical measures make their application difficult for fishermen. To ensure the implementation of the CFP objectives, future technical measures will need to be simplified, within a clearly structured legal framework and developed on the basis of sound peer-reviewed scientific advice.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report was to simplify fisheries measures. In adapting the technical measures to the fisheries and the landing obligation, the goal was rather laudable. However, the Commission does not want to move to a regional scale so that the measures are geographically adapted. However, it will streamline regulations, without lowering the level of protection for marine species. I always defend the simplification of the rules when it does not mean abandoning the measures defended. So I voted for this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. We are voting in favour because this report is moving in the right direction and is trying to solve the chronic problems created by the implementation of the Common Fisheries Policy.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In accordance with EPP guidelines, I voted in favour of the adoption of the non-legislative report. On the one hand, the debate on competences between the EP and the Council needs to be put to an end, on the other hand, the adoption of fishing quotas and technical measures needs to be simplified and accelerated, and finally the range of scientific organisations involved in the preparation needs to be broadened. It is clear that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is being forced to impose appropriate restrictions on sea fishing. 30% of the earth's seas are overfished and marine fish stocks are at risk. Justified steps to maintain them will result in a continuous and significant reduction in the amount of marine fish fish fished. Therefore, the common fisheries policy should pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, i.e. aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant number of fish ponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 sites. These farms do not pose any threat to the natural assets of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is precisely because of our closed-system fish ponds that they have created or preserved individual wetland associations. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture should be prioritised and given as much EU support as possible. Furthermore, this area should be freed from unduly stringent and unnecessary sustainability standards, which are justified only for sea fishing.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is in the direction of simplifying the fishing techniques required.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We generally monitor proposals to simplify legislation, the participation of fishermen in the definition of fisheries policies, particularly at regional level, the improvement of fishing gear, increasing their selectivity, and a sustainable approach to stock management. Technical measures and multiannual plans are useful and potentially tools in fisheries management. Multiannual plans have, in general terms, the advantage of allowing some stability and predictability to a sector affected as few by enormous instability. But these plans must be framed in proximity management, capable of involving the sector and in which Member States play a leading role. The strict alignment and submission of these plans to the constraints imposed by the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) undermine much of its potential and accentuate limitations and disadvantages. This is the dominant view throughout this report – the defence of a strict submission to the new CFP. For our part, we support the need to promote a profound change in the existing institutional framework, which since the Treaty of Lisbon has enshrined the management of marine living resources as an exclusive competence of the EU. The disastrous results of this centralised management are in sight. Hence our abstention.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, as the report meets the needs to involve more stakeholders in the fisheries sector in the decision-making process and to enhance the peculiarities of each maritime area.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the reasons for the diversity and inconsistency of technical measures in the field of CFP is that a large part of them were adopted gradually by the Council within the framework of the annual regulations on total allowable catches and quotas. Many of the technical measures are only the result of political agreements between states. They are poorly scientifically based and result in insignificant differences between the seas. Multiannual plans concern the management of fishing activities targeting basic species. However, these plans have only been partially effective and have a number of shortcomings, particularly in terms of reducing and monitoring fishing activities.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is just a resolution, but it has the merit of presenting a merciless picture of the complex regulatory framework underlying fishing activity in the EU. The sum of the technical measures and multiannual management plans gives operators a very complicated system, especially in the Mediterranean, where there will be the greatest criticality.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because I believe it is moving in the right direction in order to solve the chronic problems relating to the implementation of the common fisheries policy.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Technical measures and multiannual plans are essential instruments to achieve the objectives of the 2013 CFP Reform. The revised Technical Measures Regulation must ensure clarity and legal certainty. It should seek to improve the conservation and sustainable exploitation of stocks and implement the ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management in a way that is consistent with the socio-economic viability of the fisheries sector. It is important to highlight the positive aspects of ending the wasteful practice of discarding as well as available EMFF support.  I believe we must support strongly the call for a solid scientific approach to improving the conservation and sustainable exploitation of stocks, minimising the impact on the marine environment, fighting IUU fishing, supporting fishermen, in particular traditional sustainable fishing practices and small-scale fishing, training, innovation, research, involvement of all relevant stakeholders in the decision-making, and regular re-evaluation.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The objectives of the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy implemented in 2013 included achieving maximum sustainable yield (MFH) through an ecosystem-based approach. Technical measures and multiannual plans, such as conservation measures, are the primary means of achieving these objectives. Nevertheless, very little progress has been made since 2009 in legislative documents on technical measures and multiannual plans. In the case of multiannual plans, this was due to an interinstitutional 'deadlock', due to the fact that the Commission's legislative proposals on multiannual plans classified the allocation of fishing opportunities as part of the catch control rules, which led to disagreements over Article 43 TFEP. In the case of technical measures, the difficulties stemmed from the alignment of legislation with the Treaty of Lisbon.   The co-legislators must find a pragmatic solution to make rapid progress on multiannual plans in the light of the case-law of the European Court of Justice. In addition, the effective participation of stakeholders in the development and implementation of multiannual plans should be enhanced. Finally, multiannual plans should be adopted as soon as possible. This avoids the regulation of long-term measures by means of discard plans, which by their very nature only have to include measures of a temporary nature. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour considering the need to establish technical measures to prevent catches of juveniles and other by-catch, the prevention of accidental catches of cetaceans or the prohibition of the cutting of shark fins on board, etc. It is also important to keep in mind the importance of multiannual plans, which aim to manage the main species of interest for fisheries, and should therefore provide a robust and durable framework for fisheries management, based on the best available scientific opinions. A new common fisheries policy should take into account the specificity of the Mediterranean, as Atlantic and Mediterranean fisheries have specific needs, so a one-size-fits-all policy could harm European fleets.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on a new CFP: framework for technical measures and multiannual plans. I am convinced that joint research is one of the pillars that Europe will have to develop even more in the future than it has done so far. I think it is important to think about optimising the processes now.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Further measures need to be taken with a view to sustainable, ecosystem-oriented fisheries. Technical measures in particular can lead to a significantly reduced volume of juvenile fish and thus sustainably strengthen the ecosystem. At the same time, existing multiannual plans need to be enforced and further adapted.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on a new common fisheries policy.  The 2013 reform of the CFP sought among other things to secure maximum sustainable yields (MSY), using the ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management. Technical measures and multi-annual plans have become the principal conservation instruments to achieve such objectives. The revised Technical Measures Regulation must ensure clarity and legal certainty. It should seek to improve the conservation and sustainable exploitation of stocks and implement the ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management in a way that is consistent with the socio-economic viability of the fisheries sector.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained since, while the rapporteur argues that technical measures should be simple and clear so that they can be easily understood by fishermen and adapted to the specific needs of each type of fishing and region and calls for participation in decision-making by fishermen, we understand that the Spanish fisheries sector is currently struggling enormously. These difficulties are most evident in small-scale and artisanal fishing and this report does not include any solution or proposal to solve its difficulties.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The technical measures and multiannual plans are essential instruments to achieve the objectives of the 2013 reform to the Common Fisheries Policy. I voted in favour of the new revised Technical Measures Regulation because I believe that it ensures the clarity and legal certainty that is required of any revision in these matters. Any reform to the CFP should seek to improve the conservation and the sustainable exploitation of stocks and implement the ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management in a way that is consistent with the socioeconomic viability of the fisheries sector. And I believe that the amendments that the S&D has introduced to this report ensure that these are effectively called for through this own-initiative report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as in order to ensure the implementation of the CFP objectives, future technical measures should be simplified in order to remove any contradiction and/or duplication contained in a clearly structured legal framework and based on solid scientific data reviewed by peers. It is necessary that the technical measures should include specific provisions on the use of certain fishing gear in order to protect vulnerable habitats and marine species. Additionally the technical measures should ensure that destructive and non-selective fishing gear is not used, and that the general use of explosive and poisonous substances should be prohibited. There is an urgent need to establish a coherent set of technical measures for each of the three main basins, taking account of the specific nature of each, where Union decisions may have a significant impact on the recovery of fish stocks and the protection of ecosystems and on the sustainable management of shared fish stocks.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for the legislative proposal of the Commission (expected to be published in January or February 2016 and governing how, where and when fishermen can fish) to implement the objectives of the CFP  through measures such as ensuring that accurate science influences rules and procedures and minimising the impact of fishing on the environment. It also calls, among other things, for technical measures to be calculated based on regionalisation and the needs of each area, setting up measures to avoid issues arising from landing obligations and for more involvement of fishermen in the decision process. Though I agree with what this report is proposing and my vote will be positive, it covers superfluous aspects which I would like to see removed. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the recital in this report which rejects regionalisation being used as a means of renationalising controls over fisheries.  Fisheries management should be based on what works best, not on Treaty technicalities.  To date EU centralised control over fisheries management has been woeful.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I   voted   in   favour   of   this   report   that   will  ensure   the   implementation   of   the Common Fisheries Policy objectives.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on a new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP): the structure of technical measures and multiannual plans, as since 2009 there has been almost no progress in legislative proposals on technical measures and multiannual plans, and that in the period 2002-2009 the effectiveness of the multiannual plans adopted was uneven; whereas the application of current innovations that improve the selectivity of fishing gears is often hampered by legislation, and whereas regionalisation can contribute to simplifying and better understanding of the rules and regionalisation must ensure that technical measures are adapted to the specific requirements of each fishing area and each basin, allowing for flexibility and rapid reactions as appropriate.  Technical measures must be simplified to eliminate contradictions and purposefulness and the new legislative framework should facilitate further use of innovative fishing gears. As part of regionalisation, decisions on minimum reference sizes for the conservation of each species should be based on scientific knowledge. Furthermore, the needs of local populations, the sustainability of coastal communities should be taken into account, the concept and role of small fisheries clearly defined.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Eu legislation in the fisheries sector is characterised by a complex and illegible legal pile-up, making its application very difficult.  This report calls for a simplification of the rules that satisfy fishermen who call for adaptation of technical measures to fisheries, adaptation of technical measures to the landing obligation and technical measures that are not contradictory.  I voted for the amendments following this reasoning and against those who departed from them.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I abstained because, although we believe the entire Common Fisheries Policy is systemically flawed, it would not be right to stand against calls and plans for minor, mitigating changes.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from this report. While most of the measures are worthy of support, I believe that the consequences of these measures are difficult to assess.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported Parliament’s call ahead of the publication of a legislative proposal for the new Technical Measures Regulation. It should seek to improve the conservation and sustainable exploitation of stocks and implement the ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management in a way that is consistent with the socioeconomic viability of the fisheries sector.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Regionalisation must ensure that technical measures are adapted to the needs of each fishery, ensuring the right degree of flexibility. One of the strengths of the new CFP is to build on innovation and research in order to improve selectivity, as well as modernise fishing and control techniques. We are all aware of the importance of the fisheries sector in terms of employment. I have therefore supported this report because of its positive support and relaunch of the sector, and also because new fishing techniques, which are based on increasingly innovative methods, will contribute to reducing the impact on the environment.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for the report on the new PCP: structure for technical measures and multi-year plans. Technical measures have been stacked for 30 years. They are complex and very directive. Fishermen do not respect them because of these defects.  This report seeks to simplify these technical measures and adapt them to each fishery. It is therefore a question of regionalising technical measures within the framework of the multi-year plans. It is joined in this by the consultation on technical measures. The professionals who responded expressed three demands: an adaptation of technical measures to fisheries, an adaptation of technical measures to the landing obligation and technical measures that are not contradictory.  The simplification of technical measures is a good move. The report plans to regionalise them, but the Commission will have the final say and will present its draft at the end of January 2016. However, the Commission recognises that rationalisation and simplification are needed.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. FN MEPs voted in favour of this text on fisheries because it simplifies the technical measures that govern it. It corresponds to a demand from the fishermen themselves.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. Technical measures for fisheries have literally been stacked for thirty years. They are complex and very directive, as are many European regulations. The laudable aim of this report is to simplify these measures within the framework of multi-year plans, while adapting them to fisheries through regionalization.  Because I am campaigning for a simplification of standards, and I defend the common sense that their regionalisation would represent, I voted in favour of this report, hoping that the Commission will follow its main points.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Among the various objectives set out by the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) in 2013 was the achievement of sustainable core yields using an ecosystem approach. Achieving this objective requires the implementation of technical measures and multiannual plans, as well as conservation measures.  With regard to multiannual plans, the report considers it necessary to increase the effective participation of stakeholders in the design and development of them.  With regard to technical measures, these should be clear and adaptable to the specificities of each squeer and each region. However, EU co-legislators should lay down rules common to all sea basins that will not be modified within a reasonable period of time through codecision in the ordinary legislative procedure, as absolute regionalisation would not be compatible with the CFP.  Finally, greater and effective participation of fishermen in the decision-making process is appealed to the last detail of the technical measures, as well as the creation of incentives to facilitate their implementation. I consider this report to be of great importance as it includes interesting measures to achieve the objectives of fisheries policy reform (CFP).

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒2012 Future technical measures that are the main instruments for achieving the objectives of the Common Fishing Policy of the European Union must be simple to make it easy for fishermen to understand. As far as possible, they need to be adapted to the specific needs of each fishery and each region. Also, provisions common to all regions or unlikely to be changed must be adopted by EU legislative bodies as a ordinary legislative procedure. I supported MP Gabriel Mato's report because improving regulations for fisheries is an important factor in increasing GDP in countries that have conditions for its development, such as Croatia. In my view, fishermen should be more involved in the process of deciding on technical measures.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Given europe's geographical location and its historical and gastronomic characteristics, the common fisheries policy is one of the most important policies at the european union's supranational level. One of the primary problems is that, for many years now, there have been disputes between the transnational institutions regarding their decision-making powers. Consequently, not only does the actual quality of the implementation of the CFP be reduced, but also the confidence of the workers and entrepreneurs involved in this sector in the European Union, firstly due to annual quotas and the constant crisis (e.g. the Russian embargo on baltic fisheries commodities, first of all canned). The main objectives of the current CFP reform are to facilitate technical requirements (their list, implementation and reporting rules), to introduce the principle of regionalisation (where geographically groupings would propose proposals jointly made to the Commission) and to increase the effectiveness of multiannual plans. Another moment of principle is that it is planned to significantly intensify the participation of the actors directly involved in the implementation of the planning and other stages of this policy. While the reform of the new CFP looks logical enough and is certainly long to come, the most important thing for it is not only to streamline some of the rules of operation of the system, but to improve the well-being of the Europeans involved in fishing, to take their interests into account, and to promote the sustainability of marine resources without negative consequences for the population involved in the sector.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from voting on the report on the new CSP and the structure of technical measures and multiannual projects, because in my view it is neither complete nor documented. I also refer to the speeches I mentioned in detail in my speech of 14 December 2015 before the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Future technical measures must be simple and clear so that they can be easily understood by fishermen. As far as possible, they should be adapted to the specific needs of each fishery and each region (regionalisation). However, provisions that are common to all sea basins or unlikely to be modified in the foreseeable future must be adopted by the EU co-legislators under the ordinary legislative procedure, i.e. codecision. Indeed, full regionalisation would not be compatible with the CFP, under which the EU has sole competence, given that the resources are shared. Finally, fishermen must be far more closely involved in the decision-making process, down to the very last detail of the technical measures. Incentives must also be provided to ensure compliance therewith.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. Once is not customary, Parliament is clear-headed: it recognises that the technical measures surrounding fishing are too heavy and too directive, to the point that fishermen get lost and can no longer respect them. The rapporteur's draft aims to simplify these procedures and adapt them to each fishery, through the regionalisation of the measures.  It should be noted, however, that the European Commission will have the final say on simplifying these measures. However, the Commission does not seem to be in favour of regionalisation.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2013 Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) reform set out to achieve maximum sustainable yield (MRI) through the application of an ecosystem-based approach. Conservation tools such as technical measures and multiannual plans are the main means of achieving this objective. In view of their procedural complexity, I support the position expressed by Mr Mato in his report, which provides for simplification and a clearer approach to technical measures, as well as a pragmatic solution for rapid progress on multiannual plans in the light of the case law of the Court of Justice of the EU.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Sustainable management of fish stocks is essential. The report contains some good proposals on this. However, it is questionable whether such a piece of legislation should come from EU level or whether the nation states should know best how to deal with their fish stocks and what practices are most promising in their respective waters. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report as it seeks to include the fisherman in the decision making process of the Common Fisheries Policy.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The new Common Fisheries Policy is based on three strong ideas to ensure the sustainability of the fishing sector through sustainable management of fisheries resources.  Multi-year quota management aims to make it legible for companies in the fishing sector, the objective of sustainable maximum yield tends towards optimizing catches according to the state of stocks, and finally the participation of regional advisory councils brings together management decisions of local operators whether they are fishermen, scientists or members of NGOs.  The report submitted aims to simplify measures and harmonize techniques for the requirement to disembark by large regions. I maintain that in my view the objective remains to "sort at the bottom not on the bridge". This report calls for Parliament to supervise the Commission's delegated actions on technical fisheries measures. It calls for contributing to the selectivity of fishing gear and confirms the participation of regional advisory councils in formulating concrete proposals to achieve the goal of reducing fish catches that are not of the required size. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to simplify technical measures and adapt them to fisheries. The aim is to regionalize technical measures within the framework of multi-year plans.  While the Commission does not appear to favour regionalisation, it recognises that a rationalisation of measures is necessary. I am therefore in favour of this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2009, there has been little progress in the legislative procedures for technical measures and multiannual plans, very important instruments for achieving the objectives of the reform of the common fisheries policy. I have put forward my vote in agreement with the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on this matter.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as the new Common Fishing Policy will contribute to the sustainable management of marine resources without burdening the fishing industries of the countries involved as many of the measures are already in place at national level. The report also emphasises that the technical measures are simple and clear so that they can understood by fishermen and so that the fishermen are heavily involved in the decision-making process, especially in regard to the technical measures.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Technical measures and multi-year plans are essential tools in the sustainable management of our marine resources.  With regard to technical measures, which are often complex and included in many regulations, Parliament stresses the need to simplify them and provide for a 'general and readable European framework'. It is crucial to simplify their legibility as much as possible in order to facilitate their application by fishermen. In terms of multi-year plans, Parliament believes that more progress is needed to ensure the goal of maximum sustainable performance.  Parliament also recalls the objectives and principles of the new Common Fisheries Policy reformed in 2013, such as environmental sustainability and the ecosystem approach. The EU plays a crucial role in the sustainable management of fish stocks and the preservation of the marine environment. Consistent and readable technical measures and multi-year plans are the necessary corollary to sustainable fisheries.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of the report on the new common fisheries policy and the structure of technical measures and multiannual plans, I consider it necessary to take care to respect the primary objective of maximizing sustainable yield using an ecosystem approach. I therefore support the adoption of a general framework of technical measures containing general objectives and minimum common eu-wide standards. However, I note that their simplification should not come at the expense of environmental protection.
