On the contrary, Eu decisions can significantly affect the recovery of fish stocks, the protection of ecosystems and the sustainable management of common fish stocks.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With some small reservations, I voted in favour of the report on ‘A new CFP: Structure for technical measures and multiannual plans’. Technical measures and multiannual plans are among the most important instruments to achieve the objectives of the 2013 CFP Reform. The Commission will submit its legislative proposal for the new Technical Measures Regulation early next year. This own-initiative report gives a first idea of the European Parliament position on the key aspects of the new regulation.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Mato report on the new PCP aims to simplify the technical measures stacked for 30 years in the field of fishing. The aim is to regionalize technical measures as part of multi-year plans.  The problem is that the European Commission does not intend to regionalise these measures, but nevertheless plans to rationalise and simplify by reducing the number of regulations. I voted in favour of this text which simplifies positive law, even if the Commission does not envisage regionalisation, unlike this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this own-initiative report as it sets out the European Parliament’s red lines ahead of a new Commission proposal on technical measures relating to the 2013 reform of the common fisheries policy (CFP) which sought among other things to secure maximum sustainable yields (MSY), using the ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management. Technical measures and multiannual plans have become the principal conservation instruments to achieve such objectives.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the new Common Fisheries Policy, which has been in force since January 2014. This policy is based on four main areas: the maintenance of fish stocks above the maximum sustainable yield (MMR), the obligation to land all catches, management plans to manage fish stocks on a multi-year basis, and the regionalization of technical measures.  The purpose of this report is to make recommendations for negotiations on the new technical framework adapted to the objectives of the new CFP, which the Commission is expected to propose in early 2016. Technical measures regulate fishing conditions, including fishing gear characteristics, minimum catch size or fishing areas.  I am particularly in favour of the provision of this text, which calls for the simplification of technical measures to put an end to the successive accumulation of contradictory regulations. I also supported the recommendation that fishermen participate in the process of developing these technical measures, as well as the adaptation of multi-year management plans to different areas and species.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of our colleague Gabriel Mato's report on the new Common Fisheries Policy. The report stresses the following points: a simplification of technical measures to end the successive stacking of conflicting regulations; Adapting technical measures to the regional specificities of fisheries; an adaptation of the regulatory framework to the new management logic imposed by the obligation to disembark all catches; Fishermen's involvement in the process of developing technical measures; adoption of multi-year management plans for different areas and species.  Since the 2013 CFP reform, all multi-year plans must include a maximum sustainable performance target with a timetable for achieving it, measures to implement the release ban and the landing requirement, as well as safeguard mechanisms to take corrective action and review clauses.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report regarding the implementation of a new common fisheries policy including necessary technical measures and multi annual plans.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, the main objectives of the common fisheries policy are well and well thought out. Nevertheless, despite previous successes, there are still some problems. There is criticism of the new fishing quota – there is a gap between politics and science here – which will not end overfishing in European waters. We must work closely together in this area, and only then would I vote in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to ensure maximum sustainable yield and environmental protection. It is positive that fishermen need to be more involved in processes and that account has been taken of the rules to be put in place to be as simple and comprehensible as possible.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report.  In particular, a coherent set of technical measures should be established for the main pools, taking into account the specificities of each basin. Future technical measures should be simplified to make them easier for fishermen to understand. It is essential to ensure that these measures are adapted to the specificities of each species and to each region, on the basis of scientific conclusions. It is necessary to introduce a ban on the use of explosive and poisonous substances and to promote the wider use of innovative fishing gear, which increase selectivity and have a lower impact on the environment.  Fishermen should play a greater role. They should be provided with financial and other support measures. Furthermore, further efforts are needed to properly implement the discard ban.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because, although we believe the entire common fisheries policy is systemically flawed, it would not be right to stand against calls and plans for minor, mitigating changes.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I reiterate my position on simplifying the regulations on technical measures relating to fisheries. I hope that progress can soon be made on the institutional unblocking of the dossiers relating to the multiannual plans and I am voting in favour of them.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. We are familiar with the data on the reaching of the limits of sustainability of biological capacities in the seas and the data that the continuation of overfishing threatens the survival of certain commercial species, and thus the sustainable yield of the fishing sector. It is the reform of the common fishing policy in 2013 that requires ensuring the highest sustainable yield by applying an ecosystem approach. This may seem complicated, but it is simply that we cannot capture and hunt more than what can be naturally restored. Technical measures and multiannual plans are the main instruments for preserving sustainable yield. Like agricultural policy, which is also run without sufficient consultation with peasants, so fisheries policy must be better communicated among stakeholders. The technical measures and requirements put before fishermen must be clear and understandable for fishermen to implement them. It is also necessary to exempt from unnecessary restrictions occasional small-scale coastal fishing traditionally used throughout the Mediterranean, especially where those restrictions cannot be justified by the ecosystem approach framework. That is why it is necessary for fishermen to be involved in the processes of creating measures and decision-making to a far greater extent.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the new CFP aims to simplify the technical measures stacked for thirty years in the field of fisheries. The aim is to regionalize technical measures as part of multi-year plans. The problem is that the European Commission does not intend to regionalise these measures, but nevertheless plans to rationalise and simplify by reducing the number of regulations. I voted in favour of this text which simplifies positive law, even if the Commission does not envisage regionalisation, unlike this report.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The complexity of technical measures so far is mainly due to different legislative procedures, but also political compromises, which has created differences in regulation in different marine areas that cannot be justified. In this regard, it is a commendable effort to level the technical rules with due respect to certain regional differences.  I support the proposed structure of technical measures in fisheries policy, which would establish three levels of co-decision and a fourth as a regionalised level, i.e. under which the first three levels would have common centralised rules and a set of specific technical rules adopted by co-decision with one level of rules applicable regionally.  The effectiveness of multiannual plans should also be increased, not only through stronger monitoring mechanisms for fishing activity. This can be achieved by insisting on scientific criteria while allowing flexibility in relation to inventory adjustments.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. - I support Gabriel Mato's report on the new Common Fisheries Policy.  Given that the sustainability of fish stocks is a prerequisite for the future of the fisheries industry and fisheries represent a natural, renewable, movable and common good, it is of the utmost importance that we operate in the field of fisheries policy through technical measures and multiannual plans. As one of the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy is to restore and maintain the population of caught species above levels that can lead to maximum sustainable yield through an ecosystem-based approach and selectivity, I agree that technical measures and multiannual plans are among the main means to achieve these objectives.  I believe that multiannual plans should set a general objective that can be achieved in the administrative and scientific framework, and multiannual plans should cover long-term stable yields in line with the best available scientific opinion on what should be reflected in the Council's annual decisions on fishing opportunities.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that the European Commission has put forward a proposal to reform the common fisheries policy. The exploitation and exploitation of our seas is, in many respects, a fundamental problem that needs to be addressed urgently. Today's intensive fishing causes the disappearance of entire species and the consequent instability of the biological environment in the seas and oceans, affecting, inter alia, climate fluctuations and changes. The reform of the 2013 CFP has made considerable progress, but there is still a need to improve the measures and, above all, to simplify them so that we can achieve maximum sustainable yield through an environmental approach. Such a combination should be ensured by the new reform, which provides for the regulation of fishing effort, presents multiannual plans, regional cooperation and other technical measures. These measures should be adapted to each fishing area and region to the extent that they are still compatible with the CFP and thus the EU's exclusive competence in the area of shared resources. The measures must then necessarily be simple and clear, so that they are easy to understand for fishermen and that they do not provide scope for different interpretations. I think that the introduction of specific control standards to limit the explosion of the seas is a necessary step that we must take now to prevent disastrous consequences in the future.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Technical measures and multiannual plans are the main instruments for achieving the objectives of the reform of the common fisheries policy (CFP). It is of great importance that technical measures are rationalised, simplified and adapted to facilitate their understanding by fishermen and adapt to the peculiarities of each fishery and region (regionalisation). It is necessary to involve fishermen more effectively in the decision-making process up to and to ensure the creation of incentives to facilitate their application. Multiannual plans, on the other hand, must be adopted as soon as possible in order to prevent long-term measures from being regulated by means of discard plans which, by their nature, must include only interim measures. I voted in favour of european co-legislators finding a pragmatic solution for rapid progress on multiannual plans and technical measures for a new reform of the CFP.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this report, because it sends very good signals to our fishermen, especially those at home in the Mediterranean. When we ask to simplify technical measures, adapt them to regional specificities or involve fishermen even more in the development of these same technical measures, we demonstrate that we have taken into account their expectations. We still need to transform this on paper, but we will get there because we will remain committed to sustainable but competitive fisheries.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because, although we believe the entire common fisheries policy is systemically flawed, it would not be right to stand against calls and plans for minor, mitigating changes.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which considers it urgent to establish a coherent set of technical measures for the main basins taking into account their respective specificities. Given the landing requirement in force since 1 January 2015 which will be phased in for all fish stocks by 2019, the European Parliament has notably called for the technical measures to be flexible enough to take into account real-time changes in fisheries and to allow the fishing sector to put into practice innovations in gear selectivity.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Common Fisheries Policy entered into force on 1/01/2014 following the Green Paper on "The Reform of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP)" presented in April 2009. The new CFP aims to ensure optimal exploitation of the captured species - at least at levels that can produce maximum sustainable yield (MSY), by implementing an ecosystem approach that ensures minimal negative impacts of fishing activity in the marine ecosystem itself. This own-initiative report, which I voted in favour of, shows that, in the context of the practical implementation of the new CFP, there is an objective need to implement technical measures in a coherent, simplified and targeted manner in terms of type of fisheries and region, on the one hand, and, on the other hand, the absolute need to "in defining and implementing multiannual plans, strengthening stakeholder participation through advisory councils and in all decisions concerning [their] regionalisation". It also recalls that the landing obligation is a major change for the fisheries sector, which requires an adaptation of technical measures to enable their effective implementation (e.g. granting greater flexibility in mesh size, as described in the report).

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) came into force in January 2014. As part of its implementation, it will be accompanied by a new framework of technical measures to be proposed by the Commission in early 2016; The aim is to adapt the technical measures to the objectives of the new PCP. I supported this report, which gives Parliament's position on future negotiations on the technical framework. In particular, it insists on: simplifying technical measures to end the successive stacking of conflicting regulations; adapting the regulatory framework to the new management logic imposed by the obligation to disembark all catches; involving fishermen in the process of developing technical measures and adopting multi-year management plans for different areas and species.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained because, while the rapporteur argues that technical measures should be simple and clear so that they can be easily understood by fishermen and adapted to the specific needs of each type of fishing and region, and calls for participation in decision-making by fishermen, we understand that the Spanish fisheries sector is currently going through enormous difficulties. These difficulties are most evident in small-scale and artisanal fisheries and this report does not include any solution or proposal to respond to the difficulties of these fisheries subsectors.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the Mato Report on the new CFP: the structure of technical measures and multiannual plans. Although a new CFP was created in 2013, conservation progress is still expected to date. Technical measures are heterogeneous and inconsistent in nature, especially because they have been adopted through different legislative procedures and have been the response of very different motivations.  In the future, legislators must ensure that the technical measures are simple and clear, so that they are easily understood by fishermen. It is also necessary to find a solution as soon as possible in order to move forward with regard to multiannual plans. Moreover, it is essential that fishermen are consulted at every step in the revision and implementation of legislation.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Technical measures and multiannual plans are essential tools to ensure the conservation and sustainable management of fish stocks and marine ecosystems. The report adopted today represents the European Parliament's position with a view to the next proposal for a revision to be presented by the European Commission at the beginning of 2016. I hope that in the future regulatory framework due account will be taken of the specific characteristics of each maritime basin and, in particular, of the Mediterranean Sea, whose fish stocks are also shared with third countries that have conservation standards very different from those in Europe.  Multiannual plans and technical measures will be a key element in putting the principle of régionalisation into practice, in order to adapt the rules to the specific characteristics of each area and every fishing activity, simplifying and making it easier for fishermen and industry to transpose them. I voted in favour of the own-initiative report pending a more detailed discussion of the new legislative proposals in the coming months.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Gabriel Mato, on the work done in this report. We may not fully agree with some of the details of this report, but we are fully in line with the need to preserve the sustainability of fishermen, marine resources and marine ecosystems. As argued in the report, fisheries management in Europe must follow the new Common Fisheries Policy and must accommodate the Marine Strategy Framework Directive. This is a particularly important and repeatedly disrespected topic. At the same time, I disagree with this report that all catches must be landed in port in 2019, not least because that does not correspond to the truth. Only catches of species with defined quotas will be required to disembark at port.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this as I reject the structure of the CFP, this report only makes the CFP slightly less more objectionable.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The technical measures and multiannual plans are essential instruments to achieve the objectives of the 2013 Reform to the Common Fisheries Policy. I voted in favour of the new revised Technical Measures Regulation because I believe that they ensure the clarity and legal certainty that is required of any revision in these matters. Any reform to the CFP should seek to improve the conservation and the sustainable exploitation of stocks and implement the ecosystem-based approach to fisheries management in a way that is consistent with the socioeconomic viability of the fisheries sector. And I believe that the amendments that the S&D has introduced to this report ensure that these are effectively called for through this INI report.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the new common fisheries policy /CFP/, the structure of technical measures and the multiannual plan, as it must aim to achieve maximum sustainable yield using an ecosystem approach. The technical measures are intended to prevent catches of juveniles and other by-catches. In principle, the system is based on three set of geographically differentiated measures (baltic sea, Mediterranean and Atlantic and other waters), consisting of a specific set of rules. They also include specific provisions relating, for example, to the prohibition of the use of drift nets, the prevention of accidental catches of whales or the prohibition on the removal of shark fins on board. The reform of the CFP introduced a ban on discards without resolving the inflexibility typical of the CFP and quota system. Regionalisation or regional cooperation and in the field of conservation measures are an essential element of the reform of the CFP.  Future CFP technical measures must be simple and clear so that fishermen understand them well and should adapt as much as possible to the specific needs of individual fisheries and individual regions.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) include restoring and maintaining populations of hunted species above levels that allow maximum sustainable yield. This is sought through the use of an ecosystem and selectivity approach. In 2009, technical measures and multiannual plans were set up in this respect.  The report notes that only minor progress has been made since this year, partly due to frictions between the European institutions regarding their competences and partly because of the harmonisation of legislation relating to technical measures related to the Treaty of Lisbon.  I welcome the drafting of the report and agree that the review of technical measures should aim to improve the environmental sustainability of fisheries and marine resources in a way that is consistent with the socio-economic sustainability of the sector.  I also believe that, in order to ensure the implementation of the objectives of the CFP and to eliminate inconsistencies or duplication of future technical measures, it is necessary to simplify them and place them in a clearly structured legal framework. These should be based on reliable scientific data provided by peer review.  The new legislative framework would thus facilitate the continued use of innovative fishing gear, which has been scientifically proven to increase selectivity and reduce the environmental impact. As I believe that the sustainability of fish stocks is a necessary condition for the future of the fishing industry, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support this bill because the sustainability of fish stocks is a prerequisite for the future of the fisheries industry. A harmonised set of technical measures should be put in place, taking into account the specific characteristics of each, as decisions at Union level can have an important impact on the recovery of fish stocks and the protection of ecosystems and on the sustainable management of common fish stocks. Multiannual plans should be a robust and durable framework for fisheries management and should be based on the best and latest scientific and social information recognised by experts.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The 2013 Common Fisheries Policy (ZJP) Reform asked, inter alia, to ensure maximum sustainable yield through an ecosystem-based approach. Technical measures and multiannual plans have become the main conservation instruments to achieve this objective. Future technical measures must be simple and clear so that they can be easy for fishermen to understand.  The multiannual plans aim to set management targets under the conditions of individual biomass farming and deadly fishing. Most of the eleven multiannual plans currently drawn up concern total allowable catches (TACs). Following the reform of the 2013 Common Fisheries Policy, multiannual plans must include a maximum sustainable yield target and a deadline for achievement. I support the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the new Common Fisheries Policy, as it also includes multiannual plans and technical measures, the essential element of which is regionalisation or regional cooperation on safeguards. Multiannual plans are an appropriate framework for adopting and implementing specific technical measures in the context of regionalisation, and this report finally calls for stronger involvement of fishermen in the decision-making process.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it leads to the streamlining of the Common Fisheries Policy.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the new common fisheries policy: the structure of technical measures and multiannual plans. The Common Fisheries Policy was amended in 2013 with a view to restoring and preserving populations of hunted species above levels that allow maximum sustainable yield. The best way to achieve this is through technical measures and multiannual plans. The report proposes the introduction of technical measures to protect juveniles and to decide on the minimum conservation reference size, taking into account scientific advice. I welcome that the report proposes the inclusion of fishermen in the decision-making process, right up to the last detail of the technical measures.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to vote in favour of this report and to support its calls for fishermen to be more involved in decision-making and for there to be better use of scientific evidence in managing fish stocks.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report provides a number of positive elements such as stakeholder involvement in the definition of regional fisheries policy, improved fishing practices and tools, sustainable management of stocks and coordination between Member States in the creation of management plans and definition of technical measures. However, we cannot overlook the enormous problems and discrimination in the fisheries sector, particularly for smaller-scale fishermen, the implementation of the CFP and the ever-expanding harmonisation of national policies with the acquis communautaire which favour profitability and the development of large enterprises in particular. These important issues are not mentioned or promoted to address them. For these reasons we have decided to abstain.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report is moving in the right direction in order to solve the chronic problems relating to the implementation of the common fisheries policy.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union gives an important place to fisheries in its major policies. In 2013, the reform of the common fisheries policy took place with a view to establishing maximum sustainable production, using an ecosystem approach. The main instruments by which the objectives of the new policy can be achieved are technical measures and multiannual plans as conservation measures.  However, little progress has been made so far in the implementation of these instruments due to interinstitutional gridlock. In this context, it is necessary to apply without delay the measures assumed by the reformed system, such as avoiding brood catches and other by-catches, preserving and exploiting existing stocks sustainably, minimising the impact on the marine environment, combating illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, supporting traditional fishing, supporting research and innovation in the field, involving all relevant decision-makers and regular reassessment of that policy.  The application of these measures will have a direct effect on the possibility of continuing fishing in the future, by allowing the reproduction of the necessary fish stocks and avoiding the depletion of these important marine resources. For these reasons, I believe that this report should be adopted in order to clarify the regulations in this area.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the adoption of this own-initiative report regarding the common fisheries policy (CFP). To achieve the objectives resulting from its 2013 reform, technical measures and multiannual plans were identified as the two key instruments. However, little progress has been made and this report calls for improvements. It proposes that the multiannual plans should be adopted as soon as possible, involving stakeholders in their development. Regarding the technical measures, it brings simplification and regionalisation. It calls for future technical measures to be clear so that they can be easily understood by fishermen and to include them in the decision-making process on the details of the technical measures.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The Common Fisheries Policy was reformed in 2013, and it was time to revise the resulting technical measures, some of which have remained unchanged since 1998. I therefore participated in the work of the Committee on Fisheries to make recommendations to the European Commission on the future technical framework, which we adopted in the form of a resolution in Strasbourg on Tuesday 15 December.  A broad consensus has been formed around the necessary simplification and regionalization. Because some measures, if they apply to everyone indiscriminately, can have a perverse effect on specific fisheries. I am also pleased to have adopted an amendment in plenary which warns of the need for real regionalisation to allow more participation and membership of the stakeholders concerned.  Finally, the new fisheries policy must become that of selectivity. Selectivity is about avoiding juveniles and capturing only the targeted species, those for which quotas are held, using modernized fishing gear and techniques.  Some existing technical measures will have to disappear because they are now brakes on selectivity.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ This report in the PECH committee, of which I am a full member, is a precursor to the European Commission's anticipated Regulation on Technical Measures and Multiannual Management Plans; therefore of utmost importance. The Commission proposal is expected in February 2016 and should contain a very wide range of rules on how, where and when fishermen in the European Union can fish. The rules are established for all European seas, however, they vary from sea to sea according to regional needs and specificities. The two most important things planned to be revised within the CFP are the landing and regionalisation obligations, and accordingly this report calls for the Commission's legislative proposal to implement the OBJECTIVES of the CFP through improved selectivity, the minimisation of waste and the negative impact of fishing on the environment, the simplification of existing rules and the provision of accurate scientific data on impact procedures which I fully agree on, as I consider all of the above necessary and necessary. I also fully agree with the call for fishermen to be actively involved in the decision-making process and to provide them with easier access to the European Fisheries Fund accordingly. However, as a representative from Croatia, I nevertheless hold the call for technical measures to be determined in accordance with regional specificities and needs, and therefore the report has received my wholehearted support.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The report was supported by the new Common Fisheries Policy: the structure of technical measures and multiannual plans, as it is important that the measures can actually be successfully implemented. However, in order for this to be possible, they must be simple and clear and, above all, understandable for fishermen. It is also important that multiannual plans be adopted as soon as possible to ensure that long-term measures are not regulated by landing plans, which should only be temporary.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained because, while the rapporteur argues that technical measures should be simple and clear so that they can be easily understood by fishermen and adapted to the specific needs of each type of fishing and region, and calls for participation in decision-making by fishermen, we understand that the Spanish fisheries sector is currently going through enormous difficulties. These difficulties are most evident in small-scale and artisanal fisheries and this report does not include any solution or proposal to respond to the difficulties of these fisheries subsectors.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Simplifying technical measures is a good move. The report plans to regionalise them, but the Commission will have the final say and will present its draft at the end of January 2016. However, the Commission recognises that rationalisation and simplification are needed. So I'm voting for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The objectives of the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy implemented in 2013 included achieving maximum sustainable yield (MFH) through an ecosystem-based approach. Technical measures and multiannual plans, such as conservation measures, are the primary means of achieving these objectives. Nevertheless, very little progress has been made since 2009 in legislative documents on technical measures and multiannual plans. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained because, while the rapporteur argues that technical measures should be simple and clear so that they can be easily understood by fishermen and adapted to the specific needs of each type of fishing and region, and calls for participation in decision-making by fishermen, we understand that the Spanish fisheries sector is currently going through enormous difficulties. These difficulties are most evident in small-scale and artisanal fisheries and this report does not include any solution or proposal to respond to the difficulties of these fisheries subsectors.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – The objective of the technical measures is to prevent catches and other by-catches of juveniles. In principle, this system consists of three regulations, which are based on three sets of rules based on different geographical areas (Baltic Sea, Mediterranean and Atlantic and other waters). Future regulation on technical measures will require codecision in order to ensure a level playing field and facilitate enforcement and control.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text because I agree that multiannual plans are concerned with management of the principal species being fished. All of them seek to establish stock management objectives in terms of individual breeding biomass and fishing mortality. Most of the eleven multi-annual plans currently drawn up are concerned with total allowable catches (TACs). However, a number of them also refer to other instruments such as technical measures, fishing effort restrictions or specific monitoring rules. I also agree that is necessary for multiannual plans to be adopted as soon as possible, thereby ensuring that long-term measures are not regulated through discard plans, which should only be provisional in nature.  I think that the review of technical measures should take into account their impact in terms of biological resources conservation, the marine environment, fishing operating costs and profitability in socio-occupational terms.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In this report, Parliament calls for more efficient regulation of the fisheries sector, with a simplification of the rules, more attention to scientific criteria when deciding, that the situation in each region and fishing basin be accounted for and that the voice of those most directly involved, i.e. fishermen, be heard. We are therefore talking about a report which proposes positive and constructive proposals for the sector for a Regulation which the Commission is expected to present at the beginning of 2016, so I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'The new CFP promotes sustainable fishing, namely by maintaining the fish stock and maintaining long-term productivity. A new structure for technical measures and multiannual plans will ensure the long-term sustainability of the fishing sector and, moreover, help to achieve the most important objectives of the reformed CFP. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) is said to be aimed at ensuring the sustainability of fisheries while ensuring a fair standard of living for fishermen. It has recently been the subject of a reform including multi-year fishing plans (not to interfere with the reproductive capacity of species) and a series of technical measures (banning drift gillnets, preventing accidental catches of porpoises, banning the removal of shark fins on board ships..). These provisions are distributed in more than 30 different regulations and constitute a complex, heterogeneous and sometimes even contradictory system. This resolution therefore calls for a new framework that can be easily understood by fishermen, as well as for closer participation of fishermen in the decision-making process. Without prejudice to the content of the future CFP and relying only on the measures advocated in this report which I believe are going in the right direction, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. 'Multiannual plans have, in general terms, the advantage of allowing some stability and predictability to a sector affected as few by enormous instability. Unfortunately, the institutional framework in force since the Treaty of Lisbon, which enshrines the management of marine living resources as an exclusive competence of the European Union, requires centralised management of fisheries policy, far from the reality, which does not take into account the enormous diversity that characterizes the sector (in terms of resources, fleets, fishing gear and fisheries) and makes proximity management impossible and prevents proximity management , thus removing much of the advantages that such multi-annual plans could bring to the sector.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Sustainable management of fish stocks is essential. The report contains some good proposals on this. However, it is questionable whether such a piece of legislation should come from EU level or whether the nation states should know best how to deal with their fish stocks and what practices are most promising in their respective waters. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We generally follow proposals to simplify legislation, the participation of fishermen in the definition of fisheries policies, particularly at regional level, the improvement of fishing gear, increasing their selectivity, and a sustainable approach to stock management. Technical measures and multiannual plans are useful and potentially tools in fisheries management. Multiannual plans have, in general terms, the advantage of allowing some stability and predictability to a sector affected as few by enormous instability. But these plans must be framed in proximity management, capable of involving the sector and in which Member States play a major role. The strict alignment and submission of these plans to the constraints imposed by the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) undermine much of their potential and accentuate limitations and disadvantages. This is the dominant view throughout this report – the defence of a strict submission to the new CFP. Hence our abstention.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the Decision adopted on the European border and coast guard package (2015/2961(RSP)).

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, illegal entries into the Union have reached 1.5 million this year. That is almost double the total of the last five years. It clearly reveals a significant failure in how we manage and protect our external border. Large-scale irregular flows have repercussions all across the EU. Several Member States have reintroduced internal border controls. What started as a problem at our external borders has come to put into question Schengen itself. If we want to preserve Schengen, we have to improve our common external border management. Our biannual report on Schengen adopted today could not be clearer on this. The current security risks, so tragically illustrated by the Paris attacks, make action even more urgent. It is simply wrong to mix up refugees and terrorists. But we must be clear that external border controls are essential for our security. The growing number of Europeans leaving, and returning, for terrorist purposes is just one of the many reasons why we cannot do without proper checks at the external borders.  Therefore, among the Commission’s proposals today is an amendment to the Schengen Border Code, so that everyone crossing the external border, including EU citizens, is systematically checked against common databases. This will help ensure that someone who is a security threat will be stopped at the external border, upon arrival or leaving. In this plenary in September, President Juncker announced that the Commission would bring forward proposals for a European Border and Coast Guard. We have done so today, responding to calls from this House and the European Council to strengthen the protection of our external borders, which is an integral part of the European Agenda on Migration. The common European Border and Coast Guard will ensure the integrated management of the Union’s external borders, in line with the objective set out in Article 77 of the Treaty. The principle underlying our proposal is one of shared responsibility. In an area without internal borders, managing external borders effectively is a matter of common interest. Under our proposals, national border guards will remain the key actors in managing their section of the borders and in the day-to-day work. But they will work within a stronger European framework, with higher standards, integrated risk assessment, proper information flows and a proactive system to address deficiencies before they become problems. The national border guards will be supported, monitored and – when necessary – reinforced by a European Border and Coast Guard Agency. The Agency will be able to deploy equipment and a standing reserve of at least 1 500 border guards from Member States, instead of relying on ad hoc calls for voluntary contributions. All this should help correct many of the weaknesses that have hindered Frontex over the years.  The aim of this new integrated border management architecture is to prevent uncontrollable situations and to strengthen our collective ability to deal with crisis situations where a section of the external border suddenly comes under strong pressure. But we cannot exclude that there will still be exceptional situations where a Member State is, for whatever reason, unable to cope with the situation on its own. In such rare cases, the Agency itself must be able to quickly step in and assume the management of that specific part of the shared external border. This is a safety net, which like all safety nets, we hope will never need to be used. But it is essential if we are to restore the credibility of our border management system. In a way, it closes the loop.  Finally, the Agency will also have considerably strengthened powers in the field of return. Let me be very clear: Europe will provide protection for those who need it. But those who have no right to be here cannot stay. Today what we propose is an operational solution at EU level – a dedicated Return Office within the new Agency working with Member States and third countries to organise return operations and flights. I hope for the support of this House for these important proposals, and I hope that we can make progress quickly. In the meantime, we need to continue to work to improve the situation as it is today. Much still remains to be done in Italy and Greece. All Member States need to comply fully with their legal obligations. Last week we initiated a number of infringement proceedings on the application of Eurodac by Greece, Italy and Croatia, and on asylum and migration in Hungary. The Commission has also discussed other aspects of the refugee crisis today, including progress following the Leaders’ Meeting on the Western Balkan route ahead of this week’s European Council, which will be discussed by your House tomorrow morning.  I have focused here on the proposals which are most relevant for this debate on the European Border and Coast Guard. But it is clear that this is only one element of a wide range of actions we need in order to tackle the challenge of migration. The Commission will continue to pursue work on all fronts, and we will come back early next year with further proposals, in particular, to review the operation of the Dublin system. With your permission, Madam President, I now pass the floor to Commissioner Avramopoulous to walk you through the substance of our proposals.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this does not mean that what the First Vice-President said was not substantial. On the contrary, I would say that it is the substantial framework of what we have proposed so far and are proposing today. So I would like to express my thanks to the First Vice-President for his introduction.  I have repeatedly underlined that the Schengen framework is part of the solution to the current crisis. In recent months we have seen that sometimes the burden on the national border guard system of the frontline Member States has proved impossible for them to cope with. It is therefore important that the European Union can step in quickly to effectively support them.  That is precisely what we are doing today with our proposal. Now some elements of this proposal: we reinforce the obligations of cooperation and information sharing between the Agency and national authorities; we set up a monitoring and risk—analysis centre, which will go hand in hand with reliable and up—to—date risk analysis, including on relevant internal security threats.  Recent experience shows that the liaison officers can enhance dialogue and good cooperation between the Agency and the national authorities. Liaison should therefore be seconded by the Agency to specific Member States determined on the basis of risk analysis.  By also assessing the resources and equipment of the Member States, as well as their contingency planning, the Agency will determine whether they are well prepared to meet potential challenges and identify existing weaknesses. The Agency will be empowered to require Member States to take corrective measures. The decisions of the Agency will be binding upon the Member States.  The most important element of the new Agency is that it goes beyond what Frontex was able to do. But we do not replace Member States’ responsibilities and definitely not their sovereignty. Basically, where deficiencies persist and national action is not taken, the Commission – in cooperation with the Member States – will be able to adopt a decision determining that the situation at a particular section of the external borders requires urgent action and entrusting the Agency with the task of carrying out appropriate operational measures. The Executive Director will then have to submit an operational plan and will have to draw it up with the Member States within two working days. The Member State will have to facilitate the execution of the measures set out in the operational plan agreed with the Executive Director.  Let me emphasise here the strong preventive part of the regulation and the much stronger support it will provide to all Member States with external borders. The ultimate objective is that, through stronger preventive actions, we can precisely avoid emergency situations where such interventions would be necessary.  The management of the European borders will become a European responsibility in the true sense. For this, we also foresee adequate resources.  Currently, contributions of assets and expertise to Frontex are provided on a voluntary basis. For example, in the case of Greece, Frontex asked Member States to supply 743 guest officers, but only 447 have been provided so far. In the future, the Agency will have at its disposal a sufficient number of well-trained experts with the appropriate profiles, as well as the relevant technical equipment, through a standing corps.  As set out in the European Union’s action plan on return, the Agency should be able to initiate return operations and to assist Member States with the acquisition of travel documents. For these purposes, a dedicated return office will be created within the structure of the Agency. It will play a key role in return interventions.  European return intervention teams, composed of escorts and return specialists, will be able to be deployed to Member States subject to particular pressure on their return system. In urgent situations, rapid European return intervention teams could be deployed, either upon the request of a Member State, or at the Agency’s own initiative. Alongside this, we are proposing to establish a new European travel document for the return of third-country nationals that should be promoted in the context of readmission agreements. This should ensure a wider acceptance by third countries.  Since we are creating a stronger agency, it is equally important to have an adequate complaint mechanism in case a person considers that his or her fundamental rights have been violated in the course of operational engagements by the Agency. Both Parliament and the European Ombudsman have stressed the importance of such a mechanism. I refer here to the reports by Ms Metsola and Ms Keller, which we discussed, as you will remember, during the last plenary. Yes, this proposal includes sensitive parts. Member States will have to agree to transfer part of their responsibilities in the framework of the treaties, while of course keeping their sovereignty. They will be part of the scheme. Nothing – I repeat nothing – can happen without their cooperation. Our proposal is a European answer to a European issue. It is a proposal which will prevent our freedom of movement in the Schengen area from being put at stake. It is a proposal which proves that the current crisis does not divide us but, on the contrary, is becoming a catalyst for us to move ahead more united, more decided and more resolved. What we are proposing today is precisely what this Parliament has repeatedly asked for: more Europe. As always, I count on your support for this important step forward. (Applause)

name: Esteban González Pons
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, the migration crisis has highlighted the current situation: permeable external borders without internal borders. It's not the same to have an open-door house with open doors than to have a house without doors. In the last ten months, one and a half million people have entered the European Union irregularly. On an island of 30,000 inhabitants there have been days that flows of up to 15,000 people have arrived. Schengen is only feasible if external borders are secure. Without shared security there can be no shared trust. There are no countries without borders, as there are no houses without doors. Schengen does not mean that there are no borders, but that there are no borders between us.  Many of those who today are going to ask for a Europe without borders would never buy a house without a door; in fact, everyone who asks for a Europe without a border has a house with a door. If we want to continue without internal borders, we will have to strengthen external borders.  That is why I would like to support the plan proposed by the Commission today, to say that it is right and that it must be developed as soon as possible. Even if I may, let me say, it's about time! We've been waiting for you.  That is why I would like to stress what has been said: Europe's problems are solved with more Europe, whether they are economic problems, whether political problems or, as now, the need to provide a humanitarian response or security problems.  There are no more external borders. There is no longer a Greek border, an Italian border, a Spanish border. There are European borders. All borders are European and the border in Spain, Greece or Italy is also border of Germany, it is also border of France. If we live together and have common problems, the logical thing to do is for the solutions to be found together and put them in common. Welcome today's resolution.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Since October, the promised 400 police officers to be deployed by the Union to our country have so far received only about half of them. I say this because I am concerned about how the newly established agency will actually work if it has already encountered resistance from a number of countries.  I agree with you that there is an urgent need to ensure common European border controls, but I must raise some concerns. Firstly, the issue of national sovereignty. What can we expect in the event of rapid intervention by newly established bodies if a country does not agree to it? The new European system will obviously replace FRONTEX, which did not have sufficient powers and capacities to help alleviate the chaos at the Union's external borders. But the additional question is, who will provide funding? It is also essential that the proposal include parliamentary scrutiny, as well as a mechanism to ensure that the functioning of these border authorities is consistent with data protection and with fundamental rights.  I would like to stress once again: I agree that the right response is European, including and especially at the external borders. In recent weeks, a number of European countries have temporarily introduced border controls. If it is to stand, there is a legitimate fear that the Schengen system will fall apart. I therefore support the European Commission in all efforts to stop undermining the foundations of freedom of movement and, ahead of this week's summit, I call on you to continue a series of measures and, above all, to put pressure on European governments to implement them.

name: Timothy Kirkhope
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, there are countries in the EU that seem unable to protect their borders. They need to ask for help, and at the moment some are failing to do so. The implications of this are being felt across the entire European Union. Those countries cannot continue to ignore offers of help while at the same time waving through refugees and migrants on to other countries.  Therefore, we certainly need a Frontex agency capable of helping those countries in need. That agency should have resources pooled voluntarily from the Member States so it can be deployed to assist. If a country is both failing to control its borders and refusing to ask for help, then we should offer them a choice: take the help or the rest of the EU will be within its rights to take action for the protection of the EU’s internal borders.  My message to the Commission is this. The EU has rules and too often we see countries flouting those rules with little consequence. The answer from the Commission is to demand more sovereignty, but why do they not enforce the rules we already have in place? Protecting external borders is something I support, but if a country cannot cope and will not ask for help, they should face the consequences. As Alexander Pope said, only fools rush in where angels fear to tread. So, before creating ever more compulsion and more sovereignty-sharing, we must have the courage to enforce what we already have in an effective and meaningful way. No one measure is going to solve the crisis. Whilst I welcome proposals to address the challenges we face at the borders, this must not be allowed to become another piece of legislation – much like the emergency relocation mechanism – which is welcomed with fanfares but which, when implemented, is met by either intransigence or a simple failure to respond.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commission today for its – quite modest – proposals on strengthening the European capacity to control our common borders. I am convinced that the proposals do not go far enough and still need to be significantly strengthened. Knowing that there are Member States in the Council that still consider that these proposals go too far is to me quite depressing, to tell the truth.  I sometimes wonder if governments of Member States are living in a parallel universe. How else could they complain constantly about the lack of control of our common borders and then oppose measures to secure exactly this once they have been presented? This to me is utterly absurd.  Through Schengen we have agreed to have one external border of the EU and no internal borders, which means that Greece’s borders with Turkey are as much Swedish borders as are Sweden’s borders with Norway. How Member States can argue that Member States should police their own borders is simply absurd. Imagine the United States with fifty sets of coastguards and border guards, where the US Coast Guard does not have the right to have its own equipment, but has to ask if it may kindly borrow that of the state for a while. This is an absurdity, and yet in Europe it is upheld by governments of Member States as the only logical solution. Anyone who suggests that maybe a common border needs common border protection is portrayed as some kind of crazy federalist. Europe needs today a single border control agency and this should become an exclusive competence of the EU. I wish that Member States would stop worrying so much about their own bureaucracies and start, for once, to think about citizens and security.

name: Malin Björk
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for When I read this document that I have become aware of on the internet, I felt that the extreme right was breathing down our necks. But instead of taking the fight with them, you turned around and embraced them. You chose to close the borders, because those are the consequences.  A Frontex superpower with extraordinary powers at all levels: patrolling, deporting, giving orders to member states, acting in third countries to stop people fleeing. Not a word about the very people on the run or how this border control is linked to our international commitments to provide protection to people on the run or how Europe should assume its responsibilities.  Colleagues, the EU is not hanging on Schengen or whether or not we should show id cards. Europe's legitimacy depends on whether we can take responsibility for accepting people fleeing, and that is why the legitimacy of the European Union is now hanging by a thread.  When it becomes difficult, when some countries are bored, what do you do? Then you fall back on the only common denominator; apparently we're going to close the borders. We have no legal means, we have no shared responsibility, border control and terrorism are confused and refugees are defined as risks.  Common border controls should be had if we can at the same time agree on how to receive people on the run together. Otherwise, there is nothing together or anything in common to defend with external borders. Then there was imaginary solidarity, then there were imaginary tears, because when the flight was at its greatest then, europe closed its borders. That is unacceptable. It's going their way.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, it is a very interesting debate that we are having about a proposal by the Commission that we do not even have yet on paper. Still, some colleagues already seem to be agreeing with it, and that is very nice obviously for them and the Commission. However, I would really like to see the proposals first and I have a couple of questions still.  It is very nice, Commissioner Avramopoulos, that you say the complaint mechanism will be included. I am very happy about that, but other issues that have been presented leave me with a bit more doubt. Especially, Mr Timmermans, you have been saying that the problem that we have is all the irregular entries into the European Union, but we all know that those people who entered irregularly have been finding asylum here, and have been granted protection. Those are people that we do not want to push away at the borders, I believe. So how exactly does this fit together with the proposal the Commission is making? Do you not think, Commissioner Avramopoulos, that a better answer to irregular entries would be to give refugees the possibility to enter regularly, legally and safely; then you could also have all your security checks at the external borders. Unfortunately, I do not see a proposal on that; maybe I am missing something. Neither have I heard any proposal on what you are proposing to do with Member States who are refusing to receive refugees, which seems to be more of an issue right now. I am not sure how you are going to address that issue. The proposal that you are making today does not really seem to be addressing the issues I think are most at hand.  So I do have a couple of questions. Will you agree that those Frontex mandatory actions will also happen at ports and airports when security fails? Do you agree that it is difficult to force Member States into good cooperation? And how will you solve the issue of jurisdiction? – because Member States are still responsible for whatever happens in their territorial waters.

name: Diane James
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, there is no crisis too grave, there is no situation too terrible and there is no level of human suffering too great for the European Union not to see another opportunity to extend its powers. In its usual convoluted and contradictory language which we heard earlier, the European Union sets out its response to the next opportunity. So the Commission wants to deploy personnel from a new Border and Coast Guard Agency without, as currently required, the consent of the state concerned. Well I do not know how others might feel, but I do not like the idea of forces sent unbidden into a Member State to defend a common European frontier. Now what the European Union Commission obviously wants to do is a little bit more of what it is used to doing, which is to spend more taxpayers’ money, create another European Union institution and expand and extend its power base.  I do hope that European Union Member States’ citizens will see this for what it is, which is ceding border enforcement to an unanswerable, probably armed, but also unaccountable European Union body. I hope, like me, they do not want that. Do they really think it will help the situation? I do not believe it will. Will it assist European Union expansion? Well of course it will. And will it resolve the causative European Union factors behind all of this? No it will not. We will get Brexit in the UK very soon and we will be able to make our point known and it will be: walk away from this.

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – By allowing and inviting asylum seekers indefinitely, the European Union has created a new crisis about itself. And Brussels' response to a crisis is always the same: more European Union. For the achievement of a European superstate, a United States of Europe is and remains the ultimate goal of the European elite. Borders no longer exist, vetoes have been surrendered and their own currency has been exchanged for the euro.  The plan to set up an EU border guard is the next step in dismantling the nation-state. And you know damn well what you're doing. For a country that cannot control its own borders and puts its destiny in the hands of the European Union is no longer a country, exactly what all Europhiles are after. Countries already need permission from Brussels if they want to control their own territory. With this proposal, we are losing effective control and are one step closer to becoming a European superstate. This proposal will increase the happiness seekers, more terrorists and more Islamisation of the once beautiful continent of Europe. Because the borders are not closed at all and European control is in practice aimed at admitting rather than stopping them.  Finally, the Netherlands is a nation state, a sovereign country, and it must remain so. The PVV wants the Netherlands to control its own territory. We want to decide for ourselves whether, how, when and for whom we close our borders. That is the only solution, nothing more and nothing less.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Madam President, the 'border guards' package presented today by the Commission is a response to the current crisis, but as usual it is an attempt to mismanage problems that we would not have had without the Europe in Brussels. Indeed, what the Commission is proposing in the face of the influx of immigrants of all kinds is not the strengthening of cooperation, but the placing under the tutelage of these countries, a total violation of their sovereignty. In other words, it is the right to interfere with globalists, the act of intervening with foreign forces on the territory of a State that has not asked for anything, or even opposed it, supposedly for its own good. Worse, to trigger this intervention decided by the Commission's bureaucrats alone, government approval would not even be required; they could only oppose it by painfully bringing together a strengthened majority. This rule, known as reverse qualified majority voting, is an additional scandal.  Schengen suffers from an original defect: it was negotiated in secret. French parliamentarians only discovered its existence by chance, by the publication of a decree in the middle of August 1986, six months after it came into force. Schengen allows uncontrolled movement between European countries - this is basically the cause of the problem - a call for air, and these replenishments will not change that.  Let's re-establish internal border controls; that each state should regain full control of its migration policy and, please Merkel, to welcome millions of immigrants, whom she hopes will solve Germany's demographic problems or wage costs, that she will take responsibility for it on her own.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Commissioners, I would like to begin by warmly congratulating you on this proposal. I would like to congratulate you because it is a rather big step in the right direction. If we, as 28 Member States, want to belong to each other, then it is not acceptable that if a problem arises in one country and we actually have freedom of movement within the European Union, then on the one hand we cannot help one country sufficiently, because the resources are not enough, because coordination is not enough, or because a Member State simply does not want to. We must then find solutions to this, rather than putting the entire Schengen area at risk. I think that this proposal, for the first time, provides a substantive response to this, in which it is really worth thinking about intensively and building it up for the future. I also think it is very positive that in future we will have a preventive system for the early monitoring of migration movements, that the Agency should also play a supervisory role by monitoring the extent to which we have particular vulnerability at our borders or within our Member States in the area of security, and also that we can intervene directly when it is absolutely necessary to have our own technical equipment. , that there should also be a role in the coordination of proper repatriation, that, even if we have rejected asylum seekers, we have a common coordinated approach here and that not a single Member State should do so for the remaining 28. I think this programme as a whole is worth seeing. We really should deal with it. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: blue card question. " I appeal to you as a Member of the People's Party, Congresswoman. I'm not going to argue with what you said, I can see a lot of things in the same way. But do you think that the policies of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban, who is one of your ranks, fit into the policies of the People's Party, that he draws razor-bladed boundaries, in and out, and that anyone who does go in and out of the country is thrown into jail or thrown out of the country without even being able to appeal.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I think we have some who have a bit of problems. If I take Mr Zeman, the former leader of the Social Democrats in the Czech Republic, who has just joined a major congress with someone who advocates the burning of Muslims, I have to say soberly – we have difficulties in a few states.  I believe that we both do not agree with such steps and want to jointly enforce the European values we stand for. (Applause)

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Controlling our external borders is a pan-European task, but most of the time the states with external borders were on their own – there was a lack of solidarity. The refugee situation has revealed shortcomings and we are experiencing chaos and national selfishness. So now there is to be a pool of European border guards. In crisis situations, they should also take action, if necessary, without the consent of the Member State concerned. The legal basis must be clarified: what exactly would be the tasks and powers of officials, what rules apply to their actions and how coordination with national authorities takes place. Other points also require critical review: Frontex's deployments in third countries, assignment of tasks to external service providers and access to relevant databases. In addition to the current poor use of European information systems, it is worth remembering the tough debates we had about law enforcement access to Eurodac – and now Frontex. Strengthening European border management must not be the cover for European isolation. We must therefore strengthen the fundamental rights dimension of border management. A complaint mechanism for human rights violations and a strong role for the Agency in maritime rescue are the right elements. More importantly, comprehensive refugee registration and the participation of all states in the process of relocation should finally be put into practice, including the exchange of best practice in the reception and integration of refugees. The Member States must finally provide the means to improve the situation of refugees in third countries. Without these steps, increased border control will end up as a measure of foreclosure and costly, mass surveillance. This must not happen!

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: – After tourist visas for asylum seekers and visa-free travel through Turkey have been discussed, the time has come. Finally, a proposal to better guard the external borders. If Greece continues to do nothing, Europe will send border guards and take over the guard. Excellent news provided that sufficient manpower and equipment are effectively deployed. However, one more fundamental point: I learned that it is not the intention to send intercepted persons back and thus to organise pushbacks. I also learned that it is not the intention to limit the intake to any extent, let alone agree on a European maximum number.  Without registration centres in Greece, which apply such filtering, we will therefore have to take in every asylum seeker who has been intercepted and sets foot on European soil. Is that what we mean by border security? By the way, driving families into drowning with the promise of open borders for the sake of an indisputable right to asylum, is that morally defensible? The European Border Guard is a positive development, but still a little more political.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the presented proposal of a real federal Border and Coast Guard Agency presented by the Commission. This is, in my opinion, a good step forward towards a much needed common European asylum/immigration system. However, it is clear that we will have to have a close look into the details and discuss them, and make sure that fundamental rights are respected everywhere and always. We have been listening to the Council complaining about the current situation concerning border management. Now that we have the possibility to act, we cannot tolerate any lack of action or interinstitutional cooperation from the Member States’ side any more. The deadlock in the Council has to be overcome. We also know that some Member States fear that the mandate of the new border guard force will go as far as allowing the deployment of agents without the consent of the host country. I really believe that this requirement is essential if we want a workable and efficient European system in place. I am convinced at this time that Member States should transfer some responsibility to the EU level in order to increase the security of our population.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, the European Commission's proposal for a European Border Guard Corps concerns extremely serious issues, such as refugees, migration and the issue of the Union's external borders. It must therefore be ensured that the vital interests of the Member States in protecting its territorial integrity, as well as the fundamental rights of people, are respected. The Commission proposes to assign an enhanced role to this new European College in terms of cooperation between Member States and their non-Union neighbouring countries, including joint ventures on the territory of either those States or the Member States of the Union.  Very close attention is needed here so that the powers and action of the European Border Guard Corps are in line with the requirements of Article 21 of the Treaty on European Union on respect for the principles of international law. This applies in particular to cooperation with the authorities of third States outside the Union, which in practice show a lack of respect for international law. Moreover, when it comes to maritime borders, it is clear that the ultimate good is the protection of life, in accordance with the announcements in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union on respect for human rights. Therefore, control of the Union's external borders must be carried out in such a way that the tragedies of the mass drownings we have seen in recent years in the Mediterranean stop and continue to increase.  Finally, we must realise that the refugee and migration drama is not dealt with effectively at the borders of the Union, but in the countries of origin of the people. There must be peace and stability, and that is where the Union must help to create conditions of basic human life and to regain the balance that has been lost.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I must say that here europe is going over its head and sailing in the wrong direction. This will lead to even more supranationalism, which now seeks to deprive the Member States of their sovereignty in deciding and deciding on their border protection on a voluntary basis and contributing to external border protection.  This is explained by the recent emergence of an exceptional situation involving illegal migrants, weapons and terrorists crossing the Mediterranean. This should have been understood a long, long time ago.  We Sweden Democrats want to see intergovernmental cooperation with regard to our external border protection, where Frontex's main task will be to guard our external borders and the Member States should be involved on a voluntary basis, and nothing else.  If the Commission, backed by France and Germany, tries to do this, Then I believe that Brexit will soon be followed by Svexit.

name: Michał Marusik (ENF).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The idea of protecting the external borders was born in 2001. Fourteen years later, people come to Europe who wants and imports what they want – it makes us laugh enough and something needs to be done about it. And now we are being offered a three-step solution, where in the third stage there is the establishment of a completely new agency. If we do this, two billion people will come to this Europe in the next fifteen years, and then we will close the borders so that they cannot leave. And is this supposed to be europe's rescue from the influx of strangers? After all, we, as the European Union, are becoming the nail in Europe's coffin, and that is what we need to see – either we defend ourself, or let us dissolve and let each country defend itself, because that is why there are borders to protect them, not to ridicule and discredit them here. We really need to do something very quickly, not wait until it's too late, because time flows dramatically fast and plays against us.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, it made sense that the inefficient, limited operational capacity and unreliable Frontex would at some point be replaced by another force - the Coast Guard, the Border Guard, I do not know what they will call it - which will even intervene when it decides to do so. In other words, we will have a full delegation of national sovereignty. And I ask: what will be the mission of this force? Will it install check-points in Turkey? Will he control Turkey's borders so he doesn't send illegal immigrants to Greece? Is he going to arrest the illegal traffickers? He's going to apply rules of engagement, which means he's going to fire three shots in the air, and then, if the boat keeps moving, he's going to fire at the boat? If it doesn't do these things, why set it up? If he does, how will he differ from the armed forces of the countries?  I would also like to ask my compatriot, Commissioner Avramopoulos, in his former capacity as Greek Minister of Defence.
