What are you going to say, Mr. Avramopoule, to the levees of the Dry Army who, every day and under adverse conditions, guard our borders from Evros to Epirus and Macedonia? What are you going to say to the navy and coast guard lads who are sea-going to control the country's borders? What are you going to say to the eagles of the skies, our pilots who are constantly intercepting the Turks and, if they weren't cool, they would have shot down half the Turkish Air Force? What are you going to tell the police officers who sacrifice their lives to keep us safe? Finally, what will you say to the widows and orphans of these people? That we gave your men and fathers guinea pigs into the hands of the apprentice wizards of the European Union? (The President interrupts the speaker). (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Epitideios, I would like to ask you whether you do not see the rude contradiction between lamenting the helplessness of some Member States to deal with pressure at their external borders and to protest, in a loud voice, when the Commission takes an initiative precisely to ensure a European capacity for response.  And if you do not see the rude contradiction between making invocations to armed force or defence and not recognising that a European instrument regulated by European law is needed, by a law which is finally European and also subject to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which binds each of its Member States, including its own , Mr. Epitideios.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), answer with "blue card". Mr Aguilar, there is obviously no contradiction, because every state has an obligation to protect its borders and this can be done both for my country Greece and for all countries if the armed forces of these countries are allowed to guard their borders, as they know and as they are trained to do so. So there is no contradiction. We don't have to have a Coast Guard or European Border Patrol. This will be completely unreliable and completely out of the spirit of any mission.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: question posed by picking up the blue card to Michał Marusik. – Mr Marusik, is there such a great contradiction in what you said today? On the one hand, you want to protect Europe's borders and, on the other hand, you are criticising the European Union for this proposal, which is now moving in a good direction to finally protect Europe's borders in some meaningful and clear way.

name: Michał Marusik (ENF)
text: answer to the question asked by tomáš Zdechovski's blue card. – I do not criticize the will to save ourself from the misfortune that is coming to us, I only criticize sluggishness and inedibility, because this sluggishness and inedibility are catastrophic. If we wait another fifteen years, we will be trampled and lost here, and then we have to close the borders so as not to let these people go? That would just be ridiculous. We have to defend ourself now, because now we have a problem, not wait another dozen years.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for his excellent Twice as many illegal immigrants in one year as in five years before! Maintaining Schengen, as a consequence, of course, means securing the external borders as much as possible. Schengen is at the heart of what European citizens are experiencing as a united Europe. And of course we have a mess! The Commission has reacted, and I therefore support, together with the many colleagues of the European People's Party, the immediate introduction of the common border and coastguard by Frontex. It is the central precondition for finally organising uncontrolled immigration and, of course, this coastguard must have all the powers to intervene where a Member State fails! And we already have that today, so it is a logical consequence. I have no problem with an Austrian policeman providing assistance at the Greek external border, and I have no problem if an Italian policeman has to do this at the Hungarian border.  I believe that the pressure on uncooperative third countries must increase. I am glad that this package is also making progress in the area of repatriation. We cannot afford another summer like this in Europe!

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would remind colleagues that, in his opening statement, the Vice-President mentioned the ‘hot spots’ and the reception conditions for refugees. Last week the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) spent some four hours going through what is happening, and I note that the Commission today announced infringement proceedings and action against Member States who were not doing what they should have been doing. It was a very interesting debate which many people asked for. They asked for a European border and coast guard, and you today are at least embryonically delivering it. We have not seen the detail in writing, but if we do not have credibility on the ‘hot spots’ and reception centres – and Commissioner, you have admitted this and said it clearly – then there is no holistic and comprehensive approach to this.  So when colleagues call for an external border force, they must also call for a comprehensive view of this. Frontex, to me, is not yet institutionally ready for this big task, but we still have to protect the external border. That means, together, we have to have solidarity, as my colleagues have said, but also credibility. At the heart of this is credibility. You are taking infringement proceedings. Here in Parliament, we have to understand that we too have a job. If we want to have Schengen preserved and if we are to understand that 750 000 refugees have entered Greece recently, and that we therefore have to have a refugee policy – and I would add the rule of law to the complaints mechanism, Commissioner – then credibility must be at the heart of it. That means, colleagues, that the MFF, which is EUR 280 million, is not enough. Let us now work together to understand that the external border must be protected under the rule of law, that we must protect Schengen, but that we must also have the ‘hot spots’ and reception centres to have a credible refugee policy in order to look refugees in the eye and say to Member States: yes, we have the plans today, but they will fall apart unless we exhibit solidarity, credibility, funding and some determination to make all of this work together.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the plan to establish a European Border Guard is sneakily attempting from the back door to seize the sovereign right of the Member States of the European Union to guard their borders. Border guarding, especially for Greece, is a vital issue because of its proximity to Turkey but also Skopje and Albania, countries that have expressed doubts about our territorial integrity. Greece has no land border with Schengen countries. And yet, under the pretext of dealing with refugee flows, the European Border and Coast Guard now acquires the right to self-willing and autonomous action at the Greek border, even in the event of disagreement by the Greek government. Gentlemen of the Commission, Greece is a sovereign country, its borders are Greek and will continue to be protected by the Greeks and not by the European Border Guard, which will act on its own initiative, even assisting with rapid intervention teams of Bavarian, German and French police and border guards, as Mr Weber dreams.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, you say that the European Union will come to the aid of failing states, but that it is out of the question that it will encroach on their sovereignty, and you are sadly right. But I am one of those who still believe that external borders, because they are common, cannot be controlled, piece by piece, by each of the Member States taken separately. Most of them, some at least, will not. And that is why I want to welcome, however, among the proposals you have made, those which seem to me to be going in the right direction. First of all, I welcome the transformation of Frontex into a European coastguard and border guard agency. I welcome the introduction of a European right of intervention in the event of a Member State's manifest failure to do what other States legitimately expect of it. I welcome the establishment of a European operational reserve of at least 1,500 men and women who can be mobilised to help a state that is overwhelmed, and I welcome it all the more, Madam President, since I made this proposal myself when I was rapporteur of the Rabbit project and that at the time, neither the Commission nor the Member States wanted to examine it.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have so far heard a number of members speak of the fact that there are some Member States that have not been able to fulfil their obligation to protect and defend their external borders and that then refuse the help offered to them by the European Union.  Well, I speak as An Italian, Italy is one of those countries that has suffered the most from migratory flows, has suffered the difficulties of dealing with the protection of external borders. So, from this point of view, we welcome this legislative proposal. I agree that the external borders are common borders, so it is right to give a common answer to the protection of external borders, but there are a number of questions I have and several doubts raised by this legislative proposal.  Firstly, why the need for a new agency? Mr Avramopoulos, I would like you to give me an answer, why a new agency and not to strengthen, to use Frontex, the agency that already exists? What role will this agency play, of mere coordination? There is talk of strengthening cooperation and the exchange of information, what kind of information? Will yet another database be created? Well, I would like you to give us some clarification on these points.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Madam President, the Schengen area is an absolute failure, a sieve that allows millions of migrants to come, including hundreds of terrorists. The 130 deaths on 13 November in Paris were the victims. But the European Union does not want to face reality. Instead of condemning Schengen, it is fleeing forward trying to strengthen it.  I am resolutely opposed to the project she is proposing to us today. The EU has already taken control of their internal borders from states; it now wants to effectively take control of their external borders by giving an agency - super Frontex - the right to control them for them. However, I have no confidence in this type of European agency, which has already proved its inefficiency.  It is by regaining their sovereignty, not by selling it, that States will stop the migratory submersion.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Madam President, the upgrading of Frontex or the new military European Border Guard is intensifying the repression against the victims of the imperialist interventions of the EU, the USA and NATO and against the millions of migrant refugees, so that it can send them back to the hell of wars, at the same time as the imperialists are escalating these very wars. The number of refugees is increasing, Greece is being turned into a warehouse of impoverished people, fences are being erected in one country after another, border guarding is being passed on to The European Union without even the agreement of the Member States. For Greece, this means promoting co-management of the Aegean Sea with Turkey and challenging its sovereign rights under the seal of the European Union and NATO, amid competition and haggling between the urban classes and monopolistic groups. The European Union's smart borders are blinking to ensure hard work in the capital, to put downward pressure on all wages, to throw away all that is left over. The people will resist this barbarity and will fight to abolish Dublin, Schengen, Frontex, for human conditions for refugees and migrants, for immediate transfer to their countries of destination.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Madam President, my first reaction is to welcome this declaration and this proposal which provides valuable tools to improve the necessary management of external borders, especially through the new agency — a solidarity and at the same time bold development of Article 77(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. And it does so in a less complicated way than the full Community integration of border control would entail.  I support the effort of the capabilities and the role of the Frontex Agency until now, because only by better managing our external borders will we be able to guarantee more and better the freedom of internal transit. Cooperation and coordination with third States and agencies, the development of information systems or risk analyses are necessary, but, above all, rapid and urgent relief is important for those Member States suffering crises that pose a danger to effective border control.  I therefore support the subsidiary Community intervention mechanism and call on States not to see it as a limitation, but as a guarantee. I reiterate my commitment to those who come to Europe seeking asylum, but in the same way we must ensure the return with dignity of those who do not have the right to reside legally in our territory. The competencies in this field are articulated through the different return equipment. They are important, but always without forgetting the necessary safeguards and humanitarian and legal guarantees.  I therefore also support the proposed timely amendment of the Schengen Code, the impact of which should be studied in the light of the future smart border package.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Madam President, the current system of managing the Union's external borders has shown its limits. I have a few questions about that. The first relates to the Commission's response. What you are calling for is more Europe; I agree, and this is in line with the demands of Parliament, which has often spoken in favour of a European system of Community-based border guards. Having said that, sincerely, how are you going to share this option with the various Member States who complain about the porousness of borders, but at the same time refuse to work together?  Secondly, you are telling us that better border management must require strengthening the Frontex agency. Why not, to the limit? But having said that, what will be the exact outlines of Frontex Plus? Are we finally going to put an end to the hidden-hidden game of responsibilities that states and the agency are engaged in? Will the respective responsibilities be clearly defined, or will Frontex Plus remain the wrong practical instrument of the Member States? I will not go any further on this package of proposals, and I will focus on a few more general observations. Whether it is the fight against terrorism or migration policies, the current context calls for ever more reactions. Summits are multiplying, ministers are writing, the Commission is making announcements. But shouldn't we, paradoxically, take a step back? This accumulation of proposals risks losing sight of the importance of achieving a comprehensive, coordinated and intelligible policy.  I will mention two examples here. First of all, when I hear that, in order to compensate for the lack of implementation of the emergency relocation mechanisms, some of the responsibilities are being sought through the resettlement mechanism from Turkey, I can only remain dubious about the general direction and legibility. We are also working on a Commission proposal for a permanent relocation mechanism. However, emergency mechanisms are already struggling to be implemented, for about 200 people relocated. I think we should take the time to implement these provisions and how they are effective.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The Schengen system is used for the cross-border movement of people, goods and services in the common internal market. It also facilitates cross-border arms and drug trafficking, supports burglary crime and terrorism.  In the current migration crisis, Schengen is on the verge of collapse. The EU's response leads to the abandonment of national sovereignty rights. It would be better to call on the participating States to enforce the Schengen Agreement. States such as Greece that fail to make it have the opportunity to ask the EU for help.  We are happy to strengthen the new Frontex mandate to this end. We should release those who do not make it on their own and who forgo EU aid. The Schengen borders must then be shifted further inwards. At the same time, the German Federal Government must not be released from responsibility. Germany is the magnet that attracts the crowds of refugees. If German policy does not change, the other countries will not be relieved either.  German single-handedness, which no one in Europe is supported by, should not lead to a question of sovereignty.

name: Frank Engel (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it should be clear to any observer of the European scene that the Schengen area is in danger. With ever more partitions, new walls, and closing internal borders, we risk witnessing the end of an era that was felt as a liberation by a young generation of Europeans who could and can still move unhindered across the continent. The abolition of Schengen would be a disaster for this continent, both economically and humanly. I am not only talking about the border crossers who come to work in Luxembourg or Switzerland, or who cross the Swedish river every day to Denmark and vice versa, but also the millions of Europeans who take advantage every day of this opportunity and an entire economic system that operates on the basis of just in time deliveries and all that is attached to it; let us abolish it and we will struggle to regain a tiny bit of much-needed growth on this continent. But other than that, Commissioner, what the Commission is proposing today only makes sense. For our common borders, for the borders of Europe, for our external borders, what could be more logical that our borders should be protected by our troops, by our agency, by our logic of protecting these borders, wherever. An external border is a European border.  These measures are measures against the hypocrisy of all those who complain that external borders are never protected and who protest when we finally want to protect them.  I hope that, in the end, our borders will be protected by a European dynamic.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Hekk kif l-Unjoni Ewropea qed tiffa大大a l-akbar kriżi ta' refuġjati mit-Tieni Gwerra Dinjija lil hawn, l-Ewropa, iva, trid taħseb mill-ġdid il-politika tagħha dwar l-imġġjar tal-fruntieri u tressaq 'il quddiem pjanijiet ambizzjużi. F'dan il-mument, aktar minn qatt qabel, Aġenzija Ewropea għall-Immaniġġjar tal-Fruntieri għandha rwol importantissimu.  It-theddida fuq is-sigurtà kixfet numru ta' nuqqasijiet fl-Unjoni Ewropea u, kif il-pressjoni qed tiżdied, sew fuq il-fruntieri interni u esterni tagha, minflok ningħħdu flimkien, qed nispi大大aw ninfirdu aktar. Is-sistema kurrenti qiegħda taħt pressjoni qawwija, u koperazzjoni b'saħħitha fl-immaniġjarġ tal-fruntieri hija ne大essità. Qed naqblu li rridu nsaħħu l-fruntieri esterni tagħna, imma hemm ħafna mistoqsijiet li għadhom mhux imwieġba: mistoqsijiet dwar kif se tkun komposta, ir-rwol li se jkollha u l-funzjonijiet li se taqdi din l-Aġenzija. Li nsaħħu l-mandat ta' FRONTEX mhux biżżejjed. Irridu sistema li tħares fit-tul u li tindirizza d-differenzi li jeżistu bejn il-liġijiet u l-prattiikei tal-Istati Membri filwaqt li ta大大erta li ma tidħolx fil-kompetenzi nazzjonali tal-Istati Membri. Fl-istess waqt iżda, hemm bżonn ta' sistema b'saħħitha, ta' ħarsien tad-drittijiet fundamentali tal-bniedem, sistema ta' checks and balances, sistema li tassigura wkoll li EASO tkun inkluża, li niddefendu l-protezzjoni tad-data, li nipproteġu d-drittijiet fundamentali u li nassiguraw li d-dritt tamenti l mress jkun ink Irridu bilan大 bejn il-ħtiġijiet ta' sigurtà u d-drittijiet fundamentali. U għalhekk nittama li l-European Border and Coast Guard System jirnexxielha tilħaq dan il-bilan大. Għaliex jekk ma nilħqux il-bilan大 ġust allura, fl-opinjoni tiegħi, kwalunkwe sistema li noħorġu biha tkun kontroproduttiva. U nemmen li f'dan il-mument m'għandniex il-lussu li nagħmlu dan l-iżball. Jekk i nindirizzawx id-differenzi ta' bejnietna nkunu qed npoġġu l-valuri komuni tagħna f'periklu serju.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. I welcome the fact that the new security package is finally focusing on the protection of the external borders. After all, what the Hungarian Government has been saying since August has become clear: we cannot tackle the migration problem in Europe until we secure our external borders. This is also a condition for safeguarding the Schengen system. The protection of the Schengen borders is, of course, primarily the responsibility and responsibility of the Member States. We can maintain an area without internal borders as long as external border protection is in place. This conviction guided the decision of the Visegrad Four when they recommitted themselves to the protection of the external borders under the name friends of Schengen. Therefore, any proposal to strengthen the protection of the external borders, which will make it effective, will therefore be welcomed, which will facilitate prevention and reimbursement.  At the same time, of course, caution is needed when drawing up details around the sensitive issue of sovereignty in the Member States. Otherwise, it could lead to unsanned debates, which in the current crisis situation do not have time and no need, because the more concrete action at the external borders is needed as soon as possible.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal for a Border Control Coastguard is a common European assumption of responsibility, and that is why it is good for us, because it says that the borders are everyone's and not that nation's, this or that country's.  But I have some misgivings, Commissioner, not so much about the national sovereignty that would be undermined, not least because let us be frank about it, the national sovereignty so trumpeted today is an obstacle to those choices that Europe must make. But because I think immigration policy, as my colleagues from Moraes to the others have said, is one, it's comprehensive. And so, or you do it all together, but if you do only one part, it risks exploding contradictions, it is a policy that concerns security, control of those who enter Europe, certainty, knowledge of those who enter, but also reception, relocation, otherwise it happens that these contradictions pay a country, perhaps the one that has done the most , and not the others.  So I say to you, Commissioner, very frankly, that either we do all these operations together, with the time all due – those who say the times are right – otherwise something is wrong. This is the case with the hot spots that my country is doing and is also doing with great commitment, but they require all stages to go serious, otherwise here too, those who have done a lot risk being penalised and others who have done nothing allow themselves to be allowed to take the side of the judges.  One last thing, Dublin. It is clear to everyone that geography cannot decide where a refugee will go, it must be Europe's policy of solidarity. And on force let me say a word, beware of the use of force. We need responsibility, we need attention, caution. These are often people who have been violated and who do not need too much force, let us say, hard exercised.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we need better organised management of the security of our external European borders. If we want to tackle the problem of the refugee crisis and if we want to keep the Schengen solution, we have to overcome real barriers – the lack of cooperation among countries and the big deficit in data sharing. Because of terrorism we need more preventive actions, some of them on external smart borders, but this requires cooperation, common standards and procedures, and coordinated leadership in emergency cases even without Member States’ requests.  So the concept of strengthening Frontex by establishing a new model of its capability, a new role for the special groups of guards, the coast guard package and the new competences of the agency, is a very good idea and an opportunity – rather than a restriction – for national services. Member States’ independence and national security is not threatened by being more open to European coordination. It would be unreasonable to interpret it in this way. For the sake of our citizens’ security and safety we have to do this transparently, in agreement with Member States.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, exactly seven months have passed since the publication of the European Agenda on Immigration. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the Commissioner for the work he is doing.  Border management was one of the four pillars for better management of migration. This proposal is therefore not unexpected and, once it has been examined by the relevant committees, we will be able to give our opinion on a detailed analysis. From what has emerged so far, this new European Border And Coast Guard Service will ensure that the rules of integrated border management are respected. It will be able to act independently to prevent crisis situations and to intervene immediately on the external borders with urgent action on the ground to help the Member State. So, more Europe.  A real revolution, according to Commissioner Avramopoulos, but I believe that this revolution will only take place if this new service works with respect for the fundamental rights and freedoms of migrants and within a global strategy between the Service and the Member State and where the roles must be defined and shared between precisely these two institutions. I will end by saying that we will not accept any policy of closure in order to restore a fortress Europe with insurgable borders. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask Mrs Kyenge about what she said, whether she really believes that this solution is what europe needs. That is, if before you get to a business, let's say so competitive, is this the best solution? And then I also wanted to ask you whether perhaps the best solution is not the one that Donald Trump proposed in the United States not to let Muslims in again, in this case into the European Union.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I would have been happy to answer the question, but I am not answering the provocations.  (Applause)

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – I welcome the legislative package on European borders and the coast guard presented today by the European Commission. I believe that this is one of the key steps to tackle the migrant crisis. It is also an important step in stabilising the European Union. I like the metaphor of Gonzales Pons that all we want is a house with a door, not no door. The doors will be closed, too, but they will be closed to anyone who wants our home to be bad.  With this new integrated structure, the European Union accepts direct responsibility for the security of external borders. This is a huge change in our shared stay and I am immensely happy to see it. I am sorry to mention here Greece and the ruling Siriza, which, through its deliberate inefficiency in managing migration flows, is causing problems for the entire European Union. I am sorry that the Slovenian Government is not any more effective, and that the European Commission has not proposed this system since the spring.  I hope, at least, that the Member States will not now make it more difficult to set up a new system. If we really believe in the European project, we also need to take a step in the right direction, and the coastguard is.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome the Commission's proposal, which meets a requirement of efficiency, accountability and credibility. The establishment of an integrated European border management system is a no-brainer that we have postponed for too long. Today, I would like to ask two sets of questions. A first series on how it works itself. First, do we have a timetable with specific deadlines for each commitment? In order to establish a truly European border guard corps, the Agency must have its own staff and equipment and, in addition, the ability to react quickly in the event of a crisis. So who will train the guards? How long will it take to deploy a team in an emergency? If the agency takes the initiative to carry out an operation, will the Member States still have to consent or not? My second question is about Frontex's competency. How will coordination be provided for Frontex's risk analyses and Frontex's mandate for cooperation? I will conclude by stressing that this package must make it possible to really strengthen cooperation with third countries, with neighbouring countries. We are waiting for more information in this regard. And I reiterate my congratulations: this is the right direction, the right answer, namely a common European response.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: Madam President, I want to say hello to this package today. It is obvious that we have not managed our external borders well and by coordinating our policies we can certainly come to better protect our borders and therefore it is very important that we support this. However, I'd have one question, too. I want jurisdiction in this matter clearly degraded. Member States will have to transfer some of their responsibilities, but they need to retain sovereignty, as you yourself said in the introduction. But we understand that nothing will happen without the cooperation between the agency and the Member States. It is obvious that Frontex did not have sufficient capacity and that a European answer to this European question is needed. However, when it comes specifically to some countries, such as Croatia from which I come, such as Bulgaria and Romania, we want a European deal, we want to work together, but we are not part of Schengen yet. And so I want an answer to the question in your closing address, what can we do to speed up the entry of Croatia and these other countries into the Schengen area? Otherwise, we will have really second-rate and first-class countries within the European area. So, we support, but we want to accelerate our entry into Schengen an all-time, so please help answer this question.

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Of course, in view of the dilemma of 'either Schengen or strengthening the external border', it is better to strengthen the Union's external borders. It is therefore good that the European border guards will only be activated in emergency situations and when a country finds itself in a situation where it cannot deal with the problem on its own. However, as is clear from today's debate, the question arises as to whether community border guards will be activated at the request of a State or with the consent of a country threatened by major waves of migration, or will they be triggered by an autonomous Commission decision? The Commissioner said that the Commission, in cooperation with the Member State, will determine when the situation will require urgent intervention and that the agency's decisions will be binding on the Member State. I therefore ask you to answer the question: how will the Commission or the Agency react if there is neither a request nor an agreement from a Member State to mobilise the Community border guard in the event of an emergency? Will the Commission start intervening despite the lack of such consent and how will it do so in practice?

name: Alain Cadec (PPE).
text: Madam President, I welcome Parliament's adoption of the proposal for a pilot project on the coordination of the European Coast Guard, which I have been calling on the Commission since 2010. By publishing its draft, the Commission recognises the crucial value of this proposal. It is essential to coordinate the 316 authorities that perform coastguard functions in the European Union. The decommissioning of maritime security and immigration management is a prerequisite for effective joint interventions by fisheries control agencies, maritime security and Frontex. This proposal is important for maintaining Schengen, which is one of the pillars of the European Union. The European Union must take over the control of its external borders, if a Member State is unable or unable to do so. It goes without saying that this system cannot be put in place without the Member States giving up part of their sovereignty. Member States cannot complain about Europe's supposed inaction on immigration if they do not give it a mandate and cooperate with each other. The means of action are national, but coordination can only be European.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – We obviously need to know who comes to Europe and to control our common borders better. I therefore welcome the Commission package to upgrade Frontex’s role in managing external borders and enforcing solidarity. A Frontex Plus should support Member States registering migrants, take fingerprints, assist in relocation return, check biometric passports, update databases and share information. But both the control and coastguards should remain a national competence. Therefore, Commissioner Avramopoulos, we would welcome more clarification on your proposal. What about command and control – division of tasks between national border guards and European teams? Who would trigger the intervention of the joint European teams? EU action should always aim at Member States taking their responsibility in applying EU law, not at replacing Member States’ responsibility to build up the national capability, and not doing the gap-filling of inadequate implementation of EU law. To conclude, controlling our border better is not closing our border: it is a must to make sure that freedom of movement within Schengen will be ensured. It is a must to make sure that refugees are welcome in an ordered manner and for our security. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: question ("blue card"). "So you stand here again, the representatives from Sweden who have completely forgotten your voters' mandate to represent Sweden.  You are not here to represent Europe, but your homeland. I have to say I am glad that Mrs Wikström's party has now changed its name from the Liberal Party to the Liberals, for the people, you certainly do not represent that. You stopped listening to them a long time ago.  My question to you, Mrs Bildt: do you think we need to go deeper into cooperation in which europe is to decide more and more about our policy on our border protection? Do you not think that this is something that Sweden should decide first and foremost with regard to our country?

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: answer ("blue card"). I regret that my colleague from the Sweden Democrats does not listen to what I said, that it is self-determination that applies to the police and border control. However, we need better and deeper cooperation to solve the common problems that we have in dealing with the influx of refugees, to provide security for our citizens and to combat terrorism and to ensure that the free movement of Schengen persists. Unfortunately, my colleagues just want to close the border and raise the walls. Sweden alone should never be able to cope with the flow of refugees and fight terrorism, and needs freedom of movement.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I was addressed in the most aggressive way by this colleague and I simply do not accept the way that he is behaving in this House. He could have taken a blue card from me but he did not dare to. He is a coward, literally speaking.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Dear Mr Avramopoulus, Mr Timmermans, who may hear me or hear me from the record, I am always your great critic. But there are two sides to the criticism, a) it's resolute, b) it's factual. Mr. Avramopoulus, I have always criticized you for your reaction being relatively slow. You Greek, you have had a lot of time for a lot of things, but Today I must commend you, because this step that you have taken and this proposal that you have put forward is a step in a good direction. Esteban González Pons said here at the beginning that if anyone wants to come to us, they have to use the door. And we all have doors at home. And I want to warn everyone that we have a dog next to the door, and that if someone doesn't use the door but uses the window, we use our dog. And that's your suggestion, and congratulations on that proposal, and thank you for it.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate the European Commission on what seems to be another courageous proposal. Europe's response to this refugee crisis has been slow and below what is needed. Very much the council's fault. The consequences of this inaction were many, even tragic, but one of the most obvious was to have called into question one of the greatest successes of European construction: the Schengen area. I have said from the outset that we had to respond to the humanitarian emergency and find solutions to the problems in the background. We need tools to deal with crises, but also to better ensure the integrity of the Schengen area. And we must not forget that all this is based on mutual trust. All those who ignore European solidarity and express nationalist tics are condemned to failure, but also to all those who think that the solution is to ignore the involvement of the Member States. Mutual trust is therefore what we need, because we need a Union capable of responding to the challenges. With pragmatism and a willingness to act.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I very much appreciated the speeches by Commissioners Timmermans and Avramopoulos, and the initiatives that have been presented on the issue of the control of external borders and returns, on which a great deal of credibility is at stake for Europe as a whole.  Indeed, it is unacceptable that in 2013, out of the 425 000 migrants expelled, only 167 000, or less than 40%, were actually repatriated as evidence of the failure of the current system, which is based almost exclusively on bilateral agreements between Member States and the states of departure of migratory flows.  I therefore welcome the strengthening of the functions of this new agency, the creation of a special return office with specialised officials who can support the Member States, which are under great migratory pressure. I hope that the European Council will speak the same language, which the Commission and Parliament have spoken at the moment, which has not actually happened on time.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, I thank you very much for introducing the protection of the common external border. It is what we have been calling for for several months, so I must say finally! My questions point to concrete measures, I follow up on my colleague Gabriel and ask: What will be the relationship of this guard with Frontex? Do you think that the 1,500 border guards will be sufficient to ensure, in addition to border protection, the return policy you mentioned? So the aufficiency of these capacities is a question. And then the question that has been asked here several times: Who will have the right to decide if that member country does not want to accept this assistance? Then I say unequivocally, every country that forms the external borders of the European Union must be aware of this responsibility, and in this case I agree with the possibility of a re-vote.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, a few years ago, through a report which I was the author of, this Parliament called for the formation of a European coastguard function, but the Member States put it outside the European Maritime Security Strategy, hostageto an obsolete view of national sovereignty. Now, the creation of a European coast guard for the transformation of Frontex is being announced, but the experience of our navies in this matter is still not articulated and Frontex has not even strengthened sufficiently as the plan to open the hot spots had foreseen. Commissioner, I am concerned that all this is being driven by the desire to prevent refugees and migrants from entering and to return people who are asking for protection. If this package of measures is aimed at strengthening European cooperation, it must assert the Union's responsibilities in the protection of human rights, including refugees and migrants, which no security measure, in particular in the field of counterterrorism, justifies violating.  We must have the historical responsibility to manage this crisis by doing what member states have refused and which could effectively significantly improve the strengthening of borders, namely the opening of legal and safe avenues to ... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, I strongly support the Commission's intention to strengthen Frontex, as we must protect our external borders. This initiative is welcome and I believe that we must all support the strengthening of our external borders, control and everything the Commission proposes. However, today I must point out a very unpleasant fact that is happening among our Member States and on the border line between the Republic of Slovenia and the Republic of Croatia. The Slovenian government's intention to build a razor wire, a wire fence from the Mura to the sea is really unacceptable. I am pleased that many Citizens of Slovenia and croatian citizens jointly want to oppose such an initiative.  It is amazing that such a wire fence wants to be erected where migrants practically cannot and will not even pass, and this is primarily in the area of Istria and in the area of Gorski Kotar. I ask you to help and to enable citizens to live more peacefully and safely.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – This reaction from the European Union is shameful. In fact, it is quite illustrative of its nature. You do not want to save and take in immigrants, including refugees, of course! They just worry about erecting more barriers and walls. So what is the difference between this policy and Orban's?  This proposal only wants the strengthening of expulsion mechanisms, wants Frontex to access data on migrants more quickly and to more quickly expel them, or to put its agents everywhere, even without permission from Member States, to take corrective action, whatever that is. On the other hand, it removes more of the Member States from this share of sovereignty and the possibility of managing their borders more humanitarianly. It is this policy and this complex of supremacy of the European Union that makes xenophobia and racism grow. Social integration is the best weapon to fight them.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – This package of measures, which we have listened to in our presentation today, is certainly a step in the right direction and, given the hesitancy of recent months, certainly means more hope in securing the so-called external borders. In particular, I consider it important that this new agency, whatever it may be, will have sufficient resources, especially to be able to influence and direct refugee flows, that there will indeed be cooperation between Member States, and above all, if this action is, of course, effective, will also contribute to something very important: that is, in fact, the purpose of securing external borders will be important that we do not set internal borders. And if we are to protect this external part well and effectively, without, of course, encroasing on human rights, the Member States that are now erecting fences, walls, barriers can also eliminate them.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The Schengen system is one of the few real achievements of the European Union, and the border between the countries within the system has become freely interoperable. At the same time, Schengen is one of the European Union's greatest failures. As the Vice-President said, 1.5 million migrants have arrived at the Schengen borders this year, which should have been protected, and he is talking – finally wanting to move – about stopping dangerous elements at the external border. It is not only dangerous elements that need to be stopped, but also millions of economic migrants. On the liberal side, the incredible wording is that if a country defends its own national and Schengen borders, it is national egotism, and they want to deny nation states the right to protect their borders, thus projecting the image of a 'United States of Europe', which we will prevent.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the inability of overwhelmed frontline Member States to control the unprecedented flows of migrants themselves and consequently to safeguard the array of open internal borders clearly points to the design shortcomings of Schengen’s external border control system. Although the Schengen Borders Code recommends Member States to request help from the EU in case of serious deficiencies, the agency foreseen to provide such help was conceived to be a little more than a paper tiger, as has been pointed out a few times. This was because Member States were too reluctant to give Frontex the actual power that could have allowed it to step in when a national government was not able to fulfil its control duties. The situation today in Europe calls for a strengthened border control agency that can live up to its name: one that can protect frontiers, can ensure the orderly identification and registration of migrants and that can provide the support they need.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (
text: S&D). Madam President, I hear many colleagues wondering whether what the Commission is proposing is too much. Is it possible to have a European country that believes that there are no European borders? Yes, it was my country, the first six months, because of the idealism of our ministers. Is it possible to have a country that does not have the administrative capacity to implement its commitments? Yes, when the new minister mobilized the state, he discovered that our services could not, despite the self-sacrifice of our people, carry out our commitments. Is it possible that there is a country that does not know whether it has the resources to implement its commitments? Yes, and it was only in November that we asked for the activation of the European Civil Protection Mechanism, for tents, blankets, toilets.  We can't go through this again. 2016 should be the time to implement the Permanent Relocation Mechanism. The time we will offer decent accommodation to all refugees coming to Europe. This is the time when we will have a complete and complete record of all those entering the Union. We must do this in order to reduce the distance between reasons and works.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of Parliament, let me start by expressing my thanks for your contribution to this debate today, for your support and also for your concerns and worries that we have shared together here. I can tell you that I took note of what was said, but let me first say this: what we have presented here today is not about entirely closing or opening borders, because neither is realistic. So on the points you have made, the question of not going far enough, today you must all admit that it is a very important step forward. This is a gradual process as Europe moves forward. Some of you referred to the fact that rules need to be better enforced. I fully agree with you – be it the Schengen border code or asylum legislation, this Commission, I can tell you, does its job in fully enforcing EU law. We are launching infringement proceedings wherever it is necessary, but sometimes rules also need to be adapted to a new reality. That does not mean, as I said during my introductory remarks, that we substitute Member States’ responsibilities. I want to be clear on that. We do not touch Member States’ sovereignty.  What we have presented today has a strong preventive and supportive role to all Member States with external borders. The next pressure might be in a totally different part of Europe’s borders, so we must be well prepared. I think that you share with me the point of view that when the very first migratory refugee flows approached the European borders we were all caught by surprise – Member States and the European Union. The European Union did not have a migration policy, it was something fragmented, scattered around within the Commission, but now thanks to your support we have adopted the European Agenda on Migration and have taken many other decisions together: the relocation and resettlement scheme and the action plan against smugglers.  So we have made a step forward, but today we are moving ahead in a bold way. Let us be realistic and honest. The current crisis shows one thing, which is that no Member State can manage this complex situation alone and our solidarity measures have not brought the necessary support either. This is why this agency’s staffing capacities and budget will be considerably reinforced.  Let me also be clear about protection – some of you raised the point, including Ms Keller – and say that we are not creating a fortress Europe. The rights of people seeking international protection will never be put into question. We have a responsibility to offer protection to those in need and we will continue to do so.  That is why it is so crucial to see this proposal as part of a comprehensive strategy which started, as I said before, with the adoption of the European Agenda on Migration, continued with many other initiatives – the implementation measures such as relocation mechanisms and the hotspots – and will be continued with measures allowing resettlement and legal migration. That implementation and relocation mechanism remains a priority for us although it has not worked properly so far, for reasons you know as well as I do. All Member States must be part of the relocation scheme, and I would ask you to put pressure on your countries to do more, because if they all respond you will see spectacularly altered results on this.  That is also why we have presented a recommendation for humanitarian admission for Turkey, to offer legal and safe ways for people seeking protection to come to Europe. Je voudrais m'adresser à M. Deprez. Je suis vraiment honoré de votre soutien à cette proposition, soyez sûr que nous sommes conscients de votre initiative qui date déjà de quelques années. Vous avez également raison lorsque vous dites que, si cette agence avait existé aujourd'hui, nous aurions pu éviter que la pression migratoire ne se transforme en crise; tel est l'objectif pour l'avenir.  En ce qui concerne ce que vous venez de dire, Monsieur Engel, vous avez utilisé le terme approprié: notre proposition est avant tout logique. C'est la conséquence logique du fait que nous avons des frontières communes européennes et que notre première préoccupation est de préserver la libre circulation de nos citoyens, avec tous ses bienfaits, dans la zone Schengen.  Puisque certains députés m'ont posé quelques questions en grec, permettez-moi de leur répondre dans la même langue. Mr President, the MEPs who have raised the questions before are first and for all experienced lawyers and experienced politicians. I believe they will agree with me that nothing, but absolutely nothing, can happen in a Member State without its consent. No one can force him to cooperate with a third country if he does not wish to do so. This is clear from the legislative proposal we have put forward. The sovereignty of the Member States is not affected.  They will also agree with me that without genuine solidarity no Member State alone can cope with the challenges, let alone the greatest challenges that are certain to arise in the future. They will also agree, I hope, that it was time for something to finally change.  As far as Greece is concerned, the Agency we will set up in the future will substantially strengthen its capacity to prevent crises like today's and to manage its borders which are also legally identical to those of the European ones. There are two main objectives: to strengthen the Member States on the so-called 'front line' and, of course, to ensure the principle of free movement, for all citizens without exception, within the limits of the Schengen area. I want to make it clear that we do not have others guarding the Greek border, because the Greek borders are also European. Consequently, a European Agency, part of which, of course, Greece is, will strengthen the protection of the country's external borders and help to better organise migration flows, which will not stop. Let us not be naïve, nor over-optimistic. I believe that in the future they will increase. That is why we must, overall, be better organised. The conditions for the Agency's participation in each country presuppose the existence of an agreement between the country and the Agency. I think we all have to benefit from such a development, and in particular those countries that have the problem because of both their geographical and geopolitical positions. This initiative we have taken is on the basis of even more Europe and aims at greater security for Europe and a more effective functioning of our entire strategy and policy for managing refugee and migration flows.  I believe that, overall, Parliament, as it has done so far, will help us and support us. I would like to stress that nothing could have been achieved by our collective effort to deal with this situation in recent times if the European Parliament had not shown sensitivity, taken initiatives and consciously supported European vision policies. Today, I believe you agree with me that Europe is taking another bold step forward on its path towards political integration.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. – With the proposal for a European border and coast guard, Europe is finally accelerating its approach to the refugee crisis. This is not premature, because there are currently large gaps in the control of external borders. Greece, in particular, is putting too much stitches, threatening to temporarily close its internal borders.  Frontex must now be developed into an effective, common border and coast guard with more clout, more resources and a permanent corps of 1500 border guards. This new border agency must intervene where control of the external border in a Member State is inadequate. The Agency must also play a much more active role in return policy. We cannot leave the burden and responsibility solely to the border Member States: we must control our common external borders together.  The Interior Ministers must now move quickly on the concrete roll-out of this proposal. We must finally understand that Europe is not the problem, but part of the solution. For more than a decade, the number of people working on the development of a European border guard has been lost and the problems have only grown. A strong EU must tackle the refugee crisis together and not fail to provide the necessary resources.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the Commission's proposal. Securing the EU's external border is a pan-European task. I believe that this proposal is a move in the right direction. Frontex must become a genuine border management agency. Securing the EU's external border must not depend on whether an individual EU country is willing or able to do so. We have a humanitarian obligation to provide protection for people fleeing war and persecution. However, this can only be done if we have real control over the EU's external border.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – The European Commission's proposal on the European Border and Coast Guard package has its pros and cons. The proposal aims to increase Frontex's funding and capacity and restructure the agency in the European Border and Coast Guard in question.  This is a good idea because a major problem of the European Union is the lack of well-guarded external borders through which hundreds of thousands of illegal refugees pass through. Neither the Dublin Agreement nor inadequate measures to redistribtribate immigrants will work until new immigrants are constantly coming to the European Union. Separately, a large proportion of immigrants coming to the EU are not registered by the border services of member states, who miss them freely to cross the border and leave the country. In itself, this is a protest against the Dublin Agreement, and the low number of redistributed immigrants also shows the reluctance of member states to implement the arrangements.  It is not appropriate to impose by force measures which are incompatible with the interests of the Members. Another is the issue that member states will have to give up their sovereign right and obligation to defend their own borders. The new European Border and Coast Guard should not seize from the sovereignty of states, but should support and complement the capacity of member states' border services.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I have repeatedly spoken in favour of strengthening the External Borders of the European Union. I called for this in the European Parliament when words were flowing from Brussels and from some capitals about the need to open borders to a wave of refugees, in which, as we all know today, not only economic migrants but also terrorists. I have no doubt that Frontex should be strengthened. Not only financially. All Member States should also support the schengen frontline countries most burdened by the need to block the uncontrolled wave of refugees.  I voted in favour of increasing funding for Frontex. The Polish Border Guard helps its colleagues in Hungary. More needs to be done, of course. Some sensible proposals have been put forward today by the Commissioners. However, I do not agree that, as a result of the Schengen crisis, the establishment of a federalised service is the solution. Safe and tight borders are essential for Europe. However, we cannot repeat with every crisis that the only solution is 'more Europe' and the transfer of responsibilities to the European level. The proposal to provide for the possibility of deploying services to the territory of a Member State against his will only on the basis of decisions taken at official level is, in my view, inadmissible.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. – We welcome the proposal put forward today by the Commission on the European Coast and Border Guard which recognises the need to make the management of the external borders of the Schengen area a European responsibility. The Socialists have always advocated a European approach in this area, because no country can be held alone responsible for what cannot be regarded as a mere national border but a common and European border. However, this new proposal must be supplemented by the revision of the Dublin Regulation and the establishment of a permanent and binding refugee-sharing mechanism based on real solidarity between Member States and an equitable and fair sharing of the associated burdens of managing the refugee crisis. If this is not done, we run the risk of the whole system collapsing and the EU's external borders becoming large refugee camps.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – Extraordinary migration crisis with no end in sight requires extraordinary measures on European level. I welcome the initiative by the European Commission to refurbish Frontex into a new agency, the European Border and Coast Guard with a political mandate, technical means and an independent budget to conduct rescue operations, but also assist in sending back people from the borders. Frontex with its very limited mandate has been able to meet the challenges of the current situation. Without any real political commitment and binding contribution from the Member States, the EU will not be able to effectively protect its borders. I am sure that the foreseen permanent staff of around 1000 persons, plus additional 1500 deployable ones and a budget more than double of the one Frontex will help to transform Frontex into a real border and coast guard agency. I urge the Member States to support this plan. Although EU is composed of 28 sovereign Member States with their national borders, their external borders are in fact the EU common that need to be safeguarded for the common good and security of the EU as a whole.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. – We welcome the proposal put forward today by the Commission on the European Coast and Border Guard which recognises the need to make the management of the external borders of the Schengen area a European responsibility. The Socialists have always advocated a European approach in this area, because no country can be held alone responsible for what cannot be regarded as a mere national border but a common and European border. However, this new proposal must be supplemented by the revision of the Dublin Regulation and the establishment of a permanent and binding refugee-sharing mechanism based on real solidarity between Member States and an equitable and fair sharing of the associated burdens of managing the refugee crisis. If this is not done, we run the risk of the whole system collapsing and the EU's external borders becoming large refugee camps.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. I believe that the proposal presented today by the European Commission adequately reflects the need to protect the free movement of our citizens, through renewed efficiency in the management of our external borders. It was an act due above all to countries that, like Italy, find themselves forced to face migratory pressure of epochal proportions. The establishment of a European border guard will ensure coordination, the implications of which will affect the level of security of our citizens. I welcome the desire to launch a European Return Office, which I hope will work properly to repatriate third-country nationals, whose stay within our borders is irregular. If we want to manage the problem of migration properly at last, we must, of course, systematically distinguish between those who are entitled to refugee status and economic migrants. I hope that this proposal will not be confused with an attempt to dismiss the States of their sovereignty but, rather, as a concrete demonstration of burden-sharing at Community level.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. – The problems of the arrival of refugees and terrorist attacks have made it clear that national solutions, the refusal to cooperate and the transfer of responsibility will only bring trouble to the European community. We also see that if we are to maintain the European acquis of free movement, the Schengen area, we must also assume common responsibility and guarantees for the protection of borders. I therefore welcome and consider the Commission's proposal to establish a single European border guard and coast guard to be an important step forward. I am convinced that this is the only way to achieve humane but effective control of those arriving in the Union at the EU's external borders.  I find it outrageous that there are Member States who want to push this plan in order to maintain poorly understood national autonomy, thereby jeopardised the security of other Member States and EU citizens. It is particularly retent that one of them is the Hungarian Government, which until now has recited the need for stronger protection of the external borders and the guarantee of security. Once again, it has become clear that the Orban government is doing everything it can to prevent the European institutions from being effective and united in their action on asylum, against terrorism and in defence of EU borders, so that it can then point the finger at 'Brussels' as the cause of the problems in a lying way.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - The only realistic way to strengthen the protection of the European Union's external borders is the creation of a single European border guard. In the face of the wave of refugees and the security crisis, there has been growing talk of the need to strengthen controls at the external borders of the European Union. At the same time, for example, stronger controls at the external borders do not mean physically blocking people on poor boats in the Mediterranean and putting their lives at risk. The only area where European border protection can and must be strengthened is the exchange of information on the identification of criminals and common procedures in all countries at the EU's external borders. Therefore, the creation of a single European border guard is the only effective measure to strengthen controls at the EU's external borders.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – Europe has taken the first strong step towards more security. The EC presented its proposals for changes to the security of the EU's external borders, according to which a European Border and Coast Guard will be established. It will be able to effectively assume, together with the national authorities, the security of the Union's land and sea borders. The more important proposals are to provide a more serious budget and staff, but also more rights. The mandate of the Agency will enable it to carry out its own border operations, as well as a standard by which, in the event of a crisis, it can be deployed in less than 3 days in the affected area. After 1.5 million euro entered the EU in the first 10 months of 2015 alone, illegal immigrants, these measures were necessary. Only in this way can we preserve the unity of the EU and stop the return of internal borders. Without secure external borders, both Schengen and free movement within the Union are in serious danger. For Bulgaria, the proposal is important because it means an assessment of the state of our borders at all times and specific assistance with people and equipment in the event of a crisis. The proposal is one of the solutions to the problem of migration. The EP should discuss and adopt it as soon as possible.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – The current migration crisis and terrorist threat over Europe show that the European Union's external borders need to be further strengthened to ensure the security of our citizens. I welcome the European Commission's proposal for a European Border Service as a necessary first step in this regard, but in itself it will not solve the problems.  The introduction of systematic controls on all European citizens crossing the external Schengen and European borders is of paramount importance. In order for it to be effective, it is necessary to connect information systems for documents and people – thus a check will cover the full range of threats. This also means member states exchanging information on time and sharing it through these systems, something that has unfortunately not been done until recently.  Europe must also cooperate with its neighbours. Our borders can only be protected when we have good operational cooperation with countries such as Turkey so that together we can fight against existing dangers.  Last but not least, the European Border Office must ensure security not only in the Schengen area, but at all external borders, including the Bulgarian one. At the same time, however, this should not be at the expense of national sovereignty.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. "It was time, but this time Europe is acting coherently. Since the time we decided to abolish internal borders in order to promote the free movement of citizens, European surveillance of external borders had to be put in place. However, I remain sceptical or even concerned about the actual application of these measures.  Once again, since the EU budget has reached its limits, we are dependent on the Member States. However, despite their announcements, they did not provide Frontex with the experts promised during the latest migration package. In addition, the equipment dedicated to this body of European agents must also be co-financed by the Member States; we can therefore envisage the worst, like the Madad fund.  There is an urgent need to get out of the budget tinkering. The revision of the multi-year financial framework and the structure of own resources that have become obsolete can be the way out of the impasse. This revision must be based on this simple principle: Community action must be financed from the Community budget.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βοζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνιδη (
text: PPE), in writing. – In our effort to tackle the uncontrolled refugee crisis, which has far outpaced us, it is necessary to seek immediate and effective solutions that contribute with humanity, solidarity and respect both to better management of the refugee issue and to improving the INTERNAL SECURITY of the EU. In this fight, it is imperative to safeguard the Schengen area, which is part of the refugee solution. The proposal for a comprehensive system for managing the EU's external borders, with the creation of a European Border and Coast Guard, is a positive step in defending the interests of the Union, the functioning of which it is necessary for the Member States to contribute with their cooperation. Over the past 11 months, more than 1,565,000 refugees and migrants have headed for Europe, and this trend is expected to continue. My country, Greece, is among the Member States most affected by this unprecedented flow, as it is estimated that more than 790,000 third-country nationals have been welcomed by sea in recent times. Such a service will proactively and repressively help countries, such as Greece, to ensure better operational coordination between Member States and to identify weaknesses in border guarding in a timely manner.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – There is no doubt that the european Union's external borders need to be better protected. The European Union must not be defenceless against the rising tide of immigrants, some of whom have no grounds for obtaining permission to stay in Europe. The problem is that today the borders of some countries, such as Greece and the Balkan countries, are holey. These countries should urgently receive assistance from the European Union. I therefore consider it appropriate to transform Frontex into a European Border and Coast Guard Agency. However, this agency cannot count only on the support of individual EU countries. It must have real instruments of action, which needs to be expanded by at least 2 000 people and equipped with its own specialised equipment, such as observation aircraft, vehicles, equipment for identifying persons. I strongly emphasise this fact that there should not be another EU institution whose objectives are right, but that it does not have a real capacity to function effectively. Let us therefore create a European Border and Coast Guard Agency as a real, rapid and effective instrument for protecting the European Union's external borders.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the council and Commission's statements on the outcome of COP 21 (2015/2960 (RSP)).

name: Camille Gira
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Commissioner, let me first apologise to the Luxembourg Environment Minister, Mrs Dieschbourg, who would have liked to be with you, but who is already in Brussels for the preparation of tomorrow's Environment Council. Ladies and gentlemen, even three days after the end of COP 21, which I had the chance to attend, together with our Minister of the Environment, I find it difficult to fully realize the miracle of Paris. I think you agree with me that this agreement is indeed a historic achievement. This is the first time that we have adopted a universal climate agreement that contains the architecture necessary to keep global warming well below 2 degrees Celsius and in which all the countries of the world are committed to doing their part. Such an agreement is the result of a political determination hitherto unmatched to tackle the challenge of climate change. I would like to welcome here the exceptional commitment of the French Presidency of the Conference of the Parties. Throughout the year, it has pushed the Climate Agenda in all for a, and it is with great patience, impeccable impartiality and great control of the situation during the COP that it has managed to present an agreement which not only gathers consensus, but is, moreover, ambitious, sustainable, dynamic and legally binding. Of course, the French Presidency was able to carry out its work thanks to the willingness of the parties to move forward. The European Union and its Member States have always led the way in adopting and defending an ambitious position. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the European Parliament for its own commitment and support in this area, calling for an ambitious agreement to phase out global CO2 emissions by 2050 or shortly thereafter. Other major emitters, such as China, India and the United States, have also shown a great willingness to bring the agreement to fruition, as have, of course, countless non-governmental actors, such as the cities and municipalities of part of the economic world and, of course, NGOs. I must also highlight the performance of the European Union in Paris. We spoke with one voice, from start to finish, and this has made us an indispensable partner in the negotiations. Several central features of the agreement, such as the ambition mechanism, have been developed from concepts put forward by the European Union. Our influence has been real because we have been able to forge new alliances, such as the one behind the High Coalition Ambition, because we have been able to present compromise solutions linking sometimes very divergent positions. Although the agreement is still very recent and further analysis needs to be developed, I would like to briefly communicate the key points. First, it was decided in Paris that global warming should be kept well below 2 degrees and that efforts should be made to limit it to 1.5 degrees. The Paris Agreement specifies that this implies that peak emissions must occur as quickly as possible and that climate neutrality must be achieved in the second half of this century.  Secondly, the Paris Agreement specifies that national emission reduction contributions - the INDCs - will be at the heart of this agreement. All parties will have to highlight their contributions, the vast majority have already done so, and they will have to maintain it by raising it every 5 years. Thirdly, the Paris Agreement contains elements of solidarity that are very important for developing countries, and especially for the poorest and most vulnerable among them, on adaptation, loss and damage, capacity building and, of course, also financing. On financing, we are committed as developed countries to establish a concrete roadmap to reach $100 billion by 2020. In addition, a new, more ambitious target must be set by 2025 at the latest.  Finally, agreement was reached in Paris on a transparency framework that will create the necessary confidence that all countries will live up to their commitments. The Paris agreement, as you can see, is therefore taking a big step forward. This is indeed the first global climate agreement, sending a very strong signal to all non-governmental actors, be they local authorities, businesses or civil society, which I welcome the growing commitment to - a signal that this transformation to a low-emissions economy is becoming a necessity Must. But let us not forget that the Paris Agreement is only a framework that has yet to be defined and clarified on several points. So there is still a lot of work to be done. That is the task we will have to tackle in the coming months and years, when the agreement comes into force in 2020.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this is a historic moment. Thanks, to a great extent, to the efforts of the European Union, the world has its first ever universal, legally binding global climate deal. This is a new chapter in global climate governance as we move from action by few to action by all. The Paris Agreement is important on many levels: first of all, in order to be efficient in our fight against climate change. But more generally, the deal reached over the weekend is a major win for the whole international community. It shows that multilateralism can still work when faced with a truly global challenge. This is a vital lesson for the years ahead of us.  Europe has gone through turbulent times over the last few years. Today, let me assure you of one thing: we should all be proud of Europe. Paris is the culmination of Europe’s efforts for a global agreement on climate change. After many years of relentless efforts, we got a deal. And not just any deal: the Paris Agreement is ambitious and balanced, and it includes our key objectives. I would like to thank the Members of the European Parliament delegation to COP21 – led by delegation Chair Giovanni La Via and Vice-Chair Matthias Groote – for their invaluable support throughout the Conference. I must also pay tribute to the French Presidency of COP21, and the remarkable way in which they managed a very delicate and challenging process. The cooperation between Member States, ministers, the European Parliament delegation and my fellow Commissioners was excellent throughout the negotiations. The European Union spoke always with a single voice under the excellent steering of the Luxembourg Presidency. When we do so, we succeed. We were instrumental as ambitious bridge builders, and we were instrumental in building a broad coalition of developed and developing countries in favour of high ambition – the High Ambition Coalition – which was critical in securing the global deal. All of a sudden, the debate was not about developed versus developing, as it was in Copenhagen. It was about the willing versus the unwilling. The result in Paris will decisively accelerate the transition from fossil to clean fuels. This trend is now irreversible.
