When I came to this House last October on the occasion of the debate on the Pargneaux report, I made it clear that Paris had to deliver an ambitious, robust and legally binding global agreement which puts the world on track to limit global warming to below 2°C. I set out then my three ‘essentials’ for a successful outcome: first, a long-term goal; second, a robust review cycle with the flexibility to strengthen ambition over time; and third, strong transparency and accountability rules. After two weeks of intense and sometimes exhausting negotiations, the Paris Agreement delivers on all these key essentials.  For the first time ever in a legal agreement, we reaffirmed our long-term goal to prevent the adverse effects of climate change. Governments agreed to the goal of keeping the increase in global average temperature to ‘well below’ 2°C above pre-industrial levels. The Commission also welcomes the recognition in the agreement of the need to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5°C, a point which was crucial for many of our partners in our progressive alliance. The qualitative long-term goal aims for emissions to peak as soon as possible, with rapid reductions thereafter, towards achieving a balance between anthropogenic emissions by sources and removal by sinks of greenhouse gases in the second half of the century. The direction of travel has been set. The agreement sends a clear signal to investors, businesses and policy makers that the global transition to clean energy is here to stay. As I said during the Conference, you can have the best long-term target in the world, but without a robust revision mechanism raising the level of ambition over time, you will never achieve it. That is why the European Union has always insisted on a five-year review cycle. In Paris, we agreed to come back every five years, to take stock, to look at the latest science, and to ramp up our commitments accordingly. We also fought hard for strong transparency and accountability rules. We know these are the foundations of a credible international regime. Without multilaterally agreed rules, there will be no trust or confidence that countries will deliver on their commitments. Under the Paris Agreement, countries have a legally binding obligation to pursue domestic mitigation measures with a view to achieving their contributions.  An enhanced transparency and accountability system is also set up, including the submission by all countries, every two years, of greenhouse gas inventories, an expert review and a facilitative, multilateral consideration of progress. These elements fully correspond with the European Union’s priorities and ensure a fit-for-purpose transparency and accountability framework for emission reduction commitments. The European Parliament has consistently recognised climate finance as a key issue in these negotiations. I am proud that the Paris Agreement includes a solidarity package which contains provisions on climate finance and on addressing needs linked to adaptation and to loss and damage. Developed countries will continue with their collective mobilisation goal of USD 100 billion per year until 2025, when a new collective goal will be set. Under all circumstances, the European Union is committed to enhancing its level of support. Other countries are encouraged to provide financial support. So, in addition to all countries taking on commitments to reduce emissions, there is also no longer a strict division between developed and developing countries with regard to the provision of public finance.  We must recognise this historic moment. But the hard work has just begun. Today we may celebrate. Tomorrow we must act. In early 2016, the Commission will work on implementing the Paris Agreement in the European Union, and I look forward to working with the European Parliament on this. The Commission will also continue its work to implement the 2030 climate and energy framework. Following this summer’s legislative proposal for the revision of the European Union Emissions Trading System for the post-2020 period, the next step is to address the sectors not covered by the ETS. The Commission will also make legislative proposals on Effort-Sharing, Land Use, Land Use Change and Forestry (LULUCF). We will also bring forward a Communication on Decarbonising the Transport Sector. Also, our upcoming energy proposals – for renewables, market design and energy efficiency – will play an important role in making the energy market cleaner and more efficient.  Our wider climate diplomacy efforts will not stop. We will embark on further discussions and negotiations with our international partners on the detailed aspects of the Paris Agreement. It is crucial to build on the momentum of this historic agreement through our continued cooperation with stakeholders and with other countries on the implementation of INDCs, including capacity building for monitoring and reporting. When we meet again in Morocco, in a year’s time, we should all be able to report tangible progress. This is what the world expects from us. Dear Members, Paris is also a success for this Parliament. You have been a key player over the years in steering debate across Europe and putting in place the right legislation. I count on your continued support in the future.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Arias Cañete, Minister Gira, 12 December 2015 will be remembered by everyone as a very important date, which marked an epochal turning point in the history of mankind.  I would like to thank Commissioner Arias Cañete and Minister Carole Dieschbourg for their work and commitment during the negotiations. Their presence, together with that of our colleagues in the European Parliament in the delegation that I was honoured to be able to chair, led us to the important result achieved thanks to the ambitious leadership of the European Union.  This is an historic agreement, because for the first time all the COP Member States have admitted that there is a global problem which had to be resolved as a whole by all, with shared sacrifices and certainly with a view to a better world. The agreement seemed almost impossible and I believe that it represents the best possible balance between the different needs of developed and developing countries, creating an ambitious path, destined to last until the end of the century with five-year reviews.  It is also an historic moment because the agreement was made in Paris, in Europe, in the same city mortally wounded a few days earlier by deadly attacks. Today, as President Fabius also mentioned, this agreement serves great causes, in addition to the environmental one. It represents politics with a capital "P", one aimed ethically at the common good. It concerns public health, the fight against poverty, food security and, finally, peace. Peace for us, for our children, for the planet.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, this is the last Strasbourg session. It is the end of the year and I am not exaggerating when I say that 2015 was a terrible year; if you consider the war in the Middle East, the refugee crisis and the euro crisis. But what happened in Paris last week is a real game-changer, and very important, because it will give us reason to be optimistic for the future and that is what we need. It is very important. Paris, the city of light, is now also the city of hope. That is very good.  The most positive outcome of Paris is the fact that nearly all states – and all states means also developing countries and emerging economies – are committing themselves to the necessary efforts to tackle climate change. In that sense, this is the first universal climate agreement that we have. We can all be proud of that. The level of ambition shown in Paris, and the agreement on it, cannot be underestimated. We not only have the overall aim of holding global average temperatures steady, we need the 2°C target, and much more ambitious objectives as well. But the agreement is to limit the temperature increase to 1.5°C, and that means that we around the world and in the EU need to ramp up our efforts. Because with the building blocks of the intended nationally determined contributions we will not build the climate-proof house we want, so extra effort will be necessary. Therefore I ask the Commissioner not to wait too long, and I propose continuing our work within the high-ambition coalition which you formed, Commissioner, in the run-up to Paris and which contributed to a large extent to the success in the COP21. We must present, together with our partners in the high-ambition coalition, timely, ambitious pledges, and that means more ambitious pledges in the EU. We have to prepare for that. So let us be clear. Paris was not an end point; our work to build a carbon-free, renewable and circular economy begins now.

name: Ian Duncan
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I find myself in a proverbial mood today. Let me begin by paying a tribute to Giovanni La Via, who led the European Parliament delegation. There is a particular proverb I think is appropriate here: ‘Between saying and doing, many a pair of shoes is worn out’. I’m sure that sounds better in Italian, but nonetheless it perhaps sums up the challenges which we face. A tribute to Laurent Fabius is also required, and the proverb there would be: ‘The first step binds one in the second step’ – we have to recognise what that will mean for us. But my greatest praise I leave again to Commissioner Arias Cañete, who has again been the centrepiece of the high ambition coalition. Yesterday I described him as rather like a Santa Claus character bringing gifts back from Paris; I will note that some of them are ticking, and I think that is perhaps the challenge which we here in this Chamber face, because so many of our targets – the 2020 and 2030 targets – are predicated upon a 2°C limit, and the ambition now within this wider Paris accord is greater than that. I think we need to recognise what that will mean for us all, both in this Chamber and beyond.  I am the UK Conservative spokesperson on energy, so I speak only for the Conservatives in this particular debate – I wish not to speak for the rest of my Group. I think it is important to stress that we need to understand what this will mean for all that we are going to try and achieve, going forward. Will we need again to revisit any of the EU’s climate and energy package? That must be answered. We also have to recognise what this might mean for the emissions trading scheme – perhaps not in this first phase 4 revision – but beyond that. We also need to know whether the 1.5°C target will appear as an operational or aspirational component of future legislation. Finally, and perhaps most importantly, what impact assessment is being conducted? – so that we understand the full implications of what this will mean for all that we here in this Chamber must commit to and must do in the future. But this is a huge step forward.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, on behalf of my whole group – Mr Duncan, please note – I would like to call this long-awaited agreement a truly historic agreement. It is legally binding, in so far as international agreements can be. It has a strong long-term ambition of 2°C, but it actually mentions 1.5°C, not forgetting the five—year review mechanism and the strengthening action that comes with it. It is an irreversible step towards a low—carbon economy and – even more importantly – it is a huge signal to the financial world that only zero-carbon solutions will pay off. That is truly important.  Let me also congratulate both Minister Dieschbourg, through Mr Gira, and Commissioner Arias Cañete for their important role in Paris. The EU truly built a bridge between the developing world and the developed world, and that showed in the end. However, to draw attention to one negative point as well, I believe that Europe unnecessarily endangered the outcome by again being too reluctant on committing to financial donations. Again it showed how important it is that we have our own financial mechanisms through which donations from Europe do not depend on the mood of our Ministers of Finance. It is true that Paris is just paper. The real work starts today. The most important thing is that all 195 countries that are going to sign the agreement implement their national plans, and we have to monitor that implementation. This applies to the EU as well. Therefore my final question is what does Paris mean for the EU’s own policies in the future? I urge the Commission very rapidly to analyse the Paris outcome and to see what it means for our 2020 objectives, our 2030 objectives, and even what it means for 2050 because what we do know is that the figure of 1.5°C is linked to the upper limits of our 2050 target of 95%, and that has to be translated into all other policies.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Last Saturday, the Paris climate agreement was adopted by consensus. The French Presidency deserves to be congratulated on this. Never before have 195 countries pledged to work on climate change. And the approach, that the countries themselves decide what contribution they can make, the INDC, is certainly helped. The treaty mentions "2° and the aim of 1.5°".  That's a good start, but let's not tell ourselves we're already there. I would remind you that we are already on a temperature rise of almost 1° Celsius. The Philippines is currently dealing with a hurricane. Small islands are worried about their survival. Mr President, I welcome this agreement, let it be clear. But I also think the fossil fuel industry lobbyists are getting a big Christmas bonus because of this climate agreement.  The agreement is not really binding and the rudder is not going to change. The fossil fuel industry can continue to make a profit from oil. We're not going to stop producing carbon, we're going to capture it and store it. Air and shipping are not included in this Convention. It is business as usual with all the risks that entails. And the lack of a compensation scheme for developing countries is also a missed opportunity and a disgrace to the Western world. This will continue to evade our historical responsibility.  This agreement should be a starting point for further action, not an endpoint. More ambition is needed. We must move definitively away from fossil fuels and towards alternative, sustainable energy sources. We need to be more sensible and economical with our energy. Isolating homes would be a good start, which also provides a lot of work. It is therefore a great pity that Commissioner Cañete has already said that he does not want to increase the targets for 2020. I call on the Commissioner to get on with it now, now that the momentum is there and everyone feels that something has been achieved. Don't listen too much to your friends in the oil industry. European efforts are moving in the right direction. We are meeting our targets for 2020. Let us commit to 50% CO2 reduction by 2030.

name: Yannick Jadot
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Luxembourg's representative, we must of course welcome this agreement reached in Paris. This is excellent news, and we must congratulate - this has already been done - the French Presidency which has, I believe, invented a new form of presidency of the COP, managing both to have no declared opponents in a COP and to put itself at the centre of the game to create the right balance in Paris. We should also congratulate the European Union, the Commission, the Council, Minister Dieschbourg and Commissioner Arias Caete, particularly on the alliance games, which also facilitated this negotiation.  We now have a finish line, very clearly below 2 degrees, trying to get closer to a maximum of 1.5 degrees. For us, the conclusion is clear: we have to get out of carbon, we have to get out of fossil fuels, and we have to do it very quickly if we really want to get closer to 1.5 degrees.  It wasn't all good news in Paris. We have lost on the issue of shipping and international air transport. Having sectors that are completely beyond climate responsibility is also a failure of the Paris negotiations. The failure, under pressure from oil-rich countries, to include decarbonisation, the entry of fossil fuel prices and the price of carbon into the negotiations is also a failure.  What I remember is that, basically, if the path to this 1.5 to 2 degree finish line of warming is blurred, there are some extremely interesting tools, including this revision every 5 years - already hoping for a revision or, at least, a start of revision in 2018 - because it is a reflection of a new governance of climate policies. Indeed, civil society, companies that have understood the issue of climate and local authorities, which are often ahead of the states, will regularly be actors in new climate policies. I think this is really the good news of this negotiation: democratic public debates will be held regularly on climate policies and it will be up to us to rise to the challenge every time, to move from this moment of climate irresponsibility in which we are, with 3-degree commitments, to this responsibility at 1.5.  But it also implies a responsibility for the European Union: it is not the status quo, it is not a return to business as usual; 30% reduction in our emissions in 2020, Commissioner, that must be your goal. Revising the climate-energy package - as the European Parliament has again called for - with regard to emissions, efficiency and renewable energy is your programme. And this European Union must also do its job with regard to the financial transaction tax. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Jadot, I absolutely agree with you, France and the French Foreign Minister should be congratulated for this success. At the same time, I would like to ask you if you believe that the binding measures, which are quite weak, will ultimately give us results. If the revisions take place every five years, it means that many questions can arise in the meantime.

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" answer. Obviously, with the Paris agreement, it is the end of Kyoto-type governance where, basically, we were in an extremely restrictive regime and did not work, despite good intentions.  This is a new, broader governance, which is effectively based on a soft right, a right that does not really compel states. But it is basically the world in which we live, where states are only one of the actors in the fight against climate change, alongside local authorities, civil society, businesses. It is up to us to make it a tool of discipline, it is up to us to make it a binding tool so that we can indeed lead to ambitious policies.

name: Marco Affronte
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if we read the comments that have taken place over the last two or three days, from Saturday to today, we see that we are in a swing, on the one hand the enthusiasm for an agreement that is described as extremely positive historical, on the other hand there are those who say that instead there has been a failure and a deep disappointment.  The truth is probably in the middle as usual and in any case it is a historic agreement if only because we have sat around a table 195 different countries that have recognized a problem and have found the commitment and effort to try to solve it. We have set a goal that is to be well below 2 degrees of temperature, aiming if possible even at 1.5 degrees. We were happy with this goal and hailed it as a very ambitious target especially considering that the current INDCs take us to 2.7 degrees, so we really have a lot of work to do.  But then, in the next article we go to read that how do we achieve this goal? We reach the maximum peak of emissions "as soon as possible", as soon as possible, which is a formula that says nothing, could be in ten years or twenty years or thirty years and we still read that the word decarbonization disappears. Many people talk about a carbon-free market. The word decarbonisation has disappeared and there is talk of a balance between anthropogenic emissions and the removal of greenhouse gases, that is, we are relying on a technology that we do not yet know well, which is there to come because we cannot accept the guilt that we are not capable at the moment of ending our carbon emissions.  So, positive and negative together, there's a lot of work to be done.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President, it is also clear to me and, I believe, also to all colleagues: global warming concerns us all, regardless of political colour and political choices. Dear colleague, you have said, among other things, you have admitted that it was a success in Paris and I agree with what you said. Do you think that, because of the simple fact that the word 'decarbonisation' is missing, the indicators and targets we have set ourselves cannot be met?

name: Marco Affronte (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. It means that they can be achieved, but in a different way from what we all hope for here. We want to get to take away the energies that use carbon and that use the fossil and get there with green energy. If the word decarbonization disappears, it means that we get there by going through an indirect route, that is, still going to produce CO2 and somehow removing it to put it somewhere else. That is not the right way to go.

name: Steeve Briois
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if we believe the many glowing articles, COP 21 - headed by the French Foreign Minister, Laurent Fabius - would have been successful. The reality is not really that, because the Paris agreement is not binding, and it boils down to declarations of intent that will prove insufficient to limit global warming, if it is still containable.  Indeed, it is not by declarations of intent that events are weighed, but by clear acts, respectful of the sovereignty of States, as well as their need to pursue their economic development. Limiting itself to poisoning the daily lives of millions of our compatriots, a certain form of punitive ecology has failed to meet the immense challenges facing our planet and our continent, and for good reason: what the European Union gives with one hand, it takes up with the other.  COP 21 and the EU now want to reduce carbon emissions, but the EU continues to advocate totally unbridled free trade by refusing, among other things, to implement a Community preference that would encourage the relocation of our production resources and thus avoid importing consumer products tens of thousands of kilometres. However, fewer kilometres travelled for a commodity is, of course, less greenhouse gases released into the atmosphere. COP 21 and the Union also want to preserve biodiversity and encourage responsible agriculture, but at the same time the Union validates the transatlantic treaty, which will have the effect of importing into Europe products that do not meet any of our social or environmental standards, and which put hundreds of small family farms at serious risk of death. I am not even talking about the total lack of visionary policy on the part of the Union and its support, in particular for renewable sectors. I will also be moving on to facilitating the importation of oil sands from Canada, which poses a real threat to the boreal forest.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The Paris climate conference is a success, an ambitious agreement has been reached. We are no longer talking about a two-degree ceiling in temperature increases, but one and a half degrees has been said. However, the question is, to what extent can the promises of the signatories of this document be held to account under international law or how can they be sanctioned?  Let me give you an example: realization obviously depends on national decisions. If there is a Republican president and a majority in the United States next year who declare their rejection of President Obama's climate policy, what about the world's second-largest polluter? After all, they didn't even accept the Kyoto Protocol in the end, so that's another fundamental question.  And let me ask you one more question: if developing countries are supported by the developed, will, as an EU country, Hungary also support China, which is the second economic power in the world?

name: Peter Liese (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Of course, not everything that shines is gold, even in the Paris Agreement. Personally, I am also somewhat sceptical that we are now talking about 1.5 degrees, while the INDCs that are available are bringing us to almost 3 degrees. I would have liked us to bring the two figures together a little more so that the whole thing is clearer. But we should not underestimate this historic opportunity that the truly historic Paris Agreement brings. If more than 180 countries, as well as emerging and developing countries, commit themselves, that is a value in itself. If we consider that some of the states that reached an agreement together in Paris are at the same time waging war against each other, that is not at all self-evident. We should give a positive tribute to this and build on what has been achieved. I share the criticism levelled by some on the subject of aviation and maritime transport. But I believe that a positive development can also be inferred from this. Article 4 of the Convention makes it a commitment for all actors, not just States. This is a call to the International Civil Aviation Organisation and to the IMO to finally assume its responsibilities. After what was decided in Paris, they can no longer shirk their responsibilities. I would ask the Commission and the Council to take a special look at this and to put pressure on them. Thank you very much and congratulations to all those who contributed to the Convention.

name: Matthias Groote (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe that history has been decided, because a global problem, the biggest global problem, will finally be tackled and tackled globally. But now it starts with work, it has to be said. I would also like to thank the Commission, Mr Arias Caete, the Presidency of the Council and also, explicitly, the French Presidency of the Conference, which has negotiated excellently and has really succeeded with all its diplomatic skill. A number of downsides have been mentioned in the agreement. I cannot understand why two sectors are evading their responsibilities, which keep arguing that they are international sectors and that there must therefore be no legislation in Europe. These are international air transport and international maritime transport. These two sectors must continue to play their part in the future, because what was adopted in Paris, 1.5 degrees to 2 degrees reduction, can only be achieved if everyone participates. You can't give the others another job at the end of the day – steel mills, other industries that are there – but everyone has to make their contribution, and that includes these two sectors. I believe that we must now seize the opportunity – the financial industry has done so in advance, including insurance companies, which have made it very clear that we will no longer invest in fossil fuels with our funds, with our capital. We need to turn the whole thing into very clear signals for investment, including in Europe, in renewable energy. We need storage technology. The whole Energy Union must be taken forward. These are the conclusions that we really have to take with us from Paris. The whole thing is converted into jobs, and then it becomes a shoe. And then, at the end of the day, we must also stand by the commitments we have made financially. The finance ministers of the European Union must be held to account here.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I accept the Paris Agreement with a certain amount of optimism as a victory for a pragmatic approach over ideology. It is pleased to appreciate the role of forests as natural carbon-absorbing reservoirs. I am convinced that it is time for the European Union to take seriously the role of forests and land management in climate policy. I would like to draw attention to the very low funding of afforestation by the European Union so far. The Paris agreement was also reached because the final entries did not include the word 'decarbonisation', and that is very good, because each country has the right to decide on its own energy mix. I think it is worth investing in low-carbon, clean coal techniques.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome the agreement against global warming reached in Paris, which limits global warming to two degrees so as not to exceed 1.5° This represents a crucial step for humanity and the planet. It is a historic milestone that covers, for the first time, 195 countries. I congratulate the Commissioner on his excellent work, as does our President La Via. That said, it is certain that the agreement could and should be more ambitious. Scientific data indicate that we must decarbonise our economy as early as 2050 and, however, quantitative emission reduction targets have been removed from the agreement. It is also regrettable that any reference to the maritime and aviation sectors, whose emissions are expected to grow in the coming years, is also regrettable. We must now make a deep commitment to the implementation of this agreement and the transparency of this process and the periodic review mechanism are essential. I hope that each nation will be able to strengthen its national contribution to the immediate commitment to the end of coal-fueled electricity generation and in encouraging electric mobility and energy efficiency. The fight against global warming is a race against time and the Treaty of Paris was just a starting shot.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the Paris agreement is insufficient.  States have lacked political will to oppose the powers of fossil energy companies, because the agreement does not mention, not once, these fuels. There is an immense gap between street solidarity and governments, which put the benefits of the most powerful before human rights.  We are committed to transforming polluting projects into others based on a new production model. That is why we will fight trade and investment treaties, such as TTE, CETA or ACS, because they prevent action against climate change.  The role of the European Union has been dire, especially on your part, Mr Cañete, because you represent only the interests of large energy companies, with which your team has apparently met more than 80% of the time. He should resign as Commissioner because he did not want to negotiate a fair, equitable and binding agreement.

name: Bas Eickhout (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Arias Cañete for his job well done in Paris. We know that we have been critical now and then, but if you do a job right we will also acknowledge that, so thank you very much, Commissioner, from the Green Group too, for your job well done. The same goes for Carole Dieschbourg, and I am sure you will pass on to her the compliment for getting the job done. But, this now means, of course, that we have to start our work at European level. We all know that the agreement in Paris states we want to stay well below 2°C, with efforts to achieve a ceiling of 1.5°C. That means something, because all EU policies at this moment are based on the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) scenario that gives a 50% chance of staying below 2°C. All the targets we set are for a 50% chance of staying below 2°C. So if we now agree to stay well below 2°C, and even to achieve 1.5°C, it really means we have to step up our own efforts. In that sense, Commissioner Arias Cañete, I was in a good mood after the weekend but then I heard your press conference yesterday, and it was a bit disappointing to hear you say, more or less, that we would leave the extra ambition to the next Commission. No! To say that would really be to burn your legacy one day after Paris – and that would be a pity. What you need to say is, first of all, that there was a pledge that Europe would move to minus 30% in 2020 if there was a global deal. Well, there is a global deal: so Europe can move to minus 30%. Secondly, we need an impact assessment. What does 1.5°C mean – especially bearing in mind that, this morning, Parliament adopted a binding 40% efficiency target for 2030. What does that mean? There too we need more information. On aviation also there was a slight mistake in your presentation yesterday. If the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) does not deliver next year, then that means the EU will re-include aviation in the Emissions Trading Scheme right away. No discussion – it is just the law – we will put it in the ETS if ICAO does not deliver.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, this Paris agreement is a damp squib. It is little more than aspirational: there is no implementation or enforcement mechanism. That leaves the EU competitively disadvantaged as the only area with legally enforceable emissions obligations. We have talked about keeping global warming to 2°C or 2.7°C or 1.5°C. But the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) itself suggests a very wide range of values for climate sensitivity between 1.5°C and 4.5°C per doubling of CO2. With this huge range of uncertainty, it is simply delusional to pretend that we can set meaningful targets to a tenth of a degree, but the real problems we face will be political not environmental. The economic damage and the sacrifices required from citizens to implement the Paris agreement are simply not deliverable in a democratic context. Governments that seek to implement this agreement will create an economic wasteland. They will be voted out of office. Remember colleagues, when it happens to you, you heard it here first.

name: Olaf Stuger (ENF).
text: – The participants in the Paris conference are very close to each other because of an agreement that has yet to prove its worth. Because let's look back at Kyoto. What did it cost us? 1,200 billion euros. And what did it bring?  The warming was prevented by 0.017°. So no best score. But there will be plenty of people who will benefit from this agreement. Because the green entrepreneurs, as they so much like to call themselves, will see their profits increase with the environmental requirements in their hand; the billions of profits they have made after Kyoto, they will now achieve again and, Mr President, who is going to pay for that? Right, the taxpayers and especially the Dutch taxpayer. So, too, Mr. Eickhout, if he pays taxes in the Netherlands, nice, you will pay it. So on behalf of the Dutch taxpayer, thank you very much!

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Madam President, despite the great words and the prepared photographs, this agreement is nothing but air words. Firstly, the objective of keeping global temperature rise below two degrees Celsius is insufficient. Even if countries succeed in achieving this, no one can guarantee that it will be reversed or that the temperature rise will stop. Moreover, no one is entirely sure how nature actually works on the issue of climate change. Today, for example, Meteorology predicted rains in Strasbourg but it was finally a sunny day.  As long as multinationals destroy vast areas of rainforest every day, as long as China and India destroy the environment unashamedly, rest assured that with electric cars and wind turbines there is no way we will achieve anything. As long as fossil fuels are the cheapest source of energy, projects like the one agreed in Paris will have no effect. In conclusion, we are calling for action and not words: immediately imposing sanctions against all countries that do not respect the environment, banning imports from these countries, padlocking multinationals that destroy forests. Last and for all: we must in every way find an energy source that is efficient and at the same time cheaper than fossil fuels.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: Madam President, after Copenhagen and the disappointment of Copenhagen, I can say that we are coming back from afar, because bringing together 195 countries around a climate agreement was a real tour de force, and we can welcome this great step due to the unwavering will displayed by the French Presidency and the talents of its diplomacy and, above all, I welcome the role of the Luxembourg Minister , Carole Dieschbourg, and our Commissioner, Arias Caete, whose efforts have been rewarded.  This agreement, which some describe as historic and ambitious, is not legally binding, unfortunately, in my opinion. But today, in any case, concrete measures must be taken, not only in the European Union, but in China, India and the United States. This agreement will have to be ratified, respected, improved. We will see it as part of its review. The funding agreement was also a key issue that could be addressed. Paris will have at least led to a North-South partnership. It is true, everything remains to be done because this agreement is only a starting point. But I remain confident because the commitment of civil society and our companies to reduce their emissions is quite new. This will also allow us to move towards a gradually decarbonised industrial revolution and thus give full place to technological innovation. And that's where the economy and climate come together, which I think is very positive.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Madam President, first I would like to congratulate Mr Caete: Bravo for your good job. Congratulations to you, but also to Carole Dieschbourg, for the work you have done. This is a work that we owe you, we who have been with you in this delegation of the European Union.  Together with the French Presidency and Laurent Fabius, we have managed to secure a historic agreement. Historic, because it is a universal agreement: 195 countries have agreed after twenty years of discussions that saw the failure of Copenhagen at the end of 2009; so it was time to get back on track to be able to fight climate change. Universal agreement with national contributions to be revised in 2020, a revision clause from 2025 and $100 billion from 2020, a floor and not a ceiling - again, this is a step forward that we must highlight.  There is a dose of constraints in the Paris agreement, but there are no sanctions - we may also regret it too: it means that the fight continues, that this Paris agreement is a step and that we must, at COP 22, to be held in Marrakech at the end of 2016, continue to ensure that we not only have a fight against climate change. , but also a change in the economic paradigm: circular economy with its development, sustainable agriculture and short circuit, but also the development of renewable energies, with the development of a policy of energy saving and energy efficiency. Fight of the century, but opportunity of the century, this is our challenge!

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Madam President, we have been told for the last several years that it is highly unlikely, if not impossible, to meet the target of 2°C of warming. Now that we have agreed a limit of well below 2°C of warming, we are being told that we have to take further action rapidly to change our targets and our action plans to 2030 to reflect this, because we now have a global deal.  Well, do we? Is it realistic to expect us all to change our behaviours? What are we even doing here in Strasbourg this week? Is this going to be the last time we are all required to travel here? The extra climate effect of the Strasbourg circus – no, we are not going to change that. That is not going to change; we will carry on as we were. So it is fine words. The wording of the agreement is illuminating, with phrases such as ‘as soon as possible’. There is no deadline year beyond 2050. What I was looking for was certainty – certainty to encourage investment. I would rather have certainty at lower levels of ambition than fine words that do not create the right conditions for business and governments to work together without coercion.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is said that the duty is pleasant only when it is done and it is perhaps special in terms of responsibility for our planet.  195 countries have now concluded an agreement, but we have not yet done our duty. The duty is done when we have achieved the targets that we have set to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The duty is not that we now say that we should have an agreement, but the duty is that we deliver what the agreement is said to contain.  To reach an agreement in Paris it was not just duty, but we should honor what is the content. It's to do our duty.  For us in the Center Party and for us in ALDE, it has been very important to have a forward-looking and forward-looking agreement in place. We have now succeeded in doing so. It is now a matter of us doing our duty in this house, in the national parliaments and among our colleagues across the world, doing our duty and honouring the signal of the agreement by changing the energy systems, investing in innovation and ensuring that we are able to keep the target well below the 1.5 degree target.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, an historic climate agreement was reached in Paris, thanks to all those who have worked on an important issue – the agreement. So now we have finally got things on paper and concrete work can begin. Hopefully, mankind will be wise enough and will also take active action to bring about concrete change. There is still a long way to go on paper for subsidies for fossil energy sources to be shifted to supporting renewable forms of energy and fuel, or retrofitting, for example.  It should be remembered that warming by more than 2°C makes many regions of the world unfit to live, and if this is allowed to happen, we have only seen a small influx of refugees for the million people who are coming to Europe at the moment, because climate refugees talk about hundreds of millions of people. In order to prevent climate refugees and save the planet, everyone's actions in our daily lives are valuable.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE).
text: "Mr. Cañete Bitzos, you said at dawn on Sunday that we are celebrating today, but we must act tomorrow. Two days have passed since that declaration, and we agree that the time has come to act. However, this is also very important and urgent for the EU. Everything agreed by the negotiators in Paris must be translated into the European Union's own climate policy.  Climate change of less than two degrees or one and a half degrees will also require an increase in our own targets, 40% energy efficiency, at least 30% renewable share. Similarly, the five-yearly review mechanism should be transposed into European legislation, e.g. as regards the ETS, where similar mechanisms will need to be introduced. And the issue of implementation is a key issue, not only for Paris, but also for the Union's climate policy. Today, we do not know how these EU objectives, which were created a year and a half ago, will be translated into mandatory action at Member State level, and without it we will not achieve results.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question marked with a blue card in accordance with Article 162(8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Mr. Jávor, you have said that we should start acting immediately and I fully agree with you, but do you agree with me that this action should be directed precisely in such a way as to prevent attempts to build new coal-fired power plants in the European Union? For example, in Croatia one such coal-fired thermal power plant is to be built. You know this project, and I'm asking you, do you agree with me that we have to stop it?

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: blue card answer. Thank you for asking. We agree, of course, that in order to achieve the objectives that we have set in Paris, and the Eu's climate policy also sets out, it will inevitably be necessary not only not to invest money in fossil fuels, let alone public money, member states' or EU public funds, but also to drive out existing investments in the fossil sector, i.e. 'divestment'. If we cannot be effective in this, we will never achieve the objectives set.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it has been said that it is an historic agreement, that it has been said that it is an ambitious agreement, and I would just like to point out that dependence on fossil fuels in the world energy system has produced 84% of greenhouse gas emissions. Therefore, if we really wanted to save the planet, we had to abolish first of all those fossil subsidies that drug the energy market and prevent a real transition to renewables.  In Europe, more than €330 billion was subsidised in 2015. We in the world are at an astronomical eur 5 300 billion, which is more than is spent worldwide in a year on health care. Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom, the United States and alas Italy subsidise oil, gas and coal at the expense of citizens; €80 billion annually, while their commitment to the Green Climate Fund amounts to only $2 billion a year.  Therefore, Commissioner Cañete, the only gift that really was supposed to give us this year at Christmas was to abolish fossil fuel subsidies, but I realise that Santa's fairy tale is just a fairy tale.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: – First of all, our warm congratulations, it has been said a lot here, to Commissioner Cañete, to his team and to Jos Delbeke's team for this result. It is the result of years of work, great respect for it and for the result. That agreement, that result, "The agreement of Paris" is not perfect, of course, we all know that, but still, it was unthinkable until recently that this would come out. And the formal commitment of EUR 100 billion to developing countries is, of course, a very positive point, but above all this five-yearly review is a very good thing. The most important, ladies and gentlemen, is undoubtedly the signal that comes from Paris. Commissioner, the fact that, in particular, to industry in Europe, but also throughout the world, to all companies, to the economy, to the financial institutions, the clear signal has been sent that we must say goodbye to fossil technology, to the energy sector of the past. Today and yesterday, the media worldwide agree that the road to CO2-neutral or CO2-free reduction has been taken.  One final point, as has already been said here, is not covered by shipping and aviation. That is very unfortunate. But I don't think I can take up that fight, that we should certainly focus on aviation in the coming year in order to reach that global agreement.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the climate change agreement in Paris is the first global deal on climate change, which means that for the very first time we have 195 countries that managed to agree to decouple their economic growth from fossil fuel. And yes, this is also thanks to the EU. I believe that COP21 was successful in that Paris managed to unite all countries to take action. Elements of the agreement are legally binding, and it represents unmatched levels of cooperation which saw governments, regions, businesses and campaigners coming together.  However, I believe that this is only the beginning. More needs to be done. It is vital that countries ratify this agreement.  The current INDCs (Intended Nationally Determined Contributions) need to be updated because, as they stand today, they are not sufficient to achieve the 1.5°C we are hoping for. It means that we require credible plans to decarbonise our economies and protect the most vulnerable from the devastating impact of climate change.  Obviously, I wanted to see more. Once again, shipping and aviation managed to be excluded. It would also have been better to have a specific date for the peaking of emissions. I would have liked to see more happen before 2020 and fewer opportunities for legislatures to fail to ratify. But what is different this time round is that we have a robust agreement which lays a solid foundation for a more stable and better climate.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In Paris, politicians were first rescued. In order to save the climate, we need a market economy and globally effective instrument. This instrument must meet three conditions. Firstly, CO2 must become more expensive, only then will it be less emitted. Secondly, emission allowances must be tradable, only then will CO2 be used where it is really necessary. Thirdly, if Europe, as an expensive energy island, does not continue to export growth, jobs, and prosperity, this system must be effective on a global basis. I therefore call on the Commission to immediately commit itself to a binding and global emissions system. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Frankly, I did not understand what the euro has to do with carbon emissions, but you made a statement: you said that what happened in Paris actually saved politicians. Can you explain what that means? I believe that what happened in Paris is a need and everyone here, regardless of the political option, must support the framing of climate change indicators. So what do you mean by "politicians have been saved"?

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. As we have now noted, you have all patted yourself on the back, and many of the contributions have also confirmed this. As far as my Ceterum censeo on the euro is concerned, my great example is Senator Cato, who has always said at every speech in Rome, whatever the subject, that Carthage must be destroyed. I believe that the euro in Europe only leads to strife and discord and must therefore be abolished.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, at the time of the adoption of the Paris Agreement, the conditions that allow us to assume that its objectives can be met are not met. Far from it. No matter how ambitious these objectives, without reliable means to achieve them, cannot be taken seriously. This is one of the great flaws in Paris. Despite the insistence of several countries, notably Latin America, in criticising market mechanisms and so-called flexibility mechanisms, they are at the heart of this agreement. These are mechanisms that have proved perverse and ineffective in achieving emission reductions, but which serve the business prospects of some. This is what this is about, gentlemen, business, not environmental objectives! As for the financing of adaptation and mitigation, another handful of nothing. The unwillingness to raise barriers, such as intellectual property rights, shows where the millions of the Green Fund will go in the name of the so-called technology transfer. The enthusiasm around the results of COP 21 should therefore be moderated by reality.

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I agree with the Commissioner that we will have to go to 1.5°C maximum and we will have to do this early. So all INDCs will have to be raised in ambition on climate mitigation in 2018-19, which also means that all the modelling the Commission did back in 2013 is obsolete – 40/27/27 is not good enough, and it is not based on good enough modelling to achieve 1.5°C.  You will be in a dilemma. This morning we voted, as a way out of this dilemma, on a model as the basis for all the legislation next year, including non-ETS – 27/30/33/35/40 energy efficiency – and that will show you that Europe can be more ambitious on climate change, while doing something for jobs in Europe and for European competitivity.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: blue card question. – Congressman, I think, broadly, that Parliament is in the same mood, that these objectives are indeed ambitious. It is also true that Europe, nevertheless, needs to take much greater steps. But what do you think about the fact that member countries can't drill this whole thing with a bad energy mix? Because the energy mix is entirely a member state's jurisdiction.

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – You must all understand that the EU Commission was tricked and manipulated in 2013 and for the January 2014 impact assessment. We can do more in Europe on energy efficiency, we can do more in Europe on renewable energy. If we make 30:30%, then we will automatically get to 45, if we make 33:33, then we will get 50% greenhouse gas emissions. It is the Commission's duty to now provide all the EU institutions with objective information on the impact of such scenarios on jobs, competitiveness and climate.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, whenever I hear the words ‘historic agreement’, my sceptical streak kicks in. The aim is to keep warming below 2°C at a time when there has been no warming since 1997 and when we know that 1 000 years ago the earth was warmer than it is today. Current records are all too brief. Even 250 years is insufficient time for a meaningful assessment of long-term climate patterns, and so-called models are only as good as the data in the programming. The climate change industry has become a powerful, vested interest, so what will this really mean in Swindon, Exeter and Penzance?  The main problem is the demonisation of coal, which has been the provider of cheap, affordable electricity for many years. COP21 delegates state a need for cheap, affordable electricity, but this agreement will have the opposite effect. Already, millions in the UK live in fuel poverty, having to choose between heating and eating. Approximately 20% of the thousands of excess winter deaths per year are directly attributable to cold homes. COP 21 is bad for them, bad for the UK, and bad for Europe.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Reid, I would like to ask you: if you say that we do not really know whether climate change is actually taking place, because the time series are far too short, would not the fact that there is a possibility of a change in the climate be followed by a need to deal with it carefully and responsibly and still take measures to control greenhouse gas emissions in a sensible way?

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, I do not dispute there has been climate change: there has been for thousands of years. A thousand years ago we had the medieval warm period; before that we had the Roman warm period; before that we had the late Egyptian warm period, and before that the Minoan warm period. All these actually coincide with the sun’s activity. We have seen that cooling has actually started to happen since the solar cycle 24 decreased, and the sun is very inactive at the moment. In fact, some solar scientists forecast that we are actually heading for another Maunder minimum.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Thank you, Mr President. Commissioner, i would like to begin by thanking the Colleagues! We have something to rejoice about– the political goal has been achieved. Virtually all countries in the world are committed to reducing carbon emissions in order to reduce the human impact of global warming. That's a lovely thing! But let's see what's next. There are only two options that can happen. The first possibility is that this commitment is fulfilled. The second possibility is that this commitment is not fulfilled. What happens if it is executed? For us – Europe, for our companies – this would be one charming thing. We would keep our competitiveness, I think I would predict that our competitiveness would increase, because in Europe companies have understood for years what energy efficiency is, have been working on reducing carbon emissions, we have so-called green technologies, we have priority. If everyone cuts, we'll be ahead. But if the rest do not follow Europe and it remains only as, say, political commitment, then Europe will lose its competitiveness and emissions in the world will only continue to rise. So the most important thing is to keep track of that everyone is respecting their commitment, not just Europe alone. Thank you!

name: Seb Dance (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we have had the medieval warming period; we have had the Egyptian warming period; we now have the UKIP warming period, with the asinine nonsense that we hear from the other side of the Chamber. Because we know that this is the greatest threat that the planet faces – and huge credit is due to the Commissioner and to the Presidency for the work they have done. There is a lot I could say about what should be in the deal and is not. Shipping and aviation have been mentioned; we talked about the vague targets that are in place; and, of course, the fact that national legislators can now strike elements of this down. But it is really important, at a time when people are searching for ways in which the European institutions can deliver, that we have this real example of what working together can achieve – because it is not easy. We know that working together and getting agreement among 28 countries is difficult. But this agreement with 196 parties shows that it can be done, and it shows the power of working together. So you can congratulate yourselves, Commissioner: you have done well. And yes, now the hard work begins!

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner. This is the first time in history that developing and developed countries have joined their forces to protect climate change – not only well below 2°C, but even 1.5°C above pre—industrial level. We have managed to build climate change awareness and we, the global community, prefer to prevent the damage instead of adapting ourselves. It is a real great success. But there are some weaknesses too.  The first one: when we sum up intended nationally determined contributions there is the risk that the temperature rise will be closer to 3°C. Everyone declares themselves to be ready to save the climate but only very, very few, like the EU, are ready to act. Secondly, it remains to be seen whether these, very often voluntary, declarations will be kept. The agreement is based only on constant monitoring and control, as well as revision every five years. Third point: it has to be ratified in future by the 55 countries responsible for 55% of emissions. It did not work out with Kyoto. Will it now?  I am very convinced, as are our scientists, by the whole idea of climate protection. But let us be honest: it is quite obvious that in our fight against the global warming we, the EU, are still almost alone. So it is an important signal to our industry, and we should be as active as before in the coming years.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: – Mr President, well done to the Commission; well done to the Commissioner; well done to the Council; it is a good deal. We now have a plan and we now need to deliver that plan. If we do not deliver the plan, then Paris will not be remembered. I do have a worry though, and it is about my own government. We seem to be going backwards in the United Kingdom. We are not doing renewables like we were going to do them; we are not doing carbon capture and storage like we were going to do, and we are now going to expand our airports.  This is going backwards and I hope the Commissioner, next time he sees the relevant people from the United Kingdom, will point this out and use his leadership to say that there is now a gap appearing between the rhetoric of the British Government on one hand in Paris, which was fine, and the reality on the ground in the United Kingdom, which is not living up to that fine rhetoric. And the phrase that he could use next time he sees Amber Rudd is to say to her: fine words butter no parsnips.

name: Karl-Heinz Florenz (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I congratulate you, Commissioner. I also warmly congratulate the French Republic. You did it excellently! I've been with it for a long time. Of course, there are weaknesses, of course we are not satisfied. But colleagues who have not been to Paris or at other conferences should remember that it is not so easy to reconcile 190 countries. I've already walked around all the concrete walls of the world. That is why we should be careful with higher demands, because two conferences have failed because we have called for binding legislation. And they have failed – not least those in Copenhagen. I therefore believe that we will get a boost in European industry. Industry and managers, as well as consumers, have long understood that low-carbon policies are moving forward. And I think there is only one thing that is required, namely our Member States. We must now ensure this at home. In my state, North Rhine-Westphalia in Germany, this is going to be particularly hard, and yet we have to do it. The industry will help us in this, because I am convinced that it has long understood that there is a great new, modern added value in a low-carbon industry. About 50 billionaires around the world have decided to invest their money in this direction. Ladies and gentlemen, you may have a lot of idea about money, but they have even more idea of money. Now let them grant! We should support them. Once again, Mr Arias Caete, thank you very much, and stay firm! Stay tough on implementation in the Member States!

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, the Paris Agreement is rightly called historic. I am sure that a signal is coming out for a new industrial age. If we do everything in the agreement, which is to decarbonise the economy and society, then we need many new technologies. We need a fundamental renewal of our economic model, not only in terms of electricity generation, but also, of course, in transport, in buildings, in agriculture, in virtually all fields, because, as usual, we can achieve 80 to 95% decarbonisation and the exclusion of fossil fuels. I think there will be technology competition between America, Asia and Europe. That's where My concern comes about, whether we're in a good position. Battery technology is in China, the interesting cars in America, and we are sitting partly on storekeepers. I believe that the 50 billionaires in the United States would also like to see them in support of innovation policy in the EU. Finally, Mr President, Commissioner, is the EU prepared to really shoulder this overall package and enter this new industrial era ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was privileged to be one of the official parliamentarian representatives in Paris, and indeed it was wonderful to see it having a positive outcome. For that, great credit is due to the French, who organised everything excellently, and also to Commissioner Arias Cañete and his colleagues, who played a very important part. We were more or less sidelined in Copenhagen, but on this occasion we were centre stage. If you look at the proposals that came through Parliament, by and large, they were accepted. And there was recognition right across the world for what Europe is doing. Now we have to move on and deliver, particularly for the people we met, like the indigenous peoples and the small island countries, because they are under an immediate threat. That is why we need to move as quickly as possible to 1.5°C, rather than 2°C. For us, we should complete the energy union as quickly as possible and become the renewables capital of the world. In my own country, we have a great opportunity to progress with ocean energy. There is a lot of research being done on that right now and that too can be wonderful.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with those who say that in Paris we may not have saved the planet, but we have saved the chance to save the planet, and that is already a great deal.  It is a realistic and also a somewhat rigorous judgment of those who put things on the balance, the shared responsibility between countries throughout the world, industrialised and otherwise, and on the other side of the scale what is missing, the dates and the legal constraints. In short, we have seriously given ourselves a chance and now we must ensure that this opportunity becomes a reality, a real possibility. In short, we must translate declarations into concrete, binding and rigorous commitments.  This is the result and the fruit of so much effort by Europe, and that is why Europe must continue to carry that flag, now more than before. The European Union is responsible for only 10% of emissions, but as the world's leading power it can do much and much more. Europe is a commercial power, a market of producers and consumers that dictates laws and standards, it can influence trade agreements, with strict environmental standards. In short, that new model that builds competitiveness and sustainability together can go down the road of energy transition.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, thank you for the work you have done and allow me to thank you also in the light of the controversy. Many of those who had accompanied his appointment with sometimes rather capricious polemics, today thank you for the work you are doing. This shows that work reduces certain waste of time, so thank you for that.  The work that has been done in Paris gives an important signal. I do not want to point out the controversy, here too, about not everyone agreeing with the scientific basis on which that result was built. That result is good and there is and shows that countries can face major challenges. Well, I give you a parallel challenge that will give strength to this challenge you have won. Unruly countries – we are discussing the possible recognition of China's state of market economy – unruly countries are put in a position to accept this discipline, so that in addition to the environment our tradition of industry and labour is safeguarded. The Commission can do that, Parliament is sharing a strong position on this.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Paris Agreement sends out a clear signal: the era of fossil fuels is coming to an end and the development of our society must be based on renewable sources and energy efficiency.  The most important result achieved in Paris is probably the fact that almost all countries, including emerging economies and developing countries, have been included in the project of global economic conversion with the ambitious goal of halting temperature growth by a degree and a half. This is all the greater when we consider that in previous climate agreements only developed countries had committed themselves to reducing emissions.  The agreement reached in Paris takes up many of the positions contained in the action of this Parliament and Europe as a whole is the winner. However, much remains to be done. The agreement merely recommends that states behave virtuously, but does not provide for binding mechanisms and sanctions at international level. The next step must therefore be to arrive at a new legal status of agreements with binding commitments and deadlines, with related sanctions.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE).
text: – Mr President, congratulations to the Commission — to the negotiating team — to the Council and, of course, commissioner Miguel Arias Cañete, whose leadership everyone has acknowledged that he has in the end played a very decisive role in this whole process which has been promoted by the European Union. I want to say that the great success, the key to the success of this agreement is to move from a uniforming vision — which was what Kyoto represented and that is why it failed again and again, and that is why it frustrated so much that it could not have an alternative agreement in Copenhagen, because in the end virtually all of the same was asked – to a situation in which the objectives are national , but there is compliance, there is obligation and there is a transparent commitment to meet the objectives. This is the key to success. And this is what you constantly have to protect and monitor.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D).
text: – Commissioner, I have already made a positive assessment of your role in these negotiations yesterday. The Paris agreement is certainly a partial victory for all those who wanted to prevent the disaster that a rise in global temperature would surely cause. We still have to realize that this deal may not have happened at all. I very much welcome the commitment of the participating countries to do their utmost to ensure that the temperature rise does not exceed 1.5ºC, which would certainly be a major disaster for the many millions of people living in some areas of the globe. I don't think so, but we can be completely satisfied with the results. It is quite clear that some countries' commitments do not fully meet the targets set, and if we fail to force some large polluters to reconsider their position, the average temperature will rise by up to 3ºC. to which we are committed.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The agreement is impressive because it is a global agreement: 196 countries. I think that you, Commissioner Cañete, have played an excellent role there, and for that we should be thanked for that. This is a good step towards climate protection, but it is also a whole new reality and rules where by which individual economies can calculate the costs of climate and energy policies and the economy as a whole. The climate agreement talks about reducing emissions. I very much welcome this, because the decarbonisation of the economy does not necessarily mean low emissions, which is the effect that we want to achieve. Already during the Polish Presidency of the Council of the European Union, we spoke of a 'low-emission economy' and not a 'low-carbon economy'. Our Minister for Economic Affairs spoke about this. This was also reflected in the programme documents of the European People's Party, which introduced the term. Now, bearing in mind that the Union will be a leader, we should align our policy with this agreement, but provided that the partners of this agreement are firmly involved in the ratification and implementation of the Paris Agreement.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D). Mr President, for the first time a climate agreement has been signed by 195 countries, while the Kyoto Protocol, for example, was signed by only 38 countries. Funding of at least 100 billion is also guaranteed by 2020 for the least developed countries. This makes it possible to transfer them to less polluting technologies, without threatening to increase their standard of living. All of the above make the Paris conference a historic event and an important start. We may say that the principle is half of everything, but only half will remain if we do not fully implement what has been agreed. The absence of sanctions in the event of non-compliance with decisions is an open question which makes civil society the main control and pressure body. That is why it is necessary for the European Parliament to take information initiatives on the value of the fight against climate change, through a new environmental ethic that we must acquire.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, ladies and gentlemen, although the agreement reached in Paris is a strong and encouraging sign, as 195 countries have managed to reach an agreement, I do not hide my disappointment. Indeed, I would have liked to have had a binding international agreement in Paris so that as many people as possible, and in particular the most emitting countries, could approve it. However, let us consider that this summit is the starting point for a new collective international awareness on the issue of climate change, and in particular on its attendant disturbances, floods, hurricanes, droughts, which we are facing more and more frequently. I would also like to thank our Commissioner, Miguel Arias Caete, who has enabled the European Union to speak with one voice. In any case, for this summit to be successful, the most emitting countries, such as China, India or the United States, will have to take concrete steps. We, the European Union, represent less than 11% of global CO2 emissions. Without a concrete commitment from our partners, our efforts will be in vain. I would also like to mention the importance of credible funding, because we all know that money is the nerve of war.  Finally, I would like to reiterate the crucial role that citizens, civil society and business must play alongside governments. Indeed, they are the force of proposals and action. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: Blue card question. Thank you, Mr President.  I wanted to ask my colleague, I agree with what she said, but would you take the view, as another Member has already said, that for those in Europe who do not follow what are the agreements to sanction in such a way that instead of giving aid when they ask for money and this money can be invested in improving the system?

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear Colleague, I thank you for this question. I must say that we can only agree in this regard. Personally, I wanted a binding agreement, and to be, it must include sanctions. If aid is paid even if the commitments are not met, the consequences will have to be drawn.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Paris agreement, the first ever binding global climate deal, is a testament to the strong movement that climate activists from all over the world have built after the failed Copenhagen summit of 2009. I would like to express my thanks for the work of all the committed people who made this deal possible and, especially, the representative of the Commission for forging a strong alliance and France for brokering an outcome that surpassed the expectations of many. An unprecedented political recognition of the risk of climate change, the agreement is a new source of hope and optimism, sending investors and business a clear signal that it is worth investing in the transition to renewable energy. I am hopeful that we may use this strong foundation to build a cleaner and safer future for our planet.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we should welcome the decisive commitment made at COP 21, an ambitious approach to the safety of the planet. We needed to wait about 65 years when, for the first time, an oceanographer said we were subjecting the planet to a geophysical experience of releasing sequestered carbon whose results would be disastrous. Finally, we have the recognition of an ambitious and binding agreement. The objective of containing the temperature increase at 1.5º is a demonstration of this determination.  Monitoring the effort of each state to reduce greenhouse gases is essential. Let us not forget that economic and corporate interests that see short-term opportunities in global warming are still out there. Some applaud the thaw as an opportunity for the exploitation of more natural resources, including fossils.  The central issue is urgent mitigation. We must therefore keep the flame of this difficult global agreement burning. This is the last time for us to work to get the adoption processes going through.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the rapid climate change that the planet is experiencing is due to the distorted production and consumer model that has prevailed. The decision of the UN Summit in Paris on climate change does not create a clear framework for dealing with the phenomenon and its devastating consequences. It is unacceptable, at a time when large European states and their companies are part of the problem, to finally manage to get rich in the name of so-called Ecology by supposedly exporting clean technologies to developing countries. Another huge political inadequacy of the agreement is the lack of any reference to climate refugee status. At 166 million, their number is estimated for the period 2008-2013 alone, a figure which, unfortunately, will increase. Climate refugee status must be institutionalised immediately and future climate refugees must be distributed between states on the basis of size and population, but above all on the basis of each country's historical cumulative contribution to carbon dioxide emissions. The countries of the North, Germany and France, must assume their responsibilities so as not to turn the European South and Greece into a repository of climate refugees.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we welcome the Paris agreement and demand the sub-state role for global climate governance. The Basque Country was a founding partner, in 2012, of the Network of Regional Governments for Sustainable Development. Our economy is growing by reducing emissions and our country chairs the European section of The Climate Group, which links forty-four regional and local governments around the world.  Our president, lehendakari Iñigo Urkullu, presented in Paris the contribution of this group to halve greenhouse gas emissions by 2020 and 80% by 2050, in an area inhabited by 315 million people, which account for one-eighth of the world economy. The plan includes homogeneous data, concrete commitments and transparent evaluation mechanisms for all participants.  Sustainability is also one of the global contributions of San Sebastian's "Donostia 2016" programme as the European capital of culture. I invite you all, and in particular Commissioner Arias Cañete, who I congratulate on his role at the summit, to know this initiative, and I ask the Commissioner how he will integrate the role of regional and local institutions into European climate change policies.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
