text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all Members who have made very valuable contributions. I do not intend to resign at this moment, because I have to keep on working to deliver all the legislation needed to fulfil our 40% target. But when we say that Paris is a historic moment, it is not only because we have a binding agreement. I will make some comments on that later on.  We have probably not acknowledged the importance of the 187 INDCs on the table, covering 97% of global emissions. What that shows is an unstoppable movement towards sustainable energy, towards renewables, and towards energy efficiency all over the world. If you examine the INDCs, most of them were renewables, energy efficiency and some forest management. That is a big amount. From the smallest island in the Pacific to the biggest developed country. That is a major change. In that context, we have very clear work to do: sustainable energy and the phasing-out of fossil fuel subsidies. It is very clear that this is what we have to do. We now have to implement the legislation within the European Union. We have a 40% target which is, by a long way, the most ambitious INDC on the table at the moment. You can analyse all of them. Ours is the most ambitious. We also have the right policies, so we have to implement them. Mr Eickhout, a good friend, told me now we have to raise the level of ambition. Firstly, I intend to implement the necessary legislation with ambition. In the impact assessments, we will introduce the 30-35-40% scenarios – for sure.  (Interjection from the floor) Is 35 not better? (Interjection from the floor)  I do not mind, let us go for it. We want to analyse where we are in terms of cost efficiency for reaching ambitious targets.  I am for transparency and ambition, but we should also know what is going to happen. In their decisions, the COP decided to convene a facilitative dialogue among parties in 2018 in order to take stock. I think that date is really important, not only for the stock-taking. On that day, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change will provide a special report on the impact of 1.5°C and related global greenhouse gas emission pathways. Then we will have very clear steering from the IPCC Panel in their stock-taking exercise. That date is a crucial date because on that date, the entire world – including the European Union – must decide if they are going to raise the level of ambition.  We have to be prepared for that. So let us make a good impact assessment, let us implement better legislation and let us go to that stock-taking exercise with the necessary ambition. We have many COPs and we try to tell our friends that everybody must raise their level of ambition. But there must also be a level playing field. Some people said it here. We will be the leaders, but we want all the others to go along too. We also want China to be ambitious – not in 2030, but much sooner.  Secondly, the nature of the agreement: some people say this is not a binding agreement. This agreement has all the elements of a binding agreement: the long-term goal, the stock-taking process, and the transparency and accounting rules. The problem with this agreement was with the United States and binding commitments. We spent a whole year discussing them. We have two options: to take strictly binding commitments and the United States – 12% of global emissions – out of the agreement. That is one possibility. The other is to have a universal agreement. The formula that we have is that all parties have a legally binding obligation to prepare, communicate and maintain a mitigation contribution. That is absolutely binding.  Each party must also pursue domestic mitigation missions with the aim of achieving the objectives of the contribution. Combined with robust transparency and accountability provisions, this outcome will provide a solid basis for a fully inclusive regime. It will also address the need for internationally legally binding obligations and provide some flexibility to secure swift United States participation through an executive text. It is not perfect, for sure, but it is quite different from having an agreement without the United States. We need universal agreement. Let me say something about aviation. This was a very hard topic. We have established all kinds of alliances, but we did not find the same level of support in aviation as for these topics, and there was a lot of direct opposition from some parties.  We tried until Saturday in the morning to get aviation inside, but we did not succeed. In an international negotiation, you never get 100%, but I can assure you that we were trying until the last meeting. Nevertheless, even if there is not a reference to these two sectors, it is very clear that the ambitious global target we have – well below 1.5ºC – means that all sectors and all countries have to contribute. It is a certainty that they have to contribute. Now 2016 will be a key year for these two sectors to show leadership, and for the ICAO and IMO to deliver credible outcomes. We will remain very actively involved throughout the year in pressing for a solution in ICAO for a global marketplace. We will do our best, and we will try to win the same alliances and some other different alliances in order to reach this outcome, in  2016.  I take the comments made by Mr Eickhout on this topic very seriously. This is a complex topic, mainly because if you take aviation at the moment, when I say that INDCs cover 97% of emissions, 1.5 is international transport emissions. That is today, because they are rising exponentially. The other sectors are coming down, so the percentage in the future of the maritime and aviation sectors will be enormous, and we will establish clear rules on monitoring, verification and reducing emissions. The activity we do in other sectors will be meaningless. The Commission is very clear on this situation, and we will do our best.  Finally, I commend our local communities and regions. Within the mitigation and adaptation policies, acting at the local level is of the utmost importance. That is why the Covenant of Mayors, with Mayors Adapt, is an initiative the Commission is going to support. We are going to support the model internationally, because this is a history of success. We have to work with regions, communities and support the European model to the rest of the world. Mainly because the urbanisation process is unstoppable across the world, we have to work in the cities. From that, the Commission will be very clear when we design our policies. Thank you for all of your comments and now starts the real work.

name: Camille Gira
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Commissioner, thank you first of all for these debates and for the many thanks you have given us as President. I would, of course, like to relay these thanks to Mrs Dieschbourg, who is very much involved in this process. I also thank you for the fact that we can continue to count on the support of most of this great Parliament. I will not answer those who always claim that there is no climate change and, above all, that it is not due to our activities. It is true that we are in a democracy and that, in a democracy, many things can be claimed. We can always say that the Earth is flat, but I think that those who make such remarks cannot demand that they be answered. So let's move on! With regard to what the European Union has managed to pass through paris, it is true that we are also not 100% satisfied, but - I will repeat what many of you have already said - you know better than I do how difficult it is to reach agreements at 28 and you can imagine how much more difficult it is to reach an agreement between 196 parties. I will quote Laurent Fabius, who said: "If every party comes to Paris to get 100% of what it wants, we will have 0% for everyone". We would have liked to have included aviation and the maritime sector, and I can confirm what the Commissioner said: we fought to the end, but the opposition was too strong. We also lack a mid-century target for 2050. We would have liked to have had a more concrete figure than the wording in the agreement, but on this point too, the opposition was too great. But I can assure you that Europe has been a very strong partner and that we have put many of our ideas across, without the need to cross our red lines. I can compare: I was in Copenhagen and Lima, and for me, in these two conferences, the European Union was neither visible nor audible. I was ashamed to be a European! But in Paris, believe me, I was proud to be among the Europeans who played a very important role. I agree with all those who have said that, of course, this agreement is not going to solve everything. We agree that an agreement will not change the climate and a treaty will not change the world. It is paper, as some have said. But for the rest, look what's being done. The world is already on the move, there are countries, European countries that are on the move. The conference was not even over as President Hollande himself pledged to the 196 parties that he would increase France's contribution, both in terms of reducing emissions and contributing to climate finance. I have just heard from the German environment minister who said that Germany would accelerate the exit of coal. I am very pleased, as a former mayor of a small municipality in Luxembourg, that the Commission has managed to release EUR 60 million to globalise the Covenant of Mayors. There are millions of people on the march, and in the United States there are cities and states that are on the march, and let us not forget the NGOs that did a great job before Paris and will continue after that. I think the signal that is given to all these players is there; there is a paradigm shift. I do not know if you are familiar with the halma game, which is to place sticks that should not be moved. So what has been the situation of the parties and the states so far? Until now no one wanted to move because everyone thought that the first one who moved would lose. In the future, the opposite will happen, ladies and gentlemen: it is the one who will not move in the area of climate change who will lose. I believe that the European Union has always been very ambitious, that it has led the way for others, and I am sure that with your support, the European Union will not be one of those who will be punished by history because they will come too late. At the end of the discussions, and bearing in mind the atmosphere that prevailed in Paris after Mr Hollande's hammer blow, I would like to quote the representative of St Lucia who, during his contribution at the end of the conference, said: The future looks much better than three weeks ago.'

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. – The results of the Paris Climate Summit have been welcomed in many and many different ways around the world in recent days. It is an indisputable fact that on 12 December 2015 the international community took a historic step in the fight against climate change. In Paris, the global responsibility to avoid the catastrophic consequences of climate change has become palpable. After Paris, no one can ignore the fact of man-made global warming without serious consequences. Since Paris, the world has taken its own future much more seriously.  The main objective of the climate agreement between the 195 countries of the world is to keep the global average temperature increase well below 2 degrees Celsius. However, achieving this presents an unprecedented challenge for the international community. The operation of a system based on voluntary emission reduction commitments and regular review, as well as transparency and monitoring of national implementation, has many question marks for us.  The European Parliament has a key role to play in monitoring this work and in taking on enthusiastic commitments. Indeed, the shortcomings of the Convention can only be filled in the period ahead by continuing the unprecedented international commitment that has just been established. Finally, I would like to stress that particular attention should be paid to the fact that the tasks relating to the climate agreement are described in a clear way. Straight talk is needed, because the transition to a low-carbon economy, "ecological conversion", requires profound changes from all people.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – Paris has achieved a great result: the 2-degree limit has been successfully adopted with a memorandum of understanding. Action must now be taken quickly and the right incentives must be put in place for the economy and industry. It will be of particular importance what action the Member States take without restricting Europe's competitiveness. Technological development in this area has made enormous progress, so that implementing national action plans would provide a boost for energy-efficient industry and research. The mandatory ratification of Europe to achieve the 2050 climate targets is only a first step, if it is not also achieved that the rest of the world, which has only voluntarily committed itself to the agreement, remains committed to it. This is a major challenge for Europe's competitiveness, because only those companies that are making the greatest technological advances in the field of climate protection and energy efficiency will be able to compete with each other. The dialogue between politics and business must now be stepped up so that all stakeholders can benefit from the new agreement. This is the only way to ensure that Europe can maintain a sustainable position in the field of climate policy. Financial markets also need regulatory reliability in order to respond appropriately to the new challenges. The FSB will set up a Climate Change Disclosure Task Force to create a new market for the transition to a low-carbon economy.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. – COP 21 has opened a new chapter in the history of climate protection: with the approval of all 189 states to the internationally binding Paris Agreement, we are on the right track – from the ambition to date less to the action of all parties involved. In the face of the global problem of climate change, it is clear that the international community can achieve world-changing things. Implementation is all the more important now: in addition to funding EUR 100 billion, the audit of inDCs every five years is therefore essential to achieve the 1.5°C target. The great ambitions before COP 21 need just as much energy and commitment after COP 21. In doing so, we are also sending a clear signal to business, investors and politicians that there is no way around climate protection. Investments in technology, emission reduction and CO2 neutrality have finally been given the international legal framework. I would like to thank the European Parliament's COP 21 delegation, Commissioner Arias Caete and the French Conference Presidency for the success of the negotiations.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. – In Paris, a significant step forward in the fight against climate change and the care of our planet was achieved at the final session of the Climate Conference. The 195 states agreed that serious measures need to be taken in the time to come to keep the average temperature increase from pre-industrial times below 2°C.  States agreed to make the agreement binding and in line with their capabilities and the promises they made before the meeting. Also, in fulfilling their commitments, states have pledged to continue their efforts to keep global temperature rises even below 1.5°C, which will reduce the risks and effects of climate change that are already visible today and cause millions in damage worldwide.  I am pleased to reach an agreement, especially as I personally participated in a much-anticipated conference in Copenhagen, and the deal was ultimately absent because the countries that are the largest producers of greenhouse gases did not want to agree to a deal. In recent years, the awareness of the ruling elites has changed due to the damage caused by climate change that has led to the loss of a home for a large number of people and endangered their livelihoods, and they have all decided on behalf of their states to contribute to the achievement of this important Paris Agreement.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The agreement reached at COP21 is an agreement that continues without responding to climate change for several reasons: 1.Commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions are not binding on states and, continuing to do so, global warming will continue to increase. 2.It continues betting on the commodification of the climate, by maintaining instruments such as the carbon market, which allows those who have money to pay to continue emitting greenhouse gases. 3.The consumption model, the development model, the industrialization of agriculture, nor the world trade model that is driven, wasteful of energy and resources is not questioned. 4.It is a selfish agreement, which once again places the interests of industry and western powers above the rights of peoples and peoples, particularly coastal peoples who need to be rehoused because rising waters have already taken their territory. 5.Governments have failed, multinationals have won, the world has lost, but peoplewill continue their struggles until they achieve another development based on responsible consumption, renewable energy, food sovereignty, short marketing circuits, relocation of production, sustainable mobility and fossil fuel disinvestments.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. – This climate agreement is going to change the world. It is the biggest step forward on climate change in 20 years. Now 37 countries have to take action on climate change, and there will soon be 195. Of course, the text could always have been better, but it is a historic step if virtually the whole world is committed to tackling climate change.  The new agreement states that we must keep the temperature rise well below two degrees. One and a half degrees must be pursued. The latter is necessary if we are to ensure that no islands disappear into the sea. The EU will now have to do more. We have always set our policy to a two-degree rise in temperature and to the heavily outdated idea that we are the only ones fighting climate change.  Flanders and Belgium are years behind on climate policy and will now have to accelerate the pass. Nearly 200 countries will implement national climate plans. The new agreement is a support for sustainable business.  Numerous new initiatives have been launched over the past week and hundreds of billions of dollars have been released for research and sustainable projects. The world realizes that it is a bitter necessity to protect the earth and our children.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I would like to welcome the Paris agreement and the commitment of all states to this fight against climate change. It has been mentioned time and time again these days that this agreement represents a historic moment. Indeed, we are talking about an important moment for the blue planet, for our health, but now we must also act on these objectives and review how we produce and consume energy. The European Union must maintain its leading position for a climate-neutral world, for a zero-emission economy.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to begin by thanking Commissioner Arias Cañete and Minister Carole Dieschbourg and my colleagues in Parliament who took part in the negotiations for their work. I believe that the final agreement of the COP21 climate conference is a good agreement and a good starting point, especially since for the first time the agreement was signed unanimously by all 195 countries present, including the United States, India and China, the 3 countries that emit the most CO2 in the world, which sat together at the same table admitting the existence of a global problem. This is an ambitious agreement, especially as regards the commitment and effort to try to keep the temperature increase below 2 degrees compared to the pre-industrial era by aiming, if possible, at as much as 1.5 degrees. What I would like to stress, however, is that this agreement is, as I have already said, only a starting point and that much remains to be done in the coming years, and that is why we need everyone to engage and to share responsibilities more and more on the part of all the actors involved.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Anneliese Dodds and Ludak Niedermayer on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, with recommendations to the Commission on making corporate tax policy in the Union more transparent, coordinating and approximating corporate tax policy (2015/2010(INL)) (A8-0349/2015).

name: Anneliese Dodds
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, aggressive tax avoidance and evasion cost the European Union EUR 1 trillion a year. That is a huge loss for Member States, but it is an even bigger loss for the people who live in the Member States. Their public services have, in many cases, been cut to the bone while the taxes they pay have been hiked. It is also hugely unfair for those small and medium—sized businesses that pay their fair share of tax. How can they compete against giant multinationals which can get their tax bills down to almost nothing? There is a wider impact too – less tangible, but no less important. Scandals like LuxLeaks have severely undermined the public’s trust, not just in the Luxembourg Government but in tax administrations and governments across Europe. I find it impossible to explain to my constituents why giant companies like Facebook can get away with paying less in corporate tax, in a country like the UK, than the average citizen does per year in income tax. The time for hand—wringing is well and truly over. Now we need to take the hard decisions necessary to sort out the corporate tax system. Both the Commission and Member States will have to take action which, in the short term, will almost certainly be challenged by vested interests but, by stopping the vicious cycle of beggar—thy—neighbour policies, they can make their economies more efficient and help rebuild public trust in both tax authorities and governments. As with the Ferreira—Theurer report, this report shows that there is a strong consensus in the House for real hard—hitting action to be taken against tax dodging. That consensus is quite remarkable. It extends across every single political group in this Parliament. Individual MEPs from across this House have submitted amendments that have strengthened the text as, of course, have the shadow rapporteurs whose contribution has been essential. Above all, I want warmly to thank my co—rapporteur, Luděk Niedermayer, for all his incredible hard work and that of his team. Despite the inevitable differences between us, we have managed to create a text that is simultaneously comprehensive, practical and radical. As rapporteurs, we were given the brief of improving transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax. To achieve this, we drew on the work of the special committee and our own consultations with a variety of stakeholders, experts and academics. Four key measures stand out from our recommendations on transparency. First, all companies that operate across borders should report where they make their profits and where they pay their taxes. A ‘fair taxpayer’ label should be awarded to companies which engage in good tax practice. EU countries should tell each other when they introduce a new, potentially harmful, tax measure, and there must be much better protection for whistleblowers who report tax dodging. When it comes to coordination, businesses underlined to us time and time again the need for the EU to implement a full Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB). This would not set common tax rates, but would clean up the process of defining taxable assets and activities and greatly simplify tax administration.  Finally, when it comes to convergence we need clearer guidelines on tax—related state aid and a common, objective definition of tax havens. We then need to apply the definition to prevent those companies that use tax havens benefiting from EU funds. The constituency of the UK Prime Minister, for example, that of Witney in his hometown, includes 25 properties registered to tax havens and huge swathes of countryside owned in tax havens, which benefit from Common Agricultural Policy funds. We have to end this farce. To conclude, I hope that, throughout the debate to come and the vote that will follow it, we will see a continuation of our consensus so far, as a parliament, to take timely, targeted and practical measures to end tax dodging.

name: Luděk Niedermayer
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me start by saying that it was a great pleasure to work with Anneliese Dodds and with all the other shadow rapporteurs on this fascinating economic and political subject, and on an area in which we can really make things better. Anneliese Dodds talked about the revenues lost by governments. We do not know exactly what they amount to: the estimates start at tens of billions of euros a year, but there may be hundreds of billions. In any case, it is a lot of money. An even more important issue is the fact that a market in which some companies pay taxes and some do not pay is not a fair market. We must address this issue. It is not a static issue: if we do not act, the situation will just get worse, and those who pay taxes, including employees and small businesses, will have to pay more because of the others who do not pay. This is an issue that has undermined the credibility of states and governments. So we must act. We must act decisively but we must act smartly: not everything that can be done should be done. Luckily, there is enough expertise, on which we were able to build our report. I would mention the expertise of the Commission and the OECD, academics, civil society and businesses. Consequently, we have tried to put together the report with well defined, clear recommendations that are feasible and well justified. Let me look at it from a different perspective. The first area I want to mention concerns implementation of the recommendations that were the outcome of the OECD/G20 Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project. The G20 and the Commission asked the OECD to tackle this issue at global level. The results are well thought-out economic measures which have been endorsed by the governments of many countries. including the G20 and developing countries. There is no excuse for us not to implement these measures briskly. The measures concern, for example, country-by-country reporting, patent boxes, hybrid mismatches and permanent establishment. The second issue I want to highlight is the re-launch of the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base project (CCCTB). The CCCTB project has benefits both for governments, as it will generate more secure revenue collection, and, importantly, for businesses because it will substantially reduce and simplify tax compliance. There is no alternative to CCCTB if we want to tackle the issue. There is no other measure that would be as effective and as efficient at the end of the day. Lastly, let me mention some proposals that are EU specific. We want a Code of Conduct Group to function better. We want, effectively and jointly, to act against tax havens. There is the corporate social responsibility initiative that Anneliese Dodds mentioned and, last but not least, we want to work with regular estimates of the tax gap arising in the area of corporate taxation. I am very pleased that we are on the same wavelength as the Commission because we have in mind the same proposals, and I believe we will be able to convince the governments to go forward. Let me now conclude, first by thanking Anneliese Dodds for her wonderful cooperation, and all the shadow rapporteurs for their input. I look forward to the debate here and, more importantly, I believe we will gain support for the report tomorrow. I hope this is not the end. It is a start, and at the end of the day – though rather sooner than later – we will achieve the improvement that we want.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am here on behalf of my dear colleague Pierre Moscovici to express the Commission’s positions on this specific subject. Once again, Parliament is making its position on tax transparency very clear. I would particularly like to thank the rapporteurs, but also everyone else who has contributed to the drafting of this excellent report. It is rich in proposals and recommendations that will assist the Commission in moving forward on this subject of common interest. Like you, the Commission wants transparent, fair and modern taxation to become the norm in the European Union. The Commission has already taken firm steps this year to address aggressive tax planning, but we need to advance further and faster. That is why the Commission will, at the beginning of next year, present strong measures to combat tax fraud, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning within the European Union. The package which the Commission will present will be comprehensive. It will include both legislative and non-legislative initiatives. It will address both internal EU aspects and external aspects – it will contain an external strategy towards third countries. It will also include measures stemming not just from the discussions that have taken place in the EU but also internationally. For all these measures, the Commission counts on the active support of this Parliament.  Let me now come back to the main recommendations of the report. First of all, I would like to assure you that the Commission is maintaining the pace on the subject of country-by-country reporting. For us, the best way forward is to complete the impact assessment which is planned for the first quarter of 2016. We will then have the necessary data so as to be able to make appropriate proposals to the co-legislators. The Commission also wants to relaunch and make rapid progress on the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base project (CCCTB). In 2016 we intend to propose a two-step approach so that Member States reach an agreement as soon as possible. As a first step, Member States should agree on a common tax base. The consolidation would follow as a second step. I would like to stress again: the Commission remains fully committed to consolidation, but we want to overcome the current prolonged stalemate. Pending the adoption and implementation of the CCCTB, the measures included in the OECD/G20 BEPS package should be implemented in the EU rapidly and in a coordinated way. What we want to avoid at all costs is a patchwork of 28 national approaches to implementing the BEPS recommendations. A coordinated European approach towards the BEPS package is therefore essential. As regards Parliament’s recommendations on transfer pricing, I would like to stress that the Joint Transfer Pricing Forum of the EU is currently looking into the most coherent and effective implementation within the EU of the OECD guidelines. This debate, as you know, also concerns the Commission’s own internal instruments. I am thinking first of the European Semester. The Commission is, of course, ready to continue to use all the instruments at its disposal to combat tax evasion, including in the framework of the European Semester.  You are also aware of our views on state aid. Firstly, the Commission is willing to provide further guidance in the medium term to Member States and market participants on the application of state aid rules to the tax planning practices of companies. Secondly, however, to do this, the Commission first needs to close a sufficient number of cases so as to be able to assess on that basis what form of guidance would provide the necessary clarity for both Member States and market players. Thirdly, as regards the rules for recovery of state aid, these rules are based on the longstanding jurisprudence of the Court of Justice of the European Union.  A fairer distribution of tax revenues amongst Member States is a discussion that goes beyond the issue of state aid. The Commission will participate in this debate of course, bringing all relevant services into the discussion. In this way, dear colleagues, the European Parliament has a crucial role to play in maintaining political pressure and in supporting the action of the Commission in the field of taxation. The Commission, of course, counts on your support in all aspects.

name: Massimiliano Salini
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the two rapporteurs and the co-rapporteurs for the work they have done. From the point of view of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, the perspective envisaged by this work is very interesting. As the rapporteurs have pointed out, we have a main objective, to ensure that in Europe the small ones who cannot afford the luxury of tax tourism, which the large ones can afford, are put in a position to fight on equal terms in a mature market.  You have to pay the right taxes and pay them all. We have 28 different tax systems, and here the conditions are created for certain instruments, such as the rightly mentioned consolidated tax base, to make possible a gradual step towards a European tax system compatible with European economic development, so that europe can grow and have a welfare state that meets the needs of our citizens.

name: Burkhard Balz
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to make a preliminary remark: I would very much have liked the Luxembourg Presidency to have this evening in this very important debate in this Chamber, precisely because Minister Gramegna has also mentioned this as one of his priorities for these six months. And when I look at the Council here and see no one, I find that shameful. Mr. President! We must ensure that the Member States are no longer on the brakes, but allow newer and better rules, namely rules that lead to truly fair tax competition, which make tax-free allowances for multinationals a thing of the past, which will bring benefits to the EU's internal market and strengthen the competitiveness of the European business sector as a whole, and therefore also globally, and which, in the end, also mean simplification rather than more tax bureaucracy. To this end, we must push ahead with essential legislative projects such as the common consolidated corporate tax base. We naturally respect the fiscal sovereignty of the Member States, but there can be no more hiding behind them, especially when coordination is more achievable for all. The OECD has initiated significant international progress in the fight against tax avoidance and profit shifting. That is why we must continue to follow this action plan closely and ensure that tax evasion and tax evasion are no longer given a chance in Europe and internationally. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. Mr Balczó, given that you rightly attacked Mr Gramegna's absence here in this House, I wonder why we do not give political responsibility in this report to the Luxembourg Government and to Mr Juncker, who is the politician who has supported these elusive policies for more than fifteen years. If we do not give political responsibility to those states that are carrying out elusive policies, we will never be able to solve the problem. So do you agree to include Juncker's name in this report?

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Once again, a fine attempt by you, Mr Valli, to politicise the whole thing in what I believe to be the wrong direction. This is, of course, not what we see and what we want, and I believe that Pierre Gramegna belongs to a political group other than mine. I would really have liked the Presidency of the Council to have taken a very active part in this debate. That should have sent out a clear signal tonight. But, as I said, the benches are empty.

name: Hugues Bayet
text: First of all, on behalf of the Group of S and D - Mr President, I would like to congratulate my colleague Anneliese Dodds and all the rapporteurs for this work. I think the report , as you have heard , contains specific and ambitious measures to strengthen the convergence of corporate tax policies and, I would indirectly say, to effectively combat multinational tax evasion. I think that this is a constant in this European Parliament, since the SwissLeaks and LuxLeaks scandals broke; we quickly measured the need to react to implement several coordinated actions but pursuing the same objective, namely: finally, more tax justice at European level. I welcome the vote tomorrow on the Niedermayer/Dodds report. We can also mention our ambitious report by the special committee TAXE, whose mandate is extended by six months, which I welcome, but we can also pin the report on the automatic exchange of rulings between Member States, the report on taxation in developing countries or the report on shareholder rights. All this to tell you that if the evil is known, we also know the remedies. It is now up to the Commission and the Member States to set out to take up our proposals and, of course, turn them into applicable rules. We've heard a lot of speeches and beautiful speeches, that's fine. But today, we're waiting for the deeds. I think it is the vast majority of our fellow Europeans who rightly feel cheated by this situation. We have seen this again recently: in my own country, Belgium, the press reveals that the Belgian tax authorities have opened, at the end of last week, an investigation into the very advantageous agreements concluded between the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg and Belgian SMEs, providing for tax rates of 1.5 to 0%. Mr Juncker, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen of the 28 Heads of State and Government, show me that I am wrong, show me that I am wrong to find you so unaffected. Let's stop the words, let's move on to the deeds! I am counting on you, Commissioner, to move forward. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), question with "blue card". – I would really like to know whether everything that is being heard is tax justice. I'm explaining myself. We agree to tackle tax fraud, tax evasion, tax havens, the favourable environment created for multinational corporations and corporations. But is tax justice a common tax rate for all countries? The tax rate and the pursuit of a tax policy are in the social economic policy measures of a free economy and market. Are we going to do a single VAT...? (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. "Yes, I think that, really, we will only get away with fighting tax evasion with harmonization. As long as there are 28 different tax systems in the Member States, we will not get away with it. Then you may not support us. If the EPP or ALDE do not want to, that is their choice. Personally, I think it has to be done. We have been promised improvements for years, and there have been billions of euros in the public coffers for years. If that goes wrong, we will re-evaluate our proposal in a few years, but rather than say that it will not work, I think it is time to move forward and solve this problem.

name: Bernd Lucke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We all know that there is a great deal of tax avoidance in the European Union, in its Member States: by multinationals, by a large number of multinationals – not by everyone, but by many. This is detrimental to taxpayers and it is harming the competitors of these multinationals. It is therefore a challenge for legislators in the European Union to counter this. However, it is important that the EU and its institutions act together with the legislators of the Member States. It is important that they do this together. It is also necessary for them to do this together, because the proposals that we have made here, which are to a large extent good and far-making proposals, can only be implemented if we also have the agreement of the Member States to do so. Otherwise, we will not get the Council's approval. That is why it is important that we make it very clear that this is not about somehow intervening in the competence of the Member States, regulating tax matters, of maintaining the distribution of powers – the Member States are responsible for tax legislation, and the Commission is responsible for competition.  If we do not respect that, we will not move forward. In the area of competition, in the area of competition supervision, enough has to be done. From Luxembourg alone, we know, there are more than 5000 cases of possible state aid through tax measures. The Commission has only been able to deal with 65 such cases in 25 years. We need more resources for the COMP. We must strengthen the Commission with a central authority.

name: Sylvie Goulard
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would first like to thank the rapporteurs who have also done a very useful collective work and this complements the work of the TAXE Committee. I still have the impression that we are telling ourselves an old story here, that we are getting older, always telling the same things on a subject which is unfortunately - and I draw your attention, Commissioner, to this reality - more and more at the centre of the rejection of Europe by the citizens. We have sinned in two ways. The first is the internal market. We explained to people that in Europe there would be no differences depending on where an activity takes place. This applies to a multitude of other labour rules, standards and regulations. On the other hand, for all that is tax, there remains this total anomaly which is to accept that within the single market, depending on where you settle, you ultimately benefit from completely different conditions; from there, unfair competition takes place between the Member States - this has been pointed out, this question of competition is not the least. So in this regard, I think it is really urgent that the Commission re-engages in the question of the consolidated common basis for corporation tax. It is simply a question of the internal market. On the other hand, there is another particularly regrettable dimension: with the introduction of the euro and mutual control of budgets, we find ourselves with states that boast of having a triple-A rating but which, during this time, steal the tax resources of the little comrades, which allows them to improve their own performance. We have also seen that, in a country like Greece, it is not entirely neutral that we have never dared to face - I tried to do so in the two-pack - the issue of tax fraud and evasion of particularly wealthy people in Greece. So there is urgency, that is the only thing to remember. There is an urgent need to act, to stop multiplying reports, resolutions. Take responsibility!

name: Matt Carthy
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs for their efforts. There are a number of positive aspects in this report, specifically the focus on tax transparency and the need to address tax avoidance tools such as patent boxes. However, I have to say I am fundamentally concerned with the remarks that I have already heard again here tonight that the intention behind this report is to introduce tax harmony across Europe by the back door. It does not serve the interests of, for example, ordinary Irish people to have sovereignty relinquished through attempted tax harmonisation. It is absolutely and fundamentally the right of governments in each state to legislate in the best interests of their people, particularly the setting of tax rates. For our part, my party will continue to demand that genuine and credible actions are taken around corporate tax evasion, specifically in relation to the evidence which suggests that the effective rate of tax paid by multinationals and large corporations is in fact much lower than the 12.5% headline rate in Ireland. Mr Bayet and others said that whether Groups do or do not support tax harmonisation is almost irrelevant: the fact of the matter is that it is on the public record that citizens do not support it. In fact, they have stated time and time again their view that all matters relating to the setting of tax rates must remain a matter of national competency and the European Parliament has no right to attempt to attack tax sovereignty in this way. Therefore I regret to say I will be unable to support this report.

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, across our continent we see the state shrinking and being unable to fulfil its essential duties. Part of the reason for this is the failure of corporations to pay adequate tax to fund the very services that they use.  I congratulate the rapporteurs on this file for making concrete recommendations on public country-by-country reporting, tax havens and sanctions against EU companies using them. Today we are challenging the Commission to introduce these into law across the European Union to demonstrate that they will resist the power of corporate lobbying and act for the people of Europe. What has been less encouraging is the way all groups, apart from the Greens, have had Members who have put national interest above our continent’s interest. This is deeply short-sighted, since the corporations are deliberately using these variable policies on tax and the self-interest of Member States to push us all into a race to the bottom that only they can win. We are supposed to be working together for fair taxation, not dividing along national lines. Competition should be in innovation and between companies, not between Member States competing to attract companies. Finally, I would urge colleagues to support our amendment calling for a fund to protect whistle-blowers, using money clawed back from illegal sweetheart deals. The whistle-blowers have made our work possible and we should not allow them to be treated as criminals.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tax justice is a hotly felt issue in Europe and I have worked hard with many colleagues in the Taxe Committee to try to investigate this scandal that broke out last year, which saw Juncker at the centre of this practice which, for so many years, for more than 18 years, Luxembourg has been implementing under his presidency and has pursued these practices in order to charge up to 1% of taxes. to the multinationals that were entering and still entering with a red carpet within the Luxembourg Ministry of Finance.  And so if we do not give political responsibility in these reports, saying which countries are responsible and who are responsible, Juncker, for example, Dijsselbloem, who also has a political responsibility, given that the Netherlands is another country that does not respect these practices of morality that should be among the States, and therefore my fear is that some European governments do not have the slightest intention of changing the rules.  And there are some very interesting statements he made recently, for example Gramegna, who complained that European state aid rules did not give certainty to the business of companies. That is, what business do businesses have in Luxembourg? We all know what business businesses have in Luxembourg and therefore, although there are so many interesting things and which we share in this report, from country by country public reporting to the automatic exchange of information, if we do not give political responsibility to these people and stop supporting them in the Presidency of this European Commission and europeans, we will never have safe measures against tax avoidance.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this initiative report has the merit of existing, but it is largely redundant with the report of the special committee TAXE. I will therefore repeat the position we have taken before.  First of all, on the observation: we deplore the time it took the European institutions to measure the ravages of aggressive tax optimisation. Thanks to the whistleblowers! The shortfall for France would be 15 billion euros a year, probably ten times more for the Union. But I doubt the sincerity of the intentions when we know that Mr Juncker is the main architect of the LuxLeaks scandal. The same goes for Mr Dijsselbloem, who is the finance minister of the Netherlands, one of the assembly hubs that allow multinationals such as Facebook, Starbucks and Amazon to pay almost no tax.  So what answer do you give? It is important to preserve the sovereignty of states in tax matters and to combat these practices. The National Front has joined all the texts in favour of tax transparency but categorically refuses to move towards a fiscal union. I therefore once again welcome initiatives to control transfer pricing, introduce transparency in rescripts and harmonize the corporate tax bases. On the other hand, I would have liked clearer sanctions against consulting firms that help with abusive optimization.  Beyond that, it is obvious that a country like France will not save itself from a reflection on the level of its compulsory levies. Tax havens exist only in comparison with the tax hells; it's another topic, but it's related.  We need to strengthen our national fiscal attractiveness for greater legibility and stability, notably through lower levies. In France, a state-strategic and business pact will be needed to generate confidence and promote value creation.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. We need a European tax policy. This does not mean, however, that we want to standardise how much tax is taxed, but that we want to unify what is taxed and where. This must be done throughout Europe. Unanimity is blocking a European tax policy. Unanimity leads to delays, to sham solutions, to half-heartedness, it goes over the majority willing to act, and it eliminates the European Parliament. The financial transaction tax is an example of how fragmented a European solution is if unanimity is maintained. What we urgently need – and here I would ask the Commission to take up the ball that this report is once again putting on the eleven: we need country-specific reporting requirements for multinationals, because they are another means of greater transparency and fairness. We need harmonisation of the tax bases for corporate taxation in Europe. We need harmonisation of tax systems that are relevant to the internal market. That is what we are all about. Please implement the report as soon as possible!

name: Olle Ludvigsson (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I broadly welcome the report on which we are going to vote tomorrow. The work against aggressive tax planning needs to be strengthened. That is why it is quite right that we in Parliament are now pushing this agenda forward.  It is not just a question of securing resources for things such as schools, health care and infrastructure. It is also a question of ensuring fair and fair competition between large and small companies. I would like to highlight three key priorities: firstly, the BEPS guidelines, developed by the OECD and the G20, should be implemented in an ambitious and rigorous way within the EU. Secondly, eu country-by-country reporting requirements for large companies should be extended to all sectors. Thirdly, a common consolidated corporate tax base should be created within the EU. It should become compulsory and must be designed in such a way that the smaller countries are not disadvantaged. My hope now is that the European Commission will pick up these signals and make sure that it intensifies its work as early as the beginning of next year. Of course, I would also like to thank the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs for their good work.

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The TAXE report has clearly revealed the shortcomings we have in European tax competition. We have an internal market with open borders – freedom of movement of capital – and the combination of 28 over-complex tax systems creates loopholes that urgently need to be closed. I congratulate the two rapporteurs on making specific demands to the Commission now. And we in the ALDE Group, as liberals, are calling for very clear legislative proposals which, for example, will ensure that a common corporate tax base is introduced so that competition no longer takes place over the shift in the tax base, but over tax rates. And we also want an automatic, complete exchange of information. We also want the OECD's BEPS recommendations to be implemented in a binding manner. It must not be the case that these are just recommendations, we need a common European legal basis here. Only then will we reach the level playing field. That is what it is all about now!

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, socialism is the philosophy of failure, the creed of ignorance and the gospel of envy; its inherent virtue is the equal sharing of misery. So said Winston Churchill. Well, if he was in this place today, he would see that once again. The Socialists are trying to impose the equal sharing of misery across all of Europe by imposing the idea that we should have a consolidated harmonised corporate tax policy across Europe. The belief is that tax harmonisation is tax justice. If we harmonise our taxes, things will get better. Just as they said that if we harmonised the euro, the economy would get better; if we harmonised the economy in Europe, things would get better. Only look at Greece. We said if we harmonised our borders, things would get better. The only thing that is harmonised in this place is the inherent inequality of thinking of people who think harmonisation will actually work.

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs. They did a good job, a great listing, more than just a wish list. But the pressure we want to exert is missing here. I do not see Mr Moscovici, who has been represented. The Luxembourgers, the main ones affected, have left. I think it is a provocation of the Way in which the Council is dealing with us on this issue. They should have been sitting there out of recognition from Parliament, even if they could not have said anything. That is why we need to increase the pressure. Only that helps!  I am in favour of public coverage of country-by-country reporting – for a public! Only then will the pressure be so great that it cannot be circumvented in the end. Nor are it the large companies that are exploiting the loopholes, the main culprits, but the states, especially the small states, and the islands – such as Gibraltar or the Channel Islands – from the big states: Great Britain.  This has nothing to do with the competence of the Member States, which is unfair tax competition to the detriment of workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, at the expense of the large states. Nor is it because, as Mr Lucke said, we do not have enough people in the competition directorate. No, it is the unwillingness of the Member States. I have seen 15 years here of how Luxembourg, Austria and others have prevented the withholding tax on savings. This must stop.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Langen.  We note for the Minutes: standing ovations from some colleagues.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their great effort and excellent work. If LuxLeaks has showed us anything it is that without transparency we will not get tax justice. Without transparency, multinational companies will again and again find ways to avoid paying their taxes, while citizens and small companies pay their taxes and see the big companies hide profits in tax havens. This must stop. Therefore, the Social Democrats have fought for country-by-country reporting. It has to be mandatory. It has to be public. This means that all companies that operate cross-border must publicly report on their profits and the tax that they are paying. It will secure fair competition between small- and medium-sized enterprises and multinational companies, and it will protect our tax base. It will enable all of us to protect the future of our welfare state in Europe, and it will deliver tax justice.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: – Small businesses pay too high taxes and large companies too low and that knocks people to the chest. Add to that Luxleaks and you'll get the ideal cocktail to make international appointments. Unfortunately, the Commission and the European Parliament have taken advantage of this context to advance their own agenda and talk about tax harmonisation, tax harmonisation. I have already commented on the branch committee. I have made a case for healthy tax competition there.  Does this mean we don't have to do anything, that we don't have to change anything? Of course not. We need to tackle and simplify our taxation, so that cross-border business becomes easier. Above all, we need to address these gaps in our tax system, and I am looking at what the OECD has developed, the BEPS action plan. Let us look here in this Parliament, but also in the Member States, at how we can implement these recommendations as quickly as possible and finally give everyone the solutions that are needed.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE).
text: First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Anneliese Dodds and Luděk Niedermayer, for all the incredibly hard work they have put in. There are very good intentions now, but we are not there yet, because there is a global problem. Globally, we do not yet reach everything, when we put a kind of cordon fiscal around Europe; companies then simply flee outside Europe.  So I would actually like to encourage Mr Moscovici - unfortunately he is not there - to draw inspiration from what his colleague Fabius has recently achieved, namely, where it seemed unlikely to get all the countries together in one agreement; the Commissioner should also try to do the same in the area of taxation. Furthermore, I would like to stress that with Tax 2 - it sounds almost like a follow-up film to an earlier movie - we have to go on with full force; it should not become a weak infusion of Tax 1.  I agree with Mr Moscovici: we have to pay tax where the value is added. We only have to discuss the criteria in this matter.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Woolfe quoted Winston Churchill – what Churchill would have said if he was here. And I can very much agree with what Winston Churchill would have said if he was here. But the difference between you and Winston Churchill, Mr Woolfe, is that he wanted to be here. He laid the ground for a lot of this cooperation: he actually gave his name to one of our buildings here. There is a huge difference between you, Mr Woolfe, and Winston Churchill – so better let others quote Winston Churchill in this plenary, rather than yourself, because you do not want even to be here. Thanks are due to the rapporteurs who did extremely good work on a complicated subject. It is important to underline that tax is, and will remain, a national competence. It will be different in different countries and there is, I would add, sound and fair competition in relation to tax. But what we need to do is to fight unfair tax competition; we need to fight illegal tax avoidance; and we need to fight the use by Member States and governments of tax agreements as a hidden state aid, for that undermines prosperity and competition. We need to ensure that Europe can be the centre for global leaders, addressing the problems and the complexities they have in striving to be the best companies in the world.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, as you know, there have been some negative phenomena in Europe in recent years.  The first is now welcomed, without fiscal harmonisation there is no growth policy worthy of the name. Not only that, but the lack of loyalty in terms of tax behaviour on the part of companies normally penalises the smallest, that is, the most active and stimulating part of our way of producing. At the same time, unfair competition between states and between companies has taken shape, because if, instead of investing in research and innovation of the product and the process, companies go in search of the place to pay less tax, we will never be competitive in the global system.  That is why the recommendations contained in the legislative own-initiative report are very important. We need a common basis for taxes to be paid in the same way because of the characteristics of the company. We need reporting, country by country, so that everything is transparent and taxes are paid where wealth is produced.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: – Mr President, it is a pleasure to work for a fairer tax. I'm also glad there's a lot of us. A company that does not pay taxes to the country in which it operates enjoys services run by honest businesses and citizens. Tax evasion workers have access to trained labour, access to public services, motorways and railways built with taxes from others, and so on. In other words, tax evasion companies and those responsible for their activities are the worst-case bums, and the activities of these bums must be made public so that they can be boycotted by citizens and consumers. I believe that tax evasive companies must be completely excluded from public procurement everywhere, so that honest people have a better chance of succeeding in competition.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I also congratulate the authors. I also told Mrs Dodds that this is not a report, it is a real manual on what to do in the European Union. On the left of politics, I can say nothing more than that if the figure that between EUR 160 billion and EUR 190 billion of tax is not paid by large companies is true, then I say that this is exactly the same as the union's annual budget. On the one hand, governments let go so much, and on the other hand, they are very stingy when it comes to contributing to the common. But they want a Europe of people, people want a social Europe, and there is little answer to that: yes, tax, competence in the Member States.  The arrangement of taxation was not decided by the Lord God, not by the Almighty, we humans did this, so this can be changed. We do need a common fiscal union, common customs duties, common levies, common taxation, and I have also touched on vat, because it cannot be that vat on food is 0% in one country and 27% in another.  In a word, like a hundred, finally, it cannot be that large companies pay less tax than small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking you very sincerely for the work done by the two co-rapporteurs, Mrs Dodds and Mr Niedermayer. It has been an excellent job and here are all the important issues we want to address in the field of business taxation. In fact, this report too is exactly in line with everything that has been done by this Parliament and the TAXE Special Committee to drive a fundamental change in direct tax policy at European level. Direct corporate taxes, of course.  There is complete coherence between these two texts, and so it must continue to be with regard to the new legislation that will be produced, and we hope that tomorrow, in the vote, there will also be a strongly majority vote in this report. These two reports are already key to our agenda and will act as a guide for the political pressure we must continue to do to ensure that companies will pay the fair share of taxes in the European Union. (I think I have two minutes, Mr President.) We hope that after the TAXE report, Parliament's formal support for this legislative initiative report will in fact lead the Commission to continue producing the legislative texts to which it has committed itself and also lead the Council out of the unsustainable position of taking refuge unanimously in order never to move on taxation, in particular the obligation to report from country to country , public, corporate profits and taxes paid in each country, the immediate establishment of a consolidated basis as mandatory for corporate profits taxes, the creation of a list of tax havens with sanctions for the companies that use them, the protection of warning launchers, the automatic exchange of information between Member States on anticipated tax agreements , the obligation by governments to notify all new tax measures adopted at national level. These are just a few examples of a new agenda that Europe necessarily has to implement.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: This brings us to the catch-the-eye procedure. I have almost twice as many speeches as I can accept. I would therefore ask you to understand that I cannot take into account colleagues who have already spoken. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I congratulate the rapporteurs, colleague Niedermayer and colleague Dodds on an excellent report that provides a detailed overview of the problems we face due to aggressive tax planning and ingenious tax avoidance on the one hand, but also because of the opaque, often inconsistent tax policy of corporate taxation that is subject to interpretation. An uncoordinated and non-clear tax system does not favour anyone, neither countries nor entrepreneurs, least of all citizens and the development of the growing economy full of employment that we want. We lose €50-70 billion a year due to tax avoidance. These are funds taken away from innovation, science, new jobs. A major contribution to this report are the new measures that colleagues are proposing that will significantly help avoid unfair tax practices.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in a context characterised by a lack of investment and growth, a system of Community rules is truly protective of the economic and financial health of the Union only if it requires transparency, coordination and convergence in company tax policies.  It is well known that with tax rulings many companies have benefited from tax rates of less than 1% on profits then transferred to Luxembourg and that tax avoidance could result in revenue losses of up to EUR 190 billion per year for the Union with significant administrative costs and burdens for CITIZENS and SMEs. I agree with the report and the proposed recommendations, in particular the report on the mandatory notification of new tax measures and the extension of the automatic exchange of information to all rulings.  There is also an absolute need for a common and stringent definition of 'tax havens' as well as an adaptation of the definition of 'stable corporate organisation' by helping to reduce market volatility and increasing business confidence.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, this report is just one of a series of attempts to legitimize the Union-wide tax crackdown and punish the more enterprising Member States that have attracted investors through incentive tax policy. Some in this house seem to forget that members of the European Union are still independent states and as such should have the right to create a quality environment for investors on their territory through smart tax policy. If we do not already reward them for this behavior, and we should, because they attract investment from all over the world to Europe, at least leave them alone. Tax avoidance is a harmful practice that should be punished, but not used as an excuse for a war on business, as this can only lead to a new wave of job shutdowns and capital and brain drain from Europe, so the tax will no longer have anyone to pay.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, mr President, I would like to the facts of the LuxLeaks scandal are shocking. The Union's revenues foregone are estimated at the most modestly accounting for around 50 % of the Union's total annual budget. These abuses took place in the richest, solidarity-declaring country of the European Union. And it is done at a time when everyone is tightening their belts to deal with the crisis. It must also be held that aggressive tax avoidance practices have become a daily strategy for large corporations. The conclusions of this case must be drawn not only by law enforcement, but also by us politicians. I welcome the report's emphasis on better tax administration and transparency measures. At the same time, I stress that I have missed the recommendations on simplifying the european union's common tax policy. In particular, so that businesses do not have the desire to create fraud lands.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the A study commissioned by the European Parliament shows that the Member States of the European Union lose EUR 190 billion each year through profit shifting, special tax arrangements, inefficient tax collection and similar practices. In view of this volume, the fight against aggressive tax planning by multinationals is a top priority, and this report makes a valuable contribution to the transparent design, coordination and harmonisation of EU corporate tax. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteurs. The high priority of the fight against tax avoidance and avoidance is also demonstrated by the extension of the mandate for the TAXE Committee, the report on the automatic exchange of tax rulings and transfer pricing agreements and the report of the TAXE Special Committee and the OECD BEPS initiative. This report contains a number of measures aimed at ensuring fair tax competition between groups and SMEs and ensuring that taxation is actually carried out at the place of delivery of services. This is to be achieved through a common corporate tax base, country-specific reporting and the introduction of a "fair tax payer" ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to highlight the quality of the report submitted and I would like to thank the rapporteurs. I realize that the question is highly not only professional, but also political. I think there is, of course, no doubt that some elements of taxation should be harmonised, they should be uniform. I don't think that's even the basic level of contention. However, I am not sure that a common tax base should be the path that Europe will take. I am aware that it is not possible to construct a European agreement when there is actually a lack of a global agreement, but what they have created in Luxembourg and not just there, so I think it is really unfair tax competition. It is a practice that is perving a market that is based on will, and I think it is such a blow under the belt towards other Member States and citizens who believe in a common Europe. I therefore support what has already been put forward and think that this constitutes an appropriate basis for further reflection.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I simply wanted to say that national sovereignty, which some claim for fiscal policy, is clearly and clearly causing unfair competition between States, unfair competition between large and small enterprises, tax havens where taxation is circumvented. This is obvious, everyone knows that.  And I believe that this report which the rapporteurs have made , which I would like to expressly congratulate – is, together with the Tax report, a real roadmap for the next five years which will serve us very much, because there is a very important social discontent in Europe calling for fair taxation. And this is what we have to do in the coming years.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for this very interesting and comprehensive debate. I saw that there is an impressive level of consensus regarding the main recommendations of the report. We all seem to agree that what is needed today is a revived corporate tax policy tailored to the reality of the 21st  century. Tax systems need to become more transparent, definitely more coordinated and more convergent, and tax competition needs to be fair. The Commission is willing and ready to work hard towards these goals and we count strongly, of course, on Parliament’s support. Let me now address, in this very strict timeframe of two minutes, a point which was raised by many of you. There were many calls for implementation of the recommendations of the OECD/G20 Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project. The new tax package which the Commission will present at the beginning of next year will address many of your concerns. I would like to be able to give you more details but it would be premature to do so before all the elements of the package have been finalised and agreed upon by the Commission. The Commission is working hard and, as soon as we are able to, we will present the package to you, but be assured that we have carefully considered and taken into account the issues that you have raised. Finally, I would like to congratulate you all again on this very timely, comprehensive and clear report with its inspiring ideas. There is no time for ‘business as usual’. All of us – Parliament, Commission and Council – have to work rapidly and efficiently together for the benefit of our citizens and businesses, and of course our single market. My last remark: this is not the end; as the rapporteur has already said, this is only the beginning.

name: Anneliese Dodds
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am sorry to have again been scheduled as the first speaker. I am very much looking forward to what my co-rapporteur has to say as well, and I am grateful to colleagues for their comments. It is a shame that Mr Woolfe, Mr Carthy and Ms Tomašić have left, because the first thing I wanted to do was to correct the misconception that they stated in this Chamber. This report in no place calls for tax harmonisation or for a harmonised tax rate across Europe. It does not state that anywhere. Yet time and time again, that argument has been wheeled out to block action against tax dodging. How on earth is it fair that some huge companies’ tax advisers are able to play off definitional ambiguities about what is taxable in different countries? That is not about competition. In fact it is barely compatible, I would say, with the single market. It certainly is not fair and it is harming small businesses right across Europe. So please, let us stop using that excuse to block action on tax dodging.  If the report is approved tomorrow, as you all know the Commission will have a year to implement its recommendations or to explain why it cannot implement those recommendations. I very much welcome what we heard today coming from the Commission. But as others have stated, much of the battle here will be with Member States. All of them say they want to do something against tax dodging, but when it comes to the detail they have been less forthcoming. I hope that colleagues will continue to support action in this area.  We do not have the luxury of years and years to procrastinate and hope for the best on this issue. We need the billions of euros that are being lost because of tax dodging now for revenues for Member States. We need a level playing field now for our small businesses, and we need a level playing field now for our constituents, many of whose tax bills have increased, while those for some large multinationals have been reduced to almost zero. We have got to rise to this policy challenge now.

name: Luděk Niedermayer
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, let me thank all colleagues for their kind words. After working for many months with Anneliese I am not surprised that she made the same comment I would make concerning the remarks of some of my colleagues. As a former economist, I am sure that the current situation is not sustainable and I believe that no country is currently benefiting from the current situation or will benefit from it in the future. So we need a change. The questions are quite simple. Do we want to allow some firms to benefit from very low effective taxation and ask others to pay in their place? Do we want to allow some countries to redirect, intentionally or unintentionally, tax revenues from the budget of other countries to their budget? Do we want to allow or encourage some firms to benefit from very low taxation, thus creating a tax advantage and unfair conditions on the market? I guess the answer is and should be ‘no’.  I believe that we should allow countries to compete on taxation, but on fair and transparent grounds. We should aim for lower taxes, but lower taxes for everyone, not only for some. I hope that Parliament will support the report tomorrow.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 16 December 2015. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. Mr President, the effectiveness of the tax system is based on transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate profits tax policies in the EU. With these 'intra-group' transactions, multinational companies have been able to avoid tax, so that their profits are taxed at minimum rates in corresponding tax havens. Of course, this has resulted in a reduction in tax revenues in the countries in which they make their profits. It is therefore clear that such practices act against transparency in the field of taxation. This makes it necessary to combat tax evasion in all EU countries. In addition, it is necessary to have an automatic exchange of information on the various financial activities. Tax lawlessness and multinationals' recourse to tax havens should also be hit. The profits of each company should be taxed in the country where they are made.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Bas Belder's report on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on EU-China relations (2015/2003(INI)) (A8-0350/2015).

name: Bas Belder
