text: Rapporteur. – First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the shadow rapporteurs and all other people directly involved in this EU-China report for constructive, valuable cooperation. The report even deserves parliament's support because it raises the crucial eu-China relations in their full breadth and depth.  In the meantime, these relations are developing rapidly, which is why I am also calling for an annual EP report on EU-China relations in response to an equal report by the High Representative. In writing this report, I gratefully used the expertise of foreign correspondents in China. Their reporting contributes in no small part to the public perception of China in Europe. Counterproductive, however, the serious obstacles faced by foreign journalists in China continue unabated. Of course, Chinese media can now operate completely freely in Europe. We fully support that.  Hence my unfulme-made plea through an amendment for mutual media freedom between the EU and China. I regret this omission in the report. A previous report did say so. Important for the report was also the academic input I received. Because a strategic partnership - and this is the case between the EU and China - requires mutual clarity in the precise views and intentions of both sides. Inaccurate Western translations or depictions of Chinese political positions can be misleading. In two cases, we find this in the report: it concerns the universality of human rights and the rule of law.  As far as the rule of law is concerned, the Chinese government does not object to this Western translation, but President Xi Jinping does not leave any ambiguity that his country will not adopt western style of law. And on China's position on the scope of human rights, it was officially stressed this summer that Beijing is committed to, I quote 'the combination of the principle of universality of human rights with the reality of China's national circumstances'. Both examples underline the European need to know Chinese political positions accurately and recognise the appropriate and fair development of relations between them.  I am in no doubt that the EU and China can do a great deal for each other's citizens in their strategic partnership. The report goes into detail. However, this requires an open attitude from both parties, both self-directed and partner-oriented. Above all, a solid foundation for this mutual openness is a genuine interest in each other and mutual well-being. My wish is that this report will deepen and strengthen European-Chinese relations!

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I am pleased on behalf of the High Representative, Federica Mogherini, to introduce this important plenary debate on the latest European Parliament report on EU-China relations. First of all, may I congratulate Mr Bas Belder who is a veteran of the past three reports on China. The valuable work by him, by the shadow rapporteurs and by AFET as a whole is clearly visible in this very comprehensive report. As you know, the High Representative’s interactions with China have been considerable this year. She held her first high-level strategic dialogue with China on the 14th anniversary of our diplomatic relations in May in Beijing, and had further interactions at the 17th EU-China summit in Brussels, the ASEAN Regional Forum in Kuala Lumpur, and the 12th ASEM Foreign Ministers meeting in Luxembourg. That is not forgetting China’s constant presence in the Iran talks that helped make the deal. At the level of officials, there have been around 120 meetings and visits this year. Members of the European Parliament have also been active in seeking contact and visiting – not least, of course, the President of the European Parliament. The first thing we wish to emphasise is the importance of the EU-China Partnership for both sides. It is not just that EU-China relations are a vital source of economic dynamism in Europe. We need to remember also that China needs the EU just as much as Europe needs China. China knows that its relationship with Europe is vital for its economic well-being and social stability. E-knowhow and technologies assist China’s economic and governance reforms and reduce vulnerabilities in its economy. Recent concerns about the risk of a hard landing of the Chinese economy as underlined in the report show that the EU has a huge stake in the success of China’s economic and governance reforms, and in supporting a well-managed transition to a more market-driven economy. It should be remembered that China’s gradual opening up of its economy to foreign investment has helped to stimulate the big economic growth needed to lift 600 million Chinese citizens out of extreme poverty, of which fact China is rightly proud. The report acknowledges that the EU-China Investment Agreement negotiations represent one of the most important issues in EU-China bilateral economic and trade relations. The report underlines the need for balanced economic growth and the fact that the investment agreement contains disciplines for sustainable development. The EU is indeed pursuing such disciplines with China, as it does in all its agreements. We are aware of the difficulties EU companies face in their effort to access the market and operate their investments in China. We are committed to pursuing new market access opportunities, as well as overall improvements in China’s regulatory framework. In this respect, our EU delegation in Beijing, in close coordination with Member States, has participated actively in the open consultations conducted by the Chinese Government on the cyber-security, counterterrorism, NGO and national security draft laws. We will continue to put pressure on the Chinese Government and point out that these laws work directly against China’s economic interests, stifling creativity, innovation and precisely the inward investment that China cherishes and needs to avoid the middle income trap. The EU and its Member States will continue to engage China and encourage it to see its own interests in fulfilling its commitments to uphold universal values and standards as recommended by your report. The EU Special Representative for Human Rights visited China this year and our human rights dialogue was held there two weeks ago. The report lists many areas where China’s human rights record does not live up to international standards. Indeed, the situation there is deteriorating. The European Parliament, jointly with the other EU institutions, must continue to make the argument that China’s stance risks leading to more, rather than less, instability in China. On the foreign policy front, we need to look at ways of encouraging China to do more multilaterally, especially in Africa, the Middle East and Afghanistan. The High Representative’s work with the Chinese counterparts since she took office has convinced her that there is considerable potential to boost EU-China foreign policy and security cooperation. China can be a positive force in the world by making a more substantive contribution to global security and exercising its UN Security Council role accordingly. Given China’s increased willingness to work via the UN, positive areas of cooperation could be developed, including in peacekeeping, humanitarian affairs, disaster risk management, economic and social rights, and health. China could also take greater responsibility internationally concerning migration. Climate change, green growth, development assistance and the sustainable development goals are also important areas. Here the relationship has the potential to grow and I have to say that China’s role in achieving the Paris Agreement on Climate Change has been positive. China’s forthcoming G20 presidency, the WTO and fora such as the EBRD offer further avenues for EU-China cooperation on aspects of international governance. We note the position taken in the report on the South China Sea. The EU takes no position on claims but remains strongly committed to unimpeded commerce, to the freedom of navigation, right of transit passage and to the freedom of aviation according to international law, in particular as reflected in the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. The EU strongly opposes any attempt to assert territorial or maritime claims through the use of intimidation, coercion, force or any unilateral action which could cause further friction. Here, as in many cases, we do consult with the United States and other like-minded partners, but naturally take decisions based on our own assessment, our own interests and values. Finally, I wish to close on the issue of EU unity. The EU must be cohesive and effective in the pursuit of its own interests while upholding its values and international law. The EU-China framework should provide a guideline which strengthens Member States in their own dealings with China. Our negotiating strength will always be stronger when the 28 act as one.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen Belder, Mr B-tikofer, Leinen and other shadow rapporteurs who have been working with me on this report, thank you all very much. We've done a job that will be put to a vote tomorrow. China is a strategic partner of the European Union and a key player on the international stage. With last June's XVII European Union-China Summit in Brussels, we held forty years of diplomatic relations and sent, I believe, an important signal for closer cooperation with China.  The continued strengthening of our bilateral relationship has enormous potential that we must be able to harness, without prejudice to the central importance of our transatlantic relations in the Pacific; and particularly in China—which will soon be the first global economic power—much of the future is played. At the same time, China needs to be progressively involved in managing global challenges and threats by taking responsibility and acting in accordance with established standards for all.  In this regard, I would like to stress the importance of China's respect for an open global economy. China is trying to make an economic transition to a market economy. A successful transition will be beneficial for China and also for the rest of the world. Acts of intimidation and unilateral actions in the South China Sea are an element of particular concern. What happens there has a major international dimension.  Finally, I would like to stress the importance that has been given justifiably in this report to the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. Their violation — it is worth noting the plight of the Tibetan people, as well as that of other minorities such as the Christian one , is a major concern.  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Jo Leinen
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Mr Schmit, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the president for his excellent work and for the work he has The S&D Group is in favour of developing the EU's strategic partnership with China at all levels. China and the EU have different political systems. This results in different views and opinions on very different topics. However, this should not prevent us from working closely and trustingly for both bilateral and global benefit. Strategic partnership at economic, political and cultural level is also at the heart of this report. That is the essence of This Report by Parliament. The mention of some recent events should not obscure the fact that we are concentrating on this strategic partnership. China and the EU have done and achieved much together in 40 years of diplomatic relations. I think there is much more to be achieved and done in the next few years. We want economic relations to be developed and we are in favour of an investment agreement between the EU and China. China's participation in the Juncker Investment Plan and our consideration of participating in investment in the new Silk Road can be an important step forward.  However, we want a fair exchange. We are very much against all forms of dumping and, of course, against discriminatory obstacles for European companies in the Chinese market – this is also addressed in the report. China and the EU are global players. We also need to work more and more together for global challenges – for peace and development in the world. The key words are mentioned: whether cyber security is, stability of the financial markets, the fight against terrorism – there is still a lot that can and must happen. We are therefore concerned about the tensions in the South China Sea. Here, the dialogue with the ASEAN countries, with our neighbours and also the use of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea must be fully exploited. I mentioned different political systems. We are concerned about the curtailment of the freedom of the people in China, about discrimination, including human rights. The human rights dialogue and the rule of law dialogue are so important here, as is the dialogue on Tibet, on Xinjiang province, on relations in the Taiwan Strait and, of course, on democratic development in Hong Kong. I believe that our report is a template for the High Representatives' China strategy.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the ECR supports strong EU relations with China as one of the UN Security Council ‘Permanent Five’ and a strategic and global actor. Recently President Xi visited the UK on a state visit, and he was accorded the highest honours as a mark of how important the bilateral relationship is. Nevertheless, I have been a long-standing critic of the lack of human rights in China. I criticised the bullying of peaceful democratic Taiwan through its exclusion from all international organisations. I criticised the repression of peaceful Tibetan culture, the persecution of Falun Gong practitioners and other religious minorities, and the widespread censorship of the media, including Google, as well as military expansion in the China Seas. I also condemned the widespread use of the death sentence for lesser crimes such as economic subversion and pimping, believe it or not. We cannot ignore the importance of the People’s Republic of China but must never lose sight of the fact that it is a one-party communist dictatorship. The EU has much more in common with democratic India, so more needs to be done to enhance our partnership with it. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr Tannock. One minute. One minute. Mr Tannock, Mr Tannock ... (Interruption by Charles Tannock) You possibly hear more than you shout.  (Interruption by Charles Tannock) Possibly you hear ... I try to explain. Mr Tannock, I have admonished you three times with a discreet hammer. The interpreter's booth - I'm sure you ... (Interruption by Charles Tannock) We already know each other for a few days. I am convinced that you now believe that I have something personal against you. That is not the case. I even find you personally very sympathetic. But you talk too fast all the time. And if you were to try to translate what you say into any of the languages you can, you would know what a difficult job the interpreters are doing. I have you three times during the speech – let me excuse you, otherwise I will call you to order – I have you through three times ... (Interruption by Charles Tannock) Mr Tannock, you do not have the floor.  Mr Tannock, Mr Tannock, Mr Tannock, I call you to order. I call you to order. I did not take the floor from you because you have spoken for too long, but because I have drawn your attention three times to the fact that the interpreting booths – I can explain the system to you – are sending an emergency call here because you are too fast. That is why I have withdrawn the floor from you, not because you have spoken for too long. I myself know that I was not sufficiently attentive to the two previous speakers before, because I looked up something here and who therefore spoke longer than I normally do. But I have withdrawn the floor because you are speaking too quickly.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, we have had this discussion before. I have a right to speak at a rate I choose to do so to make my points in a language that 90% of the Parliament understands. I am sorry if I go too fast ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Tannock, you must not speak as long as you want or as fast as you want. Because if the interpreting booths here stop interpreting, then any colleague can complain. And then the session ends anyway. That is why not everyone can talk as quickly as they want, certainly not as long as they want. (Interruption by Charles Tannock) Even if you repeat it and even if you scream, sir, it will not get any better. I give you the second call to order! If you let it come down to a third, I will have you removed from the Chamber. (Interruption by Charles Tannock) Mr Tannock, I refer you to the Chamber. I refer you to the Chamber. There is now enough noise made. On a point of order.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, Mr Tannock is a political opponent of mine, not only from a different political party but from a different political group, but I have to come to his defence. He was cut off at exactly one minute. I think you have a duty to be impartial to Members of all political groups and political parties, and certainly from where I am sitting, with respect, that was not what I observed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I have now explained to him three times – and if you had listened, you would know – that I did not withdraw the floor from him because he exceeded speaking time, but because he exceeded the speed of speech. We have a button here – I can show you this and explain this – and it says: Slow down. And if several interpreting booths press at the same time and can no longer provide a proper translation, then a lamp is lit here, and then I am obliged to draw the attention of my colleague.  I've done this three times with this noise (the president hits the desk with the hammer). He did not respond. That is why I withdrew his word because he spoke too quickly.

name: Urmas Paet
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank – The European Union and China share the objective of developing relations in a growing number of areas. This includes, of course, the role of economic and trade relations, in which it is important that the Investment Protection Agreement finally becomes operational. However, the current general positive background in European-China relations also gives hope of real change in many other areas.  China is active on a wide range of global issues that are of utmost importance to Europe, such as climate change, the recently concluded climate agreement in Paris and the implementation of this agreement, as well as non-proliferation, counter-terrorism, urbanisation and energy security. However, there are areas where more effort must surely be made to find common ground. I consider it extremely important to cooperate more on security and defence policy issues, especially in view of, for example, the fight against terrorism in Ukraine. China's support is needed in the fight against Da'esh. China has already experienced the hess of Da'esh on its own and it is important that China actively participates in international cooperation to resolve the situation in Syria, Iraq and Libya. The area of cyber security is not only a growing security problem, but it is already a very important area where action must be taken together today. China has an important role to play in ensuring the security and stability of the Asian region, so it is important that tensions in the South China Sea are reduced and peaceful solutions are found with other countries in the region. China is also one of the few that can influence North Korea. We certainly hope that China will do so more actively than before, and this will, of course, bring the broader issue of human rights to china as well. The situation of ethnic minorities in China, as well as the restriction of freedom of expression, remain a concern.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are discussing the relations between two economic and not just superpowers, the European Union and China. We believe and support a relationship of honesty and cooperation, in which one must respect each other's views on the various issues. It is important to have a channel of dialogue and cooperation between the European Union and China to address issues of global scope. The report we are discussing attempts to promote the economic, political and geostrategic interests of the European Union. It recognises the importance of economic cooperation between the European Union and China but is still trying to achieve the objective through intervention in China.  The human rights that we defend above all are used by the report to put pressure on China. This does not mean, of course, that this country must not respect human rights. Death sentences must be stopped immediately in this country and the country must reconsider its policy on a number of labour issues. As far as foreign policy is concerned, however, we believe that the European Union has a long way to go until it is entitled to make suggestions to others. The blood in Afghanistan, Libya and Syria speaks for itself. So the urges for China to follow NATO in the choices it has made find us the least opposed.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to begin by thanking Mr Belder, the rapporteur, for his openness in cooperation and his willingness to compromise.  Mr Belder, I believe you will remain a record holder for a long time in this Parliament's China reports. I would also like to thank Minister Schmit for some very clear words. This report comes in the 40th year of EU-China relations. In these 40 years we have seen many changes. But one rule still applies today, as it was 40 years ago: the exchange can only be fruitful if it is fair oncoming traffic. In other words, we must also take very clear note that China, as a global power, is becoming an issue for us, not only directly in its EU relations, but also indirectly – as it interferes in global relations. Both sides – China and the EU – remain in transition. That is why, Mr Belder, I would like to express my support for what you have said. We need an annual report in this Parliament, which the High Representative gives us, on the development of relations between China and the EU. It is developing so fast that we need this instrument – just like Congress in Washington – to stay at the height of the debate. The role of the proud Parliament is to say certain things even if they do not like them on the other side. That is why I mention, for example, our criticism of China's law against foreign non-governmental organisations or our expectation of China that it will abide by the arbitral tribunal, which is likely to be handed down by the middle of the year, by the middle of the year, the arbitral tribunal under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (Unclos). Finally, we need a common European policy on China. Only in this way can we have an effect with what we do.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate Mr Belder on this ambitious and sincere report on the issue of denied human rights, the oppression of uighur and Tibetan ethnic minorities, crushed by the policy of forced 'Chineseisation', the censorship and repression of political, civil and religious freedoms, and the barbarity of the thousands of death sentences every year.  The report certainly lacks confidence in the Juncker plan and institutions such as the International Monetary Fund, which have often adopted failed and at least ambiguous policies. I would also have liked to see a greater decision in calling for Europe to cut its political actions out of its own interests, moving away from washington's suffocating umbilical cord. But the real test will be to move from noble words to concrete political decisions. Rather than proposing the absurd, suicidal and unacceptable recognition of China's status as a free market economy, the Commission has a political and moral duty to demand genuine reciprocity, conditionality and respect for universal human rights. This is the Union we want, not the strong one with the weak and weak with the strong.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the figure of the EUR 46 billion allocated by China to the Silk Road Fund should make us all reflect on the geo-economic prospects of the transformations taking place and developments that cannot but be of great interest to the European Union; Although I fully agree with the calls that several voices have made, including the last one, about vigilance, which must be kept very high, about respect for human rights, especially for minorities and also for the rights of religious freedom, because I understand that in China certain seminaries are held behind underground doors, as in ancient Rome when they persecuted Christians, and this is not tolerable.  Let us turn the page, let us talk about what China is doing, links with new countries, some 60, including even Iran, Turkey and Serbia, which are necessary for it to obtain precious metals for its industrial production. It is a great country in the process of transformation. But what is Europe's policy towards China? Of course, we would like to hear from the High Representative, who does not honour us with his presence. It's actually not clear.  On the one hand, the European Union does not express a clear 'no' to the recognition of China as a market economy, and I would say that it is doing very well for the time being, but on the other hand it is too late to play an active role in the Silk Road project, which, as an Italian I would like to remind you, is of great interest to me, not only symbolically but because the terminus ad quem to which the Silk Road arrives is in our country and is a great historical reminiscence.  (The President withdrew the floor from the speaker)

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are instructing China here, particularly humorously, in what Mr Schmit said. Well, I propose that Mr. Schmit see what Paris looked like thirty years ago and what it looks like now, and compare Shanghai thirty years ago and see what Szanghai looks like now. We should learn from China, not the Chinese from us. We should implement their solutions.  I will give a drastic example, and here I read in the report in point H that China's family planning policy has led to a rapid ageing of the Chinese population and more than two hundred million Chinese are over sixty years old. Well, Mr. Schmit, a Chinese woman has an average of 1.5 children, and a European woman 1.2. The European Union is much better at destroying its society than Mao Tse-tung, and that is why I think the European Union must be destroyed. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: blue card question. - Colleague, have you heard about what is happening in China? What happens to the Tibetan minors, or the Uighurs, or the falun kung followers? How can you say it's better there than it is for you or even in Europe?

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. –We need to adopt Chinese methods on some issues. We do not have a Tibetan minority, and if we had it, there would certainly be no more lamas who believe in lamaism. Nor would there be Uighurs, because they would melt in our society. I don't know what's worse for Tibetans: whether to be in Europe or to be in China. In any case, they are not fleeing China somehow, and I would like you to understand that if, for example, we do not have the death penalty, then there is a retreat of 4 000 years, and there is the death penalty in China, and this makes society modern.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Mr President, I always speak after nightmarish speeches like the ones we have just heard, and it is not easy. I would like to stress the fate of Tibetans because a few days ago international human rights day was being celebrated, but they had nothing to celebrate because their rights and freedoms are constantly being violated.  Mr Belder's report takes the right approach, openly denouncing the serious deterioration of human rights in Tibet and calling for the resumption of negotiations between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama. I would like to go further today, saying that in order to put an end to the manifest violations of Tibetan rights, torture and arbitrary detention, it is time to put China in front of its responsibilities.  We must engage China publicly on the issue of Tibet, while exerting constant pressure at the highest political level. The Union and its Member States must speak with one voice to send the same message to China.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this is a very important report and I am glad that a lot has been done in order to improve the original text. Only now does the text reflect the strategic dimension of our relations with China. The EU and China are different from many points of view; they will never agree on everything, but they remain fundamental reciprocal partners nonetheless. We know, as China knows, that there is an absolute need for our cooperation to succeed in common challenges. I could mention climate change and sustainable development – as COP21 has just ended in Paris – and the position, agreed by the EU and China at the end of June this year, certainly played an important role. I could also mention security, defence and counter-terrorism, which are today more important than ever and require all actors to cooperate, or development aid which is related to the migration crisis we are confronted with. We know how important China’s investments in Europe are in relaunching the economy, and there is also a huge market for European companies wanting to enlarge their perspectives and their businesses in China.  The bilateral investment agreement needs to be put in place as soon as possible. It is good news that eight rounds of negotiations have been successfully concluded. On the other hand, we have to constantly build and rebuild the One China policy, so we need to be coherent. I find it inappropriate that the report refers to the negotiations on a bilateral investment agreement with Taiwan. Finally, I welcome the references to the importance of building synergies between China’s ‘One Belt, One Road’ initiative and the Juncker investment plan, in which China has already shown an interest.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is that China is not a democratic state; india remains the world's greatest democracy. This is a country that certainly cannot be a model of standards, although of course we can admire very rapid economic progress, and we, without giving up economic cooperation, ba, putting on it, should not, however, be an ostrich that hides its head in the sand and we should also talk about what we do not like, because this is a question not only of European standards, but also of certain humanitarian and world standards. For me, however, it is important whether this country, which has little in common with democracy, wants to work with the West, with us or with other non-democratic systems. If he does the latter, I will be very skeptical of him.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to note that the situation in Hong Kong has rightly been highlighted in this report. This former British colony was, of course, guaranteed political independence under the ‘One State, Two Systems’ agreement following the transition of British sovereignty to China in 1997. Hong Kong is a good example of a successful, and mostly democratic, Asian territory holding elections and continuing to use a system based on English common law. However, around a year ago, China attempted to interfere in the election of the Hong Kong Chief Executive, proposing that only candidates from a pre-selected list were eligible to stand. I pay tribute to the Legislative Council of Hong Kong who rejected these proposals in June, but I remain concerned by further possible Chinese interventions in Hong Kong’s democratic affairs. Hong Kong’s ability, as guaranteed by the Sino-British Joint Declaration, to continue to operate as a free and democratic territory must be maintained. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Carver, since you mentioned the election of the Chief Executive, can you please remind us when, during the time that Hong Kong was a British colony, did you allow Hong Kong citizens to elect the Chief Executive?

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the question, Mr Bütikofer. Quite frankly, we look to the future and we do not look to the past. I think you are giving an insular response in looking to the past and the lessons of the past. Quite frankly, your approach to the European Union, I believe, is a 20th Century answer to a 19th Century problem. I actually look and learn from the lessons of the past and I think it is important to take this opportunity, as I have done in this debate, to highlight that point of view.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I knew power diplomacy, I knew diplomacy of interest, we - Europe, Parliament - are inventing a diplomacy of 'rights of hommism'. It marks a certain way of doing things, a new specificity, but does it not hide something? Is it not, in a way, hypocritical? Doesn't it hide a "double standard" attitude, is it not a kind of neo-colonialism? We can ask ourselves about what we are doing in Iraq, Serbia, Libya, Syria, Turkey, the country with which we are currently negotiating while it supports terrorism. We need to find real diplomacy with China, talk about our interests, talk about our joint interests and find economic balances that are to be built and that are absolutely essential for the future of Europe and for the future of China. China is ready for that. Are you? Are you ready to have a serious discussion with China?

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I have a question for the representative of the Council. We voted on two resolutions in the European Parliament on 9 October 2013.  In the first resolution, we welcomed the opening of negotiations on an investment agreement with China. In the second resolution, we called on the European Commission and the Council to negotiate with Taiwan in parallel. When will you set the course in the Council for these negotiations to run in parallel?  We certainly agree on the one-China policy. But precisely because we agree on this, it would make sense not to negotiate with one part alone and to leave the other part to the left. One China policy should mean that we then treat China uniformly, appropriately and not forget a part.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the relationship between the European Union and China is of fundamental importance within the overall framework of our external action, which will inevitably grow in the coming years and for which it is right to be satisfied.  On the subject of international trade, the European Union is discussing with China the bilateral negotiations on investment and the negotiation of geographical indications, and we note with satisfaction the efforts that both sides are making to close a major agreement. We are now calling for even greater engagement in order to reach a speedy conclusion of both negotiations.  However, any good friendship, such as that in place and in progress between the European Union and China, is fuelled by certain essential elements for strengthening the link, and that is why we believe it is important to call for every possible effort to find a constructive solution to the issue of recognising market economy status, aware of the serious impact it could have on the Community's production system and on the world of work. The rules must be the same between the two partners, and we think it is fair to point out that they do not exist to date. (The President withdrew the floor from the Speaker)

name: Amjad Bashir (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I thank my colleague Mr Belder for his report. With power comes responsibility, and China appears to be more interested in the first whilst avoiding the second. A responsible global power cannot engage in distortive currency manipulation, bully its neighbours in the South China Sea and have a human rights record that leaves much to be desired. Beijing cannot push for recognition as a market economy while turning a blind eye to deliberately under-priced steel exports.  Steel dumping has had a devastating impact on what was the economic engine of my region, Yorkshire and the Humber. Our relationship with China should be a two-way street and I ask my colleagues to help call it to account when so many jobs are being unfairly jeopardised.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF).
text: – Mr President, over the last twenty years, the People's Republic of China has had sustained economic growth, and during this time the realities of the world economy have changed. So now is the time to rethink a European Union relationship with China, but also for bilateral agreements between Member States and China. I believe that there is now a mutual interest in the area of Chinese capital in the European Union. China does indeed have problematic chapters, but the global context must also be taken into account, highlighting the beneficial rise in relations between China and the United States, as well as the China-Brazil relationship.  Turning to the importance of this resolution, I stress that this partnership must be beneficial to all the Member States of the Union. Rethinking economic relations with China must not threaten the security of European capital, nor should it favour certain countries, but come to their aid in chapters where there are difficulties – that is why we are a union of nations. In this situation, I believe that now is the time to start renegotiating a thorough economic relationship on new grounds and criteria aimed at identifying ways in which investment from China can be integrated into The realities of Europe in the medium and long term.

name: Thomas Mann (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In the report on EU-China relations, the chapter on Tibet was adopted by a large majority. We are noting organised repression against the Tibetans. What the administration calls equal treatment is a violation of human rights. Activists are arrested and their families persecuted. The monk Tenzin Gelek died in captivity under unexplained circumstances. We demand the full exercise of Buddhism. The so-called anti-terrorism law is only intended to legitimise sanctions.  The consequence and expression of despair is the increasing number of self-immolations of monks and nuns – more than 140 in the last three years. We have warned that pollution on the Tibetan plateau is increasing dramatically. The world's third-largest glacier landscape – the source of Asia's six largest rivers – is in danger of being destroyed. Finally, it is time for the negotiations between the Dalai Lama's representatives and the Chinese authorities to finally resume!

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, with the BRICS Development Bank and the AIIB, Beijing is driving the reshaping of global governance. Yet we do not have a strong common approach to promoting the European strategic interest. There is none for the South China Sea, where tensions threaten to undermine security and destabilise key trade routes; none for the Chinese ‘One Belt, One Road’ plan, which offers important grounds for cooperation on investment. Meanwhile, China is focusing negotiations with Central and Eastern European countries on the 16 + 1 framework, which risks weakening the interests of the EU Member States that are not involved. Minister Schmit, how are we ensuring that our neighbourhood policy is strengthened rather than undermined by Chinese investment initiatives in this region? The recent impact of China’s Black Monday on the stock market and the impact on our industry of Chinese dumping, not least in the UK steel sector, show that its financial economic policies should also be put on our radar.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Communist China is changing, but are they changing their essence? The one-child policy, m.in. m.in. abortion rape of mothers in the last days before childbirth has today replaced the policy of two children, namely the brutal economic persecution of married couples and families who want to welcome more children into the world. Why is Europe silent in the face of such an attack on the most primal of human rights, the right to parenthood?

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the EU as a value-based entity is committed to promoting universal human rights and freedoms – even in our relations with big partners – in parallel to advancing our strategic and economic interests. There are three points of concern: first, the imminent adoption of a new law on foreign NGOs that would severely restrict the activities of normal civil society; second, a new law on cyber-security that would institutionalise government censorship of cyberspace; third, the fact that Tibetans and Uighurs remain endangered minorities. Both groups need credible guarantees for the preservation of their language, religion and identity. The terrible fact that 140 Tibetans have already committed self-immolation is an indication of a dramatic national desperation, which is caused by the lack of meaningful dialogue. We should convince Beijing to renew dialogue with the Dalai Lama.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – I was in Beijing a month ago in a delegation of the LIBE Commission to talk about data protection, cybersecurity, drug trafficking and other forms of organized crime coming from China or passing through China. I have been convinced of the importance of continuing the dialogue and diversifying contacts in Chinese society, as Mr Belder proposes in this report. We are interested in a fair strategic relationship with Beijing, also because of the global security challenges to which China must contribute constructively and consistently with its obligations under international law and agreements with the European Union. That is why we cannot refrain from asking Beijing to abandon internal censorship and repression on Tibetan and Uighur minorities, Christians, falun gong followers, and not only. China has 23 journalists arrested and the trial of lawyer Pu Zhiqiang is just the latest case in which the regime shoots in the foot while trying to silence human rights activists. Precisely because it occupies a permanent place on the Security Council, China's credibility in global security and stability, begins in the very region in which it is part, from the South Seas, the Korean peninsula... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in 2015 EU-China relations have turned forty years old. Throughout this time, China has undergone an extraordinary transformation at the economic and social level: several hundred million Chinese have risen out of poverty.  We need to intensify, for mutual benefit, our economic relations. European companies must be able to take advantage of the sustained growth of the Chinese economy. I also hope that the investment agreement negotiations will be concluded soon.  At the international level, China, a permanent member of the Security Council, plays a growing role, which still has before it, given its potential, a large space to explore.  We need cooperation with China. In this globalized and interdependent world, we need a China fully involved in the joint struggle against common challenges. I am thinking about climate change, development aid, terrorism, pandemics, failed states, international crime, smuggling of illegal immigrants, piracy and much more, which also includes the problem of illegal fishing.  I conclude by welcoming, Madam President, the constructive role played by the Government of Beijing at the recent Paris Conference.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: "The wise Confucius said thousands of years ago that he taught that if you cannot come to an agreement with someone on fundamental things, do not forge plans with them. By comparison, I see that the European Union as a whole and the Member States, one by one, old Member States and new Member States, all want to cooperate with China, to conclude economic agreements separately.  We will come into this chamber and the MEPs from some of the countries want to adopt tomorrow a report that will train China on all sides, rather than talking about how to bring our Juncker plan into cooperation, to put Europe's economy into the 'One Belt, One Road' programme with the new Chinese Silk Road.  I therefore propose to colleagues that old, new Member States, all of us, should think about how to work together, not how to carry on the thinking and education of the former colonial world.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Congratulations to Mr Belder. The document clearly reflects the importance of strategic relations between the EU and China, in particular the global challenges we face every day. We must find an answer for all of them together, as happened at the Paris climate conference in order to save our planet. We must work closely with China – even if we are rightly dissatisfied on a number of issues. One-party rule subordinates human rights to economic interests, religious freedom is severely restricted in Tibet, national minorities, including Uighurs, are severely persecuted, the death penalty remains in force and freedom of expression is also not respected, despite constitutional requirements.   The report calls on China to comply with its international obligations, to act responsibly and fairly in its neighbourhood relations with Taiwan and the South China Sea region...  (the President has withdrawn the floor from the Member)

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is quite clear how important relations between the European Union and China are, a country of enormous size, all the numbers there are multiplying and the potential, but also an increasingly active player on the world stage.  We therefore hope that this role will strengthen China's political, political and social responsibility, in order to contribute actively and positively to détente in the world, to the resolution of crises, wars and conflicts, to major challenges such as emigration and sustainability and security. But China's economic clod means that China must increasingly accept and assume the very rules of the world economy, completing economic reform, including workers' rights. No more social dumping and environmental protection.  In terms of industrial and trade relations, we must recognise and note with regret that European companies in the Chinese market face obstructions, obstacles and discrimination that are not appropriate to an economy that aspires to be a market economy. That is why we believe that the recognition that Europe, on which it must give its opinion shortly, of market economy status is unfair, undeserved and certainly not ... (The President withdrew the floor from the Speaker)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Now/This brings us to the catch-the-eye procedure. I have reports from three groups. As we have moved on with the times, I shall have one speaker speak per group. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to stress that this report is very important because China is an important partner for the European Union and we must define our relationship with China. China is developing and taking a more constructive stance on the world's problems, as well as on the environment and climate change. I think China rightly deserves the status of a world power. But the report also points out that under current President Xi Jinping, the Chinese government has increasingly assertive in both domestic and foreign affairs. It recognises the greater importance of the universal nature of human rights, but the results are not yet what we would like, especially in relation to religious minorities, be they Christians, or the situation in Tibet, where the environment is further degraded and cultural and political oppression are further harmed.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Madam President, my thanks to the rapporteur and the shadows. I wanted to raise the subject of steel dumping by China onto the EU market. With an estimated 94% of dumped steel landing in the UK, it is no surprise that there is currently a crisis in the UK steel industry. In Scotland, we are witnessing over 200 job losses in Cambuslang and in Motherwell. This has not been helped by the fact that steel contracts to build the new Forth Crossing were given by the SNP government in Edinburgh not to Scottish steel manufacturers, but to China. Both the UK Government and the SNP government in Edinburgh have to take responsibility for the state of our local steel sector, but what action can be taken by the Council and Commission to secure not just the future of UK and Scottish steel, but also the future of the EU steel industry?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, China is a strategic partner of the European Union. Already a few decades ago, German and other European multinationals, in order to reduce labour costs, have gone through the well-known outsourcing process, transferring all or part of their production to China, resulting in a sharp increase in unemployment in Europe. At the time, the European Union and the governments of its Member States were closing their eyes to the massive human rights violations in China.  Over the decades, China has grown into the second most powerful economy in the world and aspires to achieve a new division of labour and a redistribution of spheres of influence and exploitation in Africa and other parts of the world. Now the European Union has begun to discover human rights violations in China and shed crocodile tears for Chinese activists. Relations between the European Union and China should be based on the principle of peaceful coexistence, cooperation based on mutual benefit, the protection of human and labour rights.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, developing a strategic partnership with China is not an option: it is simply a necessity. You cannot just ‘choose’ to cooperate with the second biggest economy in the world, the most populous country in the world and a very important trading and financial power. We share with China the same interest in stability concerning the political environment and the economic and financial environment, and we share the interest of keeping the world economy stable. So we need dialogue with China. We need it in different areas and it is clear, as was mentioned here, that there is still room for improvement in many areas. That was also underlined in the report. It is true too that, as a trading partner, China has to play by the rules. Having an open market also means respecting certain rules, including no dumping practices. I was very sensitive, as you know, to what you said on steel. Luxembourg is also a steel producer, and we gave a very clear signal because we organised a special Council on this issue. It is obvious that we do not want the European steel industry to be destroyed. In this dialogue with China, as I said, we have to tackle a lot of questions, including human rights. Human rights have to occupy an important place in this dialogue. Coming to the question of investment, it was agreed at the last summit that a possible free trade agreement should be negotiated in the longer-term perspective, and we consider that the successful conclusion of these investment negotiations could also be seen in the framework of multilateral and plurilateral trade negotiation. Concerning other negotiations – and especially the launch of the Taiwan and Hong Kong investment agreement negotiations – the Commission adopted the communication on its Trade for All strategy on 14 October 2014, underlining the importance of Asia for our trade and investment relations. The communication recognises that, operating in an increasingly integrated regional supply chain, EU investors in East Asia should benefit from a broader network of investment agreements in the region. Building on the investment provisions under negotiation with China, the EU will explore, and I quote, ‘launching negotiations on investment with Hong Kong and Taiwan’. Thank you for this very useful and stimulating debate. The view of the European Parliament, as expressed in the report and also in the contributions here, provides valuable food for thought in the process of developing the new global strategy on foreign policy and security which is on the way, and for updating our tailored strategic approaches to important partners such as China. I have also noted that Parliament has requested an annual report on EU-China relations. I would like to emphasise that we are all well aware of the need to keep track of the implementation of policy commitments in the EU-China context. That is why we agreed, at this year’s EU-China Summit, to create a senior officials’ mechanism to review progress on a regular basis. We would be glad to keep the European Parliament closely informed in that regard.

name: Bas Belder
text: Rapporteur. Mr Schmit, representative of the Luxembourg Presidency, thank you very much for your position on the substance. I very much appreciate that and I hope to hear again tomorrow what exactly you have said, but I found it encouraging that you are so substantive in this report and are also looking to the future, because the changes are indeed happening quickly. I then come to two points, Madam President, which I very much appreciate. Firstly, the Neue Zürcher Zeitung reported last Saturday through its correspondent Matthias Müller - and I found this a rejoicing development - that a dark side of the one-child policy, which is now a thing of the past, was that millions of citizens were not registered. They're called "the black ones." It is probably 13 million people, 8 million of whom were not actually registered, because the parents could not pay the fine for crossing the one-child limit. So they could not go to school, could not move freely, had no social insurance. A reform commission under President Xi Jinping is now going to fix this.  A very important first step in that so-called hukou system and the second-class citizenship of the hundreds of millions of migrant workers in the smellbanized China. I welcome the fact that Beijing is now embarking on this, because it is an extremely complicated and complicated process and we in Europe must keep a close eye on the difficulty of the whole society and the burden of the past.  Now I come to the burden of the past: I fully agree with the conclusion of the religion expert and sociology professor Fenggang Yang who says: there has been one miracle in China, the economic miracle, but there is also a second miracle, namely the religious revival and in particular the flowering of Chinese Christianity. You can understand that, as a convinced Protestant, I find this an extremely positive point in Chinese development, a second miracle.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 16 December 2015. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. – China is an important trading partner of the European Union and it is advantageous to promote trade relations, but I appeal not to neglect the debate on the human rights situation. I also express my support and solidarity with people fighting for democratic reforms, especially in Hong Kong. We must also not forget the situation in Tibet, where human rights are being suppressed. In my opinion, China should also be encouraged to change its economic model to a sustainable economy with an environmental accent.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Enrique Guerrero Salom on behalf of the Committee on Development on the preparation of the World Humanitarian Summit: Challenges and Opportunities for Humanitarian Aid (2015/2051(INI)) (A8-0332/2015).

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, the United Nations has convened the first World Humanitarian Summit for next year in Istanbul. On the way to that Istanbul Summit, the Commission has drawn up a Communication, which my report values very positively and continues almost entirely. Parliament will vote on this report tomorrow and the Council has drawn provisional conclusions which will surely become final next year, closer to the summit. My report is about answering three questions. The first question is: why is a global humanitarian summit necessary now? Secondly, what objectives do we want to achieve in Istanbul? And the third, what role should the European Union play in this process? And to answer the first question, the answer is not that we need a summit now because the global humanitarian system was adopted a quarter of a century ago and the passage of time requires a change. No, the answer is deeper: because the world has changed dramatically in this quarter of a century and the humanitarian system is now unable to respond to the new challenges we encounter. Today we have more numerous, more serious humanitarian crises than ever before, of the highest level in many parts of the world. We also have major crises from natural causes and others because of war, and we have fewer means to respond to these crises, which last longer because in many cases for up to thirty years: "enceded" crises. In the face of this situation, what are the consequences? More refugees than ever before: about forty million in 2015, half of them virtually children. More people in need of humanitarian assistance: about a hundred million people needed it last year. If we grouped them all together, they would form the tying country of the world into population. For us to get an idea, all of France and all of Spain together would need humanitarian action. And we have fewer economic means, because in the last year, for example, there has been a need on the part of the United Nations to end some provision of simple humanitarian aid in some parts of the world that urgently need such aid.  To answer the second question — what should we achieve in Istanbul?—, my report took into account the global consultation process that has been carried out in different parts of the world and which has been accumulating proposals from different sectors committed to humanitarian action, and that is why I propose four axes of joint global action. First, to promote a global consensus of action that re-entrusts the principles of humanitarian aid and focuses on the protection of people. This consensus must be strengthened with an action plan of at least five years to implement the commitments reached at the Summit.  Second, promote a code of conduct; a code jointly developed by all participants, without an exclusive Western vision, and based on respect for humanitarian principles and international laws. We call for transparency and accountability to be vector values of the Summit's conclusions.  Thirdly, we call for the creation of a comprehensive humanitarian action fund to ensure the predictability, operational flexibility and security of multiannual contributions. So far the financial mechanisms have been voluntary; we also call for mandatory commitments.  Fourth, we support local and national preparedness and response. On the other hand, we call for the independence of aid, we accept private sector participation when it can contribute to its experience and in accordance with humanitarian laws, but above all we focus on the protection of human beings.  As regards the third question — what should the European Union do?—, I refer to what the Council has adopted in an interim manner: the Union and its Member States must commit the ourselves to helping to make the Summit a success, both in the preparatory process and in the presence in Istanbul at the highest possible level. They must use all their means of development, humanitarian, diplomatic, to achieve a vision that promotes specific initiatives that transform humanitarian aid. The object of all this can be nothing but to protect people, to protect lives, to guarantee their dignity, which is the only way to guarantee our own dignity.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, human suffering has reached levels not seen before. As Mr Guerrero Salom said, 100 million people depend on humanitarian assistance. 60 million people have been forced to flee their homes, half of them children. These numbers are simply shocking. That is why the World Humanitarian Summit is such an important and timely initiative to restore humanity to the centre of political decision-making, and to improve the way in which we help people in humanitarian crises. We need the Summit to address the efficiency and delivery of humanitarian aid. But we also need the Summit to enable that aid to be delivered. Therefore, it is crucial that it addresses the increasing violation of international humanitarian law. That is a personal priority for me, and it will require political commitment from leaders at the Summit. Let us be realistic. We need more than humanitarians to achieve solutions to the underlying problems. Humanitarians cannot – and should not – carry the whole burden alone. Humanitarian aid can only be a short-term solution. It does not prevent or end conflicts. It does not generate social or economic progress. This is most evident in the worst humanitarian crisis of our times: the Syrian crisis. As long as a political solution is not reached, as long as Syrian people do not get basic social opportunities, our humanitarian assistance to Syria and its neighbouring countries will never be enough.  The fact that the Summit is taking place in Istanbul is by itself very significant. Istanbul has a strong symbolic meaning. It is a city bringing together continents, cultures and religions and it should become a symbol of bringing together humanitarian, political, development and environmental actors to better serve people in humanitarian crises. And it needs to reach beyond traditional humanitarian actors, to bring on board the private sector. To achieve this, all world leaders must be ready to make concrete commitments in Istanbul at the highest political level. The next six months will be critical in order to elevate the Summit to its rightful place. My personal commitment is to engage with partners around the world ahead of the Summit. I will encourage EU Member States to do the same. The European Parliament clearly has a role to play, too.  I would like to thank the Members of this Chamber for their interest and involvement in the discussions on the Summit. In particular, I would like to thank Mr Guerrero Salom for his personal leadership, especially on the European Parliament’s report that will be discussed in a moment. The Commission set out its position in a Communication last December. The Council adopted its conclusions last week. Parliament should now complete the EU’s contribution to the Summit by adopting this report. This way, we will have a strong collective vision on what a successful World Humanitarian Summit should be – a vision that we can communicate to partners around the globe. Regarding the massive refugee crisis, Europe has undertaken its share of responsibility. The initiatives by President Juncker and the Commission clearly show that this crisis is a major priority, and that the basic values of humanity and solidarity are at the core of the European Union. Europe is assuming its share of responsibility, in three major ways: firstly, through assistance to the refugees wherever they are; secondly, through the EU migration agenda – a difficult agenda; and thirdly, through a comprehensive response to the Syrian crisis. We are leading by example and doing our fair share. This will strengthen our credibility. We will become the main advocate for the global response we need so much.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all witnessing the enormous challenges of this century. We live in a richer world than in the past, but with a serious fragility that makes people more exposed and more vulnerable to increasing risks.  Humanitarian crises always involve enormous human suffering for the entire affected population, and even in these tragic humanitarian crises we must think of those who suffer the most, women and girls have always been the first victims, especially in armed conflicts, victims of abuse, rape and violence of all kinds. That is why humanitarian action must focus first and then on them so that they can receive adequate support and be guaranteed access to a whole range of sexual and reproductive health services, as set out in international humanitarian law.  We very much hope that the international summit planned in Istanbul will be a great opportunity to redefine a new humanitarian system capable of responding to the changes that are taking place.

name: Anna Hedh
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for As rapporteur for the FEMM committee's opinion, I would like to begin by thanking Mr Enrique for his work and taking advantage of the views of the FEMM Committee. We have before us a well-implemented report which will hopefully bring about a revival of humanitarian work, because humanitarian work needs a fresh start and a change.  I am therefore very pleased with how, in concrete terms, Mr Guerrero describes the need for SRHR and adequate health care in conflicts. For too long, women and girls who have been victims of sexual violence in armed conflicts have not been adequately served on health care. For too long, through its humanitarian work, the EU has departed from the letters of the Geneva Convention on the right to adequate medical care in the context of sexual violence in conflicts. Women and girls who are victims of sexual violence in conflicts should not have to be punished twice by also being refused the necessary medical care. That must be a starting point. I therefore call on parliament to vote tomorrow in favour of the report, including on women's right to healthcare after horrific abuses, which must be upheld.

name: Anna Záborská
text: for the PPE Group. – First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Guerrero Sal for a balanced text that could be supported with less reservation by all the political groups. Over the past year, Europe has been fiercely confronted with the consequences of humanitarian crises in the form of a massive influx of refugees. We were all surprised. We woke up to a reality in which millions of people at risk from the evening news suddenly knocked on our doors. However, this hypersensitivity is necessary. It gives us the opportunity to rethink our approach to humanitarian crises in the world and to take measures to help us better manage crisis situations. Respond more quickly and effectively and even prevent these crises. The report presented contains a number of constructive proposals that have precisely this objective. I look forward to the Istanbul Summit with hope. I am all the more sorry that no agreement has been found on the obligation to provide abortions for the victims of humanitarian crises or on the requirement for compulsory financial payments to a fund that is so far only on paper. It is a pity, because this report deserves to be adopted by a broad consensus.

name: Norbert Neuser
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Enrique, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has said. The COP 21 in Paris was a great international success! We also need this international impetus, this vigour, for the Istanbul Summit to be a success – no, it must be a success. And I believe that what we are presenting on the part of Europe can do well to achieve a common result. Demand and urgency are greater than ever. I want to repeat the figures, because then other things will fade into the background. Other things are trivialities. With 100 million people directly dependent on life-saving humanitarian aid, the one million Syrian refugees here seems relatively small.  Of the 100 million, a third are children and young people! They cannot protect their lives on their own, they need food, medicines and a roof over their heads. This also applies to 60 million displaced persons – a record since the Second World War.  The figures are clear enough. Demand has grown: within three years, from 2012 to 2015, it has risen from USD 10 billion to USD 20 billion. We are doomed to success in Istanbul. Enrique, thank you very much for the good report, that is a good basis for the negotiations in Istanbul.

name: Arne Gericke
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, Commissioner Stylianides, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. A few days ago, the climate conference in Paris came to an end. It was a great cheer when Summit President Laurent Fabius announced that the Treaty had been adopted.  The Paris Summit brings dynamism to an important process. We can achieve the same effect if we Europeans push for a UN humanitarian summit. As the world's largest donor, we have every reason to do so: environmental disasters, wars, refugees. The challenges are great. As we can only do it together in Europe, we can only do it together in the world. Our world needs a new cultura carittias, a culture of charity. No country should escape this. A global conference is worthwhile for this, and concrete ideas are needed for this. Just last week, I pushed through the appeal for a global tax on poverty in the ACP delegation. I have a majority in favour of my idea of establishing EU emergency centres worldwide in order to be able to respond more quickly to humanitarian disasters. There are certainly many of these ideas. Let's collect them and carry them to the... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Mr Stylianides, we live in a world in permanent and global emergency. The reactive has to give way to the proactive, because to move is not to move.  Humanitarian aid is inextricably linked to foreign policy and, of course, to development policy. That is why the World Humanitarian Summit in May must have the highest profile of international political representation, not only of the European Union but of the whole world, because it is the first and because it will be held in Istanbul, Turkey, a symbolic place that embodies both the problems and solutions to the desperate situation that refugees experience on the borders of Europe and in Europe itself.  This situation has shown that humanitarian aid is a major political instrument, and as such we must address it and use it from efficiency and from adapting to the problems that have changed in the world in which we live.  Our role at the Summit, as the world's leading donors, must be to influence the outcome so that the consensus reached incorporates essential humanitarian principles: the fight against impunity, putting protection, especially for women, at the centre of humanitarian aid and compliance with the international legal framework. Because, let us not forget, as long as our own Member States do not respect European and international legality, our action abroad will be very limited.  We know that the current humanitarian response is facing a constant erosion of respect for international law. And so, including civilians, aid workers, who often move to places where very few would go, must increasingly become the object of our protection and work.  The European Union has the responsibility and has the impetus to take a leading role in finding more efficient ways to meet the needs of people affected by conflict and catastrophe. The European Union should consider promoting a global consensus on humanitarian action that takes into account the diversity of the problems it faces and take advantage of all its functions at its disposal.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, there are now 250 million people affected by various humanitarian crises. Today, a harmonised policy at European level on humanitarian aid is more necessary than ever. We therefore value Mr Guerrero's work in this report and thank him very much. It is important to highlight the need to address root problems, especially those relating to economic inequality between people and between countries. It is essential that our humanitarian action guarantees people's rights, including the right of women to decide on their own bodies and the rights of migrants.  It is also necessary to have a robust public policy on humanitarian aid, and not to follow the logic of privatization as this report points out, which is why we will abstain from voting. We can collaborate with the private sector, yes, but once you are at the service of our values and objectives and are, above all, responsible for your actions.  If we really want to be effective, it is crucial that all of our policies are consistent with our development goals. For example, I miss references to international trade, corporate responsibility or European arms exports in this report. If our trade policy continues to close our eyes to human rights violations, we will be contributing to increased instability and crises, not their solution.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we are preparing for the first ever World Humanitarian Summit in a situation where international humanitarian law is severely threatened. If we think about all those attacks against civilian institutions, mainly hospitals, in Afghanistan, in Syria and in Yemen, it is outrageous what is happening to civilians who are already suffering from wars and conflicts. International humanitarian law is under threat in another way, and I am afraid we have a problem within this House in relation to the evolution of that law. It has now been clearly shown that rape is used as a systematic weapon in conflicts and wars, and the women and girls who are raped under those circumstances have the unequivocal right to all sexual and reproductive services, including the right to safe abortion, regardless of national legislation. It is our duty to prevent cruelty, and one important aspect of that is that we have to call for the right to safe abortion in these situations. Those who deny the women and girls in question this right are simply inhuman – and we have to think about this when we vote tomorrow. Can I just mention that there is an idea for establishing a new international fund? I do not think we should make payments to that fund compulsory because the time is not ripe for that idea.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the summit on world humanitarian aid comes in the long wake of other important summits that have taken place, such as COP21 in Paris, such as the New York Conference on the Sustainable Development Goals, such as the Addis Ababa Summit on Financing for Development, and it is clear that it is important to get there with a strong position and a position that is appropriate in the face of emergencies that are becoming increasingly serious.  I believe that the work done by the rapporteur Enrique Guerrero Salom is an excellent piece of mediation between different positions within the European Parliament, and so the report is an excellent text that we will support. Clearly the good work also comes from excellent advice that has arrived at non-governmental organisations, which are the ones that most of all deal with situations like this, so we must applaud them and we must work to protect those who work on the ground and to prevent attacks such as those at doctors without borders hospitals that we have seen in recent times.

name: Mireille D'Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this project of a single international humanitarian structure is ambitious. However, concrete evidence remains to be found that this project is possible. Transparency and global coordination on such sensitive issues are not decreed.  Too broad in its scope when he talks about all the populations affected by the war, he nevertheless evokes quite interesting avenues, such as a better delivery of humanitarian law or consultation with local authorities. These are good ideas.  Unfortunately, gender equality or emotional life education courses are off topic and have nothing to do with this project. As for the reception of refugees, it is again invoked here without anyone seeing that it is merely a palliative to the current problems in Syria, Iraq and Libya.  The only sustainable solution for the people in distress in these countries to live in peace at home is to solve the problem at the source. While entire families are displaced and subjected to daily violence, we expect serious proposals from the world's major players. Otherwise, I cannot reasonably give a blank-seing to yet another international organization.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Madam President, on my group, on me personally, and I think that many other MEMBERS were greatly affected by the words spoken by Pope Francis in this house when he asked that the European Union oppose the ideology of waste, to meet people who are in need, who are fleeing war and poverty, not to turn their backs, not to be treated as waste.
