Colleague Guerrero's report largely provides answers to this request and gives an image of the European Union as a credible and effective humanitarian force. Personally, I'd like Francis' message not to throw away unborn children because they're not guilty of crimes, rapes. Maybe our hearts in Europe are too hard to accept that part of the message, but I hope Europe will evolve in that sense. So we can and must do better, but I also want to show my recognition here to my colleague Guerrero for the good proposals in his report, for the openness to the dialogue he showed during the preparation of the resolution.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the philosophical and political principles that inspire the European project hold the European Union in particular responsible for addressing such a matter and importance. This report, by its quality, is up to the obligations of this Parliament. There are several useful recommendations, which could help to provide an action plan from this Istanbul summit that is applicable and accepted by all actors and has a useful link with other documents that are already being put in place, such as the Post-2015 Development Agenda and the conclusions recently adopted at COP 21 in Paris. It is also important to ensure that humanitarian aid always takes into account the principles of neutrality, impartiality, independence and humanity, and that this is the basis for all the decisions that may be taken at that summit, as is clearly proposed in this report, the quality of which I would like to stress once again.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, it is quite ironic, is it not, that the World Humanitarian Summit is hosted in Turkey, of all places. The Human Rights Watch website highlights many ways in which Turkey has abused human rights, including restricting internet access, a defective justice system and a consistent clamping down on freedom of expression.  What is even more ironic is that the EU has pushed forward Turkey’s accession process, despite human rights abuses. For an institution that prides itself on liberal values, this certainly sends the wrong message. Turkey is already a NATO member, but its posturing towards Russia highlights the danger, to the UK and other European states, of close integration with this hostile and belligerent government. We are naïve if we think trade and membership of this Parliament can change a culture that has been developed over many centuries. We should send a clear signal to the Turkish people that they need to elect a progressive government and implement wholesale reform of their legal structures, which will protect minorities and fundamental rights, before accession is even talked about.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank our colleague Guerrero Salom for his work on this subject, and I say that I personally will support his report.  As noted, the first world humanitarian summit will be held in Turkey, Istanbul, on 23 and 24 May 2016. This summit will, I hope, be an opportunity to better respond to humanitarian disasters, which are unfortunately more and more numerous. Today, more than 200 million people are affected by humanitarian crises. The financial needs are enormous. Indeed, the appeal for funds for humanitarian action in 2015 reached the amount of 19 billion euros, a level unprecedented in the history of the United Nations.  It is therefore important to think globally about what needs to be addressed in response to these disasters that affect millions of people. The effort must be global.  Nevertheless, the European Union has a major role to play at the international level as a largest donor. It should recall our principles of humanitarian assistance intervention and also contribute to all sustainable funding to respond to crises while promoting the strengthening of links between humanitarian aid and development policy.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on this systematic report and I share with him the hope that this summit will be a success. The current refugee crisis shows how urgent reforms are and where it leads if there is too little funding and the commitments are not being honoured. Mrs Merkel said at the refugee summit in September: "We have not seen that the international programmes are not sufficiently funded, that people are starving in refugee camps."  Self-knowledge is good, but it is about changing our behavior. I don't think it's the time at the moment - we're seeing that in Syria. The European level is trying. We have also done our duty as parliamentarians. However, the Member States are still in default, failing to deliver on commitments. That is why we need a compulsory mechanism. We must get away from voluntary action.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I, too, will join in congratulating Enrique Guerrero Salom, this is a very good report. The World Humanitarian Summit will be an ideal opportunity to exchange views and take courageous action to prevent conflicts and improve the situation of people living in their areas. The Middle East, the war in Syria, the situation of African countries, as well as the natural disasters caused by climate change are just some of the crises that the international community has to face. The actions of the international community should be coordinated in order to increase the effectiveness of humanitarian aid.  The safety of humanitarian workers is also an important issue. In 2014, more than 300 of them were killed, abducted or injured. Therefore, solutions should be created that will improve their status and enable them to work in the best possible conditions. The World Humanitarian Summit must be a political impetus to make this aid more effective and to ensure that, together with development instruments, it has the opportunity to guarantee the stability of states and the resilience of societies to future conflicts.

name: Die Präsidentin. –

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this year we have celebrated eight hundred years of, say, the first sprain of humanism. The Great Bill of Rights was created in England 800 years ago. In my opinion, this anniversary should have been the reason for the transmission of the information that my pre-speaking father also spoke of. I was surprised by how many national governments were unaware that the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights and Refugees had to cut very radically from week to week in refugee camps. In global times, we don't have information transfer, intelligence services. These are questions about how national governments and states actually work on such an important issue as protecting humanity and the fundamental values of humanity. Then we can only wonder how people who don't get food aid respond to it.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Nobel Peace Prize winner Mother Teresa of Calcutta once said that killing the unborn is the greatest threat to world peace. It is worth recalling these words on the eve of our vote on a document which, as one of the precepts of humanism, presents to us, I will quote literally: 'access to abortion'. There are many children in the world who the political authorities wished they would never be born, including the kind of children in this room who wished to do so. And it is worth remembering this when we vote on this report.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, allow me again to congratulate my dear colleague Mr Guerrero Salom on this very concrete report and, of course, thank you again all of you for this very constructive discussion on this very important report. I would like to re-emphasise that today’s number and level of humanitarian crises is unprecedented. This is why we must act, and we must act now. So in Istanbul next May we have an opportunity but also, maybe, a ‘last chance’ to make the humanitarian system fit for purpose and to build strong and diversified partnerships. The preparatory process has been inclusive and extensive, but there is a risk that the Summit will try to cover everything under the sun. So, if we really want to have an impact as the European Union, we need to be focused, by pushing two or three really game-changing points, and start discussing well in advance with our partners these two or three issues. That takes me to the substance of the Summit which you have addressed so comprehensively. Let me say again what three of the big issues are where we can and should make a difference. Firstly, we need to make a difference with respect to international humanitarian law and humanitarian principles. The protection of humanitarian workers is paramount. Secondly, we need a more and more effective and transparent humanitarian system, with agencies working to deliver in a more transparent and efficient manner. Thirdly, there is a desperate need for more resources and more predictable funding. You know all about this. We need to work on bringing in new sources of funding, on working better with development funding. I am delighted that our Vice-President Kristalina Georgieva is part of leading a panel which will address these issues. The Summit must address all of these in a concrete manner. For that we need to build deeper and more genuine partnerships; find ways of bringing in local actors more consistently; definitely bring in the private sector – we need it; build universal support for humanitarian principles; and of course show that humanitarian aid is not a Western enterprise. We want to work on this with all of you during the coming months, thinking creatively, being innovative, but remaining very focused. We need to be focused in order to find and achieve political commitments. I really look forward to our continued cooperation ahead of Istanbul in a very specific manner. Thank you again for this very constructive discussion.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, throughout this debate I think that some aspects have become sufficiently clear.  The first is that we cannot solve the problems of this dramatic world only with humanitarian action: we must prevent conflict and we must promote and guarantee economic growth and social protection. And only if we change this in the world will we avoid humanitarian crises.  Secondly, we need a comprehensive action plan with new donors and more means.  Thirdly, we need the European Union, on our territory, to apply the humanitarian principles it will preach in Istanbul. Only by leading by example, as Commissioner Stylianides has pointed out, will we be credible at the next Humanitarian Summit. Finally, I would like to thank the non-governmental organisations – more than thirty – which have participated in the preparation of this report, the shadow rapporteurs, the coordinators, Commissioner Stylianides , of course – and also Vice-President Georgieva, and the staff who have worked together with them.  I have tried to obtain a balanced report, trying to mediate between the position of the different groups. Even now, a few hours after the vote on the report, I would ask those groups that have decided not to support it to review their positions, because the Summit is much more important than my report. However, Parliament's position is very important to the hundreds of millions of people who expect us to make commitments in Istanbul and respond to the needs to protect lives and end humiliating situations for so many people in so many parts of the world.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 16 December 2015.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I would like to raise a point on the Rules of Procedure. Since the time is 10.10 and we still have two debates, I would like you to tell me how you intend to apply the 'catch the eye' procedure. I ask because I have been here since 3 p.m. and, with various justifications, the Presidency has not given me the floor at times. I would therefore like to know whether you will follow the rule of giving the floor to one of each group or, if there are only two or three colleagues in the Chamber who may be in the same group, whether you will give the floor without restriction, because if you are going to follow the tactics you have followed earlier, then I may not participate and leave the Chamber.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Mr Marias, I would like to thank Mr Marias for his We are already very close with the times. We are already in the planning stage so that we will not be ready until shortly after 11 p.m. The plan is 11 p.m. In other words, I have decided that we should make the catch-the-eye procedure in such a way that I only take on those Members from a group who have not yet spoken, or if you are the only one of your group, then you will come to it. But if there are others here from your group, I will not take you in, but only those who have not yet spoken. I ask for your understanding that we simply cannot accept all those who have spoken in the catch-the-eye procedure. I cannot tell you now who will actually speak in the next catch-the-eye procedure, because I do not yet have all the attributions. Thank you for your understanding. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The World Humanitarian Summit will take place in Istanbul next May. This will be an opportunity to adapt the humanitarian relief system to the current emergency scenario, which is always evolving rapidly. It is very important that the emphasis is shifted from reaction to prevention, in order to avoid disasters as much as possible rather than remedy them. From this point of view, we need a commitment on the front line of the European Union as a driving force, a leader, who exports best practices in the fields in which it has them. In short, there is a need for a strong international assumption of responsibility, and the Union must promote it. The report before us certainly goes in the right direction and I have therefore supported it with conviction.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. – Today we are faced with social and political changes, there are a large number of war crises, armed conflicts that generate the need for humanitarian aid, numerous natural disasters occur, some of which are indirectly caused by human activity. The number of people in need since 2004 has more than doubled. This year, the number of people in need of humanitarian aid is more than 100 million, while the number of forcibly displaced people has reached nearly 60 million. Almost half of the refugees are children. On the other hand, the world has never been richer, there has never been a greater level of knowledge and technological progress.  It is definitely necessary to confront globally the problem of humanitarian crises, some of which have catastrophic consequences and bring together all those actors dealing with this issue at the highest level. The World Humanitarian Summit should, along the lines of similar gatherings that try to provide answers to humanity's most important problems, involve world leaders and create lasting mechanisms that should, if not already preventable, then at least alleviate the humanitarian problems of one part of humanity. A clear action plan should be created that will be respected and implemented, a code of conduct, transparency and the creation of lasting sources of resources in dealing with and overcoming humanitarian crises is needed.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. – We are discussing a very important issue today. Globally, the number of people in poverty has more than doubled since 2004, and according to the UN, 250 million people have been affected by poverty. people are suffering from a humanitarian crisis. This problem concerns, in particular, the number of displaced persons, the highest number since the Second World War, almost 60 million. People. This is an alarming data for which we, as the European Community, cannot remain indifferent. Most humanitarian crises arise for human activities. As a result, as much as 80% of eu international humanitarian aid is provided through man-made crises, the most important of which is to make political and then economic decisions. We need to take note of this. Poverty and crisis-friendly conditions are inextricably linked, and it is therefore all the more necessary to address the root causes of crises. In order to be effective and effective, humanitarian aid must reach the population affected by the disaster. This requires the fight against abuse and organised crime, which exploits people and their misfortunes and damages. In preparing whs, the European Union should promote the adoption of actions to ensure that affected communities, especially women and children, have access to adequate medical and food assistance. The European Union should continue to emphasise the leading role of NGOs in humanitarian activities, because it is these organisations that are closest to those most vulnerable.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on labour mobility (2015/2931(RSP)).

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, there are currently intense political discussions going on in the European institutions and in the Member States about the free movement of European citizens and the entitlement of mobile citizens to social benefits. Free movement and adequate social protection for mobile citizens are core values of the European Union. They directly affect the lives of millions. Therefore, I am glad to have the opportunity today to have an exchange with you here in Parliament. Since I took office as Commissioner for Employment, Social Affairs, Skills and Labour Mobility more than a year ago, I have listened carefully to the very different views that exist on these matters. Those exchanges with many people and representatives of many organisations, many Member States and many parliaments have convinced me that, irrespective of the differences, there is also a lot of common ground in what most people want. Fundamentally, the right to move across borders, to travel, to study, to work or to retire is not put into question. On the contrary, it is considered to be one of the major achievements of the European Union and a right that is cherished by many. But people want this right of free movement to be exercised in a way which is fair for everybody. They want rules which are clear, fair and enforced on the ground, and it is precisely our job as lawmakers to provide for such rules. The Juncker Commission has committed in its political guidelines to reviewing the existing rules on social security coordination and the posting of workers, and to table legislative proposals for amendments where appropriate.  We are sticking to that commitment. We repeat it and operationalise it further in the Commission’s work programme for 2016, announcing proposals for a revision of the social security coordination regulations, as well as a targeted revision of the Posting of Workers Directive to implement the principle of equal pay for equal work. We will also outline our priorities to support and facilitate labour mobility across Europe. We are finalising the technical work on the package. When exactly we will be tabling it also depends on the political context.  As you know, the European Council will this week discuss security alongside migration, the internal market, the deepening of the EMU and the UK – all topics related directly or indirectly to labour mobility. The Commission will re-evaluate, after the European Council, when is the right time to table its labour mobility package. My ambition is for it to be a balanced package taking the interests of all 28 Member States – and, of course, of all their citizens – into account. In the meantime, I am at your disposal – of you all – to continue our exchange, which I value a lot and will take into account. Parliament will have its institutional role to play in the legislative process once the initiative – or the initiatives, because it is a package – are on the table. So let us prepare further that process now. I am available for questions.

name: Heinz K. Becker
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner Marianne Thyssen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We in the European People's Party support you in the European Commission in their concern to increase and massively promote the mobility rate of workers and jobseekers within the EU. Only about 7.5 million of European workers were active in another Member State in 2014. This corresponds to a share of only 3.1%. The mobility potential of the EU labour force is far from being exhausted. This is absolutely unsatisfactory with the highest unemployment in certain regions of Europe. The new EURES network of public and private labour market administrations will also be able to make a strong contribution to providing hundreds of thousands of vacant jobs. Of course, we want in future the posting of every worker to another country not only facilitated, but guaranteed under fair conditions. We agree with you, Commissioner, that we are giving people the security of receiving their fair wages and benefits throughout the EU. I therefore do not think it makes sense to act hastily now and to put the 2014 Posting of Workers Directive in place before it has even been fully implemented. Let us wait for the evaluation! The principle must be: review before revision, and in this way serious labour market policy must be implemented for the people of Europe.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Listening, announcing – that is not enough. The problems in Europe are pressing. And I am disappointed, yes, I am angry that today we cannot finally discuss concrete measures to improve the situation of mobile workers. Only recently, President Juncker said here that he wanted to make the fight against social dumping his priority: the mobility package should be a cornerstone of that and the European social pillar you announced a second one. What has been promised to me is also sound to my ears: a social triple A for Europe, the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place, equal treatment for all workers in Europe, fair competition. I am already asking myself the question: what is this to do? This is a pure announcement commission! The problems are on the table. For years, it has been clear where the loopholes are and with which they can be closed. They really must help the people who are suffering outside from the loopholes of the Posting of Workers Directive, including honest companies, which suffer just as much in their competitiveness. Commissioner, now is the right time, and further postponement will not help social Europe at all. People are waiting for an answer!

name: Anthea McIntyre
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I wish to thank the Commissioner, for her statement. I very much like what she said about this being fair for everybody and enforced on the ground. So often we see directives that are unenforceable, so it is very important that we take care to have things that are enforceable and are fair. I think social security coordination is important. However, I frankly cannot see why one would want to be opening up the Posting of Workers Directive while we still do not have the Enforcement Directive in place. This seems very premature and I do not understand why one would want to do it.  On the question of equal pay for equal work, this is a very noble objective and one we can support, but one has to look at the practicalities. I would urge you to look at the cases in Britain where thousands of cases are stuck in the courts because equal work cannot be defined.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, like many other speakers, I regret the delay in the mobility package but I can live with it for now, because of course it is connected to Brexit, and many of the issues that are crucial to the mobility package also play an important role in the negotiations with the UK government. Free movement is an individual right of every European citizen and, as such, it must be protected, but this should not blind us to the fact that there are pluses and minuses to labour mobility. Yes, it can provide opportunities for job seekers and it can help to deal with issues like labour shortages and skills shortages. But equally there can be a brain drain from sending countries and also, if in a receiving country there are significant numbers of posted workers arriving in a particular sector, it can have the impact of driving down wages. I believe that our job as parliamentarians is to act to mitigate the bad effects and promote the good effects of labour mobility. We need to recognise that in some cases our legislation needs updating, either to take account of new realities – and there are many in the European Union – or to deal with the unintended consequences of previous legislation. I presume none of us in this Parliament think we get it right first time, every time, or indeed that past Parliaments did. As always it depends on politics: in the Commission, in Parliament and in the Council. So that is three politics: politics, politics and more politics. Right now, I think we need to put our minds to finding workable pragmatic solutions to the challenges we face and are likely to face in the future. Our citizens deserve that – they expect it and they deserve it. Finally, your comments on equal work for equal pay in the same place. I agree with you on that because it is well-established in European legislation and, as you have said yourself on many occasions, we do it for part-time workers, for fixed-time workers, for seasonal workers, for temporary agency workers. So the question I want answered is: why do we not do it for posted workers?

name: Tania González Peñas
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, more than two million Spaniards reside abroad, a figure which has risen sharply during the last Government of the People's Party. Even if it speaks to the adventurous impulse of young people, the problem is that they are forced to choose between unemployment or precariousness. It is not voluntary and is not mobility, it is called "exile" or "emigration". And it's not new: my grandparents and many people like them had to leave their land to fight for a better future for those of us behind us. Today, as a farce, history repeats itself and those who saw in this European Union a project of future and well-being never imagined that we would be condemning the countries of the South to specialize in poverty, inequality, cheap labour, social rights and low cost labour.  We don't want our people to be forced to emigrate because they have no future in their country. We don't want brain drain, from human capital that it takes us a lot of effort to form. We want social and economic development also in our country. We want a cohesive, egalitarian and supportive Europe that lives up to its founding values and where there are no second-class citizens. And perhaps, ladies and gentlemen, because mobility is not voluntary, the People's Party has forced Spanish émigrés to vote with such complex formalities that only 6% have been able to carry them out to exercise the most basic democratic right; perhaps because many of those outside want a vote of change in this election. A vote to build a country to return to.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, like others, I also want to add my regret that we are not actually debating the published package tonight. We should realise that there are 27 countries that were extremely interested in this, and that they should not have to hang around waiting for just one. A lot is said in this Parliament – and indeed by the Commission – about the importance of labour mobility, about its positive role in the EU economy and for individuals themselves, providing new experiences and the opportunity to develop talents. They can use their talents where, as we have just been reminded by our colleague in Spain, there is no opportunity in their own countries. We also have the millions of cross-border workers on a daily basis and people filling vacancies in the labour markets at all skill levels. I want to stress that: it is at all skill levels. But this really needs to work for those individuals, and it is important that they can access their entitlements.  I really hope that this package will also look at the gaps in systems and between systems, where people are not catered for, and we can see that through the Committee on Petitions, through cases at Solvit. I would like us to look at how we really match skills rather than seeing people employed well below their skill levels. I also want to remind people that it is not only workers who move. So the extension of the scope of the 2004 Regulation was important, and I hope we are not touching that.

name: Jane Collins
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the EU loves talking about labour mobility, but what my people in the region of Yorkshire and North Lincolnshire want is real jobs. Instead, the EU has given them... (The speaker was unwell and was unable to complete her speech)

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Freedom to move and work in the European Union is one of the Union's most precious values, and it is also important in the economic sphere – we know that this is a question of competitiveness and reducing unemployment. Commissioner, we simply need this package. The barriers to mobility are already more or less known and on this basis we know what needs to be done. I consider it crucial to invest in good, free or low-paid language courses for workers, to speed up the implementation of the European Qualifications Framework and to speed up the recognition of qualifications within the European Union, to develop and improve the operation of EURES, but above all to implement the Posting of Workers Directive. It should not be opened, there is no need to open it, because it has just been amended, but it simply needs to be implemented, and it is necessary to analyse the relationship between this directive and other relevant legal acts for mobility, such as the Temporary Employment Agencies Directive.  Of course, we still face a huge challenge, which concerns the coordination of social security systems. I would like to ask you how the work is going on in this area, what was born in terms of the issue of social security systems, and I would like to ask you if you do not think that a European Migration Observatory should be set up to deal with the behaviour of immigrants, both those migrants from Member States and third countries, both migrants legally in the European Union. , as well as irregular one?

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his I would like to thank you for being here, but At the same time I would like to declare that I am very disappointed, like many others in my own group, but also in other groups in this House. This parliamentary term has been very much marked by the hope that we will finally be able to bring about order and order in the labour market, which means that there will be equal pay for equal work, that we will settle seriously with the social dumping that not only damages productivity and feelings and moods in a workplace, but also damages feelings and moods and the content of the democracies that the European Union is made up of. If you create a competitive society where you make a difference between people doing the same job, then it will not be very good societies of such a process. We still have high hopes that Commissioner Thyssen and the Commission will come back with a good proposal, for that is what you have promised us. We have lived now for eight years with the Lavaldom, which became a kind of starting point for social dumping, both in reality and on our political agenda, so we continue to hope and press.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Thyssen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I welcome the initiative on the labour mobility package. We must further strengthen the internal market of workers in Europe, a European labour market, opportunities without borders for the young generation, including social security. We need rules that are applicable and not ideologically overloaded. It is about respect for subsidiarity and sovereignty. Let us accept national and regional competences! And to those who are fundamentally railing against Schengen, I say to those: think of the workers! Mandatory border controls extend computed journeys, eat up time, endanger the economies that have grown over the years. We also need to talk about this when it is about worker mobility.

name: Ulla Tørnæs (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her statement. Like others. I am also very disappointed that we are not discussing the Labour Mobility Package tonight, but that we are just discussing your update on your work on the Labour Mobility Package. Last month, Commissioner, you gave a speech in Dublin, which I read with great interest. In the speech, you elaborate a little on your thoughts on the situation regarding frontier workers. In the speech you said that, after a year of work in another country, the country in which the frontier worker had worked should be financially responsible for the payment of unemployment benefits. The guiding principle behind this is that a frontier worker should receive benefits from the country in which he or she has contributed. This is fair for everybody, you said. I completely agree with this principle. Therefore, Commissioner, I would like to ask you tonight if you think that this principle – that a person should receive benefits from the country in which he or she has contributed – should apply not only to frontier workers, but to all mobile workers within the EU.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the right to mobility has been too conceived over time as a means of putting workers in competition with each other, because it has been separated from the law and social and human progress.  With the Services Directive and the Detachment of Workers Directive, the European Union has even organised this competition for the benefit of business profitability. We must restore equity and equality between workers in the face of access to work, labour law, the right to social protection, better working conditions and remuneration, and this partly means the creation of a European body of labour inspectors to enforce these rights. This inevitably requires an overhaul of the Detachment of Workers Directive. Yes, the principle of "equal work, equal pay" must be respected, but equal social protection must also be guaranteed.  It is time for our European Union to become a space no longer of competition, but of solidarity and social progress.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, mobility has in fact enriched all of our lives. I have worked, studied and lived in Belgium, Germany, the UK and Bosnia. I have taken advantage of the great freedom to choose where I want to work and what I want to do – an internship in Barcelona, a PhD in Stockholm or working for a company in Tallinn. To me, this freedom has always been a choice, and I have always been protected from discrimination and exploitation by European Union law. This is true for many mobile Europeans, but still not for all. We still see that the portability of social rights, non-discrimination and social security are not always safeguarded. We have seen – especially lately, due to the crisis – that many Europeans are not freely moving to other EU Member States, but are forced to do so – accepting any working conditions, not getting the same pay, or even losing access to basic social rights. With this labour mobility package, we need to tackle these problems. To do this, we need to put the rights of European citizens at the core of this debate instead of only looking at economic gains, which labour mobility certainly entails. We in this Parliament need to be the voice of the citizens and their social rights, security and protection. Make a proposal that guarantees the European principles of equality, non—discrimination and social justice. If this Commission really wants the EU to get a triple A for social standards, this is the time to prove it. And this will be crucial for the trust of the European citizens in the European project.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, we all know that the mobility of citizens and workers, equal social protection, equal pay for equal work are and must be part of the fundamental rights of citizens today. President Juncker has opened many hopes for us with the triple-A of social Europe.  On this problem of reopening the 2014 directive, which we have - as you well know, Commissioner - negotiated with great difficulty, I would like to know whether the Member States really want to transpose it. Indeed, the fact that its reopening is requested even before it is transposed shows us a lack of will in this matter. I too agree that the Member States should put in place real controls, a real European control over the implementation of this directive. Otherwise, we will not be able to achieve the goals we have set for ourselves. Finally, I would like to tell you that we must all together defend geographical and professional mobility for the best of reasons: this is our best guarantee, our first protection against unemployment and this is our objective. I trust your work, but I want you to know that we will not give up on this.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Madam President, all of us – and the Commissioner most of all – are very well aware that the whole range of issues connected with labour mobility have taken centre stage among all the other problems facing the European Union today. Given the acuteness of these problems, this merits not a discussion at 22.40 but a key discussion in this Parliament with a full House. We had a discussion of that sort this morning. Commissioner, if we are serious about building a balanced European Union, you cannot afford to pay less attention to the severe problems of labour mobility than to market competitiveness. You have said that you want a balanced package, but the situation now is highly unbalanced with a severe imbalance to the detriment of workers. If you do not fix that, problems will arise.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, let me say that, in countries such as mine, Portugal, the term 'labour mobility' is a skilled euphemism in the vocabulary of the European Union to refer to a harsh reality. It's called emigration. There have been about 500,000 Portuguese who have emigrated in the last four years, especially young people looking for jobs and minimally decent jobs who do not find them in their country.  Countries like mine have invested millions in qualifying young people who now put their precious knowledge in countries such as the UK, Germany, Belgium or others. Countries that often exploit the labour force that comes from my country, cheap labour, workers in undignified conditions, but who at least have a job they have not found in their country. But these are the problems that have to be solved. They are separate lives and families, countries condemned to dependency and to mortgage their development possibilities. As much skill as your rhetoric has, reality doesn't change. We want more rights in other countries, but also employment with rights in our countries.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: – Thank you to Commissioner Thyssen for being here and thank you for your clear explanation. Let me first say that I fully agree with Mr Pirinski and that I regret that, as a Parliament, we always talk about social Europe, a triple A status for social Europe, but that we always allow the debates on this to take place at the end of the day. I know that Mrs Thyssen is not about Parliament's agenda, but it would be good to have a good discussion about it together. Mrs Thyssen, thank you very much for your explanation. Like many of my fellow Members here, I regret that we are not discussing concrete proposals today, but I can imagine that you yourself regret it. In any case, I fully understand the external factors that make it difficult to present this package this week. However, we look forward to doing it as soon as possible. That is a promise you have made from the first hearing and which we will also keep you; that will, of course, be done in good consultation. One thing that surprises me in this debate today is that it deals with a number of issues. But Labour's ability is so much more than just social dumping and more than just the posting directive. We must ensure that, especially for citizens in the border regions, the daily reality of cross-border functioning offers real added value. If we cannot achieve this for people in border regions, then it will be very difficult to find support within Europe to tackle the major challenges. There will be a lot of work to be done.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – In October, President Juncker made it clear that equal pay for equal work should be the starting point for this Union. And the package is ready. Your work has been done, including a review of the Posting of Workers Directive. But the Commission has taken a knee-jerk attack on the British.  The labour migration package was in both Juncker's political priorities and in the Commission's work programmes for 2015 and 2016, and yet today we stand here without a proposal and without a date. Surely it cannot be the case that the Juncker Commission, the self-proclaimed Last Chance Commission, appears to be more sensitive to David Cameron's concerns than to the concerns of ordinary people and ordinary workers.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the mobility of workers in Europe is now a key role. It's a challenge and a solution. I challenge, as it is one of the key elements in fulfilling one of the true purposes of this Citizens' Europe, in a Europe without borders. This is a response to the still high levels of unemployment, youth unemployment, long-term unemployment and the labour problems of social protection and competitiveness posed by the ageing of our population. There is an urgent need to make this process fairer and to ensure that mobility workers in the European Union do not suffer from abuse. We cannot be held back in difficulties, nor give in to any form of pressure by those whose sole purpose is to destroy the union of our Europe, or who attribute the responsibilities for its failure in national governance. It is therefore urgent that we be able to launch an effective labour mobility package that ensures that mobility workers have the most fundamental labour rights. They need to be ensured that they are well-working, to ensure that they have access to health monitoring and social protection systems in the host States, and that in the future their pensions reflect all the efforts of a lifetime. Commissioner, given that labour legislation reforms are needed to ensure these benefits, it is necessary to link this package with the exclusive competences of the Member States. I would like to know how you intend to do this joint.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D).
text: – Madam President, can I first congratulate the Commissioner on not insulting us by even pretending that this package has been delayed for any reason other than not to muddy the waters of the glorious deal that we are all expecting David Cameron to do in February. At least we know where we are, and it is nice not to be patronised. But, perhaps I could also suggest to her that if this deal had been done, if this package had been finalised a year ago, then rather than the whole of Europe being in angst-ridden negotiations with David Cameron about in-work benefits, we could have been a year into a situation in which we were paying the same rate for the same job in the same place and providing a living wage and decent conditions for European workers. We would not have to argue about in-work benefits if we had the fair rate for the job in the same place, and jobs.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE).
text: – Dear Colleagues, Madam Commissioner, I am convinced that EU workers are looking for work, not social benefits, when they exercise their right of free movement. With this right, you can only win. The answer to this is not to reduce entitlements, but to eliminate abuses. With regard to the Posting of Workers Directive, I would like to express my doubt as to why a recently adopted legislation should already be revised? For example, 80 million people with disabilities had to wait 5 years for the European accessibility package to be introduced. There shouldn't be that much distinction between a citizen and a citizen.  Finally, I would like to state that equal pay for equal work in the same place can only be interpreted on the basis of the same law. And the competitiveness of businesses is undermined by the impediment to business freedom in this way.  I would like to support The Commissioner's efforts, but I would also ask you to listen to the doubts of Members.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, I want to thank you for your priority on employment. I would like to inform you that the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs is preparing a report on social dumping in the European Union. You mentioned the mobility package being prepared by the European Commission. There should certainly be no lack of measures to prevent mobility, namely language skills, non-recognition of mutual qualifications and so on. It must already be said that it should not include a new directive, its implementation should first be evaluated. I would like to ask if you have already had the opportunity to familiarise yourself with the letter from the Confederation of European Business, which does not recommend reopening the directive, which has already been mentioned here several times. Thank you in advance for your reply.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, in this period of financial crisis, we note that labour mobility is presented as the forced solution to tackling unemployment. According to the European Network of Employment Services, EUROPES, workers from the Member States of the Union who have the possibility of occupational mobility in another country within the EU will be subject to the labour and insurance legislation of the host country and not of the country of origin. According to research, Germany will need up to 490 000 workers from European Union states each year to maintain its current levels of prosperity. Already, the European Union regrets that only 700 000 people are moving within the other European Union countries in the second half of 2015 to find work. Finally, this attitude of the European Union towards labour mobility runs counter to that of some Member States which do not want this mobility.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Thank you for giving me the opportunity to reply to the comments. I want to wish Mrs Collins the best. I hope that after a working day that has probably consisted of two shifts, she will recover quickly.  What I would like to point out once again is that there is a commitment, a commitment by the Juncker Commission to deliver on this dossier. A review has been promised. Ultimately, it will amount to a revision, both of the social security coordination regulations and the posting directive, and I want to assure you that we will deliver as well. I will work very hard for that myself, you know that. But I will do the same along with the college as a whole. Ultimately, we want to achieve legally secure rules, fair rules that are enforceable and where those who have to do the inspection can also effectively ensure enforceability. Those are the three main points. What I would like to say specifically about the enforcement directive: some of my colleagues here spoke about the enforcement directive, we must first make it stand out and then see if we need to do something further.  The enforcement directive, ladies and gentlemen, is not going to be there, it is not being reopened. The enforcement directive was voted on after lengthy negotiations here in this House. We completed this process in May 2014 after lengthy negotiations between the Council and the European Parliament. That directive is what it is, remains what it is and must be transposed accordingly by each Member State. I have already asked my services to look closely at this, and I ask in every bilateral contact, and also at the Epsco, the Social Affairs Council, that ministers and governments all do their best to ensure a timely and quality transposition. But we must ensure that enforcement can also be done effectively and we see that there are still gaps there. Not in the enforcement directive, but in other parts of the mobility legislation, we will look at that and we will fill those gaps. As far as the Posting of People's Directive is concerned, we are going to open it. That's where we're going to do a target review. We have decided to revise it anyway, because otherwise we cannot comply with the principle of equal pay for equal work and we think that is a fair rule. We believe that this rule should be put in place. Someone here has said that we have that in other legislation, why can't we have that here? We will ensure that the way in which we introduce this rule ensures sufficient legal certainty to prevent it from becoming a source of many difficulties which will then have to be fought in courts and tribunals. We want the rule that is as law-a sure as possible. We have worked on this and I hope that we will be able to present it to you shortly. This is a matter of fairness.  As far as the Observatory is concerned, someone asked for an observatory, an observation centre to monitor mobility. Well, I can refer you to the European Foundation for the improvement of the living and working conditions, which has its seat in Dublin. It follows these issues closely, has carried out regular studies on and can give a good picture of the mobility flows in Europe.  A question has also been asked about the importance of companies. Indeed, we must take that into account. These are situations in which both companies and employees and the services market have an interest. What is our concern is that we are delivering on the two principles for which we introduced the secondment for workers at the time, for which we drew up that directive in the 1990s. This was a dual concern: to ensure a level playing field between companies in the service sector and to ensure the social protection of people seconded to other Member States in the context of services. That remains our dual concern and we will take into view each of these aspects. Of course, I have taken note of the letters from, among others, the business organisation you are quoting, ma'am. I take note of all the letters and I try to read everything that comes in. I usually do that thoroughly. But of course we have to form an opinion afterwards, to make sure that we put together a package that we ourselves are convinced is the best thing we can put together. And that's the way we'll go. With all due respect to the letters we receive, but we cannot always give a positive response to every letter or to every part of a letter we receive. The concern I see in this House is a concern that I share with you. We must move towards a balanced package that is at the service of the people, the citizens of each of the 28 Member States. We will work on that, too. We are going to do this from an attitude that mobility. We are convinced that mobility is a good thing for the European Union, gives extra opportunities to citizens when certain conditions are met. We will therefore ensure that this mobility is done in a fair manner, that there are no abuses. We must combat abuses, but we must give opportunities to mobility, free movement of people, of workers, but also of services, because that is a matter that ultimately benefits us.  So we're going to look at that legislation, we're going to make changes. But again, also ensure balance, i.e. look at all member states. Ensuring rules that are legally secure, clear, fair and enforceable, and where those who have to enforce them and inspect them also have sufficient tools at their disposal to ensure proper enforcement. I look forward to coming up with this package soon. Once this package has passed through the College, I look forward to continuing to debate with you on the basis of very concrete proposals. Then we can certainly exchange ideas usefully. We're going to do that in a mature way. I'm going to learn a lot from you and we're going to have a good discussion and make sure we get the best possible package and I feel that there is the spirit here to work together. I am therefore prepared to do so.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you, Commissioner Thyssen. Thank you also for your concern about Mrs Collins' state of health. I would like to tell you all that Mrs Collins is in a stable condition, that she is getting the medical care she needs. I would also like to wish her a speedy and good recovery on behalf of all of us. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. – One of the advantages of the European Single Market, labour mobility is the main condition behind economic growth and the downing of unemployment. Both occupational and demographic mobility play a central role in sustainable and balanced development. Member States' economies need to show more flexibility in order to overcome the bottlenecks in the way of employment. Moreover, continued transformations in the world economy require improved capacity to adapt to a competitive global economy.  The average unemployment rate at European level is approaching 10% and, worse, youth unemployment is at alarming levels, with a quarter of young Europeans looking for work. Paradoxically, paradoxically, there are more than two million unfilled jobs in the EU. However, European citizens show less mobility, perhaps also because of the diversity of national economies, language barriers and, last but not least, uncertainties in terms of legal certainty. We have an obligation to ensure that workers' rights are respected precisely and to put effective tools at their fingertips to use them in court when they are violated.

name: Jane Collins (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The EU loves talking about Labour mobility, but what people in my region of Yorkshire and North Lincolnshire really want is jobs. Instead, the EU has given them legislation which demands all job vacancies are advertised across the European Union. In the summer it was calculated the EURES programme has seen only 25 jobs go to British workers compared to the 34.7 per cent of jobs advertised which are based in Britain. After much toing-and-froing between the European Parliament and the Council, it was decided that all JobCentre Plus vacancies will have to be advertised across the 27 other countries in the EU as well as in Britain. The legislation has also been expanded to include apprenticeships and traineeships which would make it harder for young people to find work in the UK. This can only be described as a catastrophic failure for the British Government and what I find concerning is that they seemed to push for a solution which they could spin rather than one which would allow British jobs for British workers. I fear it is the unemployed in this country who will now find it even harder to get a job.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, the free movement and freedom of establishment of European citizens in any EU country is one of the greatest achievements of the European project and a cornerstone of European integration. However, European citizens still face unjustified obstacles to the exercise of these rights, especially with a view to equal treatment of national workers and those who, taking advantage of their right, have sought employment in another country.  I believe that further measures are needed in this regard. Such measures may include, for example, the establishment of a European Platform to provide information and support in cases of discrimination with regard to freedom of movement and work. This is necessary because in a large number of cases workers in another country are particularly vulnerable and are not aware of the legal options or competent authorities they can turn to to protect their labour and social rights in the host country.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I must confess my disappointment at the delay and lack of political concreteness on the Commission's proposals in the field of worker mobility; an issue that should have been discussed in depth before announcing new proposals for the deepening of the single market. Unfortunately, several of the Commission's interventions (the refusal to apply the German minimum wage to posted carriers, the liberalising direction with which it proposed the reform of the EURES, the implicit endorsement of the expulsions of European citizens from countries such as Belgium, their little interest in social dialogue at European level...) make us suspicious of their ambitions. Our proposals are clear: the same treatment must be ensured to all workers, regardless of their place of origin, whether or not they are displaced or whether they act as employees of service providers in a third country, denouncing companies using 'false self-employed persons' and ensuring labour inspections and sanctions throughout the procurement chain to prevent serious abuses being committed. Above all, it must be ensured that freedom of movement is genuinely free and just, unconditional and barrier-free.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The adoption of the mobility package is a central focus of the Commission's work for a more social Europe. This package should be based on the revision of the detached workers directive, which has been demanded by the European Socialists for years, to better combat social dumping, particularly in the road transport sector. It should also include the revision of the regulation on the coordination of social security systems to better take into account the increasing mobility of workers within the Union.  There is an urgent need to take action against social fraud, which undermines the internal market and dangerously fuels the rejection of the European project. For this reason, the Commissioner for Social Affairs told MEPs on 9 December 2015 that the adoption of this mobility package was a priority for the Commission. However, its postponement in 2016 has just been announced. This postponement is incomprehensible to the European Socialists: it sends a negative message to our fellow citizens, whose concerns are being put aside. Socialist MEPs will remain on the offensive to demand a precise timetable for the publication of the package from the Commission, in particular to ensure that it includes a genuine revision of the European social framework.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – We want a social Europe and we want EC directives to reinforce this principle. The objective of 'equal pay for work of equal value' and measures to eliminate social dumping are late to emerge. So far, the delay is the only 'solution' presented by the European Commission. I appreciate the communication, but we need transparency and, at the same time, more action.  Emigration directly affects Romania. There are millions of Romanians who live, learn, work and are active members in the communities of other Member States. I would like at some point for these citizens to return home and contribute to Romania's objectives of becoming a stronger state, but the principle of the free movement of labour dictates that these Romanians are protected in their capacity as European citizens and that their options are respected, whether we like it or not.  So, regardless of the level of training, regardless of the country of origin, regardless of religion and ethnicity, every European citizen must feel protected by the mobility package, and at the moment they have nothing to rely on but the promises of the European Commission. We have been waiting for these promises to come true, and we have been waiting for this for some time.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – The right to live and work in another Member State is one of the fundamental freedoms of the Union and the basic value of EU citizenship. Job mobility is an advantage that the Union offers its citizens. Unfortunately, too few people are using it. Working abroad brings both added cultural and expertise to the individual, as well as contributes to improving the efficiency of labour markets and eu competitiveness.  It is important to also highlight the personal aspect of the risks of labour migration. The European Health Card and the start of the coordination of social security systems are certainly one of the successes that will have a positive impact on improving workers' mobility. In any case, tax, pension rights and unemployment benefits remain open. In these areas, the Commission will have to be more active.  Examples of good practices by which the EU promotes youth mobility are certainly the Erasmus + programme and the mutual recognition of diplomas, education and academic experience. I hope that in the future we will be able to welcome more projects with such positive effects.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. – Freedom of movement for workers is one of the four freedoms enjoyed by EU citizens and one of the fundamental principles of European integration. Nevertheless, only a small percentage of citizens work in another Member State. That doesn't surprise me. I know very well the difficult situation of Slovenian border migrants working in Austria.  I have long been drawing the European Commission's attention to this case. Although, in the Commission's view, labour mobility is key to the success of the European economy, the area of taxation of working migrants is disorderly and this hinders the movement of labour within the EU. I would remind you that the EU Treaty prohibits discrimination against workers on grounds of nationality.  Nevertheless, Slovenian migrants working in the same environment as their Austrian counterparts pay much higher taxes than Austrians. It is true that direct taxation is the responsibility of individual Member States and, in this case, the highest blame lies with the current Slovenian Government. However, the Commission's slow response does not help to solve it.  I therefore call on the Commission to complete its Expert Group on Cross-Border Tax Problems as soon as possible and to propose ambitious steps to protect the free movement of workers. I also welcome the Commission's proposal to examine the possibility of introducing a mechanism for arbitration in cross-border disputes in the field of double taxation.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the adopted decision on the European accessibility act (2015/2928(RSP)).

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very pleased to announce the adoption by the Commission of the proposal for the European Accessibility Act. This is, for me, also an occasion to thank you for the valuable input and support received from the European Parliament throughout the preparation of this directive. As you know, there are still many obstacles preventing people with disabilities from fully exercising their rights in society. Often they cannot choose where and how to live, and they face additional challenges in finding and keeping jobs or participating in education, to name but a few examples. Technological innovation offers great potential for overcoming barriers. Take the example of smartphones or e-banking and online shopping. These are changing our society and our economy, and they make our lives easier. If these products and services are made accessible, they offer new opportunities for people with disabilities to participate in society and to make independent choices.  We see that demand for accessible products and services is increasing. This is also driven by demographic ageing. It is estimated that in 2020 120 million Europeans will face a disability or functional limitation. The European Union and its Member States have committed, under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, to making products, services and buildings more accessible. Member States have started to legislate on accessibility independently in an uncoordinated way. Unless we take action at European level, divergence in the national rules of the Member States will increase. This would make it more difficult for industry to sell products and services across borders, and it is also bad for citizens who are most in need of accessible products and services.  Our aim with this proposal is to eliminate and prevent barriers between Member States created by diverging national accessibility requirements. We want to establish Europe-wide, functional accessibility requirements based on a design-for-all approach. This will allow industries to offer a wider choice of accessible products and services throughout Europe at a better price. The functional requirements we propose in the Accessibility Act establish accessibility principles instead of prescribing detailed technical solutions. This leaves room for innovation and for flexibility. After intensive consultations with stakeholders, we have carefully selected key products and services from everyday life which are most relevant to supporting independent living. And let us be honest, at the end of the day, everybody’s quality of life can be enhanced by simple improvements to their accessibility. For example, we will all benefit from hearing train announcements in noisy stations more clearly, or from avoiding eye strain by working with enlarged document formats. This proposal is good for business, too. Europe-wide requirements will make it easier for companies, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, to sell in all the other Member States, thereby boosting cross-border trade and enhancing competition. Furthermore, when public authorities issue public calls for tenders for accessible goods, services or buildings, the businesses tendering will have certainty about the requirements they have to meet. The proposal also includes a common-sense clause which ensures its proportionality and balance, and that the situation of SMEs, particularly micro-enterprises, is well taken into account. The Accessibility Act complements the draft Directive on the Accessibility of Public Sector Bodies’ Websites, on which you have already given your first reading. Discussions in the Council on this Web Accessibility Directive have progressed to the point where we hope for the trilogue to start. We are asking Parliament to continue with its constructive and positive contribution and to facilitate the adoption of the measure as rapidly as possible. I believe this is a win-win situation for everybody. Thanks to this proposal, the cost for companies and Member States will be reduced. Moreover, European action can also have a positive impact on public budgets in the long term by reducing the dependency of older and disabled persons. Furthermore, this directive – and this is the most important aspect of it – will facilitate access by persons with disabilities to education, enhance their job opportunities and give them more freedom and more opportunities in their everyday life choices. To conclude, I would like to stress once more that it is the Commission’s firm intention to enhance social fairness in Europe. Nobody should be left behind. This proposal underlines our commitment to ensure that economic growth and social progress can go hand in hand.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Commissioner Thyssen. This was a directive highly demanded by the sector. Specifically, I had asked a lot of questions to see if it could be approved. We have been waiting for you since 2012, so I convey my sincere congratulations. Accessibility is the key word in everything, but especially in the collective of people with disabilities, because it is the precondition for ensuring equal and full participation of the collective of these people with functional diversity. What the Directive aims to do is, of course, to improve the internal market in accessible products and services by removing barriers created by existing legislation.  The Commissioner he said so: there was regulatory fragmentation, because each State was regulating differently. This has already been indicated by the United Nations Committee on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, in its general comments, referring to the implementation of the United Nations Convention itself on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, in particular Article 9, which states that accessibility needs to be ensured.  A number of services have been established – cashiers, banking services, computers, telephones, e-commerces, etc.– but the suggestion I will make, through an amendment, to the Commission itself is to expand this range and to collect the general observations, namely Comment No 2 (Article 9), which the United Nations made precisely in relation to the physical environment, information, communication and universal design.

name: Jutta Steinruck
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Commission's proposal to improve the accessibility of products and services is an important and indeed long overdue step to improve the daily lives of the approximately 80 million people with disabilities in Europe. It is important that there are common standards in a common internal market and that there is also common management. This simplifies the lives of those affected and saves costs, and that is something that is close to our hearts here. The Commission's move to implement the principle of accessibility, which is provided for in the United Nations Conventions on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, uniformly in the EU is just as important as the active integration of those affected into the labour market. The digital single market can also offer a great opportunity, if it also extends to the fact that people for whom access is otherwise difficult can be integrated much better into the labour market there in the future.

name: Anthea McIntyre
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, last week I hosted an event in Parliament where Callum Russell came to talk about gap year opportunities for young people with disabilities. Callum is studying at the College of Europe in Bruges. He is a very articulate and determined young man. He is British and he is blind. But disability cannot be allowed to define a person. Disability must not be a barrier to playing a full role in society. Callum pointed out that the websites of the European Union institutions are completely inaccessible. This is not acceptable. Let us, for goodness sake, get our own house in order. We have a saying in the UK: people who live in glass houses should not throw stones. So let us make sure that our own institutions’ websites are properly accessible before we go further.

name: Marian Harkin
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the Commissioner for doing what she said she would do, namely to introduce a European Accessibility Act. I think it is an important step towards helping to ensure that more products and services are accessible to people with disabilities.  Commissioner, as you said yourself, by 2020 we expect to have 120 million people in the EU with some form of disability. Therefore, not only will this Act make more goods and services accessible to people with disabilities, but it also makes economic sense – more customers, so better for business. What I find positive about this proposal is the wide range of services: from computers to banking services, from e-books to smartphones, and from television equipment to certain types of transport services. They are all included in this proposal. Equally, as you said yourself, while the technical solutions are not detailed, what is here are the features that the specific goods and services need to have in place in order to be accessible. They are clearly outlined. I think this type of flexibility is important for manufacturers and businesses but, equally, we need to ensure that accessibility is foreseen at the design stage. We have ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities and, in order for it to be meaningful, accessible products and services are a precondition. Finally, we are fast becoming a digital society and this act can help future-proof social and digital inclusion.

name: Martina Anderson
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, after meeting with Disability Action in Derry, it is clear that an Accessibility Act is essential, especially after the UN initiated a private inquiry into investigating violations of disabled people’s human rights as a result of British welfare cuts. Indeed, spending cuts in Member States have hurt people with disabilities the most. What must it be like for the 80 million disabled people who need access to computers, ATMs, telecommunications, banking and transport – services that we all take for granted? How many of us MEPs used those services to try to get here to Strasbourg? I certainly used them all. An Accessibility Act would put obligations on Member States to take the necessary measures to include legislation to ensure accessibility, and it would support the UN Convention of the rights of persons with a disability – a Convention that Ireland has yet to ratify. So whilst the proposed Directive is welcome, I think it is long-overdue, but at least it is a step in the right direction.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, I would like to thank you for keeping your promise to me and for presenting this package of legislation within a year. The aim is clear: to remove barriers to the internal market in order to make accessibility clear. However, I note that the scope of those affected is not exhaustive. The Commissioner rightly pointed out that after 2020 we will be talking about 120 million people with disabilities and older people, i.e. one in four EU citizens will be affected.  The Public Procurement Directive is a regulation concerning EU funds, which is particularly important. The Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, including General Recommendation No 2 on accessibility, is equally fundamental.  I would like to point out that, for the first time, definitions of accessibility have been introduced into EU law, and this provides a framework. I think we have a long way to go before it comes to law, but we can finally start work on the merits after five years.  I would like to make a final point: I would like to live in the moment where the obstacles that society has put in front of me, not my disability, are finally, once and for all.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the proposal for a European Accessibility Act, although, as many have said, it has taken a long time to get here. Ensuring that the 80 million European citizens who currently live with a disability have access to products and services in our single market is critically important in creating a more equal and fairer society. I want to particularly welcome the action point on ICT and operating systems. As the Commissioner highlighted, the accessibility of public websites is a key issue; a colleague also mentioned our own websites, and this is maybe a point we can take away with us. Many of us who have been working in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection have had a good look at our own websites to make sure that they are accessible, and we all can do the same.  These proposals to ensure that there is non-discrimination in the digital single market as well are important for all EU citizens. It is interesting that today in the UN they are considering the 10-year review of implementation of the outcomes of the World Summit on the Information Society. Point 12 of their outcome document highlights specific ICT challenges faced by persons with disabilities; this is interesting. We are sitting here in the European Parliament – although it is late – while in the UN they are also discussing these issues.  On the subject of the Marrakesh Treaty, which I continue to raise on the floor of this House, I would call on the Commission to come forward with a legislative proposal to implement this Treaty as soon as possible. The Accessibility Act mentions the issue of e-books, but with fewer than 5% of books published in accessible formats for blind and partially-sighted readers – and in poorer countries there are as little as 1% – we cannot see the Accessibility Act and the Marrakesh Treaty as separate. They are very much interlinked. I look forward to working with the Commissioner and colleagues to ensure the implementation of the Accessibility Act, and also, when we come to it, on the Marrakesh Treaty too.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: I am very pleased with the proposal for a European Accessibility Act. It is, of course, only a small part of the transposition of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I therefore expect that the Commission will also do what is necessary in other areas for which it has jurisdiction. The fact is that there is still no real single market for people with disabilities. So we need to focus on getting rid of all the remaining obstacles, such as our own website. Companies still face additional costs when they want to offer their products across Europe because of all sorts of and sometimes conflicting national rules and standards. Of course, this requires a good balance between the interests of consumers with disabilities and those of companies.
