This would give a major boost to economic growth, because there are more than 80 million people with disabilities in the Union. This number will rise to 120 million by 2020 due to an ageing population.  So better accessibility benefits society as a whole. You can certainly count on me for a strong European accessibility law. It really has to have a positive impact on our lives.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the more than 80 million European citizens with disabilities need and deserve equal access not just to the job market but also to the digital single market for buying goods and services. I warmly welcome a European Accessibility Act but, after waiting for this long-overdue proposal, we must now make sure that the act as finally adopted yields practical results. It must turn words, condemning discrimination, into action that helps these individuals in their daily lives. As rapporteur for the Web Accessibility Directive, however, I would also be grateful if you could further explain, Commissioner, how you see the relationship between the two pieces of legislation. I took good note of the references in the recital and the explanatory statement but I believe that we will need further clarification before we enter a trilogue on this directive in the New Year. What I can assure you is that Parliament will not give up on its support for widening the scope of the Web Accessibility Directive without written guarantees as to the other, non-public, websites to be covered by the European Accessibility Act. Persons with disabilities need full access to the digital single market and the internet – not just to public websites.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, I would like to speak in order to support what you mentioned at the end of your speech. And that is access to quality education for the disabled. This is the main condition for the services that are being talked about today, such as internet services, digital services, to be able to make full use of them. I think that we can all agree on promoting accessibility as it is being talked about here today, that is what we see here. The problem arises when these services are to be financed. We know this from the approval of national budgets in our Member States. I think it must be argued here that quality education and access to services for disabled citizens is our duty. And it's also an investment in their full life.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – Commissioner, the presentation of the European Accessibility Act must be unequivocally welcomed, although the experience of how difficult it is to negotiate in the Council by the scope of the much more modest Directive on the accessibility of public sector bodies' websites will somewhat temper our enthusiasm. It is therefore extremely important to bring this directive to real life. We must not allow the good thought and high expectations it rightly raises among people with disabilities to leave equally much frustration. I believe that will not be the case. Eighty million Europeans with disabilities have to face a number of obstacles in their daily lives caused not only by their disabilities. Better accessibility of goods and services is essential to improve the quality of life not only of people with disabilities, but also of older fellow citizens, for example. This is the main reason to support the European Accessibility Act and to call very strongly on the Member States to do so.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, today in the European Union there are over eighty million people who face some form of disability. We therefore consider the initiative to adopt a European directive on the accessibility of disabled people to education, trade and work to be important, which will strengthen social justice. According to Eurostat data, a person of productive age has a 66% chance of finding a job while for a person with a severe disability the probability is reduced to 25%. In my country Greece, the proportion of people with disabilities is 10% of the population and, according to ELSTAT, 84% of people with disabilities in my country are outside the labour market. The Memorandum and austerity policies further exhausted people with disabilities as they found themselves in the crosshairs of the Troika which reduced their welfare benefits and disability pensions, which now range between EUR 250 and EUR 540, thus leading disabled people to social exclusion. Thanks.

name: Marianne Thyssen
text: Member of the Commission. I would like to thank the Members of this European Parliament for their support for this proposal. I hope that we can work well together and that we can complete this package quickly. The sooner it can be transposed into legislation, the sooner it can also come into force. We have been made aware that we must also ensure sufficient accessability in our own instruments and in our own data that we disseminate from the European Commission. We must be careful about that. When I launched this package, I really made sure that all the material that was available should also be accessible to people with disabilities and that we at least meet all our own requirements there. I will also make it clear in the Commission that there is some room for improvement and that we need to work on it.  Helga Stevens, among others, has pointed out that it is a good proposal, but that it will also entail some additional costs for business. Indeed, costs are always there when conditions have to be met, but we have developed our system in such a way that those costs can be as low as possible, that there is a lot of room for choices at the companies and that the costs are low, also because we go for a design for all. The concept of a product or service must be an eye for service or product. It should also only be applied for new services and for new products being launched. It's not about transforming existing things. Because it is the reshaping that often costs money. If one pays attention to it from the start, it is often marginal costs. And if the costs are too high, is it really overburdening, is the cost or the question of accessibility such that this would mean that a product, which one intends to produce, would have to be completely modified or totally something else, then a company can still explain that, make an announcement and still launch its product as it wants. But it's first trying to make sure that there is compliance and that's ultimately what we're pursuing. So there is also real consideration of the costs for business. Because what we want is for products and services to meet as many requirements as possible. That there's accessability on the field. If everyone is behind it and can do so at a low cost, then we have the best chance of success. When it comes to the functional requirements that we impose on the websites of public services, of public authorities, I can say that the pending directive, which must be negotiated and which the trialogue has to start, scope, is different in scope. We're talking about private websites. That's what public service websites are about. However, the functional requirements are the same.  What I can say in relation to copyrights - Mrs Stihler referred to this - the Marrakesh agreement provides for an exception to copyrights for books that have been printed and which, in retrospect, are to be made in Braille or in something else. Well, what we have in mind here is: this is not about printed books, but about e-books, which can be downloaded via a website. We ask that these be accessible to people who cannot read, but who can have access through other senses. We ask that there be accessibility there, such that even non-sighted or visually impaired people can consult those books. Again, if we take care of this at the conception of such an e-book, then it is small adjustment costs that will improve accessibility, increase accessibility for many people, and that is what we ultimately strive for. Thank you for the support. I look forward to a good collaboration and my thanks for the time I have had to reply.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I am pleased that the European Commission has finally tabled a proposal for a European Accessibility Act setting out common accessibility requirements for certain basic products and services, which will help people with disabilities to participate fully in society at European Union (EU) level. I have repeatedly called on the Commission to present this initiative of particular importance to people with disabilities as soon as possible, and I congratulate the Commission on finally having a concrete proposal for a directive. This proposal for a directive aims to help companies to provide accessible products and services across borders while improving the functioning of the internal market. Common accessibility requirements will also apply in the areas of EU procurement procedures and the use of EU funds. This initiative will stimulate innovation and help to increase the supply of affordable products and services by around 80 million people. people with disabilities in the EU. The products and services concerned have been carefully selected in consultation with citizens and civil society organisations, as well as businesses. These services and products include ATMs and banking services, computers, telephones and television equipment, telephony and audiovisual services, transport, e-books and e-commerce. We will now improve this Commission directive on the European Accessibility Act in the European Parliament, and I hope that, together with the Member States, we will adopt appropriate European legislation ensuring access to all important services, products and equal rights for all people with disabilities in Europe.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: Writing. – I would like to welcome the fact that the draft directive pays particular attention to digital technologies. It is unnecessary to stress that the social integration of persons with disabilities cannot take place anywhere in 21st-century Europe without unhindered access to the Internet. I would therefore like to draw attention to the fact that in many cases the Union's own websites are not accessible. A good example is Erasmus, one of the most successful projects in THE HISTORY of the EU. There is currently no accessible version of the Erasmus Plus website, so in principle it would be in vain for people with disabilities to participate in the programme, but it is already an obstacle to being informed about their existing opportunities. Changing this is clearly not a matter of material, but of will.  I propose that, irrespective of the directive we are discussing, the Commission should remedy the problem as soon as possible and establish an appropriate support system for people with disabilities, taking into account that these persons have specific needs which often impose significant additional costs on them and their families.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – After many, many years of waiting, the Accessibility Act has finally made it. It has been five years since the Disability Strategy was announced and the process should not have been so needlessly drawn-out. The Commission will find itself accountable not only to the 80 million Europeans with disabilities but also to the elderly, who will benefit greatly from the removal of totally unnecessary barriers, particularly those regarding web-accessibility – and with Europe’s increasingly grey population, that’s a lot of people. Large incumbents such as Microsoft should have the responsibility of promoting free and open standards because when it comes to accessibility for visually impaired people, interoperability is of crucial importance. So before we become complacent, there is still a long way to go before the EU comes fully in line with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities but this is a step in the right direction.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I would like to thank the interpreters and the staff of the House for staying here with us for so long. (The sitting was closed at 11.30 p.m.)
